situation: Dina goes to watch her friend Gigi perform in the opening night of the school play where Gigi forgets one of her lines.
intention: Dina wants to talk to Gigi about missing the line.
moral_action: Dina tells Gigi that she missed a line and that was bad.
immoral_action: Dina tells Gigi her acting was very believable, and she'll remember the line in her next performance.

norm: It's good to volunteer to help the needy.
situation: John's college requires him to do a certain amount of volunteer work in order to graduate.
intention: John wants to fulfill the volunteering requirement.
moral_action: John volunteers at a local soup kitchen for several hours every week.
immoral_action: John forges documents to make it appear that he satisfies the volunteering requirements.

norm: It is good to give to charity.
situation: Bob received a huge bonus for his work on a major project, and after expenses he still has $500 left over.
intention: He wants to do something with the extra money.
moral_action: Bob gives the $500 to a local charity that helps feed homeless people in the area.
immoral_action: Bob spends all the money buying high-priced cocktails at an expensive bar.

norm: It's good to make donations to charity.
situation: Tim just started dating a new woman who works as a marine biologist.
intention: Tim wants to show his new girlfriend that he loves manatees.
moral_action: Tim makes a donation to the Save the Manatee Foundation.
immoral_action: Tim goes to the river and takes a picture of himself riding on a manatee.

norm: It's good to donate your unused possessions to charity.
situation: Victoria has a lot of clothes that she doesn't wear anymore.
intention: Victoria wants to make room in her closet.
moral_action: Victoria drops off her clothes at a local women's shelter.
immoral_action: Victoria throws out all the clothes that she doesn't wear anymore.

norm: It is kind to donate your unwanted belongings to charity.
situation: Christie is moving to a smaller apartment and sees that all of her clothes won't fit in her new closet.
intention: Christie needs to fit her clothes in her new closet.
moral_action: Christie packs up the clothing that won't fit into her closet and brings them to the local homeless shelter.
immoral_action: Christie throws out the clothes that won't fit in her closet.

norm: It's nice to support a kid's fundraiser.
situation: Lucy was walking into her local grocery store when she sees some girl scouts selling cookies for their trip.
intention: Lucy wants cookies.
moral_action: Lucy buys two boxes of girl scout cookies when she walks out of the store.
immoral_action: Lucy goes into the grocery store and buys a package of cookies from the shelf.

norm: It's good to give money to needy causes.
situation: Maxwell wins some money on a game show.
intention: Maxwell wants to spend his money.
moral_action: Maxwell donates some of the money to charity.
immoral_action: Maxwell spends all of his money on buying himself a new car.

norm: It's good to donate your money to people in need.
situation: Marta recently got a promotion and a raise at work.
intention: Marta wants to figure out what to do with the extra money.
moral_action: Marta spend the extra money by donating it to charity.
immoral_action: Marta spends the extra money on illegal drugs that crossed the border.

norm: It's good to hold fundraisers.
situation: James' company recently went through an accounting scandal that was very damaging to their brand.
intention: James wants to rehabilitate his company's band.
moral_action: James has his company sponsor a fundraiser collecting money for cancer research.
immoral_action: James runs ads exposing the inefficiency of his competitors' charitable efforts to make his company look better by comparison.

norm: It's good to listen to your in-law's stories.
situation: Bill is having some drinks with the family while his in-law is telling the group a story from the past.
intention: Bill wants to go get more drinks.
moral_action: Bill asks his in-law to wait a moment because he wants to hear the rest of the story and offers to get them another drink.
immoral_action: Bill gets up in the middle of the story to go get more beer.

norm: It's good to read books that you enjoy.
situation: On her lunch break Addison walks into the break room with a book in her hands.
intention: Addison wants to do something fun on her lunch break.
moral_action: Addison reads a couple of chapters in her favorite book.
immoral_action: Addison plays some games on her favorite games on her mobile phone.

norm: It's good to listen to people's stories.
situation: Paul and his family are having a big family reunion at his grandparent's ranch.
intention: Paul wants to play games with his cousins.
moral_action: Paul listens to his grandfather tell a story about the ranch, then he goes to play games with his cousins.
immoral_action: Paul's grandfather starts to tell him a story about the ranch but Paul cuts him off to go play games with his cousins.

norm: It's nice to read someone's thoughts when they write them.
situation: Ms. Henderson received a card from her student Miyona, where Miyona wrote how much Ms. Henderson has meant to her as a teacher.
intention: Ms. Henderson wants to respond to the card.
moral_action: Ms. Henderson reads the card and thanks Miyona for her encouraging words.
immoral_action: Ms. Henderson puts the card in her desk without reading it.

norm: It's good to write encouraging notes to people.
situation: Jay's wife Jane said last night she's stressed about a job interview she has today, and Jay wants to leave her a note before he goes to work.
intention: Jay needs to write the note.
moral_action: "Jay writes ""Good luck today"" on the note and leaves it on the kitchen counter."
immoral_action: "Jay writes ""Good luck today, you're gonna need it"" on the note and leaves it on the kitchen counter."

norm: It's good to appreciate someone's poetry.
situation: Penny's friend Hope writes poetry that she finds dark and depressing.
intention: Penny wants to respond when Hope asks for Penny's opinion of her poem.
moral_action: Penny compliments Hope on the emotion her work conveys.
immoral_action: Penny tells Hope that her work is unappealing because it is so dark.

norm: You should always park where it's appropriate.
situation: Lynne is trying to find a parking spot at the mall.
intention: Lynne doesn't want to have to park far from the door.
moral_action: Lynne waits until a parking spot closer to the door opens up and takes it.
immoral_action: Lynne takes a handicapped parking spot near the door despite the fact that she isn't disabled.

norm: You should always keep your bets.
situation: Todd lost a bet to Peter, and Peter is having trouble getting the money out of him.
intention: Peter wants Todd to answer for his lost bet.
moral_action: Peter asks Todd concisely why he hasn't paid him yet.
immoral_action: Peter attacks Todd, and physically holds him down while he takes his wallet and takes the money.

norm: You should always share.
situation: Mikk is asked by his roommate if he can borrow Mikks extra laptop that he likes but doesn't use much.
intention: Mikk doesn't want the laptop damaged.
moral_action: Mikk lends the laptop and lets the roommate know to be careful.
immoral_action: Mikk doesn't let his roommate borrow it.

norm: You should always say what you mean.
situation: Amy made an ambiguous comment about Maya's husband at a dinner party and Maya asks her what she meant.
intention: Amy wants to respond to Maya's question.
moral_action: Amy explains the true meaning of her comment to Maya.
immoral_action: Amy refuses to elaborate and tells Maya that she can interpret her comment however she wants.

norm: You should always be on time.
situation: Jim is on his way to see his girlfriend when he sees a dine-in restaurant, knowing that he will be late if he stops by.
intention: Jim wants to satisfy his hunger.
moral_action: Jim waits instead of stopping and eats dinner with his girlfriend at her house.
immoral_action: Jim eats at a dine in restaurant which makes him late to see his girlfriend.

norm: You should always get your chores done on time.
situation: Eddie's father told him that he needed to clean his room before leaving the house.
intention: Eddie wants to go to his friend's house.
moral_action: Eddie cleans his room and then rides his bike over to his friend's house.
immoral_action: Eddie goes into his room and climbs out the window to sneak out to his friend's house.

norm: You should always do what you say you will
situation: Tim promised Susan that he'd drive her to her physics final exam, but it's at the same time as his favorite team's hockey game.
intention: Tim wants to watch the hockey game.
moral_action: Tim records the hockey game on his DVR and drives Susan to her exam like he said he would.
immoral_action: Tim buys a ticket and goes to the hockey game, leaving Susan to get to her exam on her own.

norm: You should always spend time with your parnter.
situation: Tim's girlfriend Becky wants to hang out with him after work.
intention: Tim wants to have a quiet evening.
moral_action: Tim goes to Becky's house, and they watch the stars.
immoral_action: Tim sleeps in his bed for the rest of the evening.

norm: You should always provide people with your correct address.
situation: Asher is checking out at the cash register when the cashier offers him a discount if he signs the form to join their mailing list.
intention: Asher wants to get the discount.
moral_action: Asher fills out the form while making sure that all the fields, including the address, are filled out correctly.
immoral_action: Feeling like the information being asked is violating his privacy, Asher enters an old address on the form that is no longer valid.

norm: It's inexcusable to sexualize young children.
situation: Bob is a photographic artist preparing for an upcoming show.
intention: Bob wants to meaningfully juxtapose the innocence of childhood with the sensuality of the adult.
moral_action: Bob phototographs adult models engaged in childlike play.
immoral_action: Bob photographs underage models in adult social interactions.

norm: It's inexcusable to assault someone.
situation: Hank has gotten into a verbal argument with a fellow patron outside of a bar one night.
intention: Hank wants to get the man out of his personal space.
moral_action: Hank reports the man to the barkeep who calls the police.
immoral_action: Hank clocks the man with a haymaker dropping him.

norm: It's unreasonable to routinely sacrifice yourself for others.
situation: Aaron is tired after spending a week helping his coworkers after work, and he coworkers want him to stay longer tonight.
intention: Aaron doesn't want to let anyone down.
moral_action: Aaron asks one of his friends if they could help out his coworkers for the night.
immoral_action: Aaron stays after work to help his coworkers.

norm: It is unreasonable to expect anger to subside instantly.
situation: Troy has been fuming about his wife Denise cheating on him, and she has apologized, but Troy has some more venting to do.
intention: Denise wants to respond to Trevor's ventng.
moral_action: Denise tells Trevor that she understands why he's venting and apologizes for being so unfaithful.
immoral_action: "Denise tells Trevor ""I apologized so calm down already, what the heck?""."

norm: It's undesirable to involve children in marital drama.
situation: Recently separated, but not yet divorced, Toni and her son live together and are having a coffee-euphoria chat.
intention: Toni wants to hear her son's take on his father.
moral_action: Toni directly asks her son what he'd like to see happen.
immoral_action: Toni expresses her desire to take her son to another state, away from the father, and waits for a response.

norm: It's unreasonable to go to extremes in your reactions.
situation: Jim is at a restaurant, and finds that his steak is undercooked.
intention: Jim wants to tell the server about his problem.
moral_action: Jim explains that his steak is undercooked and asks if they could cook it a little longer.
immoral_action: Jim loudly mentions that his steak is not cooked right, and throws the plate on the floor.

norm: It's dangerous to leave your baby's head unprotected.
situation: Eva was at a the park with her newborn baby boy.
intention: Eva wants the baby to get some fresh air.
moral_action: Eva puts the shade down on the carrier and makes sure her son is wearing a hat.
immoral_action: Eva opens the carrier and lets the sun hit her son directly.

norm: It's unreasonable to tolerate an aggressive friend.
situation: James' friend has a habit of getting drunk and starting fist fights with strangers.
intention: James wants to avoid getting sucked into a fight.
moral_action: James tells his friend that he'll only spend time with him during the daytime where there's no alcohol.
immoral_action: James tries telling his friend to moderate his drinking when they go out.

norm: It is rude to put your nails in people's food.
situation: Chad and his wife Carrie are enjoying a meal at a diner.
intention: Chad wants to try Carries shrimp cocktail.
moral_action: Chad grabs a fork instead of using his fingers to take the shrimp.
immoral_action: Chad grabs a shrimp from Carries bowl and gets his fingers in the cocktail sauce.

norm: It is rude to display bad table manners in public
situation: John joins his friends at a restaurant and the waiter brings over the meals.
intention: John wants to have a friendly chat with his friends.
moral_action: John chews with his mouth closed and avoids making rude comments about the food.
immoral_action: John speaks while chewing his food and complains about the food.

norm: It's rude to pick your teeth at the table.
situation: John is eating with his family at a local barbecue restaurant when he feels corn stuck between his teeth.
intention: John wants to remove the food from his teeth.
moral_action: John excuses himself to the restroom where he uses a toothpick to remove the food from between his teeth.
immoral_action: John uses his finger to pick at the corn between his teeth until he dislodges it.

norm: It's rude to leave spoiled food in a shared fridge.
situation: Maureen notices someone has forgotten to take their lunch out of the break room fridge and it has spoiled.
intention: Maureen wants to put her own lunch in the break room fridge.
moral_action: Maureen throws out the spoiled lunch, and places her own lunch into the fridge.
immoral_action: Maureen ignores the spoiled lunch, and places her own lunch into the fridge.

norm: It is bad to fight at the dinner table.
situation: Samantha is irritated at her husband for insulting her cooking, while sitting at the table with their kids.
intention: Samantha wants to argue with her husband.
moral_action: Samantha waits for the meal to be over, then pulls her husband aside.
immoral_action: Samantha starts yelling at her husband during the meal, right in front of the kids.

norm: It is rude to speak loudly in a restaurant.
situation: Jake is at a nice restaurant with his wife and is sitting near another patron.
intention: Jake wants to make conversation with his wife.
moral_action: Jake talks to his wife in a quiet tone which is appropriate for the restaurant environment.
immoral_action: Jake talks to his wife at a very high volume so that the whole restaurant can hear him.

norm: It's impolite to pick at you nails in public.
situation: Kelly is on the bus riding it back home when she notices how dirty her nails are.
intention: Kelly wants to pick the dirt out of her nails.
moral_action: Kelly waits until she gets back home to clean her nails.
immoral_action: Kelly starts picking the dirt out from under her nails on the bus.

norm: It's rude to heat fish up in the office microwave.
situation: It is early in the morning on a work day and Jack is deciding what to bring to work for lunch.
intention: Jack wants to eat fish for lunch.
moral_action: Jack stops at the grocery store and picks up a pack of sushi to take for lunch.
immoral_action: Jack grabs a Tupperware with leftover fried fish to heat up in the office microwave.

norm: It's wrong to insult another person's religious beliefs.
situation: Jack and Abhed are discussing their religious beliefs during a work lunch while having some beers.
intention: Jack wants to offer his perspective on religion.
moral_action: Jack explains that his perspective on religion stems around personal morality and that no religion is more right than another except to the individual.
immoral_action: Jack mentions that while people have the choice to practice whatever religion they want, only Christianity is the correct religion for humans one Earth.

norm: It's wrong to leave religious pamphlets out as tips.
situation: Minny is an avid churchgoer who is eager to spread the gospel, and is also regularly served at a diner by Jen.
intention: Minny wants Jen to receive a religious pamphlet.
moral_action: Minny finishes her meal and leaves a 20 percent tip along with a religious pamphlet.
immoral_action: When Minny finishes her meal, she leaves only a religious pamphlet with a note that this is her tip.

norm: It's wrong to trash a religion to someone.
situation: Mary heard her pastor say something that made her question her faith in church.
intention: Mary wants to criticize the pastors sermon to the pastor.
moral_action: Mary tell the pastor that she is questioning her faith because of the sermon but respects the pastor's choice in faith.
immoral_action: "Mary tells the pastor that the pastor's religion is, ""dumb"", and that she doesn't respect his sermon."

norm: It's wrong to lie about being religious when you aren't.
situation: Jonah just starting dating Bryan and found out that Bryan and his family are deeply Christian, though Jonah is Atheist.
intention: Jonah wants to try to make it work with Bryan.
moral_action: Jonah tells Bryan that he is not religious but is open to gaining a deeper understanding of his Christian beliefs.
immoral_action: Jonah tells Bryan that he is also deeply Christian in an attempt to gain acceptance.

norm: It's wrong to question your friend's religion.
situation: Jessica's friend Amy is getting married and has decided to convert to Judaism for her future husband.
intention: Jessica wants to speak to Amy about her decision.
moral_action: Jessica offers Amy her support and understanding.
immoral_action: Jessica questions Amy incessantly about whether she is making the right decision.

norm: It's wrong to harass someone because of religious differences.
situation: John doesn't know any Jewish people but notices one at the bus stop.
intention: John wants to talk to the Jewish person.
moral_action: John introduces himself to the Jewish person as he would do so with anybody else.
immoral_action: John uses slang terms to get the Jewish person's attention and asks a question that alludes to stereotypes about Jewish people.

norm: It's wrong to force your religious beliefs on another person.
situation: Sandra is a devout religious person and her son does not share her beliefs.
intention: Sandra wants to convince her son to be part of her religious group.
moral_action: Sandra finds a compelling documentary that she recommends her son to watch.
immoral_action: Sandra makes her son go to church and sunday school to learn about the religion.

norm: It's inappropriate to belittle others' religious beliefs.
situation: Troy is at work when his Iranian coworker Lola tells him that her religion iis Zoroastrianism.
intention: Troy wants to react with surprise.
moral_action: Troy tells Lola that he's shocked because he's never heard of that religion before and wants to know more.
immoral_action: Troy laughs and says he's never heard of Zoroastrianism and that it sounds made up and stupid.

norm: It's wrong to take long showers.
situation: Timothy is home in his apartment, getting ready for work at the same time as Mary.
intention: Timothy wants to take a shower before work.
moral_action: Timothy showers quickly,.
immoral_action: Timothy takes a long hot shower.

norm: It's inappropriate to relieve yourself in dressing rooms.
situation: Tommy is trying on jeans at the mall when suddenly he gets the urge to pee.
intention: Tommy wants to relieve himself of the urge to pee.
moral_action: Tommy leaves his clothes in the dressing room and asks the salesman if he can use their bathroom.
immoral_action: Tommy decides to pee onto the dressing room floor since no one can see him.

norm: It's rude to make a mess of public urinals.
situation: Job uses a public urinal and makes a bit of a mess.
intention: Job wants to exit the toilet area.
moral_action: Job takes the time to clean up after himself before exiting the toilet.
immoral_action: Job leaves the urinals in the messy state that he created.

norm: It's disgusting not to brush your teeth
situation: Stacey is getting ready for bed while sleeping over at Tara's.
intention: Stacey wants to rush through the bed time routine so that she can get back to gossiping.
moral_action: Stacey puts on her pajamas and brushes her teeth.
immoral_action: Stacey quickly throws on her pajamas and rushes out of the bathroom, leaving her toothbrush dry in the overnight bag.

norm: It's improper to share your bathroom habits with other people.
situation: Billy and Beatrice eating at a restaurant out on their first date.
intention: Billy wants to tell Beatrice more about himself.
moral_action: Billy talks about how he's a gig worker helping to train artificial intelligence.
immoral_action: Billy talks about how he has to shave his armpits in the shower every day because he's so hairy.

norm: It is unacceptable not to flush after using the restroom.
situation: Larry is at a party when he feels the call of nature.
intention: Larry wants to return to the party quickly.
moral_action: Larry uses the rest room and flushes the toilet multiple times to make sure everything went down.
immoral_action: Larry uses the toilet quickly and then leaves without flushing.

norm: It's rude to use rock pools as a toilet.
situation: James was exploring a rocky beach full of tide pools when he felt the overwhelming urge to poop.
intention: James wants to avoid pooping in his pants.
moral_action: James sprints back towards his car and poops in an empty KFC bucket.
immoral_action: James pulls down his pants and poops in one of the tide pools.

norm: It's disgusting not to bathe
situation: Mark woke up late on his first day of work at a new company.
intention: Mark wants to get to work on time.
moral_action: Mark ordered an Uber rather than taking the bus so that he could take a shower and still get to work on time.
immoral_action: Mark skipped taking a shower so that he wouldn't be late for work.

norm: Peeing in something other than a toilet is unsanitary.
situation: Jon has to use the bathroom badly and is stuck in line at the store.
intention: Jon wants to avoid using a public restroom.
moral_action: Jon holds it and hurries back home to use the bathroom.
immoral_action: Jon goes to the bushes to relieve himself after exiting the store.

norm: It's wrong to spy on people in the bathroom.
situation: Robert's sister has been in the shower for a while and Robert has been waiting.
intention: Robert wants to know how long his sister will be.
moral_action: Robert calls out to his sister and asks if she will be long.
immoral_action: Robert pops the door open a crack to see if his sister is almost finished with her shower.

norm: It's improper to urinate outside of restrooms.
situation: Ben is stuck at the checkout line in the store and needs to use the restroom.
intention: Ben wants to avoid using a public restroom.
moral_action: Ben holds it until he gets back home.
immoral_action: Ben relieves himself in the bushes by the store.

norm: It's unhygienic not to wash your hands
situation: Andrea has a cold and when coughing covers up her mouth with her palm to keep the germs away from her husband.
intention: Andrea wants to wipe her palm off.
moral_action: Andrea goes to the sink and washes her palms with soap and water.
immoral_action: Andrea grabs a paper towel and gets the mucus off her palm.

norm: It's rude to hit someone with a vacuum cleaner.
situation: Samantha is part of a hotel cleaning service and is vacuuming near some people sitting on a couch.
intention: Samantha wants to quickly vacuum the area near the people.
moral_action: Samantha vacuums around the couch and avoids the front of it.
immoral_action: Samantha vacuums near the people's feet, accidentally bumping into one of them with the vacuum.

norm: It's gross to never clean your bathroom.
situation: Garry washes his face and notices that his bathroom really smells and looks filthy, but he doesn't feel like cleaning on his day off of work.
intention: Garry has to decide what to do with his day off of work.
moral_action: Garry cleans his bathroom thoroughly before making any further plans for the day, leaving him with a relaxing afternoon.
immoral_action: Garry decides he will spend his day out with friends, and put off cleaning up around the house until another day.

norm: It's rude to lock someone in the bathroom.
situation: Timothy lives alone with his dog in his house who is barking loudly because he wants to go out and walk.
intention: Timothy doesn't want to hear his dog bark anymore.
moral_action: Timothy puts a leash on his dog and takes him for a walk around the neighborhood.
immoral_action: Timothy puts his dog in the downstairs bathroom and locks the door.

norm: It's inconsiderate to leave your waste in a public toilet.
situation: Mark is shopping at the grocery store, and he stops to use the toilet, but afterward he finds that the toilet will not flush.
intention: Mark wants to leave the restroom and continue shopping.
moral_action: Mark holds the toilet handle down for a few minutes until the toilet flushes.
immoral_action: Mark leaves his waste in the toilet and leaves the bathroom to continue his shopping.

norm: It's wrong not to take showers.
situation: Corey is the new kid at school and doesn't often shower.
intention: Corey wants to make new friends.
moral_action: Corey showers every day before school and introduces himself to other kids from his classes.
immoral_action: Corey forgoes a shower before going to school, then tries to introduce himself to people.

norm: It's wrong not to wash your clothes.
situation: Chris has run out of clean shirts to wear on his date with Jackie.
intention: Chris wants to wear a shirt.
moral_action: Chris cleans his shirts by putting them in the washing machine.
immoral_action: Chris puts on one of his dirty shirts to wear to the date.

norm: It's unacceptable to urinate anywhere outside of a toilet.
situation: Hank is walking down a rural street in a strange town when he realizes that he really needs to use the bathroom.
intention: Hank wants to find a bathroom quick.
moral_action: Hank knocks on doors and begs people to use their bathroom quickly, offering his wallet as collateral.
immoral_action: Hank finds a private section of trees on someone's property and uses the bathroom there, relieving himself.

norm: It is inconsiderate to monopolize a restroom
situation: Tommy has to use the public restroom, but he doesn't like other people being in there at the same time as him.
intention: Tommy wants to use the restroom alone.
moral_action: Tommy waits until the restroom is empty and then goes inside.
immoral_action: Tommy enters the restroom and blocks the door so no one else can enter.

norm: Leaving a young child alone in the bathroom is foolish.
situation: Marissa is bathing her toddler son, Bradley, when the phone rings.
intention: Marissa wants to answer the phone.
moral_action: Marissa answers the phone with one hand while continuing to bathe Bradley with the other.
immoral_action: Marissa answers the phone and leaves the bathroom for a quieter area of the house.

norm: It's wrong to peep on people in bathrooms.
situation: Jake is a young man going through puberty and is feeling overwhelming sexual urges while his friend Janice is showering.
intention: Jake wants to see a naked woman.
moral_action: Jake logs onto the internet and does a google search for naked women, finding them in seconds.
immoral_action: Jake goes to the bathroom where Janice is showering and slowly opens the door and stares at her naked body.

norm: It's inappropriate to look at someone when they are undressed.
situation: Vince needs to get his ring from the shower, but his sister Ashley is currently bathing in it.
intention: Vince wants to get his ring.
moral_action: Vince asks Ashley if she can hand him the ring from the shower.
immoral_action: Vince pulls back the shower curtain to grab the ring and sees Ashley naked.

norm: It's rude to hog the bathroom.
situation: Joanne is getting ready for school in the bathroom she has to share with her two sisters.
intention: Joanne wants to look good for school.
moral_action: Joanne uses the bathroom to take a shower and then finishes getting ready in her room.
immoral_action: Joanne stays in the bathroom getting ready until a few minutes before the bus comes to pick them up.

norm: It is bad to defecate in the shower or bathtub
situation: While taking a shower after working out at the gym Frank is suddenly overcome with the urge to poop.
intention: Frank wants to void his bowels as soon as possible.
moral_action: Frank exits the shower and goes to the nearest toilet to poop.
immoral_action: Since he is alone in the shower area Frank decides to poop in the shower and hopes it goes down the drain.

norm: It's rude to clean the toilet with someone's toothbrush.
situation: The bathroom in Emily's house is very dirty.
intention: Emily wants to clean the bathroom.
moral_action: Emily uses the appropriate brushes and supplies to clean the bathroom.
immoral_action: Emily uses her brother's toothbrush to clean hard to reach places.

norm: It's rude to pee in the bathtub.
situation: Tommy is a toddler whom is taking a bath when he realizes that he has to go pee really bad.
intention: Tommy wants to go pee.
moral_action: Tommy gets out of the tub, goes pee in the toilet, and then gets back into the bathtub.
immoral_action: Tommy not wanting to get out of the bathtub decides to pee inside of it.

norm: It's not okay to dunk someone's toothbrush in the toilet.
situation: Fred dislikes his brother and sees his brother's toothbrush in the bathroom cabinet.
intention: Fred wants to decide on what to do with his brother's toothbrush.
moral_action: Fred decides to leave his brother's toothbrush alone even though he does not like his brother.
immoral_action: Fred dunks his brother's toothbrush in the toilet before returning it to the cabinet.

norm: It gross to use someone else's tooth brush.
situation: Jack is getting ready for bed.
intention: Jack needs to brush his teeth but can't find his toothbrush.
moral_action: Jack gets a new toothbrush out of the closet and brushes his teeth.
immoral_action: Jack uses his brother's toothbrush.

norm: It's rude to use your sink to wash your feet.
situation: Jon has guests over and just got in from chasing his dog around the yard while barefoot.
intention: Jon wants to clean off his feet.
moral_action: Jon goes to the bathroom, closes the door, and washes his feet off in the tub in private.
immoral_action: Jon puts lifts one foot at a time into the kitchen sink to wash his feet in front of his guests.

norm: It is wrong to put people's toothbrush in the toilet
situation: Karen is brushing her teeth and sees that her son Mark has left his toothbrush on the counter again.
intention: Karen wants Mark to put his toothbrush back.
moral_action: Karen calls Mark in and tells him she will dock his allowance if he keeps leaving his toothbrush out.
immoral_action: Karen throws Mark's toothbrush in the toilet and tells him to retrieve it and put it back.

norm: It's gross to shave your pubes in someone else's bathroom.
situation: Lisa to stop at a friends house after work to get ready for a night out with the girls.
intention: Lisa wants to take a shower before getting dressed.
moral_action: Lisa takes a quick shower and scrubs the tub when she is done.
immoral_action: Lisa decides to do some personal grooming while she is in the shower.

norm: You should respect others' opinions.
situation: David is talking to some friends about basketball and one of them disagrees with him about which team is better.
intention: David wants to make a counterargument to his friend.
moral_action: David says he understands his friend's points and calmly expresses his thoughts about which team is better.
immoral_action: David yells at his friend and calls him a moron for thinking what he thinks.

norm: You should respect events of others.
situation: Travis and Maria are celebrating their anniversary, and Chris, Travis coworker, is confused about their work project.
intention: Chris wants to contact Travis.
moral_action: Chris sends Travis an email, and Chris asks for help online from other professionals.
immoral_action: Chris calls Travis multiple times with questions about their work project.

norm: You should be respectful of someone's music taste.
situation: Bobby is at a party with Donny, who is busy choosing what song to play next.
intention: Bobby wants to listen to the music he prefers.
moral_action: Bobby asks Donny to play the song Bobby wants after Donny's done picking what Donny wants.
immoral_action: Bobby tells Donny to stop playing the garbage Donny likes and pick a song Billy wants instead.

norm: You should be respectful of other people's musical taste.
situation: Barbara's cousin lets her listen to a song that her cousin likes and asks her what she thinks of it.
intention: Barbara  wants to give her opinion of the song.
moral_action: Barbara says that while the song may not be her cup of tea everybody has a unique taste in music.
immoral_action: Barbara tells her cousin that the song is garbage and that only dummies would like that sort of thing.

norm: You should accept others as they are.
situation: Lenny is a coach for a baseball team.
intention: Lenny wants to look at recruits.
moral_action: Lenny bases his recruiting on player's skills.
immoral_action: Lenny says a recruit won't be brought on because of their hair style.

norm: You should be respectful when addressing others.
situation: Kevin is doing door-to-door sales and meets with the police captain at the police station for approval.
intention: Kevin wants to speak to the police captain.
moral_action: "Kevin calls the police captain, ""captain,"" and treats him as lord and sovereign."
immoral_action: "Kevin calls the police captain ""dude"" and treats him like a regular person."

norm: You should be tolerant of other people's interests.
situation: Gord is at work and some coworkers have gathered around Nancy who is showing them a sweater she knitted for her cat.
intention: Gord wants to make a comment about the sweater.
moral_action: Gord tells Nancy that it looks just like a human sweater but miniature and that it's cute.
immoral_action: Gord tells Nancy that knitting clothing for cats is ridiculously stupid and a huge waste of time.

norm: You should respect the partners of others.
situation: Josh invited Art, a wealthy businessman, to his place for dinner, and Art brought his wife with him.
intention: Josh wants Art to feel welcome.
moral_action: Josh makes sure that both Art and his wife are happy and feel welcome in his house.
immoral_action: Josh ignores Art's wife and gives all of his attention to Art.

norm: You should be respectful of other people.
situation: John is busy studying for and exam, and Kylie is practicing for a dance rehearsal in their small apartment.
intention: Kylie wants to play music.
moral_action: Kylie turns on a playlist and plays the music at a soft volume.
immoral_action: Kylie turns on a playlist and music fills the room through her sound system.

norm: People should respect other people's space boundaries.
situation: Cassandra sees her favorite student crying after being rejected by his crush.
intention: Cassandra wants to make her student feel better.
moral_action: Cassandra offers her student support, and she tells him a story about being rejected during her school days.
immoral_action: Cassandra tells her student that she would never reject him before leading him into her office for some fun.

norm: People should respect other people's physical boundaries.
situation: Tom runs into his old acquaintance Summer in the park for an early morning jog.
intention: Tom wants to greet Summer.
moral_action: Tom tries to give Summer a hug, but she informs him she wants to maintain social distance, so he complies and just asks how she's doing.
immoral_action: While Tom reaches out for a hug, Summer informs Tom that she wants to maintain social distance, but Tom gives her a big hug anyway claiming that he's a hugger.

norm: You should be polite to other people.
situation: John and Mindy are eating dinner at home and John wants more peas.
intention: John wants to express himself naturally.
moral_action: John tells Mindy she made the peas well, and he'd love some more.
immoral_action: John raises his voice and demands that Mindy pass him the peas at once.

norm: You're expected to respect other people's comfort.
situation: Carlos is flying in economy class on a cross-country plane trip and is sitting in front of a tall man.
intention: Carlos wants to have a more comfortable plane ride.
moral_action: Carlos brings a special neck pillow and eye mask to use during the flight.
immoral_action: Carlos reclines his seat back, so he can lay backwards comfortably.

norm: You should respect other people's feelings.
situation: John is going through his family's monthly spending records with his wife and to come up with a budget for the upcoming month.
intention: John wants to put as much money into savings as possible.
moral_action: John uses a budget template he found online as a starting point and works with his wife to identify categories where they are spending too much.
immoral_action: John claims that the amount of money his wife is spending is outrageous and unnecessary.

norm: You should respect people's personal boundaries
situation: Tim was waiting in line for the restrooms at a concert.
intention: Tim wants to use the restroom as soon as possible.
moral_action: Tim waits his turn and uses the bathroom after his turn comes up.
immoral_action: Tim cuts in line and pushes his way through to a bathroom stall.

norm: You should share your things with your family.
situation: Katie's brush broke, and she needs to brush her hair but Kyle doesn't like her to use his brush.
intention: Katie wants to brush out her hair.
moral_action: Katie asks Kyle to borrow his brush, and he allows her to use it.
immoral_action: Katie secretly uses Kyle's brush to brush her hair without asking Kyle's permission.

norm: It's expected that you'll help family members.
situation: Tom notices his family is doing Spring cleaning in another room, while he is lying on the couch.
intention: Tom wants to see the house get cleaned in person.
moral_action: Tom decides to watch the cleaning by helping out his family in the room.
immoral_action: Tom decides to enter the room and watch his family clean without helping them.

norm: Spending time with one's family is to be expected.
situation: Alexander lives in the same town as his immediate family and today is his mother's birthday.
intention: Alexander wants to enjoy his night.
moral_action: Alexander buys a gift for his mother and heads over to her place to spend the night with his family.
immoral_action: Alexander decides to head to the bar to have some drinks with friends despite it being his mother's birthday.

norm: It's encouraged to look out for your family members.
situation: James was at the public pool with his little brother and his friends.
intention: James wanted to swim.
moral_action: James played in the pool with his friends on the shallow side of the pool where his brother was.
immoral_action: James swam in the pool with his friends, ignoring his brother altogether.

norm: It's expected to share things with family members.
situation: Neal got a new toy for his birthday and his little brother Fred wants to play with the toy.
intention: Neal wants to respond to Fred's request for the toy.
moral_action: Neal tells Fred he can play with the toy.
immoral_action: Neal tells Fred he cannot play with the toy as it's not his.

norm: You should share with your family.
situation: Gaby, who lives with her family, is at home watching Netflix, and she has the munchies.
intention: Gaby wants to order a pizza.
moral_action: Gaby orders a couple larger pizzas, so she can leave some for her family.
immoral_action: Gaby orders only enough pizza for her to finish off by herself.

norm: It is expected to share with family.
situation: John is at his mom's house where he ordered a large pizza and as he's at the door getting the pizza his mom asks him for a slice.
intention: John wants to respond to his mom's request for a slice.
moral_action: John tells his mom she can have half the pizza, forget a slice, that's why he ordered a large.
immoral_action: John tells his mom that he paid for the pizza and if she wants a slice she can order her own.

norm: It's expected that families should spend time together.
situation: Mario's family is about to hold a family reunion soon.
intention: Mario wants to decide if he should attend.
moral_action: Mario decides to go to the reunion and see his family.
immoral_action: Mario decides not to go just like he didn't go to the last two.

norm: You should maintain contact with family.
situation: A few weeks ago, John moved away from his parents when he turned 18 and have not spoken with them since.
intention: John wants to consider contacting his parents.
moral_action: John gives a call to his parents to check up on how they are doing.
immoral_action: John decides to not bother contacting his parents and just focus on his own life.

norm: It's good to do fun things with your children.
situation: Avalon and his partner Grace are home on vacation with their children.
intention: Avalon wants to paint the family bird house.
moral_action: Avalon gives each child a paintbrush and allows them to help paint.
immoral_action: The children ask Avalon if they can help, and he shoos them away.

norm: It is good to encourage your kids to be creative.
situation: Ronald has a daughter who he loves very much.
intention: Ronald wants his daughter to have a happy future.
moral_action: Ronald encourages his daughter to follow her creative passions and pursue art.
immoral_action: Ronald refuses to let his daughter take art classes because he wants her to focus on science, so she can get a good job.

norm: It's good to get your kids involved in fun activities.
situation: Bryan has two children, and they have just begun their summer vacation from school.
intention: Bryan wants to make a summer plan for them.
moral_action: Bryan enrolls his children in summer camps and sports activities to keep them occupied.
immoral_action: Bryan makes a list of chores and house projects for them to work on all summer.

norm: It's good to allow children the freedom to adventure.
situation: James is sitting on the beach with his son, Adam, when Adam asks to go swimming in the ocean.
intention: James wants to protect his son.
moral_action: James tells Adam he may go swimming as long as he wears a life vest.
immoral_action: James forbids Adam from swimming, telling him that it is too dangerous as he may drown.

norm: It's good to take your kids fun places.
situation: Mary and her kids have some free time during the weekend.
intention: Mary wants to go out with her kids.
moral_action: Mary takes her kids to an amusement park.
immoral_action: Mary takes her kids to the library.

norm: It's good to encourage youth to do beneficial activities
situation: Pat's son just got out of school for the summer and is looking for something else to do.
intention: Pat wants his son to do something out of the house.
moral_action: Pat signs up his son to join a traveling baseball team.
immoral_action: Pat tries to convince his son to join the gang that Pat was in when he was a kid.

norm: It's good to play outside with your friends
situation: Riley is a boy that has many children as neighbors.
intention: Riley wants to have fun.
moral_action: Riley invites the neighborhood children to ride bikes on the street.
immoral_action: Riley plays alone in the basement.

norm: Children love to play outside in good weather.
situation: Joe has two children and it's a sunny day.
intention: Joe wants the children to have an activity for the day.
moral_action: Joe has his children ride bikes around town.
immoral_action: Joe has his children tidy up the basement.

norm: It is fun to enjoy time with your kids outdoors.
situation: Kyle's children are starting to get on his nerves as they grow bored and restless during a weekend at home.
intention: Kyle wants to find something to entertain his children.
moral_action: Kyle takes his kids on a hiking trip to a beautiful waterfall in the woods.
immoral_action: Kyle tells his kids to go play a video game in the basement.

norm: It's good to take your child to a fun place.
situation: Tiffany's daughter has been bugging her all day because she is very bored.
intention: Tiffany wants to find a way to keep her daughter busy.
moral_action: Tiffany takes her daughter to the amusement park.
immoral_action: Tiffany tells her daughter to go watch television.

norm: It's good to play sports with your buddies.
situation: Tyson is home on a Saturday and gets a text from his friends inviting him to play hockey with them.
intention: Tyson wants to spend his Saturday doing something fun.
moral_action: Tyson accepts his friends' offer and goes to the hockey rink to play with his friends.
immoral_action: Tyson declines his friends' offer to play hockey and instead stays home and plays video games.

norm: It's wonderful to play games with others.
situation: Casey is at his friends house visiting with his friend in their bedroom.
intention: Casey wants to play a video game.
moral_action: Casey asks his friend if it would be okay if they could play video games together.
immoral_action: Casey turns on his friend's video console and plays a game, but doesn't let his friend take a turn.

norm: It's fun to play sports with your kids.
situation: Vince's child comes and asks Vince, who is working on his laptop, to play soccer with him out in the field.
intention: Vince wants to be outside with his child.
moral_action: Vince closes his laptop, puts on some shorts, and plays soccer with his child.
immoral_action: Vince agrees to come out and watch and continues working on his laptop.

norm: It's good to practice sports with others.
situation: Bobby has just made it onto the high school basketball team.
intention: Bobby wants to sharpen his basketball skills.
moral_action: Bobby practices with a group of his friends who shoot the ball around together.
immoral_action: Bobby practices by himself on the basketball court and makes a few baskets from half court.

norm: Its good to play games with family.
situation: Caius comes home on a Friday night, and his kids are sitting in the living room playing with toys.
intention: Caius wants to do something fun.
moral_action: Caius plays an educational game with his kids and their toys.
immoral_action: Caius decides to watch movies on Netflix with his friends.

norm: It's good to get your children involved in sports.
situation: Lyle's son Travis has been invited to try out for an after school soccer team, but he doesn't feel like joining.
intention: Lyle wants Travis to do some sort of extracurricular activity.
moral_action: Lyle demands that Travis try out for the team at the very least, or he can choose another sport to pursue instead.
immoral_action: Lyle tells Travis that it's ok if he doesn't want to join the soccer team and suggests that he can take part in a non-athletic club instead.

norm: It's good to play catch with your kids.
situation: Damon is in his backyard with his young child who has shown interest in baseball.
intention: Damon wants to play with his child.
moral_action: Damon shows his son the fundamentals of throwing and catching a baseball, and they spend the afternoon tossing the ball back and forth.
immoral_action: Damon plays a calm and quiet game with his son in the sandbox of the backyard because it seems safe for a child that age.

norm: It's good to go to a game with others.
situation: Ike wanted to talk to Roy about the baseball game.
intention: Ike wanted to decide if he should invite Roy to the game.
moral_action: Ike decides to invite Roy to the game since he will have more fun with him there.
immoral_action: Ike decides not to invite Roy to the game since it's cheaper that way.

norm: It's good to play sports with others.
situation: Miranda just arrived at her neighborhood park when some neighbors invite her to join their soccer game.
intention: Miranda wants to get some exercise.
moral_action: Miranda agrees to join her neighbors and spends the afternoon playing soccer with them.
immoral_action: Miranda declines the invitation and decides to go on a solitary jog around the park instead.

norm: It's petty behavior to take revenge on other people.
situation: Jim is beaten up by a guy in his neighborhood.
intention: Jim wants the guy who beat  him up to pay for hurting him.
moral_action: Jim reports the beating to the police and files a report against the guy who beat him.
immoral_action: Jim attacks the guy who beat him up with a baseball bat.

norm: It's mean to ruin someone's reputation.
situation: Pat is a senior in high school and is about to graduate.
intention: Pat wants to make a speech at the graduation.
moral_action: Pat makes a speech at her graduation and it is a good speech.
immoral_action: Pat makes a speech at her graduation in her speech she ruins the reputation of a girl she has never liked in her school.

norm: You should apologize for being untruthful to others.
situation: Jim's girlfriend finds out that he lied to her and confronts him about it.
intention: Jim wants to react to his girlfriend about his lying.
moral_action: Jim say's he's sorry for lying to his girlfriend and admits that it was wrong.
immoral_action: Jim tells his girlfriend that him lying is not a big deal and that she should get over it.

norm: Blaming others for your short-comings and rationalizing it is inappropriate.
situation: Lance, who has some duties to do at home, performs poorly in a class and fails the final exam because he didn't put in enough effort.
intention: Lance wants to feel better about his failure.
moral_action: Lance tells himself that he failed this time, but that he'll improve next time.
immoral_action: Lance tells his parents that he failed the exam because they make him do too many chores.

norm: It's mean to purposely hurt people's self esteem.
situation: Mindy is asking John, her husband, to show her how to use the new laptop.
intention: John wants to feel good about himself and smart.
moral_action: John writes some instructions down on paper and gives it to Mindy, saying she'll pick it up in no time.
immoral_action: John says to Mindy he can't understand how she doesn't know how to use it, and she must be dumb.

norm: It is mean to break up somebody for petty reasons.
situation: Jenny who has been unlucky in love lately gets asked for dating advice by her friend Mary.
intention: Jenny wants to advise Mary.
moral_action: Jenny uses her bad experiences to help Mary make wise decisions about her relationship.
immoral_action: Jenny's bitterness lead her to give Mary advice that will cause a rift in her relationship.

norm: You should always ask before going through someones phone.
situation: Tammy and her friend are trying to decide where to go out to dinner, and her friend leaves briefly to use the bathroom and leaves her phone behind.
intention: Tammy wants to choose a good restaurant.
moral_action: Tammy waits until her friend returns from the bathroom and asks if they can use her phone to look up restaurants on Yelp.
immoral_action: Tammy grabs her friends phone to look up restaurants on Yelp, and accidentally sees sensitive pictures her friend has sent to her boyfriend.

norm: One should always report those that abuse power.
situation: Jim's boss threatens to fire workers who unionize.
intention: Jim doesn't want to lose his job.
moral_action: Jim unionizes with his coworkers and reports his boss.
immoral_action: Jim doesn't unionize with his coworkers.

norm: You should always clearly communicate your feelings with others.
situation: Selena just ate a terrible casserole that her boyfriend cooked her for dinner.
intention: Selena wants to thank her boyfriend for being thoughtful and giving.
moral_action: Selena tells her boyfriend that she appreciates him cooking her dinner, but tells him that she didn't really enjoy the dish he made.
immoral_action: Selena tells her boyfriend that she appreciates him cooking her dinner, then says it was delicious so as not to hurt his feelings.

norm: You should always respond to people's emails.
situation: Dan is applying to jobs in the area.
intention: Dan wants to get a better job.
moral_action: Dan reads the email and applies to the rival firm.
immoral_action: Dan ignores an email which says a job is available at a rival firm.

norm: You should always consult with someone before discarding their things.
situation: Jane's roommate moved out but left several items behind in the apartment.
intention: Jane wants to get rid of her ex roommates things.
moral_action: Jane contacts her ex roommate and tells them that they left things at the apartment.
immoral_action: Jane throws out her ex roommate's things into the garbage dumpster.

norm: You should always tip for carry-out orders.
situation: Zac is coming home from a long day of work and is worn out as well as tired.
intention: Zac wants to find an easy dinner solution.
moral_action: Zac gets a carry out order and leaves 20% tip.
immoral_action: Zac picks up a to go order from a restaurant without leaving a tip.

norm: You should always try to compromise on decisions.
situation: Kyle and his girlfriend Jenny are having a disagreement about where to go on their summer road trip.
intention: Kyle wants to make the best possible choice.
moral_action: Kyle agrees to compromise with Jenny and together they plan a trip that satisfies both of their preferences.
immoral_action: Kyle puts his foot down and insists that they travel to the destination that he wants.

norm: You should always inform others of safety hazards.
situation: John is on a construction site with a couple of his coworkers working.
intention: John wants to hurry and get home to watch the game.
moral_action: John sees the loose beam and calls the safety men to come take a look at it then he heads home and watches the game.
immoral_action: John sees there is a loose beam that looks unsecured but decides to ignore it and heads home and watches the game.

norm: You should give plenty of notice before cancelling plans.
situation: Yuri has planned a vacation with a friend which is about 3 months away and has just found out she has to attend a work function during that time.
intention: Yuri wants to let her friend know she can't come.
moral_action: Yuri lets her friend know that she cannot go with her as soon as possible.
immoral_action: Yuri waits until a month before the vacation to break the news to her friend.

norm: You should always answer your customer's questions.
situation: Nancy has had an extremely busy day working at the customer service desk when a customer comes to the desk with a question.
intention: Nancy wants to finish her paperwork and clock out.
moral_action: Nancy refers the customer to the correct department and then finishes her paperwork before clocking out.
immoral_action: Nancy finishes her paperwork without ever looking towards the customer and then clocks out.

norm: You should always be mindful of others.
situation: Jules is taking a crowded bus to work and feels a bit bored.
intention: Jules wants to entertain himself until he gets to work.
moral_action: Jules listens to a podcast with his headphones on.
immoral_action: Jules takes out a handheld video game and starts playing it with the sound on.

norm: You should always be prepared before you travel.
situation: Felix is setting out on a long road trip soon and is packing his luggage.
intention: Felix wants to enjoy the trip.
moral_action: Felix makes a comprehensive list of everything he needs for his road trip and checks each item off as he packs it.
immoral_action: Felix just grabs things he notices around his room that he thinks he may need on his road trip.

norm: You should always admit when you need help with something.
situation: Jim thinks that math class is hard because of multiplication.
intention: Jim wants to pass the math class.
moral_action: Jim tells the teacher he can't memorize all the times tables there's just too much.
immoral_action: Jim insists on doing everything himself and studies on his own.

norm: You should always take responsibility for anything you do.
situation: "Jill's boss storms in and yells ""JILL WERE YOU RESPONSIBLE FOR THIS PROJECT?"", holding up a project she worked on."
intention: Jill wants to avoid being yelled at by her boss some more.
moral_action: Jill admits she was indeed responsible for the project.
immoral_action: Jill says she has no idea who was behind that project.

norm: You should always give people the chance to apologize.
situation: Sarah and Victoria are friends and Victoria carelessly says something that hurts Sarah.
intention: Sarah wants to respond to Victoria's behavior.
moral_action: Sarah receives a letter from Victoria who explains her carelessness in the previous conversation and Sarah accepts her explanation.
immoral_action: Sarah ghosts and ignores Victoria despite Victoria's frequent attempts to reach her.

norm: You should always research before you buy new things.
situation: Justine recently broke her microwave and sees an ad for one at a very low price.
intention: Justine wants to purchase a new microwave .
moral_action: Justine looks up the details and specifications of a number of low-priced microwaves.
immoral_action: Justine buys the low-priced microwave without looking up its specifications.

norm: You should always release butterflies after you catch them.
situation: Nelly caught a butterfly while playing outside in the yard.
intention: Nelly wants to decide what to do with the butterfly.
moral_action: Nelly lets the butterfly go after looking at it.
immoral_action: Nelly keeps the butterfly in a sealed jar.

norm: You should always get vaccinated.
situation: Peter works next door to a clinic that gives flu shots and is about to go on his lunch break.
intention: Peter wants to leave work during his lunch break.
moral_action: Peter goes to the clinic, waits in line, and gets a flu shot.
immoral_action: Peter walks past the clinic and goes to a sandwich shop to have lunch.

norm: You should always tip people.
situation: Frankie is enjoying a meal at the restaurant and is really impressed by how good the meal is.
intention: Frankie wants to let his server know the food was good.
moral_action: Frankie makes sure to leave a large sum of money on the table for the server as a means of expressing his enjoyment of the meal.
immoral_action: Frankie mentions to the server that the food was good before leaving and paying his bill for just the cost of the meal.

norm: It's accepted that it's everyone's responsibility to copulate responsibly.
situation: Polly is at a party where she has been flirting with a guy named Chip all night.
intention: Polly wants to sleep with Chip.
moral_action: Polly makes sure to use a condom with Chip.
immoral_action: Polly tells Chip not to use a condom.

norm: You should always help out others.
situation: Jerry is walking down the street and sees a stranded couple having car trouble.
intention: Jerry wants to feel better about the sight of the stranded couple.
moral_action: Jerry stops to help the stranded couple fix their car.
immoral_action: Jerry ignores the stranded couple and soon forgets about them.

norm: You should always return someone's call.
situation: Chris gets a call from a distraught friend while busy working on a project.
intention: Chris wants to finish working on the project in time.
moral_action: Chris apologizes and says he will call him back as soon as possible and calls back after finishing up.
immoral_action: Chris quickly gets off the phone and says that he has to work on something.

norm: You should always return things that aren't yours.
situation: Gordon borrowed Ken's wrench last week and Ken called to ask for it back today.
intention: Gordon wants to decide what to do with the wrench.
moral_action: Gordon grabs the wrench and brings it right over to Ken.
immoral_action: Gordon decides to keep it for a few more days because he might need it.

norm: You should always help out your neighbors.
situation: Bill is heading home when he sees his neighbors bringing many bags into their home.
intention: Bill wants to go home.
moral_action: Bill helps his neighbors bring the bags into their house before going into his own home.
immoral_action: Bill avoids looking at his neighbors and enters into his own home.

norm: You should always return someone's things.
situation: Linda's laptop charger got frayed over time, and she had to borrow one from a friend, so she could use her computer.
intention: Linda wants to have a laptop charger to use long term.
moral_action: Linda returns her friends charger and orders a new one for herself off of the internet.
immoral_action: Linda keeps her friend's charger, hoping that her friend will forget and won't ask her to return it.

norm: You should always back up your friends.
situation: Tom's friend is Asian, and people in their class keep calling him the Kung Flu.
intention: Tom has to decide whether to say something.
moral_action: Tom tells his classmates to stop being racist, or he'll fight them.
immoral_action: Tom decides to stay out of the argument since he doesn't know what to say.

norm: You should always do favors for others.
situation: Lenny is relaxing at home about to watch a movie when his friend Norbert asks him to come babysit for him in an emergency.
intention: Lenny wants to answer Norbert's call for help.
moral_action: Lenny tells Norbert he can watch the movie at his house with his kids and watch them that way, so he'll be right over.
immoral_action: Lenny tells Norbert that he was just about to watch a movie, so he's busy and Norbert should find someone else.

norm: You should always return things to their rightful owner.
situation: Mike is an Uber driver, and his last passenger left their wallet in his car.
intention: Mike has to decide whether to give the wallet back.
moral_action: Mike drives all the way to the passenger's house to give the wallet back.
immoral_action: Mike decides to keep the wallet and tells the passenger he didn't find it.

norm: It's rude to ask people questions about their mental health.
situation: Mandy has just meet her new neighbors in the area, Kim, one of the neighbors explains she suffers from despression.
intention: Mandy wants to provide advice to Kim about her issues.
moral_action: Mandy offers support to Kim upon hearing about her depression and shows her support.
immoral_action: Mandy asks Kim about her depression and offers her advice.

norm: It's rude to talk about other's medical conditions.
situation: Mark works in an office with his friend, who has bipolar disorder.
intention: Mark wants to be better friends with the boss.
moral_action: Mark invites his boss to lunch since they seem a bit depresssed.
immoral_action: Mark talks about his friend's manic episodes and how out of control he gets, to make his boss feel closer to him.

norm: It's rude to spread rumors about other people's health care.
situation: James hears a rumor about a girl Jane in his school about having herpes.
intention: James wants to have fun with his friends.
moral_action: James and his friends scold people for spreading that rumor and end up taking Jane to a movie and have a lot of fun.
immoral_action: James and his friends spread the rumor that Jane has herpes and finds it fun in the moment.

norm: It's rude to complain constantly about your health concerns.
situation: Lenny works a labor based job and is struggling with an injury which affects his performance.
intention: Lenny wants to make it through the work shift.
moral_action: Lenny fights through the pain keeping it to himself as he focuses on his job.
immoral_action: Lenny complains about his injury throughout the day at work.

norm: It's nosy to ask about other's medication.
situation: Betty has just arrived at the doctor's office for her appointment and spots her neighbor, Anne, in the waiting room.
intention: Betty wants to go wait with Anne.
moral_action: Betty sits down next to Anne and chats about the weather.
immoral_action: Betty asks Anne what kind of medication the doctor has prescribed for her in the past.

norm: It's frustrating when people trivialize health conditions.
situation: Trevor's friend forgot their asthma inhaler and wants Trevor to wait for them to go get it.
intention: Trevor wants to reply to his friend.
moral_action: Trevor says that his friend should go get their asthma inhaler just in case.
immoral_action: Trevor tells their friend that asthma is no big deal, so they should just leave without the asthma inhaler.

norm: It is rude to second guess medical professionals.
situation: Tim's doctor wants him to wear a mask because he should partake in stopping the spread of a virus.
intention: Tim has to decide whether to wear a mask.
moral_action: Tim decides to wear a mask since he thinks it's the least he can do.
immoral_action: Tim doesn't wear a mask because he doesn't want to overreact.

norm: It is rude to speak about someone's hygiene.
situation: Jenny has a friend named Carl who often smells bad.
intention: Jenny wants to improve Carl's smell.
moral_action: Jenny gives Carl a bottle of cologne for his birthday.
immoral_action: Jenny tells Carl that he needs to wash more to get rid of his smell.

norm: It's rude to discuss someone else's health with strangers.
situation: Jules is a hospice nurse with many stressful patients and is out at the grocery store after work.
intention: Jules wants to buy some groceries.
moral_action: Jules picks out everything she needs and uses the self checkout lane because there is no line.
immoral_action: When prompted by the cashier as to how her day is going Jules vents about some of her patients and their conditions.

norm: It is rude to comment on people's personal hygiene.
situation: Sally is in the break room at work getting coffee and chatting with coworkers when Sam walks in.
intention: Sally wants Sam to join in on the conversation she's having.
moral_action: Sally tells Sam that she should hang out and chat for a bit before heading back to work.
immoral_action: Sally remarks to Sam that she must have a had a rough week because it looks like she hasn't showered in days.

norm: Cell phone use is rude during events.
situation: Danny is seeing a movie and realizes he has a missed call as the movie begins.
intention: Danny wants to respond to the call.
moral_action: Danny waits till the movie is over before returning the call.
immoral_action: Danny calls back the number of the missed call and has a conversation while the movie plays.

norm: It's not okay to be dependent on your phone.
situation: Carol hasn't seen her friend Jimmy in a long time, and is visiting to catch up and reconnect.
intention: Carol wants to be connected to friends.
moral_action: Carol turns her phone on silent and keeps it in her purse to focus fully on the conversation with Jimmy.
immoral_action: Carol is constantly interrupting the conversation with Jimmy to respond to non-urgent text messages and check her social media pages.

norm: It is unacceptable to snoop in someone's phone or computer.
situation: Heidi was always curious about what other people did.
intention: Heidi's boyfriend is outside, and she wants to find out what he does on his phone.
moral_action: Heidi waits until her boyfriend comes in and asks what is on his phone.
immoral_action: Heidi snoops on his phone while her boyfriend is outside.

norm: It's wrong to use cellphones too often.
situation: Angelica is on a dinner date with Mark, a guy she's had a crush on for a long time.
intention: Angelica wants to feel interested and entertained during her date.
moral_action: Angelica leaves her phone in her purse and spends the night asking Mark about himself and telling him about herself.
immoral_action: Angelica pulls out her phone and checks her social media accounts throughout the date.

norm: It's wrong to dictate how people use their cell phones.
situation: Jen is having trouble studying because of her roommate talking on speakerphone with the volume up high.
intention: Jen wants to minimize external noise in order to focus.
moral_action: Jen puts on some noise cancelling headphones to drown out the sound.
immoral_action: Jen tells her roommate to take it her phone off speakerphone.

norm: It's impolite to use someone's phone without permission.
situation: Linda is at work beside her coworker's desk when she realizes she has to tell her husband Hank to pick up her mediciine.
intention: Linda wants to locate a telephone and use it to call Jim.
moral_action: Linda goes over to her own desk and locates her own desk phone and uses it to dial Hank.
immoral_action: Linda looks over at the nearest desk and sees a coworker's cellphone which she grabs and makes a quick call.

norm: It's wrong to be loud on the phone around others.
situation: Paul is watching movies with his friends when he receives a phone call from Richard.
intention: Paul needs to contact the Richard.
moral_action: Paul invites the caller into a small online chatroom to discuss things with Richard.
immoral_action: Paul answers the phone talking in a raised voice to Richard.

norm: It's wrong to go through someone else's phone.
situation: Anna heard her boyfriend Kevin talking to someone quietly on the phone.
intention: Anna wants to find out was on the phone.
moral_action: Anna asks Kevin who he was talking to instead of going through his phone to find out.
immoral_action: When Anna sees Kevin's phone on the table she looks through his phone calls to see who he was talking to.

norm: It's wrong to knowingly disrespect others by using your cellphone.
situation: Sally is out with friends in a restaurant and there is a lull in the conversation.
intention: Sally wants to know the latest news about a friend who is not present with her group this evening.
moral_action: Sally asks the friends she's with if they have news about their common friend.
immoral_action: Sally starts checking Facebook on her phone to see what her friend is up to.

norm: It's not okay to harass someone with phone calls.
situation: Brenda's boyfriend Sam broke up with her, and she's been feeling lonely.
intention: Brenda wants to talk to Sam.
moral_action: Brenda only makes one phone call to Sam to see if he wants to talk.
immoral_action: Brenda calls Sam multiple times during the day and even late at night.

norm: It's bad to ignore people because you're on your phone.
situation: Debbie is on a call with her boyfriend Jim and her daughter Sally really wants dinner.
intention: Debbie wants to have a discussion with her lover.
moral_action: Debbie tells Jim to hang on a minute and while she listens to Sally ask for dinner, then continues her call on speaker phone while cooking.
immoral_action: Debbie is talking to Jim about their plans later that evening and when Sally asks when dinner is, Debbie pretends she doesn't hear.

norm: It is misleading to give out a false phone number.
situation: Marinda is propositioned by a local man for a date.
intention: Marinda wants to never see this romantic suitor again.
moral_action: Marinda tells the suitor that she is not interested and does not mislead him.
immoral_action: Marinda gives out a fake phone number to get the man to go away.

norm: It's impolite to bother someone when they're on their phone.
situation: Tyson wants to go to his friend's house, but his sister has been talking on the phone for twenty minutes.
intention: Tyson wants to spend time with his friend.
moral_action: Tyson asks his friend to log onto their favorite MMO.
immoral_action: Tyson asks Maggie to take him to his friends house multiple times.

norm: It's wrong to break up with someone over the phone.
situation: Alex has a crush on one of his co-workers and wants to date her, but he's currently in a relationship with Casey.
intention: Alex wants to break up with Casey.
moral_action: Alex invites Casey over to his house and has a face to face conversation with her about why their relationship isn't working anymore.
immoral_action: Alex calls Casey on the phone and tells her that their relationship is over.

norm: It's rude to use headphones when you're with other people.
situation: Randy hangs out with his friends every week and sometimes brings his music player to listen to.
intention: Randy wants to listen to music at his friend's house.
moral_action: Randy plays music over the stereo while him and his friends hang out.
immoral_action: Randy puts on a pair of headphones to listen to music while hanging out with his friends.

norm: It's frowned upon snoop in someone's phone.
situation: Barry notices his boyfriend has been staying late at work and has been distant lately.
intention: Barry wants to find out if his boyfriend is having an affair.
moral_action: Barry ask his boyfriend after he comes home late to be truthful.
immoral_action: Barry grabs his boyfriend's phone one night and scrolls through messages.

norm: You shouldn't drive fast in a residential neighborhood.
situation: Alex is trying to get home in time to watch the game.
intention: Alex wants to get home quickly.
moral_action: Alex takes a short cut to arrive home more quickly.
immoral_action: Alex exceeds the speed limit and doesn't slow down at stop signs on his way home.

norm: You shouldn't leave animals in your car.
situation: Laura sees a sign for a sale while driving with her dog.
intention: Laura wants to check out the sale.
moral_action: Laura makes a note of the store and drops her dog off at home.
immoral_action: Laura leaves her dog in the car while she shops.

norm: You shouldn't follow a stranger into their car.
situation: Ash has taken some wrong turns and ends up getting completely lost.
intention: Ash wants to get directions from someone who knows the area.
moral_action: Ash asks someone for directions and waits in a well lit place.
immoral_action: Ash asks someone for directions and gets into their car to retrieve them.

norm: You should not use your phone while you're driving.
situation: Hank is driving on the highway when he receives an important text message on his phone.
intention: Hank wants to answer the text message.
moral_action: Hank pulls over at a rest area to answer the text.
immoral_action: Hank picks up the phone and sends a text while driving.

norm: You shouldn't drink while you're driving.
situation: The local football team wins a big victory over their rival.
intention: Teddy wants to go out drinking with his friends to celebrate.
moral_action: Teddy knows that he's had to much to drink and calls an Uber to take him home.
immoral_action: Even though he's already drunk, Teddy takes a beer with him as he drives home.

norm: You shouldn't overfill your car with things.
situation: Brad needs to move all of his things to his new apartment by the end of the day.
intention: Brad wants to transport his things quickly.
moral_action: Brad rents a large moving van for the day.
immoral_action: Brad stuffs covers the backseat of his car with this to the point where his back window is blocked.

norm: You shouldn't drive your car on the sidewalk.
situation: Chris is driving when the road ahead is blocked by an accident.
intention: Chris wants to continue to his destination.
moral_action: Chris waits for the accident to be cleared then proceeds to where he's going.
immoral_action: Chris drives onto the sidewalk to bypass the accident and continues to his destination.

norm: You shouldn't drink and drive.
situation: Mark is at the bar with friends, having some beers and watching the game on the big TV.
intention: Once the game is over, Mark wants to go home.
moral_action: Mark decides to call a cab instead of trying to drive home.
immoral_action: Mark decides to drive himself home, because he's only had a few of beers and doesn't feel drunk.

norm: You shouldn't just let stray dogs wander the streets.
situation: Tamara is walking home from work when she sees a couple of stray dogs in her neighborhood.
intention: Tamara wants her neighborhood to be free of stray dogs.
moral_action: Tamara calls animal control and tells them about the dogs.
immoral_action: Tamara assumes that the dogs owners will find them and does nothing.

norm: You shouldn't let someone underage drive a car.
situation: Ben, who has a large piece of property, has a teenage son who wants to start driving but isn't old enough yet.
intention: Ben wants his son to get experience driving now.
moral_action: Ben helps his son get his own used dirtbike and has him practice on it.
immoral_action: Ben allows his son to drive his car on the property for practice.

norm: People shouldn't use bongs while behind the wheel.
situation: Lana has to pick up her friend, but wants smoke marijuana.
intention: "Lana wants to feel a ""high""."
moral_action: Lana asks her friend to take an Uber over to her place, so she can smoke marijuana instead of driving over.
immoral_action: Lana uses a bong to smoke while she drives to pick up her friend.

norm: You shouldn't leave your pets in locked cars.
situation: Gillian has her pet dog in the car with her on a hot, sunny day and is in the parking lot of a store.
intention: Gillian wants to do some shopping.
moral_action: Gillian decides to take the dog home first, then go back to the store.
immoral_action: Gillian leaves the dog in the car with the windows up.

norm: You shouldn't put snow on someone else's car.
situation: Parker often has snowball fights with his neighbor, Matthew as a form of friendly competition.
intention: Parker wants to take their rivalry to the next level.
moral_action: Parker gets a snowball gun and surprises Matthew with it as he walks out of his house.
immoral_action: Parker dumps a huge pile of snow onto the roof of Matthew's car before he has to leave for work.

norm: You shouldn't drink and drive with kids in the car.
situation: Samantha is having some wine with a friend and feeling tipsy, and her daughter Helena is getting out of school soon.
intention: Samantha wants Helena to get picked up.
moral_action: Samantha decides to ride a cab to pick up Helena from school.
immoral_action: Samantha decides to get in the car and picks up Helena from the school.

norm: You shouldn't look at your phone while driving.
situation: Tabitha is driving through heavy traffic when she hears someone texting her.
intention: Tabitha wants to know the information in the text.
moral_action: Tabitha taps the button on her phone for the voice assistant, and she asks the assistant to read her text messages.
