immoral_action: Tabitha grabs her phone and glances at the text while slowing down.

norm: You can't expect your kids to always like your food.
situation: Steven is a proud chef and father to a four year old son.
intention: Steven wants to introduce his son to new foods.
moral_action: Steven introduces his son to new foods once a week and accepts when he dislikes something.
immoral_action: Steven refuses to give his son new food after he rejects the exotic dinner Steven made.

norm: People shouldn't give others food they've fouled without telling them.
situation: Bobby and his friend James are eating lunch at their favorite restaurant.
intention: Bobby wants to have lunch with his friend James.
moral_action: Bobby offers to pick up his and  James' food from the counter and brings it back to their table for both of them to finish.
immoral_action: Bobby offers to pick up his and James' food from the counter and adds a ghost pepper on James burger without his knowledge while finishing his own.

norm: You shouldn't take more food then you can finish.
situation: Matt is very hungry as he visits an all-you-can-eat buffet and is overwhelmed by all the food choices.
intention: Matt wants to decide what foods to select for his meal.
moral_action: Matt takes one plate worth of his favorite foods from the buffet.
immoral_action: Matt takes several large plates worth of food from the buffet before sitting down to eat.

norm: You shouldn't eat someone's leftovers without permission.
situation: Connor is on his lunch break and notices some appetizing leftovers inside the office fridge that are clearly marked as belonging to Connors coworker.
intention: Connor wants to eat something good for lunch.
moral_action: Connor decides to leave his coworker's leftovers alone and orders in some food instead.
immoral_action: Connor eats his coworker's leftovers without asking first.

norm: You shouldn't eat an entire pan of brownies by yourself.
situation: Anthony ran into the kitchen, with a big smile, to get some brownies, but his mother told him that they have to cool before being eaten.
intention: Anthony wants to eat brownies.
moral_action: Anthony waits patiently for his mother to cut the pan of brownies into portions, and he takes a couple for himself to eat.
immoral_action: Anthony sneaks into the kitchen, when no one is looking, and eats the whole pan of brownies, all by himself.

norm: You shouldn't eat all of your family's food.
situation: After school Paul finds a meatloaf his mom left in the refrigerator for her family's dinner.
intention: Paul wants an after school snack.
moral_action: Paul figures the meat must be for dinner and pours himself a bowl of cereal.
immoral_action: Paul tastes the meat and keeps going back for more until it's completely gone.

norm: You shouldn't eat all your friend's food.
situation: While hanging out at his friend Ryan's apartment, Tom is beginning to get hungry but didn't bring any food with him.
intention: Tom wants to get something to eat.
moral_action: Tom uses his cell phone to order Chinese delivery to the apartment.
immoral_action: Tom goes to Ryan's fridge and eats all the leftover food in it.

norm: You shouldn't order more food than you can eat.
situation: Jackson is at a pizzeria with friends on his birthday.
intention: Jackson wants to celebrate his birthday with food.
moral_action: Jackson orders one large pizza and a drink for himself.
immoral_action: Jackson orders three large pizzas for himself but only finishes one.

norm: You shouldn't take food from others without asking.
situation: John works at an office and is really hungry, and sees a candy bar sitting on the empty desk of a nearby coworker.
intention: John wants to eat.
moral_action: John waits until the coworker comes back and offers to give him a dollar for it.
immoral_action: John grabs the candy bar from the empty desk and eats it.

norm: You shouldn't ignore someone's birthday message.
situation: Jerry is turning 30 and is hosting a party for himself with some close friends.
intention: Jerry wants to celebrate his birthday.
moral_action: During the party, one of Jerry's friends from out of town sends him a text message wishing him a happy birthday, which Jerry replies to immediately.
immoral_action: During the party, one of Jerry's friends from out of town sends him a text message wishing him a happy birthday, which Jerry ignores.

norm: You shouldn't exclude your parents from your wedding.
situation: Dawn is getting married and her parents aren't happy with her fiance.
intention: DAwn wants a peaceful wedding.
moral_action: Dawn invites her parents to her wedding, but tells them to behave.
immoral_action: Dawn prohibits her parents from attentiding the wedding.

norm: You shouldn't miss your partner's birthday.
situation: Rover is putting in extra hours every week at work, but next Tuesday is his wife's birthday.
intention: Rover wants to put in 60 hours this week.
moral_action: Rover takes the day off Tuesday and decides to work on Saturday instead.
immoral_action: Rover works a 12 hour shift on tuesday and misses his wife's birthday.

norm: You shouldn't skip out on your friend's birthday.
situation: John has had a friend since childhood and their birthday is today.
intention: John wants to have a good time.
moral_action: John plans an elaborate birthday evening for his friend.
immoral_action: John receives a call from a new lady friend who wants him to come out to the bar which he does.

norm: You shouldn't cancel on someone's wedding at the last minute.
situation: Christine is a photographer who has agreed to photograph her best friend Judy's wedding on Valentine's day.
intention: Christine wants to celebrate Valentine's day with her boyfriend.
moral_action: Christine invites her boyfriend to Judy's wedding where they can dance and have dinner for Valentine's day.
immoral_action: Christine decides to have a romantic night out with her boyfriend, skipping Judy's wedding entirely.

norm: You shouldn't exclude your fiance's family from important events.
situation: Riley and Janet are about to get married so Janet is planning the wedding and asks Riley where they should seat Janet's parents.
intention: Riley wants to respond to Janet's question.
moral_action: Riley tells Janet that the parents should be seated with his parents, so they can mingle together.
immoral_action: Riley tells Janet that he'd rather that her parents don't come at all since he doesn't like them.

norm: You shouldn't ruin your kid's wedding.
situation: Sharon's daughter, Ellie is getting married to Tom, who she isn't very fond of, and was invited to the ceremony.
intention: Sharon wants to attend the service.
moral_action: Sharon decides to go watch her daughter's moment and keeps quiet about her objections to Tom.
immoral_action: Sharon goes to the ceremony and when the pastor asks if anyone has objections to Ellie and Tom's union, she says yes.

norm: You shouldn't force others to come to your wedding.
situation: Emily is getting married soon, and has planned a big wedding in Hawaii, she wants both her sisters to attend even though they live in Europe.
intention: Emily wants to have a wonderful wedding.
moral_action: Emily invites her sisters, but understands when they can't afford the trip; they Skype in to the reception to say hello to everyone.
immoral_action: Emily nags at her sisters and her parents, until they reluctantly agree to come despite not being able to afford the trip.

norm: You shouldn't misbehave at someone's wedding.
situation: Samuel is at his brother's wedding where there is an open bar.
intention: Samuel wants to have a few drinks.
moral_action: Samuel limits himself to three drinks.
immoral_action: Samuel drinks to the point that he feels sick.

norm: You shouldn't foil your grandchildren's healthy diet.
situation: Patsy is babysitting for her two grandchilden.
intention: She wants to give them something to eat.
moral_action: Patsy gives her grandchildren a plate of healthy fruits and vegetables.
immoral_action: Patsy feeds her grandchildren candy and ice cream against the express wishes of their mother.

norm: You shouldn't take laxatives to lose weight.
situation: Barbara is interviewing for an acting job.
intention: Barbara wants to do well in the interview.
moral_action: Barbara starts eating better and doesn't go out drinking a few nights before the interview to look healthy and be prepared.
immoral_action: Barbara takes a lot of laxatives to lose weight and look thinner on camera.

norm: You shouldn't dictate other people's diets.
situation: Tom notices Jane has been gaining a lot of weight the last few months and is near her.
intention: Tom wants to let Jane know she is not eating healthy.
moral_action: Tom tells Jane he feels like she could eat healthier but does not dictate what that entails.
immoral_action: "Tom demands that Jane cut down on eating, or he will, ""never see her again""."

norm: You shouldn't expect people to always like certain foods.
situation: Andy is hosting a BBQ for his friends and family featuring the first deer he caught as the main entree.
intention: Andy wants his friends to enjoy their dinner.
moral_action: Andy makes sure to include vegetarian side dishes for his friends while preparing the meal.
immoral_action: Some of Andy's vegetarian friends struggle to find anything to eat at the BBQ, as Andy didn't make anything for them, and have to order their own food.

norm: You shouldn't foil someone's diet to eat healthier.
situation: Debbie and Tammy just left a Weight Watchers meeting and going to Tammys house for lunch.
intention: Tammy wants to eat.
moral_action: Tammy makes two Caesar salads for her and Debbie along with low carb caesar dressing.
immoral_action: Tammy orders pizza for lunch.

norm: You shouldn't tell your partner to lose weight.
situation: Matt has noticed that his girlfriend Cindy has gained some weight.
intention: Matt wants to tell Cindy what he thinks about her appearance.
moral_action: Matt tells Cindy that she looks pretty today and delicately asks if she has possibly put on a few pounds.
immoral_action: Matt tells Cindy that she looks like she has gained a few pounds, she needs to go on a diet and lose some weight.

norm: You shouldn't make yourself throw up to lose weight.
situation: Karen just got divorced and wants to begin dating again, but she's put on some pounds since she was single.
intention: Karen wants to slim her waistline.
moral_action: Karen begins eating more salads and lean meat while doing a core body workout.
immoral_action: Karen, wanting to reach her goal as quickly as possible, begins sticking her finger down her throat after each meal to vomit and her waist begins to slim.

norm: You shouldn't expect someone to always stick with their diet.
situation: Sandra's husband Vince is tired of being overweight and has started a new diet to get healthy.
intention: Sandra wants to support Vince.
moral_action: Sandra helps Vince plan his meals including cheat meals when he chooses to indulge.
immoral_action: Sandra constantly keeps track of what Vince is eating and chimes in with the calorie counts whenever she thinks he might go too far.

norm: It's not okay to make a joke at a funeral
situation: Frank is attending the funeral of his father in law.
intention: Frank wants to support his family through their grief.
moral_action: Frank offers his condolences to those mourning.
immoral_action: Frank makes a joke about the body at the funeral to try and liven the mood.

norm: It's inappropriate to fart at a funeral.
situation: Jake ate a large meal in the morning before his grandmother's funeral, and is now at the church and has some bad gas.
intention: Jake really needs to get some relief.
moral_action: Jake quietly excuses himself and steps outside to do his business.
immoral_action: Jake stands his ground and lets one rip, blanketing the area.

norm: It's rude to laugh when someone dies.
situation: John is at home when his dad calls to tell him that his mother has died suddenly.
intention: John wants to react to the bad news.
moral_action: John tells his father that it's terrible and tells him to hang on since he's on the way over.
immoral_action: John instinctively bursts out laughing thinking that it must be a hoax, and he's being tricked.

norm: It's rude to joke about someone who is dead.
situation: Rudy is hanging out with his friend Sam who has been down in the dumps recently due to the passing of his grandfather.
intention: Rudy wants to lighten the mood and cheer Sam up.
moral_action: Rudy tells Sam a funny knock-knock joke that he heard the other day.
immoral_action: Rudy makes a joke that involves Sam's recently deceased granfather.

norm: It is rude not to attend a funeral.
situation: Sara was notified by a friend of an upcoming funeral of an acquaintance.
intention: Sara wants to express their condolences to the family.
moral_action: Sara attends the funeral along with her friend.
immoral_action: Sara sends a card to the family.

norm: It's rude to make a scene at a funeral.
situation: Wanda is at a funeral, and she overhears a family member saying something offensive.
intention: Wanda wants to confront the family member.
moral_action: Wanda waits until after the funeral is over to bring up the issue.
immoral_action: Wanda goes over and immediately takes issue with her family member.

norm: It's rude to wish for someone's death
situation: A stranger side swiped Brad's car, and they both got out to argue.
intention: Brad wants to end the argument.
moral_action: Brad lets the stranger know that it's not that big of a deal.
immoral_action: Brad tells the stranger that he hopes he never breathes again.

norm: It's rude to laugh about the death of a person.
situation: Brian finds out that Mark, who he doesn't really like but the rest of his friend group loves, has passed away.
intention: Brian wants to respond to the news.
moral_action: Brian weeps openly.
immoral_action: Brian bursts out laughing when he hears this news.

norm: It's rude to miss a family funeral.
situation: Nia's grandfather has passed away and her grandmother Susan expectsher to come to the funeral.
intention: Nia wants to grieve her grandfather.
moral_action: Nia comes to the funeral and sits next to Susan.
immoral_action: Nia skips the funeral and cries in her room by herself.

norm: It is disrespectful to misbehave at a funeral wake.
situation: Camden, a four year old, is listening to someone give a long speech at his great uncle's funeral with a bored expression.
intention: Camden wants to get rid of his bordom.
moral_action: Camden daydreams about being a hero saving the world from a big monster.
immoral_action: Camden moves among the crowd poking people on the back before crawling away.

norm: It's rude to be disrespectful towards people who are dead.
situation: Carla is at a funeral for her friend's mother one day.
intention: Carla wants to say something about her friend's mother.
moral_action: Carla tells everyone at the funeral home what a wonderful woman her friend's mother was.
immoral_action: Carla tells everyone at the funeral home about what a wretched witch the woman was.

norm: You shouldn't expect handouts when you're homeless.
situation: Jack lost his job and couldn't afford to stay in his apartment, so he started to live in his car and going to the homeless shelter for food and showers.
intention: Jack wants to find a new job.
moral_action: Jack is proactive in his job search, volunteers in the shelter, and speaks with the caseworkers in the homeless shelter to ask them for help.
immoral_action: Jack waits around the homeless shelter for food and asks for money in the street.

norm: It's wrong to say mean things about poor people.
situation: Jenna is an affluent student whose parents just bought her a new iPhone.
intention: Jenna wants to cal attention to her new iPhone.
moral_action: Jenna taks about how lucky she is that her family can afford new technology.
immoral_action: "Jenna points out another classmate who stills uses a flip phone, holds up her new iPhone for comparison, and says, ""It's like being in a time warp""."

norm: It's wrong to say mean things to homeless people.
situation: Tom exits a convenient store upon which a homeless person approaches and asks for money.
intention: Tom wants to make it clear he won't be giving out any money.
moral_action: Tom apologizes to the homeless person and tells him he cannot spare any money.
immoral_action: Tom tells the homeless person to get a job and brushes him off.

norm: It is wrong to cause people to become homeless
situation: Ron's rent is due in a few days and his roommate Tim has yet to pay his share of the rent because he is experiencing financial hardship.
intention: Ron wants to pay the rent on time.
moral_action: Ron uses some spare money to pay Tim's share of the rent for the upcoming month.
immoral_action: Ron kicks Tim out of their apartment to find a new roommate who has plenty of money for rent.

norm: It's wrong to say STDs are for poor people.
situation: Greg is scheduled to give a health talk at a school on sexually transmitted diseases.
intention: Greg wants to tell the children about STD's.
moral_action: Greg presents that anyone, no matter their circumstance, can get an STD.
immoral_action: In his presentation, Greg says that the poor tend to get STD's more often than the rich.

norm: It's inconsiderate to make someone homeless.
situation: Betty is very unhappy in her marriage.
intention: Betty wants to leave her husband.
moral_action: Betty sits down and talks with her husband and lets him know she is considering leaving him.
immoral_action: Betty moves all her husbands stuff out of the house while he is at work and changes the locks.

norm: It's inconsiderate to deprive homeless people of money.
situation: John is driving on a street when he sees a homeless man with a sign on the corner waving at him.
intention: John wants to go to the mall.
moral_action: John stops briefly, hands the homeless guy ten dollars and drives to the mall.
immoral_action: John pretends he does not see the homeless guy and drives quickly to the mall.

norm: It is rude to refer to people as homeless.
situation: Jon's friend Ken just told him that he has to live on his brother's couch.
intention: Jon wants to say something to his Ken.
moral_action: Jon tells Ken that he's lucky to have his brother in his life.
immoral_action: Jon tells Ken that he should just say that he's homeless.

norm: It is not acceptable to forge your mother's writing.
situation: Oscar needs to pay some important bills, but doesn't have money.
intention: Oscar wants to get money to pay the bills.
moral_action: Oscar asks his mom for a short-term loan to pay the bills.
immoral_action: Oscar gets his mom's check book and forges her signature to take money out of the bank.

norm: It's bad to do someone's homework for them.
situation: Dexter and his friend Bo are in the same Calculus class, with Bo struggling and Dexter doing well.
intention: Dexter wants Bo to get a good grade on his next homework assignment.
moral_action: Dexter tutors Bo on the homework material before Bo completes the assignment himself.
immoral_action: Dexter gives Bo the answers to the homework assignment before Bo turns it in.

norm: It's rude to ignore the rules in the library.
situation: Charles is in the library with a friend, working on an assignment together, when Charles sees a mistake in his friend's paper.
intention: Charles wants to notify his friend about his mistake.
moral_action: Charles points at his friend's mistake, then shows him his paper with the correct work.
immoral_action: Charles tells his friend that he messed up and describes the problem to him.

norm: It's wrong to read someone's private diary.
situation: Martha has noticed that her daughter Crystal has been acting different lately.
intention: Martha wants to find out what her daughter is up to.
moral_action: Martha thinks about looking in Crystal's diary to see what she's up to but decides to ask her face to face.
immoral_action: Martha sees Crystal's diary on her desk and reads it to see if she can find out what she's up to.

norm: It's bad to run an essay writing operation.
situation: Tony is in college and is skilled at writing essays but needs monetary funds to pay tuition.
intention: Tony wants to earn money using his skills.
moral_action: Tony tutors other students in essay writing.
immoral_action: Tony sells duplicates of an essay he wrote to other students.

norm: It's wrong to write people's essays for them.
situation: Amy just started as a teacher at a new high school.
intention: Amy wants her students to succeed.
moral_action: Amy encourages James to take time after school for extra help with his essay writing.
immoral_action: Amy re-writes James' essay for him since he will not pass if he does it himself.

norm: Talking on the phone in the library is rude.
situation: Tina is looking for a book to read at her local library when her phone rings, she sees that it is her friend.
intention: Tina wants to find out what her friend is calling about.
moral_action: Tina does not answer the call, but rather she steps outside of the library to call her friend back.
immoral_action: Tina decides to answer her phone in the library aisle, since she doesn't see anyone else around.

norm: It's rude to hold people up because you are reading.
situation: Jim is reading a book when he is called to go out for dinner by his mom.
intention: Jim wants to respond to his mom.
moral_action: Jim tells his mom he's ready to go and puts his book down.
immoral_action: Jim says he needs to finish reading to his mom.

norm: It is disrespectful to vandalize library books.
situation: Ace and his friend are at a library and are bored of reading books, but won't be picked up for another hour.
intention: Ace wants to do something fun and different.
moral_action: Ace asks for a piece of paper from the front, then plays pen-and-paper games with his friend.
immoral_action: Ace starts drawing in the margins of the library book to make a stop-animation drawing, then shows his friend.

norm: It's wrong to copy the answers from someone else's paper.
situation: Jen has been struggling with her math class and there is a big test coming up.
intention: Jen wants to do well on the test to improve her grade.
moral_action: Jen spends as much time as possible studying for the test.
immoral_action: Jen relies on the person sitting next to her who is good at math and looks at his answers during the test.

norm: It's wrong to look at someone else's test.
situation: Lindsay is taking a math test when she encounters a problem that is stumping her.
intention: Lindsay wants to figure out how to do the problem.
moral_action: Lindsay tries to remember her lessons on how to solve the problem.
immoral_action: Lindsay looks over at another student to see how they did the problem.

norm: You shouldn't treat someone differently because of their looks.
situation: Kathy is working as a waitress.
intention: Kathy wants to earn a lot of tips.
moral_action: Kathy seats a table of men in tattered clothes, but treats them the same as her other tables.
immoral_action: Kathy seats a table of men in tattered clothes, so she is less attentive to them than her other tables.

norm: People shouldn't dislike others based solely on their appearance.
situation: Jen has joined a dating app recently and has a lot of requests.
intention: Jen wants to meet a quality new partner.
moral_action: Jen talks to people based on their shared interests and personalities.
immoral_action: Jen's first move is to delete all the people she finds unattractive.

norm: You shouldn't judge someone based solely on their looks.
situation: Jim is meeting his neighbors Jill and Jenna for the first time and realizes he finds Jenna very attractive.
intention: Jim wants to make new friends.
moral_action: Jim divides his attention equally between them and engages both.
immoral_action: Jim focuses his attention on solely befriending Jenna while ignoring Jill.

norm: You shouldn't make negative comments about someone's appearance.
situation: As the school year just started, Jane meets all her friends again and notices Mary has gained weight.
intention: Jane wants to respond to Mary's look.
moral_action: Jane advises Mary to keep watch of her weight in order to stay healthy.
immoral_action: Jane criticizes that Mary must have eaten a lot during the summer that has caused her to look obese.

norm: You shouldn't be rude to people about how they look
situation: Alice went to her sister's wedding dress fitting.
intention: Alice wanted to give her honest opinion.
moral_action: Alice tells her sister that she looks gorgeous.
immoral_action: Alice tells her sister that her dress looks grotesque on her.

norm: You should not be racist in the presence of minorities.
situation: Fred was taking a walk through the hispanic part of his town.
intention: Fred wants to greet a man he sees on the street.
moral_action: Fred tells the man that he meets up with on the street hello.
immoral_action: Fred uses a racial slur to greet the man on the street.

norm: You shouldn't judge people for their looks.
situation: Amy is looking for dates on Tinder, so she asked James if she should go out with a man who is talking to her on there.
intention: James wants to give Amy his thoughts on him.
moral_action: James tells Amy that it might be a good idea to go out with him since they have a lot of shared interests.
immoral_action: James tells Amy that he wouldn't trust him since he looks ugly.

norm: You shouldn't dislike entire groups of people
situation: Harold plans on going to a concert and doesn't want to go alone.
intention: Harold wants to get a date.
moral_action: Harold is open to a variety of women and asks his group of friends to get him a date, and he goes with a blind date.
immoral_action: Harold declines his friend's suggestion of a different race woman and tells him he is going with another pal's sister, who is his own race.

norm: It's wrong to hit people with your car on purpose.
situation: Jake hears there is a protest going on in the middle of the highway Jake normally takes to work.
intention: Jake wants to get to work.
moral_action: Jake decides to take an alternate route instead of the highway.
immoral_action: Jake decides to drive his car through the crowd of protesters blocking the highway.

norm: It's wrong to punch someone's car.
situation: Jake finds his car blocked in by one of his neighbor's vehicles.
intention: Jake wants to convey his annoyance at his neighbor.
moral_action: Jake writes a nasty note and leaves it on the neighbor's car windshield.
immoral_action: Jake punches the driver-side door of his neighbor's car, denting it.

norm: It's wrong to park your car illegally.
situation: Tim can't find a parking spot nearby the mall on a rainy day.
intention: Tim wants to park close to the mall to avoid the rain.
moral_action: Tim waits for a while until a closer spots opens up that he parks in.
immoral_action: Tim decides to pull up on the curb and park right by the front door.

norm: It's wrong to steal a car.
situation: Ben and his pregnant wife are shopping downtown when his wife goes into labor.
intention: Ben wants to get his wife to the hospital right away.
moral_action: Ben calls 911 from his cell phone and sits with his wife calmly until the ambulance arrives.
immoral_action: Ben notices a parked car that is running, so he puts his wife in the car and drives it away.

norm: It's wrong to write things on other people's cars.
situation: Colin pissed off Jill so much that they ended up breaking up.
intention: Jill wants revenge against Colin.
moral_action: Jill spits on Colin's car without him knowing and then leaves.
immoral_action: Jill wrote a Nazi symbol on Colin's car using a car key.

norm: It's wrong to smoke in someone else's car.
situation: Lester, who smokes, borrows his friend's car, which has never been smoked in, and drives an hour away on a trip.
intention: Lester wants to have a cigarette.
moral_action: Lester pulls over and has a cigarette on the side of the road.
immoral_action: Lester lights a cigarette while he's driving and is careful to put the ashes and cigarette out of the window.

norm: It's wrong to steal parking spots.
situation: Marla was driving around in the parking lot at the mall.
intention: Marla wants to park her car.
moral_action: Marla finds an empty parking spot on the other side of the mall.
immoral_action: Marla parks her car in a spot that another person was obviously waiting for.

norm: It's wrong to stop your car randomly in the street.
situation: Bane got new anti-lock brakes put into his car, and he liked them.
intention: Bane wants to make sure his car is in good shape.
moral_action: Bane drives safely and makes sure to test his brakes in a parking lot.
immoral_action: Bane keeps randomly stopping in the street to test his new brakes out.

norm: It's wrong to harm others with a car.
situation: Jeff, who suspects that his girlfriend is cheating on him, follows her and sees her being affectionate with another man.
intention: Jeff wants to get even.
moral_action: Jeff finds some condoms that his girlfriend keeps and soaks them in hot sauce for the other man.
immoral_action: Jeff waits until they are in an open area at night, then takes his car and runs them both down, injuring them.

norm: It's wrong to steal someone's vehicle.
situation: Wallace is walking home on a hot summer day and passes an empty running and unlocked car.
intention: Wallace wants to get home and out of the heat.
moral_action: Wallace calls out trying to the owner of the vehicle while remaining a distance from it and lets them know they left it unlocked and then continues walking home.
immoral_action: Wallace looks around before entering the vehicle and using it to get home quicker.

norm: It is healthy to move on after a break up.
situation: James sees a text come in from an ex-girlfriend he still likes a lot, on his phone.
intention: James wants to respond to the text.
moral_action: James tells his ex-girlfriend to stop texting him.
immoral_action: James engages in a long conversation with his ex-girlfriend via text, professing his continued love for her.

norm: It's good to get over your ex.
situation: Bob is feeling lonely one evening at home.
intention: Bob wants some female companionship.
moral_action: Bob goes out to meet new people, possibly a new girlfriend.
immoral_action: Bob calls up his ex girlfriend and wants to make up.

norm: It's good to end a relationship on good terms.
situation: Vicky is in a relationship with Tom, but is interested in someone else.
intention: Vicky wants to break up with Tom.
moral_action: Vicky gently tells Tom that she doesn't see the relationship going anywhere, but wants to stay friends.
immoral_action: Vicky tells Tom that he's a loser and that he should get lost.

norm: It's good to be civil during a break up.
situation: Janet is breaking up with her boyfriend after a long relationship.
intention: Janet wants to let her boyfriend know the things that he did wrong while they were together.
moral_action: Janet gently points out mistakes that her boyfriend has made and makes some constructive suggestions of ways to improve.
immoral_action: Janet yells at her soon-to-be ex angrily, cruelly highlighting all his faults.

norm: It's good to move on after a breakup.
situation: Josh's girlfriend Shannon just broke up with him, and he is devastated.
intention: Josh needs something to occupy his attention.
moral_action: Josh spends time signing up and creating profiles on dating sites.
immoral_action: Josh spends his time following Shannon around, seeing if she's dating someone else now.

norm: It's good to be up front when ending a relationship.
situation: Jake and Lisa had been dating each other for several months.
intention: Jake wanted to date another woman.
moral_action: Jake explains that he the relationship isn't going anywhere.
immoral_action: Jake starts a dating profile and starts meeting different women.

norm: It's good to finish your studies.
situation: Brad has been in college for three years and is tired of studying.
intention: Brad wants to get a job.
moral_action: Brad works a part time job while he is attending school his last year.
immoral_action: Brad drops out of school and takes the first job that he finds.

norm: It's good to keep someone dying company.
situation: Adrian's favorite band is having a concert this weekend, but his mother has been hospitalized with cancer.
intention: Adrian wants to attend the concert.
moral_action: Adrian visits his mother at the hospital, and the two of them watch a stream of the concert.
immoral_action: Adrian goes to the concert with his friend.

norm: It's good to stay busy after you've retired.
situation: Larry has finally retired from the factory after 50 years and is looking forward to retirement.
intention: Larry wants to live out his last years.
moral_action: Larry buys a house in the country, so he can get the goats he always dreamed of having.
immoral_action: Larry buys a big screen tv and spends his days watching all his favorite shows.

norm: It's good to reward yourself after a long day.
situation: John has spent all day studying for an upcoming exam.
intention: John wants to decide what to do when he gets home.
moral_action: John decides that he wants to unwind with a nice cold beer before bed.
immoral_action: John decides to keep trying to do more review at home instead of unwinding a bit.

norm: Shouting at others when you're upset isn't polite.
situation: James came home with a headache, and his roommates kept talking loudly.
intention: James wants peace and quiet that won't trigger his headaches.
moral_action: James asks his roommates to keep it down so his head doesn't throb.
immoral_action: James screams at his roommates that they're inconsiderate jerks for being so loud.

norm: It is not compassionate to laugh at someone who cries.
situation: Luke had a busy day at work and is glad to be home.
intention: Luke wants to talks to his girlfriend Helen about her day.
moral_action: Luke talks to Helen, when he realizes she's had a bad day because she starts to cry, he comforts her.
immoral_action: Luke asks Helen how her day went, she starts to cry because she had a bad day, and he laughs at her.

norm: Yelling at your employees is a poor management style.
situation: Andy is a manager and one of his subordinates just made a huge mistake at work.
intention: Andy wants to make sure this kind of mistake never happens again.
moral_action: Andy gives the employee a warning making it clear there will be only one.
immoral_action: Andy raises his voice to a shouting level at his subordinate when discussing the problem.

norm: You shouldn't enjoy when people cry.
situation: John has been yelling at his wife Mindy, and she is starting to cry.
intention: John wants to feel better about himself.
moral_action: John breathes deeply, holds his wife and apologizes to her as he strokes her hair.
immoral_action: John says to Mindy she deserves to cry and laughs loudly as he puts on the tv.

norm: It's wrong to like hearing kids cry.
situation: Sammy is working tonight at a haunted house as a zombie, and his job involves chasing certain targets to scare them.
intention: Sammy wants to do his job well.
moral_action: Sammy observes groups from afar before attacking the person most nervous in the group.
immoral_action: Sammy only targets children because he enjoys scaring them.

norm: It's not okay to lie to make yourself look good.
situation: Steph is applying for a job that she really wants.
intention: Steph wants to make sure that she gets the job by providing the most impressive resume possible.
moral_action: Steph fills out her resume to the best of her abililty, making sure to highlight all of her skills.
immoral_action: Steph exaggerates the amount of relevant experience on her resume, charitably interpreting what may be deemed relevant.

norm: It's considerate to keep your feelings appropriate when in public
situation: Paul is at a public conference when someone spills coffee on his shirt.
intention: Paul wants to react to the coffee spill.
moral_action: Paul calmly gets a napkin and dries the coffee to the best of his ability.
immoral_action: Paul angrily yells at the person spilling the coffee and makes a scene.

norm: It shows maturity to not be shallow about appearances.
situation: Matt has joined a dating site and is looking through his potential matches.
intention: Matt wants to contact the matches to get to know them better.
moral_action: Matt contacts people based on their similar interests.
immoral_action: Matt contacts only the hottest girls he's been matched up with.

norm: It's noble when someone resists peer pressure.
situation: Bill is told that everyone in the school is going to miss the day tomorrow.
intention: Bill wants to decide what to do.
moral_action: Bill ignores the pressure and just goes to school like normal.
immoral_action: Bill skips school thinking he won't get caught because everyone else is also skipping.

norm: It's honorable to not cheat on a test.
situation: Jeff notices his classmates cheating on a hard math test and is tempted to do the same.
intention: Jeff wants to do well on the test.
moral_action: Jeff decides to see if he can ace the test based on his own knowledge.
immoral_action: Jeff decides to look at his classmate's answer and copy them down on his test sheet.

norm: It's smart to not get into meaningless arguments.
situation: Diego and his mother don't always see eye-to-eye on many topics, but her loves her dearly anyway.
intention: Diego wants to spend time with his mother.
moral_action: Diego carefully dodges attempts at political discussions by his mother and instead asks her about her life as a kid.
immoral_action: Diego gets embroiled into an endless and contentious political discussion with his mother.

norm: It's appropriate to express your ideas in a non-confrontational way.
situation: Ted is having a conversation with his landlord, and his landlord wants to know more about Ted's politics.
intention: Ted wants to tell his landlord some of his political views.
moral_action: Ted tells his landlord that he just thinks everyone should have healthcare.
immoral_action: Ted tells his landlord that landlords shouldn't exist and that the money they make is not earned.

norm: It's good to tell the truth instead of keeping secrets.
situation: James knew that his boss at McDonald's sometimes served hamburgers well past their expiration date.
intention: James wants to avoid unemployment.
moral_action: James applies for new jobs until he finds a better position, then calls the local food safety inspector.
immoral_action: James doesn't mention the expired meat to anyone, so he can keep his job.

norm: It's good to give a spouse a special holiday gift.
situation: Robert and his spouse Sally recently moved in with one another and their first Christmas together is coming up.
intention: Robert wants to give Sally something nice for Christmas.
moral_action: Robert buys Sally a silver necklace that she had been wanting for a long time.
immoral_action: Robert gives his spouse Sally a big hug and tells her he loves her.

norm: It's good to display the flag on national holidays.
situation: John is hosting a party for the Fourth of July and has invited all of his friends over to his house.
intention: John wants his friends to think he is patriotic.
moral_action: John buys a large American flag and flies it in his front yard.
immoral_action: John decorates his yard with red, white, and blue Christmas lights.

norm: It's good to visit your partner for a holiday.
situation: Fred and his partner are both off for holiday break, and they are in a long distance relationship.
intention: Fred wants to surprise his partner for the holidays.
moral_action: Fred shows up at his partner's place to celebrate the holidays.
immoral_action: Fred sends his partner an unexpected gift.

norm: It's good to celebrate the holidays with others.
situation: James choose to stay in his dorm room over the holidays because he was an orphan.
intention: James wants to enjoy his Christmas dinner.
moral_action: James goes door-to-door in his dorm to invite the few other people staying over for Christmas dinner.
immoral_action: James cooks a turkey, potatoes, vegetables and bread and eats alone in his dorm room.

norm: It's nice to give gifts for the holidays.
situation: Raymond knows his lonely friend doesn't get many gifts for Christmas and is thinking about buying him a gift.
intention: Raymond wants to consider buying his lonely friend a gift.
moral_action: Raymond thinks about what gift his lonely friend would want and buys it for him.
immoral_action: Raymond decides to skip on a gift for his lonely friend.

norm: It's nice to have a holiday party.
situation: James is a manager at his office and in charge of company events this holiday season.
intention: James wants to cut costs overall to save the company money.
moral_action: James finds ways to have the Christmas party while spending less money than usual.
immoral_action: James decides to cancel the annual Christmas party to save money on it.

norm: It's good to make plans for the holidays.
situation: Sue usually spends Christmas alone at home because she doesn't really celebrate.
intention: Sue wants to do something different for Christmas this year.
moral_action: Sue invites her friends over to have Christmas dinner with her.
immoral_action: Sue goes to see a movie by herself on Christmas when they release a lot of new movies.

norm: It's good to help people out during the holidays.
situation: Darren makes good money at his job, but his neighbor Glen has no money to celebrate Christmas with his son.
intention: Darren wants to spend some money.
moral_action: Darren gives two hundred dollars to Glen, so he can buy a Christmas tree and presents for his son.
immoral_action: Darren buys himself a new high-definition TV to watch football games on.

norm: It's nice to share your birthday.
situation: Jill has a twin sister and her mom is planning their birthday party.
intention: Jill wants to feel special at her birthday party.
moral_action: Jill suggests that they make two birthday cakes so their friends can sing to each of them individually.
immoral_action: Jill tells her mom she doesn't want to have to share a birthday party with her sister.

norm: It's good to give someone a thoughtful birthday gift.
situation: Sue is meeting her friend out for her birthday.
intention: Sue wants to surprise her friend with a gift.
moral_action: Sue buys a gift that has a lot of personal meaning to her friend.
immoral_action: Sue buys a thoughtless gift with no personal meaning.

norm: It's good to surprise people for their birthdays
situation: Bill is going to the birthday party of his friend, Jack, but he is too busy recently to shop for birthday gift.
intention: Bill wants to celebrate Jack's birthday.
moral_action: Bill asks his mother to make him a dog-like  costume, and he wears it to Jack's birthday.
immoral_action: Bill spends 15 minutes shopping and buys a regular T-shirt for Jack as a birthday gift.

norm: It's good to get people nice things for their birthday.
situation: Bob was on the way to a birthday party for one of his close friends.
intention: Bob wanted to get his friend a birthday gift.
moral_action: Bob stopped at Best Buy and bought his friend some nice bluetooth headphones.
immoral_action: Bob stopped at the grocery store and got his friend a card.

norm: It is fun to go somewhere for a birthday.
situation: Joanna walks home from work on her birthday with plenty of energy.
intention: Joanna wants to do something fun.
moral_action: Joanna rents a bar for a huge birthday party inviting all of her friends.
immoral_action: Joanna spends the evening drinking wine while watching her favorite movie.

norm: It's good to make plans for someone's birthday.
situation: Rodrigo's father's birthday is coming up.
intention: Rodrigo wants to celebrate his fathers birthday with him.
moral_action: Rodrigo decides to make reservations for dinner and take his father out to eat.
immoral_action: Rodrigo puts off making plans until the day of, and tries to find a place to eat at the last minute.

norm: It's nice to throw a party for your friend's birthday.
situation: Gina's best friend's birthday is coming up soon and people have suggested Gina organize a birthday party at her own house for her friend.
intention: Gina wants her house to be a private place, a refuge to get away from it all.
moral_action: Gina decides to throw a big party at a fancy restaurant for her best friend's birthday.
immoral_action: Gina decides not to organize a party for her friend because she doesn't want people in her house.

norm: It's good to wish someone a happy birthday.
situation: Laura sees her friend Jessica walking towards her.
intention: Laura wants to greet her friend.
moral_action: Laura tells Jessica happy birthday.
immoral_action: Laura waves at Jessica and says hi.

norm: It's always nice to surprise someone for their birthday.
situation: Sergio is waiting at his home for a friend who he invited over because it was their birthday.
intention: Sergio wants to celebrate his friend's birthday.
moral_action: Sergio reveals to his friend an elaborate set of events and activities the pair will be doing to celebrate the birthday.
immoral_action: Sergio entertains is friend exactly as if it were any other day and while they have fun, it is nothing out of the ordinary.

norm: It's nice to throw a birthday party.
situation: Linda was deciding what to do for her friend Luke's birthday.
intention: Linda wants to impress Luke.
moral_action: Linda throws Luke a birthday party and invites all of his friends.
immoral_action: Linda gets Luke a nice present for his birthday and wraps it up.

norm: It's good to celebrate someone's cake day.
situation: Josh is scrolling through his facebook and gets a notification that it's his friends birthday.
intention: Josh wants to wish his friend a happy birthday.
moral_action: Josh plans a small gather of friends to do something for his friend's birthday.
immoral_action: Josh posts a happy birthday message onto his friends facebook timeline.

norm: It's good to get some balloons for a birthday celebration.
situation: Kevin wants to celebrate his birthday with his friends.
intention: Kevin wants to get a birthday party.
moral_action: Kevin is sure to get plenty of balloons for his birthday party.
immoral_action: Kevin gets a bunch pf party supplies, but he forgets the balloons.

norm: It's nice to give birthday presents.
situation: It's Danny's sister's birthday today, and she calls Danny up and asks him to come see her at her place.
intention: Danny wants to go visit his sister.
moral_action: Danny goes shopping for a nice little present for his sister's birthday then goes over to her place with it.
immoral_action: Danny goes over to his sister's house empty-handed even though he knows it's her birthday.

norm: It's good to celebrate birthdays with family.
situation: After staying up for forty-eight hours for work, Stanley collapses onto the bed staring at the wall, and it's his birthday.
intention: Stanley wants to relax.
moral_action: Stanley invites his family over to his house to watch movies and drink herbal tea with him.
immoral_action: Stanley decides to take a nice long nap to refresh his tired mind.

norm: It is rude to distract others from learning in school.
situation: Dan is exited to tell a joke he just made to his friends.
intention: Dan wants to make everyone laugh.
moral_action: Dan wait's until recess, and when everyone hears it they burst into laughter.
immoral_action: Dan stands up in class and tells his quip to the room and everyone loved it.

norm: It's bad to come to class unprepared.
situation: Hank wakes up 10 minutes before class and realizes that he has to go.
intention: Hank wants to go to class.
moral_action: Hank takes some extra time to pack his bag and arrives to class a bit late.
immoral_action: Hank leaves quickly and shows up to class as fast as possible.

norm: Helping a person cheat on school work is wrong.
situation: Beth is hanging out with her friend Matt who asks her for help on a math test review assignment they have to complete for homework.
intention: Beth wants to help Matt with the homework.
moral_action: Beth spends time going over each test review question and letting Matt work out the answers himself.
immoral_action: Beth fills in the homework for Matt without teaching him what any of it means.

norm: Looking at another student's test is bad.
situation: Mary did not study her Math test hard enough, and she takes the test today.
intention: Mary wants to finish the test.
moral_action: Mary works over the test carefully and diligently.
immoral_action: Mary peeks at the answers of the girl sitting next to her.

norm: It's bad to fool around when you're in class.
situation: Alice is in math class with her best friend Roger.
intention: Alice wants to tell Roger a joke she just thought of.
moral_action: Alice writes the joke down, so she doesn't forget it and tells Roger after class.
immoral_action: Alice passes notes with Roger in class to tell him the joke.

norm: It's bad to not be honest about your grades.
situation: Lenny gets his report card which is all B's and comes home when his mom asks him how he did in school this semester.
intention: Lenny wants to answer his mom's question.
moral_action: Lenny tells his mom that he got all B's as it said on the report card.
immoral_action: Lenny tells his mom that he got one B but otherwise he got straight A's.

norm: It is bad to get into fights at school.
situation: Brian and Cole are having a disagreement at school.
intention: Brian wants to settle their disagreement.
moral_action: Brian listens to Cole's perspective, then offers his own.
immoral_action: Brian insults Cole's intelligence, then punches him.

norm: It's bad to help someone cheat on their schoolwork.
situation: Kelly is a student in high school that gets good grades.
intention: Kelly wants to help another student get better grades.
moral_action: Kelly tutors the student after school.
immoral_action: Kelly allows the student to copy off them.

norm: It is bad to have teacher student relationships.
situation: Jenny is a teacher who is quite attractive and one day a student, Billy asks her to sleep with him.
intention: Jenny wants to respond to Billy's request.
moral_action: Jenny tells Billy that it's not happening because of the age difference and the fact that she's his teacher.
immoral_action: Jenny tells Billy that she would love that and that they should meet at her place tonight.

norm: It's bad to copy off of someone else's schoolwork.
situation: Trent is on the verge of failing math class, and he just forgot to do a homework assignment.
intention: Trent wants to save his grade.
moral_action: Trent talks to his math teacher about his struggles with the class, and they put together a study plan.
immoral_action: Trent asks a friend to copy his homework, so he can turn something in.

norm: It's bad to cheat on exams.
situation: Joan has to take an important test that makes up half of her grade.
intention: Joan wants to get an A on the test.
moral_action: Joan dedicates an entire week to study for the test.
immoral_action: Joan hides notes in her sleeve to use on the test.

norm: It is bad to be disruptive in class
situation: Jim is bored in his literature class and sits next to his friend Johnathan.
intention: Jim wants to entertain himself.
moral_action: Jim decides to start doodling in his notebook to pass the time.
immoral_action: Jim starts to shoot spitballs at Jonhathan , who tells him loudly to cut it out.

norm: It's bad to cheat to get through school.
situation: Janice is trying to study for a very hard exam later in the week.
intention: Janice wants to pass the exam.
moral_action: Janice studies very hard for the exam and gets a tutor to help her.
immoral_action: Janice decides to write down the answers on a sheet that she surreptitiously checks during the exam.

norm: It's bad for a teacher to be a predator.
situation: Merle is a high school English teacher, and finds himself attracted to one of his teenage students.
intention: Merle wants to do something about his attraction.
moral_action: Merle tamps down on his attraction and acts professionally toward the student like any other.
immoral_action: Merle grooms the student and eventually tries to get her alone with him.

norm: It's bad to act on your feelings for a teacher.
situation: Marvin is in love with Mrs. Erickson, his teacher, who assigns him to write a romantic poem for class.
intention: Marvin wants to write the love poem assigned to him.
moral_action: Marvin writes a romantic poem about a fictional female and hands it in.
immoral_action: Marvin writes a romantic poem dedicated to Mrs. Erickson and hands it in.

norm: It's bad to repeat a grade multiple times.
situation: Luna is struggling in school and has already repeated her junior year because of bad grades.
intention: Luna wants to catch up in school.
moral_action: Luna decides to sign up for summer school during her summer break.
immoral_action: Luna decides to repeat the grade another time in order to learn the material.

norm: It is bad to get kicked out of class
situation: Stewart was sitting in class when he realizes that he needs to go to the restroom.
intention: Stewart wants to get out of the classroom.
moral_action: Stewart asks the teacher if he can be excused to go to the restroom.
immoral_action: Stewart loudly announces to the teacher and the rest of the class that he is leaving to go take a piss.

norm: It's bad to cheat on a school exam.
situation: Michael needs to get an A on his history exam, or he'll fail the class.
intention: Michael wants to get an A on the exam.
moral_action: Michael stays up all night to study for the exam.
immoral_action: Michael hides note cards in his sleeve to aid him during the exam.

norm: It is rude to disturb someone who is studying.
situation: Dave's brother Kyle is in his bedroom studying when Dave finds out a band he likes is coming to town.
intention: Dave wants to tell someone about his excitement for the upcoming concert.
moral_action: Dave calls up one of his friends on the phone and tells him all about his excitement for the show.
immoral_action: Dave runs into Kyle's room and tells him all about the concert and how he can't wait to go.

norm: It's rude to interuppt teachers while in class.
situation: Missy is listening to her instructor give a history lesson on World War 2.
intention: Missy wants to ask a lot of questions.
moral_action: Missy asks the instructor her questions after class.
immoral_action: Missy asks the instructor her questions one after the other.

norm: It's rude to single someone out in class.
situation: Roy has a class full of students who are bad at math.
intention: Roy wants to point out their errors.
moral_action: Roy points out a common error made by the class as a whole.
immoral_action: Roy points out a specific error made by only one student.

norm: It's wrong to talk in class and disrupt the class.
situation: Dean has just received some excited and good news while he's sitting next to his friend in class.
intention: Dean wants to share the news with his friend.
moral_action: Dean waits until after class is over to share the news with his friend.
immoral_action: Dean tells his friend what happened while in the middle of class.

norm: It's rude to disturb others in the classroom.
situation: Cary is confused about something in his texbook.
intention: Cary wants help from his teacher.
moral_action: Cary puts his hand up and waits until the teacher is free.
immoral_action: Cary sees the teacher helping another student so starts yelling for her to come help him instead.

norm: It's inconsiderate to act out in your teacher's classroom.
situation: Tim has moved to a new school and is sitting in math class with the other students and their teacher.
intention: Tim wants to show his classmates that he is funny.
moral_action: Tim waits till lunch time then entertains his classmates with jokes and silly dances.
immoral_action: Tim starts goofing around in class even getting up and doing a silly dance.

norm: It is inconsiderate to your teacher to distract the class.
situation: Tara understands the class materials and is feeling bored in class.
intention: Tara wants to do something to pass the time in class.
moral_action: Tara draws cartoon characters in her notebook.
immoral_action: Tara makes paper airplanes and throw them at other students.

norm: It's hurtful to others to be an alcoholic.
situation: Pete is an alcoholic at a work party and feels his mouth is dry.
intention: Pete wants something to drink.
moral_action: Pete orders a water.
immoral_action: Pete orders a glass of wine.

norm: It's bad to assume you'll have an anxiety attack.
situation: Kathryn's friends just invited her to go to a skydiving class with them, something she is secretly scared of doing.
intention: Kathryn wants to keep her fears secret.
moral_action: Kathryn decides she can manage skydiving even though it's scary to her.
immoral_action: Kathryn assumes she will have a complete meltdown if she goes skydiving and tells her friends she already has something else planned.

norm: It's dangerous to lie about medical conditions
situation: Perry just got dumped by his long time girlfriend and is extremely depressed over it.
intention: Perry wants to get something to numb the pain.
moral_action: Perry parties with his friends, and they drink some alcohol together.
immoral_action: Perry tells his doctor that he has chronic back issues in order to get a prescription for pain medicine.

norm: It's dangerous to share prescription medication with anyone else.
situation: Frank has a perception medicine for migraines and his wife has a headache.
intention: Frank wants to decide if it's okay to share the medicine.
moral_action: Frank tells his wife that it's a prescription and thus sharing it could be dangerous.
immoral_action: Frank shares the medicine with his wife to try and help her.

norm: It's hurtful to reject someone due to a mental illness.
situation: Josh lives in an apartment with his friend Frank who recently was diagnosed with schizophrenia, and it's time to renew their lease.
intention: Josh wants to decide whether to continue living in the apartment.
moral_action: Josh decides to renew the lease with Frank and stay for another year.
immoral_action: Josh decides he'd feel safer moving out and finding an apartment for just himself.

norm: You shouldn't comment on how messy someone's car is.
situation: Joe is getting a ride from his friend, who's car is messy.
intention: Joe wants to ride in a clean car.
moral_action: Joe offers to help his friend clean his car quickly before they leave.
immoral_action: Joe calls his friend a pig and demands he clean his car before he will get in.

norm: It's wrong not to care about someone's car accident.
situation: Bobby is driving down the highway and sees a car wreck on the side of the road.
intention: Bobby wants to make it past the car wreck safely.
moral_action: Bobby pulls over to call 911 for the person in the wreck and drives home safely after paramedics arrive.
immoral_action: Bobby sees the car wreck on the side of the road and drives right past it safely and heads home.

norm: You shouldn't make jokes about hurricane devastation.
situation: Dan is in a barber shop and hurricane Irene is ravaging the East Coast of the United States that day.
intention: Dan wants to talk about hurricane Irene.
moral_action: Dan expresses verbal grief over the loss of lives in hurricane Irene.
immoral_action: Dan jokes about the number of deaths in hurricane Irene to the patrons.

norm: You shouldn't believe in fortune telling and palm reading.
situation: Shelly is walking along the boardwalk and sees a psychic's store, so she checks it out.
intention: Shelly wants to get her palm read.
moral_action: Shelly does not allow herself to be convinced by the result of the palm reading.
immoral_action: Shelly is convinced by what the psychic tells her, and she acts on it.

norm: You shouldn't farm karma on reddit.
situation: Jones sees that posting something gives him one karma by default.
intention: Jones wants to earn karma on reddit.
moral_action: Jones decides to just have fun with his own posts on the site and try to earn karma that way.
immoral_action: Jones programs his computer to post a million times on different places on reddit.

norm: You shouldn't referee a sports match you're betting on.
situation: Dean is a soccer referee and has been struggling financially lately.
intention: Dean wants to make more money to help with his finances.
moral_action: Dean asks his boss if he can referee more games in the near future.
immoral_action: Dean places a large bet on the outcome of the game he will referee and then tries to influence the outcome of the game.

norm: You shouldn't send people glitter bombs.
situation: A local politician has been pushing a new ordinance that Kelsey is strongly against.
intention: Kelsey wants to oppose the politician's actions.
moral_action: Kelsey makes an appointment to talk to the politician, so she can explain her views and ask him to reconsider.
immoral_action: Kelsey has a glitter bomb anonymously sent to the politician's office with a note expressing her opposition to the ordinance.

norm: It is creepy to send long emotional texts to people.
situation: John receives a text from Sandy about a work lunch that's being planned for tomorrow afternoon.
intention: John wants to respond to the text.
moral_action: John replies with a quick message telling Sandy that he thinks the lunch would be productive, and he'll be there.
immoral_action: John replies with a ten paragraph text to Sandy explaining that he's loved her for years and thinks they're meant to be together.

norm: It's rude to break up with someone over text.
situation: Bill and his girlfriend Jane have arguing intensely for months.
intention: Bill wants to end the relationship with Jane.
moral_action: Bill meets with Jane and tells her that he wants to break up.
immoral_action: Bill sends a text to Jane that he wants to break up.

norm: It's rude to ignore your partner's texts.
situation: Nick is trying to plan what days to ask off from work to go on vacation.
intention: Nick wants to get his wife's opinion on their vacation dates.
moral_action: Nick texts back and forth with his wife until they settle on the perfect date for both of them.
immoral_action: Nick sees his wife's reply to his text message, but he doesn't open and read it.

norm: It's rude to start texting when holding a conversation.
situation: John is on a date with a girl, and he gets a text from a friend.
intention: John wants to answer his friend to make sure everything is ok.
moral_action: John waits and excuses himself to the bathroom later and checks his phone then.
immoral_action: John takes out his phone and texts his friend.

norm: It is rude to end a serious relationship over text
situation: Robert and his girlfriend Sally are experiencing a lot of conflicts in their relationship lately.
intention: Robert wants to end the relationship with Sally.
moral_action: Robert breaks up with Sally face to face the next time they see each other.
immoral_action: Robert breaks up with Sally by sending her a text saying the relationship is over.

norm: It's rude to use your phone while having a conversation.
situation: Mark is talking and eating with his mom at a restaurant when his phone dings.
intention: Mark wants to check his email.
moral_action: Mark tells his mom he needs to use the bathroom and checks his phone email there.
immoral_action: Mark pulls out his phone as his mom is talking and checks his email.

norm: It's rude to ignore someone's phone call.
situation: Lee is in a bad mood because of an incident at work and his friend, who he knows needs some advice, is calling.
intention: Lee wants to be left alone for the time being.
moral_action: Lee picks up the phone to tell his friend he can't talk now and to wait until he calls back later.
immoral_action: Lee just lets it ring and presses the volume button to silence the ringtone.

norm: It's invasive to check someone else's texts.
situation: Yuri watches her younger Daisuke burst into tears as he lays his phone down onto the table.
intention: Yuri wants to know why her brother is crying.
moral_action: After hugging him, Yuri asks Daisuke if he's okay.
immoral_action: Yuri searches through his phone reading her brother's texts and emails.

norm: It's impolite to break up with someone with a text.
situation: Jake is planning on breaking up with Ana, but he doesn't know how he should do it.
intention: Jake wants to break up with Ana.
moral_action: Jake tells Ana he's going to pick her up and breaks up with her in person.
immoral_action: Jake texts Ana and tells her he doesn't want to be with her anymore.

norm: It's rude to comment on someone's weight.
situation: Oscar and Peter are out having drinks, and they see a large man enter the bar.
intention: Oscar wants to make Peter laugh.
moral_action: Oscar tells Peter a joke he heard the other day.
immoral_action: Oscar makes fun of the fat man who entered bar for his weight.

norm: It is rude to criticize people due to their weight
situation: Sara has a friend who put on tons of extra weight which is clearly having a dangerous unhealthy effect.
intention: Sara wants to help her friend lose weight.
moral_action: Sara convinces her friend to go hiking with her.
immoral_action: Sara constantly comments on her friend's weight and nags her about it.

norm: It's wrong to judge people by how much they weigh.
situation: Andrea has a best friend, Christina, who is self-conscious about her weight.
intention: Andrea wants to go swimming with Christina.
moral_action: Andrea tells Christina that she looks great no matter what she wears.
immoral_action: Andrea tells Christina that two-piece bikinis don't suit her body type.

norm: It's wrong to criticize someone's body size.
situation: Daisy is overweight.
intention: Leona wants to encourage Daisy to lose weight.
moral_action: Leona expresses concerns about Daisy's health and invites her to the gym.
immoral_action: Leona tells Daisy she is too fat to ever be attractive and that she needs to lose weight if she wants to be pretty.

norm: It's rude to view women based on their weight.
situation: Sam is a long time single person longing for an intimate connection who just made a profile on a dating app.
intention: Sam wants to find a romantic partner.
moral_action: Sam spends time getting to know people regardless of their appearance.
immoral_action: Sam brushes off the women who are overweight and focuses on those who are in shape.

norm: It's rude to tell someone they need to lose weight.
situation: Andy hasn't seen his sister who has gained weight in a while.
intention: Andy wants to tell his sister how she looks.
moral_action: Andy tells his sister that he noticed she had her hair done.
immoral_action: Andy tells his sister that she is fatter than the last time he saw her.

norm: It's wrong to look down on obese people.
situation: Howard is at a restaurant and sees that his server is quite fat.
intention: Howard wants to order food.
moral_action: Howard ignores the server's weight and orders his food and smiles.
immoral_action: Howard starts ordering his food and then makes a crack about the server's weight.

norm: It's rude to judge people based on their size
situation: Lola, who is single, has met two nice guys recently, one is an athlete, the other one a slightly plump nerd.
intention: Lola wants a nice, loving boyfriend.
moral_action: Lola decides to look past appearances, spends more time with the plump nerd and eventually starts dating him.
immoral_action: Lola decides there is something wrong with the plump nerd, based on his appearance and starts dating the athlete.

norm: It's wrong to put someone down for their weight.
situation: Felton is at a party with his overweight friend Tracy.
intention: Felton wants to entertain people.
moral_action: Felton asks Tracy to help him act out a scene from their favorite movie.
immoral_action: Felton makes a joke comparing Tracy to a whale.

norm: It's rude to be critical of family members' weight.
situation: Gemma notices that her daughter is starting to gain an excessive amount of weight.
intention: Gemma wants to address her daughter's weight.
moral_action: Gemma cooks healthy lunches and dinners for her daughter to eat.
immoral_action: Gemma tells her daughter that she's an embarrassment because of her weight.

norm: It's wrong to discriminate against people because of their weight.
situation: Jamie isn't sure if she wants her friend Sandra in her wedding party because she thinks Sandra is too heavy to look good in a bridesmaid dress.
intention: Jaime wants her wedding day to be perfect.
moral_action: Jamie asks Sandra to be in the wedding party because having all of her friends at the wedding is more important than the aesthetics of the wedding photos.
immoral_action: Jamie decides that Sandra is too heavy to be in the wedding and doesn't send her an invitation.

norm: It's rude to judge people for their weight.
situation: Jessica is at a new Summer camp where she doesn't know anyone.
intention: Jessica wants to make new friends at camp.
moral_action: Jessica introduces herself to every girl at camp, regardless of what they look like.
immoral_action: During lunch, Jessica walks over to a table of girls and introduces herself to everyone except one larger girl.

norm: It's rude to ask people how much they weigh.
situation: Bruce has not been meeting any new women lately, so he decided to try online dating.
intention: Bruce wants to find out more about the women before he goes on a date.
moral_action: Bruce talks to the women about their hobbies, favorite foods and long term goals.
immoral_action: Bruce asks the women how tall they are and much they weigh.

norm: It's rude to insult someone based on their size.
situation: Tom is very skinny, and his friend, Devin, is very big compared to him.
intention: Tom wants to talk to Devin about their weight.
moral_action: Tom tells Devin that he wishes he were as big as Devin.
immoral_action: Tom tells Devin that he has to lose weight if he wants to keep hanging out with him.

norm: It's wrong to reject people based on their weight.
situation: Paul has dinner with his friend Angie, and she expresses romantic feelings for him, and he feels the same way but finds her weight to be a problem.
intention: Paul needs to decide if he wants to reciprocate and tell Angie that he has romantic feelings for her too.
moral_action: Paul tells Angie that spending time with her is one of his favorite things, and he isn't sure about romance, but would be willing to explore the idea with her.
immoral_action: Paul tells Angie that he doesnt have time right now to pursue a new, romantic relationship with her, but the truth is that he finds her extra weight unattractive.

norm: It is rude to point out their weight problem constantly.
situation: Randy watches his overweight friend Marshall eats a big tub of ice cream.
intention: Randy wants Marshall to lose weight.
moral_action: Randy suggests that they go jogging after Marshall eats his ice cream.
immoral_action: Randy reminds Marshall about his appearance multiple times.

norm: It is rude to be concerned with someone else's weight.
situation: Jillian and her friend Cassidy have been invited to a pool party, but Jillian is worried that people will judge them based on Cassidy's weight.
intention: Jillian wants to avoid being embarrassed by Cassidy's weight.
moral_action: Jillian lets go of her worries about Cassidy's weight.
immoral_action: Jillian tells Cassidy not to attend the pool party, so she doesn't have to be seen with her.

norm: It's rude to make fun of someone's weight.
situation: Alexis is hosting a cookout when she notices her friend Chrissy eating something that breaks the rules of the diet she's been on.
intention: Alexis wants to talk to Chrissy about her diet.
moral_action: Alexis asks Chrissy if she can make her something that would adhere to her diet.
immoral_action: Alexis tells Chrissy that she wouldn't be so fat if she was able to stick to a diet.

norm: It's rude to make someone feel insecure about their weight.
situation: Bella is spending time with her friend who has been depressed lately.
intention: Bella wants to get her friend out of her funk.
moral_action: Bella has a nice long discussion with her friend and encourages her to talk through her current problems while listening.
immoral_action: Bella tries to motivate her friend by pointing out that she has put on weight from being so depressed and doesnt look especially good.

norm: It's rude to judge others only by their physical appearance.
situation: Adam is at the gym when an obese woman comes and gets on the treadmill beside him.
intention: Adam wants to talk to the woman beside him.
moral_action: Adam strikes up a conversation with the woman and offers to help her with the treadmill controls.
immoral_action: Adam tells the woman it's not easy to stop being lazy and try to lose weight.

norm: It is hurtful to call someone overweight.
situation: Josh's coworker Steve is a fat guy who loves to eat more than his fair share of the office's donuts every day.
intention: Josh wants to tell Steve to stop eating so many donuts.
moral_action: Josh suggests to Steve that it would be fairer to his colleagues is Steve only had a couple donuts every day.
immoral_action: Josh tells Steve he needs to stop eating so many donuts because he's morbidly obese.

norm: It's mean to make fun of someone for being overweight.
situation: Tom notices that his friend has put on a seriously unhealthy amount of weight.
intention: Tom wants to discourage unhealthy eating habits.
moral_action: Tom offers to go to the gym with his friend.
immoral_action: Tom mocks his friend for becoming so overweight.

norm: It's rude to treat someone badly because they are overweight.
situation: Tony's sitting with his daughter whom is overweight, she asks him if she can have some chips.
intention: Tony wants his daughter to achieve a healthy weight.
moral_action: Tony gently tells his daughter he is worried about her weight, but respects her freedom and offers her some chips.
immoral_action: Tony tells his daughter that she is too fat and will get even uglier if she keeps eating, so she can't have any chips.

norm: It's rude to stare at overweight people.
situation: Jackie is standing behind an obese man in the line at a fast food restaurant.
intention: Jackie wants to appear to be a kind person.
moral_action: Jackie pays no attention to the man and looks at the menu while he orders.
immoral_action: Jackie pretends to not be looking but secretly stares at the man as he orders.

norm: It's rude to tell your significant other they are overweight.
situation: After several years of dating, Ron notices that his girlfriend Melissa has been gaining weight.
intention: Ron wants Melissa to look more attractive.
moral_action: Ron starts going for walks with Melissa every day after dinner to get some exercise.
immoral_action: Ron berates Melissa for gaining weight and tells her she's becoming a fat ugly cow.

norm: It is offensive to make fun of someones weight.
situation: Tanya notices her daughter has been gaining way too much weight lately.
intention: Tanya wants to tell her daughter to lose weight.
moral_action: Tanya tells her daughter she is too heavy very directly, and offers to help with a diet.
immoral_action: Tanya makes fun of her daughter's weight in hopes of setting her straight.

norm: It's rude to tell someone they are overweight.
situation: Jane is attending a high school reunion and is surprised to see how much weight the former prom queen has gained.
intention: Jane wants to find a topic to discuss with the former prom queen.
moral_action: Jane decides to catch up on their respective families and careers.
immoral_action: Jane decides to talk about effective ways that the other woman can use to lose weight.

norm: It's rude to assume Hawaiians are overweight.
situation: Sam is the new kid in class from Hawaii, and Pat wants to learn more about him.
intention: Pat wants to ask Sam a question.
moral_action: Pat asks Sam what he misses the most about Hawaii.
immoral_action: Pat asks Sam if his parents weigh a lot since he thinks most Hawaiians do.

norm: It is mean to discriminate against people with bipolar disorder.
situation: John is playing soccer with some friends, when Frank who is bipolar asks if he can join in and play.
intention: John wants to respond to Frank's question.
moral_action: John tells Frank that he would be happy to have another player join and tells him to come into the game.
immoral_action: "John tells Frank that no, he cannot play as he's known to be ""mental"" and he doesn't like crazy people."

norm: It is mean to spread hurtful rumors.
situation: Jane is at a party and overhears some gossip.
intention: Jane wants to fit in.
moral_action: Jane interrupts and steers the conversation in a different direction.
immoral_action: Jane joins in on the gossip and the person they are talking about overhears.

norm: It's mean to scare people for fun.
situation: John is spending time with his children and family.
intention: John wants to have fun with his son.
moral_action: John sets up a game for his son to play with him that is fun for both.
immoral_action: John hides from his son only to burst out and take him by suprise.

norm: It is mean to throw things at people
situation: Ethan and his friends are riding on the bus going home from school.
intention: Ethan wants to get a friend's attention who is sitting far away from him.
moral_action: Ethan sends his friend a text message telling them to turn around, so they can talk.
immoral_action: Ethan throws a pencil at his friend and it ends up sticking in his friend's arm.

norm: It's mean to make rude comments to little league players.
situation: Greg is at his son's little league game, and a player on the other team keeps talking trash.
intention: Greg wants to say something to the kid talking trash.
moral_action: Greg tells the kid that he's really good and that he respects his confidence.
immoral_action: Greg tells the kid that he would kick his butt if he were the same age as him.

norm: It's mean to swear at people in public.
situation: John is walking down the street when a man bumps into him.
intention: John wants to let the man know he doesn't like being bumped by them.
moral_action: John firmly but politely tells the man that it's not okay to bump into people in the street.
immoral_action: John uses strong language against the man calling him bad words for bumping into him.

norm: It's mean to be a bully.
situation: James is in the schoolyard with the other kids at recess time, and they're all playing.
intention: James wants to draw attention to himself.
moral_action: James screams loudly for everyone to look at him and does a cartwheel to impress them.
immoral_action: James screams loudly that one of the kids, Billy is a pansy and calls him names in front of everyone.

norm: It's mean to yell at someone.
situation: Harry is waiting for a cashier to bring him the food he ordered while his taxi waits outside.
intention: Harry wants to let the cashier know that he is in a rush.
