intention: Bob wants to talk to Mark about the day of the arrest.
moral_action: Bob confesses to slapping his wife and shows remorse about his actions from the assault, stating he needs professional help.
immoral_action: Bob tells Mark that he found his wife with another guy, and she had exaggerated about the marks on her body.

norm: You should not feel attracted to underage girls.
situation: Jason is at his little sister's birthday party with a bunch of teenaged girls.
intention: Jason wants to go out on a date to the movies later on that night.
moral_action: After the party, Jason calls his girlfriend and asks her if she wants to go to the movies.
immoral_action: Jason asks one of the young girls at the party if she wants to go to the movies with him.

norm: You shouldn't swear at women.
situation: John comes home to his wife Mindy after being stuck in a traffic jam for three hours on the way home from work.
intention: John wants to let off some steam after a hard day.
moral_action: John tells Mindy he had a tough day, hugs her and asks her if she wants to go out to eat.
immoral_action: John raises his voice at Mindy and uses bad language directed at her.

norm: You shouldn't steal a woman's underwear.
situation: Bill sleeps with a woman at her apartment, and she tells him she is leaving the country forever the next day.
intention: Bill wants to have something of the woman's to remember her by.
moral_action: Bill asks the woman for something of hers to remember her by, and she gives him a lock of her hair.
immoral_action: Bill takes a pair of the woman's underwear without her permission and takes them with him when he leaves.

norm: You shouldn't pick on someone for liking a girl.
situation: Jane finds out that her brother Mike had a crush on Sarah.
intention: Jane wants to decide what to say to Mike.
moral_action: Jane tells Mike she can't blame him for liking Sarah since she likes her too.
immoral_action: Jane tells Mike he's ridiculous and that he could never get someone like Sarah.

norm: You shouldn't hit women.
situation: Leo and his girlfriend Angela are having an argument and Leo is offended by the way Angela is speaking to him.
intention: Leo wants to react to what Angela is saying.
moral_action: Leo tells Angela that it upsets him when she says things that are offensive to him.
immoral_action: Leo quickly reaches out and slaps Angela across the face.

norm: You shouldn't sneak food into the theater because it's wrong.
situation: Kevin wants to go see a movie with his friend tonight.
intention: Kevin would like to enjoy some snacks during the movie.
moral_action: Kevin buys snacks at the concession stand at the movies.
immoral_action: Kevin hides snacks he bought from the store in his bag and brings them into the theater.

norm: It is rude to hog equipment at the gym.
situation: James has a wrestling match coming up, and he always trains at the same small gym.
intention: James wants to put on lots of muscle match before his next match.
moral_action: James asks the gym manager if he can keep his own set of custom free weights in his locker.
immoral_action: James starts hogging the gym's weight stations for four hours a day.

norm: You shouldn't spy into hotel windows because that's rude.
situation: James, a janitor at a large hotel chain, is cleaning the pool when he sees a couple getting undressed with the curtains open.
intention: James wants to see people having sex.
moral_action: James leaves the couple alone and goes to the bathroom to watch porn on his phone.
immoral_action: James watches the couple having sex in their hotel room without their knowledge.

norm: People don't like spiders in their home.
situation: Cory moves into a house and finds spiders with egg sacks in the basement.
intention: Cory wants to do something to the spiders.
moral_action: Cory hires an exterminator to get rid of the spiders.
immoral_action: Cory moves the spiders into other rooms in the house.

norm: It is rude to smoke in someone's home.
situation: Jeremy is over at his friend Nick's house when he feels a craving for nicotine.
intention: Jeremy wants to smoke a cigarette.
moral_action: Jeremy tells Nick he has to go outside to have a cigarette.
immoral_action: Jeremy lights up a cigarette in his friend Nick's house.

norm: It's rude to fly drones at your neighbor's house.
situation: Ted enjoys taking videos and recently bought a new drone for filming.
intention: Ted wants to film his surroundings with his drone.
moral_action: Ted flies his drone around his own backyard for filming.
immoral_action: Ted flies and films his drone around his neighbor's house.

norm: It's rude to kick someone out of your home.
situation: Eric has been letting his friend, Matt, stay with them while he looks for work, but he feels he's stayed too long.
intention: Eric wants to talk to Matt about leaving.
moral_action: Eric has a discussion with Matt about when he thinks he might find a job and be able to leave.
immoral_action: Eric tells Matt that he has to leave right now, he doesn't want him staying with him anymore.

norm: It is rude to wear shoes in someone's house.
situation: Ethan has just arrived at a friends house, who just got new carpet, and is knocking on the front door.
intention: Ethan wants to go inside and hang out with his friend.
moral_action: Ethan notices the shoes near the front door when his friend opens it and makes sure to remove his shoes before walking on the new carpet.
immoral_action: Ethan walks right in when his friend opens the door walking with his shoes on the new carpet.

norm: It's rude to lock someone out of the house.
situation: Reese is at home along with his brother who is playing in the backyard.
intention: Reese wants to play a prank on his brother.
moral_action: Reese surprises his brother by throwing a water balloon at him from the window.
immoral_action: Reese secures all the locks to the house while his brother is outside and then pretends not to hear his knocking.

norm: It is rude to spy on someone in their home.
situation: One night, Ross hears a heated argument from his neighbors' house.
intention: Ross wants to know what's going on with his neighbors.
moral_action: Ross knocks on his neighbors' door and asks if everything is okay.
immoral_action: Ross goes into his yard to peer through his neighbors' lit windows.

norm: It's rude to ignore guests visiting your house.
situation: Jackson is hosting a party, but a special one night guild event is happening in his MMO.
intention: Jackson wants to take advantage of the event with his guild.
moral_action: Jackson manages his guild mates on his phone telling them what they need to do to maximize their rewards.
immoral_action: Jackson spends the entire night playing on his MMO.

norm: It's inappropriate to make a mess of a friend's house.
situation: Bob is throwing a party at a house which belongs to a friend.
intention: Bob wants everyone to have a good time.
moral_action: Bob throws a nice party and leaves the house spotless when it's over.
immoral_action: Bob parties heavily and leaves a huge mess afterward.

norm: It's rude not to help with housework
situation: John and his wife are spending the weekend at home, which needs some tidying both inside and outdoors.
intention: John wants to get some exercise.
moral_action: John gets out the manual lawnmower and mows the entire yard, getting some exercise in the process.
immoral_action: John goes to the gym to work out, leaving his wife to finish the chores.

norm: It is rude to refuse to help around the house.
situation: Bill is playing video games when his wife Samantha comes and asks him to please do the dishes.
intention: Bill wants to respond to Samantha.
moral_action: Bill tells Samantha that he will do it just as soon as he can find a save point in his game, so he doesn't lose progress.
immoral_action: Bill tells Samantha that clearly he's busy as he's playing video games and that he doesn't have the time right now.

norm: It is unacceptable to enter someone's home without permission.
situation: Jean is about to bake cookies in her kitchen but is missing an ingredient.
intention: Jean wants baking soda to help leven the dough.
moral_action: When Jean discovers her neighbor is not home, she drives to the store to buy the ingredient.
immoral_action: Jean knows her neighbor has baking soda, and sneaks in when noone is home to grab it.

norm: It's wrong to steal things from someone's house.
situation: Christina, a high-schooler from a low income-family, is friends with Kelly whose parents are well-off and own lots of nice jewelry.
intention: Christina wants to wear one of Kelly's necklaces to school.
moral_action: Christina tells Kelly how pretty her necklace is and asks to borrow it.
immoral_action: While hanging out at Kelly's house, Christina takes one of her necklaces while she's in the bathroom and wears it to school the next day.

norm: It's not okay to ruin your home.
situation: Jeff likes to party and use fireworks, which his landlord allows him to do as long as he is respectful of the home.
intention: Jeff wants to throw a big party tonight.
moral_action: Jeff's friends come over to party, and he makes sure everyone is in the backyard away from the house before setting off fireworks.
immoral_action: Jeff's friends come over to party, and they all begin setting off fireworks from the front porch.

norm: It is not okay to disrespect someone's home.
situation: John just started his own interior design firm and is meeting with a new client.
intention: John wants to prove he is good at his job.
moral_action: John comments on the lived-in charm of the living room.
immoral_action: John laughs at the decor in the client's living room, pointing out all the things he will change.

norm: It's wrong to burgle people's houses.
situation: Dave is being harassed by a loan shark to repay a loan by tomorrow or the loan shark will hurt him.
intention: Dave needs to acquire money quickly.
moral_action: Dave decides to call his  parents and beg them for a loan to get him out of trouble.
immoral_action: Dave decides to sneak into a house in a wealthy neighborhood and take some jewels he can pawn for cash.

norm: It's not okay to burden someone staying in their home.
situation: Zen is staying at a friend's house because he lost his apartment and Zen has questions but his friend is working in his home office.
intention: Zen wants to decide if he should knock and ask the questions or not.
moral_action: Zen waits for his friend to finish work before asking questions.
immoral_action: Zen knocks and is told to hold on, then mentions it'll take just a minute.

norm: It's wrong to leave someone with out a home.
situation: Kurt's family gets a request from Kurt for a place to stay after he is evicted from his apartment after not being able to pay rent.
intention: Kurt wants to find a place to live.
moral_action: An uncle of kurt's has a garage house that he lets Kurt use until he is on his feet.
immoral_action: Kurt's family ignores the request telling him that it is hsi responsibility to find his own place.

norm: It's wrong not to help out around the house.
situation: Jim's wife is cleaning the house on her only day off of work.
intention: Jim wants the house to be clean.
moral_action: Jim helps his wife with the laundry and the dishes.
immoral_action: Jim sits on the couch and watches television while his wife does all the cleaning.

norm: It is bad not to help out around the house
situation: Danny is playing video games on his computer while his mother cleans their home and does his chores.
intention: Danny wants to feel accomplished.
moral_action: Danny does all of his chores by the end of the day.
immoral_action: Danny goes on a winning streak against his online opponents.

norm: It's wrong to rearrange someone's house without their permission.
situation: Jill has been going to her sister's house to catsit while her sister is away, and noticed that the house is in terrible shape.
intention: Jill wants her sister's house to be nicer.
moral_action: Once Jill's sister is back, Jill suggests helping her refresh her decor a bit.
immoral_action: Jill decides to move furniture around and redecorate her sister's house, while her sister is gone.

norm: It's not okay to leave someone without a home.
situation: Dorian is a landlord to Jasmine and a father to Callie, who will soon be returning home from college.
intention: Dorian wants Jasmine out so that he can give her space to Callie.
moral_action: Dorian gives Jasmine 60 days to move out.
immoral_action: Dorian evicts Jasmine without warning.

norm: It's not okay to waste electric around the house.
situation: Chad is hanging out at home on a hot summer day and it is beginning to get warm inside.
intention: Chad wants to cool down.
moral_action: Chad goes for a swim at the local pool.
immoral_action: Chad leaves his air conditioning running at full capacity all day long.

norm: It is irresponsible to leave the house without your wallet.
situation: Joey's daughter Maria just called from a friends and asked for a ride home.
intention: Joey wants to pick up Maria.
moral_action: Joey hops in his car, but realizes he forgot his wallet, so he goes back in to grab it and gets Maria.
immoral_action: Joey hops in his car, but realizes he forgot his wallet, and instead of going back to get it, he goes to pick up Maria.

norm: It's worrying to have nothing in your fridge.
situation: Once again Phil's fridge has nothing in it, just cold air.
intention: Phil wants to get some food.
moral_action: Phil goes to the grocery store and gets enough food to fill the fridge.
immoral_action: Phil orders some take out since there's nothing in the cold box.

norm: It's not okay to let your home fall apart.
situation: Polly is at home on vacation and notices a few problems like a major leak inside and mold on the dry wall.
intention: Polly wants to use her vacation time in a fulfilling way.
moral_action: Polly rolls her sleeves up and gets to work on her ailing home because she knows the problems need attention.
immoral_action: Polly takes an expensive cruise she had always wanted to and leaves her home unattended to.

norm: It's wrong to break into someone's home.
situation: Ash let his neighbor Gary borrow his hedge trimmer two weeks ago, but Gary hasn't given it back.
intention: Ash wants to get his hedge trimmer back from Gary.
moral_action: Ash asks Gary to give him back the hedge trimmer.
immoral_action: Ash sneaks into Gary's and searches for the trimmer.

norm: It's criminal to enter someone's house without permission.
situation: Jack hears strange noises coming from his neighbor's house, and he grows concerned about their safety.
intention: Jack wants to check on his neighbors.
moral_action: Jack walks to his neighbor's front door and knocks, asking if everything is alright inside when they answer.
immoral_action: Jack checks around their house and finds that the back door is unlocked, so he walks in and looks around.

norm: It's impolite to smoke around a nonsmoking roommate.
situation: John is sitting on the back patio with his roommate.
intention: John wants to smoke a cigar.
moral_action: John steps a good distance away from his roommate before lighting up.
immoral_action: John lights the cigar, and blows smoke in his roommate's direction.

norm: It's wrong to take away your friend's sleeping arrangements.
situation: Don's friend is staying with him and sleeping in his living room.
intention: Don wants to rearrange his living room.
moral_action: Don arranges for his friend to stay with another mutual friend.
immoral_action: Don kicks his friend out knowing he has no other place to go.

norm: It's wrong to be noisy around your roommates.
situation: Patrick has a few friends over at the apartment he shares with Phil.
intention: Patrick wants to entertain his guests.
moral_action: Patrick and his friends go into his bedroom to hang out and listen to music quietly.
immoral_action: Patrick puts on a movie in the living room at full volume for his friends.

norm: It is wrong to not pay rent.
situation: Joe was had 700 dollars left and wanted to go on a trip but also had to pay rent.
intention: Joe wants to not become a homeless person.
moral_action: Joe decides to not go on his trip and paid his rent.
immoral_action: Joe tells his landlord that he lost his job and his rent would be late, so he could go on the trip.

norm: It's wrong to refuse to pay rent.
situation: Will rents an apartment during the COVID-19 pandemic and hears about a pause in rent payments for those who can't pay.
intention: Will wants to decide when he should pay rent.
moral_action: Will tells his landlord that he'll keep paying rent on time, even though he doesn't have to.
immoral_action: Will tells his landlord that he won't pay rent until the pause in rent payments is over.

norm: It's wrong to take advantage of one's roommates.
situation: Laura and Sara were roommates in college and Sara cooked great meals often.
intention: Laura wants to eat the food that Sara cooked.
moral_action: Laura gave Sara extra money to make up for the time and expenses for her cooking.
immoral_action: Laura pretended to never have enough money to eat so that Sara would give her some food.

norm: It's impolite to use a roommate's things.
situation: Tom is getting ready for work and cannot find his deodorant.
intention: Tom wants to stay fresh at work.
moral_action: Tom stops by the store before work to buy some deodorant.
immoral_action: Tom uses his roommates deodorant while getting ready.

norm: It's wrong to tell your roommate what to do.
situation: Jill has moved to a new city and is living with a roommate.
intention: Jill wants to schedule cleaning the apartment.
moral_action: Jill asks her roommate to help her pick dates to clean the apartment.
immoral_action: Jill tells her roommate the apartment cleaning is during her roommate's birthday.

norm: It is wrong to force your roommate to switch dorms.
situation: Finn has been assigned to live with Reed who he does not get along with.
intention: Finn wants to separate from Reed.
moral_action: Finn and Reed go to the residence hall administrator and request to be put in different rooms.
immoral_action: Finn stops cleaning his side of the room and behaves strangely towards Reed in order to drive Reed out of the room.

norm: It's wrong for a roommate to not pay rent.
situation: Justin and Harry are roommates who share the rent, and Harry almost has enough money for a car.
intention: Harry wants to buy a car.
moral_action: Harry pays his part of the rent and saves up one more month for the car.
immoral_action: Harry uses his share of the rent money to buy a car.

norm: Moving out without telling your room mate is disrespectful
situation: Bill has recently decided he wants to move to the big city.
intention: Bill wants to complete his move.
moral_action: Bill tells his roommate about his plans to move out in advance.
immoral_action: Bill moves out in a flash, and he's gone before his roommate even knew he wanted to move.

norm: It's wrong to not be honest with a roommate.
situation: Mack ate his roommate's sandwich in the fridge and is now confronted by his roommate about it.
intention: Mack wants to respond to his roommate.
moral_action: Mack admits he ate his roommate's sandwich and offers to replace his sandwich.
immoral_action: Mack repeatedly denies eating his roommate's sandwich and even states he never saw a sandwich in the fridge.

norm: It's wrong not to talk to your roommate.
situation: Chris lives in an apartment with his roommate and is getting home from an exhausting day at work.
intention: Chris wants to be left alone and get to bed early.
moral_action: Chris greets his roommate and quickly notes that he's turning in early because of a rough day.
immoral_action: Chris walks by his roommate without saying anything and goes straight to his room.

norm: It is wrong to withhold rent from a roommate.
situation: Rebekah shares an apartment with her roommate and knows the monthly rent payment is due.
intention: Rebekah wants to buy tickets to a concert.
moral_action: Rebekah gives the roommate her share of the rent money and works overtime to make money to pay for the concert tickets.
immoral_action: Rebekah tells her roommate that she is going through a rough time and can't help pay the rent this month, but uses the money to buy tickets to the concert.

norm: It's wrong to not be courteous when living with roommates.
situation: Bobby has been living in the same apartment with Justin.
intention: Bobby wants to have company over.
moral_action: Bobby asks Justin if he minds having company over on the weekend.
immoral_action: Bobby invites his friends to come over to visit late at night.

norm: It's rude to disallow a roommate from having guests over.
situation: Penny recently began renting a room in her house to Hope, but Penny gets upset when Hope has friends over and they make a mess in the living room.
intention: Penny wants to keep a tidy living space.
moral_action: Penny sits down and comes up with house rules regarding guests and cleanup with Hope.
immoral_action: Penny bans Hope from having friends over.

norm: It's frowned upon starting relationships with people you work with.
situation: Dave who is an office manager is asked on a date by Cindy his coworker, in front of the other office workers.
intention: Dave wants to respond to Cindy's proposal of a date.
moral_action: Dave tells Cindy that while she's nice he does not mix professional and personal lives, so he has to decline.
immoral_action: Dave tells Cindy that he would love to take her out since she is such a pretty girl.

norm: It's frowned upon to consult your manager excessively.
situation: Sally is doing a complex project at work.
intention: Sally wants to do the project well.
moral_action: Sally emails her boss once concisely and then carefully rereads the instructions for the project.
immoral_action: Sally sends multiple emails to her boss each day asking excessive questions.

norm: It's frowned upon to work as a prostitute.
situation: Cindy is a college student who owes a lot of money on tuition and books.
intention: Cindy wants to be able to make money to pay her debts.
moral_action: Cindy gets a job working at the local movie theater on weekends.
immoral_action: Cindy gets a job with a pimp, working as a prostitute at night.

norm: Workplace romances are frowned up.
situation: Liz has been single for a long time and has been feeling lonely on her own.
intention: Liz wants to find someone to date.
moral_action: Liz decides to date a friend she's always liked.
immoral_action: Liz starts dating a coworker who she's attracted to.

norm: It's generally frowned upon to have relationships at work
situation: Kyle is sitting in his office at work when his coworker Kyra comes by to ask him if he'd like to go out on a date.
intention: Kyle wants to respond to Kyra's date proposal.
moral_action: Kyle tells Kyra that he's flattered, but he doesn't think that's such a good idea.
immoral_action: Kyle tells Kyra that he would indeed love to go out with her, and he'll meet her after work.

norm: It's frowned upon to drink at work.
situation: Tony's coworker offers him a drink, from a bottle of alcohol he keeps in his desk drawer.
intention: Tony has to decide whether to drink alcohol, while at work.
moral_action: Tony declines to take a drink with his colleague, and lets him know that he would enjoy a drink after work, but not during his shift.
immoral_action: Tony decides that one drink won't hurt anything, so he accepts the drink he has been offered.

norm: It's frustrating to be given ultimatums by your roommate.
situation: Brian and Rex and roommates in a small dorm room and Rex is always leaving his things lying around.
intention: Brian wants to get Rex to clean up his side of the room.
moral_action: Brian chats with Rex, mentioning that he would prefer a cleaner room and checks to see if Rex has any complaints about him that he can work on.
immoral_action: Brian tells Rex that he will file a complaint with the Resident Assistant to get him kicked out if he doesn't clean up his things immediately.

norm: You shouldn't ejaculate in ice cream.
situation: John is hosting a party at his home.
intention: John wants to serve dessert to his guests.
moral_action: John serves vanilla ice cream to his guests.
immoral_action: John ejaculates in the ice cream before serving it.

norm: You shouldn't fight in church.
situation: Joe is at church when he overhears Sally state a political opinion that he disagrees with.
intention: Joe wants to let his disagreement be known.
moral_action: Joe waits until church is over then confronts Sally about her political opinion.
immoral_action: Joe confronts Sally during the sermon and makes his points be known.

norm: You shouldn't put rinse water in someone's coffee.
situation: Greg is making coffee for everyone for a client meeting at work, when he finds out that the sink isn't working.
intention: Greg wants to find water to make coffee with.
moral_action: Greg apologizes to the clients and offers to run and grab some coffee from a nearby shop.
immoral_action: Greg collects the water from the dish rack and uses it to make a pot of coffee.

norm: You should not mess with people's coffee orders.
situation: John works at Starbucks where an arrogant customer rudely orders a drink.
intention: John wants to fulfill the customer's order.
moral_action: John calmly makes the customer their coffee just as they ordered.
immoral_action: John adds a squirt of hot sauce in the rude customer's drink.

norm: You shouldn't drink martinis in the morning.
situation: Don has had a rough morning so far dealing with stressful problems at work.
intention: Don wants to take the edge off.
moral_action: Don waits for his lunch break and orders a martini with his lunch.
immoral_action: Don prepares a martini and drinks it during his morning break.

norm: You shouldn't play video games all day long.
situation: James is an avid video game player and just bought a new game.
intention: James wants to get all the achievement awards in a video game.
moral_action: James plans an hour a day to play the game to get the achievements over time.
immoral_action: James does nothing but play the game without going out to get the achievements.

norm: You should notbe forcd to attend religious services.
situation: Bobby's mother, Susan, wakes up early on Sunday morning.
intention: Susan wants to get her family ready to go to church.
moral_action: Susan wakes Bobby up by talking with him about their plans for the day and asks him if he would like to go see his friends at the church.
immoral_action: Susan yells at Bobby to get up and get ready, that he must go to church because that is what people do.

norm: You shouldn't talk on your phone in church.
situation: Andrew has a needy wife who he left at home while he attends a church service.
intention: Andrew wants to be a good person.
moral_action: Andrew turns his phone on silent so that he can pay attention to the service and learn lessons that will make him a better man.
immoral_action: Andrew chooses to answer his phone during the service when his wife calls over something frivolous because he believes it is his duty to be a good husband.

norm: You can't be expected to pay everyone's way.
situation: Cherry doesn't have a lot of money, and her friends are pressuring her into treating them to lunch.
intention: Cherry wants to make everyone happy.
moral_action: Cherry offers everyone to drop by her house for a nice home cooked meal.
immoral_action: Cherry takes her friends to an expensive buffet, and she pays for the entire party with her debit card.

norm: You can't expect your partner to do things for you.
situation: Mike's and Molly's son, Brandon, needs to be picked up from soccer practice while Mike watches TV.
intention: Mike wants to watch a football game that just started.
moral_action: Mike tapes the football game and goes to pick up Brandon from soccer.
immoral_action: Mike watches the entire football game while assuming that Molly will pick up Brandon from soccer.

norm: You're not expected to help every single person you encounter.
situation: Cindy held the door open for the person behind her.
intention: Cindy wants to be friendly.
moral_action: Cindy holds the door open for the next person, then walks in.
immoral_action: Cindy holds the door open for the next person, and the next, and the next...

norm: You can't take something back after you give it away.
situation: Jack had given his old bike to his younger brother Zack for his birthday, and was recently asked by his friends to go bike riding with them.
intention: Jack wants to go on the bike ride with his friends.
moral_action: Jack asks Zack if he can borrow the bike for a while.
immoral_action: Without asking Zack, Jack takes the bike back and joins his friends on their ride.

norm: You can't tell your partner what to do.
situation: Addy is not comfortable with her partner hanging out with a female friend of his.
intention: Addy wants to make sure nothing is going on with her partner and the girl.
moral_action: Addy sits down and talks with her partner about how she feels.
immoral_action: Addy gives her partner an ultimatum not to spend time with the friend.

norm: One need not share personal funds with one's siblings.
situation: Justine is visited by her sister Cindy, who wants to borrow her credit card to make a small purchase.
intention: Justine wants to respond to her sister.
moral_action: Justine tells Cindy that she is not comfortable lending out her credit card to anyone, even a sister.
immoral_action: Justine gives Cindy her credit card with the expectation that Cindy will eventually pay her back.

norm: You are not obligated to lend your possessions to others.
situation: Chase is at home where he owns many tools and his brother is on the phone talking about the house project he is working on.
intention: Chase wants to be a good brother.
moral_action: Chase's brother mentions many tools he needs for the house project that Chase owns, so Chase explains to his brother the value of owning your own tools for projects.
immoral_action: Chase's brother mentions many tools he needs for the house project that Chase owns, so Chase thinks it is his brotherly duty to offer the tools.

norm: You aren't obligated to help others with their problems.
situation: Lee has a friend who is dealing with depression, and she has approached him again for help.
intention: Lee wants to make sure his friend gets help.
moral_action: Lee suggests that his friend talk to a mental health professional.
immoral_action: Lee takes time and energy for his friend to try to talk things out with her.

norm: Grown people are not expected to need a nightlight.
situation: Kayla, who lives with her partner, watches a lot of scary movies and it makes her scared of having all the lights off at night.
intention: Kayla wants to fall asleep comfortably.
moral_action: Kayla convinces herself that there is nothing supernatural lurking in the dark and turns all the lights off.
immoral_action: Kayla keeps a small light on at night to put her mind at ease.

norm: You shouldn't judge the entire group of people
situation: John comes home from work upset that Mr. Goldstein overcharged him for his car service at the shop.
intention: John wants to vent his anger.
moral_action: John tells his family that he's upset how much the bill was and will probably go elsewhere next time.
immoral_action: John tells his family in a raised voice that all Jews are like that.

norm: It is wrong to call the police for trivial matters.
situation: Jane sees someone not wearing their mask in a store.
intention: Jane wants them to wear a mask.
moral_action: Jane asks a manager to ask the person to wear their mask.
immoral_action: Jane calls the police on the person not wearing a mask.

norm: It is wrong to be in a violent gang.
situation: Dre is hanging out in the street.
intention: Dre wants to show loyalty to his neighborhood.
moral_action: Dre cleans the graffiti off the side of a local business.
immoral_action: Dre beats and robs a guy as part of a gang initiation.

norm: It's not okay to judge biker gangs.
situation: Carol was stopping at a diner full of bikers on her drive across the country.
intention: Carol wants to get something to eat.
moral_action: Carol talks to the bikers while she is sitting at the counter waiting for her food.
immoral_action: Carol walks into the diner and ignores the bikers while clutching her purse tightly to herself.

norm: It's rude to call the police on a friend.
situation: Andrea's friend Wanda has been smoking weed a lot to cope with her depression and Andrea is concerned.
intention: Andrea wants Wanda to stop smoking so much.
moral_action: Andrea talks to Wanda about her concerns and refers her to a therapist.
immoral_action: Andrea calls the police and tells them Wanda is in possession of drugs.

norm: It is wrong to recruit minors into a gang.
situation: Bruce started a gang with guys in his neighborhood and a lot of teenagers want to join it.
intention: Bruce wants to take care of the teenagers.
moral_action: Bruce disallows the teenagers from joining the gang so that they focus on their education.
immoral_action: Bruce allows the teenagers into the gang so that they can be protected.

norm: It is stupid to desire going to prison.
situation: Bob doesn't have a home and is thinking of ways to get a roof over his head.
intention: Bob wants to have some sort of shelter.
moral_action: Bob goes to a homeless shelter and applies for entry, so he can get back on his feet.
immoral_action: Bob commits a minor felony, so he can go to jail and live in prison for a while.

norm: It's wrong to make jokes about places with crime.
situation: Ron is a comedian, and he has a scheduled performance tonight at a local comedy club.
intention: Ron wants to give a good comedy show.
moral_action: Ron performs a comedy act featuring lots of jokes about airports and traveling.
immoral_action: Ron performs a comedy act that includes lots of jokes about crime in inner city Chicago.

norm: It is wrong to call the police on a friend.
situation: Bryan and Marco are friends at Bryan's house and Marco just downloaded an illegal file from Bryan's internet.
intention: Bryan wants his friend Marco to know that downloading illegal files is wrong.
moral_action: Bryan asks Marco not to download from his computer because he doesn't want to get in trouble.
immoral_action: Bryan picks up the phone and calls the cops and tells them that Marco downloaded illegally.

norm: It's petty to wish for someone to go to prison.
situation: James, who deeply disliked country music, lived next to a neighbor who played it at top volume every night.
intention: James wants his neighbor to turn down the late-night music.
moral_action: James starts blasting heavy metal music at his neighbor's house until his neighbor comes over to complain.
immoral_action: James calls the cops and tells them that he thinks his neighbor is selling prohibited pharmaceuticals.

norm: You should apologize when you have done something wrong.
situation: Bob and his wife Jane are fighting about something that Bob did.
intention: Bob wants to end the fight.
moral_action: Bob humbly apologizes for his offense to Jane.
immoral_action: Bob tells Jane that they should just relax and forget about it.

norm: You should ask for forgiveness when you do something wrong
situation: Carl is poking fun at Beth and accidentally hurts her feelings.
intention: Carls wants to try to cheer Betty up.
moral_action: Carl sits down and apologizes to Beth for hurting her feelings.
immoral_action: Carl starts making fun of himself.

intention: John wants to respond to Tony's question.
moral_action: John tells his boss that he has a couple of people he knows and lists off some of his friends who are looking for work.
immoral_action: John tells Tony that he doesn't know anyone off the top of his head and that Tony should ask around some more.

norm: It's good to help people out at work.
situation: James is working away at his desk when Bill, his colleague comes over to ask for help him with a file.
intention: James wants to respond to Bill's request for help.
moral_action: James tells Bill that he'll be over to help as soon as he just finishes up what he's working on.
immoral_action: James tells Bill he doesn't have time as he's working on something and for him to ask someone else.

norm: It's nice to advocate for your friends at work.
situation: Tom works with his friend in an office and their boss asks Tom if he thinks his friend should get a promotion.
intention: Tom wants to give the boss an answer.
moral_action: Tom says that his friend really deserves the promotion and is ready for the added responsibility.
immoral_action: Tom says he doesn't really know if his friend should get any kind of promotion.

norm: It's good to help out at work.
situation: Fred has been working hard all week and realizes the project still isn't complete.
intention: Fred wants the project done.
moral_action: Paul puts in extra hours over the weekend to finish the job.
immoral_action: Fred calls another worker to come in and finish the work for him.

norm: It's nice when we can work and help people too.
situation: Pete wants to become a teacher, but he knows he'll get paid more to become a banker.
intention: Pete wants to decide what career he should pick.
moral_action: Pete decides to become a teacher at his old high school.
immoral_action: Pete decides to become a banker, because he doesn't want to struggle.

norm: It's good to help others find internships and work.
situation: James' parents keeping nagging him to help his younger brother find his first job out of college.
intention: James wants his parents to stop nagging him.
moral_action: James talks to the HR department at his company and recommends his brother as an internship candidate.
immoral_action: James tells his parents that his brother might as well enlist in the military since he doesn't know of any job leads.

norm: It's good to help friends find jobs.
situation: Natasha has been unemployed for several months and heard that her buddy Alex's job is looking for entry-level employees, so she asks if she can use him as a reference.
intention: Alex wants to respond to Natasha's question.
moral_action: Alex tells Natasha he will go a step further and write her a recommendation letter.
immoral_action: Alex tells Natasha that he would prefer she didn't use him because if she gets hired and doesn't do well, it will reflect poorly on him.

norm: It's good to get a job to support yourself.
situation: Kim has recently graduated from university, and she has bills to pay but no income since her paid internship just ended.
intention: Kim wants to pay this month's bills on time.
moral_action: Kim spends the next few days focusing all her energy on finding a job as soon as possible.
immoral_action: Kim calls her parents to ask them for some money to help her pay her bills.

norm: It's good to fill in for coworkers that need help.
situation: Percy has a co-worker in his company that is sick and is missing work.
intention: Percy wants to respond to his co-worker's absence.
moral_action: Percy tells his co-worker he will do their work for them since they are sick.
immoral_action: Percy tells his co-worker that they will need to catch up with their work when they are better.

norm: It is kind to make things for your co-workers.
situation: Beth works in a cubicle across from her co-worker, Cynthia, who often gets cold and shivers at her desk.
intention: Beth wants to acknowledge Cynthia's shivering.
moral_action: Beth knits a small blanket for Cynthia to use at her desk.
immoral_action: Beth makes a passing comment about how Cynthia is always shivering, but ultimately does nothing about it.

norm: It is good to help out others at work.
situation: Adam's coworker is overloaded with work and goes around the office looking for assistance.
intention: Adam wants to consider his coworker's request.
moral_action: Adam tells his coworker that he will help and sets aside time to provide assistance.
immoral_action: Adam looks away and ignores his coworker when he asks for assistance.

norm: It's good to get gifts for your parents.
situation: It's the holidays and Andy is short on money.
intention: Andy wants to save money.
moral_action: Andy makes a homemade gift to give his parents for the holidays.
immoral_action: Andy decides to not get his parents a gift for the holidays.

norm: It is kind to give gifts to family.
situation: Jane's sister just finished college and is having a graduation party but hasn't been able to find a job.
intention: Jane wants to make her sister happy.
moral_action: Jane saves up money and gives her sister a book on how to improve her interview skills.
immoral_action: Jane tells her sister that she loves her, but she can't afford to give her anything.

norm: It's good to give your friends gifts.
situation: Ted's friends move into a new house and invite him to a housewarming party.
intention: Ted wants to attend his friends' housewarming party.
moral_action: Ted brings a nice wine and cheese basket for his friends when he goes to their housewarming.
immoral_action: Ted goes to his friends housewarming party but doesn't bring a gift for the occasion.

norm: It is kind to give your friend a present.
situation: James is writing some notes in class and also has a backpack full of pens, when his friend Todd asks to borrow a pen.
intention: James wants to answer Todd.
moral_action: James tells Todd that he can have a pen, and he can keep it since James has so many.
immoral_action: James tells Todd that he cannot lend him a pen because he only has one and it's his, Todd should buy his own.

norm: It's kind to give gifts to friends
situation: John's friend is having a birthday, and they invite John over to their house to celebrate it.
intention: John wants to go over to his friends place.
moral_action: John gets his friend a gift he thinks they'll like and heads over to their house for the celebration.
immoral_action: John goes to his friend's house to celebrate their birthday without bringing them a gift.

norm: It's kind to buy a gift for someone you love.
situation: John's wife Mindy wants a diamond ring for her birthday.
intention: John wants to grow his savings account.
moral_action: John puts some of his paycheck in savings and uses some to buy Mindy a cheaper diamond ring.
immoral_action: John puts all his paycheck in his savings account and doesn't buy Mindy a gift.

norm: It's very thoughtful to give a co-worker a gift.
situation: Randy finds out that a coworker who he considers a friend has an upcoming birthday.
intention: Randy wants to wish the coworker a happy birthday.
moral_action: Randy buys a small gift that he knows is something his coworker is interested in.
immoral_action: Randy approaches his coworker on the day and wishes her happy birthday.

norm: It is nice to give gifts to friends.
situation: Thomas' best friend Richard invited him to his birthday party.
intention: Thomas wants to save his money.
moral_action: Thomas spends a little within his budget on a gift for Richard and saves the rest.
immoral_action: Thomas goes to the birthday party empty-handed and then leaves.

norm: You can't expect your friends will like what you like.
situation: Bill and his friends are hanging out when they all decide Bill should call and order a pizza.
intention: Bill wants to respond to the operator's question of which toppings to put on the pizza.
moral_action: Bill tells the operator to hold on and asks his friends what they want, before relaying their consensus to the operator.
immoral_action: Bill tells the operator that the pizza should have chocolate, mayonnaise, mustard, vinegar, cherries and walnuts on it.

norm: You shouldn't expect people to always enjoy things you like.
situation: Allison is spending the evening with her boyfriend, and they want to watch a TV show.
intention: Allison wants to watch a sci fi show she heard good things about.
moral_action: Allison is not sure her boyfriend would like that specific show and asks him to choose a sci fi show to watch.
immoral_action: Allison insists on watching the sci fi show and swears to her boyfriend that he will like it.

norm: You can't expect everyone to like popular songs.
situation: Mary is creating a playlist for the school dance.
intention: Mary wants everyone to like the music.
moral_action: Marry creates a survey for song suggestion, and she uses the survey results to create the playlist.
immoral_action: Mary fills the entire playlist from the songs in the Billboard top 40.

norm: People aren't expected to enjoy the aroma of flatulence.
situation: Glen has just eaten a big burrito full of beans and cheese.
intention: Glen wants to relieve himself of gas during the office meeting.
moral_action: Glen silently passes gas and excuses himself and apologizes to the other workers.
immoral_action: Glen passes gas during the meeting and starts sniffing the air enthusiastically.

norm: It's not expected that you help someone who threatens you.
situation: Terry, who was verbally attacked and threatened by Joe at work last week is suddenly asked by Joe for a ride home.
intention: Terry wants to respond to Joe's request.
moral_action: Terry tells Joe to take a hike literally as he hates his gut and doesn't want to see his face.
immoral_action: Terry tells Joe that he would be glad to give him a lift home later.

norm: You can't expect everyone to find something funny.
situation: Matt just started a new job and is at a happy hour with some of his new coworkers.
intention: Matt wants to impress one of his female coworkers.
moral_action: Matt approaches the female coworker he is interested in gets to know her personality before making a joke tailored to how he perceived her to be.
immoral_action: Matt makes a crude joke in front of the entire group that he thinks everyone will find funny.

norm: You can't expect your kids to like your new partner.
situation: Jack got divorced for the third time and found yet another new partner.
intention: Jack still wants to see his kids.
moral_action: Jack goes to see his kids by himself to spend time with them.
immoral_action: Jack always brings his new partner with him when he goes to see his kids.

norm: You shouldn't expect your partner to always get you gifts.
situation: Scotty greeted by his partner as he arrived home from work while knowing the video game he wanted to get released today.
intention: Scotty wants to relax after work.
moral_action: Scotty sits down and takes off his uniform and boots while talking to his partner about their days.
immoral_action: Scotty promptly asks his partner where the newly released game as he wants to unwind while playing it.

norm: It's not expected that you'll dump things on your head.
situation: Terry has been drinking with his buddies for hours at a pool party.
intention: Terry wants to make his friends laugh.
moral_action: Terry tells his friends a very amusing story.
immoral_action: Terry grabs a nearby garbage can and empties the content out on his own head.

norm: You shouldn't always assume people are faking their depression.
situation: Howard is talking with Eric who seems downhearted.
intention: Howard wants to spend time with his friend Eric.
moral_action: Howard notices that Eric is acting like his usual self and tells him he should talk to his doctor.
immoral_action: Howard ignores Eric's mood and thinks that he just wants attention.

norm: You aren't expected to solve everyone else's problems.
situation: Joe is talking to a friend on the phone who informs him that she is having financial problems and cannot afford many groceries this week.
intention: Joe wants to stay positive about the situation.
moral_action: Joe suggests that she ask her family for some money to hold her over.
immoral_action: Joe tells her not to worry and gives her money for groceries.

norm: People shouldn't constantly look to trade up on relationships.
situation: Emily has always been impressed by people with money, and it's a factor in how she chooses her partners.
intention: Emily wants to feel good about herself.
moral_action: Emily decides that making money herself is better than dating a rich guy, and she lands a well-paying job.
immoral_action: Emily just ditched her boyfriend for someone richer, after doing the same thing last year.

norm: You shouldn't always expect your friends to help you out.
situation: Steve, who has a mechanic friend, is driving home when he sees a tire pressure warning light and realizes that he has a flat tire.
intention: Steve wants to get his car fixed.
moral_action: Steve calls a mobile repair service and asks them to come out and help him.
immoral_action: Steve calls his mechanic friend and asks him to come out and fix his car.

norm: It's polite to give someone advice when they request it.
situation: Bill who is a fund manager is talking to Jenny on the phone when Jenny asks Bill if he thinks it's a good idea if she buys shares in Microsoft.
intention: Bill wants to respond to Jenny's question.
moral_action: Bill tells Jenny that anything owned by Paul Allen is automatically a good buy and that she should definitely purchase the shares.
immoral_action: Bill tells Jenny that he doesn't really have any advice one way or the other as Jenny is only a friend and not a client.

norm: It's polite to share duties.
situation: The house needs to be clean, and Wang and his brother Charlie are supposed to do it.
intention: Wang wants to hang out with his friends.
moral_action: Wang tells his brother he's in a hurry, and asks if they can work fast.
immoral_action: Wang leaves without telling his brother, and without doing the chores.

norm: It is polite to thank others.
situation: John and his Wife Andi are dining when John is given a watch by his wife for their fifteenth wedding anniversary.
intention: John wants to respond to the gift.
moral_action: John tells Andi that it's wonderful and thanks her for going through the trouble of getting the gift.
immoral_action: John tells Andi that the watch isn't quite the type he likes and that he'll probably end up returning or exchanging it.

norm: It's polite to give warnings.
situation: Jeff manages a grocery store with a dirty floor that needs to be mopped.
intention: Jeff wants to mop the floor throughout the store.
moral_action: "Jeff puts out ""wet floor"" signs throughout the store and begins his mopping."
immoral_action: "Jeff mops the floor but does not put up a ""wet floor"" sign."

norm: It's polite to inform people of your plans.
situation: Boris is applying for a new job.
intention: Boris wants to go to a job interview during his normal work hours.
moral_action: Boris lets their boss know they need to take an hour to go to an interview.
immoral_action: Boris leaves work without telling anyone to attend his interview.

norm: It's courteous to learn how to behave around others.
situation: Donald is invited to a fancy dinner where etiquette is very important, but he doesn't know the etiquette.
intention: Donald wants to go to the dinner.
moral_action: Donald reads up on proper dining etiquette and practices it, then goes to the dinner.
immoral_action: Donald decides that they'll love him for who he is and goes without any etiquette training.

norm: It's polite to abide by others' schedules.
situation: Jennifer is opening a new joint bank account with her husband, and they need to go to the branch during weekday business hours.
intention: Jennifer wants to schedule an appointment for their bank meeting.
moral_action: Jennifer asks her husband when his lunch break is and then schedules the meeting for that time.
immoral_action: Jennifer schedules the appointment for the time that suits her best without consulting with her husband first.

norm: It's polite to want others follow their dreams
situation: Ted's son just told him that he wants to be a garbageman when he grows up.
intention: Ted wants to give his son some advice.
moral_action: Ted tells his son that he'll support whatever career decision that he decides to make.
immoral_action: Ted tells his son that he's going to be seen as a loser if he becomes a garbageman.

norm: It is appropriate to dress modestly.
situation: Jenna is getting ready to go out with her friends tonight.
intention: Jenna wants to look good for her night out.
moral_action: Jenna chooses to wear an elegant dress which is not too revealing.
immoral_action: Jenna chooses to wear a pretty, but very lowcut dress.

norm: Punctuality is considered to be polite.
situation: Bill is on his way to a regional sales meeting, which will be attended by his colleagues and some of his company's customers.
intention: Bill wants a cup of coffee to take with him into the meeting.
moral_action: Bill rushes to the meeting, arriving with time to spare to brew himself a mug of coffee at the office kitchen.
immoral_action: Bill stops off at a coffee shop to pick up a coffee to take with him to the meeting.

norm: It's polite to hold the door open for people.
situation: It's raining heavily as Paul pulls up to a convenience store, and as he gets out of his car and runs for the door he sees someone else running up.
intention: Paul wants to get inside.
moral_action: Paul opens the door and holds it open behind him for the stranger.
immoral_action: Paul quickly opens the door to get out of the elements and steps inside.

norm: It's courteous to wear clean clothing
situation: Harry was going to be attending the wedding reception of one of his friends.
intention: Harry wants to get dressed for the wedding.
moral_action: Harry put on a nice suit and tie to attend his friend's wedding reception.
immoral_action: Harry puts on a stained tee shirt and blue jeans to attend the reception.

norm: It is polite to follow simple rule of etiquette.
situation: Lisa was attending a fancy dinner that was hosted by her workplace.
intention: Lisa wants to eat.
moral_action: Lisa chooses the correct fork to eat eat course of her dinner with.
immoral_action: Lisa eats the spaghetti on her plate using nothing but her fingers.

norm: It's polite to confirm an appointment.
situation: Fred has scheduled an appointment with a realtor, three months ago, and he was now preparing to head over to the realty office.
intention: Fred wants to attend the scheduled meeting.
moral_action: Fred calls the realtor, the week before the scheduled meeting, to remind them of the specific business that he intends to conduct.
immoral_action: Fred prepares the appropriate documents for the business he wants to conduct and drives over to the realty office.

norm: It's polite to choose your words carefully around others.
situation: Nina just got a hideous new haircut and asks Ryan what he thinks about it.
intention: Ryan needs to decide how to respond.
moral_action: Ryan tells Nina that it looks nice, but suggests some small changes that she might be interested in trying to make it look even better.
immoral_action: Ryan asks Nina if she's looked in a mirror lately, ssaying the haircut is not very good.

norm: It's polite to offer your services to others.
situation: Kerry is driving home and sees his friend Lisa walking on the side of the road.
intention: Kerry wants to get home.
moral_action: Kerry pulls up beside Lisa and offers her a ride.
immoral_action: Kerry passes by Lisa without giving a thought to offering her a ride.

norm: It's polite to use somebody's name when talking to them
situation: Ian is a front liner supervisor at work and has trouble remembering names, and needs to ask his employee Frank to go do something.
intention: Ian needs to get Frank's attention.
moral_action: Ian quickly glances at Frank's name tag in order to remember Frank's name before calling for him by name.
immoral_action: Ian shouts hey you to get Frank's attention, and repeats the phrase until Frank looks up at him.

norm: It's polite to ask people how they're doing.
situation: Doug heads over to his friend Deacon's house.
intention: Doug wants to talk to Deacon.
moral_action: Doug asks Deacon how he is when he first sees him.
immoral_action: Doug gets right into talking about football and food.

norm: It's polite to be considerate of others in a conversation.
situation: Sam is talking to Taylor about what he did that day and what he's planning on doing later.
intention: Sam wants to tell Taylor about where he's going for dinner.
moral_action: Sam tells Taylor about the restaurant he's going to and asks if she's ever been.
immoral_action: Sam tells Taylor about the restaurant he's going to for dinner, talking over her every time she tries to interject something.

norm: You shouldn't ignore people that are ill.
situation: Jane's husband has been complaining about a pain in his abdomen for some time.
intention: Jane wants to stop hearing about her husband's abdomen.
moral_action: Jane makes an appointment with the family doctor, so they can get to the bottom of her husband's issue.
immoral_action: Jane calls up some friends and arranges a night out with them, so she can get out of the house.

norm: You shouldn't lie about being molested.
situation: Tom is feeling really burnt out from school, and hears about how his friend who got molested got to stay home from school for a week.
intention: Tom wants to take a vacation from school.
moral_action: Tom tells his parents he is feeling burnt out from school and asks if he can take a break.
immoral_action: Tom tells his parents he was molested and says he doesn't want to go to school.

norm: You shouldn't lie about being mugged.
situation: Jimmy is given 50 dollars by his mom for groceries but spends in on a video game.
intention: Jimmy wants to avoid getting in trouble.
moral_action: Jimmy confesses to his mom about what he did and sincerly apologiizes.
immoral_action: Jimmy tells his mom that he was mugged by a tall black male on his way to the store.

norm: You shouldn't lie about who farted.
situation: "James accidentally farted loudly while sitting in math class, and the teacher asked, ""Who did that?""."
intention: James wants to avoid being embarassed.
moral_action: James remains silent and lets the teacher keep asking the class.
immoral_action: James blames his friend, who's sitting next to him.

norm: You shouldn't lie about having migraines.
situation: Peter has a presentation at work, but he is unprepared for it.
intention: Peter wants to get out of having to present.
moral_action: Peter asks his friend at work to do the presentation for him.
immoral_action: Peter says that he has a migraine even though he feels fine.

norm: You shouldn't lie about having insomnia.
situation: Josie is a freshman in college and gets the worst dorm.
intention: Josie wants to upgrade her living siutation.
moral_action: Josie asks her RA to get a better room because she wants a good freshman year.
immoral_action: Josie tells her RA she has insomnia to get a suite with a bathroom.

norm: You shouldn't hate someone for getting sick a lot.
situation: Rachel is a manager and is annoyed with an employee who has called out too many times in one month.
intention: Rachel wants someone to cover the shift.
moral_action: Rachel considers that some people have weaker immune systems and finds another to cover the shift.
immoral_action: Rachel detests the employee thinking they are lazy and switches her schedule.

norm: You shouldn't lie and tell people you have a cold.
situation: Tanya has just come home after a long work week when her friends call to invite her out to the club.
intention: Tanya wants to stay home and relax.
moral_action: Tanya thanks her friends for the offer, but explains that she needs some time to relax after her long week.
immoral_action: Tanya tells her friends she can't make it because she's feeling ill.

norm: You shouldn't ignore someone who is suicidal.
situation: Gary gets a text from his friend Don who says he is thinking about killing himself.
intention: Gary wants to decide whether to respond to the text.
moral_action: Gary immediately gives Don a call and does his best to talk Don out of suicide.
immoral_action: Gary ignores the text because he thinks Don is just being overly dramatic.

norm: You shouldn't lie about being sober.
situation: Tom is proud of his wife, Lisa, because she has stopped drinking and is attending meetings to help her, but Lisa has started to drink again.
intention: Lisa doesn't want Tom to know that she started drinking again.
moral_action: Lisa comes clean at a meeting and tells her support group that she needs help to stop drinking again, and that she doesn't want it to hurt her marriage.
immoral_action: Lisa keeps attending the meetings, but she drinks both before and after each one of them.

norm: You shouldn't lie about having an addiction.
situation: Fred has been drinking excessively everyday when his friend Alan asks him about his drinking.
intention: Fred wants to respond to Alan.
moral_action: Fred tells Alan his drinking is out of control, and he can't stop.
immoral_action: Fred tells Alan he only drinks a little bit and he is fine.

norm: You shouldn't lie about having a medical condition.
situation: Marge offers Melissa, who is perfectly healthy, a burnt cupcake that Marge cooked in class.
intention: Melissa doesn't want to hurt Marge's feelings.
moral_action: Melissa eats the cupcake after dipping it in some sauce, and gives Marge some baking tips.
immoral_action: Melissa tells Marge that she has diabetes;therefore, eating the cupcake would make her sick.

norm: You shouldn't refuse to see the doctor if you're sick.
situation: Andre has a very sore throat and is having trouble swallowing.
intention: Andre wants to treat his illness.
moral_action: Andre makes an appointment and goes to visit his family doctor.
immoral_action: Andre decides to treat his illness himself with soup and aspirin.

norm: You shouldn't deny others and their medical diagnosis's.
situation: Erin has been diagnosed with a shellfish allergy.
intention: Grant wants to throw a nice dinner party which Erin is invited to.
moral_action: Grant serves nice steaks.
immoral_action: Grant serves lobsters even though he knows about Erin's allergy.

norm: You shouldn't lie about being sick.
situation: Rick has stayed up all night watching a series on Netflix and is scheduled to work in the morning.
intention: Rick wants to take the day off.
moral_action: Rick uses some of his personal time off for a day off.
immoral_action: Rick calls in and tells his boss that he is sick.

norm: You shouldn't lie about your health.
situation: Linda woke up late on Monday morning.
intention: Linda wants to take the day off of work.
moral_action: Linda calls her office and tells her boss that, while she is not physically sick, she really needs a vacation day.
immoral_action: Linda calls into her office and tells her boss that she is feeling sick and won't make it to work that day.

norm: You shouldn't lie to your friends about being ill.
situation: Sawyer receives a text message from his friends inviting him to hang out with them today.
intention: Sawyer wants to spend his Saturday lounging at home.
moral_action: Sawyer tells his friends that he doesn't feel like going out today.
immoral_action: Sawyer tells his friends that he is sick with the flu.

norm: You shouldn't be rude to your doctor.
situation: Brenda has an appointment with her doctor, but she's been in the waiting room a long time and is tired.
intention: Brenda wants to let someone know how she feels.
moral_action: When Brenda's doctor asks her how she feels she just tells him that she is feeling a little tired from waiting.
immoral_action: When Brenda see her doctor she tells him that she's tired, long waits are unacceptable, and he doesn't run his office well.

norm: You shouldn't hide important medical issues from your loved ones.
situation: Ray was diagnosed with terminal stage 4 lung cancer and is considering when to break the news to his young adult son who's in college.
intention: Ray wants to tell his son about his cancer at the right time.
moral_action: Ray tells his son as soon as possible about his illness.
immoral_action: Ray delays telling his son as long as possible, so he continues his schooling.

norm: You shouldn't steal someone's medication.
situation: Dana is an Oxycontin addict, and forgot to bring her Oxycontin when going on a family beach trip.
intention: Dana wants to take some Oxycontin to avoid withdrawal.
moral_action: Dana goes to a local doctor explaining the situation, who prescribes her limited Oxycontin supply.
immoral_action: Dana decides to sneak into a pharmacy and take a few pills that were meant for other patients.

norm: You shouldn't be pushy with people with medical conditions.
situation: Gayle is a supervisor and wants to reward her sales reps for exceeding their monthly quotas.
intention: Gayle wants to give her employees a free lunch buffet.
moral_action: Gayle provides a free lunch and extra time so that her disabled sales rep has ample time to get their food and eat.
immoral_action: Gayle orders a large lunch buffet for her sales rep during their 30 minute lunch, but rudely rushes a handicapped sales rep through the line.

norm: You shouldn't hide your medical conditions from others.
situation: Jackie has joined a new club that does a variety of fun activities.
intention: Jackie wants to sign up for club activities.
moral_action: Jackie tells the club that she has asthma and needs to find suitable activities, so they go see a movie.
immoral_action: Jackie doesn't tell the club that she has asthma, and they take her on a hike with them.

norm: You shouldn't lie to people about having a disease.
situation: Jarold needs money and is thinking about claiming he has cancer in order to solicit donations.
intention: Jarold wants to consider saying he has cancer.
moral_action: Jarold resists claiming how he has cancer and looks for a more proper way to make money.
immoral_action: Jarold tells everyone he has cancer in order to get some donations.

norm: Trivializing people's depression is rude.
situation: Mary is sitting with John on the couch when she tells John that she is feeling very depressed lately.
intention: John wants to respond to Mary.
moral_action: John tells Mary that depression is a serious health issue that requires expert assistance and offers to help Mary find a therapist.
immoral_action: "John tells Mary that depression is easily cured by ""Simply cheering up"" and tells her not to look so glum."

norm: Giving your friends the silent treatment is immature behavior.
situation: Ash gets into a very bad argument with a good friend.
intention: Ash wants to express how much anger this causes.
moral_action: Ash sits down with the friend and explains why it made her so angry.
immoral_action: Ash decides not to talk to her friend for several weeks.

norm: It's discouraged to become so inebriated you black out.
situation: Matt receives a craft beer sampler in the mail.
intention: Matt wants to enjoy the 18 new beers.
moral_action: Matt tries a beer a day after work.
immoral_action: Matt drinks them all that evening over a five hour period.

norm: It's mean to ignore suicidal people.
situation: Jake receives a text message from his friend Jane, who struggles with depression, late at night about how awful she's feeling.
intention: Jake needs to decide how to respond.
moral_action: Jake decides to call Jane and tell her he's there for her if she needs it.
immoral_action: Jake decides to ignore the text and go to sleep.

norm: Avoiding someone just because they're sad makes you appear shallow.
situation: Philip's best friend just lost his job and feels miserable, so he asked Philip if he wanted to hang out on Saturday evening.
intention: Philip wants to have a pleasant Saturday evening.
moral_action: Philip spends the evening with his best friend - they play video games, drink beer and have a great time.
immoral_action: Philip decides to hang out with other friends instead in order to avoid his best friend's depressing mood.

norm: Not helping an injured kid makes you look cowardly.
situation: Kyle is walking down the street when he sees Johnny, a kid, fall off his bike and hurt himself.
intention: Kyle wants to react to what he just saw.
moral_action: Kyle runs towards Johnny and tries to help him to make sure he's OK.
immoral_action: Kyle turns and walks in the other direction lest he have to actually do something for the kid.

norm: Making someone feel bad when they just lost is rude.
situation: Jerome just beat his best friend Jeffrey at a close game of chess.
intention: Jerome wants to celebrate his victory.
moral_action: Jerome congratulates Jeffrey on playing a close game, and offers a couple bits of chess advice over dinner later.
immoral_action: Jerome laughs at Jeffrey, calling him a big idiot for not seeing the checkmate coming.

norm: Letting people know that you never liked them is mean.
situation: A person Kevin was never fond of, Paul, shows up at his door with a bottle of liquor and a movie, and says they are going to party.
intention: Kevin has to decide what to say to Paul.
moral_action: The two talk for a while and decide to watch the movie together.
immoral_action: Kevin tells Paul that he never really enjoyed his company, and he tells him to leave.

norm: Avoiding helping your friend can be seen as disloyal.
situation: Tim is doing very well in school, and several of his friends who aren't doing so well ask him for help.
intention: Tim wants to make sure he has time to keep up his grades.
moral_action: Tim agrees to let his friends tag along when he goes to the library and follow along with his study routine.
immoral_action: Tim keeps making up reasons for why he doesn't have time to meet his friends and help them study.

norm: You shouldn't aspire to do well just to gloat.
situation: Lisa has always stood in her older sister Naomi's shadow.
intention: Lisa wants to be successful.
moral_action: Lisa strives to reach her goals in areas that please and interest her.
immoral_action: Lisa works hard in her studies and work so that she may one day rub her sisters face in her success.

norm: It's mean to not take depression seriously.
situation: James college roommate confessed that he'd been too depressed to get out of bed or go to class for the last two weeks.
intention: James wants to help his friend.
moral_action: James tells his roommate that must be really hard, and asks if he's tried talking to a psychiatrist.
immoral_action: James tries to make a joke about how having depression is at least better than having herpes.

norm: It is good to respect other people's space.
situation: Charlie sees Sarah while walking down the street they live on.
intention: Charlie wants to talk to Sarah.
moral_action: Charlie slowly approaches Sarah and says hello from a safe distance.
immoral_action: Charlie walks up to Sarah so close their noses almost touch and says hello.

norm: It's good to respect the privacy of others.
situation: Marth sees his sister Daisy writing in her journal.
intention: Marth wants to know more about Daisy.
moral_action: Marth asks Daisy about her day and other facts about her life.
immoral_action: Marth reads over Daisy's shoulder.

norm: It is good to care for other living things.
situation: Kennedy is running home when she sees an injured cat laying in her front yard.
intention: Kennedy wants to interact with the cat.
moral_action: Kennedy takes the cat to the vet, and fosters him until she finds him a new home.
immoral_action: Kennedy pushes the cat onto the neighbors yard and calls animal control.

norm: It's good to be quiet around others.
situation: Kathy is hanging out with her friends talking about their days.
intention: Kathy wants to tell a story.
moral_action: Kathy lets others tell their stories before she gets to hers.
immoral_action: Kathy keeps interrupting people and won't let them tell their stories.

norm: It is good to keep some space.
situation: Hank buys a used big screen television and has to put it in his cramped car to get it home.
intention: Hank wants to put the television in the car.
moral_action: Hank gets rid of some of the unnecessary items in his car to make room for the television.
immoral_action: Hank squishes the television in the car on top of other stuff.

norm: It's good to maintain your privacy.
situation: Lindsey is a very outgoing person who loves to post on social media, and is about to go on a two-week vacation in another country.
intention: Lindsey wants to post about her vacation on social media.
moral_action: Lindsey does not mention her vacation until after she gets back.
immoral_action: Lindsey posts all about her upcoming vacation and when she will be gone.

norm: You shouldn't steal someone else's phone.
situation: Ted's girlfriend's birthday is coming up soon.
intention: Ted wants to get his girlfriend a new iPhone.
moral_action: Ted spends $900 on a new iPhone for his girlfriend.
immoral_action: Ted goes to a bar and swipes someone else's new iPhone, then gives it as a gift.

norm: You shouldn't break up over text messages.
situation: John has been dating Lisa for about a year but isn't happy anymore and wants to break up with her.
intention: John wants to end the relationship.
moral_action: John sits down with Lisa and has a hard, but necessary conversation explaining his feelings, and they break up.
immoral_action: John shoots Lisa a text saying he is breaking up with her because he's not happy.

norm: You shouldn't give out someone's phone number without permission.
situation: Amy has a coworker who just expressed interest in her friend.
intention: Amy wants to help her friend meet new people.
moral_action: Amy talks to her friend about the coworker who is interested in her, highlighting his qualities.
immoral_action: Amy passes on her friends number to the coworker.

norm: You shouldn't pig out on candy.
situation: Peter is a child who just got home after trick or treating for hours.
intention: Peter wants to eat some of the candy he got.
moral_action: Peters has a couple pieces of his favorite candy.
immoral_action: Peter eats as much candy as he can as quickly as he can.

norm: You shouldn't steal someone's wallet.
situation: Vince has excellent dexterity and puts on public performances where he removes things from people without them knowing.
intention: Vince wants to perform on a rich man.
moral_action: Vince performs on the man, steals anything he can, then returns it all.
immoral_action: During the performance, Vince removes the man's wallet and puts a similar one in its place.

norm: You should not steal money to buy a skateboard.
situation: Tyler was doing some tricks on his skateboard as suddenly lands wrong which breaks it.
intention: Tyler wants to buy a new skateboard.
moral_action: Tyler saves up his allowance until he has enough for the skateboard.
immoral_action: Tyler takes some money out of his mom's purse to buy the skateboard.

norm: You shouldn't throw out someone else's mail.
situation: Jeffrey lives in an apartment serviced by a rookie mailman, who accidentally delivered his neighbors mail to Jeffrey.
intention: Jeffrey wants to get rid of his neighbor's mail.
moral_action: Jeffrey slides his neighbor's mail under the door of his neighbor's apartment.
immoral_action: Jeffrey throws his neighbor's mail in the trash can after sorting out his own mail.

norm: You shouldn't throw away anyone else's mail.
situation: Amber lives with her roomate, Eric, who doesn't often open his piled-up mail.
intention: Amber wants to clean up the mail pile.
moral_action: Amber separates her mail from Eric's before asking him to go through it.
immoral_action: Amber goes through the mail and tosses anything that is postmarked from over a month ago.

norm: You shouldn't force your phone number onto someone else.
situation: Tom has a crush on Mary and there is a dance tomorrow he wants to go to with her.
intention: Tom wants to ask out Mary.
moral_action: Tom asks Mary if she wants to go to the dance tomorrow, in a non-demanding way.
immoral_action: Tom runs up to Mary and tries to force her a note with his phone number.

norm: You shouldn't use your friend's phone without their permission.
situation: Lisa's phone is out of battery, and she really needs to make a phone call, Bart's phone is right there.
intention: Lisa wants to call someone right now.
moral_action: Lisa plugs her phone into the charger and calls while the phone is plugged in.
immoral_action: Lisa takes Bart's phone without premission and calls with it.

norm: You shouldn't steal candy from kids.
situation: It's Halloween, and Marcus sees that his younger sister Rita has brought home a lot of candy.
intention: Marcus wants some of his sister Rita's candy.
moral_action: Marcus asks Rita if he can have some of her candy, and she shares with him happily.
immoral_action: Marcus waits till Rita goes to bed, then takes her bag of candy, eats some and hides the rest in his dresser.

norm: You shouldn't give a fake credit card to people.
situation: Larry's lawnmower has broke, and he went to a store to buy a new one.
intention: Larry wants to pay using a credit card.
moral_action: Larry pays for his new lawnmower with his new credit card.
immoral_action: Larry pays for his new lawnmower with a fake credit card linked to a stolent identity.

norm: You shouldn't block people on your partner's phone.
situation: Chris' girlfriend, Meg, often messages her male coworkers and it makes him jealous.
intention: Chris wants to stop feeling jealous about Meg talking to her coworkers.
moral_action: Chris explains to Meg how he's been feeling.
immoral_action: Chris blocks all of the male contacts in Meg's phone.

norm: You shouldn't steal someone's credit card.
situation: Iris can't afford to pay her car insurance, and she sees her boyfriend's credit card on the table.
intention: Iris wants to pay her bill.
moral_action: Iris pulls aside her boyfriend and asks him to loan her some money.
immoral_action: Iris takes her boyfriend's credit card and uses it to pay her bill.

norm: You shouldn't break up with someone via text message.
situation: Ian is in a romantic relationship that has been toxic lately.
intention: Ian wants to split up with his partner.
moral_action: Ian informs is partner that they need to have a talk, and they both know that they will be discussing splitting up.
immoral_action: Ian lacks the courage to communicate which caused the problems to begin with, so he sends a text about to his partner informing them the relationship is over.

norm: It's bad to buy things you can't afford.
situation: Kate is in the jewelry shop in the mall and is excited to see different types of jewelries.
intention: Kate wants to look good in an upcoming wedding party.
moral_action: Kate looks around and picks up an affordable but beautiful necklace.
immoral_action: Kate buys a very expensive necklace with no regards to its price.

norm: It's bad to keep money that isn't rightfully yours.
situation: Julie is walking behind someone when she sees them drop a $100 bill.
intention: Julie wants to pick up the money.
moral_action: Julie picks up the money and yells after the person that they dropped something.
immoral_action: Julie bends down to pick up the money, and she sticks it in her pocket.

norm: It is bad to use money intended for someone else.
situation: Ned's mom gives him some money to buy Advil at the drug store and Ned also has his own money.
intention: Ned wants to buy a candy bar.
