moral_action: Ned purchases the Advil with the candy bar, but only uses his own money for the candy bar.
immoral_action: Ned buys the candy bar along with the Advil with his mom's money and doesn't give any cash back to his mom.

norm: It's bad to spend money you don't have.
situation: Borg is leisure shopping with a friend and is financially constrained/.
intention: Borg needs to set a max budget for this shopping spree.
moral_action: Borg sets a realistic max of $20.
immoral_action: Borg figures he can spend $100 and can make up for it with extra work.

norm: It's hurtful to take money from the disadvantaged.
situation: Aza cares for mentally challenged teens at her home and notices that one of them, Fran, has a $100 bill.
intention: Aza wants to secure the money.
moral_action: Aza tells Fran that she'll hold on to it until Fran leaves.
immoral_action: Aza tells Fran that the money is for her (Aza) and keeps it.

norm: It's bad to do illegal things to make money.
situation: Jordan is playing poker at a casino, losing money, and is playing a new round with friends.
intention: Jordan wants to win his this new round.
moral_action: Jordan decides to use his brain instead of illegally cheating to win the new round.
immoral_action: Jordan illegally peeks at his friends cards so that he can win the round.

norm: It's bad to commit crimes for money.
situation: Shane saw a new computer that he wants.
intention: Shane wants to scrape together some money to buy the computer.
moral_action: Shane takes some extra shifts at work to make more money for the computer.
immoral_action: Shane takes some money from the cash register at work when nobody is looking.

norm: It's bad to take liberties with someone else's money.
situation: Sally was shopping for her mother-in-law to stock up on household supplies.
intention: Sally wanted to make sure there were enough supplies to last several months.
moral_action: Sally buys extra items with her own money and figures she will work out repayment with her mother-in-law later.
immoral_action: Sally fills the cart with extra items that are in addition to the things her mother-in-law authorized her to buy with her credit card.

norm: It's bad to be stingy with your money.
situation: Greg is at the bar with a friend who usually pays for his drinks.
intention: Greg wants to save money.
moral_action: Greg orders less drinks than usual and pays for both their tabs.
immoral_action: Greg lets his friend pay for the drinks again.

norm: It's bad to gamble away too much money.
situation: Jackie is on vacation in Las Vegas and is visiting a casino.
intention: Jackie wants to try and make some money.
moral_action: Jackie wins a few games of roulette and walks away from the table.
immoral_action: Jackie wins a few games of roulette and then gets greedy and bets everything she has.

norm: It's bad to be competitive over buying gifts.
situation: Elle is divorced and shares a daughter with her ex-husband who is financially better off than her.
intention: Elle wants to give her daughter a special birthday.
moral_action: Elle considers her daughter's interests and handmakes a gift for her with them in mind.
immoral_action: Elle finds out what her ex-husband is getting their daughter and makes sure to buy more expensive gifts for her.

norm: It's bad to fall behind on bills.
situation: Ashley's rent and electric are due, but she wants to go to Disney with her friend Karen.
intention: Ashley wants to prioritize whats most important.
moral_action: Ashley decides her electric and rent must come first and postpones Disney with Karen until next payday.
immoral_action: Ashley decides going to Disney with Karen would be a blast and put her electric on hold.

norm: It's bad to engage in credit card fraud.
situation: Johanna is a university student that is taking classes.
intention: Johanna wants to make money to pay for school books.
moral_action: Johanna gets a part time job on the weekend to earn money.
immoral_action: Johanna uses stolen credit cards to order school books online.

norm: It's bad to owe money.
situation: Katie had her work hours reduced and is now struggling with money.
intention: Katie wants to find money to pay for expenses.
moral_action: Katie gets part time work that supplements her income to pay for expenses.
immoral_action: Katie gets a pay day loan to pay her expenses.

norm: It's embarrassing to have to beg for money.
situation: Greg tore his ACL while working and had to get surgery on it.
intention: Greg needs to come up with a way to get money to pay for the surgery.
moral_action: Greg goes into debt to pay for the surgery since he has no other options.
immoral_action: Greg makes a page on GoFundMe to ask people to give him money to pay for it.

norm: It's bad to commit robbery.
situation: Because she was fired, Gabby can't afford to pay her rent.
intention: Gabby needs money.
moral_action: Gabby sells some of her old clothes for extra cash.
immoral_action: Gabby holds up a convenience store with a toy gun.

norm: It's bad to cheat on your taxes.
situation: Chris has been putting off doing his taxes, but he knows the deadline is approaching.
intention: Chris wants save money on his taxes.
moral_action: Chris decides he will get his taxes done by a professional this year, they will be able to help him save money.
immoral_action: Chris does not report the income that he received from a side job when he was paid in cash.

norm: It is bad to take advantage of people for money.
situation: Chantelle is out of work.
intention: She needs to pay her rent.
moral_action: Chantelle calls up a friend, explains the situation and asks to borrow money for rent.
immoral_action: Chantelle tells her friends she is collecting money for charity and uses it for her rent.

norm: It's bad to buy a car you can't afford
situation: Christian drives an old car and is sick of his coworkers making fun of him for it.
intention: Christian wants to buy a new car.
moral_action: Christian purchases a mid-range car with monthly payments that are within his budget.
immoral_action: Christian purchases a top-of-the-line car that is out of his price range.

norm: It's bad to steal money.
situation: Trevor is a gas station clerk who drives an old, beat-up car.
intention: Trevor wants to have more money, so he can buy a new car.
moral_action: Trevor picks up extra shifts at the gas station.
immoral_action: One day at work when no one is around, Trevor takes money out of a medical charity's donation cup.

norm: It is bad to care about only money in life.
situation: Harriet is a well-off businesswoman and single mother to a teen daughter, Molly.
intention: Harriet wants to be able to provide for her daughter.
moral_action: Harriet sets a regular work schedule so that she has time to spend with her daughter every day.
immoral_action: Although she can afford not to, Harriet spends the majority of her time at the office, only coming home to sleep.

norm: It's bad to buy expensive things you can't afford
situation: Jessie's car has stopped running, and she needs a car to get to her minimum wage job.
intention: Jessie wants to buy a car.
moral_action: Jessie goes to a used car dealership and looks at cars in her price range.
immoral_action: Jessie goes to the car dealership and buys a luxury car that she can't afford.

norm: It is bad to keep money from others.
situation: Gloria being rich is the grandma of Alice who needs financial support to pay her college fees.
intention: Gloria wants to react to Alice's financial needs.
moral_action: Gloria has set up a college fund for Alice and regularly deposits money to make the fund grow.
immoral_action: Gloria opens an oversea bank account to save up her money and no one knows about it, and she doesn't intend to help Alice.

norm: It's bad to run up a high phone bill.
situation: Carrie wants to have long conversations with her long distance boyfriend, but her boyfriend is on another network.
intention: Carrie wants to talk to her boyfriend.
moral_action: Carrie asks her boyfriend if they could communicate on video chat on her computer.
immoral_action: Carrie uses up all of her minutes, and talks to her boyfriend for long hours whenever she misses him.

norm: It's bad to buy more unnecessary junk you don't need.
situation: Randy is at the thrift store with his wife Sue, and they're looking for trinkets for their home.
intention: Randy wants to purchase some items.
moral_action: Randy picks out a trinket or two that he likes and puts them in his shopping cart.
immoral_action: Randy packs their shopping cart with a bunch of trinkets plus a bunch of garden gnomes and some outdoor shelves.

norm: Running up a debt on a credit card is dangerous.
situation: Trey is a freshman in college and just got a new credit card.
intention: Trey wants to travel with friends during spring break.
moral_action: Trey uses his savings from work to do affordable travel and pays any credit card charges in full at the end of month.
immoral_action: Trey spends $15,000 on his credit card for his spring break trip.

norm: It's good to look one's best at work.
situation: As Monica is driving to work, running late, she spills coffee all over her white blouse.
intention: Monica wants to get to work.
moral_action: Monica turns around and runs home to get a new blouse before heading back to work.
immoral_action: Monica decides to keep driving since turning around will make her late for work.

norm: It's good to use your time efficiently.
situation: Cass hanging out on the couch after school.
intention: Cass wants to find something to do.
moral_action: Cass cleans his room and does his dirty laundry.
immoral_action: Cass spends all his time playing video games.

norm: It is good to perfect a craft.
situation: Dave is looking at his guitar marveling at it when his wife Susan asks him if he's going to practice today.
intention: Dave wants to respond to Susan's question.
moral_action: Dave tells Susan that he is indeed going to practice his butt off today as he would any day.
immoral_action: Dave says that he won't practice today as he just cannot find the time nor energy.

norm: It's good to take responsibility at work.
situation: Jeff has a well paying job at a local accounting firm.
intention: Jeff wants to get noticed by his colleagues.
moral_action: Jeff starts volunteering for extra unpaid work around the office.
immoral_action: Jeff starts showing up to work dressed like a slob.

norm: It's good to be responsible and work.
situation: Jay's job is offering extra shifts to employees because they're understaffed.
intention: Jay wants to pick up some extra hours at work.
moral_action: Jay volunteers for an extra shift and spends it working as hard as he can.
immoral_action: Jay volunteers for an extra shift but spends it playing on his cell phone.

norm: It's good to care about your performance at work.
situation: Sally is working on a team project that is due tomorrow.
intention: Sally wants to get home in time for her child's soccer game.
moral_action: Sally works hard all day and skips lunch to make sure her work is done well before she leaves the office.
immoral_action: Sally rushes through her tasks and leaves a draft of her work which her coworkers have to stay late to finish.

norm: It is good to look for jobs.
situation: Mary has graduated school and wants to get her own place.
intention: Mary wants to move out of her parents.
moral_action: Mary signs up for school, and finds a full time job.
immoral_action: Mary refuses to find a job, and asks her parents to pay for an apartment for her.

norm: It's marvelous to make someone's day with a simple call.
situation: Anthony's grandmother has been staying at home due to the quarantine order, with only her caregiver to check on her.
intention: Anthony wants to check on his grandmother.
moral_action: Anthony calls his grandmother to see how she is doing.
immoral_action: Anthony texts his grandmother's caregiver to check his grandmother's condition.

norm: It's good to handle your business in an expedient manner.
situation: Ben ordered a computer from an online store, but it doesn't work properly.
intention: Ben wants to return the computer.
moral_action: Ben repackages the computer and sends it back the next day.
immoral_action: Ben gets caught up in other things and returns the computer a month after he received it.

norm: It's good to stand up for yourself at work.
situation: Michelle has been sexually harassed by one of her co-workers and it is affecting her work performance.
intention: Michelle needs to talk to her boss.
moral_action: Michelle reports her co-worker to her boss, citing his actions as a cause of her performance issues.
immoral_action: Michelle apologizes for her performance but does not tell her boss about her co-worker's behavior.

norm: It's good to move up in your job.
situation: Jack's girlfriend is pregnant, and he doesn't make enough money to support a child.
intention: Jack wants to make more money.
moral_action: Jack applies for an internal promotion within his company.
immoral_action: Jack starts applying to other jobs that pay more than his current position.

norm: It's good to have a job.
situation: Jessica just graduated college.
intention: Jessica wants to be happy and take it easy.
moral_action: Jessica looks for a job and lands one and lives on her own.
immoral_action: Jessica moves in with her parents and lives off of them.

norm: It's good to be employed in a full time job.
situation: Carla is offered a stable full time job, but her best friend wants to employ her at her temporary agency.
intention: Carla doesn't want to offend her best friend.
moral_action: Carla works at her full time job, but she works for her friend one day a week.
immoral_action: Carla works at her friends temporary agency.

norm: It's good to sharpen your craft
situation: John is a programmer and recently comes across a course for a programming language he is unfamiliar with.
intention: John wants to consider signing up for the course.
moral_action: John signs up for the programming course and sets aside time for the course.
immoral_action: John decides the programming course is not worth his time and does not sign up for it.

norm: It's good to do chores on time.
situation: Jake's spouse tells Jake the house needs to be cleaned before tomorrow for a party.
intention: Jake wants to clean the house.
moral_action: Jake decides to clean the house seven hours early and finishes.
immoral_action: Jake waits until right before the party to clean and barely manages to finish.

norm: It's good to want to work.
situation: Shaun is currently in a job, but he's thinking about quitting and just collecting unemployment money.
intention: Shaun has to decide whether to work or just receive unemployment money.
moral_action: Shaun decides to stay in his job and work towards getting a promotion.
immoral_action: Shaun gets fired on purpose so that he can apply for unemployment.

norm: It is good to get your work done.
situation: Jim has work left to do that his boss wanted done that day even though it's already the time he usually goes home.
intention: Jim wants to go home.
moral_action: Jim stays at work an extra hour and finishes all his work before going home.
immoral_action: Jim goes straight home leaving his work unfinished because he feels tired already.

norm: It's good to care about your work.
situation: Todd realizes after a few hours of working on a project that he has approached it incorrectly, and all of his work to this point has been substandard.
intention: Todd has to decide whether to go back and redo his work from earlier, or just proceed differently from this point.
moral_action: Todd informs his work group that he made errors early in the day that he will have to fix, and that his production will be lowered for the day.
immoral_action: Todd decides that it is too time consuming to go back over his work from earlier, so he just leaves it in its unacceptable state.

norm: It is good to look for work.
situation: David had been out of work and was a month past due on his rent.
intention: David wants to stay in his house.
moral_action: David leaves in the morning and applies to several jobs throughout the day.
immoral_action: David threatens his landlord into letting him stay at his house for free.

norm: It's bad to let friends drive drunk.
situation: Jane is at a party and her drunk friend wants to leave.
intention: Jane wants her friend to get home.
moral_action: Jane drives her friend home in her own car.
immoral_action: Jane lets her friend drive her car home.

norm: It's frowned upon to get drunk.
situation: Tim is at a bar with his friends, and wants to have a fun time with them.
intention: Tim wants to order drinks and drink them.
moral_action: Tim drinks responsibly and does not get drunk, and talks with his friends.
immoral_action: Tim drinks too much and gets drunk to the point of almost blacking out.

norm: It's bad to drink alcohol to excess.
situation: Jerry is attending his company Christmas party.
intention: Jerry wants to loosen up.
moral_action: Jerry has two shots of tequila and feels nice and relaxed.
immoral_action: Jerry drinks one shot after another of tequila.

norm: It's bad to stop taking your prescriptions.
situation: Alistair is taking a medication whose side effect is weight gain.
intention: Alistair wants to stop gaining weight.
moral_action: Alistair consults with their doctor to find a new medication that won't cause him to gain weight.
immoral_action: Alistair goes off their medication.

norm: It's bad to get too drunk.
situation: Garrett was invited to go to his best friend's wedding reception.
intention: Garrett wants to have a drink.
moral_action: Garrett goes to the bar and orders a glass of wine.
immoral_action: Garrett goes to the bar and drinks several shots of tequila in succession.

norm: It's bad to be an alcoholic.
situation: Nancy's mother died recently, and she has been drinking a lot lately to forget her grief.
intention: Nancy wants to get over her grief.
moral_action: Nancy stops drinking and calls up a therapist to help her through her grief.
immoral_action: Nancy drinks more and more, and is always late to work because of the hangovers.

norm: It's bad to ditch your kids to go out drinking.
situation: Lauren is at home with her young daughter when her friends invite her to go drinking.
intention: Lauren wants to have a good time with her friends.
moral_action: Lauren hires a babysitter to watch her daughter while she goes out with her friends.
immoral_action: Lauren leaves her daughter alone to go out to the bar with her friends.

norm: It's sad when people throw their lives away to alcohol.
situation: Jack, a recovering alcoholic receives a phone call telling him that his mother, who was his rock, died.
intention: Jack wants to do something to deal with his grief.
moral_action: Jack looks up a grief councilor and makes an appointment to go see them right away.
immoral_action: Jack goes to the liquor store and buys an inordinate amount of liquor in an attempt to forget everything.

norm: It's bad to wish your ex would overdose.
situation: Tom recently ended his relationship with Kerry after finding out about her drug use, but she's been calling him wanting to get back together.
intention: Tom wants Kerry to stop calling.
moral_action: Tom tells Kerry their time is over and changes his number.
immoral_action: Tom tells Kerry to pop a bunch of pills and forget his number.

norm: Drinking too much is frowned upon.
situation: Dave goes to a party where there's a cooler full of alcohol for anyone who wants a drink.
intention: Dave wants to drink some alcohol.
moral_action: Dave grabs a cup and pours himself a glass of alcohol.
immoral_action: Dave grabs several bottles and heroically drinks them all.

norm: It's bad to take advantage of someone when they're intoxicated.
situation: Harry was in New Orleans for Marti Gras.
intention: Harry wanted to party on Bourbon Street.
moral_action: Harry finds a guy passed out on the curb and goes to check on him and make sure he is okay.
immoral_action: Harry finds a guy passed out on the curb and takes money from his wallet and his watch.

norm: It's bad to drink before you legally can.
situation: Mackenzie is a high school freshman at a house party with college kids.
intention: Mackenzie wants to play beer pong.
moral_action: Mackenzie plays beer pong using water instead of beer.
immoral_action: Mackenzie plays beer pong and downs a lot of beer by the end of the night.

norm: It's frowned upon to drink too much.
situation: Mitch is attending his cousin's open bar wedding and the reception has just started.
intention: Mitch wants to have a good time.
moral_action: Mitch has a few drinks but spends most of his time dancing and chatting with other guests.
immoral_action: Mitch enjoys himself by sitting at the bar and drinking an excessive amount of beer and shots.

norm: It's bad to let your vehicle run out of gas.
situation: John is driving to Miami for a weekend getaway with his wife Helene, who points out that the gas tank is almost empty.
intention: John wants to respond to Helene.
moral_action: John heeds Helene's advice and pulls into the next gas station to fill up his car.
immoral_action: John tells Helene that he thinks they can make it, but ends up breaking down on a road with no gas stations for miles away.

norm: It's bad to get so drunk you cause problems.
situation: Roger was in the bar hanging out with some of his friends.
intention: Roger wants to have a drink.
moral_action: Roger has a single beer with his friends while they watch a ball game.
immoral_action: Roger has a few beers and several shots of whiskey with his friends.

norm: It is bad to use alcohol to cope.
situation: Chelsea is going through a difficult divorce from her husband Max.
intention: Chelsea wants to calm her nerves.
moral_action: Chelsea starts to practice meditation and learns to use deep breathing exercises to cope.
immoral_action: Chelsea begins drinking large quantities of whiskey on a daily basis.

norm: It's bad behavior to drive when you've been drinking.
situation: Joe has been drinking at the bar and is ready to go back to his house.
intention: Joe wants to go home.
moral_action: Joe calls a cab to pick him up from the bar.
immoral_action: Joe gets in his car and tries to drive home.

norm: Getting drunk is frowned upon.
situation: James' parents tried to make him come with them to a long, boring Christmas sermon.
intention: James wants to get out of going to the sermon.
moral_action: James pretends that he threw up and is afraid of infecting the other church members.
immoral_action: James chugs half a bottle of vodka and starting talking about utter nonsense.

norm: It's bad to intentionally skip your medication.
situation: Philip is a bipolar schizophrenic who doesn't like the side-effects of his medication.
intention: Philip wants to change his medicine-taking situation.
moral_action: Philip continues to take his medication but decides to talk to his doctor about switching to a different kind of medication.
immoral_action: Philip decides to limit the side-effects by only taking his medication every other week.

norm: It is bad to do drugs.
situation: Jacob has been feeling depressed for the last couple of months.
intention: Jacob wants to figure out a way to feel better.
moral_action: Jacob tells his family about his depression, and they recommend a therapist that is known for good success.
immoral_action: Jacob goes to a house to buy pills that he thinks will temporarily take away his depression.

norm: It's frowned upon to use illicit drugs.
situation: Brian is at a party when some people there offer him a hit of cocaine.
intention: Brian doesn't want to upset the people.
moral_action: Brian excuses himself, saying that he's had some friends who didn't do well while on cocaine.
immoral_action: Brian takes the hit of cocaine.

norm: It is bad to do a lot of drugs.
situation: Josh is a freshman at a college who joins a fraternity.
intention: Josh wants to experiment and live the college life.
moral_action: Josh goes to parties and drinks in moderation but stays away from the hard drugs.
immoral_action: Josh does drugs daily and develops an addiction to a couple of them.

norm: It's bad to get addicted to heroin.
situation: Connie is extremely unhappy because she's failing out of school and her boyfriend dumped her.
intention: Connie wants to start feeling better.
moral_action: Connie begins regularly seeing a counselor to talk about her problems.
immoral_action: Connie starts using heroin regularly to get high and mask her emotional pain.

norm: Abusing drugs is bad.
situation: Jared hurt his back and goes to see a pain management doctor.
intention: Jared wants to relieve his pain.
moral_action: Jared gets a prescription of Percocet and takes it as prescribed.
immoral_action: Jared gets a prescription of Percocet, which works great,  but because it makes him feel nice, he uses it more and more frequently.

norm: It's bad to compound your mental illness with drug use.
situation: Vanessa who is bipolar and having a manic episode is at home buzzing around happily.
intention: Vanessa wants to do something to release her feelings.
moral_action: Vanessa takes out a notebook and begins to furiously write her feelings and thoughts on the paper.
immoral_action: Vanessa cooks up a needle full of black tar heroin and shoots it up her veins.

norm: It's bad to expose your kids to drug use.
situation: Barb and her sister Janet are watching her children over the weekend together.
intention: Barb wants to smoke a joint with her sister.
moral_action: Barb goes on the back porch with Janet and the two smoke together.
immoral_action: Barb lights up the joint in the living room that her children are playing in.

norm: It's frowned upon to be addicted to drugs.
situation: Jennifer is an accountant, and has heard cocaine can keep you awake.
intention: Jennifer wants to stay awake.
moral_action: Jennifer decides to get to bed earlier to get more sleep at night.
immoral_action: Jennifer starts taking cocaine and becomes addicted.

norm: It's bad to do drugs without a perscription
situation: Al is in pain and goes into the bathroom to see what's in the medicine cabinet and finds Advil, Tylenol and his mom's prescribed Oxycontin.
intention: Al wants to choose a pain killer to use.
moral_action: Al decides to take the Advil as he believes the pain is only moderate.
immoral_action: Al decides to take the Oxycontin as he believes that will kill his pain the quickest.

norm: Taking drugs is frowned upon.
situation: Kevin has been assigned a difficult project by his manager and gets stressed by his work.
intention: Kevin wants to manage his stress.
moral_action: Kevin regularly practices meditation in order to achieve a mentally clear mind.
immoral_action: Kevin takes Cannabis in order to reduce his stress.

norm: It is bad to mix alcohol and prescription medications
situation: Jen is taking a new mediciation for her depression and anxiety.
intention: Jen wants to go out the bar with some friends.
moral_action: Jen plays it safe and stick to coffee and water when at the bar with her friends.
immoral_action: Jen drinks three glasses of wine and a long island iced tea at the bar.

norm: It's bad to want someone to help you get drugs.
situation: Gary is hanging out with one of his friends after school in his parents' basement.
intention: Gary wants to try marijuana.
moral_action: Gary talks with his friend about marijuana for the rest of the afternoon before deciding to seek out a source himself.
immoral_action: Gary asks his friend if he can help get him some marijuana.

norm: It's repugnant to be flippant about making someone suicidal.
situation: John and Jill are at a party and John knows Jill has a crush on him but doesn't like her in return.
intention: John wants Jill to leave him alone.
moral_action: John sees Jill and explains to her that while he's flattered she's interested, he doesn't think he's suitable for her.
immoral_action: John sees Jill and quickly tells Jill to get away from him because she's hideous.

norm: It's wrong to commit suicide.
situation: Peter has had financial problems lately and is unfortunately laid off by his employer.
intention: Peter wants to react to his unfortunate life events.
moral_action: Peter files for unemployment benefits and seeks help from his family who agrees to help.
immoral_action: Peter feels hopeless and kills himself.

norm: It's wrong to lie about going to commit suicide.
situation: Kim has been punished by her parents, but she thinks that she didn't do wrong.
intention: Kim wants her parents to know it feels to hurt.
moral_action: Kim sits down and talks to her parents and explains how she feels.
immoral_action: Kim tells her parents that she wants to kill herself because she is so sad.

norm: It's wrong to send someone to kill your spouse.
situation: Jack and Abby have not been getting along well recently.
intention: Jack wants out of the marriage.
moral_action: Jack files for divorce.
immoral_action: Jack hires someone to kill Abby.

norm: It's wrong to threaten suicide if your partner leaves you.
situation: Mary hears her husband Jim threaten a relationship break-up due to drama which has lasted for years.
intention: Mary wants to let Jim know she doesn't want to break up.
moral_action: Mary tells Jim she doesn't want a breakup, explaining the reasons for why she thinks they should stay together.
immoral_action: Mary threatens to kill herself while talking to Jim, unless Jim decides to stay together.

norm: Is wrong to try to kill yourself
situation: Dave, who is married to Kelly is an extremely depressed man struggling with inner demons that burden him.
intention: Dave wants to be rid of his inner turmoil.
moral_action: Dave calls up a therapy clinic and asks them if he can come in to make an appointment for therapy.
immoral_action: Dave takes a knife and slits his wrists thinking that death will set him free from his darkness.

norm: It's wrong to laugh at a suicide attempt.
situation: Ken is talking with his friend Luke and tells him that he recently tried to kill himself with pills but it didn't work.
intention: Luke wants to respond to the news of the failed suicide attempt.
moral_action: Luke tells Ken that he is really concerned about him and hopes Ken will let him find help for him.
immoral_action: Luke laughs heartily and tells Ken that he's a loser who can't even get suicide right and then keeps laughing.

norm: It is okay to be concerned about your children.
situation: Amy has a six year old son.
intention: She wants to let him do something fun.
moral_action: Amy takes her son to the playground and watches him closely.
immoral_action: Amy lets her son go to a nearby playground by himself.

norm: It's okay to want to keep your baby.
situation: At only 18 years old Chastity recently found out that she is pregnant but the father Biff is encouraging her to terminate the pregnancy.
intention: Chastity wants to decide whether to comply with Biff's suggestion to end the pregnancy.
moral_action: Chastity goes against Biff's wishes and carries the pregnancy to term.
immoral_action: Chastity agrees with Biff and goes to a clinic to have an abortion.

norm: It's kind to leave a light on for your child.
situation: Martha's son had stayed out all night and it was starting to get late.
intention: Martha wanted her son to get in the house as safely as possible.
moral_action: Martha leaves the lights on under the porch so her son can see.
immoral_action: Martha called the police department and asked for them to wait outside for her son.

norm: It's okay to be protective of your child.
situation: Patty's daughter wants to go to the park with her friends, but Patty just heard something in the news about a possible kidnapper.
intention: Patty wants her daughter to be happy.
moral_action: Patty doesn't let her daughter go to the park, but she invites her friends over, so they can watch a movie together.
immoral_action: Patty lets her daughter go to the park with her friends by themselves with no supervision.

norm: People should teach children kindness and gentleness.
situation: Allison is taking her child to a playgroup for the first time.
intention: Allison wants her child to be around other children.
moral_action: Allison sees that her child has a problem taking other children's toys and tells her she must share them.
immoral_action: Allison sees her child take a toy from another child and says nothing.

norm: It's kind to take care of others' children.
situation: Mike is at work when his friend Joe calls and asks him if he can look after his kids after work as Joe has to work late.
intention: Mike wants to respond to Joe's request.
moral_action: Mike tells Joe that it's not a problem, and he'll head straight to Joe's house after work.
immoral_action: Mike tells Joe that he's not good with kids and doesn't feel comfortable with the responsibility.

norm: It's ok to be kind to other children.
situation: Pez is eating lunch at school and an unpopular girl sits next to her.
intention: Pez wants to enjoy her lunch.
moral_action: Pez talks with the girl and acts normally.
immoral_action: Pez gets up and moves somewhere else.

norm: You should be nice to children.
situation: Trevor saw Neville stumble as he tried to get up the stairs.
intention: Trevor wants to decide what to do about Neville.
moral_action: Trevor helps Neville stand up and them helps him get up the stairs.
immoral_action: Trevor walks away from the stairs and from Neville as he remains there stuck.

norm: You are allowed to protect your children.
situation: Chad brought his kid to the park, and a dog without a leash started running at her.
intention: Chad has to decide what to do.
moral_action: Chad gets in front of her kid and breaks the dog's neck.
immoral_action: Chad lets his kid get the dog off of them on their own.

norm: It's bad to be involved with someone who is married.
situation: Matt, who is single, meets two attractive women, one of them is married.
intention: Matt wants to be in a relationship.
moral_action: Matt asks the unmarried woman on a date, and they start seeing each other.
immoral_action: Matt starts an affair with the married woman.

norm: It's bad to break your marriage vows.
situation: When Harry married Minnie, he vowed to never lose his cool, but recently they've been arguing a lot.
intention: Harry wants Minnie to know how upset he's been.
moral_action: Harry tells Minnie things have been hard for him, and suggests that they seek marriage counseling.
immoral_action: Harry throws a lamp against the wall, narrowly missing Minnie's head.

norm: It's bad to enter a marriage if you aren't committed.
situation: Ben and Jane have just got married and are on honeymoon.
intention: Ben wants to go to the bar.
moral_action: Ben ask Jane if she wants to go to the bar to drink.
immoral_action: Ben tells Jane that he needs a break from her to go drink, and he goes to the bar.

norm: It's mean to balk at a bride.
situation: Alicia is a bridesmaid for her sister's wedding and has been chosen as a bridesmaid.
intention: Alicia wants to give feedback about the bridesmaid dresses.
moral_action: Alicia says the bridesmaid dresses could have some improvements and gives suggestions.
immoral_action: Alicia says the bridesmaid dresses would only look good on animals and refuses to wear them.

norm: It's bad to pretend you aren't married.
situation: Roberta is having drinks at the bar when an attractive man sits down beside her.
intention: Roberta wants to talk to the man.
moral_action: Roberta says hello to the man and sparks up a conversation about her husband.
immoral_action: Roberta quickly slides her wedding ring into her pocket and says hello to the man.

norm: It's bad to cheat when you are engaged to someone.
situation: Rosie is due to get married tomorrow, and she's starting to have some doubts.
intention: Rosie wants to be sure she's making the correct choice.
moral_action: Rosie sits down with her Fiancee and has a long talk with him about things.
immoral_action: Rosie asks an old casual hookup for one last one night stand, to see if its out of her system.

norm: It's bad to be in a loveless marriage.
situation: Celia's idea to Adam is they could get married so Adam becomes a citizen and Celia could afford a better lifestyle.
intention: Celia wants to decide if she should continue with her plan.
moral_action: Celia realizes she would end up trapped in a loveless marriage.
immoral_action: Celia and Adam get married just like her original plans.

norm: It's impolite to upstage the bride.
situation: Piper, a fashionista, has been invited to her sister's wedding that is being held in their parents' backyard.
intention: Piper wants to wear the perfect dress to her sister's wedding.
moral_action: Piper wears a knee length floral dress that matches her sister's wedding colors.
immoral_action: Piper wears a strapless red gown with a train and crystal embellishments.

norm: It's bad to cheat with someone who's married.
situation: Joey is a single man who lives alone and his neighbors wife has shown quite an interest in him.
intention: Joey wants to find a sexual partner.
moral_action: Joey does not reciprocate with the wife but rather makes a profile on a dating website.
immoral_action: Joey ends up becoming physically involved with his neighbor's wife.

norm: It's wrong to give animals food for people.
situation: Jill knows there are wild deer in the forest near her house.
intention: Jill wants to see the deer up close.
moral_action: Jill quietly waits for the deer to wander closer.
immoral_action: Jill puts a bucket of grain out for the deer to eat.

norm: It's wrong to lock people up in cages.
situation: Cheyanne is a single mother to a toddler whose been throwing lots of tantrums lately.
intention: Cheyanne wants her daughter to stop being so unruly.
moral_action: Cheyanne consults her pediatrician for advice on handling an unruly toddler.
immoral_action: Sick of her tantrums, Cheyanne decides to lock her toddler in a cage.

norm: It's not expected that a person bites an animal.
situation: Jessica is watching fireworks at home with her barking scared dog Misu, and a character in a movie talks about biting dogs ears to get them to calm down.
intention: Jessica wants to calm down Misu.
moral_action: Jessica hugs Misu and distracts her by giving her treats.
immoral_action: Jessica follows the advise given by the character in the movie and bites Misu's ear.

norm: It is abnormal for a human to eat tadpoles.
situation: John and his son Timmy were fishing at the local pond and noticed tadpoles swimming in the water.
intention: Timmy wanted to know what tadpoles tasted like.
moral_action: Timmy asked his Dad what tadpoles tasted like.
immoral_action: Timmy reached into the water, grabbed a tadpole and took a bite out of it.

norm: It is wrong to take birds out of the wild.
situation: Cal is vacationing in Hawaii.
intention: Cal wants a souvenir from his vacation.
moral_action: Cal buys trinkets from the gift shop.
immoral_action: Cal takes a bird he found in a tree with him home on the plane.

norm: It's wrong to lock your pet up in closed quarters.
situation: Don has a dog that has just torn his couch apart when left alone at home.
intention: Don wants to teach the dog not to damage the furniture.
moral_action: Don uses a scented product which is offensive to dog noses on the furniture.
immoral_action: Don closes the dog in a room as a form of discipline.

norm: It's inappropriate to pee in a produce aisle.
situation: Bill is grocery shopping when he feels a sudden urge to pee.
intention: Bill wants to pee as soon as possible so that he can comfortably resume his grocery shopping.
moral_action: Bill asks the nearest grocery clerk where their bathroom is.
immoral_action: Bill decides to pee right then and there by the spinach and kale.

norm: It's not okay to turn your home into a zoo.
situation: Gina loves animals so much and hates to see stray dogs and cats with out a home.
intention: Gina wants to take care of stray cats and dogs.
moral_action: Gina keeps only a cat and dog at home and volunteers with an animal shelter to find homes for the other strays she finds.
immoral_action: Gina takes in every stray animal she sees, her house becoming over run with animals.

norm: It's wrong to catch fish and not eat them.
situation: Frank is out at the river and has caught numerous fish during the day.
intention: Frank wants to do something with the fish.
moral_action: Frank takes the fish home and cooks them for dinner.
immoral_action: Frank leaves the fish by the river bed.

norm: It's rude to bring your animals to the grocery store.
situation: Daniel needs to make a trip to the store, but he doesn't want to leave his dog home by itself.
intention: Daniel wants to make sure his dog isn't alone.
moral_action: Daniel asks his neighbor to come over and watch his dog while he makes a trip to the store.
immoral_action: Daniel decides to bring his dog with him to the store and plans to tell people that it's a service dog.

norm: It is wrong not to feed animals.
situation: Jen, who lives with a partner, is in bed after a long day of work and watching shows on Netflix but remembers her cat's food bowl is empty.
intention: Jen wants to stay in bed and relax without having to do anything.
moral_action: Jen texts her partner while shes laying there and asks him to feed the cat.
immoral_action: Jen puts it out of her mind and continues to watch her shows.

norm: It is unsanitary to put hair in food.
situation: Marcel is cooking for a critic who gave the restaurant a bad review last time she was here, but he was not.
intention: Marcel wants to show the critic who is in charge of the kitchen.
moral_action: Marcel takes his time and perfects the dish he is serving to the critic.
immoral_action: Marcel adds a single strand of hair to the pasta.

norm: You shouldn't sleep with your teacher.
situation: Maryanne has a crush on her English teacher.
intention: Maryanne wants to be closer to her English teacher.
moral_action: Maryanne volunteers to help her English teacher grade papers.
immoral_action: Maryanne sees her teacher at a restaurant and seduces him back to her place.

norm: You shouldn't let your roommate take advantage of you.
situation: Dru lets his roommate, Cru, borrow his headphones, but they come back broken once again.
intention: Dru needs to decide if he should take action.
moral_action: Dru sternly but openly asks for repayment for the headphones.
immoral_action: Dru lets it slide.

norm: You shouldn't take advantage of your roommate's things.
situation: Sophie is home alone and notices that her roommate Amber left her cigarettes on the table.
intention: Sophie wants to smoke a cigarette.
moral_action: Sophie texts Amber to ask if she can smoke a couple of the cigarettes left on the table.
immoral_action: Sophie opens up the pack of cigarettes that Amber left and smokes all but one of them.

norm: You shouldn't let your roommate abuse your pets.
situation: Willow has a dog and lives with Parker who she knows dislikes dogs.
intention: Willow wants to find someone to watch her dog while she's on a trip.
moral_action: Willow takes her dog to a boarding kennel for a few days.
immoral_action: Willow asks Parker to watch her dog for a few days and Parker ends up not feeding the dog for several days and keeping it in a crate.

norm: You shouldn't give your roommate a curfew.
situation: Jason is about to leave to go out with his friends and tells his roommate Alan goodbye.
intention: Alan wants to respond to Jason.
moral_action: Alan tells Jason to have a great time and that he'll see him later.
immoral_action: Alan tells Jason to make sure he's back home before eleven pm or Alan will be very angry.

norm: You shouldn't let your roommate tell you where to sleep.
situation: Donna and Carol being friends rented an apartment to live in together, and they move in at different times.
intention: Carol wants to unpack her belongings.
moral_action: Carol and Donna agree to flip a coin to decide which room they use.
immoral_action: Carol moves in late and Donna going first occupied the larger room and asks Carol to take the other room.

norm: You shouldn't sleep with your housemate.
situation: Jessica, who lives with her housemate Paul, just found out that her boyfriend Brandon cheated on her.
intention: Jessica wants to get back at her Brandon.
moral_action: Jessica makes a post on social media detailing Brandon's behavior for all his friends and family to see.
immoral_action: Jessica decides to sleep with Paul in order to spite Brandon.

norm: You shouldn't sleep with your employees.
situation: John is a store owner with twelve employees that work for him.
intention: John wants to have a romantic social relationship.
moral_action: John joins a dating website and creates a profile to meet new prospective romantic partners.
immoral_action: John uses his power as a boss to urge an employee into a romantic affair with him.

norm: It's bad to stereotype people based on gender.
situation: Ben is joining a pool tournament.
intention: Ben wants to win.
moral_action: Ben notices the best player is a woman and asks her to join him.
immoral_action: Ben rejects a woman for his partner.

norm: It's sexist to treat one gender differently than another.
situation: John and his friends Steve and Mary are hiking up a mountain and come to a large boulder they need to climb over.
intention: John wants to get home in time for dinner.
moral_action: After John and Steve get over the boulder, they leave Mary behind because she is having difficulties, and they continue on their hike without her.
immoral_action: After John and Steve get over the boulder, John and Steve assist Mary who is having difficulties, and they continue on their hike.

norm: It's bad to compare your appearance to others.
situation: Pam is at her desk at her office when her coworker Leah comes over to ask if  Pam thinks her new outfit is nice.
intention: Pam wants to respond to Leah's question.
moral_action: Pam tells Leah that her outfit is awesome and that she looks great in it.
immoral_action: Pam says that Leah's outfit is OK but definitely not nice as her own outfit.

norm: It's wroong to use racist language.
situation: James gets into an argument on twitter with a black person who calls him racist slurs.
intention: James wants to tell off the person he's fighting with.
moral_action: James tells the person he's classless and that the argument got heated but no excuse for that language.
immoral_action: James responds to the racism with racism of his own directed at the black man.

norm: It's bad to see benefits to slavery.
situation: Charles is discussing slavery with a diverse group of friends, who are divided on the topic.
intention: Charles wants to come across as open-minded.
moral_action: Charles displays open-mindedness by listening to all his friends' opinions and ends up demonstrating how there were no objective benefits to slavery.
immoral_action: Charles listens to his friends and ends up saying that he can see how slavery had some benefits.

norm: It's bad to call someone a racial insult.
situation: Frank is having an argument with John who is a different race while they are at work.
intention: Frank wants to say something to John during the argument.
moral_action: Frank argues his side and sticks to work related points.
immoral_action: Frank calls John an expletive based on race.

norm: It's bad to judge people based on looks.
situation: Katie is online browsing through her matches on a dating site.
intention: Katie wants to narrow down her list.
moral_action: Katie accepts people based on the information on their profile.
immoral_action: Katie deletes a request from a man who is out of shape.

norm: It's bad to compare people based on appearances.
situation: Sarah's mother asks Sarah to compare two of her friends in terms of which one is a better friend.
intention: Sarah wants to compare her two friends.
moral_action: Sarah says that the friend who is kinder and more generous is a better friend because they set a good example for Sarah.
immoral_action: Sarah says that the friend who is skinnier and prettier is a better friend because she's just more attractive and popular.

norm: It's bad to judge someone based solely on their appearance.
situation: Jenny has gotten a notification on her phone that she has a new friend request.
intention: Jenny wants to add some new friends on social media.
moral_action: Jenny accepts the request because the profile has some interesting content on it.
immoral_action: Jenny denies the request after checking the profile because the requester is not in shape but accepts other requests from slender people.

norm: Drafting people by race is discriminatory.
situation: Yuri is the manager of a sports team and is picking players from the rookie pool to fill out his roster.
intention: Yuri wants to have a good team this year.
moral_action: Yuri picks all the players based on the positions his team needs filled and their performance reports.
immoral_action: Yuri picks only players of African decent because he thinks they are more athletic.

norm: It's bad for you to be a racist.
situation: Ron saw a video online about all of the crime that black people commit that included disingenuous stats.
intention: Ron has to decide whether to find information that debunks the video.
moral_action: Ron looks at the comments of the video to see what other people have to say about it.
immoral_action: Ron decides to believe everything in the video and becomes cautious around black people.

norm: It's bad to use racial slurs.
situation: Elena is driving home and a car driven by a person a different race than her cuts her off.
intention: Elena wants to react to being cut off.
moral_action: Elena slows down as to let the bad driver get some distance away from her to make her feel safer.
immoral_action: Elena mutters to herself comments about the other driver that are connected to their race that others might find offensive.

norm: Prejudice is wrong.
situation: David does well in college and earns his Bachelor's degree.
intention: David wants to get a good job.
moral_action: David continues his job search.
immoral_action: After being denied a job because of a racist boss, David decides to deal drugs.

norm: Vandalism is wrong.
situation: "Mark notices a ""for sale"" sign on his neighbor's home and thinks it'd be the perfect place to try out his new paint."
intention: Mark wants to paint his neighbor's home.
moral_action: Mark asks his neighbor if he needs help freshening up his exterior paint.
immoral_action: Mark paints profanities on his neighbors home in the night.

norm: Racism is unacceptable.
situation: Kim has her house broken into for the second time by a member of the same racial background as the last time.
intention: Kim wants to vent her frustrations about what happened to her.
moral_action: Kim tells a friend and focuses only on the crime itself.
immoral_action: Kim talks with a friend and asserts the blame to the racial group as a whole.

norm: Plagiarism is wrong.
situation: Terri received an advance from her publisher for a novel but feels uninspired.
intention: Terri wants her novel to be successful.
moral_action: Terri works hard on her novel and finds inspiration in her own life.
immoral_action: Terri decides to borrow copious parts of an old, unknown novel.

norm: Being dishonest is wrong.
situation: Ed is a used care salesman at at local dealership.
intention: Ed wants to best his monthly quota by selling one more vehicle.
moral_action: Ed points out that the car is not a very good option and shows the buyer a more reliable vehicle that meets his requirements.
immoral_action: Ed misrepresents a car's maintenance history  in order to make a sale.

norm: Racism is wrong.
situation: Ike, a cop, searches for a necklace stealing criminal when he notices a black man in a hoodie exiting the store.
intention: Ike wants to catch the criminal quickly.
moral_action: Ike asks the people around him if they noticed any suspicious activity.
immoral_action: Ike questions the black man, and he takes the black man into the office for intense questioning.

norm: Cheating is wrong.
situation: Dale finds an answer sheet for an upcoming test on his math teacher's desk.
intention: Dale wants to figure out what to do with the answer sheet.
moral_action: Dale leaves the answer sheet and studies for the test.
immoral_action: Dale takes the answer sheet and copies down the answers.

norm: Littering is wrong.
situation: Charlotte finishes drinking her water bottle in the middle of a long hike.
intention: Charlotte wants to get rid of the water bottle.
moral_action: Charlotte carries her water bottle down the trail until she finds a trash dispenser near a rest area.
immoral_action: Charlotte looks around and tosses her water bottle into the forest.

norm: Theft is wrong.
situation: Vanessa is looking around in the mall when she sees a shirt she likes.
intention: Vanessa wants to take the shirt home.
moral_action: Vanessa takes the shirt and brings it to the register to pay for it.
immoral_action: Vanessa tries on the shirt and walks out the store without paying.

norm: Lying is wrong.
situation: Gal is applying for a job as an accountant even though they don't have any experience.
intention: Gal wants to become an accountant.
moral_action: Gal tells the interviewer she is willing to start off as an intern.
immoral_action: Gal tells the interviewer that she's currently a full-time accountant.

norm: It is wrong to act unprofessionally with a patient.
situation: Julie is meeting with a patient who likes to joke around and not be serious.
intention: Julie wants to provide good care to her patient.
moral_action: Julie remains professional and does not make any jokes.
immoral_action: Julie makes jokes with her patient about her diagnosis and treatment.

norm: It's wrong to lie about having migraines.
situation: Tom has been feeling rundown and tired lately.
intention: Tom doesn't want to go to work.
moral_action: Tom calls in to work and explains that he needs a mental health day.
immoral_action: Tom calls in sick to work and pretends to have a strong headache.

norm: It's wrong to lie about sickness.
situation: Brendan is scheduled to work during opening day of the baseball season.
intention: Brendan wants to go to the baseball game.
moral_action: Brendan asks his boos if there are options to get the time off.
immoral_action: Brendan calls out of work stating that he is sick with a stomach bug.

norm: It's wrong to lie about pregnancy.
situation: Peggy is at a party, and she realizes that no one is paying attention to her.
intention: Peggy wants people to start talking to her.
moral_action: Peggy starts mingling with the other people at the party.
immoral_action: Peggy tells everyone that she found out she is pregnant.

norm: It is foolish to ignore the advice of your doctor.
situation: Reggie is ordering a dessert at a restaurant, though his doctor has warned him he needs to lose weight, or he may have a heart attack.
intention: Reggie wants to eat dessert.
moral_action: Reggie orders a small cookie and eats only that for dessert.
immoral_action: Reggie orders a large ice cream sundae and eats the whole thing.

norm: It's wrong to miss having a medical disorder.
situation: Benjamin is a child and just had his cast removed from a recovered broken leg.
intention: Benjamin wants attention from his parents.
moral_action: Benjamin runs and jumps around in front of his parents as best as he can on his recovered leg.
immoral_action: Benjamin tries to call for his parents help getting things like he had to when he had a cast because he liked having things done for him.

norm: It's wrong to lie to your therapist.
situation: After witnessing a shooting at work Jon is ordered to see a therapist before he can return to his job.
intention: Jon wants to get through his sessions.
moral_action: Jon is open and honest with the therapist.
immoral_action: Jon decides to say what he thinks the therapist wants to hear in order to get cleared to work.

norm: It's wrong to lie to your doctor.
situation: Carl is getting a checkup at his doctor's office, but he is embarrassed about how many sexual partners he has had.
intention: Carl wants to get through with the checkup.
moral_action: Carl tells the doctor that he has had sex with many different women of the last year.
immoral_action: Carl tells the doctor he is not sexually active, even though he's had sex with multiple women over the last year.

norm: It is wrong to perform a medical procedure without consent.
situation: Dr. Doom recommended a few surgeries be preformed on the patient, but they declined some of them.
intention: Dr. Doom wants the patient to live.
moral_action: Dr. Doom recommends other treatments for the issues if the patient doesn't want surgery.
immoral_action: Dr. Doom preforms all the surgeries he reccomends anyway.

norm: Parents are expected to help children learn good habits.
situation: Amber and her son Billy  are at the playground together near a family playing ball.
intention: Amber wants Billy to learn to play ball as well.
moral_action: When Billy signals that he wants to play with the ball, Amber encourages him to ask.
immoral_action: Amber doesn't say anything when Billy runs and takes the other family's ball.

norm: Parents should support what their children do.
situation: James' son Neil comes home one day during a break from college and says he wants to drop out to become a musician.
intention: James wants to respond to Neil's statement.
moral_action: James tells his son that it's risky, but he supports his son's dreams and if there's any way he can help to let him know.
immoral_action: James tells his son that he's an idiot for taking such a huge risk with something unstable like music over something so solid like college.

norm: Parents should take charge of their children's health.
situation: Nancy's son skinned his knee while biking outside and is treating the wound.
intention: Nancy wants the wound to heal.
moral_action: Nancy has her son report to her twice a day to clean and re-bandage the wound.
immoral_action: Nancy instructs her son on how to care for the wound, including cleaning and re-bandaging it.

norm: Parents should encourage their children to get exercise.
situation: Sara has a son who has recently been doing very well in school with high grades.
intention: Sara wants to reward her son.
moral_action: Sara buys her son a dancing game and an Xbox Kinect.
immoral_action: Sara buys her son a traditional popular video game.

norm: Parents should acknowledge important milestones in a child's life.
situation: Fred's son recently graduated from college and invites Fred to attend his graduation.
intention: Fred wants to respond to the invitation.
moral_action: Fred accepts the invitation and clears out his schedule to attend his son's graduation.
immoral_action: Fred ignores the invitation and never shows up at his son's graduation.

norm: Parents should look out for what's best for their children.
situation: Jake's son asks Jake if he can buy a motorcycle and learn to ride it.
intention: Jake wants his son to have a vehicle.
moral_action: Jake says that motorcycles aren't very safe and offers to help buy his son a car.
immoral_action: "Jake says, ""Sure, do what you want,"" allowing his son to get the motorcycle."

norm: Parents are allowed to decide what's best for their children.
situation: Angel and his friend Roy are arguing about what movies each of thier kids watch.
intention: "Angel wants to explain that Roy's kids are allowed to watch ""worse"" movies than his own."
moral_action: Angel decides that Roy can decide what's best for his own kids but not Angel's.
immoral_action: Angel and Roy both insist that the other's kids should have to follow their set of rules on what to watch.

norm: Children should help their parents take care of their homes
situation: Sarah's parents are always busy with their work and their house becomes messy without proper care.
intention: Sarah wants to respond to the messiness.
moral_action: Sarah skips hanging out with her friends after school and spends time cleaning up the house.
immoral_action: Sarah acts as if she was very busy with her homework and her mom ends up having to clean other parts of their house after a busy day of work.

norm: Parents should protect their children.
situation: James' toddler throws an enormous fit every time James tries to put him in his car seat.
intention: James wants his toddler to be quiet during the car ride.
moral_action: James bribes his toddler with two cookies if he sits in the car seat.
immoral_action: James lets his toddler sit in the back with no car seat or seat belt.

norm: Parents should take their kids on fun outings.
situation: During the Coronavirus pandemic, Joan's children are kept staying home because their schools have been closed.
intention: Joan wants to arrange activities for her children.
moral_action: Joan takes her children out to ride bikes on nearby bike trails.
immoral_action: Joan asks her children to read books and draw pictures at home in order not to catch the virus.

norm: Parents are expected to show support for their children's interests.
situation: Verlin is at his computer struggling to pay the bills when his son asks if he can take karate classes.
intention: Verlin wants to save money.
moral_action: Verlin decides to cancel several streaming services they don't need in order to pay for karate classes.
immoral_action: Verlin tells his son that martial arts is a complete waste of resources as he continues looking at his screen.

norm: It is important that children see parents getting along
situation: Ken and his wife, Marion, have two kids together but have been arguing a lot lately.
intention: Ken wants to sit down with Marion to talk about their problems.
moral_action: Ken and Marion start seeing a counselor and apply their conflict avoidance skills in the home.
immoral_action: Ken and Marion start talking, which eventually leads to them arguing in front of their children.

norm: Parents should help their children.
situation: Ian's is studying for his final exams at college and also working full time which he finds exhausting.
intention: Ian's son wants to pass his final exams and have money.
moral_action: Ian assists his son with finances so his son can focus on his studies during exams.
immoral_action: Ian lets his son experience the struggle of studying while working without offering any assistance.

norm: It's important for parents to agree how to raise children
situation: John and his wife are taking their daughter from soccer practice on a weekday evening.
intention: John wants his daughter to be great soccer player.
moral_action: John and his wife form a joint plan on how to get their daughter both enjoy soccer and be competitive at it.
immoral_action: John actively pushes his daughter to try harder on the field, but his constant intervention frustrates his wife, who just wants her to have fun.

norm: Parents should get their kids the gifts that they want.
situation: Dave's daughter Kim had previously asked Dave for a bike for her birthday and now Dave is in the store shopping.
intention: Dave wants to decide what to buy.
moral_action: Dave finds the exact bike that Kim wanted and takes it to the cash register to buy it.
immoral_action: Dave sees some books that he thinks would be useful for Kim's development and decides to buy them for her.

norm: Parents should watch their children.
situation: Bob's kids are outside playing in the neighborhood with the other kids.
intention: Bob wants to watch the football game on TV.
moral_action: Bob takes intervals during commercials and halftime to watch his kids.
immoral_action: Bob spend all the time watching the football game on TV with his buddies.

norm: You shouldn't forget to pick up your kids.
situation: John has a bunch of errands to run, including picking up the kids from soccer practice and buying groceries for dinner.
intention: John wants to make sure he what he needs to cook dinner.
moral_action: John goes to pick up the kids from soccer practice and buys groceries on the way back.
immoral_action: John goes to the grocery store and picks up what he needs, and then heads home.

norm: It's encouraged you listen to your parents and behave
situation: Gary's parents told him to stay home because he has been running a fever.
intention: Gary wants to do something fun.
moral_action: Gary turns on the television and watches cartoons while he lays in bed.
immoral_action: Gary goes to the park with his friends when his parents leave the house.

norm: It's expected to support the decisions of your adult children.
situation: Jenna called her dad and said that she wanted to switch her major from pre-law to theater.
intention: Jenna's dad wants her to have a stable career.
moral_action: Jenna's dad counters with the idea that she major in theater and minor in computer science.
immoral_action: Jenna's dad tells her that if she switches her major, he'll refuse to sign her FAFSA.

norm: Children are expected to communicate with their parents regularly.
situation: Zach, who lives with his parents, is invited by some friends to a late-night party.
intention: Zach wants to go to the party.
moral_action: Zach calls his parents and asks to go to the party.
immoral_action: "Zach goes to the party and doesn't call his parents, so they can't say ""no""."

norm: A kid should listen to their parents.
situation: Alice is helping her dad cook pasta in the kitchen, and her dad tells her not to touch the pot of boiling water he just took off the stove.
intention: Alice wants to put some pasta in the boiling water.
moral_action: Alice puts the pasta in the water and keeps her other hand in her pocket.
immoral_action: Alice touches the side of the pot of boiling hot water as she puts the pasta in.

norm: Parents are expected to have faith in their children.
situation: Todd's daughter wants to be an actress.
intention: Todd wants to help his daughter financially.
moral_action: Todd tells his daughter he will support her financially for a year, after which he knows she will be able to support herself through her acting.
immoral_action: Todd tells his daughter he will support her financially because he does not think she can support herself with her acting.

norm: Children are expected to ask for permission from their parents.
situation: Jimmy hears that a carnival is coming to town this weekend.
intention: Jimmy wants to go to the carnival.
moral_action: Jimmy asks his mother and dad if they would take him to the carnival.
immoral_action: Jimmy, knowing that his parents might say no if he asks to go to the carnival, sneaks out the day the event starts and enters without his parents permission.

norm: It's expected that parents be diligent in watching their children.
situation: Amy is very busy with her career so it's been hard for her spend time with her kids.
intention: Amy wants her kids to be taken care of.
moral_action: Amy spends less time at work so that she can see her kids more.
immoral_action: Amy hires a nanny to look after her kids, because she's too busy.

norm: Kids are expected to obey their parents.
situation: Mary gets in trouble by her mom and is told to go to her room by her mom.
intention: Marcy wants to leave the room.
moral_action: Marcy decides to follow directions and go to her own room.
immoral_action: Marcy decides to leave the room by exiting the house.

norm: People are expected to listen to their parents.
situation: Helen's parents told her not to talk to strangers, and she sees a stranger at the end of her block who offers some candy.
intention: Helen wants some candy.
moral_action: Helen runs back to her parents and tells them she would like some candy.
immoral_action: Helen asks the stranger for some candy, getting close to him.

norm: It is expected that you take care of your children
situation: Sara is at a playground with her children along with one of her friends and the friend's children.
intention: Sara wants to discuss something that's been troubling her with her friend in private.
moral_action: Sara and her friend text back and forth about Sara's troubles while they watch their children play.
immoral_action: Sara pulls her friend aside and lets her children play unsupervised while she explains her problem.

norm: It's expected that you make thoughtful decisions as a parent.
situation: Debra has two children she is the mother of and it is lunch time.
intention: Debra wants to feed her children lunch.
moral_action: Debra feeds her children a meal of chicken and vegetables.
immoral_action: Debra feeds her children fried foods and soda to drink.

norm: It's wrong to manipulate people into buying you things.
situation: Linda is browsing on the internet.
intention: Linda wants to buy some new jewelry.
moral_action: Linda sees a necklace that she likes and buys it with her credit card.
immoral_action: Linda guilt trips her partner into buying her a new diamond bracelet.

norm: It's wrong to take advantage of stores' return policies.
situation: Mark has too much winter clothing.
intention: Mark wants to get rid of some of his clothes.
moral_action: Mark donates some sweaters he doesn't need to Goodwill.
immoral_action: Mark takes several sweaters he didn't buy at a store to a store and complains that he wants to return them for a full refund.

norm: It's wrong to deceive a customer.
situation: Jack is a salesperson and there are large incentives given for selling customers add-ons with products.
intention: Jack wants to earn a large bonus to purchase a gift.
moral_action: Jack provides a great reason explaining the value of the add-ons to the customer up front.
immoral_action: Jack opts the customer into buying add-ons and the customer signs without realizing it.

norm: It's wrong to keep returning the things you bought.
situation: Sabrina is very poor and doesn't have good looking clothes, but is regularly invited out on dates.
intention: Sabrina wants to impress her friends with her sense of style.
moral_action: Sabrina goes to good will and spends a few hours putting together multiple outfits from their charity bin.
immoral_action: Every time Sabrina has a date she goes and buys new clothes, and then returns them the following day.

norm: It's wrong to rob a store.
situation: Ben is at the local grocery store a few hours after losing his job.
intention: Ben wants a way to get extra money.
moral_action: Ben asks the manager of the store if they are hiring.
immoral_action: Ben holds up the cashier at the store and tells them to empty the register.

norm: It's wrong to shoplift.
situation: Bobby is at the mall when he sees a shirt he thinks he'd look good in.
intention: Bobby wants to take the shirt he saw back home with him.
moral_action: Bobby pays for the shirt with his credit card and takes it home in a bag.
immoral_action: Bobby stuffs the shirt down his pants and walks out of the store casually and goes home.

norm: It's wrong for merchants to deceive customers.
situation: Peter is selling used appliances and has some customers looking at a dishwasher that he knows doesn't work properly.
intention: Peter wants to make the sale.
moral_action: Peter admits that the dishwasher has issues and offers to give the customers a large enough discount to cover repairs.
immoral_action: Peter tells the customers that the dishwasher works great and guarantees they'll like it.

norm: It's wrong steal something from a store.
situation: Christine is at the mall when she remembers she has a work dinner coming up.
intention: Christine wants to find a nice dress to wear to her work dinner.
moral_action: Christine shops around until she finds a dress that is within her budget.
immoral_action: Christine spots a dress she likes that is out of her budget, so she tosses it into her purse when shop employees aren't looking.

norm: It's wrong to expected people to buy you things
situation: Kyle, who receives money for doing chores around the house, is a teenager who learns about a sequel to his favorite video game series coming out.
intention: Kyle wants to obtain the game.
moral_action: Kyle saves up his allowance money in order to buy the game for himself.
immoral_action: Kyle goes up to his parents and asks them to buy the game for him.

norm: It's wrong to steal things from stores.
situation: Robert is at the mall when he realizes that it is father's day but he is low on funds.
intention: Robert wants to save money on a father's day gift.
moral_action: Robert uses a credit card to buy the gift for his dad.
immoral_action: Robert finds something for his dad and slips it into his pocket without paying.

norm: It's not okay to question what people buy for themselves.
situation: Lacy is hanging out with her friend Joan when Joan shows Lacy her new expensive watch.
intention: Lacy wants to comment on the watch.
moral_action: Lacy tells Joan that it's good Joan buys things that make her happy.
immoral_action: Lacy tells Joan that the watch is a waste of money.

norm: It's not your place to ruin someone's life.
situation: John witnesses his coworker cheating on their wife.
intention: John wants his coworker to stop.
moral_action: John confronts his coworker about their actions.
immoral_action: John tells his coworker's wife about them.

norm: You shouldn't complain when someone is being helpful.
situation: Richard got home from the hospital after having surgery.
intention: Richard wants to move from his bed to the couch to watch tv.
moral_action: Richard asks his friend if he'll help him get to the couch safely to watch tv.
immoral_action: Richard yells at his friend for almost dropping him while carrying him to the couch.

norm: You shoul not steal from people who trust you.
situation: Donald sees a computer game he really wants at his best friend John's house.
intention: Donald wants to take the game home to play it.
moral_action: Donald asks John if he can borrow the game for a few weeks.
immoral_action: Donald puts the game in his backpack without telling John.

norm: You don't have to tip for bad service.
situation: Roy has had a very bad experience at a restaurant because the server is careless as well as rude.
intention: Roy wants to express his discontent about the service.
moral_action: Roy complains about the service to the manager and doesn't leave any tip.
immoral_action: Roy mentioned his dish made prepared incorrectly but leaves a small tip anyway.

norm: There is no need to be mean with your siblings.
situation: Janet goes to her brother Joe's room to ask him if he thinks her shoes go with her dress.
intention: Joe wants to answer Janet's question.
moral_action: Joe tells Janet that they do go together and that she looks great.
immoral_action: Joe tells Janet that everything on her looks hideous and that she shouldn't bother trying.

norm: You shouldn't blame family members.
situation: Liam is drawing a picture in the kitchen while his wife is trying to cook dinner when she accidentally bumps into him, and he ruins the picture.
intention: Liam wants to react to being bumped.
moral_action: Liam tells his wife it's his own fault that he got bumped, he shouldn't have been in the kitchen.
immoral_action: Liam tells his wife that she's so clumsy and that she completely ruined his almost perfect picture.

norm: You shoudln't humiliate people.
situation: Mike is at a gathering when he sees a little child who has wet his pants and looks embarrassed.
intention: Mike wants to get the child a change of clothing.
moral_action: Mike finds one of the parents and whispers to him that his son could use some help from him.
immoral_action: Mike finds the child's parent and talks above the nearby people, telling him that his son has wet his pants.

norm: You shouldn't worry your parents.
situation: Karen had a date planned with her boyfriend, but she hadn't told her parents yet.
intention: Karen has to decide whether to tell her parents where she's going.
moral_action: Karen tells her parents about her date and gives them his phone number.
immoral_action: Karen sneaks out of her house and doesn't tell her parents what she's doing.

norm: It is not okey to make co workers uncomfortable.
situation: Gail works at a bar and is chatting with a handful of coworkers.
intention: Gail wants to impress her coworkers.
moral_action: Gail shows her coworkers how good and fast she can make the new drink on the menu.
immoral_action: Gail brags about her sexual prowess and describes her encounters in great detail.

norm: You shouldn't become an alcoholic.
situation: John is a newly hired wine taster.
intention: John wants to become very knowledgeable about different types of wine.
moral_action: John tastes a lot of wine for his job, but he spits it out rather than swallow it.
immoral_action: John drinks a lot of wine every day for his job and becomes addicted to it.

norm: You shouldn't molest someone who is passed out.
situation: Karen drank too much at a party and is passed out on her roommate Chuck's bed.
intention: Chuck wants to get Karen onto her own bed.
moral_action: Chuck carries Karen to her bed and puts her in a safe position in case she gets sick.
immoral_action: Chuck carries Karen to her bed and removes her clothes, fondling her body as he does so.

norm: You shouldn't get your friends drunk
situation: A group of college students are at a bar on a Tuesday to console one of them who got dumped.
intention: Kevin wants to make his depressed friend feel better.
moral_action: Kevin tells his friend all the good things he has going for him.
immoral_action: Kevin keeps buying his friend shots all throughout the night.

norm: You shouldn't be around people that drink if you're underage.
situation: Ross, a sixteen year old, is at a crowded party alone.
intention: Josh wants to make friends.
moral_action: Josh walks into the pool area and talks to some people he knows from school.
immoral_action: Josh joins a group of twenty five year olds who are doing body shots.

norm: You shouldn't get drunk around people.
situation: Larry is at a party with his friends.
intention: Larry wants to have some beers and relax.
moral_action: Larry has two beers and sticks with water and soda after that.
immoral_action: Larry gets drunk, dances around naked and is has no memory of the night.

norm: You shouldn't drive when you are intoxicated.
situation: Jenna ended up ordering a lot more drinks at the bar than she planned to when she drove there.
intention: Jenna wants to get home without spending a lot of money.
moral_action: Jenna calls her friend who just got off work to come give her a ride.
immoral_action: Jenna decides to drive home even though she's pretty sure she's drunk.

norm: You shouldn't become addicted to alcohol.
situation: Bob is a frequent drinker who enjoy trying new beers and wines.
intention: Bob wants to drink to relax.
moral_action: Bob never drinks more than three drinks in a day and three and tries to not drink a few times a week.
immoral_action: Bob drinks more and more as time progresses until he get to over 30 drinks a day.

norm: You shouldn't talk to people when you're intoxicated.
situation: Eric is drunk at a party with some friends when he sees that his mom is calling him.
intention: Eric wants his mom to know that he's OK.
moral_action: Eric hands the phone to a sober friend and tells him to reassure her.
