moral_action: Tony worked hard at becoming a better player and regained his spot as the starting quarterback.
immoral_action: Tony told his coach that he was quitting the football team and was going to try to become a famous rapper.

norm: It's frowned upon to be selfish.
situation: Sally's mom gave her a bag of chocolates to share with her classmates.
intention: Sally wants to eat chocolate.
moral_action: Sally takes some of the chocolates for herself then shares the rest with the whole class.
immoral_action: Sally keeps the whole bag of chocolates for herself, eating it all by the end of the day.

norm: It's frowned upon to be a dictator.
situation: John's boss has put him in charge of an important project with several of his other coworkers.
intention: John wants to lead his team.
moral_action: John moves everyone into the same office dividing the tasks evenly among everyone, and he asks anyone who has problems to come to him directly.
immoral_action: John insists that his teammates follow tight guidelines and frequently checks on his coworkers three times an hour.

norm: It's frowned upon to fight.
situation: Dave is shopping with his wife Ann when a stranger, Bill shouts that his wife Ann is fat.
intention: Dave wants to reprimand Bill for insulting his wife.
moral_action: Dave shouts back at Bill that he must be a classless peasant to say such things to strangers.
immoral_action: Dave runs over to Bill and proceeds to start punching Bill in the face repeatedly until Bill falls down.

norm: Outbursts are frowned upon.
situation: Mary's kid broke a vase at home by accident.
intention: Mary wants her kid  to answer for the damage.
moral_action: Mary asks her kid to explain the accident and promise to be careful next time.
immoral_action: Mary gets very furious while questioning her kid about the accident.

norm: It's frowned upon to pick your nose.
situation: John's nose feels congested while at school.
intention: John wants to clear his nasal passages.
moral_action: John goes to the bathroom and blows his nose.
immoral_action: John picks his nose in class.

norm: Smoking is frowned upon.
situation: Arnold is visiting his friend at his friend's house for dinner one night.
intention: Arnold wants to smoke a cigarette.
moral_action: Arnold goes outside and lights up his cigarette away from the others.
immoral_action: Arnold lights up a cigarette at the table when he is finished eating.

norm: Cheating is frowned upon.
situation: Jon is taking an exam in his math class this is worth 50% of his final grade.
intention: Jon really wants to pass.
moral_action: Jon studies hard and tries his best on the exam.
immoral_action: Jon copies the answers of the smart kid that sits right in front of him.

norm: It's frowned upon to be self centered.
situation: Bob takes Jamal's bike because Bob wants a bike for himself.
intention: Jamal wants to teach Bob a lesson.
moral_action: Jamal points out to Bob that if he cares for others, others will care for him too.
immoral_action: Jamal takes everything he can from Bob because Jamal wants things for Jamal.

norm: Losing your temper is frowned upon.
situation: Ray and his wife Ellen are out of town and are looking for a restaurant.
intention: Ray wants Ellen to help him with the directions, so he can keep his eye on the road.
moral_action: When Ellen gives Ray the wrong directions, and he realizes they went the wrong way he tells her to look at the directions again.
immoral_action: When Ellen gives Ray the wrong directions by mistake he takes a wrong turn, so he gets mad and yells at her.

norm: Arrogance is frowned upon.
situation: Jake just landed a big client for the financial management company he is working at.
intention: Jake wants to be admired by his peers.
moral_action: Jake discusses the new client with his coworkers and is proud, yet modest about the whole thing.
immoral_action: Jake boasts about securing the client and how he used this clever technique to woo them.

norm: It's frowned upon to be aggressive.
situation: Brad is at a party and sees a girl he is attracted to.
intention: Brad wants to make a move on the girl.
moral_action: Brad casually chats with the girl and stops after she showed no interest.
immoral_action: Brad keeps hitting on the girl despite the girl telling him how she wasn't interested.

norm: It's frowned upon to be lazy.
situation: Baxter arrives home from work tired, but he needs to do his taxes.
intention: Baxter wants to do something relaxing.
moral_action: Baxter turns on an episode of his favorite television show while he does his taxes.
immoral_action: Baxter takes a long nap followed by several rounds of his favorite video game.

norm: Showing off is frowned upon.
situation: Benny is at a local fair where a man named Ken is breathing fire and wowing the crowd.
intention: Benny wants to react to the fire breather.
moral_action: Benny says to the crowd that Ken is really impressive and that he's never seen anything like it.
immoral_action: Benny says to the crowd that the fire breather isn't all that impressive, and he can do better, then proceeds to dance for them.

norm: Bullying is mean.
situation: Tom finds out a classmate of his stole a pencil from him without asking.
intention: Tom wants to teach his classmate a lesson for stealing.
moral_action: Tom tells his classmate to stop stealing, using examples, without being mean.
immoral_action: Tom comes up with mean nicknames for his classmate and taunts him the rest of the schoolyear.

norm: Nudity is frowned upon.
situation: Brad is sitting at home naked just relaxing, when his doorbell suddenly rings.
intention: Brad wants to respond to the doorbell ringing.
moral_action: Brad tells the people at the door that they need to wait a minute before he can come answer, so he can get dressed.
immoral_action: Brad goes to his front door and opens it to see who's ringing the doorbell.

norm: Yelling is frowned upon.
situation: Jeremy is walking past the doors of a testing area when he receives a text about winning a prize.
intention: Jeremy wants to express his excitement.
moral_action: Jeremy makes a post on Twitter about his big win.
immoral_action: Jeremy declares that he's one in a loud tone that echos down the halls.

norm: It's frowned upon to be overly dramatic.
situation: Someone stole Tara's $5 bracelet, and she hasn't told anyone yet.
intention: Tara wants to tell her friends that her bracelet was stolen.
moral_action: Tara tells her friends that someone stole her bracelet, but she's glad that she can buy a new one.
immoral_action: Tara tells her friends that someone stole her super expensive bracelet with tears in her eyes.

norm: It's frowned upon to be insane.
situation: Frank and his friends were at a baseball game, and they were getting bored.
intention: Frank wanted to make his friends laugh.
moral_action: Frank tells his friends a humorous story about something that happened to him.
immoral_action: Frank runs onto the field without his clothes on and starts running all over the field.

norm: It's frowned upon to be rude.
situation: Zach who isn't wearing  a watch is asked by a stranger, Nick if he knows what time it is.
intention: Zach wants to tell Nick he doesn't know the time.
moral_action: Zach tells Nick that unfortunately he doesn't own a watch, so he has no idea.
immoral_action: Zach tells Nick that he's a moron for not seeing that he's not wearing a watch so Nick should realize that he doesn't know.

norm: It's frowned upon to overeat.
situation: Joseph has been invited by his mother to eat at her house.
intention: Joseph wants to serve himself.
moral_action: Joseph serves himself a moderate amount of food in his plate.
immoral_action: Joseph serves himself and eats three servings of the food.

norm: It's frowned upon to be loud.
situation: Marcus stand in the hallway next to the testing area checking the results of his test, and he receives a perfect score.
intention: Marcus wants to express his excitement.
moral_action: Marcus shares the results of his test on Facebook and Twitter.
immoral_action: Marcus exclaims that he made a perfect score on the exam in a loud tone jumping up and down.

norm: It's frowned upon to be shallow.
situation: Ina is walking to Sephora to buy a lot of makeup, but she walked past a homeless family on her way there.
intention: Ina has to decide what to spend some of her money on.
moral_action: Ina gives some of her money to the family since they needed it more.
immoral_action: Ina thinks about how better she would look with all the makeup she could buy.

norm: It's frowned upon to accuse people without proof.
situation: Maria works at a bakery.
intention: Mary wants to find out who is stealing from the bakery.
moral_action: Mary sets up cameras and figures out who is stealing from her.
immoral_action: Mary decides one of her employees is stealing because he works nights when she's not there.

norm: It is important to not praise yourself too much.
situation: Ted is a professional swimmer and is preparing for a big event.
intention: Ted wants to improve his self-esteem.
moral_action: Ted improves his swimming technique and times himself to track his improvement.
immoral_action: Ted constantly repeats that he is the greatest swimmer alive.

norm: It's frowned upon to want to harm yourself.
situation: Chris is feeling overwhelmed by his school work and employment and is talking to his friend Mary.
intention: Chris wants to feel relief from his stress.
moral_action: Chris tells Mary that he needs some support and help in managing his life.
immoral_action: Chris tells Mary that the only thing that helps him feel better is burning himself and that he wants to immediately.

norm: It's not okay to waste time because your so selective.
situation: Jones is trying to decide what he should write his book about.
intention: Jones wants to write a good book.
moral_action: "Jones decides to let an RNG just ""pick"" certain things and stick with them."
immoral_action: Jones keeps changing his mind and wastes lots of time on the title, the font, and what genre the book should be.

norm: It's frowned upon to spend resources frivolously.
situation: Xavier is out of work thanks to COVID-19 and gets a stimulus check from the government.
intention: Xavier wants to spend the money.
moral_action: Xavier puts some of the money in the bank and uses the rest to buy bulk food items.
immoral_action: Xavier celebrates by going on vacation and renting a hotel room for a week.

norm: It's frowned upon to be invasive into someone's life.
situation: Sasha watches Hannah leave the room for some water leaving her computer open.
intention: Sasha wants to learn more about Hannah.
moral_action: Sasha asks Hannah questions about her life.
immoral_action: Sasha looks through Hannah's computer reading her files.

norm: It's frowned upon to discuss the value of gifts.
situation: Susan receives a high tech and fancy looking bread maker as a wedding gift from her friend Samantha.
intention: Susan wants to find out more about the gift.
moral_action: Susan asks Samantha where she got the gift.
immoral_action: Susan asks Samantha how much the gift cost.

norm: It's frowned upon to wear revealing clothing to work.
situation: Christine is in her bedroom getting ready for work in the morning.
intention: Christine wants to decide what to wear.
moral_action: Christine picks out a nice pant suit with some smart flat top shoes to wear to work.
immoral_action: Christine picks out a really tight miniskirt and a low cut top that accentuates her cleavage.

norm: It's frowned upon to tell people what to do.
situation: Wyatt is relaxing at home when his wife Jody tells him she's going out shopping.
intention: Wyatt wants to react to Jody's statement.
moral_action: Wyatt tells Jody to drive safely and to have a great time out and about.
immoral_action: Wyatt tells Jody she can't go because he doesn't want her spending their money and forbids her from leaving.

norm: It's unacceptable to not repay your debts.
situation: Lori borrowed twenty dollars from Pete last week and is getting paid today.
intention: Lori wants to buy herself a dress.
moral_action: Lori pays Pete back, pays her bills, and gets a dress at the local thrift shop.
immoral_action: Lori spends her entire paycheck on rent and on one dress, leaving nothing to repay Pete with.

norm: It's frowned upon to spread conspiracy theories.
situation: Kyle hears a friend at school strongly defending their opinion that the Earth is flat.
intention: Kyle wants to gain his friend's approval.
moral_action: Kyle looks up information online and has a civil conversation with his friend about what he read.
immoral_action: Kyle decides to tell others that the Earth is flat when his friend is around and uses his friend's arguments when doing so.

norm: It's frowned upon to purchase counterfeit goods.
situation: Steve's old family watch drops down a sewer pipe.
intention: Steve needs a new watch.
moral_action: Steve buys a moderately priced watch from Walmart, at a nice price limit.
immoral_action: Steve goes to a street in NYC where he knows bootleggers sell counterfeits, and he buys a fake Rolex.

norm: It's frowned upon to fail to return a high-five.
situation: Reese is walking up to the podium during high HS graduation ceremony, where his principal is standing with an arm raised for a high-five.
intention: Reese wants to accept his diploma.
moral_action: Reese high-fives his principal, does a little dance, and goes off stage with his diploma in hand.
immoral_action: Reese takes the diploma from his principal's hand and walks off the stage wordlessly.

norm: It is considered uncivil to not leave when asked to.
situation: Colt went to a bar, but the employees didn't want him inside since he was wearing a t-shirt with Che Guevara on it.
intention: Colt wants to drink some beer.
moral_action: Colt decides to leave and go to another bar instead.
immoral_action: Colt decides to stay at the bar because he doesn't want to go elsewhere.

norm: It's frowned upon to go back on your word.
situation: Charles, a journalist, invites Martin, a criminal with a record, to an interview and promises him safety from prosecution.
intention: Charles wants to keep Martin from committing more crimes.
moral_action: Charles has the interview and tries to convince Martin to leave a life of crime.
immoral_action: Charles contacts the police and has them show up at the meeting and arrest Martin.

norm: It's frowned upon to not have a job.
situation: Keith was living with his parents in the basement of their house.
intention: Keith wanted to play video games every day.
moral_action: Keith got a job doing video game reviews on the internet.
immoral_action: Instead of working, Keith played video games in the basement everyday.

norm: It's frowned upon to fantasize about violence.
situation: Stan just had a bad argument with a customer, and he can't stop thinking about it.
intention: Stan wants to think about what he'll do the next time it happens.
moral_action: Stan thinks about what he'll say to diffuse the situation the next time.
immoral_action: Stan imagines grabbing the customer by the throat and throwing them against the wall.

norm: It's uncaring to avoid your friends.
situation: Kyle is playing video games when his phone starts ringing, and he can see it's from his friend John.
intention: Kyle wants the phone to stop ringing.
moral_action: Kyle answers the phone and says hello to his friend John.
immoral_action: Kyle quickly puts the phone on mute, stopping the phone from ringing.

norm: It's considered inappropriate to use explicit language in work communications.
situation: Francine is composing an email to her work group after they lost a big account.
intention: Francine wants to express her disappointment through the email.
moral_action: Francine uses phrasing that is professional but emotive.
immoral_action: Francine uses many explicit words in the email to express herself.

norm: It's frowned upon to back out of an agreement.
situation: Robert just agreed with his regular plumber about a big repair job at his house when he discovers that another plumber would charge him less.
intention: Robert wants to save money.
moral_action: Robert discusses the situation with his regular plumber, and they agree on a lower price.
immoral_action: Robert cancels the job with his regular plumber without explanation and hires the less expensive one instead.

norm: Backing out of a deal is frowned upon.
situation: Tony was saw that Brian was selling a car and offered to buy it.
intention: Tony wants a car.
moral_action: Tony gets the cash from the bank to pay for the car.
immoral_action: Tony goes to the dealership and buys a used car from a salesman there.

norm: It's discouraged to always be silly.
situation: Mike is a comedian who likes to make people smile, and he's about to make a speech at his uncle's funeral.
intention: Mike wants his speech to be memorable.
moral_action: Mike tells a story about his uncle's life and accomplishments accompanied by a note about how much his uncle enriched his life.
immoral_action: Mike strings together a series of jokes about his uncle's personality as a tribute of sorts.

norm: It's frowned upon to get an F on an assignment.
situation: Ginny has a big test at school tomorrow that she hasn't studied for yet, but she wants to go out to play.
intention: Ginny wants show up for the exam.
moral_action: Ginny decides to have a cram study session instead of playing, then takes the test.
immoral_action: Ginny decides to not go over her notes and plays outside instead, and then takes the test.

norm: It's wrong to get drunk and harass others.
situation: Bob is out at the bar drinking with a couple of friends and a group of ladies walk by.
intention: Bob wants to act like a clown and make his friends laugh.
moral_action: Bob starts to act like a clown and does a dance in front of the ladies while laughing.
immoral_action: Bob starts to act like a clown, making jokes but then reaches out and smacks a passing lady on her butt.

norm: It's wrong to take your friend's beer.
situation: Jake and Bill are at the bar and are talking over some drinks, Jakes cup of beer is empty, Bill's is not.
intention: Jake wants to drink more beer.
moral_action: Jake calls the bartender over and orders himself another glass of beer.
immoral_action: Jake grabs Bill's cup and takes a big swig of Bill's beer without asking Bill first.

norm: It's wrong to do drugs when you're underage.
situation: Jane is at a party when she is offered drugs.
intention: Jane wants to fit in.
moral_action: Jane declines and says that she feels too young to experiment with drugs.
immoral_action: Jane takes the drugs even though she has never done drugs before.

norm: It's rude to take a soda from someone else.
situation: Jacob was at a diner with all of his friends, but he ran out of his drink.
intention: Jacob wants something to drink.
moral_action: Jacob calls the waitress over to order himself another drink.
immoral_action: Jacob takes a sip of soda that his best friend had ordered for himself.

norm: It's rude to pressure your friends to drink with you.
situation: Jeff has arranged a mixer for some of his college classmates.
intention: Jeff wants everyone to have fun.
moral_action: When an attendee declines any alcohol Jeff makes sure he is not made to feel left out.
immoral_action: When one of the attendess declines alcohol Jeff boisterously pushes drink after drink on him.

norm: It is irresponsible to leave children around an alcoholic alone.
situation: Mary has two young children at home with her alcoholic husband and considers getting a babysitter before she leaves for work.
intention: Mary wants to find someone to watch over her children.
moral_action: Mary finds a babysitter to help take care of her children.
immoral_action: Mary simply decides to leave her children in care of her alcoholic husband.

norm: It's wrong to throw drinks on people.
situation: Lance is drinking soda near a soccer game when he sees some fans of the opposing team walking by.
intention: Lance wants to annoy the other fans.
moral_action: Lance calls out to the other fans and makes some light jokes about their team.
immoral_action: Lance chucks his drink at the opposing fans, hitting one on the side of the head.

norm: It is reckless to leave your wallet at a bar.
situation: Steve is drunk and tired, he left the bar, forgetting his coat, and in it, his wallet, not realizing until he's in an uber on his way home.
intention: Steve wants to get home.
moral_action: Steve asks the Uber driver to turn around, so he can get his stuff.
immoral_action: Steve doesn't say anything to the uber driver, and just goes home, figuring he'll get the wallet the next day.

norm: It's wrong to get into fights at the bar.
situation: Chad ran into a guy that he didn't like when he was at the bar drinking.
intention: Chad wanted to drink the rest of his beer.
moral_action: Chad took his beer and drank it on the other side of the bar.
immoral_action: Chad drank the rest of his beer and cracked the bottle over the other man's head.

norm: It is unprofessional to consume alcohol while working.
situation: James works in retail and has had a stressful day, so he takes a break and thinks of how to relieve the stress.
intention: James wants to do something to relieve his stress.
moral_action: James takes a few walks around the building to clear his head.
immoral_action: James decides that everything is better with alcohol, so he drinks a few beers while on break.

norm: It is wrong for kids underage to be drinking.
situation: Heather attends her first high school party with her friends.
intention: Heather wants to look cool in front of her friends.
moral_action: When Heather is offered an alcoholic beverage, she thanks her friend for the thought but declines to take the drink.
immoral_action: When Heather is offered an alcoholic beverage, she takes a big drink to impress her friends.

norm: It's inappropriate to drink a beer in a government office.
situation: Jake, who is carrying some beer for his friends in his backpack, is waiting in a long line at immigration services and is bored.
intention: Jake wants to pass the time.
moral_action: Jake strikes up a conversation with a person near him in line.
immoral_action: Jake takes out a beer and quietly drinks it, taking the edge off of the wait.

norm: Its foolish to dare someone to drink too much.
situation: Randal is watching his friend Chad enter a drinking competition at a fraternity.
intention: Randal wants to make Chad feel accepted by his peers.
moral_action: Randal tells the other boys at the party stories about Chad bailing him out of tough situations.
immoral_action: Randal cheers Chad on urging him to drink ten shots of tequila in a row.

norm: It's wrong to get too drunk to fulfill your obligations.
situation: Halen is entertaining his boss' daughter Trisha for the night, and Trisha wants him to enter a drinking contest.
intention: Halen wants to make Trisha happen.
moral_action: Halen suggests that they return home for a glass of wine and a fun movie on Netflix.
immoral_action: Halen drinks eight shots in a row to win the contest.

norm: It's irresponsible for bartenders to serve people too much alcohol.
situation: Vic is a bartender and one of his regular customers has already had 10 shots of vodka, yet wants more.
intention: Vic wants his customer to be safe.
moral_action: Vic tells the customer that he's had enough and that he can talk to security if he has a problem with that.
immoral_action: Vic tells the customer that he can have more if he gets a designated driver, then gives him all he wants.

norm: It's wrong to give underage kids alcohol.
situation: Wes is looking for a drink in the fridge when his little brother Max ask for something to drink.
intention: Wes wants to give Max a drink.
moral_action: Wes grabs a bottle of orange juice and pours a glass for Max.
immoral_action: Wes reaches in the back of the fridge and gives Max a beer.

norm: It's wrong to go to brothels if you're underage.
situation: David is walking home from school with one of his friends.
intention: David wants to do something fun and exciting.
moral_action: David and his friend walk across a train bridge to cross over a creek instead of sticking to their usual route home.
immoral_action: David and his friend sneak in to an adult only club through an open door they notice in a nearby alley.

norm: It's wrong to drink alcohol in excess.
situation: John is going out to a work happy hour with his coworkers.
intention: John wants to create a more relaxed atmosphere for the group.
moral_action: John only has a couple drinks and tries to think of some conversational topics that he has in common with his coworkers.
immoral_action: "John drinks a lot to try to get into more of a ""fun"" mood."

norm: It's frowned upon to drink alcohol in excess.
situation: Joe is at work function where there is an open bar.
intention: Joe wants to have a good time.
moral_action: Joe limits his alcohol consumption to a reasonable amount, so he is just buzzed enough.
immoral_action: Joe drinks way too much and gets drunk.

norm: It's wrong to drink too much alcohol.
situation: Ted goes to the bar with his friends for a night out with the boys.
intention: Ted wants to have an awesome time on his night out.
moral_action: Ted has a few shots and cracks jokes with his friends all evening.
immoral_action: Ted gets wasted and acts foolishly in front of his friends, laughing the whole time.

norm: Drinking to excess is wrong.
situation: Sam drives from his house to meet a few friends at a local bar for some socializing and live music.
intention: Sam wants to have a really fun evening.
moral_action: Sam has two beers and spends most of the night on the dance floor enjoying the live music.
immoral_action: Sam drinks nine beers at the bar and is extremely intoxicated.

norm: You shouldn't cope with your emotions by drinking.
situation: Jason was getting over a bad breakup with his girlfriend and was feeling depressed.
intention: He wanted to do something to make himself feel better.
moral_action: Jason went to a nearby arboretum and walked around for hours enjoying the nature scenes.
immoral_action: Jason went to a nearby bar and drank his sorrows away for several hours.

norm: It's unacceptable to drive after you've been drinking.
situation: Danny went to the bar with Andrew and gets intoxicated afterwards.
intention: Danny wants to go back home.
moral_action: Danny asks Andrew for a ride back home and Andrew agrees to do so.
immoral_action: Danny drives his car back home even though he is drunk.

norm: It is wrong to drug someone's drink.
situation: Peter told Carl he had not yet had sex with his new girlfriend, Tammy, so Carl gave Peter a powder to put in her drink to make her willing.
intention: Peter wants Tammy to say yes to sex.
moral_action: Peter throws away the powder and talks to Tammy about sex, she says yes after they talk through a few things.
immoral_action: Peter makes Tammy a drink with powder in it , she becomes  affectionate and tell's Peter she wants him.

norm: It's unacceptable to consume too much alcohol.
situation: Nick has been at the bar and had a few drinks already when Nell the bartender asks him if he'd like another.
intention: Nick wants to answer Nell's question.
moral_action: Nick tells Nell that he's had enough and that it's probably time he went home.
immoral_action: Nick tells Nell that he'd definitely like another and to actually keep them coming all night.

norm: It's irresponsible to drink too much alcohol.
situation: Clay is at a business meeting and the client tells him to help himself to some scotch.
intention: Clay wants to have a drink.
moral_action: Clay pours himself a small shot of scotch and sips it throughout the meeting.
immoral_action: Clay pours himself an over-sized glass of straight scotch and gets really drunk.

norm: It's not okay to drink yourself to excess.
situation: Martin had a bad day at work with disaster after disaster.
intention: Martin wants to forget about his day at work.
moral_action: Martin decides to tackle some really difficult puzzles.
immoral_action: Martin decides to drink to forget all about his day.

norm: It's wrong to drink excessively.
situation: Sean is upset and depressed because he recently broke up with his girlfriend .
intention: Sean wants to manage his depression.
moral_action: Sean joins a health club and goes to do workout regularly.
immoral_action: Sean goes to the bar and orders a dozen of beer to drink hoping that he can forget the breakup, and then he drives back home despite the hangover.

norm: It's not good to drink to excess.
situation: Tim goes to a big party with lots of booze.
intention: Tim wants to drink.
moral_action: Tim decides to only drink so much, and he brought a designated driver as well.
immoral_action: Tim drinks and drinks and drinks some more until he passes out.

norm: It is wrong to drink if you are an alcoholic.
situation: Sarah has been sober from alcohol for 4 weeks and just made a serious mistake at work which is stressing her out.
intention: Sarah wants to do something to put her mind at ease.
moral_action: Sarah looks up mindfulness and meditation techniques when she gets home.
immoral_action: Sarah picks up some alcohol on the way home and has some drinks.

norm: It is unacceptable to force someone to drink alcohol.
situation: Paul is celebrating a work promotion at a bar with his friends, including Wayne, who's acting as the designated driver.
intention: Paul wants to buy rounds of shots for his friends.
moral_action: Paul buys shots for all of his friends except Wayne, because he needs to be sober to drive them home.
immoral_action: Paul insists that everyone, including Wayne, drink five shots before they go home.

norm: People should not violate the laws concerning illegal deeds.
situation: John works as a bookkeeper for a small company where he handles a lot of cash transactions.
intention: John wants to have more money.
moral_action: John asks his employer for a pay raise.
immoral_action: John embezzles money from his employer.

norm: You shouldn't do things that would put you in jail.
situation: Vince is an accountant with a company.
intention: Vince wants to get some extra money.
moral_action: Vince helps his friends with their taxes for a fee.
immoral_action: Vince takes some money and works the accounting so that no one can see the loss.

norm: One should not accuse another person of stealing without evidence.
situation: Will bought an expensive smartwatch that has gone missing and strongly suspects his roommate.
intention: Will wants to find out what happened to his smartwatch.
moral_action: Will looks around for it more carefully and uses the device tracker to track it's location.
immoral_action: Will confronts his roommate immediately when he gets home.

norm: You shouldn't blame others unless you have proof.
situation: Bob is an accountant for a marketing firm and notices a discrepancy that indicates possible fraud.
intention: Bob wants the discrepancy investigated.
moral_action: Bob points out the accounting discrepancy to his boss.
immoral_action: Bob points out the discrepancy to his boss and says he suspects the regional manager.

norm: You shouldn't let children break the law.
situation: Marcy and her daughter, Amy, are at the toy store when Amy grabs an expensive doll she fancies.
intention: Marcy wants Amy to go home with the doll.
moral_action: Marcy tells Amy she'll buy her the doll if she takes up some chores.
immoral_action: With Amy still holding the doll, Marcy rushes her out of the store, skipping the cashier entirely.

norm: You should not be unwilling to go to Jury Duty.
situation: Lyle receives a piece of mail and upon opening it sees it's a jury summons for next week.
intention: Kyle wants to decide what to do with the letter.
moral_action: Kyle takes the jury summons and puts it on his office desk at home to take with him when he reports for jury duty.
immoral_action: Kyle takes the jury summons and tosses it in the garbage since he has no intention of responding to it.

norm: One shouldn't break the law and end up in court.
situation: Daytona is driving down the highway running late to work.
intention: Daytona needs to get to work on time.
moral_action: Daytona uses google maps to send her on an alternate route to work.
immoral_action: Daytona drives thirty miles over the speed limit, and is pulled over by the cops.

norm: You shouldn't do anything that will get you in jail.
situation: Larry has had too much to drink at the bar, and now it's time to go home.
intention: Larry wants to leave for home.
moral_action: Larry calls a cab to pick him up at the bar and drive him home.
immoral_action: Larry gets in his car and starts heading for home.

norm: You shouldn't let criminal behavior become an obsession.
situation: Mark used to illegally download movies, but now he has a job.
intention: Mark wants to watch more movies.
moral_action: Mark buys multiple streaming services so that he can watch as many movies as he can.
immoral_action: Mark continues to download movies, because he loves how easy they are to obtain.

norm: You shouldn't blame people if you have no proof.
situation: Jason went to grab his Red Bull from the refrigerator only to discover it is missing.
intention: Jason wants to find out what happened to his Red Bull.
moral_action: Jason knocks on his roommates door and asks if they drank his Red Bull.
immoral_action: Jason storms into his roommates room and accuses them of drinking his Red Bull.

norm: You shouldn't break the law and get arrested.
situation: Axle lost his job recently and doesn't have enough money to buy food for the week.
intention: Axle wants to be able to eat for the week.
moral_action: Axle goes to his local food bank and asks for help.
immoral_action: Axle goes to the grocery store, fills the cart up, and tries to walk out without paying.

norm: You shouldn't let people get away with DUIs.
situation: George, a police officer, just caught his neighbor driving under the influence; he feels bad because he knows his neighbor needs his car for his job.
intention: George wants to help his neighbor.
moral_action: George decides to impound his neighbor's car, but tells him he will give him a ride to work every morning.
immoral_action: George decides to ignore his neighbor's DUI violation and give him a chance.

norm: It's rude to send people junk mail.
situation: Crystal works in marketing for a company that has developed a new product.
intention: Crystal wants to increase product sales.
moral_action: Crystal organizes a public event where the product is demonstrated.
immoral_action: Crystal sets up a mailing campaign to target everyone within a 200-mile radius of the store about the product.

norm: Stealing money is something that you shouldn't do.
situation: Bob has been laid off from work.
intention: Bob needs to pay his rent before the end of the month.
moral_action: Bob asks his brother if he can borrow money to pay his rent and his brother says yes.
immoral_action: Bob goes to the local convenience store that night and robs it.

norm: It's wrong to steal your relative's purse.
situation: Jane is hanging out with her grandma and Susan and Susan has to step away and go to the garage for something.
intention: Jane wants to get some money to buy a new shirt.
moral_action: Jane asks her grandma for a bit of money when she gets back in the room and Susan gives Jane a ride to the store to buy a shirt.
immoral_action: Jane takes her grandma's purse while she is in the garage and drives to the store and purchases a shirt.

norm: It's wrong to steal a purse from another person.
situation: Mary is leaving a bar when she notices a purse sitting on a bench unattended.
intention: Mary wants to go home.
moral_action: Mary picks up the purse and gives it to the bar manager to find the owner, then drives home.
immoral_action: Mary picks up the purse and takes it home with her.

norm: It's bad to steal someone's gold when they find it.
situation: Ron and Jamie are panning for gold on vacation.
intention: Ron wants to find some gold and take it home.
moral_action: Ron keeps panning for gold and finds a nice bit to take home.
immoral_action: When Jamie back is turned Ron takes some of her gold.

norm: It's wrong to use a credit card that's not yours.
situation: Andy found a credit card left at the ATM, and it hadn't expired yet.
intention: Andy wanted to do something with the card.
moral_action: Andy hands the card over to a cop so that they can help find the person.
immoral_action: Andy used the card to buy an Xbox and then throws the card away.

norm: People won't trust you if they know you're a thief.
situation: Greg walks into the lunch room at work one day when he realizes that he forgot his lunch at home.
intention: Greg wants to eat lunch.
moral_action: Greg orders a sandwich from a local cafe to be delivered to the office and picks it up by the front door.
immoral_action: Greg opens the fridge, finds a lunch bag belonging to another coworker, and eats its contents.

norm: It's careless to send an email to the wrong person
situation: Jacob is writing an email to a coworker complaining about their boss.
intention: Jacob wants to vent to a coworker.
moral_action: Jacob makes sure the email is addressed to the coworker before sending it.
immoral_action: Jacob doesn't check the email before sending it and accidentally sends it to the boss.

norm: You shouldn't take someone's tip money because that's stealing.
situation: Marty is a busboy, and he and the waitress Ann are the last ones in the cafe when it's time to close.
intention: Marty needs to clear the last table before they leave.
moral_action: Marty sees Ann's tip money is still on the table when he's clearing it, and he brings it to her.
immoral_action: When Marty goes to clear the table he sees a customer left Ann a tip, and he pockets the money for himself.

norm: It's wrong to pay with a fake check.
situation: Tony is shopping to buy his girlfriend a necklace, but the one he wants is pretty expensive.
intention: Tony wants to try to get the gift.
moral_action: Tony talks the salesman down in price and pays for the necklace with his debit card.
immoral_action: Tony takes a check from a checkbook for an account he no longer has and gives it to the clerk.

norm: It's wrong to scam people with junk mail.
situation: Rob has been fired from his job and is facing eviction if he doesn't pay his back rent soon.
intention: Rob needs to scrape together some money fast.
moral_action: Rob sells as many of his possessions as he can and starts working gig jobs.
immoral_action: Rob decides to try running a phishing scheme he learned about from an old friend to get people to wire money to him.

norm: It is worrying to leave your wallet behind unintentionally.
situation: Zach is eating at a diner and has to leave in a hurry because he is running late for a movie he has tickets to.
intention: Zach wants to get to the movie on time.
moral_action: Zach makes sure he has all of his personal belongings before leaving the diner for the movie theater.
immoral_action: Zach is in such a hurry that he accidentally leaves his wallet behind on the table at the diner.

norm: It's wrong to steal from a lost wallet or purse.
situation: Jane was walking through a store when she found a wallet laying on the ground.
intention: Jane wants to turn the wallet in.
moral_action: Jane gives the wallet to the lost and found after reporting how much cash it contains.
immoral_action: Jane takes the money out of the wallet before putting it in the lost and found.

norm: Taking money from someone's wallet would be wrong.
situation: Ken has a bill that needs to be paid and finds his brother Oliver's wallet lying around.
intention: Ken wants to pay the bill.
moral_action: Ken asks Oliver if he can loan him the money he needs.
immoral_action: Ken pulls money from the wallet without asking Oliver first.

norm: It is wrong to disregard your education.
situation: Brad is talking about college with his cousin Josh and his mother Connie who paid for Brad's education.
intention: Brad wants to give Josh advise.
moral_action: Brad tells Josh about how he uses what he learned in his degree in his job.
immoral_action: Brad tells Josh that his degree in English was a waste of money.

norm: It's wrong to not take your studies seriously.
situation: Bob was contemplating going out with his friends on a Friday night.
intention: Bob wants to pass his history exam that is scheduled for Saturday morning.
moral_action: Bob tells his friends he needs to study and stays in, getting a full night of sleep.
immoral_action: Bob decides to go out to the bar and drinks until two am.

norm: It's wrong to give up on your education.
situation: Jerry has one more year left in high school before he graduates.
intention: Jerry wants to be a basketball player.
moral_action: Jerry stays in school and plays the best year of basketball during his senior year.
immoral_action: Jerry drops out of school because he thinks that he is good enough to play for the NBA.

norm: It's wrong for schools not to teach kid right.
situation: Emery is teaching her students how to convert fractions into decimals, but she is having a hard time because she has never understood this well.
intention: Emery wants to finish the lesson today.
moral_action: Emery meets with another teacher during lunch, learns how to do the conversion, and is able to teach the students correctly.
immoral_action: Emery comes up with a way of converting the fractions that she thinks might be right and explains it to the class for their daily lesson.

norm: It's not good to ignore school responsibilities.
situation: Henry's friend Corin invited him to go to the park, but he has to catch up on his schoolwork.
intention: Henry wants to respond to Corin's invite.
moral_action: Henry tells Corin, thank you, but he has to put his schoolwork first.
immoral_action: Henry wants to have fun, so decides to blow off his classwork.

norm: It's wrong to not give your best effort in school.
situation: Bella and her friends are all currently in high school.
intention: Bella wants to graduate.
moral_action: Bella joins clubs, takes AP classes, and gets an A in all her classes.
immoral_action: Bella does the bare minimum so that she can pass her classes with a C.

norm: It's wrong to bail on an academic obligation.
situation: Mr. Smith could see that Andy was doing poorly in Algebra, so he offered to tutor Andy and Andy agreed to it.
intention: Andy wants to get better at Algebra.
moral_action: Andy stays after class and gets taught some tips on how to learn Algebra better by Mr. Smith.
immoral_action: Andy decides to study Algebra on his own so that he doesn't have to spend too much time on it.

norm: It's wrong to lie about your education.
situation: Helen is a high school graduate filling out job applications when she has to put down her education credentials.
intention: Helen wants to get a job.
moral_action: Helen says she is a high school graduate on the application.
immoral_action: Helen says she is a college graduate on the application.

norm: It's wrong to give up on school.
situation: Maya is in 11th grade and just found out she is pregnant with her first child.
intention: Maya wants to decide whether or not to drop out.
moral_action: Maya, wanting to be a good parent, signs up for homeschooling, so she can further her education and focus on being a new mom at the same time.
immoral_action: Maya, wanting to focus on preparing to be a new mom, quits attending classes.

norm: It's wrong to not care about your education.
situation: Jacob has a late final exam that's at the same time as when his friends are going to beach week.
intention: Jacob wants to be able to go to beach week with everyone else.
moral_action: Jacob talked to the professor to see if he could take the exam at an earlier date.
immoral_action: Jacob skips the exam to go to the beach, assuming that his grades leading up to the final would be enough to pass.

norm: It's not okay to falsify school grades.
situation: Reese has been struggling in many classes at school and works in the school's office.
intention: Reese wants to get better grades.
moral_action: Reese puts his nose to the grindstone and starts working harder in the classes he is struggling in before it is too late.
immoral_action: Reese uses his office access to adjust his school records to reflect better grades than he earned.

norm: It's wrong to cause someone to get a bad grade.
situation: Sam's friend has an important test the next day that they haven't studied for yet.
intention: Sam wants to go out drinking.
moral_action: Sam leaves his friend to study for his test and finds some other people to go drinking with.
immoral_action: Sam insists that his friend go out drinking with him instead of studying for the test.

norm: It's wrong to plagiarize for class.
situation: Susan has a big paper coming up for her ethics class.
intention: Susan wants to achieve an A on the paper.
moral_action: Susan finds a paper about the same topic online and reads it then drafts an alternative position.
immoral_action: Susan finds a paper about the same topic online and copies large portions of it.

norm: It's wrong to cheat on a test in school.
situation: Rob is taking his final exams.
intention: Rob wants to get a high score.
moral_action: Rob stays up all night studying extra hard for the exams.
immoral_action: Rob hides his study notes in his sleeve and uses them to ace the exam.

norm: It's wrong to cheat on your school assignments.
situation: Marie was not doing well in her math class.
intention: Marie wants to get good grades.
moral_action: Marie asks a friend to help tutor her in the subject.
immoral_action: Marie finds copies of the test answers and memorizes them.

norm: It's wrong to steal money from your school.
situation: Austin is part of a school drama club that needs to find a way to fund a team trip.
intention: Austin wants to have a benefit car wash where all of the group helps out.
moral_action: Austin helps with car wash, making sure to safely keep all of the proceedings locked up in a cash box.
immoral_action: Austin is in charge of handling the money received from car wash customers, which he sneaks half of the money for his own pocket.

norm: It's wrong to be dishonest with school work.
situation: John copied a story that he found online for an overdue creative writing assignment, and was asked by his teacher how he came up with such unique plot.
intention: John wants to answer the teacher's question.
moral_action: John reluctantly admits to the teacher that he ran out of time, so he copied and pasted that whole story and none of it is his work.
immoral_action: John tells the teacher he leaned on some past memories and experiences to come up with the plot.

norm: It's wrong to waste school supplies.
situation: Maci is a student who enjoys using her school's art room to paint as they provide all necessary supplies at no cost to students.
intention: Maci wants to paint a canvas in the art room.
moral_action: Unsatisfied with her work, Maci paints over the imperfections on her canvas.
immoral_action: Unsatisfied with her work, Maci discards over 40 canvases before keeping one to work on.

norm: It's wrong to cheat as a student.
situation: Bill has an important test in a difficult class coming up at school.
intention: Bill wants to do well on his test.
moral_action: Bill studies hard for his test spending a lot of time and effort to learn the subjects that will be covered on it.
immoral_action: Bill buys the answers to his upcoming test so that he will be able to finish it easily.

norm: It's wrong to cheat on an exam.
situation: Roman is sitting in class taking a big final exam in his math class.
intention: Roman wants to score well on the exam.
moral_action: Roman blocks out everything and concentrates extra hard to remember everything he studied for the test.
immoral_action: Roman uses his smartwatch to pull up answers to some of the test questions.

norm: It's dishonest to cheat on a test
situation: Scott has his final test in a week and feels he might flunk it.
intention: Scott wants to make his parents proud.
moral_action: Scott asks a friend to help him study for the test, he studies day and night for a week.
immoral_action: Scott writes helpful notes on a tiny piece of paper that he hides in his sock and checks during the test.

norm: It's wrong to bully your classmates.
situation: Riley is the most popular girl in her school and there has been another student who she has been finding annoying lately.
intention: Riley wants to address her issues with the annoying student.
moral_action: Riley has a private conversation with the student, and they talk out their issues.
immoral_action: Riley uses her popularity to start rumors about the other student and make them feel small in front of others.

norm: It's wrong to cheat in school.
situation: James is in class and the teacher gives him a pop quiz.
intention: James wants to take the test.
moral_action: James isn't sure of all the answers, but he tries his best.
immoral_action: James idn't very well prepared, so he takes out his phone to look for the answers online.

norm: It is wrong to use school paper for something wasteful.
situation: Cody was sitting at his desk with a stack of loose leaf paper.
intention: Cody wants to use the paper.
moral_action: Cody uses the paper to work on his writing assignment that the teacher had given him.
immoral_action: Cody uses his school paper to make paper airplanes which he threw around the class.

norm: It is wrong to cheat on tests.
situation: There is a special reward for the highest scoring grade in Jane's class.
intention: Jane wants to ensure that she gets the top grade.
moral_action: Jane studies harder and longer than all the other students in her class.
immoral_action: Jane brings a small piece of paper with the answers with her to use during the test.

norm: It's wrong to fail your class.
situation: Kate has a big final exam to take, but she doesn't feel like going to school.
intention: Kate has to decide whether to go to school.
moral_action: Kate gets up and forces herself to go to school.
immoral_action: Kate decides to skip school and watch a movie at home instead.

norm: It is wrong to steal school property.
situation: Mike had a report to work on, but he didn't have a computer at home.
intention: Mike wants to use the school computer.
moral_action: Mike asks his teacher if he can work in the computer lab during lunch.
immoral_action: Mike takes a laptop from school without permission from the staff.

norm: Stealing from a business is illegal and morally wrong.
situation: Jeff is at the store looking for a new pen.
intention: Jeff wants to return home with a pen.
moral_action: Jeff brings a pen to the cashier and purchases a pen with cash before returning home.
immoral_action: Jeff takes a pen, puts it in his pocket and leaves the store.

norm: It's wrong to falsely report a crime.
situation: Janine has a neighbor who always lets their dog poop in her yard during their walk.
intention: Janine wants to get the neighbor to stop.
moral_action: Janine talks to her neighbor and asks if they would mind taking the dog across the street to go to the bathroom.
immoral_action: Janine calls the police and accuses her neighbor of committing a very serious crime, hoping that they'll be arrested and taken away.

norm: It is wrong to engage in criminal activities
situation: David is in a convenience store and see the candy aisle.
intention: David wants a candy bar.
moral_action: David takes his candy bar to the cashier and pays for it.
immoral_action: When the cashier is not looking, David hides the candy bar in his shirt and leaves.

norm: It is wrong to conceal the evidence of a crime.
situation: John sees his friend Rick steal a homeless man's wallet on the way to school.
intention: John wants to stay friends with Rick.
moral_action: John writes an anonymous note to an authority about what he witnessed, but doesn't tell Rick about it.
immoral_action: John offers to burn the wallet for Rick if he splits the contents of it with him.

norm: It's wrong for people to commit a crime.
situation: Mary sees a beautiful necklace while shopping at a department store.
intention: Mary wants to get possession of the necklace.
moral_action: Mary decides to save up money to buy the necklace.
immoral_action: Mary puts the necklace into her bag without paying for it at the cashier.

norm: It is unlawful to commit several crimes.
situation: Steve is at a convenient mart when he notices the only employee on duty is in the restroom.
intention: Steve wants something cheap to eat.
moral_action: Steve waits for the store's attendant to return from the restroom then lawfully purchases a sandwich and chips.
immoral_action: Steve takes a sandwich and drink from the store without paying and then decides to take a ride in a car that is idling nearby.

norm: It's wrong to be involved in organized crime.
situation: John is in his usual Brooklyn hangout when some known Mafioso come in and ask John if he's willing to help them out with a task.
intention: John wants to respond to the mafioso.
moral_action: John tells the mafioso that he respects him, but he cannot involve himself in such activities.
immoral_action: John tells the mafioso that he'd be glad to do a task as he's sure the mafia will repay him bigtime later.

norm: It's wrong to lie to the police about a crime.
situation: Jason steals a candy bar from a convenience store because he's hungry, and is caught by the owner who calls the cops.
intention: Jason wants to discuss the matter with the authorities.
moral_action: Jason explains to the cops and owner that he's hungry and had no money.
immoral_action: Jason tells the cops it wasn't him and blames a random shopper.

norm: It's wrong to ignore a crime in progress.
situation: James was waiting for the bus when a mugger tried to snatch the purse from the lady standing behind him.
intention: James wants to avoid getting injured.
moral_action: James records the mugging on his phone and gives the recording to the police.
immoral_action: James stares forward and pretends that he can't hear anything.

norm: It is wrong to commit a robbery.
situation: Lois sees a watch that she really wants in a jewelry store, but she can't afford it.
intention: Lois wants to get the watch.
moral_action: Lois takes some extra hours at work, so she can get more money to buy the watch.
immoral_action: Lois breaks into the jewelry store after hours and takes the watch.

norm: It's criminal to destroy other's property.
situation: Gavin is driving home and finds the road to his garage is blocked by another vehicle.
intention: Gavin wants to drive to his garage.
moral_action: Gavin decides to wait for the car to move out of the way and then drive down to his garage.
immoral_action: Gavin drives on his neighbors yard to get to the garage, ruining his neighbors yard.

norm: It's rude to assume another is a criminal without proof.
situation: There is a kidnapper on the loose, and Ray found a guy who he thinks looks suspicious.
intention: Ray wants to help his community.
moral_action: Ray waits for more information to come out about the kidnapper before targeting anyone.
immoral_action: Ray calls the proof just based on his opinion of him.

norm: Stalking people is illegal and wrong.
situation: Edward just met a new girl at school, and he likes her a lot.
intention: Edward wants the new girl to notice him and like him back.
moral_action: Edward puts on his best outfit and tries to talk to the girl the next day at school.
immoral_action: Edward follows her home from school every day trailing about twenty feet behind her.

norm: Terrorism is cowardly and criminal.
situation: Jamie is angry to hear that her government is unwilling to address the climate change crisis.
intention: Jamie needs to do something to motivate her government officials to take climate change more seriously.
moral_action: Jamie writes a thoughtful letter to her congressional representative and copies several high profile news outlets on the content of the message.
immoral_action: Jamie starts a fire in a government building to show her disapproval of government policy related to climate change.

norm: It's wrong to defend a heinous criminal.
situation: Victoria is at the full court house where her family member is being sentenced for a severe crime they committed.
intention: Victoria wants to speak her mind to the judge.
moral_action: Victoria stands with the victims when she speaks to the judge explaining that some things go beyond family and blood.
immoral_action: Victoria stands by her family member and asks the judge to consider leniency as she describes the good things about her family member.

norm: It is wrong to hit women
situation: "James is shopping at a WalMart when he hears a security guard shout, ""Stop, thief!"" as a woman runs past him carrying ten iPhones."
intention: James wants to stop the woman from stealing from the WalMart.
moral_action: James steps into the woman's path, so she runs into him and knocks them both down.
immoral_action: James punches the woman in the face as she runs by him.

norm: It's unreasonable to avoid a woman when she's menstruating.
situation: John and his currently menstruating wife are both home for the evening.
intention: John wants to watch TV.
moral_action: John makes his wife a treat and invites her to join him in the living room for their favorite TV show.
immoral_action: John sees that his wife is already watching TV in the living room, so he goes to the watch the basement TV instead.

norm: It's wrong to touch a woman's behind without consent.
situation: Jack is at the store, and he sees a woman with a very plump butt that he likes.
intention: Jack wants to show his interest in the woman.
moral_action: Jack says hello to the woman and tries to strike up a conversation.
immoral_action: Jack goes up to the woman and grabs her butt with hand and laughs.

norm: It's not okay to condemn women for their sexuality.
situation: John is a conservative father to an adult daughter who works as a model.
intention: John wants to be a good parent.
moral_action: John has a hard time understanding his daughter's profession but makes it clear that as long as she is safe and happy he will always be there for her.
immoral_action: John bluntly tells his daughter that he does not believe it is moral or good for her to work in an industry that objectifies her body.

norm: It's wrong to objectify women.
situation: Thomas is a manager at a consulting firm and has a subordinate named Beth who he enjoys working with.
intention: Thomas wants to compliment Beth.
moral_action: Thomas tells Beth that she's been doing a very good job on her assignments recently.
immoral_action: Thomas tells Beth that she looks very sexy in the tight tight blouse and skirt she's wearing.

norm: It is wrong to hit a woman in the face.
situation: Paul is walking down the street when a crazy lady jumps out with a knife, demanding Paul's money.
intention: Paul wants to defend himself.
moral_action: Paul wrestles the knife away and pins the woman to the ground, then shouts for help.
immoral_action: Paul deflects the knife and punches the woman in the face repeatedly.

norm: It is unacceptable to criticize the way another woman looks.
situation: Karen and Cathy are friends and are on a double date at a restaurant.
intention: Karen wants to make her date laugh.
moral_action: Karen tells a story from work about something she messed up in a funny way.
immoral_action: Karen makes a joke about the way Cathy's hair is styled.

norm: It's wrong to think of all women the same way.
situation: Linda and Dave are watching Kim Kardashian say something incredibly stupid on TV.
intention: Dave wants to react to what he just heard on TV.
moral_action: Dave tells Linda that Kim Kardashian is a vapid idiot and that he's glad she's not like her.
immoral_action: Dave tells Linda that women are morons and that Kim Kardashian is an excellent example of why.

norm: It's not okay to be bias because of gender.
situation: Erika was upset she lost the floral arranging competition to Brock.
intention: Erika wants to analyse her anger.
moral_action: Erika realizes it's all just part of the competition, and she should chill out.
immoral_action: Erika realizes she's upset because she lost a traditionally feminine pursuit to a boy.

norm: It's bad to think there's a way all feminists look.
situation: Harry was told by his dad that all feminists look the same.
intention: Harry wants to think about what his dad said.
moral_action: Harry considers his dad's words and realizes that unless feminists have a dress code they all don't dress the same.
immoral_action: Harry just assumes that anything daddy says is true.

norm: It's wrong to marry more than 2 women.
situation: Brigham is a married man twice over and is courting yet another woman.
intention: Brigham wants to be with the third woman.
moral_action: Brigham does some self reflection and ends his first two marriages so that he can be monogamous with the third woman.
immoral_action: Brigham marries the third woman bringing his total number of wives to three.

norm: It's rude to assume what all women enjoy.
situation: Jim and Sammy are about to have sex for the first time ever.
intention: Jim wants to see what Sammy likes.
moral_action: Jim asks Sammy if she likes anal sex and proceeds to do it after she says yes.
immoral_action: Jim chokes Sammy while penetrating her without asking if she liked it.

norm: It's wrong to beat women.
situation: Victor has come home from work to find his wife cheating on him with another man.
intention: Victor wants to respond to his wife cheating on him.
moral_action: Victor gets very angry, but keeps his hands off her and tells her he is leaving her.
immoral_action: Victor raises his voice very loud and starts beating his wife.

norm: It's unacceptable to hold men and women to different standards.
situation: Tito is the CEO of a successful company that has been needing new leadership.
intention: Tito wants to promote some of his employees to leadership positions.
moral_action: Tito looks over his employee's performance reports without their genders listed.
immoral_action: Tito gives the men easier tasks to fulfill than the women, then promotes only men.

norm: It's wrong to ignore women.
situation: Steven gets approached by a woman to ask him a question for directions, but he's in a hurry.
intention: Steven doesn't want to help her.
moral_action: Steven tells the woman he doesn't know the way, and apologizes.
immoral_action: Steven keeps walking acting like he didn't see or hear the woman.

norm: It's bad to be too loud and wake people up.
situation: Jordan woke up very early this morning.
intention: He wants to make some breakfast.
moral_action: Jordan quietly makes himself a bowl of cereal for breakfast.
immoral_action: Jordan noisily bangs a lot of pots and pans when making his breakfast.

norm: It is rude to be loud and disruptive.
situation: An esteemed professor is giving a guest lecture at the University.
intention: Phil wants to ask a question of the Professor.
moral_action: Phil approaches the professor after the lecture.
immoral_action: Phil continuously interrupts the lecture, demanding the professor answer in a satisfactory way.
