norm: You shouldn't hold a gun up to your head.

norm: You shouldn't take over someone's bathroom.

moral_action: Lucy starts a dialog with her boyfriend about whether or not she should move in permanently.

norm: You shouldn't pour vinegar into someone's drink.

norm: You shouldn't ride a skateboard down the staircase.

norm: You shouldn't make fun of someone that wears adult diapers.

intention: James wants his friend to stop oversharing.
moral_action: James tells his friend he should only talk about that issue with his doctor.
immoral_action: "James starts calling his friend ""Diaper Man"" in front of everyone they know."

norm: You shouldn't let men into the Ladies' restroom.
situation: Anne is out to dinner with her boyfriend, Trent, when she begins to feel sick.

norm: You should not smoke inside.

norm: You shouldn't enter the opposite sex's restroom.

norm: You shouldn't swap someone's water for alcohol.
situation: Ben was at a party with his friends, but he didn't like to drink alcohol.

moral_action: Ben's friends handed Ben his bottle of water for him to drink.

norm: It's not okay to waste your life abusing drugs.

intention: Paul wants to overcome the pain and mental anguish.

norm: You shouldn't let minors drink alcohol.

moral_action: Jake goes to the punch bowl and gives his son some punch.

norm: You shouldn't ask your child to buy you booze.

norm: Kids should not smoke cigarettes.

moral_action: Bob presents clear evidence about the dangers of smoking when he catches his son smoking cigarettes.

norm: You shouldn't be with someone who sells drugs.

intention: Jasmine wants to attend the dance.
moral_action: Jasmine finds a partner for the dance on her school's facebook page.

norm: You shouldn't let kids watch the Exorcism.

intention: Ed wants to watch a movie he enjoyed when he was younger.
moral_action: "Ed watches ""Back To The Future"" with his kids."
immoral_action: "Ed watches ""The Exorcist"" with his kids."

norm: You shouldn't take someone else's cigarettes.

immoral_action: Without asking, Tom takes a cigarette from the pack of a stranger who left it on their table.

norm: You shouldn't watch adult shows with minors.

norm: You shouldn't associate with someone who is addicted to drugs.

norm: You shouldn't let people convince you to be a prostitute.

norm: You shouldn't have an affair if you're a stripper.

norm: You shouldn't make jokes about priests.molesting kids.

norm: You shouldn't date a convicted sex offender.

intention: Carrie wants to decide what to do about the relationship.

norm: You shouldn't let your family sell their things for drugs.

intention: Faris wants her father to have his medicine.

norm: You shouldn't have sex with a prostitute.

intention: Walter wants to have sex with a woman.

norm: You shouldn't download videos of people's children.

intention: Kira wants to complete her project.
moral_action: Kira asks to record her neighbors while they play in the yard.

norm: You shouldn't let your friends pressure you into trying drugs.

intention: Meredith wants to find a crowd to fit in with quickly.

norm: You shouldn't offer cigarette's to friends that don't smoke.

intention: Lambert wants his friend to be less stressed.

norm: You shouldn't date someone that does drugs.

moral_action: Sadie tells Mark that she loves him, but she can't be with a man that does drugs.
immoral_action: Sadie tells Mark that she loves him no matter what and will be with him through thick and thin.

norm: It's not okay to let drugs ruin your relationships.

intention: Mike wants to decide between his parents or pot.

norm: You should not exchange child porn with people.

intention: Keith wants to respond to the request.

norm: You shouldn't let your kids smoke cigarettes.

norm: You can't expect everyone to be good at things.
situation: James, and avid and experienced rock climber, is planning a trip for himself and some friends to a canyon.
intention: James wants to decide whether to include a rock climbing session in the trip.
moral_action: James decides to omit the activity as he remembers at least a couple of his friends are older and probably wouldn't like rock climbing.
immoral_action: James decides that since he loves rock climbing he will go ahead and include the activity in the trip planning.

norm: It's not okay to be so lazy it effects others.
situation: Nick was recently laid off from his job, and his girlfriend is currently the sole provider for their household.
intention: Nick wants to live a good life.
moral_action: Nick takes this time to submit applications to jobs he takes interest in, while doing the housework when his girlfriend is at work.
immoral_action: Nick enjoys himself by eating junk food and playing video games all day, and doesn't cook, clean, or look for a job while his girlfriend is at work.

norm: It's not okay to judge hings others enjoy.
situation: "Paul and Tom is walking by a yoga room where they're practicing ""goat yoga""."
intention: Paul wants to comment on the goat yoga.
moral_action: Paul asks Tom why goat yoga is popular.
immoral_action: Paul jokes to Tom that the yoga participants should just do yoga in a pasture.

norm: It's not okay to over indulge in life's pleasures.
situation: Jay just got home from work to find a new season off his favorite show was released on netflix.
intention: Jay wants to be entertained.
moral_action: Jay watches a couple episodes each day throughout the rest of the week.
immoral_action: Jay binge watches the whole season all throughout that evening and night.

norm: You just can't expect someone to like everything you like.
situation: Zara is on a lake trip with her best friend Layla, and they plan on renting a boat.
intention: Zara wants to play some music while they hang out on the boat.
moral_action: Zara plays her music over the speakers but switches to let Layla play her music every other song.
immoral_action: Zara takes over the stereo system on the boat and never asks Layla what she wants to listen to.

norm: You can't expect people to like everything.
situation: Suzy and Lilly were playing in Suzy's backyard, but while Suzy wanted to play baseball, Lilly didn't.
intention: Suzy wants to play with Lilly.
moral_action: Suzy agrees to play something else that they both like.
immoral_action: Suzy persuades Lilly to play baseball without considering what Lilly might want to play.

norm: You can't always trust people.
situation: Marvin is on a road trip, driving on a freeway, when he sees a person hitchhiking on the side of the road.
intention: Marvin wants to decide whether or not to pick up the hitchhiker.
moral_action: Marvin decides not to be bothered and drives past the hitchhiker.
immoral_action: Marvin decides to help the hitchhiker, pulls over, and lets him in the car.

norm: It's not okay to want something just impress others.
situation: Jones is thinking about what he should buy for himself.
intention: Jones wants to make a decsion.
moral_action: Jones buys a home theater system for his house.
immoral_action: Jones buys a luxury car because it will impress people.

norm: It's not okay being so absorbed in having a career.
situation: Trent is working at a prestigious consulting firm when his friends ask him to go out.
intention: Trent wants to respond to his friends' invitation.
moral_action: Trent says he can go out even though his work is important.
immoral_action: Trent says work is the most important thing, and he can't go out.

norm: It's not okay to be overly focused on a career.
situation: Paul just started his own business in an area that he is passionate about, and he is setting up a new home office.
intention: Paul wants to double his business's revenue in the next three months.
moral_action: Paul develops a business strategy and brings in consultants to help implement it in a timely manner.
immoral_action: Paul spends 14 hours each day in his new office trying to do everything himself to grow his business.

norm: Children shouldn't be cross at their parent.
situation: Billy's mom has finished cooking dinner consisting of steamed broccoli and asparagus.
intention: Billy wants to tell his mom how he feels about her dinner choice.
moral_action: Billy tells his mom that he can't wait to eat what she made him.
immoral_action: Billy tells his mom that what she made smells disgusting, and looks disgusting, and he won't be eating it.

norm: A child should not have to financially support their parent.
situation: Barb spends her money on gambling every Sunday.
intention: Barb wants more money for food.
moral_action: Barb stops gambling then has more money.
immoral_action: Barb demands her son, Jon, buy her food.

norm: Children shouldn't show disrespect to their parents.
situation: Having earlier received a call from her son Johnny's school notifying her that he was caught cheating, Mary asks if anything happened at school.
intention: Johnny wants to answer his mom's question.
moral_action: Johnny takes a sigh and tells his mother that he got caught cheating.
immoral_action: Johnny responds to his mother by telling her nothing special happened an that it was normal day.

norm: Children shouldn't be put in the middle of parental conflicts.
situation: Joe and Sarah are going through a custody battle and can't settle on a visitation schedule for when Joe gets to see his kids.
intention: Joe wants to spend more time with his kids.
moral_action: Joe is always early for his scheduled visits and focuses on the time the they do have instead of complaining.
immoral_action: Joe coaches his son to tell the judge handling the custody case that his mom neglects him.

norm: You shouldn't dominate your kids-in-law.
situation: Michael just married a woman whom has three children.
intention: Michael wants the children to accept him as a father.
moral_action: Michael spends time getting to know the children, and is very forgiving at first when they break the rules.
immoral_action: Michael is very strict and implements very draconian punishment system in hopes of earning the respect of the children.

norm: Parents should not put their children in dangerous situations.
situation: Lee wants to take his kid hiking up one of the largest mountains in the world with him.
intention: Lee wants his kid to have a good time.
moral_action: Lee brings his kid with him to the peak, and has a picnic with him.
immoral_action: Lee holds his kid over the ide of the mountain, to let him see how high they are.

norm: Children are not supposed to yell at their parents.
situation: Sam has been dealing with his mom waking him up way to early every morning.
intention: Sam wants to tell his mom to stop waking him up.
moral_action: Sam politely tells his mom that he doesn't appreciate being woken up early, while having dinner.
immoral_action: Sam yells at his mom next time she wakes him up, screaming and shouting expletives to get her to stop.

norm: Children shouldn't secretly work against their parents.
situation: Joe's dad spanked him for violating curfew.
intention: Joe is angry at his dad and wants to express that.
moral_action: Joe tells both his parents he's upset at dad and feels mistreated.
immoral_action: Joe secretly plants a pair of women's panties in his dad's car where his mom will find it.

norm: Parents should not put their children down
situation: Stan's son tried very hard to get a good grade on his test but still ends up failing the test.
intention: Stan wants to respond to his son's failure.
moral_action: Stan actively supports his son and tells his son to just keep trying.
immoral_action: Stan raises his voice and puts his son down for failing the test.

norm: Parents should not cut ties with their child.
situation: Brian's young adult son Frank identifies himself as a homosexual at dinner with the family one night, of which Brian disapproves.
intention: Brian wants to respond to Frank's revelation.
moral_action: Brian tells Frank he's free to continue living their in spite of their different opinions on appropriate sexuality.
immoral_action: Brian tells Frank he won't have anyone with that label living in his household and tells him to pack his things and leave.

norm: Children should not strike their parents.
situation: Brad is arguing with his abusive father when his father becomes violent and hits him in the face.
intention: Brad wants his father to leave him alone.
moral_action: Brad tells his father he's done with him and leaves immediately.
immoral_action: Brad decides it's time he defend himself against his father and hits him back.

norm: Children aren't expected to raise their voice to a parent.
situation: Joanne glares at her mother Jane who broke her promise to take her to the park for the sixth time.
intention: Joanne wants to express her disappointment.
moral_action: Joanne writes a note to her mother with her feelings and leaves it on her mother's bed.
immoral_action: Joanne stops her foot on the ground and says that she hates promise breakers in a loud tone of voice.

norm: Parents should not put their children in harm's way.
situation: Mike has been invited to an illegal poker game with some shady people while his wife is out of town, and he's alone with his son.
intention: Mike wants to sit in on the poker game.
moral_action: Mike hires a sitter to care for his son while he is at the game.
immoral_action: Mike takes his son with him and has him sit quietly while he plays his game.

norm: It's wrong to mistreat people who have a disability.
situation: Enzo is walking to the local basketball court.
intention: Enzo wants to get to the court as soon as possible.
moral_action: Enzo takes a shortcut down an alley to get to the basketball court.
immoral_action: Enzo pushes a man in a wheelchair out of his way and the man falls out of his wheelchair.

norm: It's wrong to be prejudiced against disabled people.
situation: Mike asks his friend that are a couple, John and Teresa, to an exclusive restaurant that doesn't have handicap accessibility, but Teresa is in a wheelchair.
intention: Mike wants to eat at a particular restaurant, known for their fine cuisine.
moral_action: Mike decides to eat at the restaurant the next weekend and takes John and Teresa out to a restaurant that has handicap accessible entrances.
immoral_action: Mike tells John to just go without Teresa, since she has no adequate way to enter, because he wants eat at the exclusive restaurant.

norm: It's wrong to not include disabled people in events.
situation: Joan needs to book a restaurant for the office Christmas party.
intention: Joan wants a restaurant with top reviews.
moral_action: Joan ensures the top rated restaurant she selects can accommodate handicapped patrons.
immoral_action: Joan selects a top rated restaurant that doesn't accommodate handicapped patrons.

norm: It's wrong to be with someone who bullies disabled people.
situation: Justin sees Billy picking on a disabled man in a wheelchair at a restaurant.
intention: Justin wants a ride home from the restaurant.
moral_action: Justin calls a taxi service to get a ride back home from the restaurant.
immoral_action: Justin asks Billy for a ride home from the restaurant.

norm: It's wrong to make fun of people with disabilities
situation: Don is walking down the street when he encounters a man with one leg hobbling along.
intention: Don wants to feel good about himself.
moral_action: Don offers the man assistance and ask him how he is.
immoral_action: Don breaks out laughing at the guy and impersonates him.

norm: It's wrong to be rude to disabled people.
situation: Roy is standing in line and a man in a wheelchair cuts in line in front of him.
intention: Roy wants him to go to the back of the line.
moral_action: "Roy tells him ""hey, that isn't the back of the line"" and points to the back instead."
immoral_action: Roy tells him to get out of line because this line is only for STANDING in.

norm: It's wrong to act rudely toward mentally challenged folks.
situation: Danny was watching his kids play at the park, when a bigger kid came along and took a toy away from one of his children.
intention: Danny has to get the toy back for his child.
moral_action: Danny walks over to the bigger kid, and it becomes apparent that the child is developmentally challenged, Danny decides to let him keep the toy.
immoral_action: Danny yells at the bigger kid and tells him to give the toy back, he also refers to the older, bigger child as stupid.

norm: It's wrong to get upset with people who are disabled.
situation: A disabled man using a cane stumbles and bumps into Gary outside of a grocery store after which he apologizes.
intention: Gary wants to respond to the man's apology.
moral_action: Gary immediately accepts the man's apology and tells him not to worry about it.
immoral_action: Gary refuses the man's apology and loudly tells him to watch where he's going.

norm: It's wrong to not be considerate to the disabled.
situation: Haley is approaching a building she wants to go into when she sees that a man in a wheel chair is behind her.
intention: Haley wants to enter the building.
moral_action: Haley holds the door open for the man in the wheel chair then enters after him.
immoral_action: Haley enters the building and closes the door behind her before the man in the wheel chair can enter.

norm: It's wrong to make rude remarks to disabled people.
situation: Greg is a greeter at Wal-Mart, and someone in a wheelchair is coming into the store.
intention: Greg wants to say something to the man.
moral_action: Greg tells the man that if needs anything, don't feel afraid to ask.
immoral_action: Greg asks the man if he happens to know Stephen Hawking.

norm: It's good to take responsibly when you're young.
situation: Sam accidentally breaks a vase and his mother asks him what happened.
intention: Sam wants to respond to his mother's question.
moral_action: Sam tells his mother that he broke the vase and apologizes.
immoral_action: Sam tells his mother that the cat knocked the vase over.

norm: It's good to want kids to get some physical activity.
situation: Mary's kids are bored staying at home due to the Covid-19 stay-at-home order.
intention: Mary wants to the kids to do something to pass the time.
moral_action: Mary encourages the kids to do exercises together for 30 minutes each day.
immoral_action: Mary bought many video games so that the kids have something to play with.

norm: It's good to be physical in a relationship.
situation: John's girlfriend is going on a trip, and he's driving her to the airport.
intention: John wants to say goodbye to his girlfriend.
moral_action: John hugs his girlfriend tightly while saying goodbye.
immoral_action: John says and waves goodbye as his girlfriend goes into the airport.

norm: It's good for children to be in clean environments.
situation: Aaron sees that  his house is a mess and his kids are living in it, but he doesn't feel like cleaning.
intention: Aaron has to decide whether to clean up the house or not.
moral_action: Aaron cleans the house and assigns each of the kids a few household tasks that they can handle, to help keep it clean.
immoral_action: Aaron doesn't do any cleaning, he just accepts that the place is messy and assumes the kids will get used to the mess.

norm: It's good to have your kids get some fresh air.
situation: Keisha is at home with her two children and is cooking dinner.
intention: Keisha wants to keep her kids occupied.
moral_action: Keisha decides to grill dinner so her kids can run around outside while she keeps an eye on them.
immoral_action: Keisha gives her kids their tablets and tells them to play games, so she can concentrate on cooking.

norm: It's good to have a job when you're young.
situation: Dylan is a smart college student who is not working.
intention: Dylan wants to have a good paying career that he enjoys.
moral_action: Dylan takes retail and service jobs while he gets his education.
immoral_action: Dylan turns down entry level jobs hoping that his degree gets him the job that he wants.

norm: It's good to control your children.
situation: Tom takes his kids, Lee and Brad, to a toy store to get some Lego; the checkout line is long and the boys get bored waiting.
intention: Tom wants to purchase the Lego for Lee and Brad.
moral_action: Tom keeps an eye on the kids, and suggests they sit on one of the benches and play on his phone while they wait.
immoral_action: Tom ignores the boys, playing games on his phone while he waits in line; the boys start playing with stuff on the displays.

norm: It's good to discipline children.
situation: Carol and Tom have two children together but Tom always lets the children get away with they do wrong.
intention: Carol wants the children to be better behaved.
moral_action: Carol talks to Tom about the importance of making sure the children act good, and they act as a team when addressing the children's behavior issues.
immoral_action: Carol follows along with Tom's preferences in not disciplining the children, leaving it to teachers and family to make them act better.

norm: It's good to keep track of children.
situation: Claire takes her child Rod to the park for the afternoon.
intention: Claire wants to occupy herself while Rod plays.
moral_action: Claire follows Rod around the park and shows him how to use the playground equipment.
immoral_action: Claire lies down and takes a nap on the grass.

norm: It is good to provide a safe environment for children
situation: Tracy saved up enough money to build a pool for family and friends to enjoy.
intention: Tracy wants to stay within her pool budget.
moral_action: Tracy child proofs the pool while spending less on fancier materials to stay under budget.
immoral_action: Tracy passes on child proofing the pool to stick with budget.

norm: You shouldn't be picky when it comes to food.
situation: Johnny is young and enjoys playing games.
intention: Johnny wants to play video games.
moral_action: Johnny goes down to dinner to find vegetables on his plate and quickly eats his dinner regardless returning to his video games.
immoral_action: Johnny goes down to dinner to find vegetables on his plate and refuses to eat it returning to his video games.

norm: You shouldn't let your partner comment on your eating habits.
situation: John's eating a snack of potato chips when his wife Sally tells him that he's being unhealthy by eating the chips.
intention: John wants to respond to Sally's statement.
moral_action: John tells Sally that he's eating a small portion, and she should mind her own business.
immoral_action: John tells Sally that he's sorry for eating food that she has deemed unnaceptable and puts the chips away.

norm: You should not judge others eating habits.
situation: Bill and Peter are at the restaurant and are ordering food when Peter orders french fries soaked in gravy.
intention: Bill wants to comment on Peter's order.
moral_action: Bill tells Peter that his choice sounds delicious and tempting and that he'll order that next time.
immoral_action: Bill tells Peter his choice of appetizer was gross and unhealthy and that he'll die eating stuff like that.

norm: You shouldn't eat someone else's things.
situation: Fred forgets to bring his lunch to work.
intention: Fred wants to get something to eat for lunch.
moral_action: Fred purchases lunch from a local cafe.
immoral_action: Fred sees a lunchbox belonging to his coworker in the office kitchen and eats its contents.

norm: You shouldn't eat things that aren't meant to be eaten.
situation: Samuel is hiking along a mountain trail when he suddenly feels hungry.
intention: He wants to eat something.
moral_action: Samuel reaches into his backpack and pulls out some trail mix to eat.
immoral_action: Samuel picks some berries from a nearby tree to eat even though he doesn't know anything about them.

norm: You shouldn't eat animals that aren't meant for eating.
situation: Wang is going through his local wet market looking at all the creatures for sale.
intention: Wang wants to buy some meat for dinner.
moral_action: Wang buys a chicken to fix for dinner.
immoral_action: Wang buys a bat to take home to eat for dinner.

norm: You shouldn't serve someone a low quality food item.
situation: Gula's kid has friends over, and they're hungry, so she goes to the kitchen to make something.
intention: Gula needs to pick between food options.
moral_action: Gula makes something fresh for the kids.
immoral_action: Gula decides to make sandwiches with dated mayo, to get rid of it.

norm: You shouldn't serve people food that they are allergic to.
situation: Evelyn is having her family over for dinner, and she knows her sister is allergic to peanuts.
intention: Evelyn wants to serve a delicious dinner.
moral_action: Evelyn makes sure that all of the food she is serving is safe for her sister to eat.
immoral_action: Evelyn makes her favorite barbecue sauce that contains peanut oil thinking that her sister's peanut allergy is overblown.

norm: You shouldn't dump food on others.
situation: Sally has been spreading nasty rumors about Becca in the cafeteria at lunch time.
intention: Becca wants to express her dissatisfaction to Sally.
moral_action: Becca walks over to Sally and calls her out for spreading rumors.
immoral_action: Becca walks over to Sally and dumps a plate of food onto Sally's head.

norm: You should not leave food unattended
situation: Sam is birdwatching while eating lunch in the park when he receives a phone call.
intention: Sam wants to answer the phone call.
moral_action: Sam answers the phone call while remaining seated on a bench.
immoral_action: Sam leaves his food on the bench to get up and walk around while talking on the phone.

norm: You shouldn't eat food that tastes foul.
situation: Jo is hungry, but she can't find her car keys.
intention: Jo wants to find something to eat without leaving the house.
moral_action: Jo orders a large pizza to be delivered to her house.
immoral_action: Jo finds an expired container of yogurt in the refrigerator and decides to eat it.

norm: You shouldn't teach your children to eat unhealthy food
situation: Kim is about to eat dinner with her kids.
intention: Kim wants her children to eat something tasty.
moral_action: Kim prepares a tasty healthy meal of pasta, meat and vegetables.
immoral_action: Kim orders pizza.

norm: You shouldn't eat loudly around others.
situation: Frank is at a crowded diner eating his sandwich.
intention: Frank wants to finish his sandwich.
moral_action: Frank keeps his mouth closed while quietly chewing his sandwich.
immoral_action: Frank loudly chews his sandwich.

norm: You shouldn't mess with other people's foods
situation: Alex had a huge fight with a customer at her sandwich shop.
intention: Alex wants to get back at him.
moral_action: Alex refuses to serve the customer for his rudeness.
immoral_action: Alex decides to hide some hot sauce in the client's food.

norm: You shouldn't make fun of people's eating habits.
situation: Kevin is a student attending high school and all the students are on their lunch break where a particular classmate is eating heavily.
intention: Kevin wants to enjoy himself.
moral_action: Kevin doesn't notice his classmate who is eating heavily and spends the lunch break making jokes about a popular movie with a friend.
immoral_action: Kevin pokes fun at the classmate who is eating heavily calling them names and drawing attention to their eating.

norm: You shouldn't eat food that isn't yours.
situation: Joey's date Melinda is in the restaurant restroom when their desserts arrive, and after taking a bite of his own, Joey realizes that he hates it.
intention: Joey wants to enjoy some dessert.
moral_action: Joey flags down the waiter and asks for the same dessert that Melinda ordered.
immoral_action: Joey eats some of Melinda's dessert while she is in the restroom.

norm: You shouldn't let someone else go hungry.
situation: Carson is eating lunch in the break room when Amy says she forgot her lunch.
intention: Carson wants to interact with Amy.
moral_action: Carson order pizza for his coworkers.
immoral_action: Carson tells Amy to buy some food from the vending machines.

norm: You shouldn't eat junk food and be lazy.
situation: Candace has recently lost her job and is quite depressed about it.
intention: Candace wants to be less depressed.
moral_action: Candace immediately starts looking for a new job and updates her skills.
immoral_action: Candace responds to her job loss by sleeping all day and eating candy.

norm: You shouldn't hog someone's food.
situation: Wanda is eating at a restaurant with her boyfriend, who ordered a different meal, and when their orders arrive she notices how delicious his fries look.
intention: Wanda wants to eat some fries.
moral_action: Wanda tries a fry and decides to order another side of them for herself.
immoral_action: Wanda ends up eating more of her boyfriend's fries than he does.

norm: You shouldn't bother someone while they are eating.
situation: Cash often plays pranks on his mother, Tiffany, with scary props.
intention: Cash wants to prank Tiffany with a fake snake.
moral_action: After dinner, Cash puts a fake snake in the dishwasher.
immoral_action: Cash puts a fake snake beneath the lid of a serving dish at dinner.

norm: You shouldn't pee in someone's food because that's unsanitary.
situation: Anthony, a chef in a rather prestigious restaurant overhears a customer, who recently ordered pasta with tomato sauce insult his looks to someone else.
intention: Anthony wants to pay back the customer.
moral_action: Anthony excuses himself from the kitchen and walks up to the customer and confronts him.
immoral_action: In the late stages of the tomato sauce, Anthony decides to pee a small amount into it.

norm: You shouldn't serve people food that is horrible.
situation: Martha cooks dinner for her children but it gets burned and is in terrible condition.
intention: Martha wants to do something with the food she cooked.
moral_action: Martha throws the burnt food away and orders delivery for her children to eat instead.
immoral_action: Martha serves the burnt food to her children even though it's not appetizing at all.

norm: You shouldn't feel responsible to feed your friends.
situation: Ben hardly has any food left until payday, but his friends, Julie and Jim, just showed up to play cards, and he wanted to eat some potato chips.
intention: Ben wants to have a snack.
moral_action: Ben takes out just enough chips for himself, and tells Julie and Jim, he's sorry, but doesn't have anything to offer them,.
immoral_action: Ben dumps the chips into a bowl and tells Julie and Jim to help themselves because he didn't want to feel like a bad host.

norm: You shouldn't let people throw away perfectly good food.
situation: Kelly was sitting at a restaurant with her parents, but her parents didn't finish eating their food.
intention: Kelly wants to get the food off the table.
moral_action: Kelly tells the waiter to put her parents's food in a to go bag.
immoral_action: Kelly lets her parents throw the rest of their food in the trash bin.

norm: You shouldn't laugh at someone's food.
situation: Joe's girlfriend May has invited him over for dinner.
intention: Joe wants to react to the vegetarian menu.
moral_action: Joe thanks May for the meal.
immoral_action: Joe laughingly refers to the meal as rabbit food.

norm: You should not touch other people's food
situation: Nick and Leah are eating and Leah has ordered a unique looking sausage that the waiter brings her.
intention: Nick wants to ask Leah about the sausage.
moral_action: Nick points to the sausage on Leah's plate and looks at it and asks what it is.
immoral_action: Nick picks up the sausage off of Leah's plate and looks at it and asks what it is.

norm: You shouldn't leave your food laying around.
situation: Sally just finished a late meal at her kitchen table and has leftover food.
intention: Sally wants to go to bed.
moral_action: Sally puts the food in the refrigerator before going on to bed.
immoral_action: Sally leaves the leftovers out on the table and heads to bed.

norm: You shouldn't let people tell you how to eat.
situation: John's friend tells John not to eat the french fries, as they are fattening.
intention: John doesn't want to offend his friend.
moral_action: John tells his friend that it's his cheat day for his diet and it's a one-time treat.
immoral_action: John agrees with his friend and doesn't eat the french fries.

norm: It's not okay to mock someone's diet choices.
situation: Keara is talking to her friend about their new diet.
intention: Keara wants to give feedback about the diet.
moral_action: Keara constructively outlines the pros and cons of vegan diet.
immoral_action: Keara makes fun of her friend for going vegan.

norm: You shouldn't talk with food in your mouth.
situation: Greg is having dinner with his family.
intention: Greg wants to tell his family about his day.
moral_action: Greg chews and swallows his food, then talks about his day at work.
immoral_action: Greg tries to talk with a mouthful of chicken nuggets.

norm: It's not right to take someone else's sandwich.
situation: James' blood sugar is running low while walking on a sidewalk, and he feels he will pass out if he does not eat.
intention: James wants to get food from someone fast.
moral_action: James runs up to the picnic and explains his situation before asking for a small sugary snack.
immoral_action: James runs up to a nearby picnic and grabs someone's sandwich to help his blood sugar.

norm: It's mean to not share your food.
situation: Lin has been working all day after skipping lunch and has become famished.
intention: Lin wants to order a pizza.
moral_action: Lin orders an extra large pizza and shares it with her coworkers.
immoral_action: Lin buys a personal pan pizza which is only enough for one person.

norm: You shouldn't care about how much someone eats.
situation: Oscar has a large friend named Tom, whom he thinks is too heavy, and is eating at a restaurant with him.
intention: Oscar wants to help Tom lose weight.
moral_action: Oscar offers to start an exercise routine with Tom to get in better shape.
immoral_action: Oscar tells Tom that he needs to cut down on how much food he eats, so he doesn't die.

norm: You shouldn't take someone's food.
situation: Chris just finished eating lunch in the school cafeteria and is still hungry, but his friend James has a whole tray.
intention: Chris wants to eat more.
moral_action: Chris sees James step away for a moment but waits for him to come back to ask to have some fries.
immoral_action: Chris notices that James walked away for a moment and takes his french fries.

norm: It's frowned upon to refuse food that someone offers.
situation: Brad is on a diet, but he's over at a house party and his friend Ted offers him a homemade cookie.
intention: Brad wants to lose weight.
moral_action: Brad accepts a cookie and goes for a run later to make up for it.
immoral_action: Brad pushes the cookie away and refuses to eat it.

norm: You shouldn't eat food off the ground.
situation: Bart went to the restaurant and his waitress dropped his food on the floor when she was bringing it to him.
intention: Bart wants to eat.
moral_action: Bart asks his waitress if she could bring him another plate.
immoral_action: Bart gets on the floor and eats the food off of the ground.

norm: You should not fry everything you eat.
situation: Mickey doesn't have an oven, only a hot plate, so he fries all of his food, but lately he has been feeling lethargic and weakened.
intention: Mickey has to decide whether he needs to change his diet to feel better.
moral_action: Mickey starts eating more raw vegetables and fruits, and only cooks his food a few times a week until he gets an oven.
immoral_action: Mickey decides that his lethargy has nothing to do with his food, so he doesn't make any changes to his diet.

norm: You shouldn't play with your food.
situation: Cameron is at a fancy restaurant eating dinner with his parents.
intention: Cameron wants a bite of mashed potatoes.
moral_action: Cameron takes a bite of mashed potatoes and uses his napkin to clean up his face.
immoral_action: Cameron takes a bite of mashed potatoes and has it erupt out of his mouth like a volcano.

norm: You shouldn't let someone eat your food.
situation: James often bought frozen dinners, but someone kept eating them before he could get to them.
intention: James wants to always have frozen dinners available.
moral_action: James secretly installs a camera in the kitchen to catch the person taking his food.
immoral_action: James starts buying twice as many frozen dinners at the grocery store each week.

norm: It's wrong not to show up for an appointment.
situation: Jane and Lisa are working on a project at work that they must present soon.
intention: Jane wants to find the perfect outfit for the presentation.
moral_action: Jane picks out an outfit the day before the presentation and gets there early enough to prepare.
immoral_action: Jane spends so much time picking out an outfit, she misses the presentation entirely.

norm: It's wrong to complain all the time.
situation: Connie is out with friends on lunch break, and they are talking together.
intention: Connie wants to make conversation.
moral_action: Connie says how grateful she is for her job and her friends.
immoral_action: Connie complains about her job, her boss, and the company during the whole lunch break.

norm: It's rude not to open the door to somebody
situation: A stranger asks John to hold the door as he is entering the store.
intention: John wants to respond to the request.
moral_action: John smiles and holds the door open for the stranger.
immoral_action: "John says ""no"" and lets the door swing closed."

norm: It is unprofessional to forget when you have an appointment.
situation: Marnie is very busy with work and has an appointment with a vendor this afternoon.
intention: Marnie wants to do well and get her work done.
moral_action: Marnie sets a reminder on her phone for the meeting.
immoral_action: Marnie gets so wrapped up in her work that she forgets to go to the vendor meeting.

norm: It's rude not to keep a scheduled appointment.
situation: Ari has a client meeting scheduled but his friend has just invited him to go rock climbing.
intention: Ari wants to have fun with his friend.
moral_action: Ari tells his friend that he has a meeting and makes plans to go rock climbing once he's done.
immoral_action: Ari goes rock climbing with his friend and skips the meeting.

norm: It's rude to expect people to always give you rides.
situation: Xavier is in a foreign country without a car and needs to make a long trip.
intention: Xavier wants to hitchhike to his destination.
moral_action: Xavier starts walking and sticks his thumb out as people pass by.
immoral_action: Xavier stands by the side of the road and attempts to jump into the first pick-up truck he sees.

norm: It's unprofessional to be late to work.
situation: Jane has recently started a new job where she is expected to come in at 9:00.
intention: Jane wants to make an appointment with her doctor who only has appointments available in the morning.
moral_action: Jane schedules her appointment with the doctor for 8:00 and informs her manager in case it runs late.
immoral_action: Jane schedules the appointment with her doctor at 9:00 without informing anyone at work.

norm: It's not nice to expect others to wait for you
situation: Jenna was supposed to meet her friends at 8 AM to drive to an amusement park, and woke up hungover at 7:30.
intention: Jenna wants to get more sleep.
moral_action: Jenna goes directly to meet her friends and asks them if she can sleep in the backseat of their car.
immoral_action: Jenna falls back asleep in her bed and arrives to the meeting point an hour late.

norm: It's rude to expect others to always include you.
situation: Dana is told by her friend Mindy that she is going out on a date with a guy she's interested.
intention: Dana wants to respond to Mindy.
moral_action: Dana tells Mindy she should have fun on the date.
immoral_action: Dana says that she should have been invited on Mindy's date.

norm: It's wrong to mooch off other people all the time.
situation: Jackie watches her traditional boyfriend Jared fumble around his wallet for cash to pay for their meal.
intention: Jackie wants to avoid an embarrassing situation with the waitress.
moral_action: Jackie hands her card to the waitress before Jared can respond.
immoral_action: Jackie tells Jared to  put the meal on his credit card.

norm: It's rude to have someone wait for you.
situation: Steve promised to meet Laura at the library at 7pm to study for a test, but he's feeling hungry.
intention: Steve wants to get something to eat.
moral_action: Steve gets something to eat at the cafe in the library.
immoral_action: Steve stops at a pizzeria on the way to the library.

norm: It's rude not to hold the door for other people.
situation: Jim is walking towards the bank with a man on crutches walking behind him.
intention: Jim wants to enter the bank.
moral_action: Jim opens the door, steps aside for the man on crutches to enter, then walks inside the bank.
immoral_action: Jim opens the door and walks inside the bank.

norm: It's impolite not to open the door for someone.
situation: Barry was walking into the hotel and Sally was walking in after him.
intention: Barry wants to open the door.
moral_action: Barry opens the door for himself and holds it open for Sally to go through.
immoral_action: Barry opens the door for himself and lets it close behind him.

norm: It is rude to complain about waiting.
situation: A bored Rachael has been waiting for her food at a restaurant for twenty minutes.
intention: Rachael wants to get rid of her boredom.
moral_action: Rachael plays games on her cellphone until her food arrives.
immoral_action: Rachael passes time by making comments about the wait time to the person sitting near her.

norm: It's rude to keep other people waiting for you
situation: Utari is playing a match in Overwatch when his alarm notifies him of his meeting with a client in twenty minutes.
intention: Utari wants to have fun.
moral_action: Utari drives to the meeting place, and reads his favorite book while he waits for his client.
immoral_action: Utari continues playing Overwatch until he reaches a stopping point.

norm: It's disrespectful to keep people waiting
situation: Jeremy is meeting up with his friends to go to a concert but is feeling hungry.
intention: Jeremy wants to get something to eat.
moral_action: Jeremy leaves early to eat first then meets with his friends.
immoral_action: Jeremy gets something to eat right before he has to meet with his friends.

norm: You shouldn't yell at your teachers.
situation: John is in class passing notes when his teacher Mary notices him and takes the note away.
intention: John wants to react to what just happened.
moral_action: John apologizes to the teacher for being distracted during class and distracting others as well.
immoral_action: John screams at the teacher to give his note back to him, that it's his and that she's mean and unfair.

norm: You shouldn't swear at your teachers.
situation: Jordan has had his hand raised for a while in class and his teacher hasn't called on him.
intention: Jordan wants to ask to go to the restroom.
moral_action: Jordan coughs loudly and says his teacher's name to get her attention.
immoral_action: Jordan gets up, calls his teacher a bitch, and tells her he has to use the bathroom.

norm: You shouldn't tell your classmate to shut up.
situation: Mary and Edward are giving a presentation to their class together, but Mary doesn't understand the topic well.
intention: Edward wants to present accurate information.
moral_action: Edward waits for Mary to finish speaking, then adds the corrections to her information as bullet points on the board beside the presentation.
immoral_action: Edward interjects while Mary is speaking and tells her to shut up, then supplying the audience with the correct information.

norm: You shouldn't tell your parents to shut up.
situation: Emma was watching videos on her phone at the family dinner table.
intention: Emma wanted to hear the music from the video better.
moral_action: Emma put in her bluetooth headphones and turned up the volume of the music.
immoral_action: Emma told her parents they need to pipe down, so she could hear better.

norm: You shouldn't give your students mean looks.
situation: Mrs. Smith is handing out graded papers to her students at the end of class.
intention: Mrs. Smith wants to let Jimmy know he could have done better.
moral_action: Mrs. Smith puts Jimmy's test on his desk and asks to speak to him about his performance after the bell.
immoral_action: Mrs. Smith puts Jimmy's test down on his desk and gives him a mean look full of spite and disappointment.

norm: You shouldn't humiliate your professors.
situation: Bruce is taking a nuclear physics class at Harvard University.
intention: Bruce wants to correct his professor's mistake during a class about gamma radiation.
moral_action: Bruce asks the professor a clarifying question, giving the professor a chance to catch his mistake.
immoral_action: Bruce interrupts the lecture to tell the rest of the class that the professor made a simple mistake that anyone should have noticed.

norm: You shouldn't let someone quit school.
situation: Jon's son Billy has been really unhappy in school lately.
intention: Jon wants Billy to be happy.
moral_action: Jon, Billy and the school guidance counselor sit down and have a long discussion.
immoral_action: Jon signs Billy out of school after Billy begs him to do it.

norm: It's good to offer to tutor people.
situation: Trent is listening to his friend Jake complain about his difficult math class.
intention: Trent wants Jake to get some help.
moral_action: Trent offers to help Jake understand the topic.
immoral_action: Trent directs Jake to a math tutoring website.

norm: It's good to award your students for their efforts.
situation: Mr. Brown is a high-school teacher who is tough on his students.
intention: Mr. Brown wants his students to work hard.
moral_action: Mr.Brown throws pizza parties for his students when they reach major milestones.
immoral_action: Mr.Brown assigns heavy work on a daily basis without ever commending his students for doing their part.

norm: It is good to encourage students.
situation: Mary is an elementary school teacher who has one student who is struggling to learn fractions.
intention: Mary wants the struggling student's parents to view her positively.
moral_action: Mary sets up mentoring sessions for the struggling student where they receive encouragement and tutoring.
immoral_action: Mary tells the student's parents that their child is doing okay and inflates the student's grade to avoid conflict.

norm: It's good to study with your friends.
situation: Fred and George are friends and classmates who have an important final exam coming up the next day in math class.
intention: Fred wants to get a good grade on the test.
moral_action: Fred asks George to study with him, and they spend the rest of the evening going over notes together.
immoral_action: Fred studies his math notes by himself at home that evening.

norm: It's good to be supportive of your classmates.
situation: James, who isn't particularly interested in sports, just found out that his school's football team qualified for the state championships.
intention: James wants to avoid annoying his classmates.
moral_action: James congratulates all his classmates who are on the football team.
immoral_action: James plays with his phone while everyone else is congratulating the football team.

norm: It's good to help your classmates out.
situation: Rudy's classmate can't see that far, so they're asking Rudy if they can copy his notes.
intention: Rudy wants to respond to the classmate.
moral_action: Rudy sits closer to the classmate so that they can copy his notes easier.
immoral_action: Rudy tells his classmate to get some glasses, so he can take his own notes.

norm: It's good to mentor students.
situation: Anna had been working as a teacher for a while, and she wanted to be promoted soon.
intention: Anna wants to do something that will impress her boss.
moral_action: Anna starts mentoring students by spending time with them after school to impress the boss.
immoral_action: Anna enrolls in classes, so she can further her education to impress the boss, so she must leave right after class each day.

norm: It's wrong to verbally abuse your mother.
situation: Steve is not happy with his mother asking him to do so many chores.
intention: Steve wants to express anger at his mother.
moral_action: Steve asks his mom to talk and explains how he feels that the amount of work is unfair.
immoral_action: Steve swears at his mother and calls her stupid.

norm: It's considered inappropriate to yell at your own mother.
situation: Alan lives with his mother who has dementia, and he notices that she left the stove on.
intention: Alan wants his mother to be safe and not burn the house down.
moral_action: Alan talks to his mother calmly and decides to install safety locks for the stove.
immoral_action: Alan gets angry and yells at his mother not to leave the stove on.

norm: It's wrong to harm your mother.
situation: Jessie lives with her mom, Mary, who often opens Jessie's packages without permission.
intention: Jessie wants to confront her mom about opening her packages.
moral_action: Jessie kindly asks Mary to stop opening her packages and threatens to move out if she continues.
immoral_action: Jessie catches Mary with one of her packages and pushes her.

norm: It is wrong to do anything that hurts your wife.
situation: Danny and his wife Diane invited their friends over for the night.
intention: Danny wants to entertain his friends.
moral_action: Danny suggests that they play a fun card game.
immoral_action: Danny pranks Diane in front of their friends.

norm: It's wrong to lie to your family about your pregnancy.
situation: Joan grew up in an abusive household and is pregnant with her first child with her husband.
intention: Joan wants to protect her future child from her abusive parents.
moral_action: Joan tells her parents she is pregnant and lays out rules they must follow to have a relationship with their grandchild.
immoral_action: Joan decides to hide her pregnancy from her parents for as long as she can.

norm: It's wrong to call your mom stupid.
situation: Charles is annoyed when his mother asks him questions about how to operate her new tv.
intention: Charles wants to help his mother.
moral_action: Charles reads the instruction manual with his mother explaining all the technical terms to her.
immoral_action: Charles configures the TV while he compares his mother's intelligence to a two year old.

norm: It is wrong to force your daughter to marry.
situation: Steve's daughter is 25 and still at home, he is worried she'll never find a suitor.
intention: Steve wants his daughter to marry.
moral_action: Steve tells his daughter how important seeing her married is to him.
immoral_action: Steve pressures his daughter into marrying her abusive boyfriend.

norm: It is wrong to neglect your pregnant wife.
situation: John is at home with his pregnant wife who is nearing labor.
intention: John wants to have a fun time on the town.
moral_action: John tends to his wife's needs, takes her to the hospital and waits for her to give birth before going out with friends.
immoral_action: John ignores her and goes bar-hopping.

norm: It's wrong to hit your wife.
situation: Brad's wife burned a hole in his favorite shirt when she was ironing.
intention: Brad wants his wife to see why he can't wear the shirt.
moral_action: Brad lets his wife know that he is throwing the shirt because of the burn marks.
immoral_action: Brad shows the shirt to his wife and then slaps her across the face for burning it.

norm: It is wrong to steal a ring from your mom.
situation: Marlon lives with his parents and has a girlfriend that likes jewelry and their anniversary is coming up.
intention: Marlon wants to give his girlfriend a ring.
moral_action: Marlon gets a job and earns money to buy a ring for his girlfriend.
immoral_action: Marlon finds a ring in his mom's jewelry box and takes it to give to his girlfriend.

norm: It's wrong to disrespect a person's mother.
situation: Clayton is trying to comfort his best friend Maurice who was punished by his parents for low grades.
intention: Clayton wants Maurice to make Maurice smile.
moral_action: Clayton recites an inspirational quote and offers to help Maurice study.
immoral_action: Clayton makes a silly impersonation of Maurice's parents.

norm: It's wrong to make a new wife feel unwelcome
situation: Rick is at home when his son and his new bride arrive back from their honeymoon.
intention: Rick wants to talk about the couple's future.
moral_action: Rick tells his son and his wife that their marriage will have ups and downs but as long as their love is strong their future will be great.
immoral_action: Rick tells his son and his wife that they can't stay with him long, and they both need jobs, so they can get out of there soon.

norm: It's wrong to argue with your mother.
situation: Sarah bought a new outfit to wear to school but her mother tells her to wear something else because it's inappropriate.
intention: Sarah wants to respond to her mother.
moral_action: Sarah realizes her mother is right about the outfit and tells her that she will go change.
immoral_action: Sarah asks her mother why it's inappropriate and says that she's being too critical, this is what all her friends are wearing.

norm: It's bad to pry into the personal lives of others.
situation: Stacy wants to know why Larry has been so secretive lately.
intention: Stacy wants find what Larry is hiding.
moral_action: Stacy sits down and talks with Larry to see why he has been so secretive.
immoral_action: Stacy goes through Larry's phone.

norm: It is rude to ask personal questions for other people.
situation: Phil was at work talking to his coworkers Mike and Jane.
intention: Phil wants to stimulate conversation.
moral_action: Phil asks Mike and Jane what their favorite hobby is.
immoral_action: Phil asks Mike and Jane what religion they happen to be.

norm: It's bad to misrepresent yourself in a chatroom.
situation: Will is bored and logs onto a chatroom full of teenagers.
intention: Will wants to have fun chatting with people.
moral_action: Will starts talking about life, the universe, and everything with the other people.
immoral_action: Will pretends to be a girl and starts flirting with the guys in the chatroom.

norm: It is rude to tell everyone about private messages.
situation: Sally gets a private text message from her husband while she is visiting her friend.
intention: Sally wants to make conversation with her friend.
moral_action: Sally talks to her friend about topics of mutual interest but doesn't bring up the text.
immoral_action: Sally tells her friend what her husband wrote to her in the private text message.

norm: It's bad to look in your significant other's private things.
situation: Linda tends to be jealous and thinks she has seen her husband furtively texting behind her back.
intention: Linda wants to know what kind of texts his husband is sending.
moral_action: Linda directly asks her husband what he was texting about.
immoral_action: Linda looks at her husband's phone at night while he is sleeping.

norm: It's rude to ask personal questions of strangers.
situation: Bob is working at a store and meets a talkative stranger.
intention: Bob wants to carry a conversation with the stranger.
moral_action: Bob asks the stranger about what he does for work.
immoral_action: Bob asks the stranger about his personal love life.

norm: It's wrong to publish someone's secret emails.
situation: Crystal receives an email from a male friend, expressing deep feelings of attraction and love.
intention: Crystal wants get advice from her friends about the possibility of forming a new romantic relationship.
moral_action: Crystal calls a close friend and discusses the email she received, in private, asking for advice on how to proceed in the potential relationship.
immoral_action: Crystal posts the full text of her friend's email to her Facebook account as a status, asking her friends for comments.

norm: It's bad to read someone's private conversation without them knowing.
situation: Tina notices her boyfriend has been messaging a female friend of his all day.
intention: Tina wants to know what they are talking about.
moral_action: Tina casually asks her boyfriend directly what they are talking about.
immoral_action: Tina waits for her boyfriend to go to the bathroom and checks his phone.

norm: It is rude to pester people with personal questions.
situation: Debby is having a dinner gathering with her friend Emma and Emma's boyfriend Scott, and Emma goes to the bathroom for some time.
intention: Debby wants to socialize with Scott.
moral_action: Debby asks Scott how and where he first met Emma.
immoral_action: Debby asks Scott about his occupation and salary.

norm: It is rude to snoop through other people's private messages.
situation: Dave is dating a partner who has a friend who he is feeling jealous over.
intention: Dave wants to see if there's anything going on between them.
moral_action: Dave finds a way to casually ask his partner about the nature of their relationship.
immoral_action: Dave takes his partner's phone and starts looking through her messages.

norm: It's rude to pry into a person's private affairs.
situation: Nicole is working out at the gym, and she sees her friend, Becky, who recently got a divorce.
intention: Nicole wants to know how Betty is doing.
moral_action: Nicole stays away from any sensitive topics and just inquires about Betty's general well being.
immoral_action: Nicole repeatedly asks Betty lots of personal questions about her divorce.

norm: It's rude to be snooping on other people's personal lives.
situation: Callie is sitting in a diner when she overhears a couple having a heated discussion.
intention: Callie wants to eat her lunch.
moral_action: Callie takes her food and moves to another table to give the couple privacy.
immoral_action: Callie stays at her table, so she can hear what the couple is talking about.

norm: It is good to accommodate peoples allergies if you can.
situation: Tom is hosting his friends for a dinner party and one his friends is allergic to peanuts.
intention: Tom wants everyone to have a good time.
moral_action: Tom accommodates his friend and cooks peanut-allergy-friendly dishes.
immoral_action: Tom ignores his friends allergy and makes the main course include peanuts or peanut oil.

norm: It's good to want to take people's mental conditions seriously.
situation: John and Mary just had a baby but Mary has been depressed since the birth.
intention: John wants Mary to get back to her normal self.
moral_action: John persuades Mary to seek professional help and takes on more responsibility caring for their child.
immoral_action: "John ignores Mary's growing depression and assumes she'll ""snap out of it"" eventually."

norm: It's good to call people to get problems fixed.
situation: Dave is at home with his wife Jane when their hot water pipe bursts in the basement.
intention: Dave wants to get the pipe repaired.
moral_action: Dave gets on the phone and calls a professional plumber to come over right away.
immoral_action: Dave goes downstairs and pulls out his tools and attempts to fix the pipe on his own with no expertise.

norm: It's good to inform your landlord of problems.
situation: Tom has his hours cut at the restaurant that he works at because of the pandemic.
intention: Tom wants to be able to maintain a place to live.
moral_action: Tom explains his work situation to his landlord, who agrees to allow Tom extra time to pay his rent over the coming months.
immoral_action: Tom starts selling weed to get money to pay his rent.

norm: It's good to speak to your neighbors about problems.
situation: Sonya's downstairs neighbor watches TV late into the night at a loud volume.
intention: Sonya wants a quieter residence at night.
moral_action: Sonya knocks on Rudy's door and lets him know that his TV is too loud late at night.
immoral_action: Sonya complains to the apartment for three nights in a row without ever expressing concern to Rudy.

norm: It's good to help customers with their problems.
situation: June is nearing the end of a long shift at her retail job when a customer approaches her for help with a time consuming problem.
intention: June wants to clock out, so she can get off her feet.
moral_action: June helps the customer until the next shift arrives then hands the customer issue over.
immoral_action: June tells the customer to wait for the next shift to come and help her, then leaves the customer to wait.

norm: It's good to tell people your problems.
situation: Kathleen just lost her job, feels hopeless and hasn't even told her best fiend, Julie.
intention: Kathleen wants to react to her situation.
moral_action: Kathleen tells Julie whats going on in her life and how she feels.
immoral_action: Kathleen decides to keeps her feelings bottled up.

norm: It's good to use words to settle your conflicts.
situation: Rhonda is confronted by her friend Amy who says she wants to talk about an argument they left unresolved.
intention: Rhonda wants to react to Amy.
moral_action: Rhonda tells Amy exactly how she feels and gives Amy a chance to respond.
immoral_action: Rhonda gives Amy the silent treatment and refuses to discuss the issue further.

norm: It is good to let people know of game glitches.
situation: Jim is a game tester at a major game developer and toward the end of his work day found a glitch in the game he is testing.
intention: Jim wants to go home.
moral_action: Jim reports the glitch to the system before he leaves for home.
immoral_action: Jim doesn't spend the time reporting the glitch before going home.

norm: It's good to look out for your mental health.
situation: Bob has been feeling increasingly down and unmotivated lately and begins to wonder if he has depression.
intention: Bob wants to do something to feel better.
moral_action: Bob seeks help about his concerns from a mental health professional.
immoral_action: Bob begins drinking regularly to feel better and forget his problems.

norm: It's good to find resolutions to arguments.
situation: Mary is accused of stealing from Ted while in a room with Ted.
intention: Mary wants to end the conversation.
moral_action: Mary decides to help Ted with any losses he occurred and resolves the conflict.
immoral_action: Mary decides to leave the room without resolving the argument.

norm: It's good to give people space to process a tragedy.
situation: Noor has just lost his father in a tragic accident and is currently sitting in a tutoring session with Jade.
intention: Jade wants to help Noor feel better.
moral_action: Jade asks Noor if he'd rather sit alone for some time, and lets him decide what feels best.
immoral_action: Jade offers to take Noor out on the town to party and forget his sadness.

norm: It's encouraged to resolve conflicts amicably.
situation: Basil is about to park at the mall when Austin drives into his parking spot.
intention: Basil wants to react to having his spot snatched.
moral_action: Basil gets out of his car and tells Austin that he was there first and Austin should really let him park there.
immoral_action: Basil gets out of his car and tells Austin that he should probably wipe the floor with him for being so rude.

norm: It's smart to talk about one's grief with others.
situation: Frank is going through some inner turmoil which is beginning to show on his face so his friend Andy asks him what's wrong.
intention: Frank wants to answer Andy's quesiton.
moral_action: Frank tells Andy that he's been going through some mental anguish, and he's not feeling great about it.
immoral_action: Frank tells Andy that nothing is wrong, and he simply is concentrating on some thoughts, so he might look weird.

norm: It's good to help people out with their problems.
situation: Jennifer just started her new office job and noticed that one of her co-workers is having trouble figuring something out.
intention: Jennifer wants to make a positive impression on her supervisor.
moral_action: Jennifer walks up to her coworker and asks him if he would like some help with the problem.
immoral_action: Jennifer decides to work out the problem on her own and submits the solution to her supervisor before her coworker does.

norm: It's good to get help with your mental issues.
situation: Brody has been feeling depressed and run down the last few days.
intention: Brody wants to take some pills.
moral_action: Brody goes to the doctor's office and gets a prescription for antidepressants.
immoral_action: Brody takes a handful of pills from the medicine cabinet at his mother's house.

norm: It's good to try to talk through disagreements.
situation: Zelda is having an argument with her friend over how they should solve a puzzle.
intention: Zelda wants to show her way is the right solution.
moral_action: Zelda demonstrates to her friend how the solution she has in mind would actually indeed work.
immoral_action: Zelda tells her friend to leave her alone and that she will just do the puzzle herself.

norm: It's good to tell your friends about your problems.
situation: Matthew and his friend Nick are hanging out, when Nick notices that Matthew looks down and asks him what's wrong.
intention: Matthew wants to get some advice on how to deal with his problems.
moral_action: Matthew opens up to Nick and tells him all about his problems, asking him what he should do to fix them.
immoral_action: Matthew tells Nick that he has some problems that are too private to discuss with him and that he's seeking professional help for them.

norm: It's good to admit when you have a problem.
situation: Gin is a closet alcoholic who really needs to get her drinking under control with the help of her family.
intention: Gin wants to get the help that she needs to recover.
moral_action: Gin asks her family if they would be willing to help her pay for rehab.
immoral_action: Gin drinks until she is admitted to the hospital and required to go to inpatient rehab.

norm: It's good to be direct with someone who upset you.
situation: Bill and his friend Bob get into an argument after Bob said something rude to Bill's sister.
intention: Bill wants to move past the transgression.
moral_action: Bill lets Bob know that what he said is not OK and that if they are to remain friends that cannot happen again.
immoral_action: Bill does not say anything to Bob about the transgression and let's Bob get away with it.

norm: It's good to keep your composure when you are upset.
situation: Stacy is giving a presentation at work, and one of the coworkers is berating her mercilessly.
intention: Stacy wants to get one over on her coworker.
moral_action: Stacy calmly explains how the coworker is wrong and exactly what is wrong with his reasoning.
immoral_action: Stacy unloads a torrent of screaming and profanity at the coworker.

norm: It's good to be there for others who are upset.
situation: Lilian's friend is going through a bad breakup and asks Lilian to spend Saturday evening with her because she feels very lonely.
intention: Lilian wants to have a pleasant Saturday evening.
moral_action: Lilian spends the evening with her lonely friend, and they watch a great comedy together.
immoral_action: Lilian tells her friend she is not free on Saturday evening and goes out with other friends instead.

norm: It's nice to offer advice when someone is confused.
situation: Noelle is a supervisor at her company that has new employees who are learning the ropes.
intention: Noelle wants to talk to a new hire.
moral_action: Noelle encourages the new worker to ask them questions when they don't know what to do.
immoral_action: Noelle tells the new hire that they'll be let go if they can't learn on their own.

norm: It is good to care for something that is helpless.
situation: Diana is at a new years party at her friend's house when she notices her friend's dog trembling under the table.
intention: Diana wants to interact with the dog.
moral_action: Diana holds the dog close to her and gives the dog a treat.
immoral_action: Diana pushes the dog outside.

norm: It's good to help out the hard of hearing.
situation: Sally is on vacation in the Bahamas taking a guided tour of the island, but her husband Dan is hard of hearing.
intention: Sally wants to react to Dan.
moral_action: Sally understands what the guide is saying, so she tells Dan what's being said.
immoral_action: Sally understands what the guide is saying, but doesn't bother to tell Dan what she hears because she doesn't want to take away from her enjoyment.

norm: It's good to say a well-meaning remark to someone struggling.
situation: Claire sees that her friend Ashley is down in the dumps about a breakup.
intention: Claire wants to give Ashley her advice.
moral_action: Claire tells Ashley that she is a strong person, and she will be fine.
immoral_action: Claire tells Ashley that it's her fault for the breakup because she has bad taste in men.

norm: It is good to vent your frustrations.
situation: Micky has been having a lot of stresses in his life lately and is at home with his wife.
intention: Micky wants to spend quality time with his wife.
moral_action: Micky opens up to his wife about his situation and is able to get some weight off of his shoulders.
immoral_action: Micky puts on a front for his wife as to not make her share in his situation, and they watch a movie together.

norm: It's good to realize when you're bothering others.
situation: Bob is talking with a coworker but it seems like they are trying to get work done and that Bob might be annoying them.
intention: Bob wants to decide whether to keep talking to his coworker.
moral_action: Bob decides it's best to leave the coworker alone to do their work and see if they instigate further conversation.
immoral_action: Bob keeps talking to the coworker figuring that they would tell him to stop if they wanted him to.

norm: It is good to control yourself.
situation: Paul is out drinking with some friends at the bar.
intention: Paul wants to enjoy the evening.
moral_action: Paul makes sure to pace his drinking so that he stays present enough to make wise decisions while having fun.
immoral_action: Paul orders drink after drink as he feels it is fueling his good time.

norm: It's good to overcome the things you struggle with.
situation: Ben has been addicted to heroin ever since his friends gave him some at a party.
intention: Ben has to decide whether he wants to keep doing heroin.
moral_action: Ben meets with a counselor in order to see what he can do about his heroin use.
immoral_action: Ben decides that heroin makes him feel good, so he's going to keep using it.

norm: It's good to assure people when they are worried.
situation: Greg's friend Jim told them they were really worried for his next algebra exam.
intention: Greg wants to say something to Jim.
moral_action: Greg tells Jim that he's worried because he hasn't studied enough.
immoral_action: Greg tells Jim that he needs to suck it up and stop thinking about it.

norm: It's wrong to replace people's medication.
situation: Jason is the caregiver for his elderly uncle but is not feeling well today.
intention: Jason wants his headache to go away.
moral_action: Jason waits until his shift is over and picks up some Advil from the pharmacy.
immoral_action: Jason swipes the last one of his uncle's prescription pain killers and replaces it with a vitamin.

norm: It's wrong to spread your illness to another person.
situation: Tim has been terribly sick at home with the flu for the past few days.
intention: Tim wants to get some soup to feel better.
moral_action: Tim orders a soup with contact-less delivery.
immoral_action: Tim goes out to the store to buy some cans of soup.

norm: It's wrong to abuse medication.
situation: Jane has been burdened with a huge workload, and she has been struggling to keep up with the work.
intention: Jane needs to find a way to get more energy throughout the day.
moral_action: Jane consults a doctor about how to get more energy.
immoral_action: Jane starts taking her sons Adderall to give her an energy boost.

norm: It is wrong to be anti-semetic.
situation: Ray lives in a multicultural town, needs to do repairs to his home, and wants to hire a professional.
intention: Ray wants to choose a contractor from those available.
moral_action: Ray hires the best contractor in town who happens to be Jewish.
immoral_action: Ray learns the best contractor in town is Jewish and chooses a lesser skilled contractor.

norm: It's wrong to fake an illness.
situation: Jerry has to work tonight.
intention: Jerry wants to go a concert tonight.
moral_action: Jerry asks his boss if he can take some extra time off to go to the concert and his boss agrees.
immoral_action: Jerry pretends to be sick, so he can get out of work and go to the concert.

norm: It's wrong to use your illness to your advantage.
situation: Kati has cancer, it's a slow moving cancer but a scary one all the same, and she's in an argument with her friend.
intention: Kati wants to win the argument.
moral_action: Kati uses some logic to outwit her friend in this argument.
immoral_action: Kati asks her friend how she can be happy fighting with a person who has cancer.

norm: It is wrong to tamper with someone's prescribed medications
situation: Phil wants to start a family with his wife May, but she is hesitant.
intention: Phil wants to have a baby.
moral_action: Phil makes a persuasive argument for the couple starting a family.
immoral_action: Phil switches out May's birth control medication.

norm: It's wrong to take your child's medication.
situation: Kaito is having problems concentrating on work when he notices his son's adderall sitting on the table.
intention: Kaito wants to finish his work.
moral_action: Kaito drinks two cups of his favorite coffee before he continues working.
immoral_action: Kaito takes a pill of his son's adderall without asking his son.

norm: It's wrong to give disease.
situation: Paul just found out from his doctor that he has a highly infectious disease.
intention: Paul wants to pick up his medicine from the store.
moral_action: Paul stays home and pays someone to deliver his medicine to the door.
immoral_action: Paul goes to the store to pick up his medicine even though he knows he could spread the disease.

norm: It's unacceptable to use someone else's medication.
situation: Eddie's roommate, Gene, recently got into a car accident, and he is throwing a party to celebrate his release from the hospital.
intention: Eddie wants to take drugs at the party.
moral_action: Eddie asks his friends to bring party drugs.
immoral_action: Knowing that Gene is on pain meds, Eddie digs through the medicine cabinet to find them and shares them with the party.

norm: It's not good to use someone else's prescriptions.
situation: Heather can't sleep because she is worrying about a big exam she has to take in the morning.
intention: Heather wants to get some sleep.
moral_action: Heather makes herself a cup of hot tea and then reads a book until she falls asleep.
immoral_action: Heather takes one of her mom's prescription sleeping pills to help her sleep.

norm: It is bad to bully people online
situation: Anna is reading about the election on an internet forum.
intention: Anna wants to discuss her views.
moral_action: Anna has an informative discussion about who she thinks will win the election with another forum user.
immoral_action: Anna berates a person who doesn't agree with her views and calls them racist names.

norm: It is wrong to bully online.
situation: Stephen's iMac was damaged by his friend who dropped it by accident.
intention: Stephen wants his friend to answer for the damage.
moral_action: Stephen asks his friend to cover the costs of the necessary repairs.
immoral_action: Stephen insults and threatens his friend in a chat group for his damage.

norm: It is bad to stalk or creep on people online
situation: Mark has a crush on his classmate, and he finds her on Facebook.
intention: Mark wants to see what she is up to.
moral_action: Mark sends her a message and asks if she wants to catch up.
immoral_action: Mark follows her every move online and obsesses over every post.

norm: It's bad to treat people rudely online.
situation: Marry is  annoyed with a new user Sarah for asking a common question in the subreddit.
intention: Marry wants to respond to Sarah.
moral_action: Marry directs Sarah to the subreddit's resource post with answers to frequently asked questions.
immoral_action: Marry tells Sarah that she should pay attention because her question has been asked several times on the subreddit.

norm: It's bad to behave poorly on the internet.
situation: James feels very frustrated after a long day dealing with rude customers at work.
intention: James wants to vent his frustration.
moral_action: James boots up a single-person military video game and blows up imaginary enemies.
immoral_action: James logs onto an internet forum and deploys a wide array of profanity against people with different political beliefs.

norm: It's rude to ghost someone online.
situation: Allister was having an online relationship with Betty, but has become bored with it.
intention: Allister wants to break it off with Betty.
moral_action: Allister tells Betty he wants to move on and wishes her well.

norm: It's bad to air your dirty laundry on social media.
situation: Nicole is unhappy with her partner and feels quite frustrated by lack of attention.
intention: Nicole wants to vent about how her partner is acting.
moral_action: Nicole talks to a close friend in private about what is going on.
immoral_action: Nicole posts negative and lengthy status updates on Facebook about her partner.

norm: It's rude to troll others on social media.
situation: Jack is bored and goes on Twitter to amuse himself.
intention: Jack wants to make a post on Twitter.
moral_action: Jack posts on Twitter asking for fun ideas to pass time.
