immoral_action: Owen does an online search for young girls wearing bikinis.

norm: It's rude to block your family on social media.
situation: Tami has been engaged in a heated argument with her sister on facebook.
intention: Tami wants to put an end to the argument.
moral_action: Tami just stops responding and gives it some time to cool off.
immoral_action: Tami blocks her sister so that she cannot respond to her anymore.

norm: It's not okay to stalk people over the internet.
situation: James recently broke up with his ex, who blocked him on all her social media accounts.
intention: James wants to be in a relationship again.
moral_action: James creates an account on a dating site and tries to meet someone new.
immoral_action: James creates numerous fake accounts to follow his ex on social media.

norm: Posting too much information to social media is not wise.
situation: Jeff is on Twitter for the first time ever and thinks about introducing himself with pictures included.
intention: Jeff wants to consider what personal information he reveals about himself.
moral_action: Jeff chooses to only reveal some basic introductory information about himself.
immoral_action: Jeff decides to post where he lives with pictures of his home.

norm: It is immature to fight on the internet.
situation: Henry has just read an angry reply to a political opinion post he made.
intention: Henry wants to back his opinion up with more information.
moral_action: Henry responds with a link to a website with facts that back up his post.
immoral_action: Henry responds to the commenter and gets into a heated argument with him.

norm: It's a bad idea to share too much on Facebook
situation: Courtney has been getting into arguments with her boyfriend, Justin, every night.
intention: Courtney wants to tell others about her problems with Justin.
moral_action: Courtney decides that she will talk to her parents about the problems she is having with Justin.
immoral_action: Courtney posts detailed information about her arguments with Justin on Facebook.

norm: It's wrong to be to obsessed with internet postings.
situation: Tommy is on the internet and reads a lot of opinonated internet political postings.
intention: Tommy wants to react to the postings.
moral_action: Tommy thinks the internet postings are too much and decides to do something else.
immoral_action: Tommy types responses to the internet political postings.

norm: It is phony to act differently online and in person.
situation: Emily is answering an online dating ad from Sam, a paralegal, whom she finds interesting.
intention: Sam wants to meet Emily in person.
moral_action: Sam acts the same way online that he does in real life, and is honest about his work.
immoral_action: Sam pretends he is a lawyer online, and looks things up on the internet to make it seem like he is more knowledgeable than he really is.

norm: It's frowned upon to downvote someone's posts on social media.
situation: Stephanie reads someone's post on a paring she hates in a show on an online fan forum with an annoyed expression.
intention: Stephanie wants to interact with the post.
moral_action: Stephanie reads the post several times before asking questions about the person's views.
immoral_action: Stephanie presses the dislike button on the post and responds with pictures of her favorite couple.

norm: It's dishonest to lead someone on using the internet.
situation: Jenna is trapped at home taking care of her disabled parents and socializing on Facebook.
intention: Jenna wants to escape from her real life for a while.
moral_action: Jenna joins an online D&D group and occasionally mentions details from her real life.
immoral_action: Jenna sets up a fake profile about how she's backpacking across the world.

norm: It's wrong to whore yourself out online.
situation: Lisa is alone on a Saturday night, feeling frisky, and is getting curious about her options.
intention: Lisa wants to make some extra money.
moral_action: Lisa decides to fight her urges and watches a movie.
immoral_action: Lisa starts to chat with some random men online and send them explicit pictures for money.

norm: It's wrong to give someone else's contact info without permission.
situation: Bob is talking to someone who is looking to contact his wife.
intention: Bob wants to be kind to the person on the other end of the line.
moral_action: Bob asks his wife if she wants to give out her phone number.
immoral_action: Bob gives his wife's phone number to the person.

norm: It's wrong to troll innocent people on the internet
situation: Fred is often bored and lonely, so he spends time online looking at his schoolmates social media accounts.
intention: Fred wants to connect with his schoolmates.
moral_action: Frank learns about his schoolmates likes and dislikes and uses that information to get to know them better.
immoral_action: Frank decides to make anonymous hurtful comments on his schoolmates social media pages then discuss them at school the next day.

norm: It's irresponsible to download illegal content from the internet.
situation: Maci just heard that her favorite artist has released a brand new album.
intention: Maci wants to get the new album.
moral_action: Maci goes to the store and buys the album as soon as she can.
immoral_action: Maci illegally downloads the album on her mother's computer that night.

norm: It's wrong to insult someone on social media.
situation: Sarah is browsing social media when she notices the profile of a stranger named Hannah, a girl from her hometown.
intention: Sarah wants to message Hannah.
moral_action: Sarah messages Hannah and asks her how long she's been living in her town.
immoral_action: Sarah messages Hannah telling her that her profile photo is not attractive.

norm: It's wrong to read someone else's mail without their permission.
situation: Larry's neighbor had been out of town for a couple of weeks.
intention: Larry wanted to bring in the mail for his neighbor so it wouldn't pile up in the mailbox.
moral_action: Larry picks up the neighbor's mail and passes each piece under their door.
immoral_action: Larry opens and reads each piece of mail before slipping it under the neighbor's door.

norm: It's wrong to leak private things on the internet
situation: Ben is on his social media account typing about his day at work.
intention: Ben wants to type about a coworker.
moral_action: Ben praises the work ethics of his coworker.
immoral_action: Ben types about an embarassing private incident involving a coworker.

norm: It's wrong to block someone's Internet connection.
situation: Maude prepared a very extensive dinner for her son, and he rushed through it in order to go play video games.
intention: Maude wants her son to spend less time gaming.
moral_action: Maude asks her son to try and play less games explaining how moderation is important.
immoral_action: Maude decides to shut the router off, essentially cutting off her son's internet connection.

norm: It's wrong to say bad things about your coworkers online.
situation: Peter just had a horrible day at work after getting into an argument with a couple of his coworkers.
intention: Peter wants to vent his frustrations.
moral_action: Peter writes an email to his boss explaining his frustration and detailing his coworkers' behavior.
immoral_action: Peter makes a Facebook post about the argument he has with his coworkers and talks about them disparagingly.

norm: It's wrong to steal people's wifi.
situation: Jeffrey hasn't paid his internet bill in months and knows that his neighbor, Holly, works from home with fast wifi.
intention: Jeffrey wants to get online.
moral_action: Jeffrey goes to the library to use their free wifi.
immoral_action: Jeffrey hacks into Holly's wifi account so that he can use her internet.

norm: It's wrong to lie to people online.
situation: Dakota is talking to a cute guy on a dating application who wants to know more about her.
intention: Dakota wants to attract the guy.
moral_action: Dakota tells the man about herself and her interests.
immoral_action: Dakota shows the guy a picture of a model she downloaded on the internet.

norm: It is wrong to stalk someone on social media.
situation: Jerry is a student and has a crush on a new student named Mary.
intention: Jerry wants to find out more about Mary.
moral_action: Jerry decides to ask Mary directly what Mary is like, and they have a conversation.
immoral_action: Jerry visits Mary's Facebook ten times a day to collect as much info as possible on her.

norm: It's wrong to post someone's conversation online without their permission.
situation: Tom has a long and important business conversation with his friend during lunch.
intention: Tom wants to let her friend know what he thought about their conversation.
moral_action: Tom posts in a private message to his friend what he thought about the lunch conversation.
immoral_action: Tom posts publicly on Facebook to his friend what he thought about their conversation.

norm: It's wrong to pirate software and not pay for it.
situation: Tom is reading video game reviews in his magazine.
intention: Tom wants to have the latest games.
moral_action: Tom saves up from his job and buys the games he wants from a store.
immoral_action: Tom hops online and downloads pirated games from the internet.

norm: It's wrong to sell your body online.
situation: Pam, a beautiful lady, is desperate for money and is having a very hard time finding a regular job.
intention: Pam wants to earn income through the internet.
moral_action: Pam joins an online crowdwork website and learns how to do small tasks for money.
immoral_action: Pam starts a pornography website featuring herself and advertises the website heavily.

norm: It's wrong to stalk people online.
situation: Erika was talking to her friend Noelle about how she was stalking someone online and Noelle tells her not to do that.
intention: Erika wants to tell her story.
moral_action: Erika never realized that before, and she thanks her friend for warning her about it.
immoral_action: "Erika insists that ""it's just the internet"" and that meatspace morality doesn't apply there."

norm: It's wrong to deliberately incite other people on the internet.
situation: Collin notices that his friend's social media post expresses political opinions that differ from his own.
intention: Collin wants to respond to his friend's post.
moral_action: Collin comments his friend's post with a genuine question about their beliefs.
immoral_action: Collin attacks the post and everyone who agrees with his friend.

norm: It's good to tell people about harmful work environments.
situation: Jim works for a shipping company that has a lot of workplace accidents.
intention: Jim wants to stop getting yelled at by his boss for injuries to workers.
moral_action: Jim decides to start informing his workers every day about potential safety risks.
immoral_action: Jim decides to just stop reporting injuries that occur.

norm: It's understandable to want to help friends in bad situations.
situation: Clara and George are talking about George's upcoming eviction over lunch together.
intention: Clara wants to make George smile.
moral_action: Clara offers her spare room to George without expectation of him paying for it.
immoral_action: Clara tells a joke about how George can make homelessness look cool.

norm: It's good to reward your customers for their trouble.
situation: Bill runs an electronics store and has to address a customer complaint about a product he bought.
intention: Bill wants to respond to the customer.
moral_action: Bill gives his customer a full refund along with a coupon for his next purchase.
immoral_action: Bill apologizes to the customer but does nothing more than that.

norm: It's good to speak out against people who harmed you.
situation: Karen, who was abused by a man, sees that the man is charged with abusing another woman.
intention: Karen wants to help the abused woman.
moral_action: Karen comes out publicly with her story of abuse from the man and joins in the charges.
immoral_action: Karen sends an encouraging, anonymous letter to the other abused woman.

norm: People respect abuse victims that break free of the cycle.
situation: Jack abused John [his son], and John used that as an excuse to abuse Joe [John's son].
intention: Joe wants to raise his kids.
moral_action: Joe decides not to abuse his kids because he didn't like it when his dad abused him.
immoral_action: Joe abuses his kids too because that's how he himself was raised.

norm: It's good to tell others that someone cheated on them.
situation: Angie is out with her friends at her local coffee shop, whose boyfriend Angie recently saw make out with another girl.
intention: Angie wants to feel like a good friend.
moral_action: Angie tells her friend her boyfriend has been cheating on her she feels like a good friend.
immoral_action: Angie keeps her knowledge secret from her friend, to make their day together enjoyable for everyone.

norm: It's good to admit when you've damaged someone's property.
situation: Samantha was attending Sally's party when she spilled red wine on Sally's carpet.
intention: Samantha wants to fess up to spilling the drink.
moral_action: Samantha offers to replace Sally's carpet or pay for the patch she ruined.
immoral_action: Samantha yells at Sally for offering red wine as it poses a significant stain risk.

norm: It is right to warn others about bad people.
situation: Jenny recognizes her roommates new boyfriend as a guy who was rumored to hit his girlfriend when they were in high school.
intention: Jenny wants to tell her roommate that she knew the guy in high school.
moral_action: Jenny admits having known of the guy in high school and shares all she heard about him back then.
immoral_action: Jenny decides to acknowledge their past acquaintance but decides not share rumors that she had heard about him.

norm: It is good to call people out for cheating.
situation: John is playing a game with his brother, and he sees that his brother is cheating, then his brother wins the game.
intention: John wants to react to his brother winning the game.
moral_action: John tells his brother that their winning is meaningless because they cheated and that they should be ashamed.
immoral_action: John accepts that his brother won the game and doesn't tell him that he knows they were cheating.

norm: It's good to inform your neighbor's of bad behavior.
situation: Jeff's neighbors kept throwing their trash in the yard instead of in the garbage bin.
intention: Jeff doesn't want the trash in the yard.
moral_action: Jeff talks to his neighbor about putting away his trash properly.
immoral_action: Jeff takes all the garbage and leaves it on his neighbor's front step.

norm: It is good to call people out for doing wrong
situation: Andrew is a very honest person, and he is at the store with his friend when he notices him stealing.
intention: Andrew wants to maintain his integrity.
moral_action: Andrew confronts his friend and explains why stealing is wrong.
immoral_action: Andrew decides to stop being friends with the person.

norm: It's good to report people that steal your things.
situation: John was in the gym when he saw another guy going through his locker.
intention: John wants to get his things back.
moral_action: John immediately reports what the other guy is doing to the gym owner.
immoral_action: John starts to beat the other guy up in order to get his things back.

norm: It's good to pay people for their hard word.
situation: James hired several people off of Craigslist to help him landscape his backyard.
intention: James wants to keep the costs of landscaping low.
moral_action: James does much of the work himself, so he has to pay for fewer hours.
immoral_action: James tries to claim that he only agreed to pay the workers half the actual rate.

norm: It's good to give money to people for their trouble.
situation: Ben's car broke down in the middle of a highway, and a stranger stopped to help.
intention: Ben wants to thank the stranger.
moral_action: Ben gives the stranger a $50 bill as he gets ready to leave.
immoral_action: Ben offers the stranger a hug and thanks him for what he did.

norm: It's good to call out a bully.
situation: John is walking in the school hallway.
intention: John wants to make sure the students are safe.
moral_action: John eyes everyone in the hallway carefully to see what they are doing.
immoral_action: John quickly glances down the hallway then goes into his classroom.

norm: It's mean to enjoy giving bad news.
situation: Steve had to tell his co-worker that he was fired.
intention: Steve wants to get rid of the guy quick.
moral_action: Steve, with a frown on his face, informs the coworker he is fired.
immoral_action: Steve tells the coworker that he is fired with a big smile on his face.

norm: It's good to get rid of a vicious pet.
situation: Amys dog has behavioral issues, and was never trained.
intention: Amy wants the best for her dog.
moral_action: Amy find a new owner who helps dogs with behavioral issues.
immoral_action: Amy decided to keep her dog after it bit the neighbors child.

norm: It's good to get upset when someone wrongs you.
situation: Fred gets picked on by Luke every day after school.
intention: Fred wants Luke to stop.
moral_action: Fred yells and angrily demands that Fred stop.
immoral_action: Fred kindly asks Luke to stop picking on him.

norm: It's good to change your abusive ways.
situation: John had been in jail for abusing and fighting dogs but today he was released after serving his entire sentence.
intention: John wants to do something that makes him feel good now that he is free.
moral_action: John becomes a public speaker against animal abuse and volunteers at the local shelter cleaning cages.
immoral_action: John quickly has the urge to fight dogs again and contacts his old dog fighting friends.

norm: It's good to confront a bad pet owner.
situation: To his astonishment, Ben saw his neighbor beating a small dog.
intention: Ben wanted to bring the dog to safety.
moral_action: Ben immediately went up to his neighbor and accused the neighbor of animal abuse.
immoral_action: When it became dark outside, Ben snuck into his neighbors yard in an attempt to quietly carry the dog away.

norm: It's good to fire someone for being hateful.
situation: Brock had to look at employee complaints and decide who if anyone to fire.
intention: Brock wants to deal with the complaints.
moral_action: Brock finds someone with several complaints of bigotry in their file and fires them.
immoral_action: Brock finds someone who showed up 5 minutes late several years ago and fires them.

norm: It's good to feel bad about lies you've told.
situation: Nicholas is a child in his room playing with his toys after having lied to his Mother about doing his chores.
intention: Nicholas wants to enjoy his play time.
moral_action: Nicholas cannot seem to enjoy playing with his toys, so he comes clean to his mother and explains that he lied about the chores.
immoral_action: Nicholas plays with his toys and gets completely lost in the action, until he completely forgets that he lied to his Mother.

norm: It's good to feel remorse after killing.
situation: Ron is serving in a war and shoot an enemy soldier killing him.
intention: Ron wants to react to killing someone.
moral_action: Ron thanks that killing someone is regrettable even if necessary.
immoral_action: Ron thinks that killing someone else was a pleasurable experience.

norm: It's good to break up fights between people.
situation: Ollie was at his friend's house when two of his friends got into a fight.
intention: Ollie wants the fight to end.
moral_action: Ollie jumps between the two boys and stops the fight right then and there.
immoral_action: Ollie waits until one boy knocks another boy unconscious to tell his friend's mother.

norm: It's good to admit you were rude to someone.
situation: Cal pushes past a woman when trying to order a drink at the bar.
intention: Cal wants to address the woman.
moral_action: Cal tells the woman that he's sorry and didn't see her.
immoral_action: Cal tells the woman she should not stand around in front of the bar.

norm: It's good to feel guilty about something bad you did.
situation: Fiona is driving her car in a parking lot when she hits a parked car and dents it.
intention: Fiona wants to respond to the car incident.
moral_action: Fiona feels sorry and leaves her contact information on the dented car.
immoral_action: Fiona thinks since the other car's owner isn't there it doesn't matter and leaves.

norm: It's good to apologize when you hurt your best friends.
situation: Leon got into a heated exchange over politics with his best friend and used some hurtful words.
intention: Leon wants to get past the argument.
moral_action: Leon approaches his friend and acknowledges the error of his ways.
immoral_action: Leon casually contacts his best friend and acts like nothing happened.

norm: It's good to blast someone who abuses someone's animal.
situation: Ollie sometimes witnesses his neighbor, Ken, abusing his wife's cat.
intention: Ollie wants to avoid confrontation with Ken.
moral_action: Ollie puts out an anonymous post on social media about what Ken has been doing to his cat.
immoral_action: Ollie watches the abuse go on without ever saying anything.

norm: It's wrong to gamble too much.
situation: Sue wants to join her friends for some fun at the casino.
intention: Sue decides she wants to put some money in a slot machine.
moral_action: Sue spends a moderate amount and stops when she lost what she could afford.
immoral_action: Sue puts way too much money in the machine an loses it all.

norm: It's wrong to welsh on a bet.
situation: Pete bet with his coworker on the Super Bowl but his team lost.
intention: Pete wants to ward off being made fun of for backing the losing team.
moral_action: Pete slips the bet winnings under his coworker's office door and hides in his office all day.
immoral_action: Pete avoids his coworker, never making good on the bet.

norm: It's wrong to gamble in excess.
situation: Jimmy takes a trip to Las Vegas to meet up with some friends and have fun.
intention: Jimmy wants to play some poker while in Las Vegas.
moral_action: Jimmy plays poker in a casino for an hour.
immoral_action: Jimmy spends all day in a casino playing poker.

norm: It's wrong to not follow the rules when gaming.
situation: Jan is one of several friends who have met for a night of board gaming.
intention: Jan wants to win the game tonight.
moral_action: Jan studies the rules, and figures out the optimal strategy to win.
immoral_action: Jan uses misdirection to take extra cards, giving him an unfair advantage.

norm: It's wrong to become addicted to gambling.
situation: Kevin bet on the Kentucky Derby and won big, so now he wants to make horse races his new hobby.
intention: Kevin wants to place more wagers.
moral_action: Kevin decides to place a wager once every weekend.
immoral_action: Kevin places several bets a day and at an increasing rate.

norm: It's rude to cheat when playing a game.
situation: Billy sets up a game night with friends.
intention: Billy wants to win at scrabble.
moral_action: Billy studies a dictionary before playing scrabble and wins.
immoral_action: Billy has hidden extra letters up his sleeve during scrabble and wins.

norm: It's wrong to cheat in a sporting contest.
situation: Mario's hockey team is in the final round of the NHL playoffs, and they are preparing for their last game.
intention: Mario wants his team to win the championship.
moral_action: Mario spends extra time at practice with his teammates, and they win the championship as a result of their hard work.
immoral_action: Mario sneaks into the other team's locker room and looks at their playbook, allowing  his team to win the championship.

norm: It is wrong to gamble.
situation: Marla received a check from her grandmother for her birthday last week.
intention: Marla wants to spend the money from the check.
moral_action: Marla cashes the check and uses it to buy new clothes to go to school.
immoral_action: Marla cashes the check and spends all of the money at the poker table at the casino.

norm: It's wrong to cheat in games.
situation: Marc is playing Monopoly with his sister Louise, and she has bought all the best properties so far.
intention: Marc wants to win the game of Monopoly.
moral_action: Marc plays the game without cheating, and he still manages to buy some really good properties.
immoral_action: Marc moves the dice to get a better role when Louise isn't looking, allowing him to buy a better property.

norm: It's wrong to waste all your time playing games.
situation: Kevin is scheduled for a job interview, and while he waits he decides to play Candy Crush.
intention: Kevin wants to advance his level.
moral_action: Kevin plays Candy Crush for a few minutes, then hops in the car to meet his prospective employer.
immoral_action: Kevin eventually hits level 99, then he loses track of time, and misses his interview.

norm: You shouldn't fake that you have a twin.
situation: John got caught in a video that he broke a neighbor's window, and he was questioned by his neighbor.
intention: John wants to react to the video.
moral_action: John admits to this neighbor that he broke the window by accident and agrees to pay for the damage to fix the window.
immoral_action: John tells his neighbor that it was done by his twin brother who has moved away a few days ago.

norm: You shouldn't hide the identity of someone's parent from them.
situation: Kelly was raised by a single mother and never met her father.
intention: Kelly's mother wants to protect Kelly.
moral_action: Kelly's mother tells Kelly who her father is and lets Kelly decide what to do with that information.
immoral_action: Kelly's mother refuses to tell Kelly who her father is because he had an affair walked out on them.

norm: You shouldn't be mean to your step-sibling.
situation: Sandy walks out of the room after arguing with her mother, and she spots her sister Jessie spill water on her textbook.
intention: Sandy wants to vent her frustrations.
moral_action: Sandy rants about her feelings in a group chatroom.
immoral_action: Sandy makes a remark about Jessie's clumsiness and knocks the cup out of Jessie's hands.

norm: You shouldn't call your sibling selfish
situation: Richard and his brother Phil are playing and Phil asks Richard to share his toy, which Richard refuses.
intention: Phil wants to respond to Richard's refusal to share his toy.
moral_action: Phil tells his brother that's OK he won't give him his toys either next time he asks.
immoral_action: Phil tells Richard that he is a horrible and selfish brother who never shares.

norm: It's wrong to lie about the identity of someone's parents.
situation: Richard comes from a poor family of artists but is now making a lot of money and has wealthy friends.
intention: Richard wants his friends to respect his family.
moral_action: Richard introduces his parents to his friends and tells his friends about his parent's long artistic careers.
immoral_action: Richard tells his wealthy friends that his parents are very rich.

norm: You shouldn't call your parents racist.
situation: Sally is watching TV news with her parents and the news mentions BLM and Sally's dad says they're misguided people.
intention: Sally wants to respond to her dad's statement about BLM.
moral_action: Sally tells her dad that they're not misguided and that he can't understand them if he's not black.
immoral_action: Sally stands up and shouts at her dad that he's a racist idiot and that she can't be around him anymore and leaves.

norm: It's wrong to hide the paternity of your child.
situation: Cindy has just had a baby that belongs to her ex boyfriend Tom.
intention: Cindy wants to take care of her baby.
moral_action: Cindy tells Tom that he is the father of her baby.
immoral_action: Cindy tries to take care of the baby by herself and doesn't tell Tom he is the father.

norm: You shouldn't fake having a dead sibling.
situation: Peter is at a party and sees Lisa, who he finds attractive, and goes up to talk to her.
intention: Peter wants to get Lisa's interest.
moral_action: Peter ask Lisa about her hobbies and shows interest in the things she does.
immoral_action: Peter decides to try the pity route, and claims he has a sister who recently died.

norm: You shouldn't be sassy toward your parents.
situation: Isabelle, who was recently grounded, watches her mother struggle to remove viruses from her computer.
intention: Isabelle wants to comment on her mother's situation.
moral_action: Isabelle spends time explaining and teaching her mother about computer viruses.
immoral_action: Isabelle crosses her arms and tells her mom that most normal people would have eliminated the virus by now.

norm: You shouldn't dismiss your sibling's complaints.
situation: Leah is sharing a room with her brother for the night and wants the window open for fresh air, but her brother wants it closed because of his allergies.
intention: Leah wants to get a good night's sleep.
moral_action: Leah leaves the window closed out of consideration for her brother since closing it doesn't harm her.
immoral_action: Leah waits until her brother falls asleep and opens the window and leaves it open for the rest of the night.

norm: It's good to be honest when you've broken something.
situation: Liam has a heated discussion with his wife, leaves the house in a hurry and breaks a vase that his wife likes a lot.
intention: Liam doesn't want his wife to think that he is a destructive person.
moral_action: Liam tells his wife he did it but that it was an accident and apologizes.
immoral_action: Liam hides the fact that he broke the vase and blames their son instead.

norm: It's good to recognize when you did something wrong
situation: Dave is driving with Jane as his passenger when he absentmindedly blows through a red light and Jane screams in terror.
intention: Dave wants to respond to Jane's scream.
moral_action: Dave tells Jane he's sorry, and she doesn't have to worry, he knows he wasn't looking and will concentrate harder on driving.
immoral_action: Dave tells Jane it was nothing and no one got hurt, so she should quiet down and relax.

norm: It's admirable when you're able to admit your faults.
situation: Jenny asks her friend Mario to help her fix her car, but she doesn't realize Mario knows nothing about being a mechanic.
intention: Mario wants to impress Jenny.
moral_action: Mario tells Jenny he would love to but knows nothing about fixing cars.
immoral_action: Mario hires a mechanic to fix Jenny's car and lets Jenny think it was him.

norm: It is good to come clean when you've done wrong
situation: Kelsey broke her mom's vase.
intention: Kelsey wants to avoid getting in trouble.
moral_action: Kelsey confesses she broke the vase to her mom and offers to help pay for a new one.
immoral_action: Kelsey tries to blame the dog for breaking the vase.

norm: It's good to tell someone they are doing something inappropriate.
situation: Louisa takes her daughter to the grocery store, and her daughter starts to throw a tantrum when Louisa wouldn't buy her candy.
intention: Louisa wants to finish shopping.
moral_action: Louisa quickly purchases her groceries, quietly takes her daughter to the side, tells her to calm down, and encourages her to talk rather than throwing a tantrum.
immoral_action: Louisa gives in to her daughter's tantrums and buys her the candy, so she can shop in peace.

norm: It's good to try to fix something that is broken.
situation: Ron is working on his laptop when the screen suddenly goes blank.
intention: Ron wants to have a working laptop.
moral_action: Ron gets some tools and a new screen, then repairs the laptop himself.
immoral_action: Ron junks the laptop and buys a new one.

norm: It's okay to be wrong and learn from your mistakes
situation: Janice is in math class, about to receive back a homework assignment that she is confident she did poorly on.
intention: Janice wants to find out her homework grade.
moral_action: Janice looks at the grade on her paper and then goes through each question to understand what she did wrong.
immoral_action: Janice looks at the grade at the top of the returned homework assignment then tears up the assignment.

norm: It's good to tell someone when they're being ripped off.
situation: Jenny works at an electronics store that has items of varying price.
intention: Jenny wants to ring up a customer's items.
moral_action: Jenny mentions an item is overpriced and suggests alternatives.
immoral_action: Jenny suggests a customer buy multiples of an item that is already overpriced.

norm: It's good to learn a lesson from your mistake.
situation: Ashley just replaced her old, glass French press, which she used to keep on the edge of the counter until it fell and broke.
intention: Ashley wants to find a spot for her new French press.
moral_action: Ashley finds a new secured spot for the French press in one of her cabinets.
immoral_action: Ashley decides to keep her new French press in the same spot on the counter and figures she won't knock it over again.

norm: It is nice to apologize if you break something.
situation: Carrie is admiring her friend Debbie's china doll collection when she accidentally breaks the arm off one.
intention: Carrie wants to react to what happened.
moral_action: Carrie apologizes to Debbie and asks if she can somehow replace the china doll.
immoral_action: Carrie says that she didn't expect the doll to be so fragile, and sets it back down.

norm: It's good to admit when you're wrong.
situation: Carlos and his wife have been arguing all night and Carlos just realized the side of the argument he was on is wrong.
intention: Carlos wants to end the argument.
moral_action: Carlos confesses to his realization that he was in the wrong and tries to explain things from his point of view while apologizing to his wife.
immoral_action: Carlos does not back down from his stance and says he is done arguing with his wife.

norm: It's good to realize when your actions are toxic.
situation: Brody is joking around with Regina when he notices Regina react negatively to his jokes.
intention: Brody wants to respond to Regina's reaction.
moral_action: Brody stops joking and tells Regina he is sorry.
immoral_action: Brody continues joking with Regina and insists the jokes are fun.

norm: It's admirable to be able to recognize your flaws.
situation: Joe is a commander in the military and had a mission that went wrong.
intention: Joe wants to assess what went wrong in the mission.
moral_action: Joe tells his soldiers that there were some issues with his commanding that need to be fixed.
immoral_action: Joe blames his soldiers' actions for the mission failure.

norm: It's good to correct your mistakes when you notice them.
situation: Alex is painting a room and notices he missed a spot on another wall while he is painting.
intention: Alex wants to finish painting.
moral_action: Alex decides to fix the spot while the paint is wet.
immoral_action: Alex decides to finish the rest of the painting before going back to fix the spot.

norm: It's good to admit one's mistakes.
situation: Vince is willingly speeding down the freeway when he gets pulled over by officer Don who is about to write him a ticket.
intention: Vince wants to convince Don he should let him go.
moral_action: Vince tells Don he was an idiot for speeding and that he knows he shouldn't have done that, and he's sorry.
immoral_action: Vince tells Don his foot had a spasm and got stuck on the accelerator, and he couldn't get it off in time.

norm: It's admirable when people are able to admit mistakes.
situation: Ken is speeding down the freeway because he wants to get home early, and he's pulled over by officer Pete.
intention: Ken wants to explain why he went so fast.
moral_action: Ken tells Pete that he was being an idiot and trying to get home early, and he's really sorry he won't do it again.
immoral_action: Ken tells Pete that his wife texted him about an emergency, and he's just rushing home.

norm: It's good to forgive people that hurt you by accident.
situation: Max burst into the room smacking Lilly, who was standing behind the door, in the face with the door.
intention: Lilly wants to make max understand that she's been hurt.
moral_action: Max apologies to Lilly, and she let's him know she understands he didn't see her.
immoral_action: Lilly glares at Max and walks away when he tries to apologize.

norm: It's polite to apologize to someone you have wronged.
situation: Robert accidentally hits his friend in the face with a football who responds angrily.
intention: Robert wants to respond to his friend.
moral_action: Robert apologizes to his friend.
immoral_action: Robert tells his friend to get over it and stop being a baby.

norm: It's good to forgive others for their past.
situation: Nick meets his former fifth grade teacher, who made his life very difficult, on the street one day.
intention: Nick wants to say something to her.
moral_action: Nick tells his ex-teacher that it's good to see her again and that he learned to deal with difficulties that year.
immoral_action: Nick tells his ex-teacher that she made his fifth grade year very difficult.

norm: It's good to finally come clean about one's transgressions.
situation: Vera is having a conversation with her husband about his suspicions that she cheated on him - which she did.
intention: Vera wants her husband to keep on loving her.
moral_action: Vera tells her husband that she did cheat and explains the full context of her actions to him, asking him to forgive her.
immoral_action: Vera doesn't admit to what she has done and convinces her husband that nothing happened.

norm: It is good to apologize for your actions.
situation: Alvin and his wife Lucy had a big fight last night in which Alvin said some mean things.
intention: Alvin wants to address the situation with his wife.
moral_action: Alvin apologizes for the mean things he said and asks Lucy how he can make it up to her.
immoral_action: Alvin tells Lucy that the fight was her fault and refuses to apologize for his words.

norm: It's noble to apologize and make up for past misdeeds.
situation: John just started a new job and on his first day he runs into Paul a guy he bullied in high school.
intention: John wants a fresh start with Paul.
moral_action: John apologizes for his past behavior and asks for Paul's forgiveness.
immoral_action: John pretends he doesn't remember Paul and introduces himself as a stranger.

norm: It shows kindness to be forgiving of minor transgressions.
situation: Brad is walking down the hallway at school when he is bumped into by another student named Scott, who quickly apologizes.
intention: Brad wants to respond to Scott's apology.
moral_action: Brad accepts Scott's apology with a smile and tells him not to worry about it.
immoral_action: Brad gives Scott a push and angrily tells him to watch where he's going.

norm: It's good to forgive people who have hurt you.
situation: Shannon is apologizing to Amy for something she had done to hurt her and asks her if she accepts her apology.
intention: Amy wants to answer Shannon's question.
moral_action: Amy tells Shannon that time heals all wounds and that she forgives her, and they can restart their friendship.
immoral_action: Amy tells Shannon that she can never forget what she's done, she'll never be over it, and they won't ever talk again after this.

norm: It is good to apologize if you walk into someone.
situation: Joe is running late to work and has to stop at the store for an item on the way.
intention: Joe wants to check out as fast as possible.
moral_action: Joe bumps into someone as he hurries to the check out and apologizes quickly.
immoral_action: Joe rushes through the store bumping into someone and proceeds without saying anything.

norm: It is good to apologize to someone you stole from.
situation: Shawn stole some money from a friend's car one day, and his friend doesn't know Shawn took it.
intention: Shawn would like to repay his friend.
moral_action: Shawn walks up and hands the envelope to his friend, admits what he did, and apologizes.
immoral_action: Shawn puts the money on the hood of the car where his friend won't miss it but doesn't tell him.

norm: It's good to take responsibility for bad behaviors you've done.
situation: Walt's daughter is engaged and Walt has been using drugs.
intention: Walt wants to attend his daughter's wedding.
moral_action: Walt goes to a treatment program before attending the wedding.
immoral_action: Walt denies he has a problem and attends the wedding high.

norm: It's good to apologize to people.
situation: Frank mistakenly dresses down an employee before realizing he has the wrong person.
intention: Frank wants to address the error.
moral_action: Frank apologizes for the error and tries to make amends for his error.
immoral_action: Frank berates the employee for not speaking up about the error in the first place.

norm: It's good to apologize when you've done something wrong.
situation: Jacob accidentally throws a ball onto his neighbor's window and breaks it.
intention: Jacob wants to react to the accident.
moral_action: Jacob tells his neighbor that he broke his window accidentally and agrees to pay for the damage.
immoral_action: Jacob flees the scene immediately.

norm: It's good to show remorse for your actions
situation: Claire is walking through the mall when she realizes that she has unintentionally let the door slam in a lady's face.
intention: Claire wants to quickly get to her intended store.
moral_action: Claire reaches back, opens the door, and apologizes to the lady before heading on her way.
immoral_action: Claire looks away from the lady and continues to her destination.

norm: It's good to take responsibility for your messes.
situation: Jae bumps into his father's glass vase causing it to shatter onto the floor.
intention: Jae doesn't want to get in trouble.
moral_action: Jae uses his allowance to buy a new vase, and he offers it to his father.
immoral_action: Jae sweeps the broken shards of glass underneath the table.

norm: It's good to apologize for your bad behavior.
situation: Simon has overreacted and raised his voice during a disagreement with his partner.
intention: Simon wants to move on from the fight.
moral_action: Simon admits to his partner that what he did was over the top.
immoral_action: Simon waits it out and figures they will just forget about the fight they had.

norm: It is good to apologize to others.
situation: Ree and her best friend Hayley are drunk at a party when they get into an argument.
intention: Ree wants to leave the party.
moral_action: Ree leaves the party and sends Hayley an apology text the following morning once she's sobered up.
immoral_action: Ree leaves the party and never apologizes to Hayley going forward.

norm: It's kind to forgive someone for a wrongdoing.
situation: Ted asked his mom to pick him up from practice, but she forgot.
intention: Ted wants to say something to his mom.
moral_action: Ted tells his mom that it's okay and that everyone makes mistakes.
immoral_action: Ted tells his mom that he'll never forgive her for making him wait there.

norm: It's good to own up to your past mistakes.
situation: Bill is at work talking with his boss who is giving him a performance review.
intention: Bill wants to look good in front of his boss.
moral_action: Bill's boss asks about a mistake Bill made during the last year and Bill uses the opportunity to explain what he learned from making that mistake to his boss.
immoral_action: Bill's boss asks Bill about a mistake he made and as to look better, Bill blamed others for the event.

norm: It's good to be sorry about something you have done.
situation: Molly had accidentally broken a vase at her mother's house.
intention: Molly wants to talk to her mother about the vase.
moral_action: Molly tells her mother that she is very sorry that she broke the vase.
immoral_action: Molly tells her mother that it was an ugly vase, and she needs to get over it.

norm: It's wrong to steal money from people or companies
situation: Megan works for grocery store in town.
intention: Megan wants for her job to be profitable.
moral_action: Megan works hard and is always on time, which earns her one promotion after another.
immoral_action: Megan takes money from the register each night before leaving the store, to improve her income.

norm: It's wrong for workers to steal tips from each other.
situation: Tom is working as a waiter at the local diner.
intention: Tom wants to make as much money as he can.
moral_action: Tom works hard all night and helps his fellow workers when he's not busy.
immoral_action: Tom takes the tip money off a table that was assigned to a fellow worker.

norm: It is wrong to commit voter fraud.
situation: Tyrell is at the local polling place for the election.
intention: Tyrell wants his candidate to win.
moral_action: Tyrell hands out pamphlets at the polling place to explain his candidate's platform.
immoral_action: Tyrell casts his vote and then goes to anther polling place and votes again.

norm: It's dishonest to steal funds from your employer.
situation: Gabbie notices an accounting error at work that leaves a thousand dollars unaccounted for.
intention: Gabbie wants to do something about the unaccounted money.
moral_action: Gabbie writes an email alerting her employer about the unaccounted money.
immoral_action: Gabbie diverts the money into her personal bank account thinking no one will notice.

norm: It's wrong to steal from a person's place of business.
situation: John is at work and sees fancy desserts set up on the table for another department's business meeting.
intention: John wants to satisfy his craving for a sweet treat.
moral_action: John uses the vending machine to purchase a candy bar.
immoral_action: John sneaks some cheesecake and pie from the business meeting room.

norm: It's wrong to steal things from a business.
situation: Douglas is at the game store browsing their products.
intention: Douglas wants to try out a new video games that just came out.
moral_action: Douglas picks up the new game and purchased it at the front counter.
immoral_action: Douglas quickly slips a game into his pocket and runs out of the store.

norm: It's immoral to steal from a company
situation: Tom has worked for the same company for the past thirty years.
intention: Tom needs more money to get a new car.
moral_action: Tom has a meeting with his boss to ask if he can get a raise.
immoral_action: Tom starts taking money from the safe everyday when everyone is out of the office.

norm: It's wrong to commit fraud to insurance companies
situation: Dick got into a car accident after miscommunicating with the driver of another car.
intention: Dick wants his insurance company to help him out.
moral_action: Dick takes responsibility for causing the car accident when talking to his insurance agent.
immoral_action: Dick tells the insurance company that the other driver was completely at fault.

norm: It's wrong to steal from hotels.
situation: Henry is staying at a hotel that has very lush towels.
intention: Henry wants the towel for himself.
moral_action: Henry asks the front desk where he can buy the towel.
immoral_action: Henry puts the towel in his luggage when he leaves.

norm: Is wrong to steal clients from your employer
situation: John is an accountant leaving his employer of several years to start his own business.
intention: John wants to start his new business off with lots of clients.
moral_action: John advertises heavily prior to opening his business, and gets many new clients when he opens.
immoral_action: John copies the e-mails of several top clients at his old job and reaches out to them with lower rates than his old employer which they accept.

norm: It's inappropriate to dress poorly when you represent a business.
situation: Jacob was getting dressed to meet with a client for lunch one day.
intention: Jacob wants to put a shirt on.
moral_action: Jacob grabs his best button down shirt that he finds in his closet.
immoral_action: Jacob grabs a tee shirt with a band name on it to go to his meeting.

norm: It's wrong to defraud government entities for the benefits.
situation: Tina works but doesn't receive health insurance from her employer and knows that some people get their coverage from the government.
intention: Tina wants to get health insurance.
moral_action: Tina applies for and gets a new job that she knows provides health insurance.
immoral_action: Tina applies for government medical insurance by filling out an application with someone else's social security number, so she'll qualify.

norm: It's wrong to do things that will cheat a business.
situation: Karen has spent many years shopping at a store that offers a very generous return policy.
intention: Karen wants to return a TV.
moral_action: Karen returns the TV she bought a week ago in exchange for one that better suits her living room.
immoral_action: Karen returns all of the TV's in her home after years of use, in exchange for new ones at no cost to her.

norm: Its wrong to commit tax fraud.
situation: It's tax season and Roy is currently preparing his own tax return.
intention: Roy wants to save money on his taxes.
moral_action: Roy looks up every possible deduction that he can use and itemizes them all.
immoral_action: Roy takes some questionable deductions that will not hold up under scurtiny.

norm: It's wrong to cheat on your taxes.
situation: Peter realizes that Tax Day is coming up, and he hasn't filed yet.
intention: Peter wants to complete his tax return.
moral_action: Peter fills out his tax return, reporting all of his income and only taking credit for deductions he has receipts for.
immoral_action: Peter fills out his tax return but doesn't include all of his income and takes credit for numerous deductions he hasn't earned.

norm: You shouldn't leave your spouse for someone you barely know.
situation: Jess was in a relationship with Joe, but had recently taken a liking to Bill.
intention: Jess wants see what her future holds with Bill.
moral_action: Jess stays friends with Bill and does not peruse anything romantic.
immoral_action: Jess decides to break things off with Bill to see what will happen.

norm: You shouldn't let your friends hold you back in life.
situation: John is hanging out with his friends when Jenny asks him to take her out on a date, but Johns friends tell him that Jenny is bad news.
intention: John wants to respond to Jenny's request for a date.
moral_action: John looks at his friends, then at Jenny and tells her he will take her out because he doesn't care what his friends think, he thinks she's swell.
immoral_action: John looks at his friends, then at Jenny and tells her that if his friends think she's bad news, then she probably is and says no.

norm: You shouldn't let your partner control your friendships or you.
situation: Jane is at home with her significant other.
intention: Jane wants to know what her significant other wants to do that night.
moral_action: Jane goes out with friends after her significant other complains about them.
immoral_action: Jane stays home with her significant other because they were ranting about not trusting Jane's friends.

norm: You shouldn't keep things from your partner.
situation: Bobby and Grace are getting married and Bobby has $50,000 in debt that he has not told Grace about.
intention: Bobby wants to have a nice wedding day with Grace.
moral_action: Bobby tells Grace about his debt before their wedding, and they have a nice wedding day.
immoral_action: Bobby and Grace have a nice wedding day and Grace finds out about Bobby's debt a few days after the wedding on accident.

norm: You shouldn't leave your partner for someone else.
situation: Mark and Anna are in a long distance relationship, and Mark is lonely on a Friday night while his ex asks him out.
intention: Mark wants to do something to make himself less lonely.
moral_action: Mark calls Anna and asks to watch a movie with her over Zoom.
immoral_action: Mark accepts his ex's offer, and being with her Mark stops talking to Anna to be with his ex.

norm: You shouldn't distance yourself from your friends.
situation: Ebeneezer is working overtime on a project to please his client, and his friend Jeremy keeps asking him to hang out.
intention: Ebeneezer wants to get on his client's good side.
moral_action: Ebeneezer presents a detailed project outline for his client before taking Jeremy to the arcade.
immoral_action: Ebeneezer continues to work overtime to get ahead of project deadlines.

norm: You should not make career choices for someone else.
situation: Rita and her son are talking about careers and her son says he dreams of being an astronaut.
intention: Rita wants her son to be happy and successful.
moral_action: Rita tells her son to always follow his dreams wherever they may lead.
immoral_action: Rita tells her son astronauts are not practical, and he needs to be a doctor.

norm: You shouldn't keep people from their friends.
situation: Mary is worried about her daughters friendship with a wild girl in their neighborhood.
intention: Mary doesn't want her daughter to follow her friend into trouble.
moral_action: Mary reminds her daughter of the values she has been raised with and trusts her to make the right choices.
immoral_action: Mary turns the girl away whenever she comes to she her daughter.

norm: You shouldn't keep things from your significant other
situation: Joey is spending time with a female coworker after hours for work purposes and knows that this would concern his insecure partner.
intention: Joey wants to keep his partner from worrying.
moral_action: Joey tells his partner upfront that they have to do a work project together.
immoral_action: Joey avoids telling his partner who is he with after work.

norm: You shouldn't put your life on hold for somebody else
situation: Jenna had just been accepted to college, but her boyfriend told her his band had a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to tour.
intention: Jenna wants to support her boyfriend.
moral_action: Jenna and her boyfriend decide to date long distance while Jenna goes to college.
immoral_action: Jenna decides to take a gap year and tour with her boyfriend's band.

norm: You shouldn't enjoy watching gruesome videos.
situation: Sam had a morbid curiousity about a gore site on the internet.
intention: Sam wanted to see what the big deal was.
moral_action: Sam saw the gore site and decided it was not for him.
immoral_action: Sam kept going back to the shock site to see more bad things.

norm: It's wrong to glorify mass shootings.
situation: Jon is having a conversation with friends.
intention: Jon wants to talk about the Las Vegas massacre.
moral_action: Jon comments on how horrible the loss of life was in shooting in Las Vegas.
immoral_action: Jon lauds the Las Vegas shooter for being so accurate from such a long distance away.

norm: It's wrong to use someone else's pictures without their consent.
situation: Mark wants to advertise the new wigs from his store.
intention: Mark wants to capture people's attention.
moral_action: Mark asks his graphic designer friend to create a creative graphics for his store's twitter and website.
immoral_action: Mark places a picture of an instagram influencer with hair similar to his wig in an advertisement.

norm: It's rude to threaten people with a gun.
situation: Hank, who is armed with a pistol, is walking down the street when he sees a stranger, Tom yelling at his girlfriend Janice.
intention: Hank wants to stop Tom from yelling at Janice.
moral_action: Hank tells Tom that he's making a public scene and that it's rude to yell when you talk.
immoral_action: Hank pulls out his pistol and points it at Tom telling him to back off, or he'll shoot him.

norm: It's wrong to joke about mass shootings.
situation: Jimmy is a little known stand-up comedian and has a big show at the local comedy club, which could jump start his career.
intention: Jimmy wants to test some new edgy material.
moral_action: Jimmy tells a joke filled with sexual innuendos to the audience.
immoral_action: Jimmy tells a joke about a recent mass shooting tragedy.

norm: It's wrong to kick people in the groin.
situation: Howard and Will are play wrestling out in the park.
intention: Howard wants to win the wrestling match.
moral_action: Howard slips behind will and puts him in a headlock, winning the match.
immoral_action: Howard kicks Will in the groin and wraps his arms around Will while he's writhing in pain.

norm: It is bad to be careless about gun safety.
situation: Erin's neighbor just had his house broken into so Erin wants to teach her daughter Rihanna how to use a gun.
intention: Erin wants Rihanna to be able to protect herself.
moral_action: Erin signs her daughter Rihanna up for a gun safety class prior to giving her a gun.
immoral_action: Erin gives her daughter Rihanna a loaded pistol for her birthday and tells her to learn how to shoot it by watching a youtube video.

norm: It is wrong to hit people in the head
situation: Dan was getting bullied in school by a senior because of something his sister did.
intention: Dan wants to hit the bully to teach them a lesson.
moral_action: Dan doesn't want to hurt the bully too much, so he hits the bully in the stomach.
immoral_action: Dan hits the bully on the side of their head, and they end up going unconscious.

norm: It's wrong to Heckle at sporting event
situation: Jeff is in the stadium of a live sporting event.
intention: Jeff wants to express his excitement with the game.
moral_action: Jeff shouts positive encouragement toward his own team.
immoral_action: Jeff starts loudly chanting that the opposing team should go home and learn how to play the game.

norm: It's invasive to take photos of someone without their knowledge.
situation: James has a crush on Sarah and likes to look at pictures of her.
intention: James wants to get new photos of Sarah.
moral_action: James friends Sarah on Facebook and downloads every picture she uploads.
immoral_action: James follows Sarah around and takes candid photos of her when she's not looking.

norm: It's wrong to kick people in the testicles.
situation: Ben and Harry were arguing with each other after school was out.
intention: Ben wants it to be quiet.
moral_action: Ben walks away from Harry for a few minutes to be alone.
immoral_action: Ben pulls his foot back and kicks Harry right in the testicles.

norm: It's wrong to think shootings are funny.
situation: Sam is at school when news comes in about a school shooting in a nearby town.
intention: Sam wants to talk with his friends about the shooting.
moral_action: Sam talks with his friends about how crazy that kid must have been and how they shouldn't let it happen at their school.
immoral_action: Sam talks with his friends, laughing and joking about who he would like to shoot at the school.

norm: It's irresponsible to pretend to shoot at people in public
situation: Frank loves cowboys and the history of the wild west and has lots of toys and costumes that he uses when he plays.
intention: Frank wants to play cowboys at recess today.
moral_action: Frank wears a cowboy hat and sheriff badge to play cowboys at school and only pretends to shoot into the air with his fingers.
immoral_action: Frank chases the other kids around the play ground waving a black water gun he snuck into school to play cowboys today.

norm: It's wrong to punch someone else in the face.
situation: Brad is at home when he notices the neighbor, Bill roaming through his garage.
intention: Brad wants to confront Bill.
moral_action: Brad runs into the garage and demands to know why Bill is in there and what he wants.
immoral_action: Brad runs into the garage and grabs Bill and wrestles with him before swinging one of his fists into Bill's face.

norm: It's negligent to shoot fireworks near someone else's property.
situation: Shawn is hosting a 4th of July party at his beach house, and he wants to light fireworks as part of the celebration.
intention: Shawn wants to pick a spot to setup the fireworks.
moral_action: Shawn sets up the fireworks well away from his neighbors.
immoral_action: Shawn sets up the fireworks at the property line between him and his neighbor.

norm: It's bad to take pictures without getting permission.
situation: Jack was in a restaurant, and Brad Pitt walked in out of nowhere.
intention: Jack wanted to take a photo of Brad.
moral_action: Jake asks Brad if he can take a photo with him.
immoral_action: Jack takes his phone out and sneaks a photo of Brad while he's eating.

norm: It's bad to do anything that affects your child's health.
situation: Ron is a cigarette smoker and sometimes uses cigarettes while indoors.
intention: Ron wants to avoid smoking in the cold.
moral_action: Ron goes out to smoke in his car.
immoral_action: Ron smokes in a closed room in the house.

norm: Pressuring your child about their lif choices is wrong.
situation: Bob is looking to pass on his family restaurant business while his son wants to become a doctor.
intention: Bob wants someone to take over his family business.
moral_action: Bob sells off his family business to a highly capable owner.
immoral_action: Bob pressures his son to become the new owner of the family business.

norm: It's hurtful to not trust your husband with your baby.
situation: Lola is at home with her husband and baby where they are all trying to enjoy some family time together.
intention: Lola wants to make sure her baby is safe.
moral_action: Lola and her husband take turns giving their baby attention both in awe of the thing they have created together.
immoral_action: The entire time they are having family time, Lola doesn't let her husband hold the baby for fear he may drop it.

norm: It's hurtful to wish your child wasn't born.
situation: Bob's child wrote on the wall with a marker.
intention: Bob wants to punish his child.
moral_action: Bob tells his child to clean the wall and that they will have no play time for a week.
immoral_action: Bob tells his child that life was better when they were not around.

norm: It's bad to lie about your child's real father.
situation: Tina's young daughter, who doesn't know that Tina remarried, asks why she doesn't look anything like her stepdad, Tina's new husband.
intention: Tina wants to answer her daughter's question.
moral_action: Tina sits down with her daughter and explains that she and her biological father had a falling out, and that the stepdad is not the father.
immoral_action: Tina tells her daughter that her stepdad is her biological father and that sometimes accidents happen.

norm: It's bad behavior not to comply with your parents' rules.
situation: Diana is going out for the night with her boyfriend Daryl, and her parents give her a midnight curfew but Daryl wants her to go to a party at midnight.
intention: Diana needs to decide whether to go to the party.
moral_action: Diana says she can't go to the party and has Daryl drop her off at home.
immoral_action: Diana decides that she'd have a good time at the party and decides to go.

norm: It is paranoid to believe that your parents poisoned you.
situation: Edgar is eating dinner that his mother prepared for him and something seems off about it.
intention: Edgar wants to know if the food is safe.
moral_action: Edgar suggests to his mother that perhaps an ingredient she used in the meal was expired.
immoral_action: Edgar believes his mother has deliberately tampered with the meal and says as much to her.

norm: It's bad to undermine the self-esteem of a grandchild.
situation: Joan granddaughter confides that she wants to be an actor when she gets older.
intention: Joan, a failed actor, wants to respond to her granddaughters declaration.
moral_action: Joan is cautionary but encouraging to her granddaughter wish.
immoral_action: Wanting to curtail what she feels is a fruitless dream Joan decides to crush her granddaughters dream before it grows too big.

norm: It's wrong for parents not to support their children.
situation: Dee is a teacher who lives with her son Frank, who dreams of being a musician.
intention: Dee wants to feel better about herself.
moral_action: Dee tells Frank he can do anything he puts his mind to, and she supports him.
immoral_action: Dee tells Frank to forget his dreams and do something practical, like become a teacher.

norm: It is bad to violate your child's trust.
situation: Eve is Mike's mother, and has promised Mike she will attend his big soccer game today, though she is feeling tired.
intention: Eve wants to take a nap.
moral_action: Eve sets an alarm to wake up in time to make Mike's soccer game.
immoral_action: Eve takes a nap without setting an alarm and sleeps right through Mike's game.

norm: It's bad for parents not to watch over their babies.
situation: Christina is playing with her baby on her bed when the doorbell rings.
intention: Christina wants to answer the door.
moral_action: Christina picks up the baby and answers the door with her baby in her arms.
immoral_action: Christina runs out of the room to answer the door, leaving her baby on the bed.

norm: Being a burden on one's parents is wrong.
situation: Donald is an adult and recently got a new job near where his retired parents live.
intention: Donald wants to find somewhere to live.
moral_action: Donald tells his parents he will live on the same street as them, so he can visit them often.
immoral_action: Donald tells his parents he will live with them, so he doesn't have to pay rent.

norm: It's unacceptable to act out sexually in public.
situation: Kelly and her new boyfriend are going to the movies.
intention: Kelly wants to show him how physically attracted she is to him.
moral_action: Kelly tells him that they are going to have fun together at her place after the movie.
immoral_action: Kelly puts her hand down his pants, causing him to moan while the movie is playing.

norm: It is unacceptable to destroy people's relationships.
situation: Jack is the only child of his parents who are arguing a lot.
intention: Jack wants his parents to stop fighting around him.
moral_action: Jack tells his parents that they need to keep their disagreements between them, he's just a kid.
immoral_action: Jack tells his mom that his dad is abusing him, so they'll get a divorce.

norm: It is unacceptable to tease someone for making a mistake.
situation: Tony's son leaves his bike out in the rain and it rusts.
intention: Tony wants this son to realize the mistake he made.
moral_action: Tony talks to his son about the importance of taking care of things and tells him he'll need to help pay to repair his bike.
immoral_action: Tony makes fun of his son for leaving his bike out and laughs about how his son can't use it anymore.

norm: Bigotry is unacceptable.
situation: Barney has two new neighbors which he learns are a gay couple.
intention: Barney wants to say something to the new neighbors.
moral_action: Barney welcomes his new neighbors and says he hopes they can hang out sometime.
immoral_action: Barney tells his new neighbors that he thinks their lifestyle is disgusting, and they should get out of his neighborhood.

norm: It is unacceptable to spy on someone.
situation: Paula has been dating Rebecca for several months.
intention: Paula wants to know what Rebecca has been doing Wednesday nights.
moral_action: Paula asks Rebecca what Rebecca has been doing Wednesday night because Rebecca is always to busy to be together.
immoral_action: Paula follows Rebecca around and watches her Wednesday night without Rebecca knowing.

norm: It's unacceptable to steal.
situation: James was mad that his parents wouldn't give him money to buy candy.
intention: James wants to eat candy.
moral_action: James asked the shopkeeper if there were any chores he could do in exchange for store credit.
immoral_action: When the shopkeeper isn't looking, James sneaks the candy bar into his pocket.

norm: It is unacceptable to rape someone.
situation: John has a crush on Susan but is too coward to express his love.
intention: John wants to have a closer relationship with Susan.
moral_action: John plucks up his courage, sending Sally a bouquet of red roses and asks her to be his girlfriend.
immoral_action: John invited Susan to his home and has sex with her despite her unwillingness.

norm: It's unacceptable to judge others.
situation: Dan is attending a festive dinner with his Indian friends family.
intention: Dan wants to contribute to the dinner conversation.
moral_action: Dan participates in the familys customs and savors the food.
immoral_action: Dan criticizes the familys habits during the dinner and makes fun of their personal hygiene.

norm: It is unacceptable to manipulate people.
situation: Jake is a professor and is giving a class to his students.
intention: Jake wants to talk about current politics.
moral_action: Jake tells his students to take rational approach towards politics.
immoral_action: Jake tells his students that he is disgusted with current politics, and they should riot.

norm: It's unacceptable to discriminate against others.
situation: Luke is in charge of HR and is asked about hiring a man of Arabic descent.
intention: Luke wants to give his opinion of the man.
moral_action: Luke tells the man to send his resume, and he'll look over his qualifications.
immoral_action: "Luke tells the man, ""We don't need any towel-head terrorists working here - forget him""."

norm: It is unacceptable to be violent.
situation: The people in the city are dissatisfied with the government's decision to raise property tax rates.
intention: The people wants to show their disagreement.
moral_action: The people organize a peaceful demonstration and voice their opinions.
immoral_action: The people cause riots and arson all over the cities to vent their anger.

norm: It is unacceptable to talk in an offensive manner.
situation: Kevin has recently started playing a new multi-player video game with a voice chat.
intention: Kevin wants to interact with other players in the game.
moral_action: Kevin treats everyone with respect during the voice chats, and any teasing is good-natured and fun.
immoral_action: Kevin uses a lot of obscenities, slurs, and sexist remarks in the voice chat.

norm: It is unacceptable to cause harm to yourself.
situation: Jim has had a rough day at work due to dealing with stressful customers.
intention: Jim wants to find a way to unwind.
moral_action: Jim decides to watch a comedy using a streaming service.
immoral_action: Jim ends up drinking heavily in order to take the edge off the day.

norm: Abusing someone is unacceptable.
situation: Darin is in a relationship with Sue, who often gets on his nerves.
intention: Darin wants Sue to know how she makes him feel.
moral_action: Darin sits Sue down to talk and explain his feelings.
immoral_action: After losing his patience with Sue, Darin throws a chair at her.

norm: It's unacceptable for people to cheat on their romantic partners.
situation: Stacey is not happy in her relationship because of the constant problems she faces with her partner.
intention: Stacey wants to have a more fulfilled romantic life.
moral_action: Stacey breaks up with her partner and cites the change in their relationship.
immoral_action: Stacey gets involved with someone else while she's still with her partner.

norm: It's unacceptable to lie.
situation: Jamie's friend was shot at a party so cops are questioning people who were at the party, and Jamie knows who did it.
intention: Jamie doesn't want to look like a snitch in front of his friends.
moral_action: Jamie makes the cops give him witness protection in order to tell them what they want to hear.
immoral_action: Jamie tells the cops that he didn't see anything and doesn't know what happened.

norm: It's morally unacceptable to manipulate another person.
situation: Alan's girlfriend Jessica has a best friend, Kary, who Alan finds very annoying.
intention: Alan wants to deal with Kary's annoying tendencies.
moral_action: Alan tries to limit his time with Kary and encourages Jessica and Kary to hang out together without him.
immoral_action: Alan convinces Jessica that Kary doesnt value her as a friend and is only using her to get free food and drinks, for which Alan has no evidence.

norm: It's morally unacceptable to have relations with a child.
situation: Steve has raised his step daughter for 5 years now and is starting to fall in love with her.
intention: Steve wants to show his step daughter how much he loves him.
moral_action: Steve makes sure to buy his step daughter whatever she wants.
immoral_action: Steve asks his step daughter if she wants to be his girlfriend.

norm: It's unacceptable to judge the way someone grieves.
situation: Patty's mother recently passed away and her brother did not want to attend the funeral.
intention: Patty wants to talk to her brother about not attending the funeral.
moral_action: Patty tells her brother it's okay for him to process their mother's death in his own way.
immoral_action: Patty tells her brother it was rude to not attend the funeral.

norm: It is unacceptable to have prejudiced views.
situation: Kathy is with her friends outside, and they see a classmate who is Muslim.
intention: Kathy wants to comment on the Muslim classmate.
moral_action: Kathy says they should invite the classmate to hang out with them.
immoral_action: Kathy says the classmate must be a terrorist and says he should go back to the Middle East.

norm: It's unacceptable to curse at people.
situation: Steve was having an argument with the manager in his local supermarket.
intention: Steve wants to express his distaste with the manager.
moral_action: Steve tells the manager he thinks he's not paying attention to the needs of the consumers.
immoral_action: Steve calls the manager all types of vulgar names, cursing at him.

norm: It is unacceptable to sexually harrass someone.
situation: John notices a new girl at school named Jane.
intention: John wants to talk to Jane.
moral_action: John asks Jane what she did on the weekend.

norm: It's wrong not to care when someone dies.

intention: Timmy needs money to pay his bills.

norm: It's not okay to want someone else's death.

moral_action: Sarah decides to call her ex boyfriend and cuss him out.
immoral_action: Sarah buys a book of magic spells and recites a spell that is supposed to kill whoever she is thinking about.

norm: It's not nice to hope that someone dies.

intention: Kendra wants to tell Mike how she feels.
moral_action: Kendra tells Mike that she's really angry with him and that she will never talk to him again.
immoral_action: Kendra tells Mike that she's angry with him and that she truly wishes he gets killed soon.

norm: It's wrong not to respect the dead.

norm: It's wrong to take advantage of the deceased.

intention: Hank wants to get a headstone for his now-deceased wife.
moral_action: Hank finds a modestly-priced headstone and gets it for his wife.
immoral_action: Hank goes to a graveyard at night, removes a headstone from a grave, and re-engraves it for his wife.

norm: It's frowned upon to want to die.
situation: Alicia is depressed and feels that life has been a series of disappointments, she also feels no one hears understands her pain.

moral_action: Alicia phones her parents and tells them about her depression and how she would like their help and support.
immoral_action: Alicia phones her parents and tells them she would like her life to be over since it's so painful.

norm: It's not healthy to want to die
situation: Benjamin is at home with his wife Kendra and lately is having a hard time in life and is very depressed and can't seem to shake it.
intention: Benjamin wants to tell Kendra what he's going to do next.
moral_action: Benjamin tells Kendra that he is going to call a psychiatrist and set up an appointment to try to get medicine.
immoral_action: Benjamin tells Kendra that he's decided he's probably going to kill himself, and he can't take it anymore.

norm: It's wrong to guess when people will die.

intention: Bob wants to comment on Jim's plans.
moral_action: Bob is supportive of his friend and cheers him on.
immoral_action: Bob tells Jim that he is most likely to fall to his death on such a difficult climb.

norm: It is dark to hope for your own death.

intention: Angel wants to publish some new work.
moral_action: Angel's new poem talks about her depression but turns toward a hopeful tone as she also talks about the work she loves, writing poetry.
immoral_action: Angel publishes a poem in which she details her depression and states that she hopes she doesn't live much longer.

norm: It's frowned upon to commit suicide.

intention: Jason wants to stop feeling so bad.

norm: It's wrong to wish that your loved ones were dead.

intention: Katie wants to vent her anger somehow.
moral_action: Katie goes for a run to work off some of her anger.
immoral_action: Katie tells her sister that she wishes she was dead.

norm: Is wrong to be amused by somebody's death
situation: John is watching a live horse race on television with his wife Nancy when one of the riders falls off and gets trampled by the horse and dies.
intention: John wants to verbally react to what he just witnessed.
moral_action: "John says ""oh my god"" and tells Nancy that a horrific thing just occurred, and he feels awful witnessing it."
immoral_action: John gets up from the couch and starts to laugh and point at the TV and remarks how funny it was the way the jockey fell.

norm: It is wrong to be happy over elderly people dying.

intention: Billy wants to move up in his company.
moral_action: Billy picks the mind of a coworker who is several tiers above him in the company heirachy.

norm: It's wrong to not sympathize with a creatures death.

intention: Dave wants to react to Jenny telling him her dog died.
moral_action: Dave tells Jenny that the news is terrible and that he feels really bad for the poor dog.
immoral_action: Dave tells Jenny that it's fine since it's just a dog, not someone important like a human so not to worry about it so much.

norm: You should not be happy about someone's death.
situation: Steve's parents died in a tragic accident recently, but they were abusive to Steve and thus he's happy they are gone.
intention: Steve wants to get his parent's funeral over with.
moral_action: Steve remains silent and allows his family to grieve despite his own feelings.
immoral_action: "Steve plays ""another one bites the dust"" the entire time and offends his siblings, aunts and uncles."

norm: It's wrong to fake your own death.
situation: Sam has been invited to the wedding of a distant cousin he secretly dislikes and everyone is expecting him to attend.
intention: Sam wants to get out of having to go to the wedding.
moral_action: Sam pretends to fall ill the week before the wedding as an excuse why he cannot attend.

norm: It's wrong to be happy that someone died.

intention: Tanya wanted to talk to her husband about her brother dying.
moral_action: Tanya expresses concern for the fact that her sibling died while talking.
immoral_action: Tanya verbalizes her glee about her sibling dying, and jumps up and down in celebration.

norm: It's wrong to make light of people's death.

intention: Casey wants to drive his friend home.

norm: It is wrong to replace a dead partner quickly.

moral_action: Tammy decides to get a cat instead of seducing someone online, and is no longer lonely.

norm: It's wrong to lie about your parents being dead.
