intention: Paulie wants to make friends at school.

norm: It is heartless to wish death on someone's loved one.

intention: Bill wants to end the argument.

norm: It is wrong to be responsible for three people dying.

intention: Karen wants to feel more awake.

norm: It is wrong to want to die.

norm: It is wrong to lie about someone dying.

moral_action: Donna makes a bunch of different soups for her sick friend.

norm: It is good to help others in need.

norm: IT's good to know when you need help in life.

norm: It is good to help those who need it.

moral_action: John tells Jane that she doesn't have to ask twice and leaps on top of her to start kissing her passionatelly.

norm: It's good to share the parenting load between partners.

norm: It's good to do nice things for your loved ones.

norm: It's good to work to make your marriage work.

norm: It's good to do nice things for love interests.

norm: It's good to care for your loved ones.

norm: It's rude to spy on your neighbors.

norm: It's inconsiderate to annoy your neighbors with your noise.

norm: It's rude to use your housemate's things without permission.

norm: It is rude to insult someone's pet.

norm: It's rude to litter your neighbors property.

immoral_action: Juan decides to do all the louder yard work, like mowing, so that his neighbor who is probably sleeping the party off can hear it.

norm: It is rude to be loud and disturb the neighbors.

immoral_action: "Maddie yells at her neighbor to ""pick up her dog's shit""."

norm: It's rude to hurt close family's feelings with bad behavior.

moral_action: John goes to work out in his gym and then goes to a movie with his family.

moral_action: Mark applies a liberal amount of scented body spray on before he leaves.

norm: It's rude to spew body fluids on other people intentionally.

intention: Marcus wants to get home quick enough to catch the end of the Celtics game.
moral_action: Marcus, annoyed at getting pulled over, complies with the officers instructions.
immoral_action: Mark annoyed at the cop for pulling him over spits at him.

norm: It's rude to ruin someone's flower beds.

norm: It's immoral to poke holes in condoms.

moral_action: Jake takes the condom and without much ado slips it on before contiuing.

norm: It's bad to take medication that you don't need.

norm: It's irresponsible to overindulge in snacks.

intention: Vince wants to eat.

norm: It's wrong to harm your body with excessive drug use.

intention: Luke wants to have a good time.
moral_action: Luke decides to avoid the party entirely and watch a movie at home instead.
immoral_action: Luke dives back into substance abuse without hesitation at the party, doing line after line through a rolled up twenty dollar bill.

norm: It's rude to take candy without permission.
situation: Lisa sees a candy dish at her friend's house.
intention: Lisa wants some candy.
moral_action: Lisa asks her friend if she can have a piece of candy.
immoral_action: Lisa sneaks handfuls of candy and puts them in her pocket.

norm: It's wrong to judge how others live their life.
situation: Dave has just met Kevin at a party when Kevin tells Dave that he lives life as a nudist.
intention: Dave wants to respond to Kevin's admission.
moral_action: Dave tells Kevin that he loves warm clothes too much to be a nudist but respects Kevin's choice as it's his home.
immoral_action: Dave tells Kevin  that he is disgusting and that he should be ashamed of himself.

norm: It is greedy to not let anyone use your stuff.
situation: Dora's roommate Kim has an interview in the morning and her iron broke, she knows Dora has an iron.
intention: Dora wants Kim to leave for the interview.
moral_action: Dora grabs her iron and lends it to Kim, wishing her well on her interview.
immoral_action: Dora tells Kim that her iron is broken as well and that her outfit looks fine as is.

norm: It's wrong to judge others based on their life choices.
situation: Jason had just read something about trans people, and his next client is trans.
intention: Jason wants to comment on their gender.
moral_action: Jason asks the client what their pronouns are.
immoral_action: Jason tells the client that trans identity is a form of mental illness.

norm: It is wrong to disrespect people you live with.
situation: Henry's roommate Jill comes home in a new dress and asks Henry what he thinks of it?
intention: Henry wants to answer Jill's question.
moral_action: Henry ells Jill that the dress looks nice and that it compliments her eyes.
immoral_action: Henry tells Jill that the dress looks horrible on her as do most things since she's so fat.

norm: It's wrong to stop someone from living their life.
situation: Stan was walking home when he walked past a gay nightclub.
intention: Stan wanted to see what it was like inside.
moral_action: Stan is glad to see so many people happy and dancing and goes about his business.
immoral_action: Stan goes into the nightclub and starts beating people up just for being gay.

norm: It's selfish to not share with others your living with.
situation: Coy has just gone to the grocery store and is putting his groceries away in the cabinet.
intention: Coy wants to eat some of the chips that he bought.
moral_action: Coy eats some of his chips and offers to share some with his father.
immoral_action: Coy eats some of his chips and refuses to share any with his father.

norm: It's wrong to use your neighbor's stuff without their permission.
situation: Mitchell's getting ready to go to the garage to get his mower when he notices his neighbors mower is already outside on the lawn.
intention: Mitchell wants to decide which mower to use.
moral_action: Mitchell decides to walk an extra ten feet and get his own mower from his garage.
immoral_action: Mitchell decides to use the neighbor's mower since it's right there, and he won't be long.

norm: It's wrong to use your roommate's things without their permission.
situation: Jeff has been stuck inside all day, and he thinks he should get some fresh air.
intention: Jeff wants to go for a bike ride.
moral_action: Jeff's bike has a flat, so he decides to wait until his roommate Ben comes home to ask if he can borrow his bike to go ride.
immoral_action: When Jeff sees that his bike has a flat he decides to take the other bike that belongs to his roommate Ben.

norm: It's wrong to disrespect the people who raised you.
situation: Bill is mad that his parents have grounded him for a month for sneaking out the house.
intention: Bill wants to say something to his parents about his punishment.
moral_action: Bill apologizes and asks for a shorter punishment.
immoral_action: Bill tells his parents that they're the worst parents ever.

norm: It's rude to not consider someone else when living together.
situation: Rob needs to get something from downstairs in the middle of the night, and he lives with a roommate.
intention: Rob wants to get the item and get back to his room.
moral_action: Rob makes sure to move quietly while retrieving the item as to not disturb his roommate given it is the middle of the night.
immoral_action: Rob moves quickly through the home with loud footsteps as he goes to retrieve the item from downstairs.

norm: It's wrong to steal from your neighbor.
situation: Jenny has recently moved into a new neighborhood, and she notices that her neighbor has a unique lawn gnome.
intention: Jenny wants to own the lawn gnome for herself.
moral_action: Jenny asks the neighbor about the lawn gnome, and he tells her the name of the local shop where he purchased it.
immoral_action: Jenny goes into the neighbor's yard after dark and takes the lawn gnome, then places it in her back yard.

norm: It's wrong to be a nuisance to your neighbors.
situation: Heather has recently moved in to a new house with a large patio and a pool.
intention: Heather wants to have a housewarming party.
moral_action: Heather has a small barbecue with five of her closest friends, and they keep their noise level low.
immoral_action: Heather buys a keg of beer and invites twenty friends over for a dance party on the patio.

norm: It's wrong to use your co-worker's things without permission.
situation: Tina works in an office and deals with a variety of sensitive documents.
intention: Tina wants to shred some papers.
moral_action: Tina gets her own paper shredder and uses it to shred her documents.
immoral_action: Tina uses one of her co-workers' personal paper shredders to shred the documents.

norm: It's wrong to disturb your neighbors.
situation: Karen is having a party in her backyard and is playing music.
intention: Karen wants to have fun with her friends.
moral_action: Karen keeps her music at a reasonable volume, and moves the party inside at 9 PM.
immoral_action: Karen plays her music too loud, and late into the evening.

norm: It's wrong to question how someone else live's their lives.
situation: Erin feels a strong sense of disapproval as she watches her brother sign up for classes in school that won't help him earn a big salary.
intention: Erin wants to talk to her brother about his educational decisions.
moral_action: Erin explains to her brother that she is taking a different set of classes and talks about what she hopes to achieve in life, with her education.
immoral_action: Erin tells her brother that the classes he selects are worthless and a complete waste of money.

norm: It's wrong to prevent someone from enjoying their life.
situation: Valarie is overseeing a project with tight deadlines, and one of her workers Emily wants to celebrate her birthday.
intention: Valarie wants to meet her goals.
moral_action: Valarie switches around Emily's shift with another one of her coworkers.
immoral_action: Valarie forces Emily to work on her birthday.

norm: It's wrong to litter a neighbor's property.
situation: Heysel is walking down the sidewalk in a residential area and has just finished a bottle of water on a hot day.
intention: Heysel wants to discard his water bottle.
moral_action: Heysel smashes the water bottle and puts it in his pocket until he passes by a trash can.
immoral_action: Heysel casually throws his bottle to the side and onto someone's lawn, then continues walking.

norm: It's not okay to abuse others to improve your life.
situation: Gary is neighbors with a rich but weak man named Ted and Gary has big gambling debts.
intention: Gary needs to find a way to get more money.
moral_action: Gary asks Ted to loan him some money and that he promises he'll repay with interest.
immoral_action: Gary threatens Ted and tells him if he doesn't pay Gary an allowance Gary will beat on him regularly.

norm: Not wanting to infect your coworkers is common decency.
situation: Joe has a bit of cough and fever and isn't feeling that great on Monday morning.
intention: Joe wants to avoid losing money for the day.
moral_action: Joe calls his boss and asks if he can work from home since he isn't feeling well.
immoral_action: Joe ignores his symptoms and goes to work anyway, so he doesn't miss out on his pay.

norm: You should never get so angry that you hit someone.
situation: Matt is with him roommate cooking dinner in the kitchen of their shared apartment.
intention: Matt wants his roommate to clean up after himself.
moral_action: Matt asks his roommate to clean up for himself or else he'll move out.
immoral_action: Matt angrily confronts his roommate about the messy kitchen and hits him so hard that he falls backward.

norm: You shouldn't tell your friends they are crazy.
situation: Jenny's best fried tells her that she thinks things are being moved around in her house when she is out, but Jenny thinks she is imagining things.
intention: Jenny wants to dismiss her friends fears.
moral_action: Jenny helps her friend contact a security company that installs surveillance cameras around her house.
immoral_action: Jenny tells her friend that she is probably mistaken and that she should relax more.

norm: You shouldn't continue texting people that are cheating their partners.
situation: Tom learns that his brother-in-law Kent is cheating on Sarah, his wife.
intention: Tom wants to confront Kent about Kent's infidelity.
moral_action: Tom meets with Kent, accuses him of cheating on Sarah, and tells him to stop.
immoral_action: Tom texts Kent and asks him about the details of his affair.

norm: You shouldn't misbehave or you'll be punished by your teacher.
situation: Fred is sitting with friends at a school assembly and is bored by the presentation.
intention: Fred wants to talk with his friends.
moral_action: Fred takes out some paper and a pencil and passes notes to his friends.
immoral_action: Fred starts talking with his friend, laughing and joking.

norm: You shouldn't laugh at your friend when they hurt themselves.
situation: Billy is skateboarding with friends, when his friend Evan falls off his skateboard and skins his knee.
intention: Billy wants to do something about Evan.
moral_action: Billy asks if Evan needs help and tries to get him some medical attention.
immoral_action: Billy laughs about Evan's injury and posts mean things about it on social media.

norm: You shouldn't make fun of people just for their name.
situation: William meets a fellow named Norvel while he is walking down the road.
intention: William wants to break the ice.
moral_action: William tells Norvel a joke he remembered off of Reddit.
immoral_action: William asks him what type of cornfed name is Norvel and laughs.

norm: You shouldn't make fun of someone's fear of blood.
situation: Arjun is at a clinic waiting for a phlebotomist to draw blood samples, but Arjun is nervous because of his fear of blood.
intention: The phlebotomist needs to draw blood from Arjun.
moral_action: The phlebotomist notices Arjun's nervousness and explains the procedures calmly.
immoral_action: The phlebotomist giggles at Arjun's anxiety and tells him he's acting like a little kid, and he should tough it out.

norm: You should not let people's words drive you to murder.
situation: James was in a bar when another man used a slur to refer to his sexuality.
intention: James wants to punish the man who insulted him.
moral_action: James tells the bouncer about the man's use of the slur and asks to have him thrown out.
immoral_action: James smashes a whiskey bottle on the bar and attempts to drive it into the other man's neck.

norm: You shouldn't tell your friends that you hate them.
situation: Robert's friends prank him as he walks home from school by pouring a bucket of water on him.
intention: Robert wants his friends to know they hurt him.
moral_action: Robert tells his friends the prank bothered him as he's very sensitive and asks to go out with them tomorrow.
immoral_action: Robert tells his friends he can't stand them anymore and never wants to see them again.

norm: You shouldn't want to be friends with murderers.
situation: Phil is studying behavioral science with a focus on serial killers.
intention: Phil wants to pick the mind of a serial killer.
moral_action: Phil arranges to conduct monitored interviews with a convicted serial killer.
immoral_action: Phil starts a correspondence with a convicted serial killer and soon develops a friendship with him.

norm: It's rude to use humor at the expense of others.
situation: Chris and his friends are sitting at the food court in the mall talking and people watching.
intention: Chris wants to entertain his friends.
moral_action: Chris relates a tale of camping trip he took with his family that was full of adventure and good times.
immoral_action: Chris makes a fat joke about the size of a portly man walking by the food court with a tray of food.

norm: It's rude to laugh at other peoples misfortune
situation: Tom is walking down the street at night, and he sees someone fall down and drop all of their groceries.
intention: Tom wants to react to the situation.
moral_action: Tom rushes to the man's aid and asks if he's okay.
immoral_action: Tom laughs at the man falling down and does not help him.

norm: It is rude to laugh at a stuttering kid.
situation: Ms. Jane is teaching  a class of middle school students about public speaking.
intention: Ms. Jane wants to give the students feedback.
moral_action: Ms. Jane listens to a child that is stuttering through his presentation and makes sure to compliment him on his structure and topic choices.
immoral_action: Ms. Jane listens to the speech a child with a stutter is giving, then criticizes him for his speech being poor and difficult to understand.

norm: It's rude to laugh at others.
situation: Jennifer sees that her classmate got a new haircut which Jennifer thinks looks really bad.
intention: Jennifer wants to talk to her classmate.
moral_action: Jennifer talks to her classmate about school work and other regular topics.
immoral_action: Jennifer goes up to her classmate and makes fun of their haircut, laughing at how bad it is.

norm: It's rude to laugh at German rappers.
situation: Rico is in Germany at a rap concert.
intention: Rico wants to express how he feels about the music.
moral_action: Rico cheers on the rappers performing on stage.
immoral_action: Rico laughs at the performers on stage.

norm: It's rude to sabotage someone's life and smile about it.
situation: Jack does not like Ben and has the opportunity to ruin a major project that Ben is working on.
intention: Jack wants to make a decision on the opportunity.
moral_action: Jack resists the temptation to ruin Ben's major project and simply observes Ben.
immoral_action: Jack ruins Ben's major project and smiles about it in front of Ben.

norm: It's wrong to laugh at hurtful jokes.
situation: Daimen is at a party with his disabled sister Hannah when Travis makes fun of Hannah's disability.
intention: Daimen wants to get on his Travis good side.
moral_action: Daimen explains how Hannah's good qualities could assist Travis.
immoral_action: Daimen giggles and builds on Travis' joke.

norm: It's wrong to laugh at less intelligent people.
situation: Al is in class listening to the history lesson and his classmate Gina is called on to answer a question, and she doesn't know it.
intention: Al wants to react to Gina's inability to respond.
moral_action: Al see's Gina struggling, so he chimes in to help her understand.
immoral_action: Al thinks it's funny that Gina didn't know how to answer such an easy question, so he bursts out into laughter.

norm: It's wrong to laugh at someone.
situation: Jane's history class has been preparing presentations, and they are ready to start delivering them.
intention: Jane wants to listen to Martin's presentation and comment on it.
moral_action: "After Martin presents, Jane asks, ""How did you select such an interesting topic?""."
immoral_action: "After Martin presents, Jane asks, ""Why did you pick such a silly topic?"" and laughs."

norm: It's rude to make fun of your friend's dancing.
situation: Paul has a large group of friends who enjoy planning activities together.
intention: Paul wants to go clubbing with his friends.
moral_action: Paul notices that one of his friends is not very good at dancing and gives some pointers to help his friend get into the rhythm.
immoral_action: Paul notices one of his friends dancing awkwardly at the club and takes a video with his phone to post online.

norm: It's rude to hi-jack your friend's joke entirely.
situation: Steve starts telling a joke at a party that his friend, Chris, already knows.
intention: Chris wants to contribute to the joke.
moral_action: Chris lets Steve finish telling the joke and joins in the raucous laughter even though he'd heard it already.
immoral_action: Chris starts talking over Steve to tell the rest of the joke.

norm: It's rude to laugh at someone who is afraid.
situation: Tony and his younger brother, Paul, are swimming at the local pool where there are several diving boards.
intention: Tony wants to teach Paul how to dive.
moral_action: Tony is scared and won't jump off the diving board so Paul talks to him and tells him that it's alright to be afraid but to try to be brave.
immoral_action: Paul is afraid to dive and Tony laughs out loud, and calls his brother a chicken.

norm: It's hurtful to lead someone on in a relationship.
situation: Mary  has been dating Fred since high school but lately she has also been interested in a guy she works with.
intention: Mary wants to explore new relationships.
moral_action: Mary tells Fred she wants to take a break and see other people.
immoral_action: Mary asks her coworker out but wants to keep seeing Fred incase her new relationship doesn't work out.

norm: You shouldn't like someone who is already in a relationship.
situation: Mike, Amy and Jeff are at the bar when Amy, who is married asks Jeff if he wants to have a sexual affair with her.
intention: Jeff wants to respond to Amy's question.
moral_action: Jeff tells Amy that because she is married, he does not even think of her as a possible object of affection.
immoral_action: Jeff tells Amy that he would love to have sex with her and is open to a long term affair.

norm: It's bad to date someone who is underage.
situation: Dave who is an adult is mowing his lawn when his neighbor's seventeen year old daughter asks him on a date.
intention: Dave wants to respond to the neighbor's date offer.
moral_action: Dave tells the neighbor girl that he's flattered but that she should find someone her own age to take her out.
immoral_action: Dave tells the neighbor girl that he'd love to take her out and maybe buy her a drink.

norm: It is destructive to be argumentative in a relationship.
situation: Nick and Kelly are a couple who occasionally criticize one another, but love each other very much.
intention: Nick wants to respond to Kelly's criticisms.
moral_action: Faced with her criticism, Nick gently asks Kelly why she feels the way she does, and apologizes for his actions.
immoral_action: Faced with her criticism, Nick screams at Kelly and denies everything she says.

norm: It's bad to be emotionally unavailable in a relationship.
situation: Tom heard that his wife had a horrible day at work and isn't sure how to deal with it.
intention: Tom wants to give her wife advice on how to handle the next day.
moral_action: Tom tries to empathize with his wife and emotionally comfort her to help prepare her for the next day.
immoral_action: Tom tries to tell his wife what to do without being emotionally available or empathizing with his wife.

norm: It's bad to become involved in unhealthy relationships.
situation: Julie is an aspiring students who is dating demanding high school dropout Joe.
intention: Julie wants to be in a committed relationship.
moral_action: Julie breaks up with Joe when he doesnt support her choice.
immoral_action: Julie is admitted to a prestigous college, but does not go when Joe says that she is being selfish by going to college.

norm: It's bad to be with someone that you don't want.
situation: Jane has been sending expensive gifts to Nathan in an attempt to woo him into dating her, but he has no interest in her.
intention: Nathan wants to talk to Jane.
moral_action: Nathan tells Jane that he cannot accept her gifts, and she deserves to be with someone who takes interest in her.
immoral_action: Nathan agrees to date Jane because he enjoys the gifts.

norm: It's bad to hook up with someone who isn't single.
situation: Mike was at a bar after work one Friday afternoon.
intention: Mike wants to get a date for the weekend.
moral_action: Mike leaves the bar with a single woman that he meets there.
immoral_action: Mike leaves the bar with a woman who told him that she was married.

norm: It's bad to date convicts.
situation: Trevor is at his computer looking for prospective romantic dates on various website.
intention: Trevor wants to go on a date.
moral_action: Trevor joins a reputable dating website and eventually has his first date with a retail worker he meets through the website.
immoral_action: Trevor finds a website that teaches people how to contact prison inmates and decides to try to find a date that way.

norm: It's bad to be controlling when in a relationship.
situation: Brenda is about to leave to go see her friend at the mall when she says goodbye to her husband, Dan.
intention: Dan wants to respond to Brenda.
moral_action: Dan tells Brenda to have a great time and to drive safely out there.
immoral_action: Dan tells Brenda that she's not going anywhere since she never asked Dan if she was allowed to leave.

norm: It is bad to be dangerous when dating.
situation: Ted was taking Rita to eat on their first date together.
intention: Ted wants to drive to the restaurant.
moral_action: Ted drives to the restaurant safely and at a reasonable speed.
immoral_action: Ted picks up Rita and drives fast and recklessly on the way to the restaurant.

norm: It's bad to be abusive in a relationship.
situation: Hank is dating Gina and Gina didn't put enough salt in the food she made.
intention: Hank wants to respond to the lack of salt.
moral_action: Hank tells Gina that the food is good but can use a little more salt.
immoral_action: Hank takes the food and tosses it against the wall.

norm: It is bad to be too clingy in a relationship.
situation: Rachel has been ignoring her girlfriend Tanya's calls and texts because Rachel is at work.
intention: Tanya wants to know what Rachel is up to.
moral_action: Tanya waits for Rachel to respond before texting or calling her again.
immoral_action: Tanya keeps calling Rachel's phone and leaving messages asking why Rachel won't answer.

norm: It's bad to date someone that causes you pain.
situation: Julie's boyfriend is verbally abusive and her sister urges her to leave him.
intention: Julie wants to respond to her sisters suggestion.
moral_action: Julie listens to her sister and ends her relationship.
immoral_action: Julie decides to ignore her sister and give her boyfriend another chance.

norm: It's bad not to act civil when in a relationship.
situation: Stan is at a park with his wife, and his wife keeps trying to feed the pigeons human food.
intention: Stan wants his wife to stop feeding the pigeons.
moral_action: Stan tells his wife in his indoor voice that she might kill the pigeons by feeding it human food.
immoral_action: Stan raises his voice and asks his wife how many times he has to tell her to not feed the pigeons.

norm: It's bad to date someone who isn't single.
situation: Marla had met Todd and his wife at a party over the weekend.
intention: Marla wants to visit with Todd.
moral_action: Marla invites Todd and his wife to her house for dinner one night.
immoral_action: Marla invites Todd to her house for a candlelit dinner date.

norm: It's bad to tempt someone who's already in a relationship.
situation: Ash has a crush on a guy at work, but she knows he's married.
intention: Ash has to decide whether to hit on the guy.
moral_action: Ash decides to leave the guy alone and doesn't say anything to him.
immoral_action: Ash tells the guy that she's really good at giving oral sex.

norm: It's bad to date a bunch of people at once.
situation: John is dating Susan but sees other attractive girls at a party he likes.
intention: John wants more sexual excitement in his life.
moral_action: John asks Susan back to his place where he tries new romantic stuff with her in bed they've never done before.
immoral_action: John asks three other girls at the party to date him, and they say yes.

norm: You shouldn't interfere in a country's election.
situation: Bob wants his favorite candidate to win the presidential election.
intention: Bob wants his candidate to get more votes.
moral_action: Bob goes door-to-door trying to convince people to vote for his candidate.
immoral_action: Bob hacks a voting machine and adds 1,000 more votes for his candidate.

norm: You shouldn't call the cops on a friend.
situation: John and Jim are leaving a party and Jim is very drunk and wants to drive himself home.
intention: John wants to keep Jim from hurting himself.
moral_action: John convinces Jim to ride home in John's car instead, saying it isn't safe for Jim to drive.
immoral_action: John calls the cops as Jim is getting in the car and tells them there's a drunk driver in the area.

norm: You shouldn't call the cops for petty reasons.
situation: Janice's neighbor Paul loves Trump and puts a huge Trump supporter sign in his yard that looks tacky and violates housing community guidelines.
intention: Janice wants to get Paul to follow community guidelines.
moral_action: Janice reminds Paul about the housing guidelines and asks him nicely to take action.
immoral_action: Janice places a tip to the police hotline that Paul has violated housing community guides.

norm: You shouldn't get in arguments with your in-laws.
situation: John is having dinner with his in-laws, and they express a political view that he disagrees with.
intention: John wants to respond to his in-laws statement.
moral_action: John acknowledges his in-laws' point of view and then expresses his own in a respectful manner.
immoral_action: John criticizes his in-laws' point of view and starts a heated political argument with them.

norm: You shouldn't call the cops on your in-laws.
situation: Sally took care of her mother-in-law in return for a small payment each week, but she has not been paid lately.
intention: Sally wanted to obtain payment for the last few weeks of her work.
moral_action: Sally talks to her in-laws to tell them it is important to her that she receive the money they owe her.
immoral_action: Sally calls the police to report that her in-laws owe her money to scare them and make them pay her.

norm: You shouldn't leak a friend's inormation to debt collectors
situation: Will lives with a roommate and has been getting calls from a strange number to the house.
intention: Will wants to see who has been calling so much.
moral_action: Will tells the debt collector nothing and asks his roommate about it.
immoral_action: Will picks up the call and confirms that his roommate lives there and gives the debt collector his cell number.

norm: It's not neighborly to call the police on your neighbors.
situation: Tom hears loud banging and yelling from his neighbor's house.
intention: Tom wants to quiet his neighbors down and have a peaceful day.
moral_action: Tom walks to his neighbors house, knocks on the door, and asks if everything is alright inside.
immoral_action: Tom calls the police to report that his neighbors are making too much noise.

norm: You shouldn't harass citizens if you're a police officer.
situation: Victor is a new police officer fresh out of the academy whom was just assigned to patrol a new community.
intention: Victor wants his community to respect him.
moral_action: Victor goes out of his way to help members of his community and spends time talking and getting to know them.
immoral_action: Victor constantly pulls people over whom are doing nothing wrong and is very mean to them.

norm: You shouldn't use the internet to ruin a business's reputation.
situation: Kate recently visited Colby's restaurant and the waitress forgot her ketchup.
intention: Kate wants Colby to know about the service she got.
moral_action: Kate talks to Colby the next time she sees him in town.
immoral_action: Kate goes on every site she can find to leave Colby a bad review.

norm: You should not help corporations violate people's rights.
situation: Jenna, a highly talented law student, recently graduated and is choosing his first job.
intention: Jenna wants a prestigious job.
moral_action: Jenna goes to work for the local public defender's office and plans to run for office in a decade or so.
immoral_action: Jenna goes to work for Monsanto and argues, against the balance of scientific evidence, that their pesticides are safe.

norm: You should't kick out your in-laws.
situation: Meg's mother and father-in-law had been staying with her and her husband for a month because they were out of work.
intention: Meg wants to be alone with her husband.
moral_action: Meg tells her mother and father in-law that she and her husband will be going out to dinner.
immoral_action: Meg tells her mother and father in-law that they have to leave by the afternoon.

norm: Leaving your sister on read is disrespectful.
situation: Jen has a sister who messaged about a problem but also has a serious a work deadline.
intention: Jen wants to get her work done on time.
moral_action: Jen replies quickly explaining her work deadline that she will make sure to get back to her ASAP.
immoral_action: Jen sees the message but ignores it and focuses on her work.

norm: It is rude to be negative about your girlfriends mother.
situation: Jim and Zoe are having dinner at his girlfriends parents house and the mom tells Jim his tattoo's make him look like a punk.
intention: Jim wants to react to the situation.
moral_action: Jim makes a joke by saying that he loves punk music, so thank you for the compliment.
immoral_action: Jim tells Zoe's mom that her dress makes her look overweight.

norm: It's hurtful to cancel your child's visit with her parent.
situation: Kitty lives with her mother who divorced with Kitty's father and one day Kitty doesn't do her Math homework properly.
intention: Kitty's mother wants to punish her.
moral_action: Kitty's mother asks her to do two more pages of practice in the Math book.
immoral_action: Kitty's mother does not let her see her father on the weekend.

norm: It's rude to evict one's mother.
situation: Bobby is a landlord who rents a unit to his mother Beth who hasn't paid her rent.
intention: Bobby wants to find out where his payment is.
moral_action: Beth tells  Bobby she doesn't have the money and won't until next month, so he tells her not to worry about it.
immoral_action: Beth tells  Bobby she doesn't have the money and won't until next month, so he tells her she has a week to vacate the premises.

norm: It is rude to joke about a friends mom.
situation: Joe and his friends are joking around and one of his friends gets a good crack in against Joe.
intention: Joe wants to get his friend back.
moral_action: Joe cracks a joke about his friend that is similar to what the two have joked about before.
immoral_action: Joe responds by making a crude joke about his friend's mom.

norm: It's wrong to fat-shame your daughter.
situation: Billy's daughter has put on a lot of weight recently, and Billy is concerned.
intention: Billy wants his daughter to lose weight.
moral_action: Billy sits her down and talks to her about how he's concerned and how he loves her so much.
immoral_action: Billy starts making fun of his daughter loudly every single time she walks by.

norm: It's wrong to date a friend's sister behind their back.
situation: Hannah has a crush on her friend Renee's twin sister Carla and wants to date her.
intention: Hannah doesn't want to hurt Renee.
moral_action: Hannah and Carla go to Renee and tell her about their feelings for each other and ask for her blessing.
immoral_action: Hannah and Carla start to date secretly and do not tell Renee what is going on.

norm: It's rude to leave a girl ignored and ghosted.
situation: Ryan doesn't get along well with his girlfriend Sandra for quite a while.
intention: Ryan wants to decide on his relationship with Sandra.
moral_action: Ryan requests for a peaceful breakup and explains the reasons sincerely to Sandra.
immoral_action: Ryan without explaining anything to Sandra blocks all her messages and distance himself from her.

norm: It's rude to yell at your sister.
situation: Maggie's sister is playing with Maggie's doll.
intention: Maggie wants to play with her doll.
moral_action: Maggie asks her sister if she can have her doll back when she's done playing with it.
immoral_action: Maggie screams in her sister's face that it is Maggie's doll not hers.

norm: It's wrong to be attracted to your future sister-in-law.
situation: Jay is about to get married, but he thinks his fiance's sister is really attractive.
intention: Jay wants to figure out how to handle this situation.
moral_action: Jay decides to leave his fiance's sister alone since he's in love with his fiance.
immoral_action: Jay decides to secretly have an affair with his fiance's sister.

norm: Refusing a proposal after dating for a while is hurtful.
situation: Mitch shows his girlfriend Amy an engagement ring and asks her to marry him after 10 years of dating.
intention: Amy wants to continue being with Mitch.
moral_action: Amy tells Mitch that she would love to marry him.
immoral_action: Amy tells Mitch that she only wants them to be a couple instead of a married couple.

norm: It is rude to ignore your mother.
situation: Zach is talking with a friend when his mother comes up and starts asking him something.
intention: Zach wants to choose someone to listen to.
moral_action: Zach tells his friend to hold on and asks his mother to repeat what she just said.
immoral_action: "Zach gives his mother ""the hand"", telling her to be quiet, and continues to talk to his friend."

norm: It's wrong to kick down your estranged wife's door.
situation: Fred just found out his ex wife is trying to gain full custody of his child.
intention: Fred wants to confront his wife on the issue.
moral_action: Fred contacts his attorney and prepares to meet his wife on the issue through legal means.
immoral_action: Fred lets his mood get the better of him and goes to his wife's front door and makes his way through it when she does not answer.

norm: It is rude to hang up on your mother.
situation: Tara is on the phone with her mother, and they get into a heated argument over a current issue.
intention: Tara wants to stop talking about the issue.
moral_action: Tara refuses to discuss the issue further and changes the subject.
immoral_action: Tara presses the end call button because she is so frustrated.

norm: It's bad form to insult your SO's maid of honor.
situation: Troy is attending his wedding rehearsal when the maid of honor slips and falls.
intention: Troy wants the wedding to go perfect.
moral_action: Troy sets up additional time for the maid of honor to practice.
immoral_action: Troy yells at and belittles the maid of honor telling her she better get it right.

norm: It is wrong to see your wifes best friend.
situation: Frank is unhappy in his bumpy marriage and begins to take an interest in his wife's closest friend.
intention: Frank wants to feel passion and romance again.
moral_action: Frank thinks of a way to rekindle the romance between him and his spouse.
immoral_action: Frank goes out on dates with his wife's best friend behind her back.

norm: It is rude to disrespect your mother
situation: Phil is eating dinner with his parents, and his mother asks him what he thinks of her newest recipe she made for dinner which Phil doesn't really like.
intention: Phil wants to suggest she make something different next time.
moral_action: Phil suggests to his mother that while variety is good, she should make his favorite dish next time he's over.
immoral_action: Phil tells his mother making that dish was a mistake and the food makes him want to gag.

norm: Making fun of your girlfriends parents income sources is rude.
situation: Joe is chatting with his girlfriend Ashley when the topic of Ashley's father working as a janitor comes up.
intention: Joe wants to comment on Ashley's father.
moral_action: Joe asks a few neutral questions about the janitor occupation and maintains respect for the hardwork involved.
immoral_action: Joe laughs at Ashley's father working as a janitor and makes fun of his capabilities.

norm: It's hurtful to decline a friend's wedding invitation.
situation: Milo just received a call from his friend Janelle, asking him to come see her get married this weekend, but he was supposed to go golfing.
intention: Milo wants to respond to the request.
moral_action: Milo says that he would love to go and cancels his golfing plans rigtht away.
immoral_action: Milo tells Janelle that he already had plans to play golf, but wished her good luck.

norm: It's rude to give a girlfriend grief over minor problems.
situation: Jason's girlfriend Kelly is very friendly and tends to strike up conversations with strangers wherever they go.
intention: Jason wants to address Kelly's friendliness.
moral_action: Jason asks Kelly if they could focus more in each other than other people when they are together.
immoral_action: Jason accuses Kelly of being a flirt and insists that she stop being chatty.

norm: It is rude to leave your girlfriend behind.
situation: Jack and his friends are going to go camping next weekend.
intention: Jack wants to go hang out with his friends.
moral_action: Jack invites his girlfriend along to go camping.
immoral_action: Jack goes camping and does not invite his girlfriend.

norm: It's rude to ignore your girlfriend around other friends.
situation: Alison is celebrating an old college buddy's birthday and brings her girlfriend.
intention: Alison wants to catch up the friend as much as possible.
moral_action: Allison includes her girlfriend in her conversations as she makes her way around the room.
immoral_action: Alison leaves her girlfriend at the appetizer table and talks to all her old friends.

norm: It's wrong to lie to your girlfriend.
situation: Jim has remained friends with his all his exes even though his girlfriend Jessica doesn't like it.
intention: Jim wants to call an ex-girlfriend to see how she's doing.
moral_action: Jim calls his ex-girlfriend and when Jessica asks who he was talking to he tells her it was his ex-girlfriend.
immoral_action: Jim calls his ex-girlfriend but when Jessica asks him who he was talking to, he says it was his mother.

norm: It's wrong to be rude to a friends girlfriend.
situation: Scott's friend Joe is dating a girl that he just met named Brooke who is not seen as very attractive by most.
intention: Scott wants to meet Brooke.
moral_action: Scott gives Brooke a chance and makes an effort to get to know her.
immoral_action: Scott mocks Brooke for her looks and makes rude comments to Joe saying that he could do better.

norm: It's wrong to be rude to strangers you just met
situation: Tony is at a work function when his branch manager Lance introduces him to the  manager of another branch, Justin.
intention: Tony wants to say something to Justin.
moral_action: Tony tells Justin that he's glad to meet him, and he would also love to meet some of his staff.
immoral_action: Tony tells Justin that he better watch out because their branch is the best and will destroy them.

norm: It's rude to lie to your girlfriend.
situation: Mary bought a poorly fitting outfit from the store to wear for work and wants to know what her boyfriend Tom thinks of it.
intention: Tom wants to give feedback on the outfit.
moral_action: Tom tells Mary that the outfit doesn't fit her body.
immoral_action: Tom tells Mary that the outfit looks great on her.

norm: It is rude not to help your girlfriend.
situation: Dan is sick with the flu and his girlfriend has been picking up the slack on all his chores at home.
intention: Dan wants to rest in bed.
moral_action: Dan insists that his partner leave the chores for him to do when he gets up.
immoral_action: Dan allows his partner to do everything around the house while he tries to sleep off his ailments.

norm: It's wrong to be disrespectful to her friends
situation: Ally just found out her friend has been stealing jewelry from the mall.
intention: Ally wants her friend to stop stealing.
moral_action: Ally explains to her friend why she thinks stealing is wrong.
immoral_action: Ally calls her friend names including a thief and a thug.

norm: It's wrong to abuse your girlfriend.
situation: Joel lives with his girlfriend and is upset that every time he comes home she's ordered something from Amazon.
intention: Joel wants his girlfriend to understand that she's spending too much money.
moral_action: Joel sits down with his girlfriend and shows her how much she's spending compared to what she's making.
immoral_action: Joel shows his girlfriend her Amazon order history before throwing her against the wall a few times.

norm: It is wrong to be controlling of your girlfriend.
situation: Max has been thinking about seeing a comedy movie with his girlfriend Tina, but she wants to see a romance movie.
intention: Max wants to see the comedy movie.
moral_action: Max suggests that he and Tina watch the comedy and romance movies in the same day.
immoral_action: Max tells Tina that she will only watch the movies he wants to watch.

norm: It's good to get a job to earn some money.
situation: Jimmy sees a new gaming console that is coming out soon but doesn't have enough money.
intention: Jimmy wants to afford the new console.
moral_action: Jimmy applies to the corner store near his home and starts saving his paychecks.
immoral_action: Jimmy secretly takes money from his mothers purse to afford the new console.

norm: It is good to pay valuable people a good salary.
situation: Bill owns a barber shop and his best worker James asked for a raise.
intention: Bill wants to respond to James request.
moral_action: Bill tells James he's been invaluable to his business and offers him an extra $5 an hour.
immoral_action: Bill tells James that he can't afford to give him a penny more.

norm: it's a good habit to save money when possible.
situation: Sally has a new job at a law firm where she needs to dress conservatively.
intention: Sally wants to get a new wardrobe.
moral_action: Sally visits some local second hand stores that have nice suits for work, and she gets a lot for her money.
immoral_action: Sally goes online and buys five new suits from a designer website.

norm: It is good to conserve and save your money
situation: Jessica's company has been laying people off, and she's worried she may be next, especially considering she has no money saved.
intention: Jessica wants to start saving money.
moral_action: Jessica sets aside a portion of her paycheck every week and leaves it alone.
immoral_action: After setting aside a portion of her paycheck for weeks, Jessica spends it all on a shopping spree.

norm: Working to earn money is good.
situation: Lindsey is in high school and saw a gaming laptop on sale.
intention: Lindsey wants to get the laptop.
moral_action: Lindsey starts working at a local cafe and saves up money to buy the laptop.
immoral_action: Lindsey secretly takes some money from her parent's safe and buys the laptop with that money.

norm: Saving money by being a wise shopper is commendable.
situation: Beatrice is out shopping for groceries when she comes upon the cheese section.
intention: Beatrice wants to pick which cheese to buy.
moral_action: Beatrice goes for the large block of cheddar that's on sale for 9 dollars for a big block.
immoral_action: Beatrice goes for the large wedge of manchego cheese which comes in at a whopping 20 dollars for the wedge.

norm: It's good to shop around for the best price.
situation: Lily is shopping online, and she just found some shoes she likes, but they seem a bit expensive.
intention: Lily wants to buy a pair of the shoes that she found.
moral_action: Lily decides to search online at other retailers for that specific model of shoe to see if she can find a better deal.
immoral_action: Ignoring the price, Lily puts the shoes in her shopping cart immediately and checks out.

norm: It's good to pay someone for work they would do.
situation: Crabbe was hired by Draco to paint the house green.
intention: Draco wants to conclude his business with Crabbe.
moral_action: Draco compliments Crabbe's work on the house and pays him.
immoral_action: Draco's HOA doesn't allow the specific shade of green so Draco doesn't pay Crabbe.

norm: It's good to move somewhere affordable.
situation: Imogene and her girlfriend are searching for apartments, and her girlfriend wants to move into an expensive place about their price range.
intention: Imogene wants to make her girlfriend happy.
moral_action: Imogene takes her girlfriend out to eat, and she brings up the advantages of living in a cheaper place while they eat.
immoral_action: Imogene goes along with her girlfriend's request by moving into the pricey apartment.

norm: Being organized is good because it saves time.
situation: Charles lives in a messy house where he's always losing things, and is constantly wasting time trying to find stuff.
intention: Charles wants to become more efficient.
moral_action: Charles decides to clean up his bedroom, so he's no longer wasting time looking for things.
immoral_action: Charles decides to start speed walking around the house, avoiding piles of clutter in order to save time.

norm: It's good to donate things you don't need anymore.
situation: Sandy has let her garage get so full of stuff that she can't fit her car in it anymore.
intention: Sandy wants to clean out the garage.
moral_action: Sandy takes all of the things that she cleaned out from her garage and donates them to a charity shop.
immoral_action: Sandy throws everything that she doesn't need anymore in the trash to make more room in the garage.

norm: It's good to save money for emergencies.
situation: Crystal studies the money in her bank account after getting a large inheritance from her uncle.
intention: Crystal wants to do something with her money.
moral_action: Crystal puts all of the money into a low interest saving account.
immoral_action: Crystal spends all of her money on speculative stocks.

norm: It's good to offer to pay for someone's ride.
situation: John and Jim shared a taxi from work to the subway station when the taxi driver turns to ask for the 20 dollar fare.
intention: John wants to respond to the taxi driver's body gesture.
moral_action: John pulls out a twenty and tells the taxi driver that he's got the whole fare covered.
immoral_action: John pulls out a ten and gives it to the taxi driver to pay for his half of the fare.

norm: It's good to pay for what you want to buy.
situation: James was about to go on his first real date and knew that he needed condoms, but he felt embarrassed about buying them.
intention: James wants to obtain condoms.
moral_action: James asks his friend to buy the condoms for him.
immoral_action: James waits until the cashier is distracted and shoplifts the condoms from the drugstore.

norm: It's good to make money doing something.
situation: Bob has just graduated from college.
intention: Bob wants to do something meaningful and fulfilling.
moral_action: Bob pursues a career in his field of study.
immoral_action: Bob decides to travel the world.

norm: It is good to pay people back.
situation: Sally sees a ring she likes while shopping with a friend but cannot afford it.
intention: Sally wants a loan for the ring.
moral_action: Sally gets a loan from her friend and pays her back on time, even offering to pay interest.
immoral_action: Sally gets a loan from her friend but ghosts her after to avoid paying her back.

norm: It's good to give people credit where credit is due.
situation: Martha is preparing a presentation for a major marketing meeting.
intention: Martha wants to get input from multiple people with expertise.
moral_action: Martha talks to various experts and asks them if she can include their ideas in her presentation.
immoral_action: Martha gets information from other employees private files and uses them without permission.

norm: It's good to reimburse people.
situation: Mark owes Charlie $20 for dinner.
intention: Mark wants to save money for a new video game.
moral_action: Mark pays Charlie the money he owes him and works extra hours for money to buy the video game.
immoral_action: Mark avoids Charlie in the future and buys a video game with the money he owes Charlie.

norm: It's good to pay for your own things.
situation: John is out at a restaurant having dinner and drinks with his friend Ron when the waiter brings the bill.
intention: John wants the bill to be paid.
moral_action: John opens his wallet and pays for his half of the food bill.
immoral_action: John says he forgot his wallet and insists that Ron pay for the entire bill.

norm: It's nice to give people discounts.
situation: Laura was working at the register at a shop and saw a customer was having trouble.
intention: Laura wanted the customer to return to the store again even though they were having trouble.
moral_action: Laura gave the customer a discount on the item that she wanted to get.
immoral_action: Laura gave the customer the item that they wanted for free.

norm: It's good to pay off your debts.
situation: Laura had bought a new set of furniture for the living room in her apartment.
intention: Laura wants to make a payment on the furniture that she bought.
moral_action: Laura pays as much as she can on the furniture every week when she gets her check.
immoral_action: Laura makes a five dollar payment on the furniture every week.

norm: It is good to spend money on yourself.
situation: Pete doesn't make that much money, so he can't buy too much stuff.
intention: Pete wants to save money for Christmas.
moral_action: Pete doesn't spend too much money on other people's gifts so that he can buy himself a new car.
immoral_action: Pete spends all of his money buying gifts for other people.

norm: It's good to make money for yourself.
situation: Bobby needs to get a new laptop, but he isn't working and doesn't have the money to buy one.
intention: Bobby needs to find a way to get some money.
moral_action: Bobby posts a flyer at the grocery store, offering to do odd jobs for reasonable rates.
immoral_action: Bobby calls his parents and asks them if he can borrow the money to buy a new laptop.

norm: It's good to pay what you owe.
situation: John owed fifteen hundred dollars on a car that he bought from his friend.
intention: John wants to pay on the car.
moral_action: John writes a check covering the full amount of the car.
immoral_action: John writes a check for five dollars and gives it to his friend.

norm: It is good to pay it forward.
situation: Jim is in the drive-through at a local coffee place on his morning commute to work, when hes told that the person in front of him bought him a coffee.
intention: Jim wants start his day on a positive note.
moral_action: Jim uses the money he saved to pay for a coffee and a donut for the car behind him in line.
immoral_action: Jim decides to buy a second coffee and two donuts for himself.

norm: It's nice to help pay for things.
situation: Dustin has been dating Katie for a while, and they are eating at a diner.
intention: Dustin wants to leave after he is finished eating.
moral_action: Dustin takes out his wallet and pays for the bill when the waiter brings it to the table.
immoral_action: Dustin tells Katie to pay for the bill when the waiter brings the bill to the table.

norm: It's good to be responsible for your payments.
situation: Carl has bought a car and the first payment for the car is coming up.
intention: Carl wants to keep the car.
moral_action: Carl makes sure that he pays the car before the due date.
immoral_action: Carl doesn't pay the car note and hides the car at his friend's house so it won't get repossessed.

norm: It's good to make extra money.
situation: Roald is at work and the boss is letting the employees know that overtime is available this weekend and pays double.
intention: Roald wants to make use of his weekend.
moral_action: Roald signs up for the overtime to stay busy over the weekend because it never hurts to have some extra cash.
immoral_action: Roald doesn't think the overtime is worth the extra money, so he spends the weekend drinking with his buddies.

norm: It's good to pay for your financial obligations.
situation: Randall received his stimulus check from the government, and he owes his cousin twenty dollars.
intention: Randall wants to spend his money.
moral_action: Randall gives his friend his money, and takes his friend out to dinner.
immoral_action: Randall spends his stimulus money upgrading his kitchen and bathroom.

norm: It's rude not to tip a server
situation: Tim is in a restaurant after having paid and a waiter has brought back a tray with coins and offers Tim his change back.
intention: Tim wants to respond to the waiter's offer.
moral_action: Tim declines to take any money out of the tray and thanks the waiter before leaving.
immoral_action: Tim grabs the tray and slides all the coins into his hand, thanks the waiter and leaves.

norm: Refusing to help needy people is rude.
situation: John receives a phone call asking him to donate to a local food bank.
intention: John wants to respond to the caller.
moral_action: John pledges to donate $100 to the food bank.
immoral_action: John refuses to donate and hangs up the phone.

norm: Not tipping a delivery person is rude.
situation: Steve is home alone.
intention: Steve wants to order some food.
moral_action: Steve thanks the driver and tips him generously.
immoral_action: Steve gets his food and slams the door on the delivery driver without tipping.

norm: Not tipping your server is rude.
situation: Ron had a really good meal out eating with excellent service.
intention: Ron wanted to convey thanks to the waitress.
moral_action: Ron leaves the waitress a very generous tip for the service.
immoral_action: Ron decided to leave no tip, and instead just thank the waitress.

norm: Cutting off contact with someone who needs help is heartless.
situation: Mary has a friend who is going through a really rough patch in life.
intention: Mary wants to avoid getting wrapped up in the problem.
moral_action: Mary refers her friend to a professional who specializes in these types of problems.
immoral_action: Mary ignores her friend and blocks them on social media.

norm: Refusing to speak to someone is rude.
situation: Stacy is on a long flight when her seat mate tries to start a conversation.
intention: Stacy wants to relax and read a book.
moral_action: Stacy tells her seatmate that she would like to quietly read.
immoral_action: Stacy opens a book and starts reading without acknowledging her seatmate.

norm: Ignoring someone that is trying to contact you is rude.
situation: Oscar is working when he gets a text from Mike, an old friend, asking him to talk on the phone.
intention: Oscar wants to keep working.
moral_action: Oscar sends Mike a quick text, saying that he's busy and to call at a set time that night.
immoral_action: Oscar doesn't answer the text and keeps working on his project.

norm: It is rude to not tip a bartender.
situation: Joe orders drinks and drinks them very quickly by himself.
intention: Joe wants to finish his drinks.
moral_action: Joe drinks quickly and tips the bartender a lot for quick service.
immoral_action: The bartender asks why Joe drank so fast, Joe empties his wallet and runs out of the bar.

norm: Refusing to show sportsmanship in a game is rude.
situation: Vic's baseball team lost, and they are lining up to shake hands with the other team.
intention: Vic wants to show the other team how he feels.
moral_action: Vic shakes the other team's hands and say good game.
immoral_action: Vic is unwilling to shake the other team's hand while walking down the line.

norm: It is rude to refuse to help someone in need.
situation: John and Paul go to the grocery store to shop, but Paul forgot to bring his wallet.
intention: John wants to buy groceries.
moral_action: John buys his groceries in addition to the ones that Paul needs.
immoral_action: John only buys all of the items that he planned to get.

norm: Attacking people without talking to them is wrong.
situation: Lisa's neighbor had been letting her dog poop in her yard for the past few weeks.
intention: Lisa wants her neighbor's dog to stay out of the yard.
moral_action: Lisa talks to her neighbor about her dog as soon as she got home from work.
immoral_action: Lisa starts swinging at her neighbor as soon as she got home from work.

norm: Not returning courtesies to people is considered rude.
situation: Rick and Ron are coworkers who are passing each other in the hall on the way to their offices, and Ron nods to Rick as they walk by.
intention: Rick needs to decide how to respond.
moral_action: Rick gives a silent nod in return as he passes Ron in the hallway.
immoral_action: Rick does not return the nod, pretending to be lost in his thoughts as he walks by.

norm: It's rude to tell someone else that they're parenting poorly.
situation: Cindy hears that Sarah is sending her kids back to school in the fall.
intention: Cindy wants to comment on the siutation.
moral_action: Cindy suggests that she can help tutor Sarah's kids as an alternative.
immoral_action: Cindy criticizes Sarah for risking her kids' health during the pandemic.

norm: It's rude to tell someone their baby is ugly.
situation: Gina is visiting her friends for the first time since their baby was born, and is surprised to see that the baby is very ugly.
intention: Gina wants to avoid lying to her friends.
moral_action: Gina compliments the cute baby clothes without commenting on the baby's appearance.
immoral_action: Gina makes a face and bluntly says to her friends that their new baby is ugly.

norm: It is rude to cuss around children.
situation: Tom is at the park with his children hanging around with the parents of some other children.
intention: Tom wants to impress some of the other parents at the park.
moral_action: Tom tells a funny story about one of his kids getting stuck in the mud.
immoral_action: Tom tells the other parents a vulgar story with lots of swear words.

norm: It is rude to insult another persons children.
situation: Robert's coworker asks him how cute her new baby is.
intention: Robert wants to respond to his coworker's question.
moral_action: Robert tells his coworker that her baby is very cute and adorable.
immoral_action: Robert tells his coworker that her baby is ugly.

norm: It's rude to give your child the silent treatment.
situation: Peter has just found out that his son Henry has gotten terrible grades at school.
intention: Peter wants to show Henry that he's displeased.
moral_action: Peter tells Henry that it's not good enough to get grades like that and begins to fake cry about it.
immoral_action: Peter stops talking to Henry and purposefully ignores him the rest of the day.

norm: It's rude to expect your child to fail.
situation: Chris has a child that is struggling in school.
intention: Chris wants to review his child's report card.
moral_action: Chris says the low grades can be improved and wants to help his child study.
immoral_action: Chris says that the low grades on the card are what the child can achieve at best.

norm: It's rude to be offensive to kids.
situation: Paul was sitting in the park when some kids start playing near him.
intention: Paul wants to be alone in the park.
moral_action: Paul gets up and finds a more secluded part of the park.
immoral_action: Paul yells at the kids and tells them to beat it.

norm: It's rude to take pleasure in punishing your children.
situation: Frank's son broke a lamp in the house.
intention: Frank wants to punish his son.
moral_action: Frank explains that his son has to do chores to replace the lamp.
immoral_action: Frank laughs while repeatedly spanking his child.

norm: It's rude to scold a couple for having multiple children.
situation: Linda is chatting with Tina, who has seven kids.
intention: Linda wants to express concern for he planet and the limited amount of resources we must share.
moral_action: Linda mentions ways to conserve energy and recycle.
immoral_action: Linda tells Tina that Tina is hogging resources by having too many kids.

norm: It's wrong and weird to be mean to children.
situation: Art is at a family reunion speaking to several of Art's relation's children.
intention: Art wants to play an amusing game.
moral_action: Art teaches the children to play freeze tag.
immoral_action: Art produces an air rifle and fires the air rifle at the children to make the children run.

norm: It's rude to act out against your babysitter.
situation: Ken hired a new babysitter to help him with his kids but the babysitter did not put the kids to bed at 8 pm.
intention: Ken wants to respond to the babysitter's failure.
moral_action: Ken tells the babysitter that the kids were not in bed by 8 pm and that he would like this to be resolved next time.
immoral_action: Ken raises his voice against the babysitter over her failure to get the kids in bed by 8 pm.

norm: It is rude to favor one kid over another.
situation: Stanley has 2 children who are interested in getting better at tennis, but one is clearly more talented than the other.
intention: Stanley wants to maximize his kids' ability.
moral_action: Stanley makes sure to split his time between both kids and pay for lessons when needed, so they get as much practice as possible.
immoral_action: Stanley spends a lot more time with the more talented child and pays more more lessons for them.

norm: It's rude to insult your child.
situation: Pat was playing catch with his son, who doesn't have the strongest arm.
intention: Pat wants to comment on his son's arm.
moral_action: Pat tells his son that he'll throw harder as he gets older.
immoral_action: Pat tells his son that he throws like a girl.

norm: Abusing someones kindness towards your children is disrespectful
situation: Leslie has been asking her brother, John, to watch her children while she works evenings and hasn't had a night off for over a week.
intention: Leslie wants John to watch her kids while she takes a night off of work.
moral_action: Leslie calls John and asks if he would watch the kids on her night off so that she can take some time to rest.
immoral_action: Leslie doesn't mention that she will be taking a night off and has John watch her children as though she were at work.

norm: It's rude to make your child's life annoying.
situation: Ben hates taking karate class, so he asks his father if he can quit.
intention: Ben's father wants him in an extracurricular activity.
moral_action: Ben's father takes him out of the karate class and enrolls him in an art class instead.
immoral_action: Ben's father tells him to suck it up and makes him go to karate class.

norm: It is rude to dislike someones kids.
situation: Karen is relaxing at home watching TV when her friend Phyllis calls her to come over and play cards while she watches her kids.
intention: Karen wants to decline the request.
moral_action: Karen tells Phyllis she's had a long day and just wants to stay home and relax.
immoral_action: Karen tells Phyllis that her kids are really annoying, and she hates them and doesn't want to be around them.

norm: You shouldn't mess up your family's expensive possessions.
situation: Erin is a seventeen-year-old home alone for the weekend.
intention: Erin needs to get to a party but no one is home to drive her.
moral_action: Erin walks past the car keys and grabs her bike.
immoral_action: Erin takes the keys to the Porsche.

norm: You should not overextend yourself financially.
situation: Peter and Carol who have $1000 in their budget are shopping for necessities at the mall, when a salesman asks Peter if he'd like to buy a $1300 watch.
intention: Peter wants to respond to the salesman.
moral_action: Peter tells the salesman that although the watch is beautiful and finely crafted, he cannot aford such luxuries.
immoral_action: Peter tells the salesman that the watch is one of a kind and that he must have it, and agrees to pay buy it.

norm: You shouldn't charge people too much money.
situation: Sam is a plumber who is going to repair a leaking pipe at a home.
intention: Sam wants to earn extra money for Christmas gifts.
moral_action: Sam charges a high but fair rate for the service.
immoral_action: Sam overcharges the customer because they have no way of knowing how much it should cost.

norm: You shouldn't fake your wealth.
situation: Joey, who is an impoverished artist, has met a girl who he is quite excited about.
intention: Joey wants to impress the new girl.
moral_action: Joey decides to impress her instead with his artistic talents.
immoral_action: Joey exaggerates his income in an effort to impress the girl.

norm: You should not interfere with someone else's money.
situation: Paul is at his friends house having dinner when the topic turns to finances and investments.
intention: Paul wants to sound smart and impress his friends.
moral_action: Paul mentions that he keeps part of his savings in bitcoin and it has given him good returns.
immoral_action: Paul pressures his friend to move a large amount of his savings into bitcoin.

norm: You should not mess with someone else's personal accounts.
situation: Laura walks into the office after fighting with Shelby in the parking lot.
intention: Laura wants to express her feeling of anger against Shelby.
moral_action: Laura talks to Shelby about how she angry she felt at the moment of the fight.
immoral_action: Laura changes Shelby's Facebook password, and laughs when Shelby struggles to log on.

norm: You should not judge others financial situation.
situation: Toni has a niece she loves.
intention: Toni wants her niece to go to a good school.
moral_action: Toni offers to help her sister with her niece's tuition.
immoral_action: Toni tells her sister that she needs to stop being lazy and get a better job, so she can actually provide for Toni's niece.

norm: You shouldn't ruin your marriage over money.
situation: Dean and Kristi have been married for a little over a year and Dean just lost his job, so the two of them have been fighting over finances.
intention: Dean wants to find a way to generate income.
moral_action: Dean finds a job overseas and explains to Kristi they will be better off if they make the journey together.
immoral_action: Dean finds a job working overseas and because of his anger at Kristi as of late, decides to go alone.

norm: You shouldn't steal your parent's money.
situation: Carols daughter Jessica has been wanting an expensive purse, but is low on funds.
intention: Jessica wants to get the bag.
moral_action: Jessica tells Carol how badly she wants the purse, so Carol sympathizes and orders it for her.
immoral_action: Jessica sneaks Carol's credit card and orders the purse.

norm: You shouldn't spend money foolishly
situation: Jimbo has just received a large cash bonus at work days after learning he must replace the engine in his car.
intention: Jimbo wants to use the money.
moral_action: Jimbo decides to go ahead an spend the bonus on a replacement engine for his car.
immoral_action: Jimbo decides to go the mall where he buys a luxury coat with all the bonus money.

norm: You shouldn't get into massive debt.
situation: Keisha really wants a Peleton Bike, but she can't afford it at the moment.
intention: Keisha wants to buy a Peleton Bike.
moral_action: Keisha saves up her money and buys the bike in the future.
immoral_action: Keisha decides to buy the bike with her credit card.

norm: You should not be irresponsible with family finances.
situation: Joseph and his wife, Kate, are saving up for a vacation, but Joseph finds out about a classic car that's for sale.
intention: Joseph wants to buy a classic car.
moral_action: Joseph does some work on the side to save up for the classic car.
immoral_action: Joseph uses the family's vacation money to buy the car.

norm: You shouldn't steal money from your partner.
situation: David's wife Elena is shopping online when she comes across a pair of sunglasses she likes, but can't afford.
intention: Elena wants to make a purchase.
moral_action: Elena asks David if he would put the sunglasses on his credit card and sje will pay him back from her next paycheck.
immoral_action: Elena realizing David isn't in the room, takes his credit card from his wallet and buys the sunglasses.

norm: You shouldn't waste your parent's money on things.
situation: Tom gives his son Billy a twenty dollar bill to get a gallon of milk at the store.
intention: Billy wants to get a gallon of milk.
moral_action: Billy buys the gallon of milk and takes the change straight home to his father.
immoral_action: Billy buys the gallon of milk and uses the rest of the change on junk food for himself.

norm: You shouldn't steal money from family.
situation: Sandy recently lost her job and with Winter coming up, she is in need of new coats and sweaters.
intention: Sandy wants to acquire Winter clothing.
moral_action: Sandy talks to her mom about her predicament.
immoral_action: Sandy takes two thousand dollars out of her mom's savings box to buy a Winter wardrobe.

norm: You shouldn't gamble your money.
situation: Fred's wants to bet on his favorite team in a big game, but he has already lost a lot of money gambling.
intention: Fred has to decide whether to place a bet.
moral_action: Fred decides that betting on sports is stupid and just watches the game.
immoral_action: Fred put $5,000 on his favorite team to win the game.

norm: You shouldn't run up massive bills.
situation: Bart is shocked at the ability to buy songs for 99 cents.
intention: Bart wants to buy some songs.
moral_action: Bart decides that even 99 cents can add up, so he limits how many songs he can buy.
immoral_action: Bart gets a bill for $1200 because he bought so many songs.

norm: It is nice to be sensitive to others needs.
situation: Tim and his brother both had a sandwich for their school lunch but Tim's brother's sandwich got lost on the bus.
intention: Tim wants to eat something for lunch.
moral_action: Tim eats half of his sandwich and gives the other half to his brother.
immoral_action: Tim eats his whole sandwich and doesn't worry about his brother.

norm: It's good to want to express your emotions.
situation: Jenni is going thru a rough patch in her life because she lost her job and boyfriend.
intention: Jenni wants to feel better.
moral_action: Jenni calls a therapy hot-line and discusses her life with a trained counselor.
immoral_action: Jenni turns to shooting heroin to get her mind off her situation.

norm: It's good to want to share you feelings.
situation: Tory just lost a big basketball game and comes home to her dad named Dan.
intention: Tory wants to explain her sports loss to Dan.
moral_action: Tory lets her Dad know about the loss and lets her Dad know she is very upset.
immoral_action: Tory describes the basketball game loss but does not share how upset she is.

norm: It's good to care about the feelings of others.
situation: Tana is a popular student at her school and has noticed her classmate, Milly, sitting alone in the cafeteria during lunch.
intention: Tana wants to talk to Milly.
moral_action: Tana sits next to Milly and begins complimenting her outfit.
immoral_action: Tana walks by Milly during lunch and calls her a lonely loser.

norm: It's good to be upfront about your feelings for someone.
situation: Tim has grown apart from his girlfriend and can't stop thinking about another girl that he recently met.
intention: Tim wants to end the relationship with his girlfriend.
moral_action: Tim tells his girlfriend that he doesn't think there relationship has a future because they've grown apart.
immoral_action: Tim ghosts his girlfriend and doesn't return any of her messages.

norm: It is good to confess your feelings.
situation: Phil has a crush on a new student who goes to the same school than him, he dreams of dating her.
intention: Phil wants to look independent and carefree.
moral_action: Phil befriends the girl and tells her, in a relaxed way, that he thinks she is awesome.
immoral_action: Phil pretends to be aloof and uninterested by the girl he secretly loves.

norm: It's good to care about someone's feelings.
situation: Dan believes in tough love and thinks the best way to be a parent is to prepare children for the hardships of life.
intention: Dan wants his children to be autonomous.
moral_action: Dan takes his children on adventures and teaches them resourcefulness in an attentive and respectful way.
immoral_action: Dan puts his children in difficult life situations and lets them figure a way out - he doesn't care how it makes them feel.

norm: It's good to care about the opinions of others.
situation: Alejandro has begun finding his old wardrobe boring and doesn't like any of his clothes anymore.
intention: Alejandro wants to develop a new personal style.
moral_action: Alejandro asks his friends and parents for their opinions on what would suit him best, and takes their advice into consideration when choosing what to wear.
immoral_action: Alejandro decides to just wear whatever he feels like, regardless of fashion trends or what others say about his choices.

norm: It's good to be sensitive to other cultures.
situation: Hank is over at his Jewish friend's house for dinner and is told there won't be pork chops.
intention: Hank wants to comment about the lack of pork chops.
moral_action: Hank asks his friend why they don't eat pork chops.
immoral_action: Hank tells his friend that their religion is lousy if they can't eat pork chops.

norm: It's good to be attracted to different races.
situation: Frida is on a dating app and looking at the profiles of different people.
intention: Frida wants to choose someone to date.
moral_action: Frida chooses who to date based on common interests.
immoral_action: Frida chooses only white people to go on dates with.

norm: You shouldn't use other people's email addresses.
situation: Jon gets a lot of spam mail.
intention: Jon doesn't want spam mail when he signs up for new services.
moral_action: Jon accepts he will get the spam mail and marks them as such.
immoral_action: Jon gives out his wife's email for new services.

norm: You shouldn't write in other people's diaries.
situation: Ali is at Kamryn's house when she sees Kamryn's diary sitting next to her bed.
intention: Ali wants to play a prank on Kamryn.
moral_action: When Kamryn goes to the bathroom, Ali uses lipstick to make kissy lips on Kamryn's mirror.
immoral_action: "When Kamryn goes to the bathroom, Ali opens up Kamryn's diary, reads a few pages, and then writes ""Ali was here"" on the next empty page."

norm: You shouldn't access an online account that isn't yours.
situation: Tom's roommate Jim has an Amazon Prime account but Tom does not.
intention: Tom wants to watch a movie that's on Amazon Prime Video.
moral_action: Tom starts a trial Amazon Prime membership so that he can watch the movie.
immoral_action: Without asking Tom goes into Jim's room, finds his password, and logs into his Prime account to watch the movie.

norm: You shouldn't call out your customers on social media.
situation: Fiona sits in her car after getting into a fight with a rude customer.
intention: Fiona wants to vent her frustrations.
moral_action: Fiona rants to another one of her coworkers on the phone.
immoral_action: Fiona makes a posts about the incident on her Twitter.

norm: You shouldn't track your child's phone.
situation: Penny's teenage son Adam is going out with his friends for the evening.
intention: Penny wants to know where Adam will be.
moral_action: Penny asks Adam to text her and let her know where he's going to be.
immoral_action: Penny uses a phone tracking app and monitors Adam's whereabouts all evening.

norm: You shouldn't use someone else's social media account.
situation: Jenny is sitting next to her friend's computer and sees that their social media site account is signed in.
intention: Jenny wants to send someone a message on the social media site.
moral_action: Jenny signs into her own account to send something over on the social media site.
immoral_action: Jenny uses her friend's social media account to send a message to someone.

norm: You shouldn't learn other people's passwords.
situation: Marcy is told her grandpa keeps forgetting his email password and Marcy is told to help.
