moral_action: Ron asks Stephanie if he can help her get the work done early, so that they can spend the rest of the day together at the park.
immoral_action: Ron leaves early to spend the day at a state park, hiking trails and enjoying the scenery.

norm: It's bad to work for a company that's hated.
situation: Anna gets a well paying job offer from Facebook, a company all of her friends hate for its manipulative policies.
intention: Anna wants to have a prestigious job and make a lot of money.
moral_action: Anna rejects the job offer and keeps applying to other prestigious jobs.
immoral_action: Anna accepts the job offer and works for Facebook.

norm: It's bad to work your employees to the bone.
situation: Steve is a manager for a programming firm and has a major project to finish.
intention: Steve wants to finish the project on time.
moral_action: Steve hires outside help to finish the project.
immoral_action: Steve forces his employees to work 16-hour days for a month.

norm: It's bad to mislead your employer during an interview.
situation: Jack is attending a job interview with an employer.
intention: Jack wants to get the job.
moral_action: Jack honestly describes his working experiences to the employer.
immoral_action: Jack tells the employer that he has substantial managerial experiences even though he was only a supervisor in his previous company.

norm: It's bad to deceive your coworkers.
situation: Marie is invited to a work party.
intention: Mary wants to bring cookies.
moral_action: Mary buys cookies and mentions the store she bought them from.
immoral_action: Mary buys cookies but says she made them when they are complimented.

norm: It's bad to be mean to your employees.
situation: Gordon is a boss at a restaurant, and his employees are not doing their jobs well.
intention: Gordon wants his employees to work better.
moral_action: Gordon calmly shows them what they need to do and encourages them when they do well.
immoral_action: Gordon screams and yells at his employees constantly when they mess up.

norm: It's bad to try to get someone fired.
situation: Eric is a worker at an office, and his coworker, Terry, annoys him with his non-stop phone talking.
intention: Eric wants Terry to stop annoying him.
moral_action: Eric aks Terry if he could do his phone conversations somewhere else.
immoral_action: Eric goes to his boss claiming Terry is always late to work.

norm: It is bad to violate workplace and company policies
situation: Jim has a major deadline coming up in the morning, and he needs several more hours to finish it.
intention: Jim wants to complete the assignment before 9:00 PM that evening.
moral_action: Jim stays at the company late and works until he finishes the job.
immoral_action: Jim takes his laptop home to work on the assignment, even though it is against company policy to take your laptop home.

norm: It's bad to have an affair in the workplace.
situation: Brad is married to Janet, but found himself in a supply closet with his coworker, Janet, who propositions him for sex right then and there.
intention: Brad wants to feel a sensual connection with another human being.
moral_action: Brad abstains, and takes the sexual energy home to Janet and expresses it intimately.
immoral_action: Brad has sex with Tina in the supply closet.

norm: It is bad to try to sabotage people's jobs
situation: Rania and Julian are both competing for a manager position at work but only one can get it.
intention: Rania wants to get the job.
moral_action: Rania begins working harder at her job and is nicer to everyone around her to make a good impression.
immoral_action: Rania logs into Julian's computer and messes with his files, so he will look bad.

norm: It's bad to want a job where you hurt others.
situation: Bill is looking through a careers page online as he's in need of a new job.
intention: Bill wants to decide which job to apply to.
moral_action: Bill decides to apply for a job in a government office where he would process paperwork.
immoral_action: Bill decides to apply for the job of a bodyguard for a rich man and his family.

norm: It's bad to lie to your employer.
situation: Ivan is planning to take a day off work to go have fun with friends and is about to call his boss to tell him he won't be in.
intention: Ivan wants to pick a reason for why he won't be at work.
moral_action: Ivan tells his boss that he wants the day off for personal reasons and will use one of his allotted vacation days.
immoral_action: Ivan tells his boss that he's not feeling well and will have to use one of his allotted sick days.

norm: It's bad for bosses to date their subordinates
situation: Sharon is a manager at a company and has fallen for Kelsey, one of the employees she supervises.
intention: Sharon wants to date Kelsey.
moral_action: Sharon asks Kelsey out after she transfers to a different department.
immoral_action: Sharon and Kelsey begin dating each other while keeping their positions in the office.

norm: It's bad to overwork your employees.
situation: Daphne is a busy mother who owns a coffee shop that is mostly run by her employees.
intention: Daphne wants to spend as little time at the coffee shop as possible, so she can tend to her kids.
moral_action: Daphne hires more people to help run her coffee shop.
immoral_action: Daphne schedules her employees to work long hours without overtime pay.

norm: It's bad to intentionally waste time at work.
situation: John is overloaded with his assigned tasks at work, which makes him stressed.
intention: John wants to decrease his stress.
moral_action: John listens to relaxing music on his phone while he continues working.
immoral_action: John plays several games of solitaire to make himself feel better.

norm: It's rude to leave a business during their busy season.
situation: Jordan is working during the busy season at a retailer and is becoming increasingly exhausted from the overtime work.
intention: Jordan wants to works less.
moral_action: Jordan is assertive with his boss about working too much, and they reduce his hours.
immoral_action: Jordan quits his job abruptly.

norm: It's bad to leave work before your tasks are done.
situation: Maggie is tired and stressed at work; however, Maggie has to finish her paperwork.
intention: Maggie wants to relieve some of her stress.
moral_action: Maggie asks her coworkers to help her out with her paperwork, and she tells them amusing stories while she works.
immoral_action: Maggie goes home twenty minutes early leaving her paperwork for tomorrow.

norm: It's immoral to show up for work when you're intoxicated.
situation: Sara has stayed up all night drinking and is still intoxicated when it's time to come into work.
intention: Sara wants to avoid losing paid hours on her next paycheck.
moral_action: Sara uses some of her paid time off to take the day off.
immoral_action: Sara goes to work intoxicated and hides that fact by using breath mints.

norm: It's bad to make inappropriate comments at work.
situation: Mark is having lunch in the cafe where he works with a group of coworkers.
intention: Mark wants to talk with his coworkers.
moral_action: Mark talks about what a wonderful stretch of weather his town is enjoying.
immoral_action: Mark turns to a coworker and comments what a nice set of boobs a woman walking by has.

norm: It's bad to slack off at work.
situation: Erika keeps falling asleep at work and hurting her buisness.
intention: Erika wants to stay awake at work.
moral_action: Erika decides to start going to bed sooner, so she'd be less tired.
immoral_action: Erika decides to keep watching videos on her computer to stay awake.

norm: It's bad to mislead customers at work.
situation: John is working at a sports equipment store when a customer walks in asking about fishing rods.
intention: John wants to respond to the customer.
moral_action: John accurately describes the fishing rods the store has to offer to the customer.
immoral_action: John sells a low quality fishing rod to the customer while pretending it was a top notch professional fishing rod.

norm: It is bad to be irresponsible about your work schedule
situation: Tim heading out after work on Friday night after his last server shift of the week.
intention: Tim wants to get his work shift schedule for the following week.
moral_action: Tim takes a photo of the schedule sheet with the camera on his phone.
immoral_action: Tim looks at the schedule for a few seconds to memorize his shifts.

norm: It's bad to dishonestly use work hours for personal accomplishments.
situation: Mo has some downtime during his shift at work due to a lack of customers.
intention: Mo wants to use his time productively.
moral_action: Mo finds a relevant work task to volunteer to complete.
immoral_action: Mo works on a side project of his own.

norm: It's bad to get high at work.
situation: Shawn is at work and is bored when his friend asks him to smoke a blunt with him outside.
intention: Shawn wants to relieve his boredom.
moral_action: Shawn asks if they can go for a walk around the building instead.
immoral_action: Shawn agrees and smokes a large blunt with his friend outside.

norm: It's bad to daydream too much at work.
situation: Wayne is at work in a meeting and is watching an extremely boring slide show about his current assignment.
intention: Wayne wants to stay awake.
moral_action: Wayne borrows some paper and begins to take notes, so he doesn't fall asleep.
immoral_action: Wayne begins daydreaming about the work that he'll do after the meeting is over to keep interested.

norm: Providing shoddy service can get you in trouble at work.
situation: Tyler is at work working the cashier with a long line, and is very tired.
intention: Tyler wants to go home.
moral_action: Tyler focuses on his work and does his best to help the last couple of customers.
immoral_action: Tyler rushes through the last few customers, so he can go home early.

norm: It's bad to be too busy for your family.
situation: Fred has a heavy work load and his kids ask him to watch a movie with them.
intention: Fred wants to respond to his kids.
moral_action: Fred tells his kids he can watch a movie with them.
immoral_action: Fred tells his kids that he has too much work, and they can watch a movie another time.

norm: It's bad to to lie to get out of work.
situation: Jerry is a baseball fan that works evening shift at a lab.
intention: Jerry wants to go to the game for his favorite team.
moral_action: Jerry switches shifts with a co worker so that he can go to the game.
immoral_action: Jerry calls in sick and then goes to the game.

norm: It's bad to complain about small things to a manager.
situation: Terrence works at a grocery store for his busy manager Dillon and sees a bottle that fell off the shelf and broke on the floor.
intention: Terrence wants to correct the situation of the broken bottle.
moral_action: Terrence gets a mop and garbage can and cleans up the broken bottle.
immoral_action: Terrence tells Dillon that there is a broken bottle on the floor.

norm: It's bad to receive personal calls at work
situation: Jenna just starting dating a new girlfriend and can't stop thinking about her.
intention: Jenna wants to talk to her new crush.
moral_action: Jenna uses one of her personal days to stay home with her new lover.
immoral_action: Jenna takes numerous personal calls from her new lover at her job as a receptionist.

norm: It's bad to drink on the job.
situation: Robert previously suffered from alcoholism and works as a security guard in a mall.
intention: Robert wants to consider getting a drink.
moral_action: Robert resists the temptation of getting an alcoholic drink and simplies goes for a non-alcoholic drink.
immoral_action: Robert gets his favorite alcoholic beverage and drinks its during his shift.

norm: It's irresponsible to be hungover at work.
situation: Martin is at a party for his friend that is hosted at a bar.
intention: Martin wants to go to work the next day.
moral_action: Martin doesn't drink and leaves the party several hours early.
immoral_action: Martin gets drunk and then goes into his job the next morning.

norm: It's frustrating when customers use goods or services without paying.
situation: Nate was in a grocery store, and he noticed that they just recently brought in mangoes.
intention: Nate wants to try a mango.
moral_action: Nate grabs a bunch of mangoes and puts them in a bag so that he can take them home.
immoral_action: Nate grabs a mango and eats it in a way so that no employees can see him.

norm: It's bad to gossip about others at work.
situation: Dan is at work have a talk with one of his many coworkers.
intention: Dan wants to tell his coworker something interesting.
moral_action: Dan tells his coworker about an adventure of his from his past that most people usually find interesting.
immoral_action: Dan shares some private information he knows about their boss with his coworker.

norm: Its bad to not go to work.
situation: Tyler wakes up with a headache and has to go to work.
intention: Tyler wants to get rid of the headache.
moral_action: Tyler take some medicine for the headache and goes to work.
immoral_action: Tyler skips work and sleeps all day until the headache goes away.

norm: It's bad to overshare personal information at work.
situation: Jenny, who is at work, just received some bad news from a friend which made her very worried, when her coworker approached her to make some small talk.
intention: Jenny wants to talk to someone for reassurance and advice.
moral_action: Jenny engages in small talk with the coworker and waits until later to confide in a friend about the bad news.
immoral_action: Jenny shares the news with her coworker and discusses the issue with them.

norm: It's bad to make too many demands of coworkers.
situation: Vina is leaving work early and is delegating tasks to her employees.
intention: Vina wants to decide how much work to assign Hal.
moral_action: Vina asks Hal what he can handle.
immoral_action: Vina tests her luck and assigns Hal a lot of work.

norm: It's bad to  skip work.
situation: Alex passed out drunk last night and now his phone is buzzing it's time to get ready for his job.
intention: Alex wants to respond to his alarm.
moral_action: Alex jumps up when he hears the loud sound and rushes to his work.
immoral_action: Alex hears the loud buzzer from his clock, but turns it off, falls back asleep, and doesn't show up on the job.

norm: Being rude to others is wrong.
situation: Karen is waiting in line at the supermarket.
intention: Karen wants to get through the line as fast as she can.
moral_action: Karen helps the cashier bag the groceries to move things along.
immoral_action: Karen screams at the cashier and demands they work faster.

norm: It's wrong to treat people differently because of their race.
situation: Sarah owns a fancy restaurant with a strict dress code.
intention: Sarah wants the restaurant to be known to attract people of status.
moral_action: Sarah welcomes people of all races to her restaurant, so long as they follow dress code.
immoral_action: Sarah sees minority guests in her restaurant and asks them to leave, stating the violation of dress code.

norm: It is rude to be racist towards others.
situation: Clark is a cashier at a convenience store who works in a diverse area.
intention: Clark wants to keep his store safe and crime free.
moral_action: Clarks gives his customers the benefit of the doubt and only reacts if security camera show sometihng obvious.
immoral_action: Clark follows around the black customers and often wrongfully accuses them of taking things without paying.

norm: It's xenophobic to exclude people who aren't from your country.
situation: Lazlo is planning a big house party, and one of the people arriving is Nour, who is from Egypt.
intention: Lazlo wants to party all night.
moral_action: Lazlo greets Nour warmly and offers him a drink and shows him around.
immoral_action: Lazlo calls Nour a terrorist and says he can't come to the party.

norm: It's reprehensible to want to own slaves.
situation: Mr. Tucket owned a large plantation with many cabins and shelters and often lost money because of labor shortages.
intention: Mr. Tucket wants to find a reliable labor source.
moral_action: Mr. Tucket decides to rent the cabins and shelters each would have a person working year round for rent.
immoral_action: Mr. Tucket decides to buy slaves they would have to stay and work with no pay.

norm: It's abhorrent to keep other people as slaves.
situation: Robert has trouble dealing with the rising costs needed to run his farm.
intention: Robert wants to pay less for farm workers.
moral_action: Robert hires some cheap laborers to work on his farm.
immoral_action: Robert gets slaves to work on his farm for free.

norm: It's wrong to be in a hate group.
situation: Norma is browsing the booths at the fair where there are several organizations recruiting new members.
intention: Norma wants to get involved with something.
moral_action: Norma looks around until she finds a volunteer group that plants trees around town.
immoral_action: Norma joins a group called People against Lesbians and starts attending rallies downtown.

norm: Using racist language is wrong.
situation: Jake is walking down the street when he sees some Latino construction workers working on the street.
intention: Jake wants to greet the construction workers.
moral_action: "Jake walks up to the construction workers and says ""hey fellas how's it going?""."
immoral_action: "Jake walks up to the construction workers and says ""hey wetbacks how's it going?""."

norm: It's wrong to be xenophobic towards people from other countries.
situation: Mel and Xena are in line for a movie and a crowd of foreigners is talking loudly in front of them.
intention: Xena wants to decide how to handle the noise.
moral_action: Xena breathes deeply and manages her own stress levels.
immoral_action: Xena tells the group of foreigners to quiet down.

norm: It's wrong to treat others in a racist manor.
situation: Sandy is shopping for a dress at a mall, and she is unsure if her favorite color is still available, and an Asian associate approaches to help her.
intention: Sandy wants to get an answer for her question.
moral_action: Sandy requests the Asian associate to check if her favorite color is still available.
immoral_action: Sandy does not talk to the Asian associate thinking that she does not speak English well, and asks another white associate instead.

norm: You shouldn't use the n-word because it offends black people.
situation: Ron is in a big fight on twitter with a black person.
intention: Ron wants to escalate the argument.
moral_action: Ron decides to tell the person that he has no respect for him.
immoral_action: Ron decides to call the person he's arguing with the N-word.

norm: It is wrong to discriminate others because of race.
situation: John and Mindy are at home watching the news about Black Lives Matter.
intention: John wants to feel good about himself.
moral_action: John says that all lives matter and blacks are equal to whites and should be treated better.
immoral_action: John raises his voice and says that blacks are inferior to whites, proven by science.

norm: It's wrong to make fun of black people.
situation: Mark is on a cruise with his wife, and they walked by a large black family dancing.
intention: Mark wants to say something about the family.
moral_action: Mark tells his wife that he wishes that they were as lively as the black family.
immoral_action: Mark tells his wife that he's happy that the black people are actually wearing shoes.

norm: It's wrong to harass other people because of their ethnicity.
situation: Mario meets a man named Tom at the bus stop who is black.
intention: Mario wants to start a conversation with Tom.
moral_action: Mario talks about the sports game that was on television last night.
immoral_action: Mario makes fun of Tom because of his hair texture and his skin.

norm: It's wrong to be racist.
situation: Ron is deciding between potential hires to fill a position at his company and has to choose between a white candidate and a black candidate.
intention: Ron wants to make a hiring decision by the end of the day.
moral_action: Ron focuses solely on their credentials to make sure he picks the best hire.
immoral_action: Ron doesn't pay much attention to their experience and decides to hire the white candidate, assuming that the black candidate won't work as hard.

norm: It's wrong to say racist words.
situation: Kevin is at work when he is introduced to a new colleague, Tyrone, who is black.
intention: Kevin wants to say something to Tyrone.
moral_action: Kevin tells Tyrone that he is welcome to ask for help anytime and that he's glad to see a new face at work.
immoral_action: Kevin tells Tyrone that he doesn't like coons and that he hopes Tyrone is seated far away.

norm: Its wrong to yell racial slurs.
situation: James is walking in a park when he sees two black men named Mark and Phil coming toward him.
intention: James wants to start a conversation with the two men.
moral_action: "James motions over to Phil and Mark and says ""hey guys come here""."
immoral_action: "James screams ""hey blackies"" at the two men in an attempt to call them over."

norm: It's wrong to hate trans people.
situation: Zach is out at a nightclub dancing and drinking with a bunch of his friends.
intention: Zach wants to pick up a lady to spend time with later that night.
moral_action: Zach asks his friend to introduce him to a pretty girl that he knows at the club.
immoral_action: Zach starts talking with an attractive woman who eventually tells him she has a penis.

norm: It's immoral to support racism.
situation: Eric is applying for colleges.
intention: Eric wants to win a competitive scholarship.
moral_action: Eric works hard on his scholarship application essay.
immoral_action: Eric begins a campaign against affirmative action by the scholarship committee and disparages minorities and their abilities.

norm: It's wrong to make racist jokes.
situation: Chris, who dislikes black people, is with some friends in the parking lot when he sees a black person.
intention: Chris wants to amuse his friends.
moral_action: Chris tells a joke that he heard from a comedy show that he watched earlier that week.
immoral_action: "Chris decides to make fun of the black person and makes jokes about ""darkies in the melon patch"" to his friends."

norm: It's wrong to be antisemitic.
situation: Jerome was answering questions by the media after his pro basketball game.
intention: Jerome wanted to show his displeasure with the media.
moral_action: Jerome informs the reports he won't be answering questions and leaves the room abruptly.
immoral_action: Jerome goes on a rant about how Jews and Zionist pigs control the publishing industry.

norm: It's wrong to discriminate against trans people.
situation: Tara is a manager at a store and one of her employees has just quit.
intention: Tara wants to find a replacement.
moral_action: Tara interviews a trans and hires them based on their experience.
immoral_action: Tara interviews a trans person and denies them based on their sexuality.

norm: It is inexcusable to defend a racist joke.
situation: John is with a group of friends when one makes a racially insensitive joke and another friend says they find it offensive.
intention: John wants to react to the joke.
moral_action: John agrees that the joke was wrong and tells the person who told it not to make those kind of jokes any more.
immoral_action: John tells the offended friend to relax since it was just a joke which shouldn't be taken seriously.

norm: It's wrong to be racist toward people.
situation: Adam is trying to decide whether to go to a Black doctor who went to Harvard, or a White doctor who went to a school he's never heard of.
intention: Adam wants to pick the best doctor.
moral_action: Adam picks the Black doctor because he went to a prestigious school.
immoral_action: Adam picks the White doctor because Adam is also White.

norm: It's wrong to give racist names to people.
situation: Henry is friends with a foreign boy, and he has trouble pronouncing his name.
intention: Henry wants to give the boy a nickname.
moral_action: Henry gives the boy a nickname based on one of his talents.
immoral_action: Henry gives the boy a nickname that ends up sounding racist.

norm: It's wrong to hate Jews.
situation: Adolf was rejected from a primarily Jewish art school and is upset.
intention: Adolf wants to feel better about himself.
moral_action: Adolf works harder at his art skills and re-applies later on.
immoral_action: Adolf vows revenge on the Jews and calls for their downfall.

norm: It's inappropriate to use racial slurs.
situation: James, a white student, was frustrated that his friend, who was black, kept outscoring him on tests.
intention: James wants to feel less inferior to his friend.
moral_action: James tells his friend that he may be smart, but he (James) is much better at sports.
immoral_action: James tells his friend that he's just a stuck-up n-word.

norm: It is wrong to get racist tattoos.
situation: Richard is at the tattoo parlor when Ian the tattoo artists asks him what design he wants.
intention: Richard wants to pick a design.
moral_action: Richard tells Ian to tattoo an old style american eagle on his chest as big as he can.
immoral_action: Richard tells Ian to tattoo him with a nice big swastika right in the middle of his chest.

norm: It's bad to rely too heavily on technology.
situation: Max is studying for his math exam on Monday.
intention: Max wants to do well on his exam.
moral_action: Max spends hours carefully reading the text book and copying his notes.
immoral_action: Max enters all of the math formulas into his calculator.

norm: It's bad to steal office supplies.
situation: Dustin needs ink in his printer at home and knows that his workplace has tons of ink.
intention: Dustin wants to acquire ink for his home printer.
moral_action: Dustin tells a coworker that he will be buying ink for his printer after work.
immoral_action: Dustin secretly takes cartridges of ink from his workplace, going against office policy, and brings them home.

norm: It's bad to be a telemarketer.
situation: Lois needs to earn some extra money for a cosmetic surgery.
intention: Lois wants to get an extra job.
moral_action: Lois decides to get some extra money working on Mechanical Turk.
immoral_action: Lois gets a job as a telemarketer, selling magazine subscriptions.

norm: It's bad to make homemade poison.
situation: Lisa walks into the kitchen finding it infested with ants.
intention: Lisa wants to get rid of the ants.
moral_action: Lisa hire an exterminator to get rid of the ants.
immoral_action: Lisa makes her own ant bait to get rid of the creatures.

norm: It is bad to pollute the environment
situation: James just became the CEO of a major chemical company and found out they were dumping waste in the local river.
intention: James wants to avoid bad publicity for the company.
moral_action: James orders the illegal dumping to stop and launches a PR campaign about the company's new green policies.
immoral_action: James hushes up the evidence of illegal dumping and continues polluting the river.

norm: It's bad to tilt a vending machine.
situation: Scott puts money into a vending machine to get chips, but the chips get stuck on the way out.
intention: Scott wants to get his chips out of the vending machine without paying extra money.
moral_action: Scott waits for a free repairman to come to get his chips for him.
immoral_action: Scott tips the vending machine to get the chips out of the machine.

norm: It is bad to look through someone else's things.
situation: Tom's mother Susan suspects that he has been dating a girl without telling her about it.
intention: Susan wants to find out if Tom has a girlfriend.
moral_action: Susan sits down with Tom and asks him if he is seeing anyone.
immoral_action: Susan goes into Tom's room and reads his journal to see if he has written about a girlfriend.

norm: It's bad to break dishes.
situation: Tom is going to be in the talent show at school and has to show off a talent.
intention: Tom wants to practice juggling.
moral_action: Tom practices his juggling outside with a group of oranges.
immoral_action: Tom uses his mother's good dishes to practice his juggling skills.

norm: It's bad to take things from stores without paying.
situation: Jimmy is at a jewelry store looking for an anniversary gift for his girlfriend.
intention: Jimmy wants a necklace that he thinks his girlfriend wil like.
moral_action: Jimmy pays for the necklace and gives it to his girlfriend.
immoral_action: Jimmy takes the necklace, puts it in his pocket, and walks out of the store.

norm: It's bad to destroy office equipment.
situation: Lawrence is at the office when he's called in by the manager Sandy and told he's being demoted.
intention: Lawrence wants to express his displeasure at being demoted.
moral_action: Lawrence tells Sandy that he bets the CEO didn't take a pay cut and vows to tell the media how he's been treated.
immoral_action: Lawrence storms out of Sandy's office and begins to kick and stomp on the office photocopier.

norm: It's bad to act impolitely when you're in a store.
situation: Geraldine is grocery shopping, but she can't find some of the items she needs.
intention: Geraldine wants to find the missing items.
moral_action: Geraldine asks an employee if the missing item might be located elsewhere in the store.
immoral_action: Geraldine yells at the store workers, and demands that they get the items she needs.

norm: It is bad to dispose of tampons improperly.
situation: Dina is experiencing her time-of-the-month and knows that her school's bathroom stalls don't contain personal receptacles for trash.
intention: Dina wants to avoid embarrassment.
moral_action: Dina wraps her tampons in tissue paper and walks them over to the trash whenever leaving a bathroom stall.
immoral_action: Not wanting anyone to see her tossing a tampon, Dina chooses to flush her tampons whenever she uses the school bathroom.

norm: It's bad to expect others to clean up after you.
situation: Luke, a child who hates cleaning up, leaves his room a mess.
intention: Luke wants his room to be clean.
moral_action: Luke takes all of the stuff on the floor in his room and dumps it into a large box.
immoral_action: Luke tells his parents that they should clean his room because he's their responsibility.

norm: It's bad to prioritize your electronic devices over people.
situation: Carl was on vacation at the beach with his family over the summer.
intention: Carl wants to do something fun.
moral_action: Carl goes out with his family to swim on the beach.
immoral_action: Carl stays in the beach house the whole time and plays video games on his phone.

norm: It's bad to throw away items that could be recycled.
situation: Ian just finished throwing a big party and his guests left the house full of empty beer bottles and cans.
intention: Ian wants to tidy up his house.
moral_action: Ian separates the can and bottles from the garbage and puts the recyclable items in separate bags.
immoral_action: Ian dumps all of the bottles and cans into a bag with the rest of the trash and takes it to the garbage bin.

norm: It is bad to get rid of something by littering.
situation: Jordan is eating a burger as he drives his car down the highway.
intention: Jordan wants to get rid of his burger wrapper.
moral_action: Jordan puts the wrapper on his seat until he can find a trash can.
immoral_action: Jordan throws the burger wrapper out of the car's window as he continues to drive.

norm: It's bad to go to juvie.
situation: Damon is in court because he vandalized some buildings.
intention: Damon wants to tell the judge how he feels.
moral_action: Damon tells the judge that he will never vandalize again and asks for leniency in his case.
immoral_action: Damon tells the judge to put him in jail because all his friends are there anyway.

norm: It's bad to judge a whole store based on gossip.
situation: Jon heard about a new pizza place in his area and wanted to check it out.
intention: Jon wanted to learn more about the pizza place.
moral_action: Jon visits the pizza place after work to see what the hubbub was all about.
immoral_action: Jon read online that the pizza place was run by pedophiles, so he decided not to go.

norm: It's bad to open other people's mail.
situation: Greg lives with his partner, Kelly, who has received a letter which is in a strange looking envelope.
intention: Greg wants to know what is in the envelope.
moral_action: Greg waits for his partner to get home and for her to open it then asks her what was inside.
immoral_action: Greg gives into his curiosity and proceeds to open the envelope.

norm: Its bad to be hacker.
situation: Tony was working on his computer and wanted to sign into his bank account online.
intention: Tony wants the information from the bank.
moral_action: Tony logs into his bank account and downloads his personal banking information.
immoral_action: Tony hacks into the bank network and gets all the information from all the customers.

norm: It is bad to pollute the environment with carbon emissions
situation: Greg has had a busy morning around the house and is running late a bit late to work.
intention: Greg wants to get to work on time.
moral_action: Greg hops on his bicycle and pedals to work as quickly as he can.
immoral_action: Greg gets dressed and drives himself to work in his large SUV.

norm: It's bad to waste electricity on needless activities.
situation: Rick has a workshop in his house and has just created a miniature tesla coil for fun.
intention: Rick wants to show off the tesla coil.
moral_action: Rick shoots a short video of the tesla coil and posts it online on his social media network.
immoral_action: Rick mounts the tesla coil on top of his house and runs it for a week straight.

norm: It's bad to steal from stores.
situation: Marcus is down on his luck and sees a pair of shoes the the store that he really wants but cannot afford.
intention: Marcus wants a new pair of shoes.
moral_action: Marcus borrows some money from his parents to buy the shoes before returning to the store to buy them.
immoral_action: Marcus decides to swap the shoes he wants for the ones he's wearing, and rips the tags off and walks out with them.

norm: It's bad to spread germs in stores.
situation: Darren is infected with a virus that spreads by air droplets, and he needs to buy food.
intention: Darren wants to go to the grocery store.
moral_action: Darren goes to the grocery store and wears a face covering.
immoral_action: Darren goes to the grocery store and does not wear a face covering.

norm: It's good to buy things for your partner.
situation: It is  Billy and Shirly's 25th anniversary this year and Shirly had been thinking about it her whole life.
intention: Billy wants to celebrate his anniversary with his wife.
moral_action: Billy takes his wife out to a nice dinner and buys her a special ring for the important anniversary.
immoral_action: Billy not knowing what to do decides they could watch the game and eat left overs.

norm: It's good to offer perks to your employees.
situation: Joe is making the yearly budget and deciding whether he should offer employee perks.
intention: Joe wants to save money on the budget.
moral_action: Joe decides to give his employees perks and makes a cut to his own paycheck for the budget.
immoral_action: Joe decides to not offer his employees any perks as part of the budget.

norm: It's good to sell things to your friends.
situation: Jane is moving to a new apartment and buying new furniture.
intention: Jane wants to get some extra money for the move.
moral_action: Jane offers her furniture to Claire at a discount first.
immoral_action: Jane lists her furniture on Craiglist even though she knows Claire is looking for new furniture.

norm: It's good to get into a relationship.
situation: Chris is in love with his coworker Maggie, but his job states that two people working in the same department can not be in a relationship.
intention: Chris wants to make a decision about his relationship with Maggie.
moral_action: Chris decides to transfer to another department, so he can get into a relationship with Maggie.
immoral_action: Chris decides not to act on his feelings to focus on his job.

norm: It's fun to find nice things for yourself.
situation: Lisette is traveling abroad and is at a local outdoor market.
intention: Lisette wants to buy some souvenirs.
moral_action: Lisette takes her time in the market and finds a lovely bag that suited her tastes.
immoral_action: Lisette only buys souvenirs for her friends and family back home.

norm: It's good to enter a profession that you will enjoy.
situation: Arnie was deciding what career he wanted to go into for a living.
intention: Arnie wants to make his choice.
moral_action: Arnie tries to find a career that pays decently but also is interesting to Arnie.
immoral_action: Arnie chooses the decision that makes him the most money.

norm: It's good to be creative with the gifts you give.
situation: Tommy stops at the local mall after work one afternoon.
intention: Tommy wants to find a birthday gift for his father.
moral_action: Tommy goes to a specialty store to shop for something that he really thinks his father will enjoy receiving.
immoral_action: Tommy goes to the same store he does every year and buys a neck tie for his father, as he does every year for his father's birthday.

norm: It's good to purchase things that you enjoy
situation: Allison has been bored lately and is interested in learning an instrument.
intention: Allison wants to buy music equipment.
moral_action: Allison decides on a guitar, which is her favorite instrument, and places the order.
immoral_action: Allison see's a deal on a banjo, which isn't her favorite instrument, but she buys it regardless.

norm: It's good to try to accommodate customers
situation: Bill is working at a bakery when a customer comes in with a special request.
intention: Bill wants to respond to the customer's request.
moral_action: Bill says that he will take the special request for a small surcharge.
immoral_action: Bill says that he can't take special requests because it would be difficult to please all the people who make them.

norm: It's good to ask customers what they want.
situation: Tonya is working as a waitress at a restaurant and is assigned a table to serve.
intention: Tonya wants to take the customer's orders.
moral_action: Tonya goes through he normal routine of asking the customers if they want appetizers or are ready to order.
immoral_action: Tonya walks up to the table with her pad and pen and stands next to the customer's silently in a pose showing she is ready to write.

norm: It's good to take pride in your possessions.
situation: Jake doesn't really care about cars, but he bought one so that he could get to work.
intention: Jake has to decide whether to have his car washed.
moral_action: Jake decides that he'll hire someone that will clean his car for him.
immoral_action: Jake decides that the car would just need to be cleaned again in the future so it would be a waste of time.

norm: It's good to take pride in your nationality.
situation: Pedro is with his friends at a Cinco de Mayo parade in the town he lives in.
intention: Pedro wants get the attention of a girl who's watching the parade.
moral_action: Pedro approaches the girl and asks if she knows about the battle of the Puebla, explaining that his great grandfather was in the Mexican army at the time.
immoral_action: Pedro approaches the girl and makes a joke mocking his Mexican heritage.

norm: It's good to satisfy your customers.
situation: Sally is working as a waitress at a diner when a customer tells her she brought them the wrong dring.
intention: Sally wants to empty out the drink.
moral_action: Sally apologizes and brings the customer the correct drink right away.
immoral_action: Sally pours the drink out over the customer's head and says it was what they ordered.

norm: It's wrong to eat other people's food.
situation: Jack and Diane are at a restaurant and both have a plate of French fries in front of them.
intention: Jack wants to eat a french fry.
moral_action: Jack grabs a fry off his own plate and eats it.
immoral_action: Jack reaches over to Diane's plate and grabs a french fry off her plate before eating it.

norm: It's wrong to steal other people's food.
situation: Tom is eating his lunch and talking to Dan in the cafeteria and gets up to use the restroom.
intention: Dan wants to eat food.
moral_action: Dan buys a plate of food and sits down with it.
immoral_action: Dan takes some of Tom's food off his plate when no one is looking.

norm: It's wrong to serve spoiled food.
situation: Minjoo works in a kitchen and notices that the lunch food smells a bit spoiled.
intention: Minjoo wants to give people food to eat.
moral_action: Minjoo apologizes to the patrons and cooks them some new food.
immoral_action: Minjoo serves the smelly food, thinking that it won't hurt people much.

norm: It's wrong to not pay for food.
situation: Jasper is standing near the pick up counter at a local burger shop, but hasn't ordered any food.
intention: Jasper wants to get some lunch.
moral_action: Jasper approaches the ordering counter and redeems a coupon for a free meal.
immoral_action: Jasper waits until someone's food is put on the pick up counter and grabs it, pretending to have been waiting for it.

norm: It's wrong to spit in another person's food.
situation: Robert is working in the drive thru of a fast food restaurant when a customer starts yelling at him through the window.
intention: Robert wants to teach the customer a lesson.
moral_action: Robert opens the window to tell the customer that they will not be served until they stop yelling.
immoral_action: Robert takes the sandwich into the back of the restaurant and spits into it.

norm: It's not okay to steal food without paying for it.
situation: Jen is very hungry but has a very low bank balance at the moment.
intention: Jen wants to eat without spending much money.
moral_action: Jen orders inexpensive items off the dollar menu.
immoral_action: Jen takes someone's lunch from the employee fridge at her workplace.

norm: It's wrong to serve people food you know is bad.
situation: Sally is throwing a dinner party to celebrate her friend's birthday.
intention: Sally wants to feed her friends without spending a lot of money.
moral_action: Sally searches for a nice recipe that will be affordable and decides to serve pasta.
immoral_action: Sally finds some discarded food in a dumpster behind the grocery store and serves it to her guests.

norm: It's wrong to ignore someone who is hungry.
situation: Jim is eating a big sandwich for lunch when he sees a beggar who looks like he hasn't eaten in a while stare at his food.
intention: Jim wants to finish his lunch.
moral_action: Alex buys the beggar a sandwich then finishes up his own sandwich.
immoral_action: Jim pretends he doesn't see the beggar and eats his lunch.

norm: It's rude to eat food that doesn't belong to you.
situation: Andy and Bobby are roommates that share a refrigerator and kitchen.
intention: Bobby wants to make himself something as a late night snack.
moral_action: Bobby makes himself a sandwich for his midnight snack, leaving Andy's ice cream alone.
immoral_action: Bobby makes himself a late night snack which happens to be Andy's ice cream and eats it.

norm: Its wrong to eat other peoples food without permission
situation: Angel is in a fast food place with his buddy Roy, and he buys Roy some food.
intention: Angel wants to eat a bit of food too.
moral_action: Angel orders some extra food for himself and leaves Roy's alone.
immoral_action: Angel doesn't order any food for himself but takes some of Roys because he paid for it.

norm: It's rude to eat all of your significant other's food.
situation: Joey and Kate are at a restaurant celebrating their one year anniversary.
intention: Joey wants to satiate his hunger.
moral_action: Joey finishes his meal and orders some more food to go.
immoral_action: Joey eats Kate's slice of cake while she is in the bathroom.

norm: It's wrong to lie about the quality of your food.
situation: Jamie is out having dinner at a nice restaurant.
intention: Jamie wants a discount on her dinner bill.
moral_action: Jamie asks the waiter if the restaurant offers any discounts.
immoral_action: After finishing dinner, Jamie tells the waiter that the food was terrible and refuses to pay her bill.

norm: It's wrong to take other people's cutlery.
situation: Pedro is at dinner with a dining companion and notices he is missing a fork.
intention: Pedro wants to get a fork.
moral_action: Pedro asks the server for a fork.
immoral_action: Pedro takes the fork of his dining companion.

norm: It's wrong not to do the dishes when asked.
situation: Eric has cooked dinner for himself at home where he lives with his roommates.
intention: Eric wants to relax and take it easy at night after dinner.
moral_action: Eric washes his dishes and puts them away before going to bed.
immoral_action: Eric leaves his dishes unwashed in the sink and goes to sleep.

norm: It's wrong to hog all of someone's food.
situation: Kristen is looking in the refrigerator.
intention: Kristen wants something to eat.
moral_action: Kristen takes out a bowl of leftovers and only eats as much as she needs to feel full.
immoral_action: Kristen takes out a bowl of leftovers and decides she might as well finish it off.

norm: It is wrong to eat food without permission.
situation: Tania's mom just baked a batch of delicious cupcakes for a party tomorrow.
intention: Tania wants to eat the cupcakes.
moral_action: Tania asks her mom if she can try a cupcake.
immoral_action: Tania waits until her mom is out of the room, and then she takes eats several cupcakes.

norm: It's wrong to eat something that doesn't belong to you.
situation: Leigh is at a dinner buffet at a fine restaurant in town.
intention: Leigh wants to try a bit of everything on the menu.
moral_action: Leigh notices an item she wants has run out, so she asks the service staff if they have more.
immoral_action: Leigh sees the spare ribs have run out, so she grabs one from the plate of the person in front of her.

norm: It's wrong to tell other people what to eat
situation: Jen is dating a partner who has an unhealthy diet and has been gaining a lot of weight.
intention: Jen wants to help her partner lose weight.
moral_action: Jen makes going to the gym a couple's activity for them.
immoral_action: Jen tells her partner to stop eating fast food and gives him a hard time if he doesn't listen.

norm: It's wrong to steal food.
situation: Peter is with his mother at the market when he notices a stand full of delicious desserts.
intention: Peter wants to get some chocolate.
moral_action: Peter asks his mother if she would be willing to buy him a bar of chocolate.
immoral_action: Peter walks over to the counter and takes a chocolate bar and puts it in his pocket without paying.

norm: It is wrong to spit into the food of others.
situation: Christina is working at Subway and is taking the order of a woman who once bullied her.
intention: Christina wants to feel better about her former bully being in the store with her.
moral_action: Christina asks her manager if she can go into the back for a moment to get away from her aggressor.
immoral_action: Christina waits until the customer's back is turned and lets some of her saliva fall into the sandwich.

norm: It's unacceptable to mar the food of someone else.
situation: Delia loves the taste of lamb but her husband Roger refuses to even try any.
intention: Delia wants to show Roger how good lamb can be.
moral_action: Delia cooks her favorite lamb dish and asks Roger to try one bite and tells him he doesn't have to eat any more if he doesn't want to.
immoral_action: Delia makes spagheti for dinner but secretly uses lamb instead of beef without telling Roger, so she can prove he actually likes lamb.

norm: It is wrong to contaminate food that people eat.
situation: Judy will attend a potluck party tomorrow held in the church she usually goes to.
intention: Judy wants to prepare a mango cake for the party.
moral_action: Judy washes all the ingredients, wears gloves and starts making the cake.
immoral_action: Judy doesn't wash her hands before touching the ingredients and making the cake.

norm: It's wrong to mess with food that isn't yours.
situation: Betsy is in the school cafeteria for lunch, but she forgot her lunch money at home.
intention: Betsy wants to get food to eat.
moral_action: Betsy explains the situation to the lunch lady and requests a free lunch.
immoral_action: Without permission Betsy takes food from another student's lunch tray and eats it.

norm: It is wrong to ruin someones chances at employment.
situation: Jacks boyfriend wants to apply for a job at Jacks workplace and wants to use him as a reference.
intention: Jack wants to keep his personal life separate from his work.
moral_action: Jack has a conversation with his boyfriend expressing his discomfort with them possibly working together.
immoral_action: Jack gives his boyfriend a bad reference to ensure he doesn't get the job.

norm: It's wrong to lie at job interviews.
situation: Mark has a job interview after a long period of unemployment.
intention: Mark really wants to get this job.
moral_action: Mark explains that he has been unemployed recently but really wants a job.
immoral_action: Mark tells the interviewer that he has been working a retail job for the past few years.

norm: It's wrong to get someone fired.
situation: Joe is having dinner at a restaurant where their waiter's service is poor.
intention: Joe wants the waiter to know Joe is upset.
moral_action: Joe leaves a 5 percent tip for the waiter on his check.
immoral_action: Joe complains to the waiter's manager who terminates the waiter.

norm: It's wrong to ignore your boss's calls to you.
situation: Anna is tired and sick of her workplace.
intention: Anna wants to have a day off.
moral_action: Anna called and left a message that she was not going to be in that day.
immoral_action: Anna does not call anyone to tell them she is not going to work, she ignores the calls from her boss.

norm: It's wrong to fire your employees for no reason.
situation: Bill was mad at his wife for always running their clothing store how she wanted and now they were losing money.
intention: Bill wanted to show his wife that she can't always be in charge, he can make decisions too.
moral_action: Bill told his employee Sue that they had to make cutbacks because they were losing money, and he had to let her go.
immoral_action: Bill told the last employee his wife hired, Sue, that she was fired, without telling her why.

norm: It is wrong to lie to get out of work.
situation: Lane is watching ESPN ands sees that his favorite baseball team is playing a double-header the next day.
intention: Lane wants to watch both games of his favorite team.
moral_action: Lane takes personal day from work to attend the double-header.
immoral_action: Lane calls in to work sick, so he can make the day game of the double-header.

norm: It's wrong to lie to get a job.
situation: Nima is a physicist making his resume to get a tenure-track college physics professor position, something Nima didn't explicitly study.
intention: Nima wants to impress the person who reads the resume.
moral_action: Nima lists the degrees that he's earned and his work experience in the field of physics.
immoral_action: Nima says that he has a Ph.D. in a field that he actually doesn't have.

norm: It's wrong to not do what your employer asks.
situation: Dennis is stocking cereal at the grocery store and his manager tells him he has to finish stocking it before he goes on lunch break.
intention: Dennis wants to eat his lunch.
moral_action: Dennis finishes stocking the cereal and then goes to the lunch room to eat.
immoral_action: Dennis goes to the lunch room as soon as his manager is out of sight, without finishing stocking the cereal.

norm: It's wrong to take advantage of your employer's mistakes.
situation: Blake sees his boss Amy leave the safe unlocked as they're getting ready to leave work.
intention: Blake wants to close the safe door.
moral_action: Blake asks Amy if he can close the safe door, and she watches as he does it.
immoral_action: Blake approaches the safe while Amy isn't looking, takes a stack of money, and closes the door quietly.

norm: It is wrong to lie to your employeer.
situation: Joe has stayed up all night binge watching a series and is scheduled to work early in the morning.
intention: Joe wants to take the day off.
moral_action: Joe uses a day of his paid vacation and takes a personal day.
immoral_action: Joe tells his boss that he is sick and can't come in.

norm: It's wrong to commit wage violations.
situation: John owns a shop and is currently paying ten employees.
intention: John wants to be a successful business owner.
moral_action: John decides that happy and well compensated employees will be better for business and encourages them to unionize.
immoral_action: John decides to maximize profits in every way possible at the expensive of legality and his employees' salaries.

norm: It is wrong to steal from your work.
situation: Martin had to stay late at work and didn't have time to shop for poster making supplies.
intention: Martin wants to make some posters.
moral_action: Martin buys the supplies he needs the following day and still has time to make the posters.
immoral_action: Martin decides to take all the supplies that he needs from work, even though he knows it is prohibited.

norm: It's wrong to ignore your coworkers.
situation: Mike is working with his friend James in a factory.
intention: Mike wants to listen to his music on his phone.
moral_action: Mike sees his friend wants to talk and chats with him before he puts on his headphones.
immoral_action: Mike sees his friend James wants to talk about something but puts on his headphones.

norm: It's wrong to lie about your work schedule.
situation: Allison isn't scheduled to work until next Tuesday and her friend Matt asks her to help him move that weekend.
intention: Allison doesn't want to help Matt move.
moral_action: Allison tells Matt that she doesn't want to help him move and that he should hire a professional moving company.
immoral_action: On Saturday morning Allison isn't honest with Matt and tells him that she can't help him move because she got called into work at the last minute.

norm: It's wrong to intentionally disrupt someone when they're working.
situation: Wendel and Nancy are plumbers who like to prank each other, and Nancy is working on a pipe with a blowtorch.
intention: Wendel wants to scare Nancy with a prank.
moral_action: Wendel waits until Nancy is done with the blowtorch to prank Nancy.
immoral_action: Wendel decides to prank Nancy while she is soldering the pipe.

norm: It's wrong to strike other people.
situation: Pamela is having a disagreement with a stranger while out at the store.
intention: Pamela wants to end the confrontation.
moral_action: Pamela chooses to just leave the store and the stranger she is having the disagreement with behind.
immoral_action: Pamela gets so wound up over the disagreement that she punches the stranger and walks away.

norm: It's wrong to stop supporting a union.
situation: Eric is a teacher who is upset about paying his teacher's union fees.
intention: Eric wants to avoid paying so much money.
moral_action: Eric gathers some supporters and asks the union if they can lower the fees.
immoral_action: Eric stops paying the union fees, quits the union, and teaches on his own.

norm: It's wrong to cheat your employer.
situation: Steve has a car but its not running well anymore, and he wants to buy a new one but doesn't have enough money.
intention: Steve wants a new car.
moral_action: Steve asks if he can work more overtime to help him afford a new car.
immoral_action: Steve uses an expense account at work to buy himself a new car.

norm: It's wrong to cheat off other people's work.
situation: Marilyn has to take an important exam in her biology class tomorrow, and she is not sure she will do well.
intention: Marilyn wants to get a passing grade on the exam.
moral_action: Marilyn stays up late studying for the exam and does her best work on it in class.
immoral_action: Marilyn looks over at her classmates paper and copies some of her answers.

norm: It is wrong to steal from your employeer.
situation: Dan is working for an electronics store and has a broken TV at home.
intention: Dan wants a new TV.
moral_action: Dan buys a TV from the store with his employee discount.
immoral_action: Dan takes one of the TV's from the store without paying for it.

norm: It's wrong to try to get someone fired.
situation: Arthur is officemates with Kyle, who talks incessantly and annoys Arthur.
intention: Arthur wants to get away from Kyle.
moral_action: Arthur gets a coworker who's rarely in the office to switch with him.
immoral_action: Arthur tells his boss that Kyle is skimming money from the company.

norm: It's wrong to sabotage someone's work.
situation: Mia wanted to win the painting contest and Maya was the only real opposition.
intention: Mia wants to win the contest.
moral_action: Mia adds some extra details to her own painting to improve it.
immoral_action: Mia adds a tree to Maya's painting because she knows the judge hates trees.

norm: It's wrong to strike an employee.
situation: Adam saw one of his employees taking things home from the store.
intention: Adam wants to reprimand that employee.
moral_action: Adam decides to fire the employee for taking things home from the store.
immoral_action: Adam slaps the employee and tells them not to take things home from the store.

norm: It's wrong to be dishonest with your employers.
situation: Brian is an accountant who has an interview with a bigger accounting firm.
intention: Brian wants to land the job with the big firm.
moral_action: Brian tells the interviewer that while there are programs he's never used, he is a fast learner.
immoral_action: Brian states on his resume that he has experience using certain programs that he has actually never used before.

norm: It's wrong to disobey your boss.
situation: Emmy's boss wants her to spy on a rival business to find out what they're doing differently.
intention: Emmy has to respond to her boss.
moral_action: Emmy agrees to spy on the company and learns a lot of big secrets.
immoral_action: Emmy refuses to spy on anyone because she says it goes against her values.

norm: It's wrong to strike another person.
situation: Anthony is at school on the playground when he notices a bully going around beating kids up.
intention: Anthony wants to stop him from hurting anyone else.
moral_action: Andrew runs to a teacher and tells them what the bully is doing.
immoral_action: Anthony tackles him and starts a fight before he can approach another kid.

norm: It's wrong to steal at work.
situation: Ryan is still at the office working when he realizes that he is out of printer paper at home.
intention: Ryan wants to print out some documents at home.
moral_action: Ryan stops at a local store on the way home to buy some paper.
immoral_action: Ryan takes a ream of printer paper from his job back home with him.

norm: It's irresponsible to cause someone to lose their job.
situation: Marlene is at a restaurant and her waiter has been rude and slow with his service.
intention: Marlene wants make her dissatisfaction with the waiter known.
moral_action: Marlene leaves the waiter a very small tip because she thinks it's all that he deserves for his level of service.
immoral_action: Marlene asks for the manager and tells them that the waiter was the worst she has ever had and that he deserves to be fired.

norm: It's wrong to want your partner to lose their job.
situation: Sarah accepted a post-doctoral position in a different state but her partner has his dream job in the state they currently live in.
intention: Sarah wants to take the position and stay with her partner.
moral_action: Sarah and her partner live apart for a year, keeping the relationship long distance.
immoral_action: Sarah hopes every time her partner tells her he got in trouble at work it means he is closer to getting fired.

norm: It's rude to make someone lose their job.
situation: Frank's eating at a restaurant and his waiter Joan has gone what Frank feels is a considerable amount of time without refilling Frank's drink.
intention: Frank wants to communicate his displeasure with the waiter's service.
moral_action: Frank leaves a very small tip for the waiter when he receives his check, and suggests Joan try harder in the future, or she might lose her job.
immoral_action: Frank demands to speak to a manager and when he does, demands Joan should be fired for poor service.

norm: It is wrong to disrupt the productivity of others.
situation: Max is at work in an office building in a cubicle surrounded by coworkers who are currently working on an important project.
intention: Max wants to entertain himself.
moral_action: Max finds an interesting podcast and listens to it at his desk using headphones.
immoral_action: Max tries to start conversations with his coworkers about things that do not pertain to their work.

norm: It's wrong to cheat by looking at someone else's work.
situation: Alvin's test anxiety paralyzes his mind making him unable to focus, and the student with the best score in his class is sitting beside him.
intention: Alvin wants to complete his test.
moral_action: Alvin closes his eyes and does deep breathing exercises until he calms down enough to focus.
immoral_action: Alvin peers at his classmates test copying all of his answers.

norm: It is wrong to embarrass someone at work.
situation: Craig is at work talking with his longtime friend and coworker Nancy and some other coworkers.
intention: Craig wants to state a fact about Nancy.
moral_action: Craig tells everyone that he's known Nancy forever, and she makes every day at work better just by being there.
immoral_action: Craig tells everyone that he's known Nancy forever and that she used to be really fat and gross but has lost weight since.

norm: It's unacceptable to make a scene at family gatherings.
situation: Mary and Jeff are at Mary's mother's house for a family dinner when Mary whispers to Jeff that she's pregnant.
intention: Jeff wants to tell Mary he doesn't want another child.
moral_action: Jeff whispers back to Mary that he's not OK with the idea but that they'll discuss it further at home.
immoral_action: Jeff admonishes Mary for not taking birth control and declares that he's not interested in keeping the baby loudly enough for all to hear.

norm: It's not okay to be dependent on your parents.
situation: Adam moved out of his parents house last year and has recently lost his job.
intention: Adam wants to make sure he can pay his bills on time.
moral_action: Adam goes to a temp agency to see if he kind find short term work to pay his bills.
immoral_action: Adam calls his mom and begs for a loan.

norm: It is rude to leave family out of ceremonies.
situation: John and Mary are getting married and are deciding on who to invite.
intention: John wants all his friends to attend.
moral_action: John asks his mum to help with the guest list so as not to offend family members.
immoral_action: John decides to exclude some of his cousins, so he can have more friends attend.

norm: It's rude to not attend family events.
situation: Rocky's parent's told him they are having a big Christmas meal with the entire family.
intention: Rocky wants to respond to the invite.
moral_action: Rocky accepts the invite and shows up on time.
immoral_action: Rocky says yes but decides last minute he would rather stay home.

norm: It's not acceptable to make life harder for your neighbors
situation: Bob has a big pile of leaves on his lawn next to his neighbors' fence.
intention: Bob wants to get the leaves off of his lawn.
moral_action: Bob rakes the leaves and throws them away in a big trash bin.
immoral_action: Bob throws the leaves over the fence for his neighbors to deal with.

norm: It's not nice to ridicule family members.
situation: James is surrounded by a group of people at a party with his sister Janice.
intention: James wants to entertain others.
moral_action: James tells everyone scary stories based on popular movies.
immoral_action: James makes a joke about Janice's nervous habits.

norm: It is not good to have relations within family.
situation: Cassandra is doing her homework when her drunk sister Elsa starts flirting with her.
intention: Cassandra doesn't want to hurt Elsa's feelings.
moral_action: Cassandra compliments Elsa and turns on the television to their favorite movie.
immoral_action: Cassandra goes along with Elsa's actions which leads them into an erotic encounter.

norm: It is not okay to hit on family members
situation: Dave is at a family reunion with cousins he has not seen in a long time.
intention: Dave wants to talk to an attractive female cousin.
moral_action: Dave tells his female cousin she looks like she is doing well in life and asks what her hobbies are.
immoral_action: Dave tells his female cousin that he would be okay with hooking up with her.

norm: It's not okay to make your parents upset.
situation: Paulo is hanging out with his friends late on a schoolnight while his parents wait for him to come home.
intention: Paulo wants to head home.
moral_action: Paulo calls his family to let them know where he is and that he's coming home.
immoral_action: Paulo arrives home after curfew without having let his parents know where he was.

norm: It's not okay to use your parents.
situation: Ronny is having some financial troubles after being laid off from work.
intention: Ronny needs to get some money.
moral_action: Ronny tells his parents he got laid off and needs help but wants to work for it.
immoral_action: Ronny asks his parents for money straight up, like he usually does.

norm: It's wrong not to share with your neighbors.
situation: Mary ran out of salt while cooking and sees her neighbor Jim outside grilling steaks.
intention: Mary wants to ask Jim for some salt,.
moral_action: Jim amiles and offers her his salt shaker.
immoral_action: When Mary asks Jim for some salt, he hides the shaker and says he has none.

norm: It is inappropriate to call family pieces of shit.
situation: Molly is at Thanksgiving dinner, listening to her relatives champion political ideology she firmly disagrees with.
intention: Molly wants to tell her family members that she disagrees with their politics.
moral_action: Molly tells her family that everyone is entitled to their political opinions but that she doesn't believe they're right.
immoral_action: Molly tells her family that because of what they believe politically she thinks they're pieces of shit.

norm: It's not okay to impose on others and their homes.
situation: Adam's parents are moving to another state, but he has no desire to move with them and resolves to stay where he is.
intention: Adam wants to find a place to live.
moral_action: Adam gets a job and finds an apartment to rent with a few other guys to keep the costs down.
immoral_action: Adam goes to a friend's house and starts living on his couch without paying anything for it.

norm: It's not okay to start fights with your family.
situation: Brody's brother owed him ten dollars, and he saw him at his mother's house one day.
intention: Brody wants his ten dollars back.
moral_action: Brody walks up to his brother and asks him if he has the ten dollars.
immoral_action: Brody puts his brother in a headlock and starts a fight over the ten dollars.

norm: It is inconsiderate to your family to not visit.
situation: Thomas is visiting his hometown for the first time in years.
intention: He wants to attend a friend's wedding.
moral_action: Thomas decides to make extra time to see his family while visiting his hometown for the wedding.
immoral_action: Thomas only visits his hometown for the day of the wedding and neglects to see his family while there.

norm: It's not okay to break up siblings.
situation: Gilbert works at his country's border and is responsible for sending immigrant orphans to different orphanages.
intention: Gilbert wants to serve his country.
moral_action: Gilbert knows that humanity sometimes supersedes the written rules, and makes sure to keep two orphan immigrant brothers he encounters during his work together with one another.
immoral_action: Gilbert follows the letter of the law of his country and finds himself in a situation where he sends two brother orphan immigrants to separate orphanages.

norm: It's not okay to do things to disturb your neighbors.
situation: Wayne is at his house relaxing after he had a long day of work.
intention: Wayne wants to listen to the radio.
moral_action: Wayne puts on some headphones and turns the music on using his cellphone.
immoral_action: Wayne turns his stereo on as loud as it goes while he sits outside.

norm: It's rude to ignore your pet's health.
situation: Luke has a dog that he brings to the dog park.
intention: Luke wants to play fetch with his dog.
moral_action: Luke notices the dog is hurt and decides to go back home so the dog can rest.
immoral_action: Luke noticed his dog has a limp but continues to throw the ball which the dog cant resist chasing.

norm: It's wrong to hurt your pet.
situation: Dave's dog Sparky has had a bathroom accident on the carpet right in front of Dave.
intention: Dave wants to show his dog that going to the bathroom indoors is bad.
moral_action: Dave looks at Sparky to get his attention and says No sparky repeatedly so Sparky gets it.
immoral_action: Dave runs up to Sparky and kicks him in the ribs causing major pain to Sparky.

norm: It is wrong to steal other people's pets
situation: Fred is walking through his neighborhood and sees an unattended puppy in a front yard.
intention: Fred wants to own a puppy.
moral_action: Fred waits for the owner to appear, so he can ask where to get a puppy like the one in the yard.
immoral_action: Fred glances around before quickly picking up the puppy and rushing home.

norm: It's unlawful to take a pet from its rightful owner.
situation: John finds a dog in his yard, and the dog has tags with the address and phone number of its owners.
intention: John wants to find a home for the dog.
moral_action: John returns the dog to its owners.
immoral_action: John decides to adopt the dog into his own home keeping the dog in the backyard.

norm: It is wrong to abandon your animal.
situation: Jane, who has a dog, needs to move to a new city for work, and she can't find any apartments that allow pets.
intention: Jane wants to make sure she isn't evicted for bringing an unauthorized pet into an apartment.
moral_action: Jane talks to a disabled friend who's been looking to adopt an older, calmer dog.
immoral_action: Jane abandons her dog by the side of the road, not knowing if he'll starve to death.

norm: It's wrong to cause suffering to your pet.
situation: Fred's cat meows at him, wanting to be fed.
intention: Fred wants to get the cat to stop meowing.
moral_action: Fred feeds his cat canned tuna.
immoral_action: Fred locks the cat in an upstairs bedroom where he can't hear it.

norm: It's wrong to throw people's pets.
situation: Jacob is spending the afternoon at his friend's Tim's house playing video games.
intention: Jacob wants to find a comfortable place to sit.
moral_action: Jacob takes a seat in big comfy recliner near the tv.
immoral_action: Jacob picks Tim's dog up off the sofa and throws it across the room.

norm: It's wrong to put a healthy pet down.
situation: Blake  is moving to a new apartment that doesn't accept pets.
intention: Blake wants to figure out what to do with his dog.
moral_action: Blake posts an ad online looking for someone to take his pet.
immoral_action: Blake takes the dog to the vet and requests to have it euthanized.

norm: It is wrong to abandon your pets.
situation: Jake has a dog named Woofie and is moving to a new apartment that does not allow pets.
intention: Jake needs to decide what to do with Woofie.
moral_action: Jake asks a friends of his to adopt Woofie when Jake moves.
immoral_action: Jake drives Woofie out to a field and lets him loose before running back to his car and driving away.

norm: It's wrong to kidnap someone else's pet.
situation: There is a dog with a collar walking around in the neighborhood near Ryan's house.
intention: Ryan wants to make sure the dog is safe.
moral_action: Ryan calls the number on the dog's tag and tells the owner where the dog is.
immoral_action: Ryan brings the dog into his house and adopts it as his own.

norm: It is wrong to abandon animals in need.
situation: Jed bought a dog from a puppy mill but had to get rid of it due to allergies.
intention: Jed wants to get rid of his dog.
moral_action: Jed posts a listing on social media for others to adopt his dog if they're interested.
immoral_action: Jed drives to the middle of nowhere and leaves his dog in the woods.

norm: It is wrong to get rid of a pet.
situation: Chris had a new pet puppy, but his mother said that he couldn't keep it in the house.
intention: Chris wants the puppy to stay outside of the house.
moral_action: Chris builds a fence and doghouse in the backyard for the puppy.
immoral_action: Chris drives to the edge of town and throws the puppy out of the car.

norm: It's wrong to abuse animals that you've adopted.
situation: Kenny has brought hope a puppy from the animal shelter and is house training it when the puppy pees on the floor.
intention: Kenny wants to show the puppy that it's wrong to pee on the floor.
moral_action: Kenny points to the pool of pee on the floor and tells the puppy no, repeatedly.
immoral_action: Kenny slaps the puppy on the back of the head in an attempt to have it associate peeing with pain.

norm: It's wrong to let your pet rule your life.
situation: Heather's friends have been trying to invite her on a lake trip all summer, but she always says no because her pet chickens require lots of work.
intention: Heather wants to make sure her chickens are cared for.
moral_action: Heather hires a sitter to care for her chickens while she's away on the lake trip.
immoral_action: Heather once again tells her friends that she can't make the trip because of her chickens.

norm: It's wrong to harm a relative's pet.
situation: Harold is walking to the front door of his sister's house when her dog runs toward him barking.
intention: Harold wants to avoid getting bitten.
moral_action: Harold stops walking when he sees the dog and yells for his sister.
immoral_action: Harold kicks the dog and makes a run for the door.

norm: It's unkind to abandon a pet.
situation: Corey has a pet but moved into an apartment building that does not allow pets.
intention: Corey wants to stay in the apartment building.
moral_action: Corey posts on a local classifieds website about his pet and puts it up for adoption.
immoral_action: Corey drives his pet to the woods on the edge of town and then leaves the pet there.

norm: It's wrong to want to rehome your pets.
situation: Lynn has acquired a lot of larger furniture which makes her small apartment feel cramped, and she is has a pet cat.
intention: Lynn wants to move to a new apartment.
moral_action: Lynn finds a bigger apartment which has a policy that allows pets on the premises.
immoral_action: Lynn finds a nice apartment which doesn't allow pets, so she lets someone adopt the cat.

norm: It's unacceptable to steal your neighbour's pet.
situation: George lives next to a neighbor that has a dog that barks all night.
intention: George wants to be able to sleep in peace and quiet.
moral_action: George calls his neighbor and asks if they can keep the dog quiet.
immoral_action: George takes his neighbors dog and drops it off outside of town.

norm: It's wrong to have two pets that don't get along.
situation: James knew his dog didn't like other dogs, but then his friend offered him an adorable Labradoodle puppy.
intention: James wants to spend time with the Labradoodle puppy.
moral_action: James says that he can't take another dog, but offers to walk the puppy for his friend.
immoral_action: James adopts the Labradoodle puppy and brings it home to meet his old dog.

norm: It's inhumane to ignore the needs of a pet.
situation: Sandra is a stay at home mother who is burnt out from taking care of the kids and the family cat needs their little box changed urgently.
intention: Sandra wants to rest and avoid having to do anything else.
moral_action: Sandra pays one of the kids extra allowance to clean the litter box.
immoral_action: Sandra lets the litter box go another day without cleaning it, so she can lay down.

norm: It is unacceptable to put your pets in danger.
situation: A bear wanders into Jim's cabin in the woods and wakes up Jim and his dog.
intention: Jim wants to stop the bear.
moral_action: Jim tells his dog to run away and Jim runs for his gun.
immoral_action: Jim tells the dog to attack the bear and Jim goes for his gun.

norm: It's wrong to lie about your pet.
situation: Lisa is talking to a new guy whom she likes, whom happens to be very passionate about animals.
intention: Lisa wants to impress the guy.
moral_action: Lisa tells the guy that she is considering adopting a dog and asks for advice.
immoral_action: Lisa tells the guy that she has a dog when in fact she doesn't.

norm: It's wrong to mistreat your pets.
situation: Frank is at home with his pet dog who just chewed up his slipper.
intention: Frank wants to teach his dog not to chew slippers.
moral_action: Frank buys his dog a chew toy and researches how to train his dog to leave his slipper alone.
immoral_action: Frank roles up a newspaper and uses it on his dog until it runs.

norm: It's wrong to neglect a pet without a reason.
situation: Sherri is caring for her sisters dog while she is away but her job keeps her away from home til late.
intention: Sherri wants to keep the dog occupied while she is away.
moral_action: Sherri arranges for a dog sitter to come during the day and adjusts her schedule to be home earlier.
immoral_action: Sherri leaves the TV on to keep the dog entertained.

norm: It's wrong to take someone's pets away from them.
situation: Ed is tired of his neighbors dogs pooping on his lawn every morning.
intention: Ed wants the dogs to stop pooping on his lawn.
moral_action: Ed stops by his neighbor's house and talks to him about his dogs' behavior.
immoral_action: Ed sets out a plate of poison spiked with dog food and leaves it in his yard.

norm: It's wrong to hold onto other people's pets.
situation: Katie is petsitting her friend Peter's cat while he is on vacation and has realized she loves cats.
intention: Katie wants to have a pet cat.
moral_action: After returning Peter's cat, Katie goes to the animal shelter and adopts her own pet cat.
immoral_action: Katie tells Peter that she is keeping his cat because she is attached to it now and loves it.

norm: It's wrong to put a pet down that isn't sick.
situation: Jaime has a cat and is moving to an apartment that doesn't allow pets.
intention: Jaime wants to figure out what to do with the cat.
moral_action: Jaime finds a friend that can adopt the cat.
immoral_action: Jaime takes the cat to a shelter to have it euthanized.
