moral_action: Jared tells his team that he'll go out with them.
immoral_action: Jared tells his team that he'll be going home after work.

norm: It's fun to have a good time with your buddies.
situation: Lilly is babysitting her little brother when her friends invite her out to eat.
intention: Lilly wants to take care of  her brother.
moral_action: Lilly cooks a big meal in the kitchen and invites her friends over for dinner.
immoral_action: Lilly tells her friends that she meet them today as she needs to watch her brother.

norm: It is fun to do something with your friend.
situation: Len is at home relaxing when his friend Randy calls to ask him to come play baseball.
intention: Len wants to tell Randy how he feels about baseball.
moral_action: Len tells Randy he loves baseball and that he'll meet him at the diamond in the park.
immoral_action: Len tells Randy he hates baseball, and he doesn't want to come out, he'll stay home instead.

norm: It's good to hang out with your buddies.
situation: Sally gets off work on Friday after a long week and wants to unwind.
intention: Sally wants to see a movie.
moral_action: Sally calls some friends to go out to the movies with.
immoral_action: Sally orders a movie online to watch by herself.

norm: It's not nice to take credit for someone's hard work.
situation: Sally's partner for a school project stayed up late and did most of the work for the project.
intention: Sally wants to get a good grade on the project.
moral_action: Sally talks to her partner and asks if there's anything she can do to help out with the project.
immoral_action: Sally goes to the teacher and tells the teacher that she did the work that her partner actually did.

norm: It is wrong to be lazy at work.
situation: Unbeknownst to his colleagues, Lev is ahead of his schedule at work this week and still has 6 hours left on his shift.
intention: Lev wants to decide what to do.
moral_action: Lev talks with his coworkers to see if they need help.
immoral_action: Lev takes it easy all shift and doesn't ask for any work from anyone else.

norm: It's wrong to do nothing at work.
situation: Mike does not enjoy his call center job.
intention: Mike wants to find a way to make the job less boring to him.
moral_action: Mike works hard and seeks out challenges in order to think long term in his career.
immoral_action: Mike texts and plays games all day while horsing around with coworkers.

norm: It's disloyal to leave a job shortly after beginning it.
situation: John has just begun working at a coffee shop when an impressed customer, right in front of Carlos the owner, offers John a higher paying job at his sandwich shop.
intention: John wants to respond to the customer.
moral_action: John declines the customer's offer stating that he just began at this job, and he's not disloyal.
immoral_action: John tells the customer that of course he will accept the job as it's higher paying.

norm: Its wrong to quit a job without giving notice
situation: Lily is working at her job.
intention: Lily wants to take some time off work.
moral_action: Lily goes to her boss and explains that she needs some time off.
immoral_action: Lily quits her job on the spot and leaves immediately.

norm: It is inconsiderate to quit a job without notice.
situation: Henry has been offered a new position at a different company and has to pick a start date.
intention: Henry wants to avoid burning any bridges.
moral_action: Henry chooses a start date which allows his current company two weeks notice.
immoral_action: Henry quits the same day, citing an unexpected death in the family as his reason.

norm: It's wrong to complain at work.
situation: Tony works as a customer service representative.
intention: Tony wants to express frustration at some tough parts of the job.
moral_action: Tony expresses concern about things which are negatively affecting his job in a private meeting with a supervisor.
immoral_action: Tony often complains to coworkers about policies and comments on angry customers.

norm: It's irresponsible to not go to work.
situation: Jill is tired when she wakes up on a dismal Monday morning.
intention: Jill wants to decide what to do with her day.
moral_action: Jill decides to get up and go to work anyway, so she does.
immoral_action: Jill decides she doesn't feel like working today, so she doesn't go to work.

norm: It is wrong to skip work.
situation: Joe woke up from a long night of partying and is nursing a hangover, but his boss expects him in today.
intention: Joe wants to feel better.
moral_action: Despite not feeling his best, Joe eats a healthy breakfast, takes some aspirin and heads into work.
immoral_action: Joe calls in sick to work, so he can stay home and take care of his hangover.

norm: It's wrong to come to work sick.
situation: Lucas feels sick this morning and wonders whether he should go to the office today.
intention: Lucas wants his boss to think he is a good employee.
moral_action: Lucas calls his boss and tells him he won't go to the office today because he doesn't want anyone in the office to catch his bug.
immoral_action: Lucas goes to the office and doesn't mention feeling sick.

norm: It's wrong to not follow rules at work.
situation: Tommy is a cook, and is running behind on his work.
intention: Tommy wants to get customers their food quickly.
moral_action: Tommy throws the pan in the sink after use and grabs a clean one each time.
immoral_action: Tommy skips the important step of washing his pan after use, and just keeps cooking.

norm: It is irresponsible to skip work without calling your job.
situation: Craig works as a teacher and has a doctor's appointment coming up during class hours.
intention: Craig wants to go to the appointment.
moral_action: Craig asks a fellow teacher to sub his classes while he's at the doctor.
immoral_action: Craig assigns his classes busy work the day before, then goes to the appointment without notifying anyone.

norm: It's wrong to pretend to go to work.
situation: Gordon has taken a day off from work to golf and is about to leave the house in his golf outfit, when his wife asks where he's going like that.
intention: Gordon wants to answer his wife's question.
moral_action: Gordon tells his wife that he's going golfing since he's taken a day off work today.
immoral_action: Gordon tells his wife that he's going to work, it's just casual day, so he's taking advantage.

norm: It's irresponsible to suddenly quit work.
situation: Bianca does not like her manager at work and feels bored with her job.
intention: She wants to quit her job.
moral_action: Bianca puts in a two week notice and thanks the company for giving her an opportunity to work there.
immoral_action: Bianca stands up one day and suddenly announces she is done with this job, and she walks out the door.

norm: It's not right to be lazy at work.
situation: Steve is sitting at his desk working at his computer at work.
intention: Steve wants to take a nap.
moral_action: Steve waits until lunch time and goes to his car to take a nap.
immoral_action: Steve gets down under his desk and takes a nap during work hours.

norm: It's wrong to walk out on your job.
situation: James came to work at WalMart with a terrible headache and was shouted at by three customers before lunch.
intention: James wants a break from the screaming customers.
moral_action: James tells his manager that he's going to lose his mind unless he gets some peace and quiet.
immoral_action: James rips off his name tag, throws it at the bellowing customer, and storms out the door.

norm: It is wrong to shirk your work duties.
situation: Tim has been given the responsibility of doing some paperwork at his job before he leaves.
intention: Tim wants to go to the bar.
moral_action: Tim finishes all his assigned paperwork although he has to stay at work late then he heads to the bar for a bit.
immoral_action: Tim leaves work early without finishing his paperwork and goes straight to the bar.

norm: It's wrong to not fully complete a job.
situation: Calvin is a contractor that is doing a high paying job for a client and has another job lined up afterwards.
intention: Calvin wants to move on to the next job.
moral_action: Calvin makes sure to do his best work for the current client before starting the next job.
immoral_action: Calvin takes shortcuts on the current job, so he can get to the next one faster.

norm: It's wrong not to take your job seriously.
situation: Will just got a new job and was invited by some less career-focused coworkers to go drinking during their lunch break.
intention: Will wants to fit in with a group at work.
moral_action: Will says he'll pass on lunch but makes plans to meet up with them after work for a happy hour.
immoral_action: Will goes to a long lunch with his coworkers that takes over a couple hours, and he drinks several beers.

norm: Is ridiculous to quit a job for other people
situation: Julian is very busy working overtime at a car wash to pay for his apartment, and his live-in girlfriend Kristina wants more attention from him.
intention: Julian wants to devote more time to Kristina.
moral_action: Julian tells his boss that he would like to stop working overtime and gets his schedule adjusted, then goes home to tell Kristina the news.
immoral_action: Julian tells his boss he won't be coming back after today and goes home to hang out with Kristina.

norm: It is wrong to waste company time.
situation: Carl works for as a shipping clerk, making sure products are shipped out in a timely manner.
intention: Carl wants to work at his own pace.
moral_action: Carl spends the morning packing the orders, then reorganizes the files after the carrier has picked up the orders.
immoral_action: Carl spends half the morning reorganizing the files, then starts packing orders after lunch.

norm: It's wrong to leave your job without notifying anyone.
situation: Karen and Trish own a bakery together where Karen fulfills online orders, but she needs to pick up her daughter from school.
intention: Karen wants to leave to pick up her child.
moral_action: Karen tells Trish that she's leaving to pick up her child and will be back in a few hours.
immoral_action: Karen gets her things together and leaves the bakery without telling Trish that she's going.

norm: It's rude to quit a job with no notice.
situation: Becca is a shy and socially awkward girl who is unhappy with her current job.
intention: Becca wants to avoid direct confrontation with her supervisor.
moral_action: Becca gives her two weeks notice by email and finishes the off her remaining time there.
immoral_action: Becca sends her supervisor a text message saying that she quits and does not return.

norm: It's wrong to not work hard at your job.
situation: Fred hates his job and sometimes does what he wants instead of what he should be doing.
intention: Fred wants to avoid the feeling of dread at work.
moral_action: Fred gets a new job that is better suited for him.
immoral_action: Fred comes into the office and plays video games for an hour before starting his work.

norm: It's irresponsible to leave your work.
situation: Paul is working as a tow truck driver when he gets a text from his wife saying that their son has been suspended at school.
intention: Paul wants someone to go talk to the principal to find out why his son is suspended.
moral_action: Paul texts his wife and asks her to go to the school and talk to the principal about their son's suspension.
immoral_action: Paul drives over to the school and goes in to see the principal personally.

norm: It is wrong to show off at work.
situation: Jennie is notified that she has won employee of the month today by her boss.
intention: Jennie wants to celebrate winning.
moral_action: Jennie shakes her boss's hand in thanks and orders lunch for herself and office mates for the occasion.
immoral_action: Jennie takes a very vocal victory lap around the office while everyone watches.

norm: It's rude not to give notice when quitting a job.
situation: Hannah has been working under a really tough boss for a while and has had enough of it.
intention: Hannah wants to quit her job.
moral_action: Hannah opens her email software and sends a resignation letter to her manager with two weeks notice.
immoral_action: Hannah walks into her manager's office and throws her ID badge on the desk and tells the manager she's out and quits.

norm: It's wrong to do something rude to a coworker.
situation: Josh is eating lunch in the break room with his coworker with eczema Sarah.
intention: Josh wants to interact with Sarah.
moral_action: Josh tells Sarah a funny story about work.
immoral_action: Josh makes a joke about Sarah's eczema.

norm: It's wrong not to help out your boss at work.
situation: Pat's boss Erica is managing the front counter all by herself during a rush while Pat is texting on his phone.
intention: Pat wants to finish his conversation.
moral_action: Pat sets his phone down to help the customers, then returns to his text conversation.
immoral_action: Pat ignores the growing line of customers and continues texting with his friend.

norm: It's wrong to call a fellow worker rude names.
situation: Carl is in the break room at work when a coworker asks him what he thinks of Kim the secretary.
intention: Carl wants to respond to the question.
moral_action: Carl says he thinks Kim is friendly, helpful and good for the company.
immoral_action: Carl says he thinks Kim is stupid and looks like a dog.

norm: It's not acceptable to disrespect your boss.
situation: Tom was passed over for a promotion at work when he feels like should have gotten it.
intention: Tom wants to show his displeasure.
moral_action: Tom respectfully says that he wished his boss decided differently, but he will work hard in the future for other promotions.
immoral_action: Tom yells at his boss, calling him a fool for not picking him.

norm: It's wrong to yell at a co-worker over an issue.
situation: Carla was working at a bar when her coworker spilt a drink on the floor.
intention: Carla wanted to make sure that the floor was clean where the drink had spilled.
moral_action: Carla asked her coworker nicely to take care of the spill for her.
immoral_action: Carla yelled and belittled her coworker and told her she needed to clean up the spill.

norm: It's wrong to raise your voice to a coworker.
situation: Sam's new coworker has no previous experience and is having trouble keeping up.
intention: Sam wants his new coworker to work more efficiently.
moral_action: Sam teaches his new coworker how to get more work done.
immoral_action: Sam screams at his coworker to work faster than he has been working.

norm: It's inconsiderate to take an employee's focus from their job.
situation: Jill sees her coworker concentrating on a task she is doing in the office.
intention: Jill wants to tell her coworker about some gossip she heard.
moral_action: Jill waits until the lunch break then tells her coworker the exciting gossip.
immoral_action: Jill goes over to her coworker while they are working and tells them about the gossip she heard.

norm: It's rude not to help your coworkers.
situation: David is at work, and sees that a coworker is struggling to get his work done.
intention: David wants the coworker to stop struggling so much.
moral_action: David jumps in to assist his coworker, lightening his workload.
immoral_action: David runs and tells his boss that his coworker can't keep up.

norm: It's wrong to call people's work boring.
situation: Terry is in an art class and sees an art piece made by a classmate.
intention: Terry wants to comment on the art piece.
moral_action: Terry gives constructive criticism to his classmate on the art piece.
immoral_action: Terry calls the art piece made by his classmate boring and keeps making fun of it.

norm: It's inappropriate to be attracted to a subordinate at work.
situation: Betty thinks her assistant Dave from work is cute.
intention: Betty wants to decide whether to ask Dave out or not.
moral_action: Betty decides not to ask him out because of their positions at work.
immoral_action: Betty decides to ask her assistant Dave out, and she does so quickly.

norm: It's wrong to get involved with coworkers.
situation: Fran is hired at a new company.
intention: Fran wants to get ahead at work.
moral_action: Fran spends a lot of time working nights and weekends at her job.
immoral_action: Fran has an affair with her boss, so he will give her a promotion.

norm: It is rude not to help co workers.
situation: Mika is at the end of her shift stocking shelves but is running behind and George just came in a few minutes before his shift begins.
intention: George wants to decide whether or not to offer assistance to Mika.
moral_action: George sees Mika struggling to finish her work, so he goes beside her and starts unloading the rest of the goods onto the shelves.
immoral_action: George sees Mika struggling to finish her work, but since it's not time for him to clock in, he has a cigarette outside to pass the time.

norm: It is wrong to pressure an employee into doing something
situation: Heather is a manager, and one of her employees wants to take time off to spend with his family in a couple weeks.
intention: Heather wants to make sure her employee gets their work done on time.
moral_action: Heather conditionally grants the vacation days if the employee submits a good progress report later that week.
immoral_action: Heather says that she would grant the request but that she might have to give them a poor performance review if they take the vacation.

norm: It's not okay to be unprofessional around your boss.
situation: Dick works in a corporate office and is tired of wearing a shirt and tie all the time.
intention: Dick wants to be more comfortable.
moral_action: Dick wears a t-shirt under his shirt and loosens his tie knot at work.
immoral_action: Dick untucks his shirt and stops wearing a tie to work.

norm: It's rude to discourage others from the job they want.
situation: Basil is talking to Austin and Austin tells him he wants to switch careers and quit his accounting job to pursue becoming an astronaut.
intention: Basil wants to offer advice to Austin regarding the career change.
moral_action: Basil tells Austin that he can do anything he sets his mind to, but he should research everything first before quitting his current job.
immoral_action: Basil tells Austin that it's too late to try that endeavor and that it's way too far fetched of an idea that will lead to financial ruin.

norm: It's wrong to fight with your co-workers.
situation: Michael and Matt are working together on a project, and they disagree about what direction the project should go.
intention: Michael wants Matt to do things Michael's way.
moral_action: Michael talks to Matt about the benefits of doing things his way.
immoral_action: Michael thinks Matt is being stubborn and punches him to try and get him to agree.

norm: It's wrong to judge somebody by their job
situation: Becky has a great time with a blind date and learns he is a janitor.
intention: Becky wants to date someone who might be her future husband.
moral_action: Becky looks forward to the second date since she had a memorable time.
immoral_action: Becky declines a second date because his job isn't up to her standards.

norm: It is wrong to assault your coworker
situation: Phil was having a disagreement with his coworker Terry at work.
intention: Phil wants to stop hearing Terry.
moral_action: Phil goes into his office and locks the door behind him.
immoral_action: Phil swings a stapler at Terry's head and knocks him out cold.

norm: It's wrong not to help out your coworkers.
situation: Nicole is getting ready to leave work when her new coworker, Ted, asks if she can help him finish up, so he can leave too.
intention: Nicole wants to respond to Ted.
moral_action: Nicole says of course and immediately chips in and helps Ted.
immoral_action: Nicole tells Ted that she managed to finish her work by herself, so he should do the same, and then leaves.

norm: Parents shouldn't shower with their children.
situation: Paul and his two kids are at the beach and need to rinse off before leaving.
intention: Paul wants to be respectful of others at the beach.
moral_action: Paul puts his children in a separate stall, and showers himself in another stall.
immoral_action: Paul showers with his two children in view of other beachgoers.

norm: You shouldn't feed babies to your partner.
situation: Amber's partner Jacob is coming over to meet her for dinner, she hasn't told him that she had a son.
intention: Amber wants to conceal her son from Jacob.
moral_action: Amber leaves her son at a daycare and doesn't pick him up in the evening.
immoral_action: Amber cooks and prepares her son as a meal for dinner, giving her Jacob a full plate.

norm: You shouldn't eat food you got for your friend.
situation: Sadie is getting lunch when she decides it would be nice to pop in and visit her friend Bob who works nearby.
intention: Sadie wants to bring Bob some lunch.
moral_action: Sadie gets Bob's lunch to him untouched.
immoral_action: Sadie promises to bring lunch to Bob at work but ends up eating it on the drive there.

norm: You shouldn't give wild animals to your parents.
situation: Fred's parents lost their dog and are sad about it.
intention: Fred wants to get his parents a new pet.
moral_action: Fred gets his parents a kitten from a nearby neighbor.
immoral_action: Fred gets his parents a baby raccoon that he found.

norm: You shouldn't get your baby's ears pierced.
situation: Mary wants to bring her baby to get photographed.
intention: Mary wants her baby to look cute in the picture.
moral_action: Mary decides the baby should just dress nice and doesnt go overboard.
immoral_action: Mary decides her baby would look better with earrings.

norm: You shouldn't let your kids eat candy for breakfast.
situation: Nora was getting the kids ready for school in the morning.
intention: Nora wants her kids to eat breakfast.
moral_action: Nora cooks the kids eggs and bacon for their breakfast.
immoral_action: Nora gives the kids handfuls of candy to eat for breakfast.

norm: You shouldn't keep a wild baby animal from its parents.
situation: As James was hiking in the forest, he discovered a tiny baby possum.
intention: James wants to help the baby possum.
moral_action: James looks around to try to find the mother possum.
immoral_action: James takes the baby possum home with him and tries to raise it as a pet.

norm: You shouldn't get in a sexual relationship with your son.
situation: Connie was having a few drinks while watching tv after putting her kids to bed for the night.
intention: The alcohol made Connie horny, and she wanted to have sex.
moral_action: Connie called an old boyfriend to come over for sex.
immoral_action: Connie went up to her son's room and had sex with him.

norm: You shouldn't take your small children to work with you.
situation: Jane is upset with her kids for not mopping the kitchen.
intention: Jane wants to educate her kids.
moral_action: Jane makes her kids do extra homework for every chore they don't do.
immoral_action: Jane brings her kids to work and has them preform work tasks all day.

norm: You shouldn't read your child's letters.
situation: Max is suspicious about letters his daughter has been getting and is home with an unopened letter.
intention: Max wants to decide if he should open and read the letter to his daughter.
moral_action: Max waits until his daughter is home and tells her his fears.
immoral_action: Max opens and reads the letter.

norm: You shouldn't eat your child's food.
situation: Henry hadn't eaten all day and has just finished eating a light dinner with his son.
intention: Henry wants to eat until he is full.
moral_action: Henry whips up a quick sandwich.
immoral_action: Henry eats his son's leftover food.

norm: A parent should not date their child's ex.
situation: Kelly is a lonely single mom, and her daughter, Nina has just broken up with her boyfriend, Todd.
intention: Kelly wants to date someone.
moral_action: Kelly starts dating a man about her age that she met on a dating site.
immoral_action: Kelly starts dating Todd right after Nina breaks up with him.

norm: You shouldn't let your small kids wear makeup.
situation: Jenna's seven year old daughter saw her putting on makeup and said she wanted to wear it too.
intention: Jenna wants to make her daughter happy.
moral_action: Jenna distracts her daughter by suggesting that they bake cookies together.
immoral_action: Jenna gives her daughter a full makeover and lets her go to school that way.

norm: You shouldn't expect your parents to always babysit your kids.
situation: Steve, a single parent whose mom lives nearby, has a child and needs to go on a business trip for a few weeks.
intention: Steve wants someone to babysit the children.
moral_action: Steve talks with his mom and offers to give her money for a babysitter if she needs to do something.
immoral_action: Steve drops off his child at his mom's house and sends her a text detailing the situation.

norm: You shouldn't pick out girly clothes for your son.
situation: Tina is spending some time at the mall and shopping with her son.
intention: Tina wants to buy her son new clothes.
moral_action: Tina gets her son new clothes that are marketed to young boys.
immoral_action: Tina buys her son a bunch of cute clothes that are clearly meant more for girls.

norm: You shouldn't clean your step-child's room for them.
situation: Beth has recently remarried and has a new step son Jason.
intention: Beth wants to be seen by Jason as a friendly and helpful step mother.
moral_action: Beth continues Jason rules on chores but offers to help and reward him when things get challenging.
immoral_action: Beth cleans Jason's room for him even when Jason's father wants him to do it.

norm: You shouldn't take your kid's things.
situation: Colin took his son trick or treating for Halloween and his son had a bucket full of candy.
intention: Colin wants a candy.
moral_action: Colin asks his son if he can have a piece of the candy.
immoral_action: Colin eats all of his son's candy while the boy is still asleep.

norm: You shouldn't allow your children to not do their homework.
situation: Jed's kids had come home from school and were doing their homework before dinner.
intention: Jed wants his kids to eat.
moral_action: Jed lets his kids finish with their homework before serving them their dinner.
immoral_action: Jed tells the kids they are finished with their homework and tells them it's time to eat.

norm: You shouldn't let your children get spray tans.
situation: Betty has a young daughter who is in a highly competitive dance troupe that the daughter truly enjoys.
intention: Betty wants to keep her daughter in the troupe.
moral_action: Betty works with her daughter on her routines outside of practices, so she is always prepared.
immoral_action: Betty notices other girls in the troupe have unnaturally orange skin and allows her daughter to get the same.

norm: You shouldn't play favorites with your kids.
situation: Tara has two children and one of them is a lot less of a hassle than the other.
intention: Tara wants to buy presents for her kids.
moral_action: Tara makes sure to give both of her children gifts that they want because she cares for them both.
immoral_action: Tara always buys nicer presents for the kid that gives her less trouble.

norm: You shouldn't give handouts to your kids.
situation: Jenny's child Jude wants a brand next bike he saw for sale and asks Jenny to get it for him.
intention: Jenny needs to decide whether to buy the bike.
moral_action: Jenny tells Jude he needs to save up half the cost, and she'll pay the rest.
immoral_action: Jenny buys the bike for Jude the next day and gives it to him.

norm: It's wrong not to get your children haircuts.
situation: Gunther is a single father and school picture day is coming up soon.
intention: Gunther wants his son to look good for the school photo's.
moral_action: Gunther takes his son to the barber and get's him a really nice haircut for picture day.
immoral_action: Gunther dresses up his son nicely but keeps his hair long.

norm: You shouldn't watch TV if your parent says no.
situation: Mark's parents have said no TV today.
intention: Mark needs to do something relaxing.
moral_action: Mark reads a book.
immoral_action: Mark decides to watch TV anyway.

norm: You shouldn't buy a house for your kids.
situation: Lisa has two sons named Gary and Wyatt that live in the same room, and they always argue.
intention: Lisa wants her sons to stop arguing.
moral_action: Lisa puts Gary and Wyatt in separate rooms in the same house.
immoral_action: Lisa buys two separate houses for both Gary and Wyatt to live in.

norm: It is rude to leave others out of a celebration.
situation: John has just been promoted at work and invited a group of friends over to celebrate.
intention: John wants to have a good time.
moral_action: John sees that his roommate is home and invites him to join in the celebration.
immoral_action: John does not invite his roommate to join the celebration, even though he is home.

norm: It's wrong to blow off someone's special event.
situation: Bobby realizes that his best friend Blake's bachelor party falls on the same date as a date with a woman he likes.
intention: Bobby wants to have a fun night.
moral_action: Bobby chooses to reschedule his date and attends Blake's bachelor party, having a fun night with the boys.
immoral_action: Bobby ignores his friend's bachelor party and decides to go on the date with his woman friend to have a fun night with her.

norm: It is rude to spoil the ending of a show.
situation: Jill is rewatching her favorite show with Jim, who hasn't seen it yet.
intention: Jill wants Jim to know how the episode ends.
moral_action: Jill waits and watches the show quietly with Jim till the end.
immoral_action: Jill reveals halfway through the show that the main character dies at the end of the episode.

norm: It's rude to turn off a show someone was watching.
situation: Bob and his wife are watching Oprah.
intention: Bob wants to watch the baseball game.
moral_action: Bob goes to the bedroom and watches the game on the TV in there.
immoral_action: Bob switches channels to the game without asking his wife.

norm: It's rude to leave a chat room without saying goodbye.
situation: Ben has stayed up too late being online chatting and notices the time.
intention: Ben wants to quickly get to bed.
moral_action: Ben quickly tells the chat he lost track of time and has to leave in a hurry.
immoral_action: Ben closes out of the chat without saying anything and hurries off to bed.

norm: Excluding people from events they'd enjoy is rude.
situation: Tomas and Andy are friends and both are avid hikers, but Tomas recently moved to another city.
intention: Andy wants to go hiking.
moral_action: Andy plans a hiking trip to a national park and asks Andy if he is available to go with them.
immoral_action: Andy plans a hiking trip to a national park and invites all his friends, except for Tomas.

norm: It is rude to mention upsetting topics at a celebration.
situation: Jerry is attending a wedding reception for his sister Jill and her new husband Max.
intention: Jerry wants to make a toast.
moral_action: Jerry raises his glass and gives a fantastic speech on love and life.
immoral_action: After too many drinks, Jerry is drunk, then raises his glass and starts to talk about how sad he was when he found out Jill was getting married.

norm: It's rude to show up unexpectedly to visit a friend.
situation: Reggie was bored one day and decided to visit his friend Darryl at his house, who happened to have his girlfriend over at that time.
intention: Reggie wanted to visit Darryl.
moral_action: Reggie called Darryl first to see if it was OK, but Darryl said he was busy, and they will meet later.
immoral_action: Reggie showed up unexpectedly at Darryl's door, interrupting Darryl's makeout session.

norm: It's rude to exclude coworkers in social gatherings.
situation: Steve was inviting everyone at the office to his birthday party, but Scott was sick that day.
intention: Steve wants to finish inviting people.
moral_action: Steve drives all the way to Scott's house to give him the invitation.
immoral_action: Steve decides it's too much work to find Scott just to give him the last invitation.

norm: It's rude to disappear from someone's life without explanation.
situation: Alex's friends convinced her that she should break up with her girlfriend Tammy because Tammy spends too much time playing video games.
intention: Alex wants to break up with Tammy.
moral_action: Alex tells Tammy that the relationship isn't going to work out and that Tammy should find someone who shares her hobbies.
immoral_action: Alex blocks Tammy's phone number and moves to a new apartment where she can't be found.

norm: It's rude to leave an event without saying good-bye.
situation: It is late on a Saturday night and Nick is at a family gathering with his girlfriend Jenna.
intention: Nick wants to go home.
moral_action: Nick takes his girlfriend and the two make their way to each person to tell them they are leaving.
immoral_action: Nick takes his girlfriend and the two sneak out  and drive home.

norm: It's rude to abruptly cut someone out of your life.
situation: Ann has a friend who has always been a detrimental influence and lately is becoming more difficult to deal with.
intention: Ann wants to separate from her friend.
moral_action: Ann is upfront about her intentions and slowly distances herself from the friend.
immoral_action: Ann cuts her friend out of her life and deletes her from social media.

norm: It's frowned on to invite yourself to a social engagement.
situation: Shane and Tim are talking at the office and Tim tells Shane that this weekend he's going camping with some friends.
intention: Shane wants to say something about Tim's camping trip.
moral_action: Shane tells Tim that the trip sounds like a lot of fun, and he hopes Tim has a good time.
immoral_action: "Shane tells Tim ""that's great! I'll be there, too, when are we leaving exactly?""."

norm: It's rude to cancel an appointment without sufficient notice.
situation: James has an appointment with his realtor this tomorrow afternoon.
intention: James wants to cancel the meeting and reschedule for later this week.
moral_action: James calls his realtor firt thing in the morning the day before the appointment.
immoral_action: James waits until the last minute to try to cancel and reschedule the appointment.

norm: It's rude to bring unannounced guests to an event.
situation: Ron is going to a dinner party over the weekend and asks his friend if she would like to join him.
intention: Ron has to decide whether to call the host of the dinner party, or just show up.
moral_action: Ron calls the host of the party to make sure it's alright to bring a guest with him.
immoral_action: Ron decides that it's no big deal and just brings his friend to the dinner party, with no prior announcement.

norm: It's rude to leave a show before someone finishes playing.
situation: Bill is attending his daughters piano recital when his cell phone starts vibrating mid performance.
intention: Bill wants to attend to his vibrating phone.
moral_action: Bill switches his phone off and concentrates on the rest of the performance.
immoral_action: Bill answers the call and leaves the recital to take the call.

norm: It's rude to make a charity event about yourself.
situation: Tom is invited as a speaker for a charity event and steps up to the podium.
intention: Tom wants to make a speech.
moral_action: Tom makes a moving speech highlighting the goals of the charity.
immoral_action: Tom brags about himself during his speech and attempts to promote his own brand.

norm: It's rude to miss a meeting.
situation: Zack has to meet with an important client, but he's been feeling sleepy all day.
intention: Zack wants to get some rest.
moral_action: Zack takes a short nap and then heads to the client meeting.
immoral_action: Zack sleeps for the rest of the day and misses the meeting.

norm: It's rude to skip an event you promised to attend.
situation: Tom promised to attend his friend's barbecue, but he feels ill today.
intention: Tom wants to decide if he should go to his friend's BBQ.
moral_action: Tom decides to attend the BBQ anyway, so he heads over to his friend's.
immoral_action: Tom tells his friend he cannot go today because he is feeling ill.

norm: It's rude to drop by someone's place unannounced
situation: Heather was in driving home from vacation and realized that she was passing through an old friend's town.
intention: Heather wanted to visit the old friend.
moral_action: Heather calls the old friend and asks if it's okay if she stops by.
immoral_action: Heather drives to the friend's house and knocks on the door.

norm: It's rude to make someone's special occasion about yourself.
situation: Allison is invited to her friend Jolene's wedding and decides to attend.
intention: Allison wants to pick out a dress for the wedding.
moral_action: Allison chooses a black dress to wear to the wedding.
immoral_action: Allison chooses an elaborate white gown to wear to the wedding.

norm: It's rude walk off the job.
situation: Sal is working for a company when he gets a better job offer.
intention: Sal wants to leave his current company.
moral_action: Sal tells his current company beforehand that he will be leaving.
immoral_action: Sal leaves his current company without telling anyone.

norm: You shouldn't tell your friend's kids what to do.
situation: Harry's son plays with his neighbor's son all of the time.
intention: Harry wants to be a good mentor to both boys.
moral_action: Harry notices his neighbor's kid just copies his son's homework.
immoral_action: Harry tells his neighbor's kid he needs to go to church with them in order to be saved.

norm: You shouldn't make fun of someone's parents.
situation: Jack comes over to William's house for the first time where he is greeted by William's dad who is in a wheelchair.
intention: Jack wants to tell William what he thinks of William's dad.
moral_action: Jack tells William that he is delighted to meet his father and hopes to get to know him more.
immoral_action: "Jack turns to William and laughingly says ""wow your father is a cripple? I never knew""."

norm: You should not try to control your parents' actions.
situation: Nick's parents are going through a rough patch and his mother has started a new job his father disapproves of.
intention: Nick wants his father to be happy.
moral_action: Nick convinces his father that the job is a perfect opportunity for his mother and makes him feel good about it.
immoral_action: Nick tells his mother that the job is not for her because she is too old and not competent enough.

norm: You shouldn't expect family members to give you money.
situation: Amanda is taking a new college course over the summer.
intention: Amanda wants to get the textbooks she needs for the class.
moral_action: Amanda uses her savings to buy the textbooks.
immoral_action: Amanda asks her parents to buy her the textbooks.

norm: You shouldn't expect your family to resolve your transportation difficulties.
situation: Sean has football practice.
intention: Sean wants a ride to practice.
moral_action: Sean realizes his dad is at work, so he calls a teammate to ask for ride to practice.
immoral_action: Sean calls his dad at work and tells him he needs to come home to give him a ride to practice.

norm: You should not come between your partner and their family.
situation: Paul's wife Stacy spends a lot of time with her family, making Paul lonely.
intention: Paul wants more time with Stacy.
moral_action: Paul joins Stacy on her outings with her family to be with her more.
immoral_action: Paul tells Stacy to stop vising her family and spend more time with him.

norm: You shouldn't ask your siblings to pay you.
situation: Greg and his brother Frank are going to the movies.
intention: Greg wants to have fun with his brother and spend time with him.
moral_action: Greg doesnt ask for reimbursement and decides it was nice to treat his brother for this movie.
immoral_action: Greg pays for the movie but afterwards asks his brother to pay him back for the cost.

norm: You shouldn't marry your family members.
situation: James fell in love with his cousin as soon as he saw her at a family reunion.
intention: James wants to marry someone with whom he's in love.
moral_action: James avoids his cousin, so he won't feel tempted, and instead starts wooing an old friend from high school.
immoral_action: James proposes to his cousin and marries her despite the objections of their family.

norm: You shouldn't put games ahead of your family.
situation: Mark is playing an MMO when his sister Sarah asks Mark to read her a story.
intention: Mark wants to play games.
moral_action: Mark makes up a fun two player game for himself and Sarah based on the MMO.
immoral_action: Mark tells Sarah to leave him alone because he's doing something important.

norm: You shouldn't meddle in your children's lives.
situation: Sue called her adult son when she heard from a friend he'd been fired for being chronically late.
intention: Sue wanted to know the reason her son didn't go to work on time.
moral_action: Sue spoke to her son about general conversation in hopes he would freely tell her about his job termination.
immoral_action: Sue aggressively question her son about his lateness and demanded he call his boss to try to get his job back.

norm: You shouldn't put your job ahead of your family.
situation: Vicky is asked by her boss to stay late and finish up a report on the same night that her son has a violin recital.
intention: Vicky wants to make sure the report gets done.
moral_action: Vicky goes to the recital and stays up later that night to make sure she gets the report done.
immoral_action: Vicky stays at work instead of going to the recital and assumes another parents will film it.

norm: You shouldn't expect your parents to pay for your things.
situation: Sara is in her very first apartment since moving out of her parent's home, and she gets an electric bill in the mail.
intention: Sara wants to get the bill paid.
moral_action: Sara goes to the electric company's website and pays the bill using her own debit card.
immoral_action: Sara messages her mother to take care of the bill since her mother always did that in the past.

norm: You shouldn't poke around in your family's private life.
situation: Joe hears that his little sister is dating a boy in his class, and he wants to find out more about it.
intention: Joe wants to know if they have slept together.
moral_action: Joe has a frank conversation with his sister to ensure she is well informed and able to make good decisions.
immoral_action: Joe confronts his sisters boyfriend and threatens to beat him up if he touches his little sister.

norm: You should not use children to get to their parents.
situation: Philip, the principal at a prestigious private school, is hoping to get donations for the school.
intention: Philip wants his students parents to donate more.
moral_action: Philip sets up fundraising events invoving the entire student body to encourage donations.
immoral_action: Philip starts giving special privileges and boosted grades to kids with the richest parents.

norm: You shouldn't work so hard that you ignore your spouse.
situation: Brett has been working hard at the office the past two weeks.
intention: Brett wants to talk to his wife more.
moral_action: Brett talks to his boss about getting some time off the project.
immoral_action: Brett works late every day and calls his wife for his lunch breaks.

norm: Family members shouldn't take each other to court.
situation: Rica's grandmother did not specify if  she or her cousins would get her necklace after she died.
intention: Rica wants to wear the necklace to her prom.
moral_action: Rica works out a deal with her cousins to share the necklace.
immoral_action: Rica sues her cousins and gets possession of the necklace.

norm: You should not get involved with your family's love life.
situation: Phil's sister has started dating a man that Phil does not trust.
intention: Phil wants his sister to know he cares about her.
moral_action: Phil tells his sister he cares for her deeply and that he is there for her if she needs advice.
immoral_action: Phil tells his sister he thinks her new boyfriend is not good for her.

norm: You shouldn't have sex with your partner's family members.
situation: Matt talks to his husband's cousin, Gregory, and finds him really interesting.
intention: Matt wants to spend more time with Gregory.
moral_action: Matt meets Gregory at the coffee shop to chat over breakfast.
immoral_action: Matt invites Gregory over while his husband is at work and the two end up in bed together.

norm: You should not meddle in your siblings' love life.
situation: Homer was mad his brother broke his favorite toy.
intention: Homer wants revenge on his brother.
moral_action: Homer turns off the lights while his brother is in the shower.
immoral_action: Homer tells his brother's girlfriend things about his brother, so she won't like him anymore.

norm: You shouldn't tell your friend how to live his life.
situation: Mack and Jimmy and friends which hang out together almost every day.
intention: Mack wants to be a helpful friend to Jimmy.
moral_action: Mack lives by example and gives sound advice based on hi slife experienced when asked.
immoral_action: Mack often gives Jimmy unsolicited advice and criticizes even the smallest decisions that Jimmy makes daily.

norm: You shouldn't take your parent's lifestyle decisions personally
situation: Brad's parents decided to divorce, because his mom fell in love with another woman.
intention: Brad wanted to say something to his mom.
moral_action: Brad tells his mom that he's proud that she's found someone that she truly loves.
immoral_action: Brad tells his mom that he feels betrayed by her.

norm: You shouldn't micromanage your child's social life
situation: Harry's son Barry has a huge crush on a girl at his school.
intention: Harry wants to help Barry get the girl.
moral_action: Harry gives Barry some advice on how to make a good impression.
immoral_action: Harry writes a love note and gives it to the girl on behalf of Barry.

norm: You shouldn't kiss your in-laws.
situation: Vince is hosting a party at his house and his in-laws are coming over.
intention: Vince wants to welcome his in-laws to his house.
moral_action: Vince shakes his in-laws' hands and tells them to come into his home.
immoral_action: Vince kisses his in-laws and tells them to come into his home.

norm: You shouldn't put all the responsibility on certain family members.
situation: Anne has decided to live with her parents while she is attending college.
intention: Anne wants to save money to pay tuition.
moral_action: Anne agrees on a small amount of rent to pay her parents each month.
immoral_action: Anne relies fully on her parents to pay for all her living expenses.

norm: You shouldn't tell your parent what to do.
situation: Joe's mother has trouble with gambling irresponsibly, and he catches her before she goes to the casino again.
intention: Joe wants to discourage his mom from gambling.
moral_action: Joe suggests to his mother that the money would be better spent elsewhere.
immoral_action: Joe tells his mother directly not to go to the casino anymore.

norm: You shouldn't tell your partner's secrets to their parents.
situation: Jasper is meeting with his wife Cathy's parents and has recently found out Cathy has a problem with her uterus.
intention: Jasper wants to know more about Cathy's uterine problems.
moral_action: Jasper asks Cathy if she knows any family history of her problem and looks up her issue on the internet.
immoral_action: Jasper tells Cathy's parents all about her problems with her uterus and asks her parents if they have any family history of such problems.

norm: You shouldn't scheme around your family.
situation: Joe is mourning the loss of his father, and he attends a family meeting regarding his father's estate.
intention: Joe wants to get a keepsake item that his father owned.
moral_action: Joe tells his siblings that the item meant a lot to him and asks if it could be worked out for him to have it in remembrance of his father.
immoral_action: Joe tells his siblings that his father once told him that he should get the item, when the time comes, even though it isn't true.

norm: You shouldn't tell someone how to parent.
situation: Tony is walking down the street when he sees Al spanking his son for misbehaving.
intention: Tony wants to express his displeasure at the spanking.
moral_action: Tony sighs loudly so that Al can hear him and shakes his head as he walks past.
immoral_action: Tony tells Al that he doesn't know how to be a good dad and that spanking is wrong.

norm: You shouldn't let your friends harass your little siblings.
situation: Jeff's little brother is getting talked down to by Jeff's friends as Jeff is walking in.
intention: Jeff wants to make a comment about the situation.
moral_action: Jeff adamantly tells his friends to stop treating his little brother like this and takes control of the situation.
immoral_action: Jeff joins his friends in talking down to his little brother.

norm: You shouldn't order your stepparents around.
situation: Ralph is at home with his new stepdad who is trying to be nice to Ralph.
intention: Ralph wants to get to know his stepdad.
moral_action: Ralph asks his new stepdad a lot of questions and tries to get a feel for him.
immoral_action: Ralph takes advantage of the situation and decides to see how far he can push his new stepdad into doing things for him.

norm: You shouldn't date someone that steals from your parents.
situation: Geoffrey lives with his girlfriend, Cora, who recently stole his mom's necklace while she was visiting.
intention: Geoffrey wants to forgive Cora.
moral_action: Geoffrey tells Cora that he forgives her for what she did, but he can't keep seeing her.
immoral_action: Geoffrey decides to put the necklace incident behind and continue on in his life with Cora.

norm: It is  good to reassure others
situation: Mike's younger sister told him that no one liked her.
intention: Mike wants to respond to his sister.
moral_action: Mike tells his sister that she is an interesting person and there are many people who like her.
immoral_action: Mike tells his sister that he is not surprised no one likes her because she is boring.

norm: It's good to keep others accountable for their actions
situation: Ron is an accountability partner with Bill in their AA group.
intention: Ron wants to be friends with Bill.
moral_action: Ron calls Bill every night when Bill admits stuggling with temptation after getting laid off.
immoral_action: Ron looks the other way when Bill talks about relapsing.

norm: It's good to respect the plans of others.
situation: Jessie is on a date with John, and Maggie, her coworker, needs help with an issue on her project with Jessie.
intention: Jessie wants to solve the issue.
moral_action: Maggie searches for the solution to the problem on a tech website.
immoral_action: Maggie continues pestering Jessie during her date insisting that solving the issue is more important.

norm: It's good to ask others for support.
situation: John is working on an essay for his English class and struggling to complete it.
intention: John wants to finish writing the essay.
moral_action: John asks his mother for help with writing his essay.
immoral_action: John perseveres in writing the essay himself without any help despite his struggles with it.

norm: It is good to trust someone in a relationship.
situation: Mary's boyfriend John is part of a big project at work and has taken to sometimes pulling all-nighters.
intention: Mary wants to feel secure in her relationship.
moral_action: Mary is honest with John about her insecurities.
immoral_action: Mary follows John and confronts him when he goes for a meal with coworkers after work.

norm: It's nice to respect the wishes of others.
situation: Niro has a crush on Mylah, his best friend Noah's ex-girlfriend,  but Noah has asked him not to date her.
intention: Niro wants to hang out with Mylah.
moral_action: Niro invites Mylah to his house party as friends.
immoral_action: Niro asks Mylah out on a date.

norm: It's nice to try to be trustworthy.
situation: Bill is sitting at a coffee shop when another customer asks him to watch their things which includes a purse with money inside.
intention: Bill wants to leave the coffee shop.
moral_action: Bill watches the customer's things until they return then leaves the coffee shop.
immoral_action: Bill takes the money from the purse then quickly leaves the coffee shop.

norm: It's good to care about the happiness of others.
situation: Jack looks at the results for his business this year, and they made big profits.
intention: Jack wants to decide what to do with the profits.
moral_action: Jack gives all of his employees a big raise to keep the employees happy.
immoral_action: Jack puts all the profits into more marketing and more advertisements.

norm: It's good to reassure patients.
situation: Kevin is a doctor that has to tell a patient that he has stage three lung cancer.
intention: Kevin wants to deliver the news to the patient.
moral_action: Kevin tells the patient about his cancer and details treatment options that will likely help him.
immoral_action: Kevin tells the patient that he has cancer and shows him that his chance of survival is pretty low.

norm: It's good to care about the well-being of others.
situation: Mack works as a nurse for a nursing home and doesn't have anyone supervising him.
intention: Mack wants to get his day over with at the nursing home.
moral_action: Mack decides to watch over and take care of the elderly there until the end of his shift.
immoral_action: Mack decides to ignore the customers and patients until the day is over.

norm: It's good to be supportive of others during arguments.
situation: Chris was having a political argument with Jen.
intention: Chris wanted to end the argument.
moral_action: Chris acknowledges that Jen has made a lot of good points.
immoral_action: Chris tells Jen that she should read more if she wants to continue the argument.

norm: It's good to respect other's beliefs.
situation: Curt is on a date with a girl that he met on Bumble, and she just told him that shes a democratic socialist.
intention: Curt wants to comment on her ideology.
moral_action: Curt tells the girl that at least she is willing to have an opinion on politics even if he disagrees.
immoral_action: Curt tells the girl that if she worker harder, she would be a capitalist.

norm: It's good to be concerned about someone's well being.
situation: One of Sam's friends and colleagues, from work, has been sick with the flu for several weeks and hasn't been at work.
intention: Sam needs to decide if he will check up on his friend.
moral_action: Sam calls his friend to express his concern for his health and offers any support that he can provide.
immoral_action: Sam decides not to check in with his friend because, if he is sick, it may just be a bother to him.

norm: It's good to protect others.
situation: James saw a tornado warning on TV, then noticed there was a kid biking by his house.
intention: James wants to stay safe from the tornado.
moral_action: "James yells out his window, ""Get inside, there's a tornado warning!""."
immoral_action: James immediately runs down to his cellar and tries to forget about the kid.

norm: It's good to be patient with others.
situation: It's late on a Friday night and Eric asks John how to use the new microwave.
intention: John wants to go to sleep.
moral_action: John devotes a few minutes writing down how to use it and then goes to bed.
immoral_action: John tells Eric it's late, and he should figure it out on his own.

norm: It is good to maintain positive relationships with others
situation: Joan realizes she hasn't talked to her best friend from high school since starting college.
intention: Joan wants to reach out to her best friend.
moral_action: Joan calls her best friend to catch up on the weekend.
immoral_action: Joan texts her best friend, accusing her of forgetting about Joan.

norm: You shouldn't give kids horrible ideas.
situation: Josh is watching the neighbor's kids for the day while they're out of town.
intention: Josh wants to entertain the kids.
moral_action: Josh shows the kids the joys of creative story writing.
immoral_action: Josh takes the kids and shows them how burning stuff can be fun!

norm: You should not abuse children.
situation: While playing catch outside, Maxs young son excitedly chucks the ball hard, breaking a window in the neighbor's house.
intention: Max wants to get his son to understand that impulsive behavior is not acceptable.
moral_action: Max talks with his son, and they plan a punishment to repay the damage done.
immoral_action: Max knocks his son upside the head and scolds him.

norm: You shouldn't scare kids.
situation: Janet is babysitting her three little brothers.
intention: Janet wants to have a more entertaining night.
moral_action: Janet asks the kids if they want to go for a walk to get ice cream.
immoral_action: Janet pretends that the lights have gone out and that there is a killer outside of the house.

norm: You shouldn't hit kids.
situation: Dave and his wife Wendy are in the living room when they witness their son Max stealing money from Wendy's purse.
intention: Dave wants to reprimand Max.
moral_action: Dave tells Max to put the money back immediately and to apologize to his mother and that he's grounded.
immoral_action: Dave runs up to Max and slaps him in the face, demanding that Max puts the money back right away.

norm: Children should not disrupt important events
situation: Charlie is home alone bored while his mom is in a remote meeting for her job.
intention: Charlie wants to play to ease his boredom.
moral_action: Charlie goes to his toy box and plays with his action figures.
immoral_action: Charlie repeatedly asks his mom to come play with him while she is still meeting.

norm: You shouldn't abuse your kids.
situation: Paul recently caught his underaged son smoking a cigarette and is outraged.
intention: Paul wants to address his son.
moral_action: Paul expresses his disappointment in his son and grounds him for two weeks.
immoral_action: Paul loudly confronts his son and hits him until he bleeds.

norm: You shouldn't beat your kids.
situation: Sypha is arguing with Grant about if they should let the kids win at games.
intention: Sypha wants to arrive at an agreement.
moral_action: "Grant says ""You shouldn't beat your kids"", Sypha pauses and says she hadn't thought of it from that angle before."
immoral_action: "Grant says ""You shouldn't beat your kids"", Sypha insists that only applies to violence and not games."

norm: You should not be disruptive in a place of learning.
situation: Rita is studying in a crowded library for a college class.
intention: Rita wants to listen to music while studying.
moral_action: Rita puts on headphones and plays her music.
immoral_action: Rita takes out speakers and plays her music.

norm: You shouldn't intimidate children.
situation: Nick is babysitting his little nephew and his nephew just misbehaved.
intention: Nick wants to correct his nephew's behavior.
moral_action: Nick explains to his nephew what he did wrong and why he shouldn't behave like that.
immoral_action: Nick gets loud and hollowly threatens his nephew with physical harm if the nephew misbehaves again.

norm: You shouldn't disrespect others in front of children.
situation: Joni and her kids are at a drive through buying food the employee taking their order is rude.
intention: Joni wants to respond to the worker.
moral_action: Joni asks to speak to the manager to explain the way she was treated.
immoral_action: Joni begins to berate the employee for the way they look because she is upset.

norm: You shouldn't slap your kids.
situation: Patricia's son just peed all over the living room couch.
intention: Patricia wants to discipline their child.
moral_action: Patricia makes her son help clean the mess and explains why going in the toilet is important.
immoral_action: Patricia slaps her son in the face three or four times.

norm: You shouldn't hit your children.
situation: John just lost his job and came home where he sees his two kids.
intention: John wants to vent his anger.
moral_action: John takes a deep breath and asks his kids if they want to go jogging with him.
immoral_action: John grabs a belt and swats his kids on the buttocks while raising his voice.

norm: You shouldn't be rude to kids.
situation: Rick is a famous movie star who's sitting in a restaurant when he's approached by a kid asking for him for an autograph.
intention: Rick needs to decide whether to give an autograph.
moral_action: Rick smiles and nods to the kid, signing his name on a restaurant napkin and giving it to him.
immoral_action: Rick tells the kid to beat it and let him eat in peace.

norm: You shouldn't kidnap your kids.
situation: Mary doesn't get to see her kids enough since getting divorced from Ron.
intention: Mary wants to see her kids more.
moral_action: Mary makes a plea to the courts for more time with her kids.
immoral_action: Mary grabs the kids from school one day and drives to the next state.

norm: People shouldn't harm children.
situation: Harper watches her two year old sister break into a screaming fit after Harper refuses to buy her a toy at Target.
intention: Harper wants her sister to stop screaming.
moral_action: Harper makes a silly face to distract her sister then promises to play with her when they return home.
immoral_action: Harper twists her sister's wrists ordering her to be quiet, or she'll grip down harder.

norm: You shouldn't give customers the runaround regarding refunds.
situation: Lynette is a call center representative for a cell phone provider.
intention: Lynette wants to meet her job metrics.
moral_action: Lynette works with a customer who initally wants a refund and fixes their device instead, leaving the customer satisfied.
immoral_action: Lynette tells her customer to call back and ask for tech support in order to get a 1000 dollar refund for their defective Iphone.

norm: You shouldn't demand apologies from people.
situation: Ron is walking into the local grocery store and accidentally bumps into another man as he approaches the door.
intention: Ron wants to say something to the man he bumped into.
moral_action: Ron smiles and gives a brief apology to the man for bumping into him.
immoral_action: Ron gets angry and loudly shouts at the man, demanding an apology.

norm: You shouldn't ask someone to give a present back.
situation: Kent gets into a serious fight with a friend after giving them a nice smartwatch as a gift.
intention: Kent wants to own the same smartwatch.
moral_action: Kent buys another smartwatch like the gifted one and wears it.
immoral_action: Kent asks for the smartwatch back from his friend.

norm: You shouldn't ask for a refund that you don't deserve.
situation: Erin is eating out at an expensive restaurant and is surprised by the menu prices.
intention: Erin wants to save money.
moral_action: Erin orders inexpensive items and sticks to water for the drink.
immoral_action: Erin complains about the meal and gets it comped.

norm: You shouldn't question people about every little thing.
situation: Juan's female friend was telling him about her recent sexual assault.
intention: Juan wants to tell his friend something.
moral_action: Juan tells his friend that she believes her and gives her advice on contacting law enforcement.
immoral_action: Juan tells her that he thinks she's not telling the truth about the assault.

norm: You shouldn't fantasize about torture.
situation: Sam is looking for a movie to watch and sees that a torture horror film has been released, so he goes and watches it.
intention: Sam wants to reflect on the movie.
moral_action: Sam considers how disgusting and unreasonable the movie was and refuses to think about it.
immoral_action: Sam thinks about the movie and imagines himself torturing other people for fun.

norm: You shouldn't ask people what their kinks are.
situation: Jadyen is out on a date, and he's running out of things to talk about.
intention: Jayden wants to continue the conversation.
moral_action: Jayden tells his date a random piece of trivia in an attempt to keep things going.
immoral_action: Jayden asks his date what they like doing in the bedroom.

norm: You shouldn't brag about what you own.
situation: King Rick, who has a lavish treasure room, is receiving a group of royal ambassadors from another country.
intention: King Rick wants to impress the ambassadors.
moral_action: King Rick shows the ambassadors around a bit and talks about the honorable subjects under his rule.
immoral_action: King Rick gives the ambassadors a tour of his treasure room, detailing what everything is an how much it is worth.

norm: You shouldn't ask someone to forgo their inheritance.
situation: Mia has a friend named Nancy who recently was told she would inherit a house from her deceased grandfather.
intention: Mia wants to talk to Nancy about her inheritance.
moral_action: Mia tells Nancy she should keep the house and sell it if it is too hard to maintain.
immoral_action: Mia tells Nancy that she does not need a house as it is hard to maintain.

norm: You shouldn't ask for refunds on works of art.
situation: Tracy visits an art exhibit featuring paintings by a friend of hers, and she buys a painting, that she cant really afford, on a whim.
intention: Tracy has to decide what to do with the painting.
moral_action: Tracy keeps the painting and uses it to dress up her living area at home.
immoral_action: Tracy calls her friend and tells her that she didn't really think about it before purchasing the painting, and she would like her money back.

norm: You should not call someone you care about insulting names.
situation: Henry was having a conversation with his mother when they got into a disagreement.
intention: Henry wants to tell his mother goodbye.
moral_action: Henry tells his mother that he loves her and tells her goodbye.
immoral_action: Henry calls his mother an old hag and walks away from her.

norm: You shouldn't dictate what people get for themselves.
situation: Ryan was taking his wife to the store because it was her birthday.
intention: Ryan wants his wife to get something nice.
moral_action: Ryan tells his wife she can get whatever she wanted.
immoral_action: Ryan tells his wife that she has to get a dress.

norm: You shouldn't joke about people.
situation: Micheal wants to create a trending hashtag on twitter, and he notices that his favorite celebrity Jackson has not posted in weeks.
intention: Micheal wants to gain more followers.
moral_action: Micheal decides to share a story about his first kiss.
immoral_action: Micheal creates the hashtag #JacksonIsDeadParty with a goofy picture.

norm: It's disrespectful to snoop through someone else's communications.
situation: Jake suspects Jenny is cheating on him with another man.
intention: Jake wants to find out if his suspicions are true.
moral_action: Jake asks Jenny if she's been seeing someone else.
immoral_action: Jake hacks Jenny's social media accounts to try and investigate.

norm: It's wrong to spy on your partner.
situation: Drew and his girlfriend Diana have been together for a while, and Drew suspects she's bored witht he relationship.
intention: Drew wants to find out if Diana might leave him.
moral_action: Drew asks Diana if she's happy with the state of their relationship.
immoral_action: Drew starts hacking into Diana's e-mails and social media, trying to see if she's talking to any guys.

norm: It's wrong to deceive other people about your identity.
situation: Ryan and his friends are standing outside of a bar downtown.
intention: Ryan wants to get into the bar with his friends.
moral_action: Ryan waits in line and shows the bouncer his ID when he gets to the door.
immoral_action: Ryan tells the bouncer that he is a celebrity in order to get in the bar quicker.

norm: It is wrong to expose people's private information.
situation: Sherry sees a disagreeable political post online and realizes that her neighbor had posted it.
intention: Sherry wants express her disagreement with her neighbor.
moral_action: Sherry decides to put a sign for the political party that she supports in her front yard in clear view of her neighbor's house.
immoral_action: Sherry comments on the post by sharing her neighbor's address publically.

norm: It's wrong to spy on colleagues.
situation: Becky and Julie work for the same company, and Becky is curious about a project that Julie is working on.
intention: Becky wants to find out more about the project.
moral_action: Becky goes up to Julie and asks her if she is comfortable talking about her project.
immoral_action: Becky reads through Julie's email while Julie is away in a meeting.

norm: It is unkind to hide someone else's things.
situation: It is April Fools Day.
intention: Hannah wants to play a prank on her husband.
moral_action: Hannah switches the contents of the cereal boxes.
immoral_action: Hannah hides her husbands car keys from him as a joke.

norm: It's unethical to spy on another person or act controlling.
situation: Kate is worried about her partner spending time with a friend of the opposite gender.
intention: Kate wants to find out more about the nature of their relationship.
moral_action: Kate asks her partner directly about her partner's friend.
immoral_action: Kate looks through her partner's phone and social media.

norm: It's wrong to steal another person's private information.
situation: Logan is broke and needs to buy a part for his car online.
intention: Logan wants money to buy the car part.
moral_action: Logan asks a parent for a short-term loan to pay for the car part.
immoral_action: Logan goes to a restaurant and copies the credit card info of another customer who leaves his card out, then uses the card to pay.

norm: It is inappropriate to snoop on other people.
situation: Alexa is home alone because her best friend and roommate is out on a date.
intention: Alexa wants to avoid being bored.
moral_action: Alexa decides to find a TV show to watch and relaxes on the couch until her friend comes back from her date.
immoral_action: Alexa decides to go to the same bar she knows her best friend went on a date to and watches the date from across the room.

norm: It is wrong to steal someone's identity
situation: Tony finds a wallet on the ground when he is walking through the park.
intention: Tony wants to see who the wallet belongs to.
moral_action: Tony looks up the address listed on the driver's license he finds in the wallet.
immoral_action: Tony takes the driver's license from the wallet and uses the information on it to create a new identity.

norm: It is wrong to eavesdrop on other people.
situation: Bob inadvertently stumbles across two of his bosses having a heated personal exchange.
intention: Bob wants to react to the situation.
moral_action: Bob reveals his presence and apologizes for the intrusion.
immoral_action: Bob conceals himself better and proceeds to listen in on the conversation.

norm: It's wrong for partners to spy on each other.
situation: Donald is concerned that his girlfriend, Wilma, has been acting secretively lately.
intention: Donald wants to find out why Wilma has been acting secretively.
moral_action: Donald tells Wilma that he has noticed some secretive behavior in her actions lately and asks to talk about what's going on with her.
immoral_action: Donald goes through Wilma's phone and the browser history on her laptop, while she is showering.

norm: It is wrong to impersonate someone's identity.
situation: Erik is technologically savvy and is looking for a way to use these skills to make money.
intention: Erik wants to start making money online.
moral_action: Erik puts his skills to work designing security improvements for business websites.
immoral_action: Erik puts his skills to work taking people's identities online and then taking money from their bank accounts.

norm: It's wrong to spy on other people.
situation: Ash has a partner who she suspects is going behind her back with another girl.
intention: Ash wants to try to find out if her partner is cheating.
moral_action: Ash approaches her partner directly and asks him if something is going on.
immoral_action: Ash starts digging around for information and monitoring her partners internet activity.

norm: It's unethical to steal someone else's property.
situation: Macy,a poor woman, is cleaning her wealthy clients bathroom when she notices a purple eye shadow pallet stacked underneath twenty other pallets.
intention: Macy wants the eyeshadow pallet.
moral_action: Macy looks up the pallet on an online marketplace and orders a lightly used pallet for cheap.
immoral_action: Macy slips the eyeshadow pallet into the pocket of her pants and takes it home with her.

norm: It is irresponsible to get somebody else's property stolen
situation: Tony borrows his friend Jim's shovel to dig a hole in his front yard.
intention: Tony wants to put the shovel somewhere after digging the hole.
moral_action: Tony puts the shovel in his locked garage.
immoral_action: Tony leaves the shovel in the front yard where it is visible.

norm: It's hurtful not to accompany your father on an outing.
situation: James' father invited him on a fishing trip up in the mountains.
intention: James wants to spend the weekend playing video games.
moral_action: James brings with portable gaming console with him on the fishing trip.
immoral_action: James tells his father that fishing is boring, and he's staying home.

norm: It's rude not to want your grandparent around you.
situation: Jonah's grandfather calls him to tell him that he's been evicted from his house and needs his help.
intention: Jonah wants to secure a place to live for his grandfather.
moral_action: Jonah tells his grandfather that he can live with him and that he has nothing to worry about.
immoral_action: Jonah tells his grandfather that he will find an apartment and that he'll help his grandfather pay for it.

norm: Excluding one member of your family from something is hurtful.
situation: Brooke doesn't get along with her brother, and she is celebrating her birthday.
intention: Brooke wants to have a great birthday.
moral_action: Brooke celebrates her birthday with her boyfriend at home binge watching her favorite show.
immoral_action: Brooke invites everyone but her brother to her birthday dinner celebration.

norm: It's unacceptable to be rude to a friend's father.
situation: Karen is at her friend Jim's house when Jim's father Henry comes home and tells Karen to go back home for dinner.
intention: Karen wants to respond to Henry's demand.
moral_action: Karen tells Henry that of course, she will leave if he wishes since it's his house, after all.
immoral_action: "Karen tells Henry to ""eat it"" as she's not going to go home just because he told her since it was Jim who invited her."

norm: Getting rid of important family items is disrespectful.
situation: Paula is helping her parents move to a different town and their house has many items such as albums.
intention: Paula wants to clean out her parent's house.
moral_action: Paula asks her parents about the picture albums she finds and what to do with them.
immoral_action: Paula throws away picture albums she finds.

norm: It is rude to show disrespect to your father
situation: James' father asked him to set up the WiFi in their house since James is more comfortable with technology.
intention: James wants to encourage his father to learn to be more tech-savvy.
moral_action: James explains what he's doing throughout each step of the process.
immoral_action: James says his father must be unbelievably thick if he doesn't understand how to get on the Internet.

norm: Taking your family member's things without their permission is wrong.
situation: Steve, who lives with his mom that has an appointment that day, is planning to shop in town, but his car refuses to start.
intention: Steve wants to go to town.
moral_action: Steve asks his mom if he can take her car to town.
immoral_action: Steve takes his mom's car without asking and goes on a shopping trip.

norm: It can be rude to not appreciate a family heirloom.
situation: Laura just inherited a large box of family heirlooms which her entire extended family treasures and has just brought the box home.
intention: Laura wants to decide what to do with the heirlooms.
moral_action: Laura displays the heirlooms throughout her house for her and any family who visits to enjoy.
immoral_action: Laura decides to put the entire box of heirlooms in her basement that is prone to flooding.

norm: Excluding your father from your academic achievements is hurtful
situation: Joan hasn't been close to her dad since her parents divorced nevertheless he asks to attend her graduation ceremony.
intention: Joan wants to make a decision about whether or not to invite her dad.
moral_action: Despite their distance Joan asks her dad to come to her graduation.
immoral_action: Since they aren't that close Joan asks her dad not to attend her graduation.

norm: Keeping a father from speaking to a son is disrespectful.
situation: Kathy recently got divorced from Dave and Dave wants to see their son who lives with Kathy.
intention: Kathy wants to respond to Dave's request.
moral_action: Kathy tells Dave he can come and visit their son.
immoral_action: Kathy tells Dave that he can't see their son.

norm: You shouldn't put up with a disobedient and rude grandchild.
situation: Paul has his grandson over for the weekend, and his grandson has been making a lot of sarcastic comments to him.
intention: Paul wants to get through the weekend.
moral_action: Paul gives his grandson a stern talking to about his attitude and puts him to work until he improves his behaviour.
immoral_action: Paul doesn't spend much time with his grand son over the weekend and generally stays in different parts of the house.

norm: It's rude to tell your father what to do.
situation: Ron is at his parent's house, and sees that the lawn is massively overgrown.
intention: Ron wants the lawn to get cut.
moral_action: Ron goes into the garage, gets the mower and cuts the grass himself.
immoral_action: Ron tells his father that he needs to cut the lawn, that the neighbors will be upset.

norm: It's wrong to yell at a grandparent.
situation: Sandra's grandmother usually sends a card with money for Sandra's birthday, but this year she has been feeling sick and forgot.
intention: Sandra wants to call her grandmother.
moral_action: Sandra calls her grandmother to see if she is doing well since it is out of character for her to forget a birthday.
immoral_action: Sandra calls her grandmother and yells at her for forgetting her birthday, saying that she was counting on receiving the money.

norm: It is wrong to lose contact with a grandparent.
situation: Grace, who is very close to her grandma, just graduated from university and doesn't have any jobs lined up.
intention: Grace wants to spend a few years travelling the world.
moral_action: Grace makes sure to send her grandma postcards detailing her travels on a regular basis and calls to check up on her whenever she can.
