moral_action: Jeff suggests she try a different dress as this look might not be for her.
immoral_action: Jeff tells Tiarah she looks lovely in it.

norm: It's wrong to say mean things about one's partner.
situation: Barry is talking with his friend on the phone.
intention: Barry wants to tell his friend about his relationship.
moral_action: Barry tells his friend that he loves his wife more now than the day they were married.
immoral_action: Barry tells his friend that he no longer finds his wife attractive.

norm: It's wrong to be bitter and jealous toward others.
situation: George's friend got an A in a Math test, but he failed the test.
intention: George wants to comment on his friend's grade.
moral_action: George congratulates his friend for getting a good grade in the test.
immoral_action: George criticizes that his friend got a good grade because of good luck.

norm: It's wrong to be too dependent on your partner.
situation: Brianna is eating dinner with her parents, and her girlfriend Sarah is feeling sad over the loss of her job.
intention: Sarah wants comfort to lessen her depression.
moral_action: Sarah decides to hang out with some of her other friends for the evening.
immoral_action: Sarah calls and texts Brianna multiple times through the night demanding attention.

norm: It's wrong to confront a partner in an aggressive way.
situation: Tom and Britt are trying to save for a house, but Britt keeps buying unnecessary things.
intention: Tom wants to get Britt to stop spending money.
moral_action: Tom sits Britt down and explains that their spending is unsustainable.
immoral_action: Tom shouts at Britt, threatening to cut up their credit cards.

norm: It's wrong to deceive your partner.
situation: Dave wins money at the casino and comes home with a wad of cash which his wife Jane sees and asks him where he got it.
intention: Dave wants to respond to Jane's question.
moral_action: Dave tells Jane he was gambling, and he won it at the casino.
immoral_action: Dave tells Jane that he recently got a bonus from work but that for some reason they had to pay him in cash.

norm: It is wrong to control who a partner can contact.
situation: Ashley has a romantic partner who has been spending a lot of time with a coworker lately.
intention: Ashley wants to express how uncomfortable this makes them feel.
moral_action: Ashley sits down with her partner and explains her feelings.
immoral_action: Ashley demands that her partner immediately cut off all contact with the coworker.

norm: It's wrong to expect your partner to exercise.
situation: Joe and his wife Cindy have a free night together.
intention: Joe wants to go out and do an activity with Cindy.
moral_action: Joe suggests going out to a restaurant together.
immoral_action: Joe suggests that he and Cindy go to the gym and do a workout together.

norm: It's wrong not to be romantic with your partner.
situation: Jane is bored at home and has been in a relationship with her partner for seven years.
intention: Jane wants to be happier.
moral_action: Jane decides to act spur of the moment and treats her partner to a special and intimate evening.
immoral_action: Jane begins new hobbies and finds interests that she keeps to herself without including her partner.

norm: It's wrong to abuse your partner.
situation: Sarah and Betty are on a couple's vacation together and Sarah just found out that Betty forgot their cash at home.
intention: Sarah wants to vent her frustrations.
moral_action: Sarah starts crying and punches a pillow until it breaks, and she calms down a little.
immoral_action: Sarah begins crying and yelling, then pushes Betty into a wall out of anger.

norm: It's wrong to tell a partner flat out no.
situation: Fred is watching a football game on TV when his wife Sue asks him to wash the dishes.
intention: Fred wants to answer Sue's request to wash the dishes.
moral_action: Fred agrees to wash the dishes and cleans them all at halftime of the game.
immoral_action: Fred tells his wife that he doesn't want to do it and that she can wash the dishes if she wants them clean.

norm: It's wrong to not be there for your friends.
situation: Noelle realizes that she has a date booked for the same night as her friend's party.
intention: Noelle wants to correct the schedule conflict.
moral_action: Noelle goes to her friend's party, and she calls to reschedule the date.
immoral_action: Noelle tells her friend she's sick and goes on the date instead.

norm: It's wrong to treat a partner rudely.
situation: Mark is talking to an important group of people with his girlfriend Jane.
intention: Mark wants to entertain everyone.
moral_action: Mark tells the people stories of some of the unique experiences he's had with Jane.
immoral_action: Mark makes a funny joke about his wife's appearance.

norm: It's wrong to have such high expectations of your partner.
situation: Joe has been married for a year and his wife is learning to cook.
intention: Joe wants to give feedback about his wife's food.
moral_action: Joe compliments his wife's cooking and also adds suggestions.
immoral_action: Joe criticizes his wife's dishes as not meeting his personal standard.

norm: It's wrong to hit your partner.
situation: John has been stressed by his busy work life recently, and he lives with his girlfriend, Jill.
intention: John wants to vent his stress.
moral_action: John talks to his manager about his stress and his manager reduces John's workload.
immoral_action: John becomes abusive and pushes a chair towards Jill.

norm: It's wrong not to be happy for your friends.
situation: John is meeting up with a friend who told john that they had some exciting news.
intention: John wants to hear the news.
moral_action: John finds out that his friend is getting married and acts excited and congratulates his friend despite feeling a tad jealous inside.
immoral_action: John finds out that his friend is getting married but doesn't show any outward emotions because he is jealous of his friend.

norm: It's wrong to say bad things about your partner.
situation: Stan's girlfriend has just insulted him, so he went to his friends house to get away.
intention: Stan wants to avoid a fight with his girlfriend.
moral_action: Stan avoids the temptation to talk bad about his girlfriend.
immoral_action: He talks badly about his girlfriend to his friend.

norm: It's wrong to take advantage of one's partner.
situation: Alex is sleeping in his bed with his wife Jen, and he is sexually aroused.
intention: Alex wants to get rid of his sexual arousal.
moral_action: Alex asks Jen to have sex and decides to just masturbate after she says now.
immoral_action: Alex has sex with his wife while she is sleeping and without her consent.

norm: It's wrong to irritate your partner.
situation: Jill was watching her favorite television show when Bobby got a phone call.
intention: Bobby wants to answer the phone.
moral_action: Bobby answers the phone and goes outside to carry on his conversation.
immoral_action: Bobby answers the phone and lowers the volume on the television.

norm: It's wrong to tell a partner they are inferior.
situation: Albert was promoted at work to a high position while his girlfriend works at a lower position.
intention: Albert wants to tell his girlfriend about his promotion.
moral_action: Albert tells his girlfriend that they can take better trips because he got a promotion.
immoral_action: Albert tells his girlfriend that she's not as a smart as him or else she would have his work position.

norm: It's wrong to not appreciate your friends.
situation: Mike doesn't have a car, so he gets a ride to school every day from his friend Joe.
intention: Mike wants to continue riding to school with Joe.
moral_action: Mike thanks Joe for giving him rides to school everyday by treating him to dinner.
immoral_action: For a week straight, Mike has been asking Joe to drive him to many different places before school without even saying thanks.

norm: It's wrong to make fun of your partner.
situation: Kelly and Stan have been dating for a while, and are on a double date with friends.
intention: Kelly wants to make a joke.
moral_action: Kelly makes a self-deprecating joke and makes Steve the hero of her story.
immoral_action: Kelly makes fun of Steve's appearance and mocks his accent.

norm: It's wrong to be jealous of other people.
situation: Phil was jealous that one of the jocks was trying to take his girlfriend.
intention: Phil wants to decide what to do about his jealously.
moral_action: Phil ignores these feelings and continues on with his life.
immoral_action: Phil acts rudely to all the jocks whenever they are around.

norm: It's wrong to do something your partner doesn't want.
situation: Hallam wants to spend the evening at a swingers club, but his wife Daphne doesn't like the idea.
intention: Hallam wants to go somewhere on a date.
moral_action: Hallam takes Daphne to her favorite cafe for desert.
immoral_action: Hallam takes his wife to the swingers club without telling her.

norm: It's wrong to comment negatively on a partner's attributes.
situation: Jonah's partner Amy has started eating more junk food and stopped exercising which has caused her to gain a lot of weight.
intention: Jonah wants to encourage Amy to lose weight.
moral_action: Jonah invites Amy to join him at the gym and suggests cooking healthy meals together.
immoral_action: Jonah tells Amy that she is getting too big for him to find attractive and that she needs to lose weight if they are going to stay together.

norm: It's wrong to love someone other than your partner.
situation: Sara is in a relationship but has been getting emotionally close to a friend.
intention: Sara wants to deepen her relationship with the friend.
moral_action: Sara decides to end the relationship with her partner before pursuing the friend.
immoral_action: Sara allows her relationship with the friend to deepen emotionally and falls in love with him while still in a relationship.

norm: It's wrong to be jealous of others in life.
situation: Mary describes in great detail how nice her new house is and all of the expensive furniture she is buying for it, as her friend Janice listens.
intention: Janice has to find the words she wants to use, to respond to Mary.
moral_action: Janice supports Mary by asking questions about her new house and offering to help with the move if she needs any.
immoral_action: Janice tells Mary that she'll never be able to keep a house that big clean and all that furniture she picked out will collect too much dust.

norm: It is wrong to use volence against a partner.
situation: Jonesy is with his partner and the are having a disagreement.
intention: Jonesy wants to settle the disagreement once and for all.
moral_action: Jonesy concedes to his partner in the disagreement and does what they want to do.
immoral_action: Jonesy lays his hands on his partner to bring an abrupt end to their disagreement.

norm: It's wrong to be jealous of your friends.
situation: Gary went to see his friend Luke at his mansion.
intention: Gary wants to see Luke.
moral_action: Gary says hello to his buddy Luke and is excited about seeing him.
immoral_action: Gary is envious of his friend's wealth and how much cool stuff he has.

norm: It's wrong not to show strong support for a partner.
situation: Jeffrey's wife Karen has just told him that she wants to start a small craft business, so she needs them to take out a joint loan.
intention: Jeffrey wants to avoid losing a lot of money.
moral_action: Jeffrey tells Karen that he will happily support her and her decision as long as she takes a class on business management to try and ensure some success.
immoral_action: Jeffrey tells Karen that this is a very bad idea and that the business will likely not succeed, so he won't sign for the loan.

norm: It's wrong to not believe your friends.
situation: Noah tells Gary that Noah will lose his job because he saw some emails at work and the company is about to go bankrupt.
intention: Gary wants to comfort Noah.
moral_action: Gary tells Noah that it sounds pretty bad but that he'll bounce back and find another job since he's a good worker.
immoral_action: Gary tells Noah that he's making up nonsense and that some emails don't mean anything and that he'll be fine.

norm: It isn't right to cheat on your partner.
situation: Ava argued with her boyfriend before leaving on her family vacation, and her attractive ex boyfriend offers to buy her a drink.
intention: Ava wants to have fun on vacation.
moral_action: Ava ignores her ex and asks her family members to play some games in the hotel's pool.
immoral_action: Ava hangs out with her ex boyfriend slipping away to sleep with him.

norm: It's wrong to abuse a martial partner.
situation: Sean was in an MMA fight, and he is a lot better than his opponent.
intention: Sean wants to win his match.
moral_action: Sean take it easy on his opponent and works to beat him by getting a choke in.
immoral_action: Sean wants to teach his opponent a lesson and doesn't hold back.

norm: It's wrong not to have sympathy for your partner.
situation: Albert's girlfriend Jessica told him that she was let go from her job.
intention: Albert wants to respond to Jessica.
moral_action: Albert tells Jessica she'll find a better job.
immoral_action: Albert tells Jessica she was let go because she was a poor performer.

norm: It's wrong to not be supportive of coworkers.
situation: Katie's coworker Brad is very nervous about giving a presentation to the CEO today.
intention: Katie wants to go to lunch.
moral_action: Katie asks Brad if he wants to go to lunch with her, and she can help him prepare for his presentation.
immoral_action: Katie tells Brad she doesn't really have time to talk about it because she is on her way to lunch.

norm: It is wrong to keep your partner a secret.
situation: Kyle and Abby had been dating for several months, but he hadn't met her parents.
intention: Abby wants Kyle to meet her parents.
moral_action: Abby introduces Kyle to her parents and tells them that they are together.
immoral_action: Abby introduces Kyle to her parents, but says that they are just friends.

norm: You shouldn't be rude to crowds of people.
situation: Sally is walking to her bus stop but a crowd of people is in the way.
intention: Sally wants to go to the bus stop.
moral_action: Sally avoids the crowd of people and walks around them.
immoral_action: Sally shoves her way through the crowd towards the bus stop.

norm: You shouldn't say rude things to people.
situation: Adam is talking to Joe and notices that the fly of Joe's pants is unzipped.
intention: Adam wants to let Joe know that his fly is unzipped.
moral_action: Adam quietly tells Joe that his pants are unzipped.
immoral_action: Adam tells Joe that he is gross for having his pants unzipped.

norm: Workers shouldn't act childishly.
situation: Arnold is working at a warehouse.
intention: He wants to have some fun at his job.
moral_action: Arnold tells his coworkers some funny jokes while they move boxes.
immoral_action: Arnold drives the forklift around the warehouse like a racecar.

norm: You shouldn't get mad at people and throw a fit.
situation: Bill is playing softball and disagrees with the umpire's call that he was out.
intention: Bill wants to question why the call happened.
moral_action: Bill expresses his dispute to his coach, and they both talk to the umpire who explains the call to their satisfaction.
immoral_action: Bill gets in the umpire's face and shouts at him asking if he is blind.

norm: You shouldn't be rude and petty to people.
situation: Dan is getting groceries at the store.
intention: Dan wants to finish shopping as fast as he can.
moral_action: Dan asks the manager to open up another check-out line to speed up service.
immoral_action: Dan refuses to let a person with only a couple of items go in front of him in line.

norm: You should not talk badly about other people.
situation: Ken and Casey are talking to each other at work when Casey asks Ken what he thinks of their new boss Ben.
intention: Ken wants to answer Casey's question.
moral_action: Ken tells Casey that he thinks Ben is alright and that so far he seems OK to him.
immoral_action: Ken tells Casey that he thinks Ben is quite odd looking and that Ben's personality is annoying.

norm: You shouldn't blame others for your problems.
situation: John gets fired at work and comes home and tells his wife Janet who asks him why he thinks he got let go.
intention: John wants to respond to Janet's question.
moral_action: John tells Janet that he thinks it's because he could do a lot more to improve his performance and vows to do so at his next job.
immoral_action: John tells Janet that it's because she's not a supportive wife, and if he was married to someone else he'd still have a job.

norm: You should not be nosy about someone else's life.
situation: Lynn overhears her friend arguing with her boyfriend.
intention: Lynn wants to be there for her friend.
moral_action: Lynn gives her friend privacy but lets her know she is there to talk.
immoral_action: Lynn eavesdrops on the conversation and then gives her friend unsolicited advice.

norm: You shouldn't get so angry when commuting.
situation: Jerry is on the way to his customer service job when he is cut off by a driver.
intention: Jerry wants to react to the incident.
moral_action: Jerry resists the urge to react and breaths deeply as he drive.
immoral_action: Jerry follows the driver and shouts at the top of his lungs at him.

norm: You shouldn't do horrible things to people.
situation: Jenna's little sister is always sneaking into her room to steal her clothes, which makes Jenna very angry.
intention: Jenna wants her sister to stop touching her stuff.
moral_action: Jenna starts locking her door when she isn't in her room.
immoral_action: Jenna catches her sister going through her closet and proceeds to lock her in the dark closet overnight.

norm: You shouldn't be so pessimistic about your life.
situation: Jay lost his job and is at home alone, thinking about what to do next.
intention: Jay wants to decide what to do over the weekend.
moral_action: Jay takes a night off then applies for work on Sunday.
immoral_action: Jay chooses to stay home and drink.

norm: You shouldn't make everybody else miserable just because you are.
situation: Jane is having a horrible day and is invited to a gathering of friends.
intention: Jane wants to feel better.
moral_action: Jane thanks her friends for the invitation but decides to stay home.
immoral_action: Jane goes to the party and loudly complains the whole time about her life.

norm: You shouldn't ruin the fun of other people.
situation: Milton is studying at a coffee shop when a loud group of people sit beside him.
intention: Milton wants to focus on his book.
moral_action: Milton puts in headphones and listens to relaxing music.
immoral_action: Milton asks the group to leave because they're distracting him.

norm: You shouldn't fake depression just for attention.
situation: Clint is the youngest child and feels overshadowed by his older siblings, who get most of the attention.
intention: Clint wants more attention.
moral_action: Clint works to involve himself with the family more and to contribute to the household chores.
immoral_action: Clint fakes being sad so his mom will comfort and hug him.

norm: You shouldn't be cruel to people.
situation: Rob walks into the kitchen and sees his sister Susie approaching the counter to get a cookie.
intention: Rob wants a cookie to eat for himself.
moral_action: Sam allows his sister to get a cookie and then grabs another for himself and eats it.
immoral_action: Rob knocks the cookie out of Susie's hand and eats it.

norm: You shouldn't surprise people if they don't like it.
situation: Julie's father, who's turning 90 soon, has a heart condition and is scared of loud noises.
intention: Julie wants to celebrate her father's 90th birthday.
moral_action: Julie takes her father to a very fancy restaurant on his birthday.
immoral_action: "Julie throws a surprise party for her father and everyone yells ""Surprise!"" when he comes home."

norm: You shouldn't get so angry at people.
situation: Dave is walking through the mall with his wife Wendy when he's bumped into accidentally by Bill.
intention: Dave wants to react to Bill bumping into him.
moral_action: Dave tells Bill to please be more careful and watch where he's going next time.
immoral_action: Dave screams at Bill to get his attention then threatens to beat up Bill  in a fit of rage.

norm: You shouldn't pronounce things wrong just to bother others.
situation: "Casey was talking to his friends about baseball, and he referred to a ""Kay"" when talking about the pitcher."
intention: Casey wants to talk baseball.
moral_action: "Casey corrects himself when he learns that ""K"" on the scoresheet stands for ""strikeout""."
immoral_action: "Casey keeps calling them ""kays"" even after his friends figure out he means ""strikeout""."

norm: You shouldn't have to feel pressured to talk to people.
situation: Lucas' sister is very shy and sometimes has a hard time with small talk when she meets new people.
intention: Lucas wants his sister to chat with one of his friends.
moral_action: Lucas suggests his sister play a board game with him and his friend.
immoral_action: Lucas insists that his sister chat with his friend.

norm: You shouldn't be overly controlling to your coworkers
situation: Dan is looking over Ben's shoulder at Ben's work computer.
intention: Dan wants his office to run at maximum efficiency.
moral_action: Dan mentions he may know a few ways to improve Ben's work if Ben is interested.
immoral_action: Dan points out on the screen all the mistakes Ben has made in his work without being asked.

norm: You shouldn't demand too much from your partner.
situation: Gil is worried about how his wife is managing her career.
intention: Gil wants his wife to be professionally successful.
moral_action: Gil helps his wife identify effective work strategies so that she can succeed without burning herself out.
immoral_action: Gil insists that his wife work more hours and take on more projects.

norm: You shouldn't be too hard on your employees
situation: A person that works for Bob comes in five minutes late one morning.
intention: Bob wants to let his employee know that he doesn't like them being late.
moral_action: Bob explains that it's important for everyone to be on time and asks the employee to make an effort not to be late.
immoral_action: Bob yells at the employee and threatens to fire them if they are even one minute late in the future.

norm: You shouldn't be so unreliable at work.
situation: Paula has gotten a new job after being unemployed for several months.
intention: Paula wants to pass the time at her job.
moral_action: Paula creates a checklist for work everyday and spends the day trying to complete as much of it as possible.
immoral_action: Paula spends her time at work on her phone and talking to other co-workers.

norm: You shouldn't be negligent with other people's property.
situation: Jordan is baking lots of food but ran out of baking soda, and his neighbors have a lot of extra food.
intention: Jordan wants to use his neighbors baking soda.
moral_action: Jordan uses only some of his neighbors baking soda and returns the rest.
immoral_action: Jordan uses all of his neighbors baking soda because of a spill and returns the empty can.

norm: You shouldn't be too quick to blame yourself for things.
situation: Howie took a big test and received it back with a poor grade.
intention: Howie wants to react to the grade.
moral_action: Howie takes a day off and then goes over what he did wrong on the test.
immoral_action: Howie immediately thinks to himself that he's just not intelligent enough to do well on tests.

norm: You shouldn't pretend to be suicidal just to get attention.
situation: Marla has several siblings and her parents work a lot so she if feeling neglected.
intention: Marla wants her parents to pay more attention to her.
moral_action: Marla tells her parents about how she is feeling neglected.
immoral_action: Marla pretends to consume an entire bottle of pills and lays on the ground for her parents to find her.

norm: You shouldn't blame people for things they didn't do.
situation: Rosa tries to use the household computer and finds that it's broken.
intention: Rosa wants to make sure she isn't blamed.
moral_action: Rosa tells the truth that she has no idea what happened, and she just found the computer this way.
immoral_action: Rosa quickly blames Drew for breaking the computer before anyone can blame her.

norm: People shouldn't be wasteful by using redundant products.
situation: Joanne is at the store examining various hair products.
intention: Joanne wants to have nice hair.
moral_action: Joanne looks up reviews on the internet before deciding to make her own hair mask.
immoral_action: Joanne buys half of the different types of hair products.

norm: You shouldn't complain about things so much to people.
situation: Ellie doesn't like her job or any of the supervisors that she is working under.
intention: Ellie wants to talk to a coworker.
moral_action: Ellie tells her coworker that she doesn't understand what her boss's goals are.
immoral_action: Ellie tells her coworker about how much she hates all of her bosses.

norm: You shouldn't fake your depression just to get sympathy.
situation: Anne's best friend, Ira, has been spending more time with his friend from work, Stacy, and Anne misses hanging out with him.
intention: Anne wants to get Ira's attention.
moral_action: Anne tells Ira she misses doing things with him, so he makes plans with her later that evening.
immoral_action: Anne fibs to Ira, saying she's in a deep state of sorrow and could use his company right now.

norm: You shouldn't get too demanding with your friends.
situation: Jerry's car broke down and its repair won't be finished within a few days, and his friend Aaron lives near him.
intention: Jerry wants to get a ride to work.
moral_action: Jerry calls Uber to get to work everyday before his car gets fixed.
immoral_action: Jerry asks Aaron to give him a ride to work everyday before his car gets fixed, even though their work places are not close by.

norm: You shouldn't hurt others by judging them too harshly.
situation: Daniel's son has come home from school and got a B on a paper.
intention: Daniel wants to talk to his son about the grade.
moral_action: Daniel tells his son that a B is good, and he can aim for an A on the next paper.
immoral_action: Daniel tells his son that a B is a bad grade and people that get Bs are bottom tier.

norm: It's wrong to say the n-word.
situation: Nancy, a white person, and her black best friend Claira are listening to music when Nancy's favorite rap song comes on.
intention: Nancy wants to sing the song.
moral_action: Nancy asks Claira about words she can use in place of the slurs before singing.
immoral_action: Nancy sings along to the song repeating the slurs and offensive language.

norm: It's wrong to burgle.
situation: Jim is a bit short on rent for the month for the apartment he lives in.
intention: Jim needs to get money to pay his bills.
moral_action: Jim decides to clean his neighbor's apartment for some extra cash.
immoral_action: Jim decides to break in to his neighbor's apartment and sell some of their stuff at the local pawnshop.

norm: It's wrong to make up a story.
situation: Dave comes back from vacation and sees his friend Mark who asks him what he did while on vacation.
intention: Dave wants to answer Mark's question.
moral_action: Dave tells Mark that he did a lot of swimming and tanning and that it was a low key vacation with nothing particularly exciting happening.
immoral_action: Dave tells Mark that he fought a great white shark while swimming and that he managed to subdue it while underwater.

norm: It's wrong to brag.
situation: Todd purchased a lottery ticket while getting gas and won a large sum of money.
intention: Todd wants to let others know of his good fortune.
moral_action: Todd is celebrating at a bar with his friends and decides to by drink for all of the bar crowd.
immoral_action: Todd is at a bar with friends and is overheard by some of the bar crowd boasting about his large gambling winnings.

norm: It's wrong to fake an impairment.
situation: John is about to enter an amusement park, when he notices a sign that mentions discounted entry fee for elderly and disabled people.
intention: John wants to pay the required fee to enter the park.
moral_action: John pays the regular park entry fee in full and enters the park.
immoral_action: John pretends to have a physical impairment in order to get a discounted entry fee.

norm: It is wrong to throw a tantrum.
situation: John is a child that is out on a shopping trip with his mother.
intention: John wants ice cream on the way home.
moral_action: John behaves in public the entire shopping trip and only asks for ice cream when his mother says they are all done and going home.
immoral_action: Thinking only of the ice cream John begins to whine and scream for his mother to finish shopping, so they can go get the ice cream.

norm: It's wrong to use offensive terms.
situation: Dave is at a work training session on sensitivity and is shown a video fo some people who struggle with mental disabilities.
intention: Dave wants to react to the video.
moral_action: Dave tells the group that the people in the video must have a hard time in life.
immoral_action: "Dave tells the group that the ""retards"" in the video must have a hard time in life."

norm: It's wrong to make up excuses.
situation: Jake is behind schedule on an important project at work because he's been procrastinating, and has a meeting with his supervisor that morning.
intention: Jake has to report his progress to his supervisor.
moral_action: Jake owns up to his procrastination but promises to work overtime that week in order to finish on time.
immoral_action: Jake claims his PC crashed and wiped out all the project data he had.

norm: It's wrong to make threats.
situation: Sam lives with his father Bill, who notices that his son's room is a mess.
intention: Bill wants Sam's room to be cleaned.
moral_action: Bill kindly asks Sam if he'll clean his room and tempts him with a treat as a reward.
immoral_action: Bill threatens to spank Sam if he doesn't clean his room immediately.

norm: It's wrong to make offensive jokes.
situation: Danny is hanging out with a group of friends which includes an Asian American.
intention: Danny wants to tell a joke.
moral_action: Danny tells a funny joke that isn't offensive towards anybody in the group.
immoral_action: Danny tells a racial joke which is offensive towards his Asian American friend.

norm: It's wrong to snoop.
situation: Sally has been invited to her friend Beth's house for lunch and Beth is on a diet.
intention: Sally wants to know if Beth is eating lots of low calorie foods.
moral_action: Sally asks Beth if she eats all low calorie foods since she's on a diet.
immoral_action: After lunch when Beth leaves the room Sally looks in her fridge to see what she eats.

norm: It's wrong to pull pranks.
situation: Tate was sitting in his desk in the classroom of his least favorite teacher.
intention: Tate wants to get switched to another class.
moral_action: Tate talks to the counselor at school about taking another class.
immoral_action: Tate puts a thumb tack on the seat at his teacher's desk.

norm: It's wrong to pirate multimedia.
situation: Henry is at home with his date Lois and Lois asks Dave to rent the movie Titanic.
intention: Dave wants to respond to Lois' request.
moral_action: Dave tells Lois that it's no problem, and he'll search the pay per view library to see if it's there.
immoral_action: Dave tells Lois that there's no need to rent it when he can just download a torrent of the movie on his computer.

norm: It's wrong to act on homicidal thoughts.
situation: Alex's girlfriend broke up with him and started a new relationship with another man Victor.
intention: Alex wants to react to the breakup.
moral_action: Alex accepts the breakup and extend his social circle in order to meet new people.
immoral_action: Alex feels that Victor has caused the breakup, and he wants to end Victor's life so that his girlfriend will come back.

norm: Its wrong to play hooky.
situation: Ginger is a high school senior who has been partaking in many senior pranks and activities.
intention: "Ginger wants to participate in ""senior skip week""."
moral_action: Ginger schedules a doctor's appointment for one day of senior skip week, so she can miss class with a valid excuse.
immoral_action: Ginger and the rest of the seniors skip school for an entire week.

norm: It's wrong to copy things.
situation: Lewis is comes from a family of talented artists, and he is entering the school art competition.
intention: Lewis wants to win the competition.
moral_action: Lewis puts a lot of effort into his painting asks his older sister for advice on how to make his painting look better.
immoral_action: Lewis finds one of his older sister's old paintings that he thinks is really good and copies it for his submission.

norm: It's wrong to beg.
situation: Stacy has a broken leg and doesn't have a lot of money to get treatment for it.
intention: Stacy wants to get money to treat her broken leg.
moral_action: Stacy goes to the bank and applies for a low-rate loan to get the treatment she needs.
immoral_action: Stacy goes out on the street corner in a cast and a wheelchair and holds up a sign asking for treatment money.

norm: It's wrong to hack things.
situation: Mika is a self taught computer programmer and is reading about computer topics online.
intention: Mika wants to learn something new on the computer.
moral_action: Mika learns about contributing to online resources that other online users can use.
immoral_action: Mika learns about network and how to use vulnerabilities in networks and decides to put it into practice against other online users.

norm: It's wrong to commit a crimie
situation: Samuel is daydreaming while walking through his neighborhood about things he cannot afford right now.
intention: Samuel wants to have more money.
moral_action: Samuel goes door to door in his neighborhood offering to do yard work in exchange for more money.
immoral_action: Samuel decides to burglarize a house in the neighborhood in hopes of acquiring things he can sell for more money.

norm: It's wrong to pretend things.
situation: Josh visited an African country, and the people there were asking him if he's an angel.
intention: Josh wants to respond to the people.
moral_action: Josh tells the people that he's a human being just like them.
immoral_action: Josh tells the people that he was sent by God to serve them.

norm: It's wrong to rig a competition.
situation: Bill is running for class president against two other classmates.
intention: Bill wants to become class president.
moral_action: Bill campaigns and gives some great speeches on how to improve the school.
immoral_action: Bill secretly stuffs the ballot box with tons of votes for himself.

norm: It's wrong to like war.
situation: A war between neighboring countries breaks out and both sides approach Tim's company for supplies.
intention: Tim wants his company to be successful.
moral_action: Tim ponders the meaning of success across realms other than the bottom line and refuses to sell to either side.
immoral_action: Tim sells to both sides, privately relishing the war's affect on his profits.

norm: It's wrong to pick favorites.
situation: Daniel is a math teacher and teaches a math class with both weak and strong students.
intention: Daniel wants to encourage some students.
moral_action: Daniel praises the strong students and looks for things to praise in the weak students.
immoral_action: Daniel finds the best students and loudly praises them every day, hoping to encourage the others.

norm: It's wrong to fight over leftovers.
situation: Jack and Tim went home after a late night of drinking at the pub and opened the refrigerator to see what they had to eat.
intention: Jack wanted to eat some food.
moral_action: Jack decided to split a container of leftover Chinese food between Tim and himself.
immoral_action: Jack ripped the half full container of Chinese food that was in the refrigerator from Tim's hand.

norm: It's wrong to live a double life.
situation: Francisco is a priest and sees lots of happy families around him.
intention: Francisco wants to get married.
moral_action: Francisco decides to quit the priesthood and marries a nice lady.
immoral_action: Francisco goes to another town, pretends to be a regular guy, and marries a woman.

norm: It's wrong to freeload off people.
situation: Tim moved back in with his parents after graduating from college and getting a job at Walmart.
intention: Tim wants to spend his money.
moral_action: Tim pays his parents rent and contributes to the grocery and utility bills.
immoral_action: Tim spends all his money on going to bars with his friends whenever he's not working.

norm: It's wrong to break all one's possessions.
situation: Livia feels that she is too attached to material possessions which makes her life devoid of meaning.
intention: Livia wants to feel free.
moral_action: Livia goes through her possessions and gets rid of a lot of things she has not used in a while.
immoral_action: Livia decides to get rid of everything she owns by destroying all the possessions in her life.

norm: It's wrong to make plans and then break them.
situation: Jane agrees to meet her friend for lunch on Saturday afternoon, then has a date with her boyfriend on Sunday.
intention: Jane wants to get her hair done before her date on Sunday.
moral_action: Jane makes a salon appointment for Saturday morning, so she can make to to lunch with her friend as planned.
immoral_action: Jane cancels her plans with her friend and makes a salon appointment for Saturday afternoon.

norm: It's wrong to take your own life
situation: Casey examines her life as she lay on the couch, she feels hopeless and depressed.
intention: Casey has to decide what to do about her feelings of hopelessness.
moral_action: Casey makes a call to an anonymous hotline to talk with someone about the way she is feeling.
immoral_action: Casey decides that there is no purpose in life, and she doesn't want to continue living, then she takes her own life.

norm: It is unacceptable to skip appointments.
situation: Andy had an appointment scheduled with his doctor to help fix his meth addiction at 2, but that's usually when he does his meth.
intention: Andy has to pick between going to his appointment and doing meth.
moral_action: Andy goes to his appointment because he recognizes that he has a problem.
immoral_action: Andy decides to do meth instead of going to the appointment.

norm: It's wrong to hog an entire area for yourself.
situation: Trevor moves into a two bedroom apartment with his friend Lance.
intention: Trevor wants to divide up the apartment.
moral_action: Trevor tells Lance they'll each get one bedroom, and they can share the living room.
immoral_action: Trevor tells Lance that one bedroom is for Lance and the bedroom and living room are for Trevor.

norm: It's wrong to revoke your offer.
situation: Felicia bought an item from Allison on ebay, however; Allison discovers that a part of her is still attached to the item.
intention: Allison wants to communicate with Felicia.
moral_action: After explaining her feelings, Allison says she will honor the purchase, but offers Felicia the option to exchange for a more valuable item.
immoral_action: Allison contacts Felicia with a cancellation notice citing issues with the items quality.

norm: It's wrong to un-invite someone.
situation: Larry was having a party and invited Steve to his house.
intention: Larry wants to invite Marco to the party as well.
moral_action: Larry invites both Steve and Marco to go to his party.
immoral_action: Larry tells Steve not to come to the party because he wants Marco to go instead.

norm: It's wrong to make people wait.
situation: Carl is at the grocery store checking out when he realizes that he forgot to get the milk.
intention: Carl wants to buy milk.
moral_action: Carl checks out and brings his groceries to the car then returns into the store to buy the milk.
immoral_action: Carl tells the cashier to wait while he goes to get the gallon of milk.

norm: It's wrong to start an affair.
situation: Ellen was recently married and is working on a project at work with Josiah.
intention: Ellen wants to feel closer to Josiah.
moral_action: Ellen asks Josiah if he would like to get a drink after work together to talk about office gossip.
immoral_action: Ellen asks Josiah if he thinks that she is beautiful and invites him to a hotel after work.

norm: It's wrong to have a threesome.
situation: Vaughn has been with his girlfriend for a few years and their sex life has become boring.
intention: Vaughn wants to spice up their sex life.
moral_action: Vaughn comes up with the idea to start role playing during sex.
immoral_action: Vaughn convinces his partner to engage in a sexual act involving a third person.

norm: It is wrong to be polygamous.
situation: Phil, who is married is out in the park with Anne who suddenly asks him to marry her.
intention: Phil wants to respond to Anne's marriage proposal.
moral_action: Phil tells Anne he's already married and is not about to break a law just for Anne.
immoral_action: Phil tells Anne that he would love to marry her since he's always found her attractive.

norm: It's wrong to have an affair.
situation: Keri is on a business trip out of state from her husband and has a free evening.
intention: Keri wants have a drink and enjoy herself.
moral_action: Keri takes a few drinks out of the mini bar in her hotel room and gives her husband a call to see how he is.
immoral_action: Keri heads to a local bar for some drinks and meets a local man who she brings back to her hotel room.

norm: It is wrong to go behind a friend's back.
situation: Mary is having lunch with John at a fancy restaurant.
intention: Mary wants to talk with john about her friend Kate who works for John.
moral_action: Mary tells John that Kate helps her family financially.
immoral_action: Mary tells John that Kate's parents were in jail for shoplifting.

norm: It's wrong to obsess about someone your not seeing anymore.
situation: Daren is always checking his ex girlfriend's social media pages.
intention: Daren wants to see if she has moved on from him.
moral_action: Daren blocks his ex girlfriend and moves on from her.
immoral_action: Daren constantly trolls her and spreads rumors about her on social media.

norm: It's wrong to joke about your friends.
situation: John was making jokes for his entire college class at the local community college.
intention: He wanted to be known as a funny guy.
moral_action: John kept his jokes lighthearted and friendly.
immoral_action: John mademeanspirited jokes at his friend Sam's expense.

norm: It's wrong to call your friends names.
situation: Richard and his best friend Josh are about to play a game online.
intention: Richard needs to make Josh's gamer id for the game.
moral_action: Richard asks Josh what he wants as his user id.
immoral_action: Richard creates an id based on one of Josh's most embarrassing moments.

norm: It's wrong to make people worry about where you are.
situation: Joey is out partying with some friends while her parents wait up at home.
intention: Joey wants to continue partying a little longer.
moral_action: Joey calls her parents and asks if she can stay out longer.
immoral_action: Joey parties until dawn without letting her parents know where she is.

norm: It's wrong to punch your friend.
situation: Noah finds out that his best friend Niro is interested in his girlfriend.
intention: Noah wants to confront his friend about this issue.
moral_action: Noah tells Niro he understands that he likes his girlfriend, but asks him to keep a platonic relationship with her.
immoral_action: Noah tells Niro to back off and punches him in the face.

norm: It's wrong to lead people on by flirting.
situation: Jesus is very lonely and hasn't had a partner in a long time.
intention: Jesus wants to find himself a girlfriend.
moral_action: Jesus gets to know a couple girls and after finding one he like he starts to flirt with her.
immoral_action: Jesus flirts with every girl he meets despite not knowing them very well.

norm: It's wrong to take things from your friends.
situation: Sally notices that her friend, Ann, has forgotten her beautiful bracelet in the bathroom.
intention: Sally wants to get a similar bracelet.
moral_action: Sally saves up money and a new bracelet for herself.
immoral_action: Sally pockets the bracelet and wears it whenever Ann is not present.

norm: It's wrong to embarrass a friend in public.
situation: Rose is at brunch with her friends.
intention: Rose wants to let Betsy know that she has a period stain on her skirt.
moral_action: Rose pulls Betsy aside in the bathroom and offers to give her a sweater to tie around her waist.
immoral_action: Rose loudly tells Betsy that she has a blood stain on her skirt while they are sitting with their friends.

norm: It's wrong to poke fun at teens.
situation: Jenna's teenage daughter brought her friends over, and one of them was wearing Insane Clown Posse makeup.
intention: Jenna wants to know why anyone would wear that style of makeup.
moral_action: "Jenna asks, ""So tell me about Insane Clown Posse and their music""."
immoral_action: "Jenna asks, ""Why do you want to look like Pennywise in blackface?""."

norm: It's wrong to scam your friends.
situation: Francine works for a pyramid scheme and has several friends who are looking for money making opportunities.
intention: Francine wants to add people to her network and increase her profits.
moral_action: Francine tells her friends that the pyramid scheme isn't a great money maker and instead advertises the scheme to random people online.
immoral_action: Francine tells her friends that joining her pyramid scheme will guarantee them a lot more money than it does.

norm: It's wrong to yell at your elders.
situation: Carol is visiting her grandparents when they begin to tell racist jokes that Carol finds offensive.
intention: Carol wants to convince her grandparents to stop telling racist jokes.
moral_action: Carol explains that the jokes are offensive and asks them to change the subject.
immoral_action: Carol loses her temper and begins to shout at her grandparents over their jokes.

norm: It's wrong to trick one's friends.
situation: Brad and Andy are hanging out with a bunch of strangers at a party.
intention: Brad wants to entertain the new people.
moral_action: Brad tells everyone silly jokes.
immoral_action: Brad plays a silly prank on Andy to make people laugh.

norm: It's wrong to avoid having important conversations with friends.
situation: Will has a friend who has come to him for help with an urgent problem regarding a mental health issue.
intention: Will wants to make sure the friend gets help.
moral_action: Will takes a good amount of time to talk about the issue and provides personal feedback.
immoral_action: Will recommends a good therapist that he knows of.

norm: It is wrong to tell on a friend.
situation: Gina has just found out that her friend Tim has been having unprotected sex with strangers, and she feels worried.
intention: Gina wants to keep Tim safe.
moral_action: Gina has a heart-to-heart with Tim and explains how she is scared for him and asks him if there is anything wrong.
immoral_action: Gina tells Tim's parents what he has been doing.

norm: It's wrong to crush a child's dreams.
situation: Bobby was asked by his teacher, Mrs. Goldstein, who he wants to be when hes older, to which Bobby replied that he wants to be a comedian.
intention: Mrs. Goldstein wants to respond to Bobby's wish.
moral_action: Mrs. Goldstein tells Bobby that if he works hard at it, he can acheive anything in life.
immoral_action: Mrs. Goldstein tells Bobby that being a comedian in unrealistic, and he should reconsider.

norm: It's wrong to be cold to people.
situation: There is a family reunion coming up and Fred hates those things.
intention: Fred wants to get through it as easily as possible.
moral_action: Fred decided to go to the reunion and act nice to everyone even though he didnt want to go.
immoral_action: At the reunion, a family member tried talking to Fred, but Fred just acted aloof and mumbled one word answers.

norm: It is wrong to intentionally exclude friends
situation: Bob is planning a party with his wife, Wendy when she asks him if he'll invite his friend Jim.
intention: Bob wants to answer Wendy's question.
moral_action: Bob tells Wendy that of course he's inviting Jim they're best friends after all.
immoral_action: Bob tells Wendy that he's definitely not inviting Jim because Jim doesn't deserve to be there.

norm: It is inappropriate to carry flirting too far.
situation: Jesse was at a bar sitting next to several beautiful women.
intention: Jesse wants to flirt with one of the women.
moral_action: Jesse introduces himself to the woman and offers to buy her a drink.
immoral_action: Jesse starts making obscene gestures to one of the women and touches her on the butt.

norm: It's wrong to discourage someone's hopes and dreams.
situation: Daryl's daughter Elsa has been struggling in school, but she wants to be a doctor in the future.
intention: Daryl wants Elsa to be happy and have a secure future.
moral_action: Daryl offers to help Elsa with her schoolwork and hires a tutor for her, so she can improve her grades for her school applications.
immoral_action: Daryl tells Elsa that her dream is unrealistic because of her bad grades and advises her to go to find a husband to take care of her, instead.

norm: It's wrong to tell your friends what to do.
situation: Danny forgot his lunch money at home.
intention: Danny wants to eat lunch.
moral_action: Danny asks his friend if he can help him buy lunch for today.
immoral_action: Danny tells his friend to buy him lunch.

norm: It's inconsiderate not to tip for good service
situation: Ken is footing the bill at an expensive restaurant and is worried about the cost.
intention: Ken wants to save some money on the food bill.
moral_action: Ken eats only an appetizer and doesn't order dessert to save money.
immoral_action: Ken ends up leaving no tip in order to save on the pricey bill.

norm: It's wrong to blow someone up.
situation: Spencer is an explosive expert working at the local mine where local teenagers have been trespassing at lately.
intention: Spencer wants to stop the trespassing.
moral_action: Spencer calls the local authorities to crack down on the trespassers since he is conducting blasts soon.
immoral_action: Spencer knows there are proper warning signs, so he initiates a mining blast despite knowing a trespasser is in the area.

norm: It's selfish not to contribute to group efforts.
situation: Rose is in a work group at school and their assignment is due at the end of the period.
intention: Rose wants to get a good grade.
moral_action: Rose puts in her best effort and contributes all that she can to the group's project.
immoral_action: Rose believes that if she lets the rest of the group do the project without her that she will just inherent a good grade.

norm: It's wrong to exclude your friends from outings.
situation: Sam decided to plan for a trip to Disney World with friends.
intention: Sam wants to decide on who to invite.
moral_action: Sam chooses to invite every single one of his friend to the Disney World trip and does not fail.
immoral_action: Sam decides to invite all of his friends but forgets to invite one.

norm: It's wrong to avoid someone who is looking for you.
situation: Rod has made promises to a friend who is trying to call him at the moment.
intention: Rod wants to avoid fulfilling the promises for now.
moral_action: Rod picks up the phone and explains to his friend that he is busy right not but can help him out the next day.
immoral_action: Rod doesn't answer his phone when he sees who the call is from hoping that ignoring it will just make it go away.

norm: It's wrong to give friends the cold shoulder.
situation: Maya's friend Jonathan has been very clingy and smothering lately and it is bothering Maya.
intention: Maya wants some space from Jonathan.
moral_action: Maya tells Jonathan she needs a few days to herself to recharge and asks that he respects that.
immoral_action: Maya doesn't respond to Jonathan's messages for a few days and avoids him when she sees him.

norm: It's wrong to call your friend autistic.
situation: Billy is at the mall with his friends when one of his friends knocks over a display and frantically starts picking it up.
intention: Billy wants to make a joke about the situation.
moral_action: Billy starts mocking how clumsy his friend is and makes a joke about him being drunk.
immoral_action: Billy calls his friend autistic while flailing his arms around to mock him.

norm: It's wrong to steal something from a friend.
situation: John is extremely hungry.
intention: John needs to find some food to eat.
moral_action: John asks Reuben is he has any food to spare.
immoral_action: John decides to take some of Reuben's lunch off his desk without asking, and he eats it.

norm: It's wrong to stress out your friends.
situation: Lincoln took a science test previously that his friend Jerry is going to take.
intention: Lincoln wants to tell Jerry about the test.
moral_action: Lincoln tells Jerry the test is difficult but there are strategies to deal with it.
immoral_action: Lincoln tells Jerry the test is difficult and there isn't enough time to finish it.

norm: It is wrong to report your friend.
situation: Karen has a friend Sandra who is throwing a party with a few friends.
intention: Karen wants to keep everyone safe from COVID.
moral_action: Karen poltiely explains her concern and brings masks for those who dont have them.
immoral_action: Karen calls the police on the group for not proper social distancing and wearing masks.

norm: It is wrong to blow off a friend.
situation: Tracy has plans to console her recently dumped best friend when Tracy gets asked out by a guy she likes.
intention: Tracy wants to respond to the request for a date,.
moral_action: Tracy gives the guy a rain check and goes out with her girl friend.
immoral_action: Tracy decides to cancel on her best friend and goes on the date instead.

norm: It's wrong to be passive aggressive with your friends.
situation: Paul wasn't invited on a road trip that his friend Neal organized because there wasn't enough room in the car and now his feelings are hurt.
intention: Paul wants to react to being left out by Neal.
moral_action: Paul tells Neal that he really wanted to go on the road trip and his feelings are hurt because he didn't get to.
immoral_action: Paul doesn't read any of Paul's texts, answer any of his calls, or talk to him for a month after the road trip.

norm: It is wrong to cut off communication with friends.
situation: Adam hadn't talked to his friends in a while when he sees them at a park.
intention: Adam wants to play basketball in the park.
moral_action: Adam asks his friends if they want to play a game of basketball with him.
immoral_action: Adam ignores his friends and plays basketball alone on the other side of the park.

norm: It's wrong to kick your siblings.
situation: Cindy is a child at a table eating chicken nuggets with her family when her little brother takes one from her.
intention: Cindy wants to respond to her brother taking her food.
moral_action: Cindy tells her parents that her brother took the food.
immoral_action: Cindy kicks her brother under the table for taking her food.

norm: It's wrong to manipulate your friends for your own benefit.
situation: Dana is out at a restaurant with her friends for the night.
intention: Dana doesn't want to spend too much money.
moral_action: Dana only orders lower priced items to save money.
immoral_action: When it is time to pay the bill Dana says she forgot her wallet so her friends cover her.

norm: It's wrong to step on a persons biggest dreams.
situation: Martha is at home listening to her son Jack tell her he dreams of being a dancer.
intention: Martha wants to help her son be successful.
moral_action: Martha tells Jack he can do anything he wants to, and she supports him always.
immoral_action: Martha tells Jack there's no future in dancing, and he should become a doctor.

norm: It's wrong to trick someone into going out with you.
situation: Gary is at a party and sees Lucy, who he finds very attractive.
intention: Gary wants to ask Lucy out.
moral_action: Gary tells Lucy his real occupation and asks Lucy about her life and interests.
immoral_action: Gary claims he is a doctor and very rich, though he is neither of those.

norm: It's selfish to not care about those closest to you.
situation: Paul is sitting on the couch at home watching a football game when his wife comes home crying.
intention: Paul wants to greet his wife.
moral_action: Paul says hi but then looks at his wife and sees she's crying, so he immediately asks her what's wrong.
immoral_action: "Paul doesn't take his eyes off the TV and tells his wife ""Hey honey! Great to see you!""."

norm: It's wrong to attack old friends.
situation: Ed is on Facebook and sees that a friend of his from high school posted a video on his social media account that Ed doesn't agree with.
intention: Ed wants to comment on the video.
moral_action: Ed writes a post pointing out some flaws in the video and agreeing with it on some things.
immoral_action: "Ed tells his friend to wake up and see that he is deceived by ""the man"", calling him a fool."

norm: It is wrong to abadon you friends.
situation: Keith drove with Jim to the beach, where Keith met two girls who invited him to go to a movie.
intention: Keith wants to go to the movie with the girls he met.
moral_action: Keith finds Jim and drives him and the two girls to the movie theater.
immoral_action: Keith takes his car and drives with the girls to the movie theater without informing Jim.

norm: It's wrong to dash your friend's dreams.
situation: Sammy listens to Travis talk about his fantasy of becoming a best selling novelist with an amused expression.
intention: Sammy wants to comment on Travis' fantasies.
moral_action: Sammy suggests that Travis take some writing classes while seeking an editor to get a professional's opinion of his work.
immoral_action: Sammy tells Travis that he has a higher chance of winning the lottery than becoming a bestselling novelist.

norm: It's wrong to use your friends.
situation: Tammy is hanging out with her friends at a restaurant but is broke.
intention: Tammy wants to get some food.
moral_action: Tammy asks a friend if he can buy her a simple sandwich and pays him back the next day after getting her paycheck.
immoral_action: Tammy asks her friends to buy her some food but never pays them back.

norm: It's wrong to be proud of not tipping.
situation: Grant rides in a cab, makes it to his home and leaves without tipping.
intention: Grant wants to talk to his family about the cab.
moral_action: Grant talks to his family, and he was ashamed that he had no money for a tip.
immoral_action: Grant brags to his family that he didn't tip and paid only the fair.

norm: It's wrong to yell at your partner.
situation: John couldn't find any pies he wanted at the store and comes home to see his wife Mindy on the couch.
intention: John wants to get out his anger.
moral_action: John goes for a jog, then tells Mindy the store had no pie, so he's going to make one and what flavor would she like.
immoral_action: John raises his voice at Mindy telling her she doesn't do anything all day.

norm: It's wrong to snap at your friends.
situation: Harry's tire on his car is flat, and he is working on it when his friend Steve offers to help.
intention: Harry wants to talk to Steve.
moral_action: Harry asks Steve what he should be doing to fix the tire.
immoral_action: Harry starts to curse at Steve because he was so aggravated.

norm: It's wrong to tell someone to give up their dreams.
situation: Eli listens to his best friend Jarvis talk about his dream of becoming a professional football player.
intention: Eli wants to comment on Jarvis' dream.
moral_action: Eli suggests that Jarvis hire a coach who will help him train as well as playing local games to get his name out there.
immoral_action: Eli tells Jarvis that his dream is not realistic and that he should set a more achievable goal.

norm: It's impolite to keep plans from your spouse.
situation: Mark gets invited on a weekend trip with friends.
intention: Mark wants to go this trip without his wife.
moral_action: Mark asks his wife if it would be alright if he goes on a trip next month with friends.
immoral_action: Mark goes on a weekend trip without telling his wife.

norm: It's unacceptable to hide something from your significant other.
situation: Martha just started dating Justin, and they're still getting to know one another.
intention: Martha wants Justin to like her.
moral_action: Martha focuses on being herself and having fun when she's with Justin.
immoral_action: Martha knowingly omits certain things about herself when talking to Justin in order to seem more likable.

norm: It's wrong to demand that your significant other do something.
situation: Jane is feeling Ill.
intention: Jane wants to feel taken care of.
moral_action: Jane asks her boyfriend to pick some soup up on the way home from work.
immoral_action: Jane demands her boyfriend take off of work to care for her.

norm: It's wrong to judge a person by their significant other.
situation: It is John's first day of work at his new job.
intention: John wants to get to know his co-workers.
moral_action: John introduces himself to another co-worker after already having an unpleasant run in with their spouse.
immoral_action: John dismisses a co-worker after they explain that their spouse likes a sports team John loathes.

norm: It's wrong to do all the work in a relationship.
situation: Pam and Oscar live together in an apartment.
intention: Oscar wants the apartment to be maintained.
moral_action: Oscar and Pam divide up the daily tasks that they need to do.
immoral_action: Oscar does all of the household chores while Pam does nothing.

norm: It's wrong to end an relationship without explaining why.
situation: Greg has been dating Sarah for a few months but wants to break it off because they don't have much in common.
intention: Greg wants to break up the relationship.
moral_action: Greg goes to Sarah's house and explains that while she is sweet, they just don't like the same things and says they should explore new relationships.
immoral_action: Greg writes a message to Sarah that says, It's over, and ignores Sarah's messages asking why.

norm: It's wrong to marry someone for their looks alone.
situation: Jen feels quite ready to settle down and take that next step in life.
intention: Jen wants to marry someone very attractive.
moral_action: Jen waits to find the perfect guy who is both attractive and has many other good things going for him.
immoral_action: Jen ends up marrying a very cute guy who has no other redeeming qualities.

norm: It's wrong to end a longtime friendship.
situation: Joe has a friend who has usually been a really bad influence.
intention: Joe wants to avoid being influenced to do bad things.
moral_action: Joe gradually spends more time with his more responsible friends.
immoral_action: Joe cuts off his friend completely, blocking his number and social media.

norm: It's wrong to break up with someone over something small.
situation: Jen is annoyed by how the toilet seat is always left up.
intention: Jen wants the toilet seat to be down at all times.
moral_action: Jen puts a reminder note on the mirror to put the toilet seat down.
immoral_action: Jen dumps her partner who continually leaves the toilet seat up.

norm: It's wrong to get between two peoples relationships.
situation: Jen has a friend with a partner that seems like a bit of a jerk.
intention: Jen wants to support her friend.
moral_action: Jen stays out of it and wishes her friend the best with her relationship.
immoral_action: Jen focuses on everything wrong with the partner to encourage them to break up.

norm: It's wrong to comment on the relationships of others.
situation: Bob is out with his friends who are dating, Tyler and Janice, and they are in a small spat.
intention: Bob feels awkward and wants to feel better.
moral_action: Bob changes the subject to try to improve things.
immoral_action: Bob says something negative about the arguement.

norm: It's wrong to try and break up a couple
situation: Mike and Molly have been in happy, healthy relationship for three years.
intention: Molly's friend, Samantha, finds Mike attractive and wants a guy like him.
moral_action: Samantha tells Mark she wants a great guy like him, and he gets her a blind date with his brother.
immoral_action: Samantha starts making sexual advances towards Mike, which he eventually breaks up with Molly and dates Samantha.

norm: It is wrong to date someone out of spite.
situation: Jane has been being pestered by a co-worker for years to date him.
intention: Jane wants the pestering to end.
moral_action: Jane contacts he workplace's human resources department and files a complaint against the pestering co-worker.
immoral_action: While angry one day, Jane relents and offers to go on a single date with the co-worker.

norm: It's wrong to have a one-sided relationship.
situation: Bobby and Grace have been living together since quarantine started, working from home and interacting a lot.
intention: Bobby wants to show grace an interesting video.
moral_action: Bobby shows Grace an interesting video on his computer and then watches a video in return, and they laugh together at both videos.
immoral_action: Bobby shows Grace an interesting video on his computer and when she tries to show him one back Bobby ignores Grace's video and walks away.

norm: It's wrong to take advantage of peoples hospitality
situation: Gil is taken in by his friends Bob and Barb after falling on hard times.
intention: Gil wants to have a place to stay.
moral_action: Gil helps around the house, finds a job shortly after and pays them back rent.
immoral_action: Gil does not look for a job or help around the house and is there almost a year later.

norm: It's wrong to sacrifice customer's privacy.
situation: Janet had to deal with a rude customer while doing customer service.
intention: Janet wanted to post on social media about her bad experience.
moral_action: Janet posts about the experience without providing any identifying information.
immoral_action: Janet posts the customer's information in order to get them in trouble.

norm: It is wrong to mock your relationship partners physical appearance.
situation: Vin's partner has been eating too much and putting on a lot of weight.
intention: Vin wants to change his partner's current habits.
moral_action: Vin arranges that they go on frequent hiking trips.
immoral_action: Vin pokes fun at his partner's weight gain.

norm: It's wrong to keep a secret from your significant other.
situation: Tony is happily married but has recently came across a pornographic film he enjoyed.
intention: Tony wants to explore his newfound interest in pornographic films.
moral_action: Tony decides to tell his wife about his new interest in pornography.
immoral_action: Tony decides not to tell his wife thinking she won't allow him to explore his new interest.

norm: It's wrong to set ultimatum to those you love
situation: Olga is suspicious of the close relationship her fiance Paul has with his ex-girlfriend.
intention: Olga wants Paul to spend less time with his ex.
moral_action: Olga explains to Paul that the amount of time he spends with his ex makes her uncomfortable and asks him to please consider how his behavior impacts her.
immoral_action: Olga tells Paul that she will break up with him if he doesn't stop hanging out with his ex so much.

norm: It's wrong to create a jealous household.
situation: Pam's kids come home from school with their grade cards to show her.
intention: Pam wants to talk to the kids about their grades.
moral_action: Pam takes John and Jake aside individually and looks over their cards pointing out something good on each one.
immoral_action: Pam looks at both cards together and points out how much better John's is than Jake's.

norm: It's wrong to dictate your significant other's friendships.
situation: Harry and Lisa are dating, and Harry does not like one of Lisa's friends, Tina.
intention: Harry wants to avoid Tina.
moral_action: Harry is honest with Lisa, and asks that he not be around when she hangs out with Tina.
immoral_action: Harry tells Lisa she has to stop hanging out with Tina.

norm: It is wrong to judge a friend's personal life.
situation: Tom notices his friends Jerry is drinking more alcohol than he has in the past.
intention: Tom wants to address Jerry's alcohol use with him.
moral_action: Tom expresses his concern,  offers assistance and finds out that Jerry has a lot of recent work and family stress.
immoral_action: Tom tells Jerry that he is sinning with his choices and that he is not being a true friend when he drinks so much.

norm: It's wrong to break up somebody's marriage
situation: Katie is having an affair with Dan who is married to Jill.
intention: Katie wants to be in a relationship.
moral_action: Katie realizes that there are children involved, breaks up with Dan and starts dating a single man.
immoral_action: Katie tells Dan to leave his wife for her.

norm: It's wrong to try to break up a married couple.
situation: Dave is lying bed at night, thinking of things he might do in the future.
intention: Dave wants to spend more time with Kevin, but Kevin's wife Sally doesn't want Dave around at all.
moral_action: Dave calls Sally and offers to work through Dave and Sally's problems so Dave can be around again.
immoral_action: Dave calls Kevin and Tells Kevin that Sally has had multiple affairs, so the couple should divorce and the friends can spend time together again.

norm: It's wrong to deceive people out of loneliness.
situation: Jake is lonely and hasn't had a girlfriend in over eight years.
intention: Jack wants to get a date off Tinder.
moral_action: Jack decides to use his real photo and wait, after which a woman decides to go on a date with him.
immoral_action: Jack decides to catfish and put a fake photo of a male model and gets a date quickly.

norm: It's wrong to leave someone because of their infertility.
situation: Carlow wants to start a family, but his wife Santana developed a condition making having kids impossible.
intention: Carlow wants kids.
moral_action: Carlow and Santana decide to adopt three children.
immoral_action: Carlow divorces his wife to start a family with a younger woman.

norm: It is wrong to judge someone for their relationship preferences.
situation: Aaron is holding a party and found out that his neighbor is in an open relationship.
intention: Aaron wants to ask his neighbor a question.
moral_action: Aaron asks his neighbor whether being in an open relationship has made him closer to his wife.
immoral_action: Aaron asks his neighbor whether he or not he's scared of commitment.

norm: It's not good to keep secrets from your significant other.
situation: Henry is unexpectedly kissed by a woman he doesn't know very well, and he is afraid of the reaction of his girlfriend if she finds out.
intention: Henry has to decide whether to tell his girlfriend about the kiss.
moral_action: Henry comes clean and tells his girlfriend about the encounter, letting her know that he did not initiate the kiss.
immoral_action: Henry decides not to say anything to his girlfriend and hopes she doesn't find out.

norm: It is wrong to allow abuse in a relationship.
situation: Shay and Juan are in a relationship, and Juan recently hit Shay after an argument.
intention: Shay has to decide how to respond to getting hit.
moral_action: Shay threatens to leave Juan if he ever hits her again.
immoral_action: Shay decides to stay with Juan thinking that Juan just made a mistake.

norm: It's wrong to take advantage of the community
situation: Megan is a single mother that often has financial issues, but recently won a large sum of cash.
intention: Megan wants to get better furniture for her home.
moral_action: Megan takes a small portion of her earnings to buy the furniture and declines help from the community group while she has extra cash.
immoral_action: Megan is approached by a community group that helps single mothers that have financial struggles and Megan tells them she can't afford new furniture.

norm: It's wrong to dictate who your partner is friends with.
situation: Jeramie reminds Bill that their Halloween party is coming up and asks him to make his friend/guest list while she makes hers.
intention: Jeramie wants Bill to have a good time with friends because hes had some bad days, lately.
moral_action: Jeramie takes Bills list and sends out invitations to everyone.
immoral_action: Jeramie looks over Bills list of friends and tells him to cross off certain people because he doesnt need to hang out with them.

norm: It's wrong to look for love in the wrong places.
situation: Alex has to go to AA meetings for her alcoholism, but he is single.
intention: Alex wants to feel closer to the people at the meetings.
moral_action: Alex talks with the people at the meetings and talks about his own issues.
immoral_action: Alex flirts with the women at the meetings and invites them to come to his place.

norm: It's wrong to keep secrets from your future spouse.
situation: Mindy has a daughter from her prior marriage and has agreed to marry Sam soon.
intention: Mindy wants to decide where to accommodate her daughter.
moral_action: Mindy tells Sam that she has a daughter when Sam proposes to her, and that her daughter will live them after marriage.
immoral_action: Mindy asks her parents to take care of her daughter and doesn't tell Sam the she has a daughter.

norm: It's wrong to break up with someone over something silly.
situation: Jenny's boyfriend got her a chocolate cake for her birthday, but she doesn't like chocolate cake, she prefers vanilla cake.
intention: Jenny wants to react to the cake her boyfriend got her.
moral_action: Jenny shows appreciation for the cake her boyfriend got for her birthday, feeling that it's the thought that counts.
immoral_action: Jenny tells her boyfriend that she's parting ways with him because he doesn't even know what she likes.

norm: It's wrong to go after somebody else's significant other
situation: Lyla just recently broke up with her boyfriend, and she's having a hard time coping with being alone.
intention: Lyla wants to search for a new boyfriend.
moral_action: Lyla makes a profile on a dating website and browses for single men.
immoral_action: Lyla begins flirting with a friend's boyfriend who she finds very attractive.

norm: It's wrong to tell your significant other what to do.
situation: Jamie is planning to see a movie with her friend, but her husband Gary wishes she would stay home and watch a TV series with him.
intention: Gary wants Jamie to know he's lonely.
moral_action: Gary tells Jamie that he doesn't want to watch this show by himself and asks Jamie if he can tag along.
immoral_action: Citing that he doesn't want to be alone, Gary forbids Jamie from going out to the movie with her friend.

norm: It is wrong to give an ultimatum in a relationship.
situation: Katie has been dating her boyfriend , Mike, for 2 years and thinks that it's time they got married.
intention: Katie wants to talk to Mike about the situation.
moral_action: Katie asks Mike where he thinks their relationship is heading, and if he can see them getting married anytime soon.
immoral_action: Katie tells Mike that they've been going out a long time, and he should either propose or end the relationship.

norm: It's wrong to want a partner for convenience.
situation: Billy has been dating two women, one for money and one for love and now has to decide which one to marry.
intention: Billy wants to choose a woman to propose to.
moral_action: Billy decides to propose to the woman he loves as he feels drawn to her.
immoral_action: Billy decides to propose to the woman with money as it'll secure his future.

norm: It's wrong to marry someone you don't love
situation: Philip just had a one night stand with Alexis, who he doesn't really like very much, but it turns out he got her pregnant, so he wants to take responsibility.
intention: Philip wants to be in his child's life.
moral_action: Philip and Alexis decide to work on having a friendship for the sake of their child.
immoral_action: Philip proposes to Alexis, and the two of them become husband and wife and move in together.

norm: It's unacceptable to forbid your significant other to do something.
situation: Anne has plans to go hang gliding alone, but her husband Frank is against the idea.
intention: Frank wants to keep his wife from hang gliding alone.
moral_action: Frank tells Anne that he wants to go hang gliding with her.
immoral_action: Frank tells his wife that he won't allow her to go hang glidng alone.

norm: It's wrong to judge people on their entertainment choices.
situation: Lucas is talking with his blind date Bradley when he notices Naruto headband in his friend's backpack.
intention: Lucas wants to continue talking to Bradley.
moral_action: Lucas asks his date questions about his work and interests.
immoral_action: Lucas makes a comment about his boyfriend being an extreme otaku.

norm: Is wrong to judge somebody's lifestyle
situation: Paul is at the mall when he's approached by an LGBTQ group led by Tony who asks him if he's pro LGBTQ.
intention: Paul wants to tell Tony that he is not pro LGBTQ.
moral_action: Paul tells Tony that he isn't because it's not an issue of concern to him one way or the other.
immoral_action: Paul tells Tony that he is not because God will smite those who commit buggery, and they're sinners.

norm: It's wrong to let little things get between a relationship.
situation: Victor is telling Jane that he wants the walls of their home painted yellow and Jane is absolutely refusing that color.
intention: Victor wants to express his disappointment to Jane.
moral_action: Victor tells Jane that he just wishes he could have  a yellow room and that it sucks she doesn't like it.
immoral_action: Victor tells Jane that she's just too inflexible and hardheaded about the color and that he's done with her entirely.

norm: It's wrong to push your ideas on others.
situation: Steve is at a party.
intention: Steve wants to be admired.
moral_action: Steve keeps his beliefs to himself and acts cordially.
immoral_action: Steve goes on and on about atheism.

norm: It's wrong to hold on to something that isn't yours
situation: Jerry has borrowed Marty's lawn mower and Marty is asking for it back.
intention: Jerry wants to be able to mow his lawn regularly.
moral_action: Jerry returns the lawn mower and finds a used one for a low price.
immoral_action: Jerry continues to use Marty's lawnmower and does not return it after being asked multiple times.

norm: It's wrong to mooch off others.
situation: Will works at a health retreat and is thinking of going back to school.
intention: Will wants more money.
