norm: It's wrong to vote for someone just to antagonize others.
situation: Connie is listening to Dennis insult her for not supporting Bernie Sanders.
intention: Connie wants to vent her frustrations.
moral_action: Connie vents her feelings in a private blog post that she sends to Dennis.
immoral_action: Connie tells Dennis as a joke that she wanted to make America great again by voting for Trump.

norm: It's wrong to divorce people without a good reason.
situation: Paul has been married for a decade.
intention: Paul wants to talk about the marriage with his wife.
moral_action: Paul tells his wife that he loves her, and they should be able to work out problems.
immoral_action: Paul tells his wife that he wants a divorce and says that's just the way he feels.

norm: It is wrong to knowingly be insane towards other people.
situation: Jack, a magician by trade, is in a mental ward for two weeks and is bored with the patients.
intention: Jack wants to show off his unique personality to the mental ward.
moral_action: Jack decides to show off a card trick to the other patients.
immoral_action: Jack decides to balance a toilet paper roll on his head while shouting random phrases.

norm: It's wrong to seek revenge on others.
situation: Fred was ripped off by a fast food place that double charged him.
intention: Fred wants to avoid getting ripped off again.
moral_action: Fred simply refuses to go to that specific fast food location.
immoral_action: Fred takes revenge on the location by standing outside and warning everyone they'll rip you off.

norm: It's wrong to hurt people you're stronger than.
situation: Bill is talking to his son Lee in the kitchen.
intention: Bill wants Lee to know that he is unhappy with his performance at school.
moral_action: Bill explains that Lee will be deprived of various freedoms until Lee's grades improve.
immoral_action: Bill grabs Lee and holds Lee while slapping Lee across the face.

norm: It's wrong to wish for destruction on people.
situation: After losing a loved one in the 9/11 attacks Peter is asked to write an article on his feelings towards Muslim's.
intention: Peter wants to express his feelings in the article.
moral_action: Peter writes about the importance of separating the actions of a few from the intent of the entire Muslim faith.
immoral_action: Peter writes an article calling for the annihilation of all Muslims in order to curtail further terrorist attacks.

norm: It's wrong to treat people like terrorists without reason.
situation: Dan is suspicious of his new neighbor Ahmed from Iran.
intention: Dan wants to make sure Ahmed is a normal person.
moral_action: Dan walks over to Ahmed's home and has a conversation with him.
immoral_action: Dan calls the FBI to do a search on Ahmed's home.

norm: It is wrong to kick someone out of a group.
situation: Harry is the leader of a gaming clan and one of the older members is causing problems with many of the others.
intention: Harry wants to keep the peace in his clan.
moral_action: Harry gives the member a warning and instructs him to change his behavior.
immoral_action: Harry kicks out the member who seems to be causing all the trouble.

norm: It's wrong to hate things meant to help people.
situation: Robert recently hears about legislation that bolsters unemployment benefits and has an opportunity to make an influential comment on it.
intention: Robert wants to comment on the legislation bolstering unemployment benefits.
moral_action: Robert offers a reasonably supportive view of the legislation bolstering unemployment benefits.
immoral_action: Robert argues against the legislation boosting unemployment benefits and explains exactly why he despises it.

norm: You shouldn't approve of your grandchildren's irresponsible behavior.
situation: Neji watches his grandson do dangerous stunts on their bicycles.
intention: Neji wants to make his grandson happy.
moral_action: Neji says that he's cooking his grandson's favorite food, and Neji gives safety tips during supper.
immoral_action: Neji cheers on his grandson for the edge of the sidewalk.

norm: It's wrong to reveal one's secrets just to spite them.
situation: Anthony had recently told Billy a deep dark secret about himself, and a few days later they are now in a large fight in front of their other friends.
intention: Billy wants to win the argument with Anthony.
moral_action: Billy uses something Anthony said prior in the argument to prove he is wrong.
immoral_action: Billy uses the secret Anthony told him against him, to try to get points with everyone else.

norm: You shouldn't be happy about your friend failing at something.
situation: Sandy was in a class with her best friend, Amy, and they studied together every night.
intention: Sandy wanted to be at the top in her class.
moral_action: Sandy offered to help Amy study harder for the test so Amy wouldnt fail, for which Amy was very grateful.
immoral_action: When Amy almost failed her final text, Sandy was happy because Amy would not be a threat to her being the top student.

norm: It is wrong to be unfaithful
situation: Glenn is away from his wife on a business trip in another city, and he runs into his ex-girlfriend Cindy, who gives him her number.
intention: Glenn wants to decide what to do this evening.
moral_action: Glenn goes back to his hotel room and calls his wife to chat all evening.
immoral_action: Glenn calls Cindy up to meet for drinks, and he ends up spending the night with her.

norm: It's wrong to use bullying tactics to get things done.
situation: Amber is a busy lunch room at school and finds that she has forgotten her lunch money.
intention: Amber wants to buy herself lunch.
moral_action: Amber asks the person next to her in the lunch room if they have an extra dollar or two.
immoral_action: Amber finds a younger student nearby and puts her hand on his chest, pushing him towards the wall to get his money out of his pocket.

norm: It's rude to yell at the top of your lungs
situation: Annie is having dinner at a restaurant.
intention: Annie wants to get a different dish than the one she has.
moral_action: Annie talks to the waiter politely, and he brings her a new dish.
immoral_action: Annie yells at the waiter at the top of her lungs, and he brings her a new dish.

norm: It's rude to yell at someone.
situation: Sarah is driving to work but is stuck on a street corner by an old lady who is crossing the street very slowly.
intention: Sarah wants to get to work as soon as possible.
moral_action: Sarah asks the old lady if she can help her and ends up helping her to cross the street.
immoral_action: Sarah yells at the old lady and tells her to hurry up.

norm: It's rude to call someone names.
situation: Peter is acting loudly and obnoxious in public.
intention: Steve wants Peter to stop.
moral_action: Steve asks Peter quietly to calm down.
immoral_action: Steve loudly calls Peter insulting names, making people look over at them.

norm: It is rude to yell at someone with a disbaility.
situation: Jerry is forced to be in a wheel chair and accidentally runs over David's toe at a party.
intention: David wants to release his sudden anger.
moral_action: David turns around and hops away grunting under his breath.
immoral_action: David yells at Jerry and tells him to watch where he's going.

norm: It is rude to leave when people are speaking
situation: Jerry is working at his desk with a chatty coworker pops in to chat.
intention: Jerry wants to get his work done.
moral_action: Jerry gets frustrated with his coworker's chatting and asks if they can talk later, so he can work.
immoral_action: Jerry gets frustrated with his coworker's chatting and storms out of the office.

norm: It's rude to snap at someone.
situation: Stacy's coworker is really bothering her with constant yammering and distractions.
intention: Stacy wants her coworker to leave her alone to do her work.
moral_action: Stacy takes some time to gently tell her coworker that she needs some quiet while she's working.
immoral_action: Once Stacy has lost all patience with her coworker she yells at them to shut up.

norm: It is rude to call people names.
situation: Jane and Jeff are having an argument over something they disagree on.
intention: Jeff wants to convey his frustration with Jane's reasoning.
moral_action: Jeff points out the flaws in Jane's logic and asks her to reconsider her position.
immoral_action: Jeff calls Jane a complete moron for disagreeing with what Jeff is claiming.

norm: It is rude to chew with your mouth open.
situation: Kendra is at Red Lobster having lunch with her coworkers.
intention: Kendra wants to see how her coworkers are getting on with their project.
moral_action: Kendra eats a bit of her meal, then asks everyone how their project is coming along.
immoral_action: Kendra shoves shrimp in her mouth as fast as she can while talking to coworkers.

norm: It's rude to shout things at people in public.
situation: Jared is out on a dinner date with his new girlfriend Lisa, and they need some menus.
intention: Jared wants to get the server's attention.
moral_action: Jared calmly signals with his hand after catching his server's eye across the room.
immoral_action: Jared rudely yells across the room that he needs some service at his table.

norm: It is rude to interrupt someone you are conversing with.
situation: Robert is eating lunch with one of his coworkers, whom is telling him about their week at work.
intention: Robert wants to express his recent frustrations that he's experienced at work.
moral_action: Robert waits for his coworker to vent their frustration, and then expresses his frustrations in kind.
immoral_action: Robert interupts his coworker in the middle of their story and starts complaining about his week.

norm: It is rude to call people incessantly
situation: Sara is really excited about a new promotion which was just offered.
intention: Sara wants to share the news with her best friend.
moral_action: Sara calls her friend once and leaves a text to call her back.
immoral_action: Sara calls her friend who is unavailable over and over.

norm: It is rude to yell at an elder.
situation: John is driving and is in front of a traffic light that has just turned green, but an old lady is still slowly crossing the street.
intention: John wants to drive through the intersection before the light turns red again.
moral_action: John avoids saying anything and cautiously drives around the old lady.
immoral_action: John yells at the old lady to move faster.

norm: It's rude to call someone an insulting name.
situation: Clara is at the pool with her friend Sandy, who has just exited the changing room in her swimsuit.
intention: Clara wants to greet Sandy.
moral_action: "Clara flags Sandy down when she sees her, saying ""Hey girl!"" to get her attention."
immoral_action: "Clara waves when she sees Sandy and says ""Hey Shamu!"" to get her attention."

norm: It is rude to cough on other people.
situation: Jane is at work when she begins to feel a little sick and has a tickle in her throat.
intention: Jane wants to relieve her throat tickle by coughing.
moral_action: Jane covers her mouth with her elbow when she feels a cough coming on.
immoral_action: Jane is speaking with a coworker when she opens her mouth wide to cough.

norm: It's rude to snap at people.
situation: Randal is working on a project when his little brother Jeremy turns on the television.
intention: Randal wants to concentrate.
moral_action: Randal tells  Jeremy to watch a documentary with calming music that Randal has studied to in the past.
immoral_action: Randal says a pointed statement to Jeremy and asks him to leave the room.

norm: It's rude to call people you cared about names.
situation: Jen has just been dumped by her partner after a huge argument.
intention: Jen wants to get back at her partner for leaving her.
moral_action: Jen takes time to focus on her goals and finds success.
immoral_action: Jen insults her ex and picks on his insecurities.

norm: It's rude to angrily raise your voice to strangers.
situation: Billy is on a bus when a passenger he doesn't know steps on his foot.
intention: Billy wants to let the passenger know that they are stepping on his foot.
moral_action: Billy informs the passenger that they are stepping on him and asks them to kindly remove their foot.
immoral_action: Billy yells at the passenger in a harsh tone to get of his foot.

norm: It's rude to raise your voice to people.
situation: Taylor is in a work meeting in a small room where plans are being discussed.
intention: Taylor wants to voice her opinion.
moral_action: Taylor states her opinion at a volume that is clear.
immoral_action: Taylor projects her voice strongly while others are sitting closely.

norm: It is rude to yell at others.
situation: Alex's friend took advantage of him very badly when asking him to help him move.
intention: Alex wants to tell his friend how wrong it was.
moral_action: Alex talks calmly and rationally to his friend about what happened.
immoral_action: Alex screams at his friend the next time he sees him over what he did.

norm: It's rude to keep repeating someone's name over and over.
situation: Cai needs permission to sleep over at his friend's house, but his mother is working.
intention: Cai wants to get his mother's attention.
moral_action: Cai waits until his mother is at a good stopping point before asking his mother about the sleepover.
immoral_action: Cai pokes his mother while chanting his mother's name to get her attention.

norm: It's rude to pretend to be deaf.
situation: A man went up to Jamie trying to get him to listen to his mixtape.
intention: Jamie wanted to figure out a way to get the man to leave him alone.
moral_action: Jamie grabs the mixtape from the man and pretends to be interested.
immoral_action: Jamie pretends that he can't hear the man in order to get him away.

norm: It is rude to interrupt someone's conversation.
situation: Sean needs help with his assignment, but his teacher is talking with someone else.
intention: Sean wants to ask his teacher for help.
moral_action: Sean waits for his teacher's conversation to end before asking for help.
immoral_action: Sean barges into the conversation and asks her teacher for help.

norm: It's rude to talk non-stop to people.
situation: Sharon is a greeter for a hotel and sees a customer coming inside to stay a few nights.
intention: Sharon wants to make the customer feel welcome.
moral_action: Sharon says hello to the customer and exchanges a few questions and answers with him.
immoral_action: Sharon engages the customer in conversation and begins to tell her about every detail of the past week.

norm: It is rude to snap at an authority figure.
situation: Farah is pulled over by a police officer for speeding on the way to work, though she doesn't believe that she was speeding.
intention: Farah wants to try to avoid getting a ticket.
moral_action: Farah is very apologetic to the police officer and explains that she was stressed about her impending work day.
immoral_action: Farah argues with the police office angrily in an attempt to get him to back down.

norm: It's rude to yell out at someone you don't know.
situation: Fred and a friend are walking down the sidewalk when they see a random person driving by slowly in a pink car.
intention: Fred wants to make his friend laugh.
moral_action: Fred points out the paint job to his friend and says that he'd prefer to die than have a car like that.
immoral_action: Fred tells his friend to watch, then shouts at the person driving by as if he knows him very well.

norm: It's rude to say someone's name incorrectly.
situation: Nolan was looking for ways to aggravate his rival James.
intention: Nolan wants to annoy James.
moral_action: Nolan decides to focus on getting better grades than James.
immoral_action: "Nolan started calling James ""Maims"" and starts running away from him in the hall."

norm: It's rude to sneeze or cough on others.
situation: James was feeling sick, but was down to only rice and canned beans to eat.
intention: James wants a decent meal.
moral_action: James uses Uber Eats to order delivery from his favorite Thai restaurant.
immoral_action: James goes to his local grocery store without a mask and coughs and sneezes on everyone.

norm: It's rude to talk with your mouth full.
situation: Finn was sitting in the cafeteria at school with his friends.
intention: Finn wants to eat his food.
moral_action: Finn starts to eat his food and chews with his mouth closed.
immoral_action: Finn puts his sandwich in his mouth and chews it with his mouth wide open.

norm: It's rude to yell at someone for what ever reason.
situation: John is shopping for groceries and finishes up, and is now checking out when the cashier hands him his change which is a dollar less than he's owed.
intention: John wants to let the cashier know they made a mistake.
moral_action: John mentions that the cashier forgot to give him the extra dollar they owed him.
immoral_action: John loudly exclaims that the cashier was trying to shortchange him on purpose.

norm: It's rude to interrupt people while they're talking.
situation: Alex is in a team meeting where one member is presenting something when he comes up with a great idea.
intention: Alex wants to get his idea out before he forgets.
moral_action: Alex writes his idea down in his notes and waits for the presenting member to finish before sharing it.
immoral_action: Alex cuts off the team member who is talking to pitch the idea.

norm: It's rude to make fun of someone's name.
situation: Jack meets a new student at school whose name is Moonblossom.
intention: Jack wants to talk to Moonblossom.
moral_action: Jack tells Moonblossom they will show they around the school.
immoral_action: Jack says that Moonblossom is a name for a person that people won't want to be friends with.

norm: It's rude to yell at people
situation: Tim is riding his bike down the road when Tom almost hits him with his car.
intention: Tim wants to reprimand Tom for the close call.
moral_action: Tim tells Tom that he could have killed him and that one day he probably will kill someone driving like that.
immoral_action: Tim starts yelling at Tom and calling him names saying he almost killed him.

norm: It's rude to play music over people talking.
situation: Charlie is playing a game on his phone while his parents are chatting on the couch.
intention: Charlie wants to listen to some music.
moral_action: Charlie grabs his earbuds, connects them to the phone, and plays music he can only hear.
immoral_action: Charlie walks over to the stereo and plays a rock song on full blast.

norm: It's rude to cut out on someone with no explanation.
situation: Frank is at a party with his friend when he starts getting tired.
intention: Frank wants to go home.
moral_action: Frank takes a minute to inform his friend that he's leaving before heading home.
immoral_action: Frank leaves the party immediately without telling his friend he's going.

norm: It's rude to not do something you promised to do.
situation: Jeff's friend Josh is having his twenty-first birthday party and Jeff volunteers to be the designated driver.
intention: Jeff wants to have a good time.
moral_action: Jeff spends the night in lively conversation with Josh, and drives Josh home after closing time.
immoral_action: Jeff decides to have a few drinks during the birthday celebrations and ends up getting too drunk to drive.

norm: It is rude not to be patient.
situation: James hasn't eaten for eight hours and is waiting in a long line at the grocery store.
intention: James wants to eat as soon as possible.
moral_action: James asks the clerk if it's okay to eat a candy bar that he bought while he's waiting.
immoral_action: "James starts loudly saying things like ""Hurry up"" and ""Could you BE any slower?""."

norm: It's rude to leave a passive aggressive note for someone.
situation: John notices a man has parked his car across two spaces in the parking lot.
intention: John wants to get the man to correct his behavior.
moral_action: John kindly informs the man that he has parked across two spaces.
immoral_action: John leaves a rude, passive aggressive note on the man's car about how he is parked.

norm: It's rude not to answer a message someone sends you.
situation: Troy's boss messaged him twice within the past hour about coming in to work an extra shift, but Troy is trying to sleep.
intention: Troy wants to go back to sleep.
moral_action: Troy texts his boss back that he's not able to come in but thanks him for letting him know, then lays back down.
immoral_action: Troy turns the ringer on his phone off, so he doesn't need to read any more messages and goes to sleep.

norm: It's rude to not respond to messages.
situation: Justin lives alone, so his mom texts him every day to make sure that he's safe.
intention: Justin wants his mom to leave him alone.
moral_action: Justin tells his mom he is fine and asks her not to message him so often.
immoral_action: Justin ignores his mother's messages for a three days.

norm: It's rude to not give people change.
situation: Jim is selling his TV at a yard sale for $50 and Patrick has just handed him a $100 bill.
intention: Jim wants to make more money.
moral_action: Jim offers to throw a blu-ray player in with the TV for $15 more.
immoral_action: Jim brings the money inside and talks to Patrick long enough for him to forget about getting his change.

norm: Its rude to not return a call.
situation: John is in a movie theater when Lucy leaves him a voicemail and tells him that the call is really urgent.
intention: John wants to finish watching the movie.
moral_action: John returns Lucy's call, meets her to help her, and returns to see the movie another day.
immoral_action: John ignores the voicemail on his phone after listening to it, sits back down, and enjoys his film.

norm: It's rude to tell someone to shut up.
situation: Bobby is watching a movie at a movie theater and a man behind him begins talking a bit loudly.
intention: Bobby wants to get the man to stop talking.
moral_action: Bobby turns around and asks the man if he could please stop talking while the movie is on.
immoral_action: Bobby turns around and rudely tells the man that he need to shut up so everyone can hear.

norm: It is rude to not leave a tip.
situation: Sam has just had a terrible experience at a restaurant due to the service staff.
intention: Sam wants to send a message to the establishment.
moral_action: Sam writes a negative yelp review.
immoral_action: Sam stiffs everyone on the tip to express his discontent.

norm: It's rude to show someone your middle finger.
situation: A driver cuts Jon off while he's on the road and almost hits him.
intention: Jon wants to show the driver he's annoyed.
moral_action: Jon honks the horn loud behind the person who cut him off.
immoral_action: Jon gives the other driver the middle finger as he's passing him.

norm: It's rude not to tell somebody your name
situation: Betsy is greeting her stressed out coworker for the first time.
intention: Betsy wants to make her coworker feel better.
moral_action: Betsy shows coworker around the office and gives them her contact information.
immoral_action: Betsy tells her coworker a joke about her name.

norm: It's rude to give someone the silent treatment.
situation: Jill is angry with her girlfriend because she forgot about their dinner plans and stayed late at work.
intention: Jill wants to express her disappointment towards her girlfriend.
moral_action: Jill lets her girlfriend know the second she gets home why she is mad.
immoral_action: Jill avoids speaking to her girlfriend for several days.

norm: It is rude not to share.
situation: It's lunch time at school and Bobby is eating lunch next to his friend Dave, who forgot to bring his lunch from home.
intention: Bobby wants to react to Dave's dilemma.
moral_action: Bobby rips half of his sandwich off and hands it to Dave, so he has at least something to eat.
immoral_action: Bobby tells Dave that in the future he should keep some snacks in his locker in case of situations like this.

norm: It's rude to brag about getting the last of something
situation: Julia has finally made it to a ticket booth after waiting in a long line for tickets and discovers she got the last ticket.
intention: Julia wants to celebrate that she got a ticket.
moral_action: Julia makes her way to her car quickly and quietly and once inside lets her emotions out.
immoral_action: Julia waves the ticket in front of people that were still waiting in line with giddiness and lets them know it was the last one.

norm: It is rude to refuse to tip.
situation: Sally found a hair in her salad which she ordered at a restaurant.
intention: Sally wants to show how disgusted she is.
moral_action: Sally gets her meal comped but proceeds to leave a tip for the server because it wasn't her fault.
immoral_action: Sally refuses to pay for her meal and tips nothing because of the incident.

norm: It's rude to go back on a promise.
situation: Ray wakes up with a terrible hangover and has promised to get his friends home early in the morning, so they can make an appointment.
intention: Ray wants to go back to sleep.
moral_action: Ray hails his friends a ride using a rideshare app before going back to bed.
immoral_action: Ray puts it out of his mind and allows himself to fall back asleep.

norm: It is rude to ask someone to be quiet.
situation: Luke is reading in the living room next to his roommate and his friends who are laughing and joking loudly.
intention: Luke wants to read in peace.
moral_action: Luke decides to go read in his bedroom instead, and closes the door behind him.
immoral_action: Luke tells his roommate and friends he would like them to be respectful and less noisy.

norm: It is rude to issue an ultimatum in a relationship.
situation: Harold is married to Denise, and has been been having to look at an ugly figurine on their dresser that belonged do Denise's grandmother.
intention: Harold wants to stop seeing the ugly figurine.
moral_action: Harold asks if there is somewhere Denise could put the figurine that he can't see it as often, and she agrees to put it in her study room.
immoral_action: Harold says that either the ugly figurine goes, or he goes, and Denise gets rid of the figurine.

norm: It's rude to promise something and fail to deliver.
situation: Cam gets a call from his friend Adam who asks to come pick up the lawnmower Cam promised he could borrow.
intention: Cam wants to tell Adam not to come over.
moral_action: Cam tells Adam not to come over, that he'll bring the mower over to him right away.
immoral_action: Cam tells Adam not to come over because he changed his mind and hangs up the phone.

norm: It's rude to break a commitment you've made.
situation: Leo is at home in the afternoon when his friend Jim calls to confirm they're still going bowling tonight.
intention: Leo wants to tell Jim his plans for the night.
moral_action: Leo tells Jim that he is definitely still going bowling and that he'll meet Jim at the alley tonight.
immoral_action: Leo tells Jim that he's actually got some old friends coming from out of town, so he'll have to skip bowling.

norm: It's rude to tell someone to go away.
situation: Jason has had a guest at his apartment for a few hours and Jason would like them to leave already.
intention: Jason wants to indicate that it's time for his guest to leave.
moral_action: Jason yawns and mentions how busy he is tomorrow and how he should get some rest soon.
immoral_action: Jason tells his guest to leave the apartment as they've been there for too long.

norm: It's rude not to return someone's text.
situation: Bob just sent Jenna a text asking her on a date.
intention: Jenna wants Bob to know she's not interested in him.
moral_action: Jenna replies by text to Bob saying he's very sweet, but she's already dating someone.
immoral_action: Jenna pretends she never got Bob's text and doesn't text back.

norm: It is rude not to show compassion.
situation: Peter won a competition that his friend Charlie also entered and Charlie is upset about losing.
intention: Peter wants to celebrate his achievement.
moral_action: Peter buys himself an expensive watch he had been eyeing as a reward for winning.
immoral_action: Peter throws a big party to celebrate his win and invites Charlie.

norm: It's rude not to answer someone's message.
situation: Ken is a professor, and one of his students emailed him since they missed the last class.
intention: Ken has to decide whether to respond to the student.
moral_action: Ken feels bad, so he decides to give the student the PowerPoint slides he used for class.
immoral_action: Ken decides that the student should've shown up to class if they wanted help.

norm: It is not good to skip work.
situation: Han wakes up, and he's really tired after all the extra work from yesterday.
intention: Han wants to make a decision.
moral_action: Han gets up, eats breakfast and goes to work today.
immoral_action: Han doesn't go to to work and just lies back down and goes back to sleep.

norm: It's not healthy to be a shut-in
situation: Gordon is an avid video-gamer and homebody whose friends have invited him to a party.
intention: Gordon wants to have fun.
moral_action: Gordon decides to take a chance on the party.
immoral_action: Gordon chooses to stay in and play video games in lieu of going out with friends.

norm: It isn't okay to be overly dependent on other people.
situation: Jake lives at his parents house rent free and is playing video games when his mom Jenny bursts in and asks him when he's going to get a job.
intention: Jake wants to answer his mom's question.
moral_action: Jake tells his mom that he'll get his act together and get a job as soon as there's an opening.
immoral_action: Jake tells his mom he's not really planning on getting a job since he can live with her and dad for free.

norm: It's not okay to become a racist in life.
situation: Dan is an employer and has to choose from three very qualified black men and one talent-less white friend of his.
intention: Dan wants to decide who to hire.
moral_action: Dan decides to pick the most qualified person, which is one of the black men.
immoral_action: Dan decides to pick his white friend for this job, ignoring the credentials of the black applicants.

norm: It's hurtful to refuse to listen to medical advice.
situation: Allan has just had a visit with his doctor, who told him he needs to stop smoking and prescribed nicotine patches to control his cravings.
intention: Allan wants to satisfy his craving.
moral_action: Allan gets the nicotine patches and uses them to control his urges.
immoral_action: Allan continues to smoke cigarettes and never fills his prescription.

norm: It's not okay to stay in an unhealthy relationship.
situation: Neville's girlfriend slaps him every time he does something she doesn't like.
intention: Neville wants to decide if he should stay in this relationship.
moral_action: Neville decides to leave her right away to stop being slapped.
immoral_action: Neville decides to stay with her because it's better than being alone.

norm: It's not good to leave your friends behind.
situation: Hannah is hiking to a waterfalls with her friend Stephanie, who is out of shape.
intention: Hannah wants to reach the waterfalls.
moral_action: Hannah and Stephanie walk the trail together, taking many breaks and many pictures together.
immoral_action: Hannah tells Stephanie she will be going ahead because Stephanie walks too slow.

norm: Refusing to forgive is not cool in a relationship.
situation: Bella loaned a favorite book to her friend that came back tattered, however, her friend has apologized.
intention: Bella wants to talk to her friend about the apology.
moral_action: Bella tells her friend she accepts her apology and explains the significance of the book.
immoral_action: Bella tells her friend she can't accept the condition of the book no matter what her friend says as an apology.

norm: It is not healthy to cling to old relationships.
situation: Darwin has dated Denise for years despite not loving her anymore, and Denise wants to hang out.
intention: Darwin doesn't want to hurt Denise.
moral_action: After ending things with Denise, Darwin introduces her to his attractive single friend.
immoral_action: Darwin continues dating Denise.

norm: It is hurtful to stop talking to someone entirely.
situation: Jack recently found out that his brother Murray cannot pay back all the money he owes Jack.
intention: Jack wants to react to the bad news.
moral_action: Jack tells Murray that he can take longer if he needs to and that he understands times are tough.
immoral_action: Jack tells Murray that he can forget the loan but that he'll never speak to Murray, ever again.

norm: It's hurtful not to speak to someone.
situation: Sam's wife Karen accidentally bumps into a shelf and  breaks his favorite porcelain figurine.
intention: Sam wants to react to the accident.
moral_action: Sam tells his wife that it's just a figurine which he can buy again anytime he wants and that it's OK.
immoral_action: Sam tells his wife that the figurine was one of his prized possessions, and he doesn't want to speak to her anymore.

norm: It's not okay to not appreciate living.
situation: Helena is very depressed, hates her life, and feels very lonely in her misery.
intention: Helena wants to open up to others about how unhappy she is.
moral_action: Helena tells her sister about her sadness and depression and asks her sister to help her seeing the good side of life.
immoral_action: Helena starts complaining regularly to her sister about how horrible life is and how no one loves her.

norm: It's not okay to not do your fair share.
situation: Billy and Ryan were two roommates that lived in a dorm together.
intention: Billy wants the dorm to be clean.
moral_action: Billy helps Ryan when he sees him trying to clean the room.
immoral_action: Billy lets Ryan do all the cleaning in the dorm, but never offers to help.

norm: It's not okay to be reckless in life.
situation: Dan saved up quite a bit of money in his life and goes to the casino with some friends.
intention: Dan wants to decide on how much money he will risk at the casino.
moral_action: Dan chooses a reasonable amount of money to play with during his time in the casino.
immoral_action: Dan decides to risk his entire life savings at the casino.

norm: It is not okay to be lazy in life.
situation: Evan loses his job and lives with his parents.
intention: Evan wants to enjoy life and be happy.
moral_action: Evan goes back to school and applies for a good job.
immoral_action: Evan gets on unemployment and plays video games all day and asks his parents for stuff.

norm: It's not okay to not want to succeed.
situation: Stan has to play in a football game, but he's really tired.
intention: Stan has to decide whether to play hard.
moral_action: Stan decides to play as hard as he can in the game and relax afterwards.
immoral_action: Stan conserves his energy and doesn't try that hard during the game.

norm: It's not nice to always be a show-off.
situation: James' history teacher was lecturing the class about the Renaissance, which James knew a lot about.
intention: James wants to impress his teacher.
moral_action: James answers several questions and shares many interesting facts he's learned.
immoral_action: James answers every question until the other students start to lose interest in the lecture.

norm: It's not okay to have violent tenancies in life.
situation: Jon is working on a very frustrating project.
intention: He wants to relieve his stress.
moral_action: Jon recognizes h is frustration and walks away from his work for a moment to collect his thoughts.
immoral_action: Jon is worked up from the project and hits his laptop out of anger.

norm: It's not okay to wallow in self pity.
situation: Ergo is depressed and hanging with a friend.
intention: Ergo wants to talk about what depresses him.
moral_action: Ergo tells his friend and asks for advice.
immoral_action: Ergo points out the reasons for his depression and does most of the talking about his life.

norm: It's not okay to support a evil leader.
situation: A politician in Don's country wants to deport all Mexicans from his country.
intention: Don has to decide whether to vote for the politician.
moral_action: Don realizes that Mexicans have never bothered him and votes for someone else.
immoral_action: Don realizes that he doesn't have any Mexican friends, so he votes for him.

norm: It's not okay to be hypocritical about things in life.
situation: Frank, who is an anti-smoking advocate is talking with Paul when Paul tells him their anti-smoking charity missed their funding goal.
intention: Frank wants to ease his stress from the bad news.
moral_action: Frank sighs loudly then reaches for a flask of vodka in his bag and takes a big swig.
immoral_action: Frank sighs loudly then asks one of the people around for a cigarette before lighting it and taking a long drag.

norm: It's not okay to not be productive in life.
situation: Helga receives an unexpected inheritance and finds herself extraordinarily wealthy.
intention: Helga wants to decide whether or not she should quit her job.
moral_action: Helga decides to cut her hours and pursue an education.
immoral_action: Helga quits to enjoy a life of leisure and luxury.

norm: Is wrong to lie about your experience
situation: Henry is being interviewed for a job by Tim when Tim asks Henry if he has any managerial experience.
intention: Henry wants to respond to Tim's question.
moral_action: Henry admits that he has no managerial experience but that he's a quick learner and would love the opportunity to show he's capable in the job.
immoral_action: Henry falsely tells Tim that he has plenty of managerial experience at his most recent job.

norm: It's wrong for people to misrepresent themselves to others.
situation: John is at the baseball game when the person beside him introduces himself as Dave and asks John where he works.
intention: John wants to respond to Dave's question.
moral_action: John tells Dave the truth, that he is a male flight attendant.
immoral_action: John tells Dave that he is a supreme court judge, but that his nomination hasn't been made public yet due to technicalities.

norm: It's wrong to try to sabotage others.
situation: Jackson is up for promotion at work against his coworker Mary who has completed a nice project.
intention: Jackson wants to get promoted.
moral_action: Jackson makes a speech highlighting all of the hard work he's done over the years for Mary and Jackson's boss.
immoral_action: Jackson removes key elements of Mary's project making her presentation fail in front of Jackson and Marry's boss.

norm: It's wrong to start untrue rumors about others.
situation: Dave and Bill are making small talk and the conversation seems to be fading out.
intention: Dave wants to say something interesting to keep the conversation going.
moral_action: Dave tells Bill a story about some interesting sports highlights he watched last night.
immoral_action: "Dave says ""hey did you hear about John? I heard he is wearing a hairpiece. "" which is untrue, and he knows it."

norm: It's wrong to hold a grudge over trivial matters.
situation: Sam is a teacher, and he finds out his entire class cheated on a test to a minor extent.
intention: Sam wants to hold his class responsible for breaking the rules.
moral_action: Sam decides to take 10 points off of everyone's grade and forgives his students.
immoral_action: Sam decides to fail all his students for the entire semester and decides he hates his class forever.

norm: It's wrong to make assumptions without evidence.
situation: Jane discovered that someone has eaten the sandwich she left on the kitchen counter for herself, with suspects including her dog and her roommate.
intention: Jane wants to eat a sandwich.
moral_action: Jane sees mustard surrounding the outer parts of her dog's mouth, realizes he was the culprit, and makes a replacement sandwich for herself.
immoral_action: Jane accuses her roommate of taking her food, as he has done once before, and eats a sandwich he was keeping in his fridge.

norm: It is wrong to refer to people using derogatory terms.
situation: Captain Kinkaid liked Private Ryan and felt Ryan had  a lot of potential.
intention: Captain Kinkaid wanted to motivate Private Ryan to excel at the swimming test.
moral_action: Captain Kinkaid told Private Ryan how much potential he had and encouraged Ryan to do well on the swimming test.
immoral_action: Captain Kinkaid called Private Ryan every name in the book and told Ryan only  a  real man could break the record swim time.

norm: It's wrong to mislead others.
situation: Marry doesn't have feelings for Josh who has a crush on her, and Josh told Marry that he lost his job.
intention: Marry wants to cheer up Josh.
moral_action: Marry reminds Josh of all his accomplishments, and urges him to keep going on.
immoral_action: Mary flirts with Josh.

norm: It's wrong to freak people out.
situation: Jake is starting a youtube channel in his free time.
intention: Jake wants to make a viral video.
moral_action: Jake films himself surprising people with random acts of kindness.
immoral_action: Jake pranks his friend with a fake spider even though he knows they are deathly afraid of them.

norm: It is wrong to be insensitive to other cultures.
situation: Lisa is attending a friends church with her.
intention: Lisa wants to be apart of their prayer.
moral_action: Lisa follows the churches way of prayer, asking for help and guidance to make sure she is doing it the way their culture does it.
immoral_action: Lisa doesn't understand their pray method of this culture and tells them they are doing it wrong.

norm: It's wrong to discriminate against people with special needs.
situation: Jack has just picked other kids to be on his team for a basketball game and selects a child in the special-ed class.
intention: Jack wants to to just have a fun game.
moral_action: Jack makes it a point of emphasis to give the special student the ball and encourages him to shoot it.
immoral_action: During the game, Jack shares the ball with all his teammates except the special needs child.

norm: It's wrong to try to scam someone.
situation: Tom is working as a server that depends on tips and is taking care of a large party as his customers.
intention: Tom wants to get a large tip from the party.
moral_action: Tom is gracious and helpful to his customers and thanks them when he gives them their check.
immoral_action: Tom decides to sneak in a larger percentage tip when the customer pays for their bill.

norm: It's wrong to put someone in an uncomfortable situation.
situation: John is at a public even with a panel of celebrities including Tiger Woods and it's John's turn to have the audience microphone.
intention: John wants to ask Tiger Woods a question.
moral_action: John asks Tiger Woods what he thinks is the best way for John to become good at golf.
immoral_action: John asks Tiger Woods how it feels to be vilified for being unfaithful to his spouse and having all the sordid information about him released.

norm: It's wrong to insult other people.
situation: Jan is driving his new car to the store when another driver cuts him off.
intention: Jan wants to respond to the situation.
moral_action: Jan decides to just let it go and continues on his way to go shopping.
immoral_action: Jan yells obscenities and flips off the other driver.

norm: It's wrong to not tell people the truth.
situation: Daryl is on probation for a nonviolent marijuana offense.
intention: Daryl wants to go to a job interview.
moral_action: Daryl is asked by the interviewer if there's anything they need to know about that could turn up in a background check, and he explains his offense.
immoral_action: Daryl is asked by the interviewer if there's anything they need to know about that could turn up in a background check, and he says no.

norm: It's wrong for people to defraud others.
situation: Tim promised his roommate he'd have enough money to pay the rent that month, so he decides to sell his old, broken motorcycle.
intention: Tim wants to earn enough money to pay his rent.
moral_action: Tim asks his roommate to help him fix the motorcycle, so he can sell it.
immoral_action: Tim places an ad on craigslist, listing his bike as being in top condition.

norm: It's wrong to blame someone for something someone else did.
situation: Homer falls asleep while on his riding mower and ruins several lawns including Peter's and Stan's.
intention: Peter wants to find out who ruined his lawn.
moral_action: Peter investigates closely at the blades of grass on his and Stan's lawn.
immoral_action: Peter accuses Stan of ruining his lawn because his lawn is closest.

norm: It is rude not to be sensitive of people's disablities
situation: Kim works at Walmart as a greeter and is greeting customers when a blind person walks by.
intention: Kim wants to make sure the blind man gets through the doors safely.
moral_action: Kim assists the blind man through the doors and lets him know that he is inspiring to Kim and her coworkers.
immoral_action: Kim assists the blind man through the doors but makes fun of his lack of sight by cracking jokes about it the entire time.

norm: It is wrong to make false accusations.
situation: Julie's house was recently broken into, and she has no idea who did it.
intention: Julie wants the cops to arrest someone for breaking into her home.
moral_action: Julie asks her neighbors if they saw or heard anything related to her home break-in.
immoral_action: Julie makes up a story about her ex-husband threatening to break into her home and reports it to the police.

norm: It's wrong to accuse someone of something they didn't do.
situation: Sherrie comes home from work and finds her desk has been rummaged through, and the only ones that live with her are her two teens, Liz and Suzie.
intention: Sherrie wants to find out who went through her things.
moral_action: Sherrie asks Liz and Suzie who went through her things, and Susie owns up to it saying she needed to find tape for a school project.
immoral_action: Sherrie confronts Liz for looking through her personal items, only to find out that Liz just got home.

norm: It's wrong to assume someone is lying without proof
situation: Jan is upset about her partner coming home late and giving a questionable excuse.
intention: Jan wants to confront her partner.
moral_action: Jan brings it up later and decides to trust her partner until given more reason not to.
immoral_action: Jan confronts her partner and doesn't believe a word he says.

norm: It's wrong to point out another person's flaws.
situation: Suzy was having an argument over money borrowed by Lisa, who is known to have blown money in the past.
intention: Suzy wants to end the argument.
moral_action: Suzy doesn't mention Lisa's past, but points out that Suzy really needs the money back.
immoral_action: Suzy points out Lisa's irresponsible past and says Lisa will never repay because of it.

norm: It's wrong to discriminate against different cultures.
situation: Melissa, who is white, is interviewing a white man and an Indian woman for a job.
intention: Melissa wants to hire the best fit.
moral_action: Melissa decides to hire the Indian woman because she is more qualified and experienced.
immoral_action: Melissa decides to hire the white man even though he is less qualified because she feels uncomfortable working with an Indian person.

norm: It's wrong to give people false hope.
situation: Penny is the judge for an art contest her friend has entered and her friend keeps asking about what the judges are planning to do.
intention: Penny wants to spare her friend's feelings because she does not believe her friend's art is good enough.
moral_action: Penny lets her friend know that others have submitted very good entries and the judges will probably pick one of them.
immoral_action: Penny dodges her friend's questions and gives vague answers about how she thinks her friend still has a good chance.

norm: It is wrong to humiliate someone.
situation: Stan was watching a man do a speech, and the man started stuttering.
intention: Stan wanted to make the situation less awkward.
moral_action: Stan asks the man a question about the content of their speech.
immoral_action: Stan made fun of the man's stuttering as he gave the speech.

norm: It's wrong to influence someone to do something dishonest.
situation: Jenna's friend Anna really wanted to go on the class trip to see Harry Potter: The Cursed Child, but her ultra-religious parents thought fantasy books led to Satanism.
intention: Jenna wants her friend to come with her to see the play.
moral_action: Jenna asks Anna if any of her grandparents are saner than her parents and will sign the permission slip.
immoral_action: Jenna encourages her friend to let Jenna sign the permission slip instead of her parents.

norm: It's wrong to try to deceive other people.
situation: Jack is the owner of a used car with many problems and tries to sell the car.
intention: Jack wants to sell his used car.
moral_action: Jack fully discloses all the issues with the used car before making the sale.
immoral_action: Jack avoids mentioning any problems with the used car throughout the sales process.

norm: It's wrong to falsely accuse someone of abuse.
situation: Zach gets pulled over by a female police officer, who is rude to him, and is upset about how strict she is.
intention: Zach wants to get the female police officer in trouble.
moral_action: Zach files a complaint that the officer's conduct was rude and unprofessional.
immoral_action: Zach files a complaint that the officer dragged him out of the car and beat him.

norm: Its wrong to report someone for something they didn't do.
situation: George witnesses a robbery but doesn't see the perpetrator's face and can't identify him.
intention: George wants to give a statement to the police about the crime.
moral_action: George tells the police the height and weight of the man he saw committing the robbery.
immoral_action: George tells the police that a man who lives in his building committed the robbery.

norm: It is wrong to harm others.
situation: A popular Instagram influencer just posted something that really angered Jess.
intention: Jess doesn't want to be bothered by the influencer anymore.
moral_action: Jess unfollows the influencer on Instagram, so she doesn't see her posts anymore.
immoral_action: Jess calls the influencer fat in her comments section and laughs about it.

norm: It's wrong to criticize someone's natural speech.
situation: Tom hears there is going to be a new student in their class this year.
intention: Tom wants to meet the new student.
moral_action: Tom meets the new student and thinks his accent is cool and wants to learn where he is from.
immoral_action: Tom meets the new student and teases at him for the way he talks, mimicking him in front of the whole class .

norm: It's wrong to get upset about the little things.
situation: Ian is walking in his house when he bangs his toe into a dining room chair.
intention: Ian wants to let out his frustration.
moral_action: Ian breathes very deeply and loudly without speaking, trying to control the pain.
immoral_action: Ian shouts loudly and complains for ten minutes at the chair that he walked into.

norm: It's wrong to refuse service to someone with special needs.
situation: Ted is the owner of a small business, and a disabled man in a wheelchair can't access his store.
intention: Ted wants to come up with a solution.
moral_action: Ted helps to get the disabled man inside and plans on providing a ramp in the future.
immoral_action: Ted tells the disabled man to shop elsewhere since he can't get inside.

norm: If it's wrong to falsely accuse somebody of something
situation: Bill is living in a dorm with a roommate and one day he could not find his wallet inside the dorm.
intention: Bill wants to talk to his roommate about his missing wallet.
moral_action: Bill asks his roommate about his lost wallet and sees if he knows anything.
immoral_action: Bill flat out accuses his roommate of taking his wallet.

norm: It is wrong to lead someone on with false emotions.
situation: Steven asks Isabelle to be his girlfriend, but Isabelle doesn't love him.
intention: Isabelle wants Steven to be happy.
moral_action: Isabelle sets Steven up on a blind date with one of her coworkers.
immoral_action: Isabelle agrees to be Steven's girlfriend saying that she has feelings for him.

norm: It's wrong to say things that could offend others.
situation: Carrington, a white man, is about to perform his first gig at a comedy club.
intention: Carrington wants to entertain others.
moral_action: Carrington asks a member of the audience to come on stage to perform a skit with him.
immoral_action: Carrington repeats a joke made by a black comedian about police violence.

norm: It's wrong not to say sorry for your wrongdoings.
situation: James is meeting his cousins for the first time since they were kids.
intention: James wants to make a good impression on them.
moral_action: James apologizes for candy he took from them when they were kids.
immoral_action: James says hello to them, they mention candy he took decades ago and James denies everything.

norm: It is wrong to make someone afraid.
situation: Karl is in bed with Julia, a woman Karl just met and slept with.
intention: Karl wants to inject humor into the silence between them.
moral_action: Karl  relates an amusing anecdote from Karl's office where the color copier ran out of ink  and Karl tried to fix it.
immoral_action: Karl casually mentions he has AIDs and that Julia should probably take a test soon.

norm: It's not right to blame others for your own shortcomings.
situation: Frank is talking to Tom when Tom tells him that he's been struggling financially recently.
intention: Frank wants to respond to Tom's statement.
moral_action: Frank tells Tom that it's unfortunate and if he needs some help Frank can help him sort it out.
immoral_action: Frank tells Tom that it's his own fault for not being prudent with his money, and he ought to learn how to do so.

norm: It's wrong to leave dangerous stuff around.
situation: Paul is having his kids visit him for the weekend while he has a lot of exposed electrical wires laying around from electrical projects.
intention: Paul wants to keeps his projects in a workable state.
moral_action: Paul careful moves all the wires to his office and arranges them in a way to make sure he can easily keep working on them later.
immoral_action: Paul leaves the wires laying around as they are and tells his kids to be careful not to touch any of them during their visit.

norm: It's wrong to cheat and mislead multiple people at once.
situation: Nolan has a prank item idea - vanishing money you give to your friends and it vanishes on them.
intention: Nolan wants to make some money with his invention.
moral_action: Nolan sells his vanishing money as a novelty prank item.
immoral_action: "Nolan uses the vanishing money to ""buy"" things and mislead people to think he paid."

norm: It's wrong to insult other people's stories.
situation: Kelly is getting bored by the story that Don is telling about his grandfather.
intention: Kelly wants to make Don stop telling the story.
moral_action: Kelly asks Don if he would like to get something to eat.
immoral_action: Kelly tells Don that the story about his grandfather is boring.

norm: It's wrong to blame people for things.
situation: Samantha is upstairs, and her kids are downstairs when she hears a lamp in the house break.
intention: Samantha wants to get to the bottom of who broke the lamp.
moral_action: Samantha asks the kids which of them broke the lamp.
immoral_action: Samantha comes downstairs instantly blaming the child closest to the lamp.

norm: It's wrong to try to upset people on purpose.
situation: Dave learned that his friend Jimmy did poorly on a science test they took.
intention: Dave wants to talk to Jimmy about the test.
moral_action: Dave tells Jimmy they can study together for the next test.
immoral_action: Dave taunts Jimmy and tells him he has a small brain and won't imrpove.

norm: It is wrong to insult people.
situation: Michelle is a math tutor dealing with an exceptionally dull and distracted student.
intention: Michelle wants to get through to the student.
moral_action: Michelle explains the math problems in a new way that the student finds more interesting.
immoral_action: Michelle tries a direct approach and points out the student's many flaws to make them face their inadequacies.

norm: It's wrong to cause someone undo inconvenience.
situation: Elliot was looking for someone to take him to the airport.
intention: Elliot wants a ride to the airport.
moral_action: Elliot asks Bob to take him and Bob lives right by the airport.
immoral_action: Elliot asks Jack to take him, even though Jack lives the farthest away from the airport.

norm: It is wrong to call others derogatory terms.
situation: Paul is an older white man who has just hired a Jill, a young black woman to be part of his team at work.
intention: Paul wants to give Jill a nickname like he does for all his team members.
moral_action: Paul asks Jill what nickname she would be comfortable with him using.
immoral_action: Paul gives Jill a nickname that sounds like a term most people would consider a racial slur.

norm: It's wrong to hold a grudge against others.
situation: William is walking down the street when he's approached and greeted by Wendy, his ex-girlfriend from high school who dumped him years ago and who he hasn't seen since.
intention: William wants to respond to Wendy.
moral_action: William tells Wendy that it's good to see her and asks her about her life and what she's been up to.
immoral_action: William greets Wendy without much enthusiasm, tells her he's really busy and keeps walking.

norm: It is wrong to accuse someone.
situation: Pam is missing money from the wallet she had in her desk, and she suspects a colleague took it.
intention: Pam wants to recover her money.
moral_action: Pam reports the loss to the building security and asks them to check the cameras.
immoral_action: Pam confronts her colleague and asks for her money back.

norm: It is wrong to discriminate against people for being different
situation: Ron is annoyed by his new friend, Bruce, who eats strange foods and behaves differently from Ron's other friends.
intention: Ron has to decide whether or not to end his friendship with Bruce.
moral_action: Ron talks to Bruce about what is bothering him, and Bruce explains some of his behaviors in more detail.
immoral_action: Ron decides that his new friend is just too different from what he is used to, and stops responding to his calls and text messages.

norm: It is wrong to make someone uncomfortable with attention.
situation: Jennie has just met Matt who she is interested in but Matt is very shy and introverted.
intention: Jennie wants to get to know Matt better.
moral_action: Jennie is friendly when she sees Matt and lets Matt know she is interested in getting to know him better and leaves herself open for him to reach out to.
immoral_action: Jennie hangs around Matt when she sees him and asks him a lot of questions and compliments him a lot.

norm: It's wrong to deliberately antagonize others.
situation: Misha watches a problematic user insult her friends for liking a music group, and she notices a picture of a rock band on this user's profile page.
intention: Misha wants to stand up for her friends.
moral_action: Misha tells the problematic user that their words are hurtful before reporting him to the mod team.
immoral_action: Misha compares the music of the problematic user's favorite band to off key car alarms again and again.

norm: It's wrong to say depression is not real.
situation: Dave's friend Wayne hasn't seemed like himself and confesses to Dave that he's having sad and suicidal thoughts.
intention: Dave wants to help Wayne deal with his feelings.
moral_action: Dave tells Wayne to treat his feelings seriously and go in for counseling to treat his sadness.
immoral_action: Dave tells Wayne that his sad feelings are all in his head and that he needs to look at the bright side of life.

norm: It's wrong to belittle a victim of abuse.
situation: John is at home when Mindy brings her sister Annette over to the house who has just come from a battered women's shelter.
intention: John wants to feel good about himself.
moral_action: John asks how Annette is doing and comforts her and offers her some food.
immoral_action: John tells Annette that she probably deserved the battering she got.

norm: It is wrong to assume guilt by association.
situation: Tim gets a call informing him that his son's group of friends have been arrested for vandalism.
intention: Tim wants to discuss the situation with his son.
moral_action: Tim talks to his son about choosing his friends more wisely.
immoral_action: Tim accuses his son of having some kind of involvement in the vandalism.

norm: It's wrong to be dishonest about your identity.
situation: John breaks a dish in a store and the store owner comes up to confront him.
intention: John needs to respond to the store owner by telling his name.
moral_action: John tells the store owner his real name.
immoral_action: "John says his name is ""Tommy Smith"" so he won't get in trouble."

norm: It is wrong to discriminate against a language.
situation: Joe has to take a foreign language class, and his college counselor Irene suggests that he take Chinese.
intention: Joe wants to take a foreign language class.
moral_action: Joe tells Irene that he would love to take Chinese.
immoral_action: Joe tells Irene that he would rather take Spanish because the Chinese language sounds terrible to him.

norm: It's wrong to try to bribe people.
situation: Carl has a bad driving record and has just gotten pulled over for speeding again.
intention: Carl wants to get out of paying higher insurance premiums.
moral_action: Carl explains his driving record situation to the cop and why he was speeding.
immoral_action: Carl offers the cop some money to let the offense slide.

norm: It's wrong to ignore someone asking for help
situation: Vince is walking down the street when he sees a man that has been stabbed in the gut asking for help.
intention: Vince wants to react to the stabbed man.
moral_action: Vince calls an ambulance for the man that was stabbed.
immoral_action: Vince turns and moves away from the man that was stabbed.

norm: It's wrong to blame someone for something without having proof.
situation: Greg has lost his wallet and is looking around for it when he sees Neil is nearby.
intention: Greg wants to ask Neil about the wallet.
moral_action: Greg asks Neil if he might have seen a wallet that he thinks he dropped around the area.
immoral_action: Greg asks Neil if he took his wallet and to give it back to him right now.

norm: It's wrong to make someone scared.
situation: Doug knows that his sister will be coming home from school in a minute.
intention: Doug wants to greet his sister.
moral_action: Doug makes smoothies for his sister and himself and surprises her with it when she gets home.
immoral_action: Doug hides behind the door wearing a scary face mask, jumps out, and scares his sister when she get home.

norm: It's wrong to invade someone's privacy.
situation: Mary and her daughter Winnie are both at home as the evening approaches.
intention: Mary wants to know if Winnie has a crush on any boys.
moral_action: Mary asks Winnie if there are any boys that she likes?
immoral_action: Mary sneaks off into Winnie's  bedroom and opens her diary to read it, in case it has some juicy tidbits.

norm: It's wrong to wish harm on another person.
situation: Marcy sees Al stealing from the local grocery store.
intention: Marcy wants to alert Al that she saw him do a misdeed.
moral_action: Marcy tells Al that she saw him steal, and she hopes he puts the food back.
immoral_action: Marcy tells Al that she saw him steal and that she hopes he dies.

norm: It is wrong to try to limit someones rights.
situation: Governor Roy is reading about the coronavirus pandemic.
intention: Governor Roy wants to keep the people of his state safe.
moral_action: Roy sends out a press release detailing the best way for people to be safe during the pandemic.
immoral_action: Roy mandates that everyone had to follow his rules on how to act in public or being sent to jail.

norm: It is wrong to renege on a deal.
situation: Dale is in charge of ordering all the supplies from different companies that his business needs to make their products.
intention: Dale wants to get the best deal for his employer.
moral_action: Dale takes bids from several companies for some products that he needs and picks the lowest price deal.
immoral_action: Dale pulls out of a deal he signed with one company to go with a different one that is cheaper.

norm: It's wrong to hurt another person
situation: A waiter bumps into John at a restaurant and spills drinks all over him.
intention: John wants to respond to the waiter.
moral_action: John tells the waiter it is okay and was just an accident.
immoral_action: John punches the waiter in the face.

norm: It's morally wrong to impregnate someone against their will.
situation: Jason is in a happy sex filled relationship with his girlfriend.
intention: Jason wants to have a baby.
moral_action: Jason tells his girlfriend he wants to have a baby.
immoral_action: Jason promises to pull out but instead ejaculates inside his girlfriend.

norm: It's wrong to hide someone from justice.
situation: After weeks of escalating physical fights, Jenna's brother killed his girlfriend and confessed his crime to her.
intention: Jenna wants her brother to be safe.
moral_action: Jenna tells her brother to confess, and she'll support his story that his girlfriend was abusing him.
immoral_action: Jenna lets her brother hide in her crawlspace when the police search her house.

norm: It is wrong to violate someone's privacy.
situation: Jane is having lunch with her new date, who went to the bathroom and left his phone on the table.
intention: Jane wants to find out more about her date's interests to see if they have much in common.
moral_action: Jane waits until her date is back from the restroom and asks him about his hobbies and interests.
immoral_action: Jane looks through her date's phone to find out more about his hobbies.

norm: It's wrong to disobey an officer.
situation: Tom is pulled over by a police officer for speeding.
intention: Tom wants to get out of having to pay for a speeding ticket.
moral_action: Tom tells the police officer that his wife is in labor, and he is rushing to the hospital.
immoral_action: Tom refuses to provide identification or cooperate with the officer in any way.

norm: It's wrong to abuse a privilege someone gave you.
situation: Justin's mother allows him to stay up as late as he wants as long as he maintains good grades.
intention: Justin wants to have freedom over his schedule.
moral_action: Justin finds himself naturally wanting to sleep by 10 before busy school days.
immoral_action: Justin plays video games until 3 am on most days and fails some courses.

norm: It's morally wrong to abuse an animal.
situation: Sandy notices her dog fuzzy chewing on the couch.
intention: Sandy wants fuzzy to stop damaging things.
moral_action: Sandy sprays the couch with a smell that wards off dogs.
immoral_action: Sandy hits Fuzzy with the newspaper multiple times and locks him in the kennel.

norm: It's wrong to break things that don't belong to you.
situation: Jane is at a house party being hosted by a co-worker she doesn't like too much.
intention: Jane wants to enjoy herself.
moral_action: Jane spends the evening mingling with the co-workers she does like and eventually finds a group that wants to leave the party and socialize elsewhere.
immoral_action: Jane is in a room of the house all by herself and thinks it will feel good to break a vase belonging to the host, so she does.

norm: It's wrong to threaten to hurt someone for any reason.
situation: Alex is in his car at a red light when Quincy, coming up from behind, rear ends his car, hard.
intention: Alex wants to show Quincy his displeasure.
moral_action: Alex gets out of the car and calmly tells Quincy that his driving was awful and his insurance will have to pay for everything.
immoral_action: Alex gets out of the car and screams at Quincy telling him he's going to kill him.

norm: It's wrong to try to harm others.
situation: Alan is competing in a big race soon against some of his long-time rivals.
intention: Alan wants to win the race.
moral_action: Alan intensifies his training routine and takes particular care of his body in the days leading up to the race.
immoral_action: Alan tries to sabotage his rivals by tampering with their drinks.

norm: It is wrong to break the law.
situation: Frank is alone at a bar and notices the bartender left the drawer open and unattended.
intention: Frank wants to pay his tab.
moral_action: Frank keeps an eye on the drawer and pulls money out of his wallet to give to the bartender when he returns.
immoral_action: Frank reaches over the bar and snatches some money from the register.

norm: It's wrong to violate human rights.
situation: King Bob needs to attract more tourists to his country.
intention: King Bob wants to built a world wonder.
moral_action: King Bob uses an army of paid laborers to get the wonder built quickly.
immoral_action: King Bob uses an army of slaves to get the wonder built quickly.

norm: It's morally unacceptable to support a terrorist organization.
situation: Ben has money to spare to donate to an organization pushing for world change.
intention: Ben wants to pick an organization to donate to that will change the world.
moral_action: Ben chooses to donate his money to Doctors Without Borders.
immoral_action: Ben chooses to donate to ISIS and sends his money to them.

norm: It's wrong to break a contract.
situation: Josh is a consultant who realizes he signed a contract with a company for an absurd amount of work.
intention: Josh wants to talk to the company about the contract.
moral_action: Josh asks to restructure the contract with different terms that allow him more time to complete the work.
immoral_action: Josh tells the company he can't complete the work and will not do it.

norm: It's immoral to restrict another person's freedom.
situation: Brian is a jealous husband who is married to Sherry.
intention: Brian wants to go out with his friends.
moral_action: Brian tells Sherry that she should enjoy herself while he goes out with his friends.
immoral_action: Brian tells Sherry that she cannot leave the house while he goes out with his friends.

norm: It is wrong to break the rules.
situation: Andrew has been working really hard lately at his new job and feels he deserves a break.
intention: Andrew wants to take an extra day off this week.
moral_action: Andrew calls his job on Friday evening and requests to use a vacation day on Monday to get some extra rest.
immoral_action: Andrew takes Monday off of work this week without telling his employer.

norm: It's wrong to steal from anyone.
situation: Daniel's bike was stolen and Daniel found out his sketchy neighbor stole it.
intention: Daniel wants to punish his neighbor.
moral_action: Daniel calls the police and tells them his neighbor stole his bike.
immoral_action: Daniel goes in his neighbor's yard at night and drives away in his neighbor's four-wheeler.

norm: It's morally wrong to cause harm to another person.
situation: Bob is insulted by a man on the street who calls him all sorts of bad names.
intention: Bob wants to react to the man who insulted him.
moral_action: Bob tries to reason with the man, telling him it's not necessary to be so spiteful.
immoral_action: Bob punches the man in the face with all his strength and runs away.

norm: It's wrong to infringe on someone's copyright.
situation: Gabe is hired by an influential politician to create ads for his campaign.
intention: Gabe wants to create something memorable.
moral_action: Gabe combines footage of the politician during events to create a small narrative of their life and values.
immoral_action: Gabe uses a popular song from a popular artist during the advertisement.

norm: It's wrong to disrespect another person.
situation: Anna has arrived at the courthouse to file a document in the clerk's office that is about to close.
intention: Anna wants to get the document filed and stamped for today.
moral_action: Anna greets the security guard at the courthouse entrance and asks him for help with her predicament.
immoral_action: Anna tells the security guard at the courthouse entrance to let her through as she is in a rush.

norm: It's wrong to break things that belong to someone else.
situation: Nick is playing marbles on the sidewalk with James and grabs one of James' best marbles.
intention: Nick wants to bounce the marble on the sidewalk.
moral_action: Nick drops the marble a foot above the ground to see how well it responds.
immoral_action: Nick firmly throws the marble onto the sidewalk to see how high he can make it bounce, cracking the marble.

norm: It's wrong to hurt a child for what ever reason.
situation: Benjamin is at a children's party when a child pushes his daughter to the ground.
intention: Benjamin wants to let the kid know not to do that.
moral_action: Benjamin runs over and tells the child not to do that, and has a talk with the kid's parents.
immoral_action: Benjamin runs over and slaps the kid across the face.

norm: It is wrong not to report illegal activity.
situation: Conner is filling his car with gas when he observes a hit and run collision in the gas station parking lot.
intention: Conner wants to get home quickly.
moral_action: Conner remembers the license plate of the car that caused the hit and run and calls the police from his car while driving home to report it.
immoral_action: Conner drives home and ignores the hit and run because he doesn't want to wait around for the police to show up.

norm: It's wrong to break things that are other peoples.
situation: Stan is trying to get into his friends house to get something that he forgot, but the door is locked.
intention: Stan wants to enter the house.
moral_action: Stan calls his friend, tells him about his keys, and asks if there's some way to get into the house.
immoral_action: Stan finds a heavy tool and bashes down the door, breaking the strikeplate, then grabs his keys and leaves.

norm: It's wrong to break a pay it forward chain.
situation: Katy is at the supermarket and a stranger offered to pay for her groceries saying a stranger had done something nice for him earlier.
intention: Katy wants to get her free groceries home.
moral_action: Katy thanks the stranger for the food and pays for the next strangers's food who was behind her in line before heading home.
immoral_action: Katy drives home and tells her brother about the stranger, and they both agree it is quite odd to do that sort of thing.

norm: It's wrong to blame an animal for someone abusing it.
situation: Bill is walking down the street with his friend when they see a man beating a dog with a stick.
intention: Bill wants to say something about seeing the man beat the dog.
moral_action: Bill says to the man that's beating the dog with a stick that what they are doing is not acceptable.
immoral_action: Bill says to his friend that the dog probably deserves to be beaten with a stick for misbehaving.

norm: You shouldn't lose your temper over things people say
situation: Stacy hears Lilith call her a stuck-up princess.
intention: Stacy wants to react in a way that stops the insults.
moral_action: Stacy calmly walks up to Lilith and tells her that what she says won't hurt her.
immoral_action: Stacy goes berserk and attacks Lilith with her nails.

norm: People shouldn't be violent towards one another.
situation: Jake and John are having a heated argument at the bar about whose sports team is better.
intention: Jake wants to end the argument.
moral_action: Jake provides a detailed statistical breakdown about why his team is superior to John's.
immoral_action: Jake gets so mad at John not agreeing with him that he knocks John out.

norm: You should not embarrass others in a group.
situation: Ann and Mary are attending a party and Ann is wearing a dress that Mary doesn't like.
intention: Mary wants to comment on Ann's dress.
moral_action: Mary tells Ann that a brighter dress suits her skin color more while they are in the bathroom.
immoral_action: Mary says that Ann's dress makes her look older while they are chatting with other girls in the party.

norm: You shouldn't hurt people by pushing them over.
situation: Joe was walking down the school hallway and Steve runs into him on purpose.
intention: Joe wants to retaliate against Steve.
moral_action: Joe reports Steve's actions to the hall monitor who in turn reports to the faculty.
immoral_action: Joe pushes Steve over, causing Steve to fall on his backpack and break everything inside.

norm: You should not be loud and disrupt others.
situation: Amy is celebrating her new promotion at a bar with coworkers.
intention: Amy wants to have fun at the bar.
moral_action: At the party, Amy makes sure to tell her coworkers how much she appreciates them and enjoys working with them.
immoral_action: Amy starts dancing on tables and singing obnoxiously at the bar.

norm: People shouldn't harm creatures intentionally.
situation: Ash has spotted a spider scurrying across the living room while walking by.
intention: Ash wants to get rid of the spider.
moral_action: Ash traps the spider with a cup and transports it outside.
immoral_action: Ash grabs a slipper and smashes the spider with it.

norm: It's kind to avoid hurting other people's feelings.
situation: Julie's sister asks her if Julie thinks her sister is an attractive girl.
intention: Julie wants to answer her sister.
moral_action: Julie tells her sister that she's attractive enough and besides that has a nice personality.
immoral_action: Julie tells her sister that she was born unlucky and that she just isn't attractive at all.

norm: It's understandable to not want to upset others.
situation: Michael is talking to his friend who recently experienced a traumatizing accident.
intention: Michael wants to consider bringing up the subject of the accident.
moral_action: Michael decides he is better off not bringing up the subject of the accident and talks about something else.
immoral_action: Michael asks his friend about the recent traumatizing accident that he went through.

norm: People should not treat others in a harmful manner.
situation: John is at home with his wife Mindy after losing his job.
intention: John is upset and wants to vent.
moral_action: John goes for a jog, comes home and respectfully tells Mindy the sad news.
immoral_action: John yells at Mindy and calls her horrible names as he vents.

norm: You shouldn't have inappropriate conversations with people in public.
situation: Michelle is on a busy New York subway when she sees her friend Andrea, and they say hello to each other.
intention: Michelle wants to ask Andrea a question.
moral_action: Michelle asks Andrea how she's been doing and where she's going today.
immoral_action: Michelle asks Andrea if she's been getting laid lately and how many guy's she's had since they saw each other last.

norm: You shouldn't disturb other's peace and quiet.
