norm: It's bad to treat people poorly for expressing themselves.
situation: Jill decides to join a Buddhist temple and shaves her head as a indication of her faith.
intention: Jill wants to show evidence of Buddhist faith by denying the vanity.
moral_action: Betty inquires on Jill's new faith and hair while listening intently.
immoral_action: Jill's friend Betty mocks her hair and her faith.

norm: It's bad to stalk people.
situation: Jeff has a crush on a girl at school named April.
intention: Jeff wants to learn more about April.
moral_action: Jeff expresses interest in April to a mutual friend.
immoral_action: Jeff stalks April's facebook for hours and accidentally likes an old photo or hers at 3 in the morning.

norm: It is bad to not listen while others speak.
situation: Steve is in math class and is bored.
intention: Steve wants to relieve his boredom.
moral_action: Steve starts taking notes on the lesson and asks questions to keep himself awake.
immoral_action: Steve doodles on his notebook paper while the teacher is talking.

norm: It's bad to play favorites.
situation: Dave is speaking to his employees.
intention: Dave wants to assign work to be done.
moral_action: Dave gives an equal amount of work to everyone.
immoral_action: Dave gives the least amount of work to his nephew.

norm: It's bad to give people the silent treatment.
situation: Liz is trying to read her book on a bus but another passenger keeps trying to talk to her.
intention: Liz wants the passenger to leave her alone.
moral_action: Liz tells the passenger that she's just not in the mood to talk and wants to read her book.
immoral_action: Liz simply doesn't respond to anything the passenger says and stays quiet.

norm: It is bad to talk to strangers.
situation: Ash has gone the wrong way and become quite lost in a new area of town.
intention: Ash wants to get directions to the original destination.
moral_action: Ash uses google maps to look up the correct directions before proceeding.
immoral_action: Ash walks up to a complete stranger to ask them where to go.

norm: It is bad to ambush or corner people
situation: Fred has a crush on his coworker Thelma.
intention: Fred wants to ask Thelma out.
moral_action: Fred asks Thelma to join him for lunch and while they are eating he asks her out on a date.
immoral_action: Fred waits by Thelma's car after work and won't let her leave until she agrees to go out with him.

norm: It's frowned upon to be in a bad mood.
situation: John is having a hard time at work and is in a bad mood because of it.
intention: John wants to stop by his parents house for dinner.
moral_action: John tries to suck it and be a little bit cheerful at dinner.
immoral_action: John stays in a sullen mood at dinner and brings down the whole room.

norm: It is bad to stalk others.
situation: Erika has a crush on a boy in her class named James.
intention: Erika wants to learn more about James.
moral_action: Erika asks James's friends questions about him to learn more about him.
immoral_action: Erika follows James home and tries to listen to everything he does to learn about him.

norm: It's bad to not share with others when you can.
situation: Jen is getting off after a long day at work soon and is far too tired to prepare dinner.
intention: Jen wants to find an easy dinner solution.
moral_action: Jen picks up enough pizza for her and the family.
immoral_action: Jen picks up a smaller pizza and enjoys it entirely on her own.

norm: It is bad to spy on others.
situation: Jack thinks that his girlfriend Kate is having an affair with his best friend Mike.
intention: Jack wants to check what Kate is doing.
moral_action: Jack goes to Kate's room and sees that Kate is studying for her exam.
immoral_action: Jack climbs up to the window of Kate's room and peeks inside.

norm: It's bad to lead someone on.
situation: Syro gas been talking with someone who is attracted to Syro, but Syro is serious in his own mind.
intention: Syro needs to determine how long to let this relationship go on.
moral_action: Syro chooses to open up with his friend next time they talk.
immoral_action: Syro decides that maybe it will change, so he gives it another month.

norm: It's bad to worry to much about other peoples' opinions.
situation: Emily has a very overbearing mother, who is always on her about her weight, even though she is fairly skinny.
intention: Emily wants to stay thin.
moral_action: Emily stands up to her mother, realizes her weight is fine, and learns to like the body she has.
immoral_action: Emily hides her eating, starts purging when she eats, and she eventually becomes bulimic.

norm: It is bad to pressure someone into doing something.
situation: Jane is planning to sending her kids to a birthday party, but they don't wanna go.
intention: Jane wants the kids to be not in the house for a few hours.
moral_action: Jane sends her kids to the movies instead, so they can have fun.
immoral_action: Jane makes her kids go to the party anyway even though they don't want to.

norm: It's bad to frame someone for something.
situation: John has made a costly mistake at work that will have strong repercussions.
intention: John wants to resolve the issue.
moral_action: John owns up to his bosses about the mistake and presents possible solutions.
immoral_action: John knows that a co-worker has a reputation for making mistakes, so he makes it seem as though that co-worker was responsible.

norm: It's hurtful to go behind someone's back.
situation: Terry is married and has an old car that is breaking down.
intention: Terry wants to buy a new vehicle.
moral_action: Terry talks with his wife about what to buy, and they decide on a truck.
immoral_action: Terry buys a truck without consulting with his wife.

norm: It's bad to gossip about others.
situation: Anita is having drinks with her sister - they are discussing one of Anita's friends' behavior.
intention: Anita wants to look like she cares about her friend's issues.
moral_action: Anita talks about her friend's many qualities and tells her sister that she wishes the best for her friend.
immoral_action: Anita tells her sister about Anita's friend's secrets as a possible explanation for the friend's behavior.

norm: It is bad to go behind someone's back
situation: Violet's mother doesn't allow sweets before dinner, but Violet's grandmother is visiting and doesn't know the rule.
intention: Violet wants a cookie.
moral_action: Violet asks her mother if she can have a cookie after dinner.
immoral_action: Violet asks her grandmother, who gives her a cookie just before dinner's ready.

norm: It's bad to make fun of those with special needs.
situation: Larry is hanging out with his friends in a store when a person he knows with Down syndrome walks in.
intention: Larry wants to respond to the person with Down syndrome.
moral_action: Larry waves to the person with Down syndrome and invites him to the group.
immoral_action: Larry makes fun of the person with Down syndrome by imitating how he speaks.

norm: It's bad to push other people's buttons.
situation: Chris, who has a slightly older sister, is in the house one day and is bored.
intention: Chris wants to add some excitement to his life.
moral_action: Chris goes outside and attempts to climb up some fences and walls for fun.
immoral_action: Chris gets a metal pot and begins banging it outside of his sister's door, just to get a reaction out of her.

norm: It's bad to be short-tempered towards people.
situation: Cindy is buying something in store, and the price shown on the register is more than the price on the shelf.
intention: Cindy wants to pay the lower price.
moral_action: Cindy asks the cashier to double-check the price and says she thought maybe it was lower on the shelf.
immoral_action: Cindy says with a raised voice that the cashier should be fired for getting the price wrong.

norm: It is bad eavesdrop on others.
situation: Lilith is at the bar and can hear two friends talking nearby that haven't noticed her arrival yet.
intention: Lilith wants to find out what they are discussing.
moral_action: Lilith announces her presence to her friends to get their attention and inquires as to the topic of discussion.
immoral_action: Lilith listens in on her friend's conversation without announcing herself and overhears them planning a surprise party for Lilith.

norm: It's rude to make light of tragic situations.
situation: Joe's mother just died, and he just told Anne.
intention: Anne wants to help Joe feel better.
moral_action: Anne offers to listen to Joe's feelings without judgment.
immoral_action: Anne cracks a joke about Joe's mother.

norm: It's rude to tell someone they're bad at something.
situation: Jack and Tim are playing golf when Jack misses an easy putt.
intention: Tim wants to respond to Jack's last golf stroke.
moral_action: Tim tells Jack that we all miss sometimes and that he'll get the next one.
immoral_action: Tim tells Jack that he sucks at putting and that his grandma could have made that putt.

norm: It's rude to point out a partner's flaws.
situation: Mary has been dating her boyfriend for a year.
intention: Mary wants her boyfriend to stay with her.
moral_action: Mary asks her boyfriend to start going to the gym with her, so they can both lose weight.
immoral_action: Mary tells her boyfriend he's fat and nobody else will want him.

norm: It is rude to be dismissive of someone else's dreams.
situation: Brenda is a high school athlete.
intention: Brenda wants to get a college scholarship.
moral_action: Brenda and Kay both agree to train together to try to get the scholarship.
immoral_action: Brenda makes up a rumor about a girl she's competing with for the scholarship after the girl said her goal was to get to the olympics.

norm: It is rude to make unwanted romantic advances.
situation: John wants to ask Daisy, his coworker out to dinner.
intention: John wants to pursue a romantic relationship with Daisy.
moral_action: John asks Daisy for her number and tells her he would like to take her out to dinner.
immoral_action: John gets Daisy's number from a friend and keeps texting Daisy even though she has said no.

norm: It is rude to make unwanted advances on others
situation: A pretty woman at the bar tells John she isn't interested in dancing with him.
intention: John wants to respond to the woman.
moral_action: John tells the woman he is sorry to bother her and goes on with his evening.
immoral_action: John grabs the woman by the arm to drag her to the dance floor.

norm: It's hurtful to accuse someone of being lazy.
situation: John is walking down the street when he sees Bill who is using a mobility scooter to get around town.
intention: John wants to comment to Bill about the scooter.
moral_action: John tells Bill that the color of his scooter is snazzy and that he loves the sleek design.
immoral_action: John tells Bill that Bill looks fine to him and that he's probably using the scooter because he's too lazy to walk.

norm: It's rude to have fun at someone else's expense.
situation: Tim is at the playground with his friends when he sees someone trip and fall down.
intention: Tim wants to react to the person tripping and falling.
moral_action: Tim goes over to the person who fell and helps them up.
immoral_action: Tim imitates the person falling in a comedic way getting a laugh from his friends.

norm: It is rude to point out people's personality short comings.
situation: A startup is preparing for a life-changing investment meeting.
intention: Stacey wants to be sure everyone is on top of their game for the meeting.
moral_action: Stacey pulls Jill aside and asks if she can help Jill with her nerves in anyway.
immoral_action: Stacey tells Jill in front of everyone to keep her anxious giggling in check.

norm: It is rude to downplay someone's hopes.
situation: Amy has a friend who has called her up to ask for some advice about her dream of becoming a singer.
intention: Amy wants to point her friend in the right direction.
moral_action: Amy tells her friend hard work and persistence are important but also tells her to have a back up plan.
immoral_action: Amy scoffs at idea, says it will never happen, and tells her friend to be more realistic.

norm: It's rude to treat someone that cares about you rudely.
situation: Johan has had an incredibly bad day at work where everything went wrong.
intention: Johan wants to vent his frustration.
moral_action: Johan calmly explains he has had a bad day then suggests him and his partner do something fun.
immoral_action: Johan snaps at his partner when he gets back home.

norm: It's rude to play practical jokes on people.
situation: Tom is spending a few days with colleagues for a team-building experience.
intention: Tom wants to have fun during the experience.
moral_action: Tom thinks of a really fun game the whole team can play together.
immoral_action: Tom decides to play a prank on a shy coworker.

norm: It is rude to be stingy with tips.
situation: John is having lunch at a restaurant and the service was poor.
intention: John wants to leave a tip after paying.
moral_action: John decides to leave a good tip because he noticed how overworked the waitress was and felt bad for her.
immoral_action: John leaves some change as a tip in order to indicate his dissatisfaction with the service.

norm: It's rude to not apologize when you've done something wrong.
situation: James was running to catch his bus when he ran into someone on the sidewalk.
intention: James wants to catch his bus before it leaves.
moral_action: "James pauses for one second to say, ""Sorry, sorry,"" before running after the bus."
immoral_action: "James keeps running and yells over his shoulder, ""Watch where you're going, moron!""."

norm: It's rude to demean someone for their opinion.
situation: Donny is in the middle of a debate with a friend.
intention: He wants to make his point heard.
moral_action: Danny lays out the reasons for his argument but listens intently to what his friend has to say.
immoral_action: Danny screams at his friend and calls him dumb.

norm: It's rude to turn someone who's suffering away.
situation: James had just enough money to buy a supersized Big Mac meal when he was approached by a hungry homeless person.
intention: James wants to have a satisfying dinner.
moral_action: James gave the homeless man half of his dinner money.
immoral_action: James refused to give the homeless man any money, rationalizing that he'd probably use it to buy drugs.

norm: It's rude to pull a harmful prank on someone.
situation: Nates roommate, Mint, is coming back home tonight, which Nate is looking forward to.
intention: Nate wants to set up a prank.
moral_action: Nate hides and scares Mint when he comes into the seemingly empty room.
immoral_action: Nate outs a bucket of water propped above Mint's door.

norm: It's wrong to call people losers because it is rude.
situation: Jane's soccer team just won a tough match against their rivals and the teams are walking off the field.
intention: Jane wants to interact with her rivals.
moral_action: Jane runs up to the captain of the rival team and congratulates her for a game well played.
immoral_action: Jane yells out to the rival team and calls them a bunch of losers.

norm: It's rude to try and ruin someone else's good time.
situation: Jack is at a party and his friends are playing a game that he does not really enjoy.
intention: Jack wants the party to be fun.
moral_action: Jack participates in the game and sucks it up, suggesting a new game shortly.
immoral_action: Jack disrupts the game and demands everyone play something else.

norm: It's rude to call someone out on their rare mistakes.
situation: James is under a lot of stress because of tight deadlines when a coworker accidentally deletes a day's worth of work.
intention: James wants to vent his frustration.
moral_action: James takes a quick break and calls his wife from outside the building to complain about the coworker.
immoral_action: James yells at his coworker, calling him incompetent and a burden.

norm: It is rude to be ungrateful of someone's kind gesture
situation: Pauline's friend Kathy just gifted her some cookies she made and Pauline takes a bite.
intention: Pauline wants to give her opinion on the cookies.
moral_action: Pauline doesn't like the cookies, but she tells Kathy they taste great and thanks her.
immoral_action: Pauline tells Kathy that they taste terrible and spits out the bite she took.

norm: It's rude to make fun of someone for their heritage
situation: Martin is at a party with his Jewish friend Luke.
intention: Martin wants to entertain his people.
moral_action: Martin tells everyone a funny story about his dog.
immoral_action: Martin points at Luke and makes a joke about Jewish history.

norm: It is rude to make fun of how somebody talks
situation: Rick is at a party with a man with a speech problem Chris.
intention: Rick wants to entertain everyone.
moral_action: Rick tells the crowd a made up story.
immoral_action: Rick makes a joke about Chris unique voice.

norm: It's rude to use someone's sexuality as an insult.
situation: Linda and her homosexual coworker Phil are together in the office when they get an email that there's forced overtime on saturday.
intention: Linda wants to express her displeasure about the overtime to Phil.
moral_action: Linda tells Phil that the overtime is ridiculous, and she can't believe that they're forcing it on them.
immoral_action: "Linda tells Phil ""this stupid overtime is so gay"" and frowns at him."

norm: It is rude to ignore someone's efforts to improve themselves.
situation: Janine is on a diet to lose weight and get healthy.
intention: Grayson wants to encourage her to keep at it.
moral_action: Grayson compliments Janine on her progress.
immoral_action: Grayson points out ways Janine could still improve and calls her out any time she slips up on her diet.

norm: It's rude to be judgmental of the choices of others.
situation: Stacy's friend has gotten a body piercing and asks Stacy what she thinks of it.
intention: Stacy wants to give her friend an opinion on their body piercing.
moral_action: Stacy tells her friend that she doesn't mind their body piercing and only judges them on their character.
immoral_action: Stacy tells her friend that getting a body piercing was a mistake and that is reflects badly on them.

norm: It is rude to downplay someone's good news.
situation: Joseph's sister just got accepted to her dream school and Joseph feels jealous.
intention: Joseph wants to help himself feel better.
moral_action: Joseph congratulates his sister and then vents his frustrations in his journal.
immoral_action: Joseph tells his sister that she was only accepted to the school because she is a girl.

norm: It's rude to express that another culture's gatherings look ridiculous.
situation: Kyle is invited to a Diwali festival parade by his Indian friend Geet.
intention: Kyle wants to say something to Geet about the festival parade.
moral_action: Kyle tells Geet that the festival participants look very exotic and unlike anything he's ever seen.
immoral_action: Kyle tells Geet that the appearance, dress, and dance of the people in the parade seems primative and backwards.

norm: It's rude to speak negatively of something someone likes.
situation: Sal is chatting with some friends about movies when his friend, Jason, mentions that he loved the last Star Wars.
intention: Sal wants to be perceived as a Star Wars expert by his friends.
moral_action: Sal compares different Star War movies in detail, but stays diplomatic about the weaknesses of the last one.
immoral_action: Sal starts panning the last Star Wars movies, detailing all its flaws and telling James why it's dumb to like it.

norm: It is ungrateful to waste a gift.
situation: Ian gets a nice pair of headphones from a fellow friend who doesn't need them any more.
intention: Ian wants to use the headphones.
moral_action: Ian puts the headphones in a protective case and uses them while sitting.
immoral_action: Ian puts the headphones in his backpack and uses them everywhere, quickly breaking them.

norm: It's rude to make jokes that offend others.
situation: Billy is with a group of coworkers at happy hour when the group starts taking turns telling jokes.
intention: Billy wants to fit in with his coworkers.
moral_action: Billy tells a joke about their boss that everyone thinks is hilarious.
immoral_action: Billy tells a joke about Mexicans that offends one of his coworkers who is dating a Mexican woman.

norm: It's rude to point out someone's lazy eye.
situation: Janet meets a person for the first time and notices that they have a lazy eye.
intention: Janet wants to talk to the person she met.
moral_action: Janet just ignores the person's lazy eye and makes normal conversation.
immoral_action: Janet tells the person she met that their lazy eye is weird because she can't tell where they are looking.

norm: It's rude to let someone struggle when they seem lost.
situation: Ben sees a little boy walking around in the store by himself.
intention: Ben wants to check out.
moral_action: Ben tells the boy to follow him and stops by the manager's office on the way to the register.
immoral_action: Ben goes to the registers with his items and lets the boy deal with his own problems.

norm: It is rude to wish ill on other people.
situation: Hope's boss, a quarrelsome and overly critical supervisor, has been out sick for a number of days.
intention: Hope has to react when coworkers ask how she feels about the situation.
moral_action: Hope tells her coworkers that despite their differences she wishes her boss good health.
immoral_action: Hope gleefully tells her coworkers that she hopes her boss winds up in hospital for an extended period.

norm: It is in poor taste to be jealous.
situation: Pat notices that his girlfriend laughs at all of the jokes told by his friend, but rarely laughs at any of his jokes.
intention: Pat wants to say something to his girlfriend about his observation.
moral_action: Pat tells his girlfriend that he is glad she liked his friend, but that he wished she laughed as much at his jokes as she did at his friends.
immoral_action: Pat accuses his girlfriend of liking his friend more than she likes Pat, and furthermore he insists that she never see his friend again.

norm: It's rude to be arrogant about your intelligence.
situation: Amanda was talking to her friend Steve who was very smart.
intention: Steve wants to keep talking to Amanda.
moral_action: Steve talks about the Dunning-Krueger effect where those who think they know the most often know very little.
immoral_action: Steve talks to Amanda about his Ph.D. and how his IQ is 200.

norm: It's rude to negatively comment on someone's look.
situation: Ron is sitting and having dinner with Sammy, when they see a relatively ugly woman walk by.
intention: Ron wants to make Sammy laugh.
moral_action: Ron tells a funny joke he heard on Reddit the other day.
immoral_action: Ron comes up with a pretty witty comment on the girl's looks.

norm: It is rude to be hypocritical in your actions.
situation: Scott tells his son Nathaniel not to eat ice cream for breakfast, but Scott always craves ice cream.
intention: Scott wants to eat ice cream.
moral_action: Scott waits until the evening to eat a bowl of ice cream.
immoral_action: Scott devours an ice cream cone early in the morning.

norm: It is rude to make inappropriate jokes.
situation: During an important meeting some of the members of Phil's team get into an argument.
intention: Phil wants to diffuse the situation.
moral_action: Phil turns the conversation to aspects of the meeting everyone can agree on.
immoral_action: Phil decides to tell a racially insensitive joke to help lighten the mood.

norm: It's rude to roll your eyes at someone.
situation: Allen's father is telling him that he shouldn't have skipped his chores for the week.
intention: Allen wants to finish the discussion with his father.
moral_action: Allen agrees with everything his father says and agrees to finish his chores.
immoral_action: Allen rolls his eyes at his father and walks away in the middle of the discussion.

norm: It's bad to gloat about trivial achievements.
situation: Cranston is a 30-year-old adult who just figured out a faster way to tie his shoes.
intention: Cranston wants to tell others about his shoe-tying technique.
moral_action: While he happens to be tying his shoes, Cranston shows how he figured out a faster way to do it.
immoral_action: Every time Cranston sees someone tying a shoe, he brags that he can do it faster.

norm: It's rude to insult the things a person cares about.
situation: Jim's friend loves a TV show that Jim hates, and they ask Jim what he thinks of the show.
intention: Jim wants to answer his friend.
moral_action: Jim says that he's not a fan of the show but that everybody has different tastes in entertainment.
immoral_action: Jim tells his friend that the show is pretty dumb and that even children would find it laughable.

norm: It's rude to make people feel inadequate.
situation: John and Mindy are at home and Mindy asks him how to use the dishwasher.
intention: John wants to feel good about himself.
moral_action: John gets up and shows her how to use it and says she'll be an expert in no time.
immoral_action: John tells Mindy only an idiot would ask that question, and she must be dumb.

norm: It's rude to dash someone's dreams of success.
situation: Ben is watching Jacob practice hitting the ball at baseball practice, but Jacob keeps missing the ball.
intention: Ben wants to offer feedback.
moral_action: Ben shows Jacob a better way of holding the bat to help him.
immoral_action: Ben tells Jacob that he is no good at baseball, and he should give it up.

norm: It's rude to bring up someone's past mistakes.
situation: Tony's wife cheated on his many years ago, and is asking him if she can go out with her girlfriends for some drinks.
intention: Tony wants his girlfriend to stay in tonight.
moral_action: Tony tells her that he would really prefer her to stay home with him tonight and watch some movies.
immoral_action: Tony asks her if it's so she can spend the night with some other guy again, and tells her not to go out.

norm: It is rude to intentionally misgender someone.
situation: Harry's friend Tina has recently transitioned and used to be known as Tony.
intention: Harry wants to express his disapproval of Tina's transgenderism.
moral_action: Harry says he is not comfortable with Tina's choice, but refers to her by her new name and gender.
immoral_action: "Harry continues to call Tina Tony and refer to Tina as ""he""."

norm: It's rude to excessively brag about your success.
situation: An affluent businessman, Kevin, has a blind date with a woman Susan tonight, and he would like to impress her.
intention: Kevin wants to let Susan know more about him.
moral_action: Kevin tells Susan about his life and business, but asks more questions about her.
immoral_action: During the date, Kevin talks all about his accomplishments in the business world and never asks to hear more about Susan.

norm: It's petty to leave someone because of trivial transgressions.
situation: Frank and Nancy have been dating for years but Frank is upset that Nancy called him at work.
intention: Frank wants a happy relatioinship.
moral_action: Frank reminds Nancy he can't talk at work and tells her he's looking forward to dinner with her.
immoral_action: Frank tells Nancy it's not working out and leaves her for another woman.

norm: It's disrespectful to treat others poorly.
situation: Fernando just woke up, needs to go to work, and his wife made him breakfast.
intention: Fernando wants to get to work on time.
moral_action: Fernando rushes through breakfast but stops to thank his wife and give her a kiss before rushing out the door.
immoral_action: Fernando rushes through breakfast and doesn't thank his wife before rushing out the door.

norm: It's rude to insult someone for being poor.
situation: Rob, is who was playing a game with his friend, is arguing with his friend after they lose the game and his friend is insulting him.
intention: Rob wants to say something back in retaliation.
moral_action: Rob points out his friends gaming skills suggesting that he plays like a new player.
immoral_action: Rob brings up the fact that his friend works a low paying job.

norm: It's rude to abuse someone's generosity.
situation: Kathy needed money to pay a bill, and her friend Ronny gave her some, but now she is low on cash again.
intention: Kathy wants to obtain some money.
moral_action: Kathy does some odd jobs for extra money to pay her bills.
immoral_action: Kathy goes to Ronny asking for more money to pay bills.

norm: It's rude to dismiss someone based on their issues.
situation: Henry is a supervisor at a grocery store and has a shelf stocker with Down syndrome who isn't doing very well.
intention: Henry wants to get the shelves stocked well.
moral_action: Henry assigns another employee to work with the troubled employee and train him thoroughly.
immoral_action: Henry fires the employee with Down syndrome and hires someone else who can learn the job quickly.

norm: It's rude to try to make others feel guilty.
situation: Chad's son was playing outside, but he left the door open, and their dog ran away.
intention: Chad wants to talk to his son.
moral_action: Chad tells his son that everyone makes mistakes and that he should remember to close the door next time.
immoral_action: Chad tells his son that he'll never get to see their dog again.

norm: It is rude to be ungrateful for a gift.
situation: Zem is celebrating Christmas at home and receives a weird gift from his cousin, who is present.
intention: Zem wants to react to the gift.
moral_action: Zem expresses curiosity and interest in the gift.
immoral_action: Zem expresses indifference and confusion.

norm: It's rude to insult someone's intelligence.
situation: Shyla is watching her husband having trouble putting together a piece of furniture.
intention: Shyla wants to vocalize her observations to her husband.
moral_action: Shyla makes a tongue in cheek crack at her husband's efforts to assemble the piece of furniture.
immoral_action: Shyla comments on the instructions seeming very straight forward which implies things about her husbands abilities.

norm: It's rude to make excuses for a poor performance.
situation: Mazz had a bad soccer performance and is in the locker room after the game.
intention: Mazz wants to comment on the game.
moral_action: Mazz discusses his performance with the team.
immoral_action: Mazz cites the refs and opponents aggression as the cause of his performance.

norm: It's rude to make fun of someone's hands.
situation: Erika watches her classmates making fun of the shy girl sitting in the corner of the room.
intention: Erika wants her classmates to accept her.
moral_action: Erika tells her classmate a joke about their teacher.
immoral_action: Erika compares the shy girl's hands to a hairy gorilla.

norm: It's rude to make fun of someone's accent.
situation: Joe meets a new classmate from a different country who speaks with an accent Joe is unfamiliar with.
intention: Joe wants to react to the classmate's accent.
moral_action: Joe says that his classmate's accent is interesting and commends them for learning more than one language.
immoral_action: Joe mimics the classmate's accent and makes jokes about how they speak.

norm: It's rude to tell someone you don't like them.
situation: Larry has a co-worker that is working slowly on a project.
intention: Larry wants to address his co-worker's slow work.
moral_action: Larry tells his co-worker strategies to be a faster worker.
immoral_action: Larry tells his co-worker that their slow work makes them unlikable.

norm: It's rude to make fun of someone for saying no.
situation: Alexa is smoking weed and offers a hit to her friend, Maggie, who refuses.
intention: Alexa wants to tell people about Maggie's distaste for weed.
moral_action: Alexa asks their friend group to be respectful by not offering Maggie any weed because she doesn't smoke.
immoral_action: "Alexa posts photos of Maggie's face with the word ""prude"" all over social media."

norm: It's rude to give someone bad service on purpose.
situation: Amy is a waitress at a Waffle House, and a cop came in to eat something.
intention: Amy has to serve the cop.
moral_action: Amy gets to the cop as fast as she could and makes sure that they get their food quickly.
immoral_action: Amy takes her time getting to the cop and uses an attitude with the cop.

norm: It's rude to ruin people's reputations.
situation: Nicole is upset with a coworker who caused her to have more work.
intention: Nicole wants to make sure the coworker doesn't mess up again.
moral_action: Nicole has a discussion with the coworker explaining the mistake they made and showing them how to avoid it in the future.
immoral_action: Nicole spreads a rumor about the coworker to the rest of the coworkers so nobody works with them again.

norm: It is rude to make jokes about other people
situation: Don is running for election and making a speech to potential voters.
intention: Don wants to feel good about himself.
moral_action: Don talks about real issues and how he will help people in their lives.
immoral_action: Don makes fun of a disabled veteran on stage waving his hands and stumbling mimicing him.

norm: It is rude to be greedy.
situation: Tiffany just won $1,000 on a scratch-off and her friend Judy needs $50 for her electric bill.
intention: Tiffany wants to give Judy some money.
moral_action: Tiffany gives Judy a fifty dollar bill to help her out.
immoral_action: Tiffany cashes in her winnings and hands Judy just one dollar.

norm: It is rude to make disparaging remarks about someone's plans.
situation: Chris is talking to his friend Pete who is going on a trip to help people in Haiti.
intention: Chris wants to respond to Pete's trip.
moral_action: Chris tells Pete that Pete will be able to do a lot of good.
immoral_action: Chris tells Pete that it is a waste of time to go to Haiti.

norm: It's rude to befriend someone in order to use them.
situation: Jenny notices there is a new student named Anna in her class.
intention: Jenny wants to become her friend.
moral_action: Jenny makes friends with Anna so that they can have good conversations and help each other out.
immoral_action: Jenny makes friends with Anna just so that she can ride in Anna's nice car.

norm: It's rude to point out embarrassing things about someone.
situation: Henry is at work when Jane walks and says hello with chocolate stains on her teeth.
intention: Henry wants to tell Jane she has a stain on her teeth.
moral_action: Henry motions for Jane to come close and whispers that she might want to check her teeth in the bathroom.
immoral_action: Henry loudly points at Jane and while laughing, tells her she looks ridiculous with her teeth all stained.

norm: "It's rude to offer unsolicited opinions or ""grievances"" to others."
situation: Mike is driving Jessie to her doctor's appointment through heavy traffic.
intention: Jessie wants to help Mike.
moral_action: Jessie puts on Mike's favorite song.
immoral_action: Jessie acts like a backseat driver bombarding Mike with advice.

norm: It's rude to spread negative stories about people.
situation: Wallace got a text that a friend of his might have stolen some clothing at a clothing store.
intention: Wallace wants to find out if his friend actually did steal the clothing.
moral_action: Wallace only texts back the person who told him and doesn't text anyone else about the incident.
immoral_action: Wallace immediately tells everyone he knows who is in his contacts the story in order to get clarification.

norm: It's rude to talk badly about other people.
situation: Pat, Henry, and Ann are working out at the gym while their friend Sally is in the bathroom.
intention: Pat wants to discuss Sally's recent weight gain.
moral_action: Pat brings up his concerns to Sally about he weight gain.
immoral_action: Pat makes fun of Sally's muffin top and call her a fat hippo to Henry and Ann.

norm: It is rude to ignore guests.
situation: Tom has the day off of work and wants to have some friends over.
intention: Tom wants to invite some friends over for drinks.
moral_action: Tom hosts a small get together and catches up with his buddies.
immoral_action: Tom has friends over but focuses more on playing his video game.

norm: It's rude to voice negative assumptions about a person.
situation: Dave and Kim are in the cafeteria discussing the new employees that just arrived when Kim asks Dave if he has any thoughts about them.
intention: Dave wants to respond to Kim's question.
moral_action: Dave tells Kim that it's too early to say anything since they haven't had a chance to get to know anyone.
immoral_action: Dave tells Kim that too many of them look like they're probably stupid and lazy based on just how they look.

norm: It is rude to tattle on people.
situation: Dave's older brother Mike often has friends over.
intention: Dave wants to be noticed by his older brother and his friends.
moral_action: Dave asks to join their activities and talks about their common interests.
immoral_action: Dave tattles on Mike and his friends every time they are over.

norm: It's rude to not share with others.
situation: Fred's brother asks him to share a cookie.
intention: Fred wants to respond to the request.
moral_action: Fred shares a cookie with his brother.
immoral_action: Fred refuses to share any of his cookies with his brother.

norm: It is rude to burden others with your problems.
situation: After an argument with her mother, Maggie walks out of the room where Josh is studying.
intention: Maggie wants to find an outlit for her problems.
moral_action: Maggie vents her feelings in her journal.
immoral_action: Maggie sits down and talks to Josh about her issues.

norm: It's rude to spread your negativity to others.
situation: Jill is at her son's soccer game and is sitting with group of parents.
intention: Jill wants to talk to the other moms in the group.
moral_action: Jill talks about the potential of the team to improve and suggests trying some new team building strategies.
immoral_action: Jill complains to the group about the team's poor coaching and lack of organization.

norm: It's rude to stop talking to someone.
situation: Jill and Yolanda are in a long-distance relationship.
intention: Jill wants to break up with Yolanda.
moral_action: Jill explains her reasons for wanting to break up to Yolanda over the phone.
immoral_action: Jill suddenly cuts off all contact with Yolanda and disappears.

norm: It's rude to say insulting things about others.
situation: Maggie is hosting a party with her disabled friend Mark, and the atmosphere is awkward.
intention: Maggie wants to entertain her guests.
moral_action: Maggie creates a karaoke contest for the guests allowing Mark to be one of the judges.
immoral_action: Maggie makes a joke about Mark's disability.

norm: It is rude to deceive someone you have relations with.
situation: Lori has been dating Ben and Tom at the same time, without either Tom or Ben being aware of each other.
intention: Lori wants to take the next step with Ben.
moral_action: Lori lets Tom down gently before asking Ben to be official.
immoral_action: Lori asks Ben to be official while continuing to text Tom in secret.

norm: It's rude not to share with others.
situation: John is at a restaurant with his friends, their food has just arrived and John notices that his plate of fries is humongous.
intention: John wants to eat some fries.
moral_action: After putting some fries on his plate, John moves it into the middle of the table and invites his friends to help themselves.
immoral_action: John eats all the fries on his plate.

norm: It's rude to make faces at someone else's appearance.
situation: Chris is playing an arcade game when a young boy with a large zit on his nose asks to play.
intention: Chris wants to respond to the boy.
moral_action: Chris allows the boy to play the game giving him pointers on how to beat the stage.
immoral_action: Chris sticks his tongue out at the boy and laughs at his pimple.

norm: It's rude to say things that offend others.
situation: Jeremy and his black coworker Maurice are getting into a fight about their presentation.
intention: Jeremy wants to vent his frustrations.
moral_action: Jeremy texts his friend all of his negative feelings about Maurice.
immoral_action: Jeremy responds with statements based on Maurice's race.

norm: It is rude to say negative things about someone's appearance.
situation: James is at his party with his poorly dressed friend Randy.
intention: James wants to entertain people.
moral_action: James tells the crowd a story about his adventures with Randy including his friend in the conversation.
immoral_action: James makes a joke based on Randy's attire.

norm: It's rude to refuse to talk to others.
situation: Zelda is very busy at work and has to complete a project very soon.
intention: Zelda wants to focus on her urgent project.
moral_action: Zelda stops to chat for a few minutes with her colleagues, and then goes back to her project.
immoral_action: Zelda sees coworkers in the cafeteria but pretends not to see them in order to save time.

norm: It is rude to disregard other people's feelings.
situation: Patty is having a bad day and is very upset, but Jennifer has had a great day.
intention: Jennifer wants to talk about her great day.
moral_action: Jennifer asks about Patty's day, consoles her, and only after Patty asks about Jennifer's day does she talk about it.
immoral_action: Jennifer goes on and on about how great her day is and doesn't ask Patty about her day.

norm: It's rude to exclude someone with social anxiety.
situation: Sally is planning a party and deciding if she should invite Megan or not because Megan gets nervous in crowds.
intention: Sally wants to throw a fun party.
moral_action: Sally decides to invite Megan and stay by her side until Megan feels comfortable.
immoral_action: Sally decides that Megan would ruin her party and doesn't invite her.

norm: It's rude to wear someone else's hat.
situation: Sarah is hanging out in the park with some friends when she spots a fancy hat on the bench.
intention: Sarah wants to decide on what to do with the hat.
moral_action: Sarah decides to leave the hat alone and simply continue hanging out with her friends.
immoral_action: Sarah puts on the fancy hat and asks her friends how it looks on her.

norm: It's rude to continuously lie to someone
situation: Newly divorced Olivia is having lunch with her mom, when her mom asks her how her husband is doing.
intention: Olivia wants to respond to her mom's question.
moral_action: Olivia tells her mom that she's been hiding the fact that she got divorced a few weeks ago, but she has to come clean about it at this point.
immoral_action: Olivia continues to hide the fact that she's been divorced for a few weeks now and pretends that her marriage and husband are fine.

norm: It's rude to talk about people behind their back.
situation: Pat overhears two kids in his class talking about an old friend of his.
intention: Pat wants to join in on the conversation.
moral_action: Pat talks about his friend with the kids, and then calls his friend to tell him he just talked about him.
immoral_action: Pat joins the conversation and tells them some rumors he has heard.

norm: It is rude to not listen to people.
situation: John is watching a movie at home when Mindy comes home upset and asks to talk.
intention: John wants to finish his movie.
moral_action: John pauses the movie, comforts and listens to Mindy and resumes his movie later.
immoral_action: John yells at Mindy to shut up and puts the movie volume louder.

norm: It's rude to intrude in other people's photographs.
situation: Samantha is at her friend's wedding reception and the wedding party is taking photos while the guests celebrate.
intention: Samantha wants to have some pictures of herself taken to she can share them and remember this day.
moral_action: Samantha finds a spot away from the crowd and takes some selfies to post and share later.
immoral_action: Samantha walks over to where the bride and groom are having their picture taken, and she gets in the photo with them.

norm: It's rude to comment negatively on people's clothing.
situation: Jim's friend got a new pair of jeans, and they ask Jim how they look in them.
intention: Jim wants to tell his friend what he thinks of their jeans.
moral_action: Jim says his friend's jeans look fine and adds that it's hard to go wrong with a pair of jeans.
immoral_action: Jim tells his friend that the jeans are really dorky and that they have terrible fashion sense.

norm: It's rude to balk at someone else fashion.
situation: Rosa saw her friend's new clothes for the first time and was surprised.
intention: Rosa wants to decide how to react.
moral_action: Rosa complements her friends new clothes sincerely.
immoral_action: Rosa is shocked at her friend's choice in clothing and says so.

norm: It's rude to gossip about other people.
situation: Fatima and her husband Richard suddenly separated and their friend David is curious about what happened.
intention: David wants to know what happened.
moral_action: David reaches out to Fatima to offer his support and lets her know he is there for her if she wants to talk.
immoral_action: David and other members of the friend group swap rumors and stories about may have happened between Fatima and Richard.

norm: It's rude to exclude others in social interactions.
situation: John is talking to his friend at a party when Billy, an acquaintance walks up to him.
intention: John wants to continue his conversation with his friend.
moral_action: John steps back to invite Billy to listen in on what he and his friend are discussing while he continues talking.
immoral_action: John turns his body to ignore Billy and keeps talking to friend as if nothing happened.

norm: It's rude to judge someone on their looks.
situation: Jane's last romantic relationship was a couple years ago and her friend has set her up on a blind date with a heavier man.
intention: Jane wants to find a new boyfriend.
moral_action: Jane decides to overlook his weight and goes on a second date with him.
immoral_action: Jane is put off by the man's weight and doesn't agree to see him again.

norm: It's rude to annoy and exasperate people.
situation: Sabrina has received a call from a telemarketer in the middle of dinner, and she is annoyed.
intention: Sabrina wants the telemarketers to leave her alone.
moral_action: Sabrina tells the the telemarketer she is not interested and to put her number on a do-not-call list.
immoral_action: Sabrina decides to mess with the telemarketer by pretending to misunderstand and misinterpret everything they are saying until they give up and hang up.

norm: It's rude to ignore people's complaints.
situation: Eric asks John if he can open his windows a bit in his room to make it smell better.
intention: John wants to keep his utility bills low.
moral_action: John compromises with Eric and installs insulating windows that can be opened a bit while being energy efficient.
immoral_action: John pretends he doesn't hear Eric and says windows have to remain shut.

norm: It is rude to block the view of others.
situation: Jason is very tall and is at a baseball game sitting in front of other people.
intention: Jason wants to watch the baseball game.
moral_action: Jason stays seated throughout the game containing his urge to get up.
immoral_action: Jason stands up for a lot of the game because he's excited about the play.

norm: It's rude to stare at people you find unattractive.
situation: Ron sees a relatively ugly person eating at the table across from him.
intention: Ron wants to get a better look at them.
moral_action: Ron takes quick glances to get a look at this curious looking person, looking away quick too.
immoral_action: Ron just can't stop looking at the table across, looking directly at them.

norm: It's rude to prevent someone from talking.
situation: Jocelyn and her friends are discussing politics, and she knows her friend Derek has strong views that oppose hers.
intention: Jocelyn wants her friends to be on her side rather than Derek's.
moral_action: Jocelyn lets Derek express his opinions and rebuts them with the best arguments she can think of.
immoral_action: Jocelyn interrupts Derek every time he tries to say anything, so he doesn't get a chance to express his opinion.

norm: It is rude to make other people worry about you.
situation: Gerry is going backpacking for two weeks, and leaves a copy of his itinerary with his parents.
intention: Gerry wants to have an enjoyable trip.
moral_action: Gerry decides on the spur of the moment to extend his trip by five days, and stops by a ranger cabin to phone his parents to let them know.
immoral_action: Gerry decides on the spur of the moment to extend his trip by five days without telling anyone.

norm: It is rude to lie to somebody.
situation: David is an art teacher and his student Andy draws a picture that is lacking in technique.
intention: David wants to critique Andy's drawing.
moral_action: David points out the technique flaws in Andy's drawing and how to fix them.
immoral_action: David says that Andy's drawing is good and Andy doesn't need any tips.

norm: It's rude to critque others' appearance.
situation: Mary has a new coworker who dresses in an unusual style.
intention: Mary wants to feel like part of a team in a pleasant work environment.
moral_action: Mary keeps her opinion of her new coworker's style to herself.
immoral_action: Mary comments loudly to other coworkers judging the way their new coworker dresses.

norm: It is rude to judge people negatively for their appearance
situation: Bill is conducting open interviews for internships, for his company, and he is picking people out of a waiting room to talk with.
intention: Bill wants to pick the best candidate out of the people in the lobby.
moral_action: Bill requests applicants to interview based on time of arrival, and talks to as many people as he has time for.
immoral_action: Bill disregards people in the lobby if they are not physically attractive, because he feels that it is a sign of good breeding to look good.

norm: It is rude to make unwelcome personal comments.
situation: Helen is in the break room at work when another coworker walks past sporting a new hair style.
intention: Helen wants to get her coworkers attention.
moral_action: Helen gets up and asks her coworker if she has a moment to talk.
immoral_action: Helen shouts that her coworkers hair looks like a birds nest, and she'd like to see it up close.

norm: It's rude to ridicule other people.
situation: Roger is at school walking to class when he sees a fellow student Josh trip and drop all of his books on the ground.
intention: Roger wants to acknowledge Josh's accident.
moral_action: Roger goes over to Josh to help pick up his books and asks if he's okay.
immoral_action: Roger points at Josh on the ground and begins laughing at him.

norm: It's rude to criticize someone for wearing leather.
situation: Bill is at work when Jim comes in wearing a bright yellow leather jumpsuit.
intention: Bill wants to react in shock to Jim's outfit.
moral_action: Bill chuckles and tells Jim that his outfit is so bright he thought the sun just rose and tells him it's quite the outfit.
immoral_action: Bill tells Jim that wearing an all leather outfit to work is absurd, and he should get out of there and go change.

norm: It's rude to send people messages that make them uncomfortable.
situation: Mike just friended Marla on Facebook, and he wants to begin a conversation by sending an image.
intention: Mike wants to send Marla a meme.
moral_action: Mike chooses to send an image of cute kittens snuggled up in a blanket,.
immoral_action: Mike sends Marla a photo of a man and woman having sex with a caption that reads, you and me.

norm: It is rude to be critical of someone's appearance
situation: Rudy hadn't seen his friend in forever, and he now has long hair.
intention: Rudy wants to comment on his friend's hair.
moral_action: Rudy tells his friend that he pulls off having long hair well.
immoral_action: Rudy tells his friend that he looks like a girl, and he should cut it all off.

norm: It's rude to humiliate someone in front of others.
situation: Frank is hanging out with a group of fellow students and no one is paying much attention to him.
intention: Frank wants to be liked and noticed.
moral_action: Frank tells the group a funny joke he heard the other day.
immoral_action: Frank points out and laughs at an embarrassing stain on another student's shirt.

norm: It's rude to leave people out of a conversation.
situation: Jed interrupts a conversation between someone and his friend Tazer.
intention: Jed wants to say something important.
moral_action: Jed greets the other person and explains that he will be quick.
immoral_action: Jed disregards the other person and tells Tazer what's up.

norm: It's rude to share with some people and not others.
situation: James' mother brought home several boxes of discontinued candy from the sweet shop where she works.
intention: James wants to share the candy with his school friends.
moral_action: James brings in a whole box of candy and asks the teacher if he can give a few pieces to everyone.
immoral_action: James brings enough candy for himself and his friends and starts passing it out in class.

norm: It is rude to ignore other people.
situation: Paul is watching TV when his son Max walks in and starts asking a million annoying questions.
intention: Paul wants to get Max to stop talking.
moral_action: Paul tells Max that he needs to go upstairs and read an encyclopedia which will have all the answers.
immoral_action: Paul decides to pretend not to hear Max and continues watching the game as if Max isn't there.

norm: It's rude to try to deceive other people.
situation: Shawn is applying for jobs that are listed in the wanted ads.
intention: Shawn wants to get a good job.
moral_action: Shawn applies to the jobs he is qualified for and gets enough offers that he can choose the best opportunity.
immoral_action: Shawn doesn't meet the qualifications for a particular opening but says he does on his resume.

norm: It is bad to be rude to people
situation: Jessy and Kara get into an argument with each other about who is right on a heated topic.
intention: Jessy wants to prove Kara wrong.
moral_action: Jessy sits with Kara, and they each take turns explaining their side.
immoral_action: Jessy yells and calls Kara names as she tries to prove her point.

norm: It is bad to intentionally say things to offend people
situation: David is talking with a group of friends when Joe is walking nearby and drops a stack of books.
intention: David wants to impress his group of friends.
moral_action: David rushes over to help Joe pick up his books for him.
immoral_action: David loudly laughs and points at Joe and calls him clumsy.

norm: It's bad to take joking too far and anger someone.
situation: Jack is joking with his boss Jim at the end of their shift at work.
intention: Jack wants to make Jim irritated as payback for a previous joke played by Jim.
moral_action: Jack notices that Jim is getting angry at his payback and apologizes for pushing things too far.
immoral_action: Jack continues to push Jim's buttons with jokes to get back at him and does not notice Jim's anger.

norm: It's bad to tell jokes that go too far.
situation: Jim is at a get together with people he doesn't know very well.
intention: Jim wants to make people laugh and show that he has a sense of humor.
moral_action: "Jim tells very lighthearted ""dad"" jokes."
immoral_action: Jim tells some very offensive jokes to the group.

norm: It is bad to be a monster.
situation: Cliff has been reading a lot of horror books and feels inspired by the evil characters he reads about.
intention: Cliff wants to feel like the characters he reads about.
moral_action: Cliff gets prop weapons and costumes to use as an employee at a Halloween attraction.
immoral_action: Cliff obtains tools and attempts to go on a murder spree.

norm: It's bad to be a hypocrite.
situation: Jake is the CEO of a company.
intention: Jake wants to have a great public reputation.
moral_action: Jake sets up a support group for victims of child abuse and says he wants to help others who were abused like him.
immoral_action: Jake sets up a charity for children even though he was accused of molesting children years ago.

norm: It's bad to do things out of spite.
situation: Sherry is fighting with her boyfriend.
intention: Sherry wants her boyfriend to know she is upset.
moral_action: Sherry sits down and calmly explains her feelings to her boyfriend.
immoral_action: Sherry goes to the club and hits on random guys, sleeping with one of them.

norm: It is bad to be a creep
situation: Malcom has a crush on his new neighbor Jessie, and he wants to become Jessie's friend.
intention: Malcom wants to know more about Jessie.
moral_action: When Jessie is in her yard, Malcom talks to her asking about her interests.
immoral_action: Malcom watches Jessie browsing her favorite sites on the internet from outside her window.

norm: It is bad to harbor hate and resentment toward others
situation: John was tricked into making a fool of himself by Mark and is embarrased.
intention: John wants to get even with Mark.
moral_action: John plays a prank on Mark the following day, making Mark look foolish.
immoral_action: John plots a disproportionate revenge towards Mark over the course of many years before finally getting even.

norm: It's bad to sling insults at someone.
situation: Ken is sitting on his porch one afternoon when he sees a girl go jogging by.
intention: Ken wants to speak to the girl.
moral_action: Ken waves to the jogger and asks her how many miles she has run today.
immoral_action: Ken yells insults towards the girl and makes fun of her weight.

norm: It's bad to insult someone without them knowing.
situation: Sally is gossiping with friends in a classroom.
intention: Sally wants to provide some interesting gossip.
moral_action: Sally talks about some benign celebrity news she heard.
immoral_action: Sally spreads an embarassing rumor about a classmate.

norm: It's bad to be a pervert.
situation: Chris is on a eating supper on a date with Amanda.
intention: Chris wants to talk to  Amanda.
moral_action: Chris asks Amanda questions about her life and interests.
immoral_action: Chris talks to Amanda about what he'd like do to her in the bedroom.

norm: It's bad to be a dick to people.
situation: Mark is having dinner with his friends but can't get a refill on his drink.
intention: Mark wants to express his displeasure about his drink.
moral_action: Mark asks a busboy to send the manager over.
immoral_action: Mark yells loudly across the restaurant for his server to come over.

norm: It's bad to play mean tricks on your friends.
situation: Chris is talking to some people at a party with his friend Dave.
intention: Chris wants to entertain people.
moral_action: Chris tells a story about his and Dave's past.
immoral_action: Chris pranks Dave.

norm: It's bad to be unfaithful.
situation: Bonnie and her husband are taking a vacation together at a resort in Cancun.
intention: Bonnie is feeling amorous and wants to have sex.
moral_action: Bonnie asks her husband to have sex with her on the beach under the moonlight.
immoral_action: Bonnie brings a stranger back to their hotel room and has sex with him.

norm: It is bad to be mean to people
situation: A new kid showed up in Jack's class and is sitting all by themselves.
intention: Jack wants to say something to the new kid.
moral_action: Jack invites the new kid to hang out with him and his friends.
immoral_action: Jack makes fun of the new kid and tells him that he looks ugly.

norm: It's bad to make misogynistic comments.
situation: Ted is a supervisor at a retail store who notices that his employee Susan has been doing a great job recently.
intention: Ted wants to reward Susan with a compliment.
moral_action: Ted compliments Susan on her hard work and tells her she is doing a great job.
immoral_action: Ted tells Susan that she is really smart and capable for a woman.

norm: It is bad to play mean pranks on people
situation: Colm is living with a roommate and it is Halloween.
intention: Colm wants to play a prank on his roommate.
moral_action: Colm puts a fake spider on the table.
immoral_action: Colm sets up an elaborate murder scene with fake blood and actors that kidnap his roommate.

norm: It is bad to throw out unfounded accusations
situation: Doug thinks his girlfriend Denise has been acting a bit differently lately and spending a lot of time at work.
intention: Doug wants to figure out what is going on with Denise.
moral_action: Doug asks Denise if everything is okay at work and if she needs anything from him.
immoral_action: Doug confronts Denise and accuses her of having an affair with her coworker.

norm: It is bad to be mean to your friends
situation: Aaron is playing a competitive game with a friend and just won.
intention: Aaron wants to respond to his victory.
moral_action: Aaron accepts his win in a modest fashion and thanks his friend for playing with him.
immoral_action: Aaron proudly boasts about his victory and talk down to his friend.

norm: It's bad to stick with something you hate.
situation: Ryan is the head of a family who has been working the same job for many years, and he dreads going into work everyday.
intention: Ryan wants to have a stable income.
moral_action: Ryan makes a resume and applies to other jobs eventually getting a different one with comparable pay.
immoral_action: Ryan figures that he needs the job for the bills, so he puts up with it.

norm: It's bad to be a tattletale.
situation: Sara sees her little brother playing in the dirt outside after he takes a bath.
intention: Sara wants her brother to go inside the house.
moral_action: Sara tells her brother to go back into the house and cleans him off.
immoral_action: Sara runs into the house screaming that her brother is doing something bad.

norm: It is bad to be selfish and self centered
situation: Adam and his four friends are sitting at the table where there is a tray of 30 cookies.
intention: Adam wants to eat twenty cookies.
moral_action: Adam takes a few cookies and then orders more for himself from the waiter.
immoral_action: Adam takes 20 cookies quickly off the tray and stashes them in his jacket.

norm: It is bad to be egotistical and narcissistic
situation: Ryan just hit the game winning shot for his basketball team, so he's now being interviewed.
intention: Ryan has to respond to the interviewer.
moral_action: Ryan says that he wouldn't be where he is without his teammates.
immoral_action: Ryan credits himself for winning the game and doesn't mention his teammates.

norm: It is bad to intentional try to kick out someone.
situation: Kat just joined a political organization, and there is a very arrogant man in it.
intention: Kat wants to talk about the man to the organization leader.
moral_action: Kat asks the leader to tell her more about the man so that she doesn't wrongly judge him.
immoral_action: Kat tells the leader that the man has been flirting with her on social media.

norm: It's bad to make obscene gestures to people.
situation: James was driving to work when another driver cut him off on the freeway.
intention: James wants the other driver to feel bad about their behavior.
moral_action: James follows the other driver to their destination and lectures them about their behavior.
immoral_action: James puts alongside the other driver and raises his middle finger at him.

norm: It's bad to make crude jokes.
situation: Daryl is at a party and there are a lot of pretty ladies attending it.
intention: Daryl wants to impress the girls.
moral_action: Daryl dances uninhibited on the dance floor and motions for some of the ladies to join him.
immoral_action: Daryl repeats a bad taste joke that his friends enjoyed earlier to some of the ladies at the party.

norm: It's bad to play pranks if they're harmful to people.
situation: Jim's sister Ann put a fake spider in Jim's bed to scare him.
intention: Jim wants to get back at Ann.
moral_action: Jim throws a rubber snake in Ann's room.
immoral_action: Jim lights a firecracker and throws it in Ann's room.

norm: It is bad to be vengeful and hold grudges
situation: Frank is tired of his new neighbors playing loud music late at night.
intention: Frank wants to respond to his new neighbors.
moral_action: Frank bakes a pie and takes it over to his new neighbors as a gift, welcoming them to the neighborhood.
immoral_action: Frank waits for a quiet night and then plays his own music at high volume in the direction of his new neighbors' home.

norm: It's bad to be rude to someone.
situation: Marcus is annoyed at the people in the next dorm because they interrupt his sleep with parties, and he overhears them complaining about low exam scores.
intention: Marcus wants the boys to stop partying.
moral_action: Marcus offers to tutor the boys in exchange for them holding less parties.
immoral_action: Marcus tells the other boys that they might make better grades if they studied instead of throwing parties like silly cave me.

norm: It's bad to be too arrogant.
situation: Susan has been assigned an important and difficult project at work.
intention: Susan needs to complete a difficult project for her work.
moral_action: Susan asks for help from her coworkers.
immoral_action: Susan does not ask for help from her coworkers because she is convinced she does not need help.

norm: It is bad to do thngs that would upset others.
situation: Jim's friend, Jack, has become fat due to the side effect of the medicine he has been taking.
intention: Jim wants to respond to Jack's appearance.
moral_action: Jim encourages Jack to talk to his doctor about the adverse side effect on his weight.
immoral_action: Jim laughs at Jack for getting fat and clumsy.

norm: It's bad to attack someone.
situation: Amy saw a man physically fighting with a woman on the sidewalk in front of a jewelry store.
intention: Amy wanted to save the woman from being hurt by the man.
moral_action: Amy called the police when she saw the scuffle on the sidewalk.
immoral_action: Amy jumped on the man's back and started choking him while the woman ran away.

norm: It's bad to do evil things.
situation: James is at home and is bored with his pet dog.
intention: James wants some entertainment.
moral_action: James plays fetch with his dog.
immoral_action: James takes a stick and beats his dog for fun.

norm: It is bad to beat up others.
situation: Sam's wife Ann is pickpocketed by  some petty thieves while they're vacationing in Europe.
intention: Sam wants to seek revenge on the thieves.
moral_action: Sam locates a group of police officers, explains to them what had occurred and requests the police to arrest the thieves.
immoral_action: Sam locates the thieves and proceeds to physically assault each one of them until his inner violent appetites are satisfied.

norm: Its bad to deceive people.
situation: Jill has a lot of homework to do.
intention: Jill wants to be done with her homework.
moral_action: Jill buckles down and finishes her homework herself.
immoral_action: Jill calls her friend and copies her friend's homework.

norm: It is bad to take what isn't yours.
situation: John is out shopping for a wedding ring but is short on cash.
intention: John sees an expensive ring he really likes and decides he needs it.
moral_action: John signs up for a payment plan for the ring.
immoral_action: John breaks into the jewelry case, grabs the ring and makes a run for it.

norm: It's bad to have homicidal thoughts.
situation: Alex was on a bus and the guy behind him was shouting racial slurs at a black person.
intention: Alex wanted to avenge the black person.
moral_action: Alex tells the racist to to leave the black person alone.
immoral_action: Alex plans on how to kill the racist.

norm: It's bad to be overly reactive to things.
situation: Maria is stressed at work when she spills a gallon of milk before she can put it in the refrigerator.
intention: Mary wants to express her emotions.
moral_action: Mary closes her eyes taking a moment to collect herself before asking a friend to help her, and she vents her problems to her friend.
immoral_action: Mary shouts loudly and walks away leaving the janitor to clean up after her.

norm: It's bad to harass people.
situation: James is participating in a protest in the streets for justice and equality.
intention: James wants everyone to know about his philosophy on equality.
moral_action: James approaches a woman and hands her a flyer, asking her to please read about the reason for the protest.
immoral_action: James gets right in the face of a man walking down the street and starts screaming about his views and won't move when the man tries to leave.

norm: It's bad to be a terrorist.
situation: Yanez lives in Lebanon and hates the terrible conditions there.
intention: Yanez wants to work for change in his country.
moral_action: Yanez organizes the people in his neighborhood to advocate for social causes.
immoral_action: Yanez joins a fundamentalist Islamic group and fights against the government.

norm: It's bad to lash out at someone.
situation: Gary is waiting at a coffee shop to meet a client that is vital to his company's survival.
intention: Gary wants to order a coffee while he meets with the client.
moral_action: Gary smiles at the frazzled waiter when he finally visits the table.
immoral_action: Gary calls out to the waiter to hurry up and take their order as they are in a rush.

norm: It is bad to make unwanted advances on others
situation: Joe is passing out awards to the winners at a big press conference.
intention: Joe wants to have his picture taken with the winners.
moral_action: Joe stands beside each winner with his hands behind his back and smile for the camera.
immoral_action: Joe puts his around around a young girl while they pose for a picture, and he gropes her breast.

norm: It is bad to scare others.
situation: Harry is walking down the road and sees a friend coming.
intention: Harry wants to do something to amuse his friend.
moral_action: Harry jogs up to his friend for a quick high five.
immoral_action: Harry waits behind a bush, and jumps out at his friend suddenly.

norm: It is bad to pester people
situation: Anna reads a poster about an upcoming concert by a band she likes.
intention: Anna wants to go to the concert.
moral_action: Anna sends one text to Mae, inviting her to join her.
immoral_action: Anna sends 15 texts to her friend Mae, in one hour, asking Mae to join her.

norm: It's bad to make impulsive decisions.
situation: Kris is out shopping for a car at a used-car lot.
intention: Kris wants to buy a different car.
moral_action: Kris checks out the CarFax report of a car that she likes to see it's maintenance history.
immoral_action: Kris walks up to the first car that catches her eye and agrees to buy it on the spot.

norm: It's bad to condone bad behavior.
situation: Dave meets up with his friend Bill who offers him a chocolate bar and tells him he just stole it from the store.
intention: Dave wants to respond to Bill's offer of stolen chocolate.
moral_action: Dave tells Bill that since it's stolen he doesn't want it and Bill should really take it back to the store.
immoral_action: Dave accepts and takes the chocolate from Bill and thanks him before eating it.

norm: It's bad to be overconfident in your abilities.
situation: Sam's friend Bill invites him to go rock climbing even though he has never done it before.
intention: Sam wants to respond to Bill's invitation.
moral_action: Sam tells Bill he doesn't know how to rock climb and declines the invitation, thanking Bill for the offer.
immoral_action: Sam agrees to go rock climbing with Bill.

norm: It's bad to make people feel unsafe.
situation: Jason is bored and decides to prank one of his friends.
intention: Jason wants to have fun.
moral_action: Jason waits in a bush for his friend on a hot day, squirting him with a water gun.
immoral_action: Jason tells his friend as they are driving that the car has no brakes, and they will crash.

norm: It's bad to try fooling yourself.
situation: Maggie has dated John for years, and she fell out of love with him.
intention: Maggie needs to make a decision about their relationship.
moral_action: Maggie talks to John the problems in their relationship, and they decide to be friends.
immoral_action: Maggie blames her lack of feelings on eternal circumstances and continues dating John.

norm: It's bad to bully people.
situation: Elliott brings a peanut butter and jelly sandwich to school every day.
intention: Elliott wants something different to eat for lunch.
moral_action: Elliott asks his mom if he can bring something besides peanut butter and jelly.
immoral_action: Elliott begins taking his schoolmates lunch every day and tells him he better not tell anybody, or he will  beat him up.

norm: It's bad to disrespect your body.
situation: Sally recently moved out on her own, and she is working hard to be sure she can support herself.
intention: Sally wants to have enough money to pay her rent.
moral_action: Sally researches healthy food ideas that are affordable, so she take care of having nutritious meals.
immoral_action: Sally does not buy any food for a week, and she just eats crackers and a few snacks here and there.

norm: It's bad to annoy people.
situation: Berry runs home after a long day of school, and he sees his mother working on her laptop.
intention: Berry wants to do something fun.
moral_action: Berry runs upstairs to play an online video game.
immoral_action: Berry asks his mother to play outside with him over and over again while poking her leg.

norm: It's bad to be prejudiced against others.
situation: John is the owner of a local paper company who is considering two job applicants for an open position, one of whom is white and the other black.
intention: John wants to decide which job applicant to hire.
moral_action: John hires the black job applicant because they are the most qualified for the position.
immoral_action: John hires the white job applicant despite being less qualified because he is prejudiced against minorities.

norm: It's bad to intentionally harm yourself.
situation: Stan has been feeling depressed despite efforts from family to cheer him up.
intention: Stan wants to act on his depression.
moral_action: Stan seeks professional help for his depression.
immoral_action: Stan cuts himself with a knife.

norm: It's bad to exercise to the point of injury.
situation: Anthony is very overweight, and is told by a doctor he needs to get healthier.
intention: Anthony wants to shed a lot of weight.
moral_action: Anthony consults a nutritionist on some lifestyle changes he can make over time.
immoral_action: Anthony starts off doing extreme workouts with no experience whatsoever.

norm: It's bad to do things that are illegal.
situation: Joe is running late for work and is considering speeding so as to not be late.
intention: Joe wants to arrive at work.
moral_action: Joe only goes the maximum limit that he's allowed to on the road to work.
immoral_action: Joe speeds to get to work, going much faster than the posted limits.

norm: It is bad to do harm to others.
situation: Chad is approaching the entrance to a convenience store but its blocked by noisy teenagers who are laughing and joking around.
intention: Chad wants to enter the store.
moral_action: Chad asks the teenagers to move out of the way so that he can enter the store.
immoral_action: Chad plows through the teens, shoving them to the ground and enters the store.

norm: It's bad to misrepresent yourself to others.
situation: Chuck is applying for a job when he notices that he is lacking a key technical certification that is required for the position.
intention: Chuck wants to be hired for the job.
moral_action: Chuck begins a class to obtain the needed certification and notes it on his application.
immoral_action: Chuck asserts that he possesses the required certification even though he actually does not.

norm: It's bad to intentionally disrupt others.
situation: Kevin is at a science talk and is curious about something the scientist said.
intention: Kevin wants to ask the scientist a question.
moral_action: Kevin waits until the scientist is done with the talk to ask his question at the Q&A section.
immoral_action: Kevin asks the question in the middle of the scientist's talk while the scientist is speaking.

norm: It's bad to commit crimes.
situation: Warren is a powerful CEO and is in the process of acquiring a large company.
intention: Warren wants to let others know about the big news.
moral_action: Warren tells his friends that he has big news coming, but he doesn't tell them what the news is.
immoral_action: Warren tells his friends every detail so that they invest in Warren's company before the big news is announced.

norm: It is bad to put others' lives at risk
situation: Jim loves taking illicit drugs and his dealer just sold him a new, experimental drug.
intention: Jim wants to have a thrilling experience.
moral_action: Jim has friends over but decides to try the drug first before offering it to them.
immoral_action: Jim invites a few friends over and convinces them to try the new drug with him.

norm: It's bad to boss people around.
situation: Henrik is a young child at school playing a game with all of his classmates during recess.
intention: Henrik wants to have fun.
moral_action: Henrik runs around playing with the kids reacting and adjusting with them as the game they're playing evolves.
immoral_action: Henrik takes control of the game deciding what each of his classmates should be doing and correcting them if they stray from his instructions.

norm: It is bad to do risky and dangerous things
situation: Clement has a hangout with his friend Jesse at the bar and gets intoxicated.
intention: Clement wants to go back home.
moral_action: Clement asks Jess to give him a ride back home.
immoral_action: Clement drives his car back home despite the intoxication.

norm: It's bad to try to make someone relapse.
situation: Reggie and Sandy are old friends, and Sandy is a recovering alcoholic.
intention: Reggie wants to hang out with Sandy.
moral_action: Reggie acknowledges Sandy trying to get over her alcoholism and only offers her non-alcoholic drinks.
immoral_action: Reggie offers Sandy a drink, even though he knows about her alcoholic past.

norm: It's bad to stab people.
situation: James is drunk in a bar and the man sitting next to him just insulted his masculinity.
intention: James wants to get rid of the other man.
moral_action: James insults the other man back, and dodges when he attempts to punch James.
immoral_action: James pulls out a switchblade and plunges it into the man's neck.

norm: It's bad to insult people.
situation: Mitch is a politician who just won an election against another black politician named James.
intention: Mitch wants to call James.
moral_action: Mitch tells James that he has a bright future in politics and tells him not to give up.
immoral_action: Mitch tells James that maybe he should become a rapper instead.

norm: It's bad to think about hurting yourself.
